title: Corrections
description: The On Sunday column yesterday misspelled the surname of the winner of the 1992 Nobel Prize in Literature and misidentified his homeland. He is Derek Walcott, not Wolcott; he is from St. Lucia, not Trinidad.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Father and Son Go Arm in Arm
description: Anyone who saw the young man's father play, even once, will never forget it. Archie Manning had that kind of effect. He had courage, panache, dash and he was the best quarterback in college football. He would walk up behind the center with that peculiar, half-bowlegged gait, take the snap, drop back, look like he was about to be engulfed by the pass rush, sprint outside, throw hissing spirals on the dead run.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Condo Tenants Urged to Move
description: The new year is beginning with uncertainty for residents of a condominium complex that was once a factory that made mercury vapor lamps.

title: MEDIA: TELEVISION;With a fenetic debut, CNN's Business network plays catch-up. And there's more to come.
description: MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI was on hand to announce: "Live, from New York, it's CNNFN!" So was Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who waited patiently to make an appearance. CNN's new financial news network even recruited a psychic, the Amazing Kreskin, to predict the direction of the stock market in 1996 (down, sharply).

title: ON HOCKEY;New Year's Memory at the Forum
description: A great Canadian hockey reporter is miffed with me, justifiably. I still have his treasured videotape of singular hockey history, the game between the Montreal Canadiens and Central Red Army of the Soviet Union at the Forum on Dec. 31, 1975, 20 years ago yesterday.

title: Happy New Year
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Brown and Boring No More
description: For the New Jersey State Aquarium, the numbers for 1995 all pointed in the right direction.

title: Deal for Berlusconi Stake
description: Five banks led by the investment bank Istituto Mobiliare Italiano paid $233 million to acquire 5.49 percent of Mediaset S.p.A., the television company controlled by former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, I.M.I. said today. The sale is part of a plan to reduce Mr. Berlusconi's stake in Mediaset, which owns three national television networks, to less than 50 percent.

title: Mistakes That Doomed a Jet Are Crash's Biggest Mystery
description: The crash of an American Airlines jet near Cali, Colombia, on Dec. 20 has confounded pilots and aviation experts like few other accidents in recent years.

title: A Palestinian Editor, Out of Jail, Says Arafat Browbeats the Press
description: A Palestinian newspaper editor who was detained for six days for not publishing an article about Yasir Arafat on the front page accused the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization today of routinely violating press freedoms.

title: The Neediest Cases;Survivor of the Holocaust Relents and Asks for Help
description: As a young man, one of six children in a poor family in rural Poland, he left home with a hatful of rebellion and dreams of returning to help lift his relatives from their poverty. He went to the industrial town of Lodz, which fell on the first day of the Nazi invasion of Poland in September 1939.

title: Nassau Police Say Officer Kills Man Pointing Gun
description: A Nassau County police officer shot and killed a man early Saturday in Elmont, L.I., and while the police said the man was armed, a minister who said he witnessed the incident said the officer shot the man while he was lying defenseless on the ground.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;A Little-Known Big Man Propels the Colts
description: He is Marshall Faulk after a heavy dinner.

title: BASKETBALL: Notebook;Cavs Dig Their Way Out of the Dumps
description: Any team -- in any sport -- that starts the season 0-7 is often doomed for a horrible year.

title: Essay;Ours Not to Reason Wye
description: For two days last week, at the secluded Wye plantation in Maryland, Israeli negotiators told representatives of Syria's dictator, Hafez al-Assad, of the economic wonders that peace would bring to the Middle East. The Syrians listened, offering nothing.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: ROSE BOWL;Northwestern Not Content Merely to Smell Roses
description: They started the season at Notre Dame and ended the season at Jay Leno's. The Northwestern Wildcats are the Rose Bowl's latest pot luck dinner, and they hardly have game officials rushing to join the bowl alliance. The Wildcats are a fair-haired coach, a Heisman Trophy candidate, a five-headed secondary and a draw in Hollywood.

title: Heiner Muller, German Playwright, 66
description: Heiner Muller, one of East Germany's most prominent and debated playwrights, died today at a Berlin hospital, a spokesman for his theater company said. He was 66.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;The Diet Coke empire strikes back, under the guise of 'Friends.'
description: SEEKING to win back younger consumers who have switched from Diet Coke to other beverages, the Coca-Cola Company will spend an estimated $30 million on an elaborate campaign centered on the hit sitcom "Friends."

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Shula Reflects on Finishing His Contract as Cox Vents
description: Don Shula is resolute in wanting to coach the Miami Dolphins one more season. And the team's owner, H. Wayne Huizenga, has indicated publicly that it's O.K. with him, despite wide fan criticism, including a three-newspaper poll in which nearly 80 percent of South Floridians voting indicated they want Shula out.

title: Federal Signal Settles Lawsuit
description: The Federal Signal Corporation said last week that it had agreed to pay $6.7 million to settle a lawsuit by Duravision Inc. and the Manufacturers Product Research Group of North America.

title: G.I. Hurt in Bosnia Is Said to Be in Good Condition
description: An American soldier wounded when his vehicle hit a land mine on Saturday was in good spirits today after he received the Purple Heart medal and word that he would be flown back soon to his base in Germany, military officials said.

title: Markets Closed
description: Financial markets, banks and government offices are closed today in observance of New Year's Day.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;For One Game, Holtz's Poor-Mouth Routine Rings True
description: Notre Dame's defensive coordinator, Bob Davie, used words like unbelievable, phenomenal and amazing to describe Florida State, the Irish's opponent in the Orange Bowl Monday night.

title: Forbes's Silver Bullet for the Nation's Malaise
description: In the back room of the restaurant 1892, a few dozen Iowa Republicans have gathered over identical entrees to listen to Steve Forbes. The invitation to the noontime event had suggested a $10 donation, presumably to cover the cost of the broiled chicken sandwich served with potato chips and iced tea. But the campaign staff has not pressed for a contribution, and almost no one in the audience, it seems, has paid.

title: Study Finds Estrogen Hormone Helps Postmenopausal Women
description: A new study provides strong evidence that taking estrogen hormone pills significantly reduces the rate of death from all causes for postmenopausal women and offers even greater protection against heart attacks and strokes.

title: The Progress of Peace
description: Granted, the structure of peace is rickety and various cease-fires could burst apart at any moment. It must be agreed as well that wars could explode overnight in countries ostensibly at peace. Nevertheless, something wonderful happened in 1995: the year ended with fewer guns being fired and fewer people being killed as conflicts long deemed intractable yielded to diplomacy. From the Caribbean to the Balkans, from southern Africa and the Middle East to the Irish Sea, the dream of Peace on Earth has circled the globe.

title: Sony to Stir Computers Into Its Traditional Product Mix
description: In the late 1980's Japan's mighty Sony Corporation spent billions of dollars acquiring American music and film companies, searching for a magic synergy with its core consumer electronics business. That strategy has seemed questionable lately -- especially in light of the recent ouster of Michael P. Schulhof, the chief executive of the Sony Corporation of America, who had been unable to recover from the film business's billion-dollar losses.

title: Underwater Challenge Tests Students' Mettle
description: At the Naval Surface Warfare Center here, a team of Canadian engineering students was putting the final touches on its computer-guided, torpedo-shaped submarine for the fourth International Submarine Race, an amateur competition for human-powered subs.

description: Their pay is modest, their labors are unheralded, and even their bosses admit that the job is grueling. Each second of their work is electronically monitored; the corporate Big Brother is always watching. So are these people seething with working-class resentment? Hardly. "This is the entry-level job of the 90's," explained Colleen Dolan, a 43-year-old former kindergarten teacher, who joined Broderbund Software Inc. last year. "This is where the jobs are."

title: A Bosnian's Generosity Transcends the Conflict
description: Hope in war, as in life, is rarely kindled by the grand gestures and pronouncements of politicians, but thrives instead on the small and anonymous act of human kindness. And during the fighting in this bleak, bombed-out shell of a city, where bands of children live little better than street urchins and hundreds of war dead lie in hastily dug graves, hope arrived with Fadil Fejzic's cow.

description: A few connections never hurt, and at Michael Ray and the Cosmic Krewe's show at the Knitting Factory on Friday night, Mr. Ray's connections helped pack the club.

description: The death in New York City of 6-year-old Elisa Izquierdo, allegedly at the hands of her mother, has focused national attention on an issue that, too often, is pushed to the sidelines. Congress, in particular, should be mindful of Elisa's fate as it moves to weaken programs that are designed to protect the nation's most vulnerable children -- victims of abuse and neglect.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Want to Resolve Anderson Contract, Team Focus
description: A meeting that could determine the Nets' immediate future will take place tomorrow when General Manager Willis Reed and the team president, Michael Rowe, meet with Kenny Anderson's lawyer, David Falk, to discuss whether the point guard would reconsider and accept a six-year, $40 million offer to remain with the club.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Packers Stay Together on Field and in the Stands
description: J. J. Birden had just run loose and free, covering 27 yards on a scoring catch and bringing the Atlanta Falcons within 10 points of the Green Bay Packers. Fourteen minutes remained. It looked like a game now. Maybe the Falcons were ready to spread their wings and pull one over on the Packers before 60,453 fans at Lambeau Field.

description: Today is New Year's Day.

title: Searching for Victims in Blaze, Firefighter Takes a Fatal Step
description: Squatters had fled the burning tenement in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday morning, but Lieut. John M. Clancy could not tell if others had been left behind. So, looking for lives to save, he took a single, fatal step into the building.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Shutdown Persists Into '96 As Budget Struggle Goes On A last-ditch effort to bring 260,000 furloughed Federal employees temporarily back to work just after the New Year failed yesterday. Republicans and Democrats in the Senate could not agree on the temporary plan passed by the House that would have allowed workers to return without pay until a Federal budget agreement was reached.

description: No team in the National Hockey League has more points than the Rangers. But at the end of a grueling month and a brutal road trip, they looked tired, beaten down and eager to return home tonight in Calgary, where they lost by 3-1 to the Flames at the Saddledome.

description: A fast-food company is circulating a questionnaire among agencies in preparation for a review of its account, according to several advertising executives, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

description: A career diplomat known as a skillful negotiator has been appointed Prime Minister of Algeria, said a statement issued today from President Liamine Zeroual, who has been trying to resolve a four-year civil war with Islamic groups.

title: POP REVIEW;Communal Jams With a Legacy
description: When the Grateful Dead disbanded in 1995, one of the band's legacies was a different kind of arena rock. It's not about brute force or exaggerated melodrama or spectacle; it's arena rock that twinkles and glides in long, open-ended jams while fans dance barefoot in the aisles.

description: Wendel Clark and Marty McInnis scored goals 18 seconds apart in the third period to lift the New York Islanders to a 5-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: Sports of The Times;When Packers Win, A Shared Celebration
description: IF football players who strut or dance in the end zone annoy you, then you'll want to hug the Green Bay Packers.

description: Pope John Paul II, apparently fully recovered from a bout of flu that spoiled his Christmas program, cautioned Christians today against excessive year-end celebrations, saying such behavior belonged to pagans.

title: World News Briefs;4 Western Hostages Sighted in Kashmir
description: An American and three other Westerners held hostage for six months were seen in a village in northern India this week, and witnesses said they were wearing warm clothes and looked healthy, Indian officials said.

title: Bridge
description: Some experts have a favorite partner, with whom they record a string of successes. It is very rare to have such a history with a favorite teammate. For Bob Blanchard, his favorite teammate is certainly Howard Chandross, and vice versa. They have never played as partners, but have played on the same team 14 times and have won every time, an extraordinary string.

title: BASEBALL;Pays to Be a Yank: Rogers May Get $10 Million in 2000
description: If Kenny Rogers pitches enough innings to guarantee the fifth year in his new contract with the Yankees, the club will pay him a whopping $10 million in 2000.

description: Anyone who has taken the time to follow the budget impasse between Democrats and Republicans in the nation's capital may secretly believe that he or she could resolve matters in minutes, if only given the chance.

title: Up at Last, Bridge to Bosnia Is Swaying Gateway for G.I.'s
description: The first American tanks rolled into Bosnia early this afternoon on a floating ribbon of a bridge across the swift-moving Sava River, marking the end of a problem-plagued engineering project and the real start to the American role in the mission here.

description: With less than 10 hours left to 1995, there was one thing Lana and James Math had neglected to do. Tango -- or try to.

title: World Cup '06 To Be in Africa
description: The 2006 World Cup will be played in Africa for the first time, the FIFA president Joao Havelange said today.

title: Pinochet Won't Step Down
description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the 80-year-old former dictator of Chile, said in remarks published today in the daily newspaper La Tercera that he intends to remain Commander in Chief of the Chilean Army until tensions with civilian authorities ease. General Pinochet handed the Government over to civilian control in 1990. Under the constitution, he cannot be fired and need not retire until 1998. Tensions between the military and the Government rose during 1995 with the imprisonment of two former military secret police chiefs for plotting to kill a former official.

title: In America;Selling Smokes -- And Sex
description: For the cigarette makers, always on the alert for efficient ways to hook new smokers, especially young ones, it was a dandy idea. This was back in the 1870's and 80's, when it wasn't considered right for women to smoke, so the advertising was directed specifically at men and boys.

title: POP REVIEW;In the Riffs and Curlicues, A Patchwork of the 1970's
description: In the film "Dazed and Confused," the director Richard Linklater looks at a day in the life of high-school students in the 1970's, replicating the music, the language and the clothing of the era. But his intent is not purely nostalgic: the film is about social issues of the present in the setting of the 70's. Thin Lizard Dawn, which performed for a packed house at Brownie's in the East Village on Saturday night, came on like a musical companion to the film. It set its music in the past to explore current social problems.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Goal for 2000: Fiscal Fitness
description: If fiscal fitness is what the doctor ordered, Rutgers University can help. Its Cooperative Extension is seeking 2,000 debtors in each of the state's 21 counties for a program known as "Money 2000."

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL: NEWS ANALYSIS;In the End, Alliance Delivered Goods
description: The system worked. In the moneyed little world of college football, where makers of tortilla chips, weed eaters, cell phones and cars provide generous donations to the entertainment division of American higher education, that rarest of entities -- A Consensus! -- has declared the new bowl alliance a success. At least this once.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Primal Emotions and Ancient Cultures
description: Abdel R. Salaam knows how to evoke strong emotions through powerful movements. Choreographic mood pieces were the highlights of the program that his Forces of Nature Dance Theater Company presented on Friday night at Davis Hall at City College.

title: Patents
description: IN his new book, "The Road Ahead," William H. Gates predicts a future where everyone will carry a wallet-sized personal computer. But an informal and highly unscientific survey asking people what inventions they would most like to see in the new year produced ideas that make Mr. Gates's vision seem like a quill pen. Many people fancifully hoped for inventions that could be wired directly into the brain to make them smarter, more efficient or better entertained.

title: With Respect to the New;Marriage Made In Heaven
description: Furtively the new stems Of clematis grip hands Behind the apple-tree's back. You can't make them if They haven't a mind to. Try it: lift one slender arm And twine it, however gently, Round the other. As soon as You've turned away, it will Let go and hang its head, Considering who to ask next, Now that the spell's been broken.

description: It begins again. And always, in this part of the stunned and stunning world, in winter. Thus -- without birdsong,

title: For New Trinidad Chief, Race Question Looms Big
description: Politics in this small but remarkably diverse Caribbean nation has always been based on race, with blacks the dominant bloc. But an election here last month brought a Prime Minister of Indian descent to power for the first time, and both ethnic groups are now struggling to come to grips with their unfamiliar new roles.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Cruise Ship Group Narrows Review
description: The Cruise Lines International Association, which handles marketing for cruise-ship companies, has narrowed a review on a new consumer cruise communications program to two finalists. The billings were estimated at $10 million a year over a three-year period.

title: Candidate Discloses Names of Contributors
description: Lamar Alexander disclosed today the names of 255 contributors who gave $4.5 million to a television network that kept his name before party members as he prepared to seek the Republican Presidential nomination.

title: For More and More Job Seekers, An Aging Parent Is a Big Factor
description: Just over a year ago, after much soul-searching, Robert W. Crispin turned down a plum job as one of the top three executives of a prestigious company on the West Coast. He decided instead to stay in Hartford, within easy visiting distance of his ailing 90-year-old father-in-law in northwest Pennsylvania.

title: Fugitive in Brazil Pinches a Living Pawning a Past
description: From the window of his house, poised on the steep curves of a hillside artists' colony, Ronald Biggs can hear fireworks by daylight -- warning signals between nearby drug traffickers that the police may be approaching. The soundtrack of today's small-time hoods mixes with the recollections of England's veteran fugitive, now turned lounge act.

title: A Film Made in Afghanistan Is a Post-Communist First
description: An Afghan production company has released the first feature-length film completed entirely in Afghanistan since the fall of the Communist Government in 1992.

title: A Dial Tone All the Same
description: Lawmakers and journalists like to describe the impending deregulation of the nation's telecommunications industry as revolutionary, sweeping, even historic. That may be true for telecommunications companies. But for most Americans, life immediately after deregulation will not seem much different than life before it.

title: Howard Petersen, 85, Banker and Trade Adviser
description: Howard C. Petersen, a former president and chairman of the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia who had earlier held posts in the Truman and Kennedy Administrations, died on Thursday at his home in Radnor, Pa., a suburb of Philadelphia. He was 85.

title: Divorce Lawyers Fear They Protested Too Much;Separation Anxiety Follows the Transfer of Judges in Manhattan
description: Say what you will about Manhattan's divorce lawyers, they are a plucky, dedicated lot. Late one recent afternoon as the city streets emptied out in advance of a monster snowstorm, more than 75 lawyers braved the sleet and darkness. Their mission? To make obeisance to three judges who will be taking over Manhattan's divorce court tomorrow.

title: After Ovitz, There's No Room for Mercy in Hollywood Agent Wars
description: Competition among Hollywood agents is never a pleasant spectacle to watch. But the new year is expected to reveal the kind of trench warfare among agents that is unusual even by Hollywood's rougher standards.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Maidens and Dragoons Trip the Comic Fantastic
description: The New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players opened their season at Symphony Space on Friday evening with "Patience," which up to a point lends itself to the company's broad approach. The rivalry between the "Esthetic" poets Bunthorne and Grosvenor can be drawn cartoon-style if you have performers as amusing as Stephen O'Brien (evoking Ernie Kovacs's supremely daffy poet, Percy Dovetonsils), and Keith Jurosko (alternating the role with Richard Alan Holmes).

title: CALENDAR;When to Park Where in 1996
description: Listed below are the days on which parking regulations will be suspended this year in New York City. Street cleaning regulations, including those at parking meters, are suspended in most communities in New York on Wednesdays. and Saturdays. Motorists should follow posted signs carefully to avoid tickets.

The assignment had been handled for the last six months by Krimstein/Clapps in New York before that agency withdrew from a review.

description: Virginia Tech, a Sugar Bowl participant by default, blitzed Texas into submission and rode two long touchdowns by Bryan Still to a 28-10 victory tonight.

description: The Netscape Communications Corporation has replaced the popular Yahoo! Internet directory in prominent positions on computer screens with two competing companies who paid for the top spots.

title: Abroad at Home;Marx And Gingrich
description: Among the memorable documents of the year just ended was a letter from Vaclav Havel, the Czech President. He sent it in October to an international environmental conference.

title: Nation's Smaller Jails Struggle To Cope With Surge in Inmates
description: The town square in the seat of rural Chenango County is postcard-perfect. The restored old courthouse has a gold dome and stately columns. The First Baptist Church is on one side of the square, the United Church of Christ on the other.

title: Kentucky's Beauty Hides the Beast of Old Wars
description: In recent days residents of this central Kentucky community have been receiving in the mail a picturesque 1996 calendar depicting, among other things, a mist-shrouded bend of Route 421 at dawn, the craggy west face of Indian Fort Mountain at high noon and a close-up of a great spangled fritillary butterfly lunching on a laurel leaf.

title: Ankara Journal;Islamic Victor Has Faith, Too, in Peaceful Politics
description: When the leader of Turkey's surging Islamic party, Necmettin Erbakan, stepped onto an Ankara street this week after a meeting with business leaders, a cheering crowd quickly engulfed him. From windows high above, people began waving and chanting his name.

title: HOCKEY;An Injury to Richter Hits Hard
description: As Mike Richter lay on the ice in pain, the color began to run out of his face, and with it, perhaps, the Rangers' run to the top of the National Hockey League this season.

title: As 7 Go to Trial in a Fatal Beating, a Philadelphia Neighborhood StillGrieves
description: In the basement of a house in the Fox Chase neighborhood of Philadelphia, a chalkboard still keeps the tally of the pool games Eddie Polec played with his father. They were tied, 5-5, more than a year ago when Eddie was beaten to death with baseball bats on the steps of his church at the age of 16.

title: Where the High-Tech Jobs Are
description: While jumping on the Internet bandwagon seems to be the latest rage, the second-largest fad for the computer industry is coming up with ever-sillier nicknames for the areas that house their home offices. Silicon Valley was one of the first, but that has spawned Multimedia Gulch (the area in San Francisco known for web site and CD-ROM development), Siliwood (the meeting place of technology and Hollywood somewhere slightly north of Silicon Valley) and Silicon Alley (New York City's attempt to claim a piece of the multimedia pie.)

title: THEATER REVIEW;Appalachian Family at Home With Horror
description: Romulus Linney may be the only dramatist today who can write about those rural Americans of the Southeast, sometimes called hillbillies, without turning them into either caricatures or picturesque mementos from another time and place. When it comes to exploring Appalachia, he has the cool, compassionate, unsentimental eye that was evident in Depression-era photographs by the great Walker Evans. Mr. Linney doesn't judge these people. All the judgment that need be expressed is contained within the clarity and intensity of his vision. He sees bones beneath skin and acknowledges the existence of mysteries not easily analyzed. The rest -- and it's a lot -- is up to you.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;A few resolutions for high-tech movers and shakers.
description: DESPITE the mood swings of high-tech stocks throughout last year, at the dawn of 1996 more people in the world are computerized, World Wide Webbed or dripping rich from Internet-related public stock offerings than anyone would have dreamed of at the dawn of 1995.

title: Treasury Schedules Week's Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills and Thursday's auction of a one-year bill.

title: A Man Kills 2 Teen-Agers Over Hubcaps
description: A man who thought someone was trying to steal his $60 hubcaps fired his assault rifle, killing two teen-agers and wounding a third in a parked car, the police said on Saturday.

title: Observer;Dream On, Big Spender
description: See him seated by the fire, nodding, chin on chest, slow heavy breathing. Now and then he is shaken by a loud snore. It wakes him. He looks bewildered. "Where am I?" he would ask if he really cared.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;Recovery in California Wears a New Costume
description: CALL it the tinsel recovery.

title: California Company Ceases Operations
description: Access Healthnet Inc., a maker of communications systems for the health care industry, has ceased operations and filed to liquidate under bankruptcy laws, the company said.

title: Hollywood Blood Bath: Too Many Holiday Films
description: Movie studio executives vacationing in Hawaii, New York and various Western ski resorts faced some bleak news over the holiday season. Although there were a handful of hits -- "Waiting to Exhale," "Toy Story," "Goldeneye," "Ace Ventura: When Nature Calls," "Jumanji" and "Sense and Sensibility" -- the movie landscape was littered with an array of flops and big-budget disappointments.

title: This New Year Starts With Sushi
description: Many people begin New Year's Day with a hangover and some ambitious resolutions that are rarely fulfilled.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;McNabb Leads Syracuse To Rout
description: Syracuse 41, Clemson 0

title: A Clean Slate in Albany
description: The State Legislature returns to Albany this week with an opportunity to move away from the blame shifting, behind-the-scenes deals, overdue budgets and mindless party-line voting that have marred so many previous sessions.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;Little Pessimism From the Executive Suite
description: AS everyone knows, you can never satisfy the boss. Business was strong at many of America's big companies in 1995, and it is looking as good or better for 1996. Profits were bountiful, and this year they are again expected to outpace the consensus forecast for economic growth of 2 to 2.5 percent.

title: Wyllis Bandler, 79, Who Sought Application of Abstract Algebra
description: Wyllis Bandler, a mathematician who worked in the rarefied sphere of abstract algebra and sought to give it practical application, died on Dec. 22 at Tallahassee Memorial Regional Medical Center in Florida. He was 79 and lived in Tallahassee.

title: Motorist Drives Into Crowd
description: A couple trying to drive away from a New Year's Eve fireworks display rammed their car into a crowd, injuring 21 spectators, the police said today. Two people were seriously hurt. The woman, who is six months pregnant, said she and her boyfriend were attacked as they tried to leave the waterfront and were trying to flee when they hit the pedestrians.

title: Bill Nyrop, Hockey Player, 43
description: Bill Nyrop, a defenseman with three Stanley Cup champion Montreal Canadien teams, died of cancer on Sunday. He was 43.

title: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;Home Pages Never Die; You Must Kill Them
description: ON a bleak winter day a year ago, a visitor to the World Wide Web of the Internet came across an eerie site: the Chicago Cubs home page frozen in time, abandoned on the day Major League Baseball went on strike in August 1994.

title: Reveler Accused of Fatally Shooting Cousin
description: Celebrating the New Year, a reveler firing a gun in the street accidentally shot and killed a cousin who was standing nearby, the police said today.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Many See Sparkle Dimming In I.P.O.'s
description: WATCHING the initial public offering market last year was enough to give anyone goose bumps.

description: ONE of the more popular prognostications for the Internet and the World Wide Web is that they will usher in a new breed of software: tiny "applets" that will replace bloated applications and continual upgrades.

description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Royals Refuse Brett
description: GEORGE BRETT offered to buy the Kansas City Royals for $100 million, but the Royals rejected the proposal from Brett, who carried the Royals to many victories, and his brother, BOBBY. The proposed ownership group reportedly included the talk-show host RUSH LIMBAUGH, a former Royals employee. (AP)

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Republicans Planning New Offensive in Battle Over Taxes
description: THIS year, voters can expect to hear a lot of politicians promise "tax reform" about as often as they exhale. But do not count on an overhaul of the tax code soon. One of the few things Republicans and Democrats agree on is that the issue will not come to a head until 1997 at the earliest, once the voters have chosen the next President.

title: For Little Italy Group, Famine After the Feast
description: Anthony Esposito, 88 years old and about 5 feet tall, spent 11 days in September guarding a statue of San Gennaro. His was a station of a certain responsibility during the Little Italy street festival that is held annually to honor the community's patron saint.

title: 4 Wounded in Drive-By Shooting in Elizabeth
description: Just four hours into the New Year, a drive-by shooting left four people wounded, including a 16-year-old girl listed in critical condition.

title: Numerous U.S. Plant and Freshwater Species Found in Peril
description: A STUDY of more than 20,000 native American species of plants and animals has found that about one-third are rare or imperiled, a larger fraction than some scientists had expected.

title: World News Briefs;26 People Die in Mexico As Buses Crash Head On
description: A bus crossed into oncoming traffic and rammed another bus head on in northern Mexico today, killing 26 people and injuring at least 22. Six of the dead were children.

title: South Korean Ex-President, Recovering From Hunger Strike, Is Queriedon Slush Fund
description: Former President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea was reported today to be recovering rapidly from his 26-day hunger strike, but as his health improves he is facing a grilling about a slush fund he is accused of having accumulated while running the country.

title: Parolee Faces Murder Charge In Queens Fire
description: Fire marshals arrested a paroled drug offender yesterday who the authorities say accidentally caused a fire in an abandoned house in Jamaica, Queens, that claimed the life of a firefighter.

description: NEW YORK CITY

description: Leaping Over Leap Years Q. Why is the year 2000 a leap year? I thought years ending in double zeros were an exception.

title: Sports of The Times;Will Barnett Ride Into The Sunset?
description: THE plain white NORTHWESTERN on purple painted grass at the south end of the Rose Bowl, a sight that generations of Wildcats thought they would never ever see, had been chewed up by a hard-fought afternoon in the sun. The San Gabriel Mountains were hidden, no longer glowing to the north and east as they had just a short while before. The most unexpected and unlikely achievement in recent college football history had ended with Northwestern's 41-32 loss to Southern California in the 82d Rose Bowl.

title: Arleigh A. Burke Dies at 94; Naval Hero of World War II
description: Adm. Arleigh A. Burke, a battle-decorated Chief of Naval Operations whose combat exploits against Japanese naval forces in the South Pacific made him the Navy's most celebrated destroyer squadron commander of World War II, died yesterday at Bethesda Naval Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 94 and lived in Fairfax, Va.

title: Chairman Is Named At New York Fed
description: John C. Whitehead, former Deputy Secretary of State and now the chairman of AEA Investors Inc., has been named chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

description: People are regaining their confidence in the Police Department," Murray L. Palent, a Township Councilman, said last week.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about New Year's Eve celebrations in New York City misspelled the name of a worker who was blowing up balloons at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. He is Jose Caballero, not Hoseas Caballer.

title: New Family Tree Is Constructed For Indo-European
description: LINGUISTS have long agreed that languages as diverse as English, French, German and even Iranian, Albanian and Armenian all descended from a long-dead tongue, Proto-Indo-European, spoken some 5,000 years ago. But the exact nature of the relationship has been a matter of dispute. How should the family tree of the Indo-European languages be drawn?

title: Disabled Train Extends Riders' Night
description: About 1,000 revelers leaving New York City after ringing in the New Year were stranded for nearly three hours early this morning on the Hackensack River Bridge after the New Jersey Transit train they were riding in broke down.

title: By Design;Clothes Ready for Action
description: New Year's resolutions and the inevitable excess of the holidays mean that at any moment now, many people will be crunching those abdominals or lifting iron. Active wear has become increasingly fashionable, while ready-to-wear is incorporating sports-oriented fabrics.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Meeting Challenges In the Insurance Business
description: After several years of slow growth, life insurers are still counting on the aging of America as their ace in the hole. But before life insurers can cash in on the baby boomers' increasing need for retirement and savings investments, they face some tall challenges: some from outside their industry and others of their own making.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;With U.S. Flat, Where Will the Money Go?
description: AMERICAN investors, pack your moneybags.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Increasing the Demand For Health Care Services
description: The providers of health care can hardly wait as the latest crop of 50-year-olds crosses the threshold to the aches and pains of middle age. Having grown up expecting and generally finding care that was both affordable and accessible, the graying boomers will now need it a lot more, and that should translate into bonanzas for drug makers, many physicians and hospitals, not to mention the makers of artificial knees for worn-out joggers who refuse to slow down.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Remember Past, But Can It Be Repeated?
description: Ironically and appropriately, while people below them were celebrating the beginning of a new year in the early hours yesterday morning, the Rangers were quietly rejoicing over the conclusion of the previous one.

description: COMPUTER security is making a transition from the university and the research laboratory to the real world. So far it is proving to be a rocky evolution.

description: Merrill Lynch & Company said on Friday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had arrested an assistant vice president of the company's Wagner Stott Clearing Corporation unit on charges of wire fraud.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Voting on Arbitration Bill
description: The lame-duck Assembly will try again this week to break the logjam on binding arbitration for police and fire contracts. The bill that will be considered by the Assembly Thursday has been passed by both houses, rewritten by Gov. Christine Todd Whitman in the form of a conditional veto, and approved again by the Senate.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Getting the Message To Aging Consumers
description: The aging of the baby-boom generation will have profound implications for consumer marketers, who are scrambling to adapt to the needs, tastes and attitudes of the boomers. Significant changes are expected in everything from the kinds of products on store shelves to the look and tone of ads.

title: Giuliani Judicial Selection Passed the Bar Exam Despite Lacking a Law Degree
description: One of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent choices for judge flunked out of Brooklyn Law School twice and never earned a law degree but became a lawyer by studying on his own and passing the bar exam.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;The Bulls Are Hot and Full of Surprises
description: Before Jerry Krause, the general manager of the Bulls, made the trade with the San Antonio Spurs to obtain Dennis Rodman, Krause and his coach, Phil Jackson, met with Rodman for two days last summer in Chicago.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMYThe Economic Consensus on 1996: The Year of the Big Yawn; . . . to Optimism on Everything
description: Gail D. Fosler, a former chief economist for the Senate Budget Committee, is not known as a particularly venturesome forecaster. This year, however, she is much more optimistic than her colleagues: her prediction of 1996 growth was more than three-quarters of a percentage point higher than any other forecaster polled by the newsletter Blue Chip Economic Indicators.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;In New York Region, Stirrings of a Revival
description: FOR a region that has long been treading a line between recession and anemic growth, 1995 was hardly a turnaround year in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. With layoffs cutting deeply into banks, insurance companies, military bases and government agencies, total employment rose less than 1 percent.

description: The playoffs will not begin for three and a half months, but there are some midseason impressions of the Rangers worth noting.

description: A police officer was slightly injured early yesterday when he was hit by a carjacked Oldsmobile just before the driver sped away, the police said.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;The Economic Consensus on 1996: The Year of the Big Yawn
description: If the consensus is on target, the economy will grow as much as 2.5 percent in 1996, somewhat less than the estimated 3.25 percent last year but a pace that many believe is about as brisk as can be sustained without ratcheting up the inflation rate.

title: The New Great Game in Asia
description: While few have noticed, Central Asia has again emerged as a murky battleground among big powers engaged in an old and rough geopolitical game. Western experts believe that the largely untapped oil and natural gas riches of the Caspian Sea countries could make that region the Persian Gulf of the next century. The object of the revived game is to befriend leaders of the former Soviet republics controlling the oil, while neutralizing Russian suspicions and devising secure alternative pipeline routes to world markets.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Registering Sex Offenders
description: Prosecutors involved in carrying out "Megan's Law" will have their work cut out for them this year. By mid-December, 3,259 convicted sex offenders in New Jersey had registered with their county prosecutor, the State Attorney General's office said. But so far, the process of notifying a community of a sex offender's proximity -- required when he or she is deemed to pose a threat -- has been completed in only 36 cases, the Deputy Attorney General, Greta Gooden-Brown, said recently.

title: Penn to Lose Relays Director
description: Timothy Baker will resign today as director of the Penn Relays, a post he has held since 1989, a University of Pennsylvania athletic department official said yesterday.

title: NATO Force In Sarajevo, But Barriers Still Remain
description: The confusion and mistrust about the NATO troops in Bosnia was evident in Sarajevo today at a bridge between the parts of this divided city. The bridge still carries the now remarkably inappropriate name it was given before the war: Brotherhood and Unity.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;Sideshows Aside, Economy Is Still Key to Election
description: WHAT will turn on -- or turn off -- the voters in 1996? Bob Dole's back-and-forth position on abortion? Bill Clinton's taste for the fast lane and fast food? The Gingrich who stole Medicare?

description: Reducing spending from state taxes for the second consecutive year, Gov. George E. Pataki's budget for 1996-97 promises an austerity not seen in Albany since World War II and a Governor named Dewey.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;About Freedom of the Virtual Press
description: THE personal computer is now officially grown up. In January 1975, the Altair 8800 kit, considered the first true personal computer, made its debut on the cover of Popular Electronics and started a revolution that has transformed businesses worldwide.

title: A Library That Has Sheltered More Than Books Leaves Its Home
description: They came this week, as always, for different reasons. Some wanted a last look at the ornate carved ceiling towering over the grand staircase. Others just wanted a roof, any roof, and they came in from the rain with bedrolls and backpacks and sat on the cold stone floor and left little puddles. Some even shuffled to the stacks and returned with books.

title: A Toll Road in California Offers A High-Tech Answer to Traffic
description: The section of the Riverside Freeway that runs past this Orange County community is one of the busiest stretches of highway in the Los Angeles region, which means it is among the busiest stretches of highway anywhere in the world.

description: It was the sort of day Woody Hayes would have loved. Dank. Hammering rain. A soaked field, perfect for 3 yards and a clod of mud. Old Woody, the legendary Ohio State coach, would have taken one look at these conditions and then he would have run it and run it and run it some more, tried to grind Tennessee into submission and establish once and for all the superiority of the Big Ten.

description: CHINA's economy may be coming to the end of its wild ride.

description: Major cities across Conecticut recorded fewer homicides in 1995 than the previous year.

description: For eight years, the sleepy coast of Maine has been stirred by an underwater gold rush. Many fishermen who were barely making a living have become flush with cash, but in the quest for riches, some novice divers have drowned and competing skippers have occasionally scuttled rivals' boats.

description: A FAIRLY basic tenet of economics holds that as worker productivity increases, so does labor's share of national income.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Forest Fire Still a Mystery
description: One of the largest forest fires in New Jersey in the last two decades remains a mystery nine months later. The fire, which destroyed 20,000 acres of Pinelands in April and caused the evacuations of hundreds of people, was confined mostly to Manchester and Berkeley Townships in Ocean County and part of Monmouth County.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Some More Visitors From 'Alien Nation'
description: A good many television movies have been spun off such successful network series as "Columbo," "The Rockford Files" and "Cagney and Lacey." Fox Broadcasting, characteristically, is going in the opposite direction, whipping up periodic two-hour spinoffs from a series that was considerably less than successful.

title: They Hate the Government, but Love Those Subsidies
description: That great Republican, Teddy Roosevelt, once said, "A nation behaves well if the natural resources and assets which one generation turns over to the next are increased and not impaired in value." Even though popular pressure and opinion polls have tempered their anti-environmental extremism recently, can anyone imagine the Republican leaders of the 104th Congress making such a statement?

title: Physicists See Long Pass As Triumph of 3 Torques
description: AS Americans sit down to tonight's Fiesta Bowl, watching Nebraska and Florida battle for the national collegiate title, one viewer is likely to be Dr. William J. Rae of the State University of New York at Buffalo. He will be paying particular attention to any long passes the quarterbacks toss down field because he is trying to figure out why a football flies the way it does.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Replenishing the Ranks Of High-Skilled Workers
description: When the United Automobile Workers begin negotiations this year with the Big Three auto companies, the shifting of work to outside suppliers is expected to be its single biggest concern. But it may not be at the top of the agenda for many U.A.W. members.

description: Zapatista rebels in the southern state of Chiapas, celebrating the second anniversary of their 1994 uprising, have announced plans to form a new political opposition movement in Mexico.

title: Second Gene Is Linked to a Deadly Skin Cancer
description: RESEARCHERS have found a second gene responsible for malignant melanoma, an aggressive and often deadly form of skin cancer.

title: Clinton Takes a Break At Focused Festivities
description: After three days of number-crunching with Republican Congressional leaders, President Clinton once again sought surcease from sorrow this New Year's weekend in the wonkish way he loves best: at the saturnalia of soul-searching by the sea known as Renaissance Weekend.

title: Palmer Williams, 79, Executive Who Helped Shape '60 Minutes'
description: Palmer Williams, a documentary film maker and CBS News executive who played a central role in creating the programs "See It Now" and "60 Minutes," died yesterday at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 79 and also kept a home in Truro, Mass.

description: To the Editor:

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMYThe Economic Consensus on 1996: The Year of the Big Yawn; Outlooks at the Edge: From Bust . . .
description: Not only is John Mueller one of the few economists predicting recession in 1996, he has been arguing for a long time that the new year will be a downturn, a Presidential election notwithstanding. No worse than 1990-1991, but a recession this year will still be the real, painful thing.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Experts Are Upbeat. Can Markets Thrive Anyway?
description: With its vertiginous rise in stock prices and a bond rally that in some respects was even more impressive, 1995 is going to be a tough year to top for financial markets.

title: New Player in the Schoolyard;Rudy Crew Settles In and Sets Own Ground Rules
description: It was another day and another disaster at 110 Livingston Street, the down-at-the-heels Brooklyn headquarters of the nation's largest school system. New York City teachers had rejected their contract, the Mayor was enraged, and Dr. Rudy Crew, the Schools Chancellor barely off the plane from Tacoma, Wash., was making his own first moves.

title: FOOTBALL NOTEBOOK;Indianapolis Cheers a Substitute Hero
description: The Colts' charter plane was over the Kansas City, Mo., area when the clock struck midnight, signaling the arrival of the new year. The Indianapolis players and coaches raised a toast in celebration of their good fortune.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Piece by Piece, Selling Upsala
description: Crushed by $12.5 million in debt, Upsala College had to close last May after 102 years. Since then, $900,000 has been raised through sales of books, artwork, furnishings and laboratory equipment, Walter J. Greenhalgh, a lawyer for the college's bankruptcy trustee, said recently. And nine bids for parts of the 37-acre campus have been received from nonprofit organizations, said Charles M. Forman, the trustee.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.F.L.;Rooney Is Recuperating
description: DAN ROONEY, president of the Pittsburgh Steelers, had gall-bladder surgery last week. The team said yesterday that the operation was performed at Pittsburgh's Presbyterian University Hospital and that Rooney, 63, is recovering at home. He is expected to return to work by the end of the week. (AP)

title: Pataki's Budget Plan in Brief: Amid Austerity, a Tax Break;Welfare
description: The single biggest cut in Mr. Pataki's budget, after Medicaid, would be in welfare, where he is hoping to save $240 million through time limits on benefits and reductions in monthly grants.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Wall St. Takes a Shine to Fee-Based Businesses
description: ONCE considered too tame for Wall Street's gunslingers, businesses like asset management, global custody and clearing are being wooed by investment bankers with Romeo-like ardor.

title: Barbara Yuncker, Science Reporter, 74
description: Barbara Yuncker, a prize-winning science reporter for The New York Post and a longtime leader of the Newspaper Guild, died yesterday. She was 74 and had homes in Manhattan and Canaan, N.Y.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Horrible Examples Of Lawyerly Excess
description: The profession that Americans love to hate is in the dock tonight at 10 on ABC. "The Trouble With Lawyers," as John Stossel sees it, is that they are major instigators and prime beneficiaries of a national epidemic of lawsuits.

title: CHRONICLE

title: Widow of Arthur Ashe Raises Objection to Site for Monument
description: Jeanne Moutoussamy-Ashe, the widow of the tennis star Arthur Ashe, said in an article published today that she opposed the City of Richmond's decision to put Mr. Ashe's statue on Monument Avenue, which now honors only Confederate heroes.

title: Remote Border Crossing Turning to Remote Control
description: From the air, the United States' "silent" border is also invisible. In a vast prairie landscape, Canadian and American wheat fields stretch smoothly to each nation's edge.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Seminoles Roar Back And End Irish Streak
description: When quarterback Danny Kanell accidentally stepped out of his own end zone to give Notre Dame a 2-point gift and help the Fighting Irish extend their lead to 12 points, it appeared that this was going to go down as one of the most forgettable seasons in Florida State's recent history.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;The Welfare State Is Alive and Welcome in Western Europe
description: FOR years, a favorite pastime of economists has been prophesying the demise of Europe's comfortable welfare state.

title: Bias Issue Is Raised in Killing by Officer
description: At 3:04 on Saturday morning, on a quiet, dark street in Elmont, L.I., a white police officer confronted a black man he thought was acting suspiciously. By 3:29 A.M., the black man was dead with nine bullet wounds, including one in the head.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;The South: Prosperity With an Asterisk
description: FROM the perspective of the bricklayers working on the Olympic Stadium and other projects in Atlanta, things could not be better.

title: BUSINESS WORLD;Outlook '96
description: From Wall Street to Hollywood, from silicon to steel, businesses will soon see the effects of changes passed by the Republican-controlled Congress. Decades of rules and restrictions have been swept away, and more deregulation is planned. But a number of hurdles could keep the Republican vision from becoming a reality.

title: Chess
description: The 1995 United States Championship in Modesto, Calif., played from Nov. 19 to Dec. 4, was closely fought and required a playoff before an individual winner could be named. Patrick Wolff of Somerville, Mass., won a speed chess tie break against Nick DeFirmian of New York and Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass. Each of the three grandmasters ended the tournament with 8 1/2-4 1/2, and each was awarded a prize of $4,850 by the Interplay company. FINAL STANDINGS

title: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;Telecommuting Options Are Gaining Sophistication
description: TWICE a week, Ralph Silvestro skips the two-and-a-half-hour train ride from his home in Martinsburg, W. Va., to his office at the General Services Administration in downtown Washington.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;1995 HIGHLIGHTS
description: So Many Deals, So Little Time It wasn't "another day, another billion-dollar merger" last year -- it was far more than that. According to the Securities Data Corporation, 1995 (through Dec. 26 anyway) saw American companies announce some $465 billion in mergers and acquisitions, surpassing the old record of $347 billion set just the previous year. And while hostile takeovers are happening with greatest frequency since 1988, a popular offshoot is the "bear hug" -- an offer too good for the target company's board to refuse. (Did someone say I.B.M.-Lotus?)

title: CHRONICLE
description: Universal Pictures is conducting a national search for boys between ages 7 and 13 to star in "Leave it to Beaver," a new feature film based on the television series that was broadcast in the 1950's and 1960's. Boys are needed to play the parts of Beaver, Wally, Eddie, Lumpy and Beaver's other friends.

title: POP REVIEW;Having Too Much Fun to Notice Lyrics
description: When peppy grooves compete with bummed-out lyrics, the grooves easily have the advantage; rhythm registers long before language does. At the Bogmen's sold-out concert on Friday night at Irving Plaza, the audience was too busy dancing, jumping up and down and crowd-surfing to think twice about what Bill Campion was singing. Songs from the Bogmen's album, "Life Begins at 40 Million" (Arista), mourned a mother's death, imagined global warming, faced a manipulative psychiatrist, attacked a self-righteous hypocrite and confronted a girlfriend who walked out when the singer lost his job. "You've got nothing nice to say, so spit it all out," Mr. Campion proclaimed.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;On the Cusp of Maturity, A Youth Is Hit by Illness
description: In retrospect, there were some early clues that Diana Cortez was getting sick. It was odd, for instance, that Diana, a 17-year-old, could not keep pace with her social worker, who often invited her on walks. She seemed increasingly clumsy, too, occasionally dropping a cup or a glass.

title: No Headline
description: I wish the members of Congress would hurry up and do it -- send states the money and let us manage it. They ought to quit fooling around and get it done." MARK W. KILLIAN, Republican Speaker of the Arizona House of Representatives. [A1:6.]

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Jerry S. Cohen, a Washington lawyer best known for class-action suits, incorrectly included information about another lawyer named Jerry Cohen, who practices in California. It was the Jerry Cohen who lives in California -- not the one who just died -- who for 14 years was general counsel to the United Farm Workers, winning court battles against the use of trespass laws to deny union organizers access to workers in the fields. He was also instrumental in writing a Farm Workers Union accord with the teamsters to end 10 years of organizing strife. And it was he who characterized attempts by Federal agents to prove that Cesar Chavez was a Communist as a "witch hunt and an exercise in guilt by association."

title: In Johnson's Own Words: He Wants to Be a Jet
description: He has draft advice for Rich Kotite: Take me.

title: Moscow Journal;At Starlite Diner, Rubles Buy Burgers and Bubbly
description: There is nothing the Russian people love more than easing themselves into aqua-colored Naugahyde booths, surveying their chrome and pink-neon surroundings, and ordering a pulled pork sandwich drenched in barbecue sauce, accompanied by a volcano of garlicky mashed potatoes and a chocolate egg cream.

title: New Orleans Cemeteries Besieged by Crime Wave
description: Pearl Davis, wrapped in a white veil and speaking in a soft Caribbean accent, seems perfectly at home walking down the narrow pathway of the St. Louis Cemetery No. 1, founded in the 1790's, where tombs and family vaults are filled with French, German, Creole, Italian, black and Chinese residents of the city.

title: A Third Gene Is Found In an Inherited Heart Ill
description: A NEWLY identified gene has been linked to about 55 percent of cases of an inherited heart disorder that can kill young, otherwise healthy people.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;New Areas in Finance, New Kinds of Crimes
description: WRONGDOING in finance took an international turn last year.

title: Wildlife Finds Odd Sanctuary on Military Bases
description: FEW places outside the tropical rain forests contain such a wealth of biological riches as a certain plot of Florida Panhandle not far from here. In this snippet of a mostly vanished landscape, the wind sighs in the flat tops of centuries-old longleaf pines spaced as invitingly as if in a park, soaring above a thick carpet of wildflowers, grasses and haphazardly arranged shrubs.

title: Air-Ticket Tax Expires; Some Will Save 10%
description: Most major airlines in the United States stopped collecting a 10 percent tax on domestic tickets yesterday, after Congress failed to renew the decades-old excise tax that expired on Monday night.

title: Sir Trenchard Cox, 90, Author And Longtime Museum Director
description: Sir Trenchard Cox, one of the most successful and personable British museum directors of recent decades, died on Dec. 21, London newspapers reported. He was 90 and lived in London.

title: Limiting Lawsuits Rewards New York's Lapses
description: To the Editor:

title: Weighing In On Tobacco At the F.D.A.
description: With just hours left before today's midnight deadline for public comments on its plans to regulate cigarettes, snuff and chewing tobacco, and with more than half a million responses already in hand, the Federal Food and Drug Administration is bracing for a last-minute flood of submissions, including impassioned postcards and industry documents more easily measured in pounds than pages.

title: Rebecca Drucker Bernstien, Writer, 105
description: Rebecca Drucker Bernstien, a journalist, critic and feminist who was a fixture in New York City literary circles from 1910 to 1950, died of heart failure on Dec. 28. A resident of Gramercy Park for the last 45 years, she was 105.

title: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Huskers and Gators Will Test Defenses
description: Somebody has to stop somebody sometime. As overwhelming a rate of success as the offensive units from Nebraska and Florida have had in perfect seasons -- the powerful Huskers with the bulk of their 556-yard average on the ground and the intricate Gators with most of their 534 average yards gained by air -- the strategic premise of college football is based on imperfection. At some point in the 25th Fiesta Bowl on Tuesday night, the richest bowl game in history, with a combined payout of $26 million, will be influenced by defenses that have often been overlooked and might yet feel overwhelmed.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY: Middle Age Catches Up With the MeGeneration; Preparing Nest Eggs For Retirement
description: For Wall Street, an industry that makes billion-dollar bets on uncertain prospects, the aging of the baby boomers is expected to become a profitable sure thing.

title: FEDERAL IMPASSE SADDLING STATES WITH INDECISION
description: State legislators across the nation convene this month as virtual captives of the budget impasse, with no idea how much Federal money they will receive for Medicaid and welfare, how much flexibility they will have in spending it or how much state money they must contribute.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;In Japan, Pessimism Is Pervasive
description: FOR Japan, 1995 was annus horribilis: an earthquake in the central city of Kobe, a nerve gas attack on the Tokyo subway, a gyrating yen, a banking crisis and a sagging economy.

title: POP REVIEW;Blues and Honky-Tonk With Roadhouse Style
description: He performed with Howlin' Wolf and Lightnin' Hopkins in the 1950's, taught John Lennon how to play the bluesy harmonica riffs that were heard on the Beatles' "Love Me Do" in the 60's, wrote country songs that became hits for Waylon Jennings and Emmylou Harris in the 70's and recorded his first Top 40 solo songs in the 80's. It's been a long, even road that the Texas-born Delbert McClinton has been traveling for four decades: respect and influence he's earned, but lasting success has always stayed just out of reach, like the mechanical rabbit at a greyhound race.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-6

title: MUSIC REVIEW;The Season's Last Chestnuts, From the Philharmonic
description: The New York Philharmonic gave itself a break this year. Instead of giving its annual New Year's Eve concert on the 31st, the orchestra played its traditional year-end program on Saturday evening. It was probably for the best: the stage of Avery Fisher Hall was decorated in silver bunting; some of the players sported glittery top hats during the final encore, and the program notes suggested using the concert to turn the final weekend of the year into a long New Year's party. Anyone intent on spending New Year's Eve with the music of Johann Strauss Jr. was still free to catch the Met's "Fledermaus."

title: Kayaker Dies in L.I. Sound
description: A 68-year-old Danbury man died on Sunday in a kayaking accident on Long Island Sound.

title: Liberia Faction Seeks to End New Fighting
description: Rebels waving white flags declared today that they were ready for talks in Liberia's civil war, after a weekend of infighting that terrorized the western countryside.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTINGWhat Now?; Even if '74 Rings a Bell, Avoiding The Market Remains a Risk, Too
description: THE reason so few professionals on Wall Street remember the last real bear market -- 1973, when stock values fell 15 percent, and 1974, when they fell 26 percent -- is that most of the unlucky ones who suffered through it have made so much money in the last 20 years that they could retire.

title: World News Briefs;Corsican Rebel Killed; 3 Blasts Hit Capital
description: A militant separatist was shot to death early today and three explosions rocked Ajaccio, the Corsican capital, the police said.

title: Unions Push for Higher Minimum Wage on New York City Contracts
description: New York City's labor unions are on a collision course with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani over the issue they have made their No. 1 legislative priority: enacting a law that would require companies with city contracts to pay more than the $4.25-an-hour minimum wage.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Have Tall Order In the Absence of Ewing
description: Patrick Ewing rode a stationary bike and walked through a couple of plays today, yet for most of this afternoon Charles Smith and Herb Williams played the role of the Knicks' All-Star center in practice.

title: The Need to Nourish Tourism
description: Some 25 million people -- nearly half the population of France or twice the population of Pennsylvania -- visited New York City last year for business or pleasure or both. From Omaha, Osaka and everywhere else, they came in record numbers, bringing joy to innkeepers and maitre d's, to theaters and merchants, and more than $1 billion to the collectors of city and state taxes.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Overseas Markets Expected to Improve
description: OVERSEAS markets are beginning to perk up and may offer better opportunities in 1996 than they did last year, several market analysts say. They argue that the favorable trends in American markets are spreading overseas.

title: Saudi Crown Prince to Take Over While King Rests
description: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia handed over authority today to his half-brother, Crown Prince Abdullah, saying he needed time to rest.

title: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;Book Chains Extending Influence
description: FOR book buyers, 1995 was the year of more superstore openings, O. J. Simpson books, pocket-size novels and giant book-movie deals.

title: Unmuzzling the Internet
description: If President Clinton signs the telecommunications bill, drastically restricting private as well as public speech on the Internet, he can expect a rollicking cat-and-mouse game.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Simplicity: Not Cheap, Not Easy
description: NO mouse or trackball. No hard drive. No CD-ROM player. No graphics. No color. No delete key. If you want cheap computing, you may have to give up a few things, including Windows, DOS and MacOS.

title: OUTLOOK '96: THE ECONOMY;1995 HIGHLIGHTS
description: Where Does Bill Gates Want to Go Tomorrow?

title: Boat Industry Back in Good Health
description: The Viking Yacht Company reacted in 1991 to a shrinking powerboat market by closing one of its two manufacturing plants. But the company, now reinvigorated, plans to show off a new line of sport cruising yachts this week at the New York National Boat Show.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Reaping Profits From Wall Street Run-Up
description: WALL STREET had its crop of winners this year as the stock market set new highs through the year, merger activity surged and interest rates declined.

title: Reprieve For PBS But Hunt For Funds Continues
description: It has been a confusing year for people who work in public television.

title: Retro Prices by Young Designers
description: How low can fashion go? It is a question ripe for discussion in 1996. Pricewise, fashion has been turned on its head. Not since the 1970's has there been such a yen for stylish inexpensive clothes and not since then, when Betsey Johnson helped establish the trend-setting store Paraphernalia and Willi Smith designed Williwear, have so many designers begun to make their names creating it.

title: Variant Gene Tied to a Love Of New Thrills
description: Maybe it is appropriate that the first gene that scientists have found linked to an ordinary human personality trait is a gene involved in the search for new things.

title: Clinton the Conciliator Finds His Line in Sand
description: Bill Clinton had been ceding ground and seeking compromise for months, by temperament always the conciliator. But one day in early November, the President spelled out the limits of accommodation.

title: OUTLOOK '96: TECHNOLOGY AND MEDIA;Rough-and-Ready Time in the Internet Business
description: IF brilliant realizations really did appear as light bulbs flashing above people's heads, 1995 would have been an especially bright year for the information and telecommunications industry. Company after company came to understand that their futures were at least partly linked to the Internet.

title: OUTLOOK '96: MARKETS AND INVESTING;Dollar's Star Tied to Budget
description: The central question about the dollar in 1996 is: If President Clinton and the Republican Congress agree on a credible plan to balance the Federal budget in seven years, will this push the dollar higher or lower?

title: Pataki's Budget Plan in Brief: Amid Austerity, a Tax Break;Education
description: When the Governor announced his budget plans, he pledged that no school district would receive less money in operating aid, the lion's share of state school financing.

title: HOCKEY;Medal Eludes U.S. Juniors
description: Per Ragnar Bergkvist's 24 saves helped Sweden beat the United States, 3-0, today, ending the Americans' medal hopes in the world junior hockey championships.

description: Changes at 'House of Style'

description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo's Lights Lure the Young To Forsake Rural Way of Life
description: Love was in the air, and Yoshihiko Tanaka talked sweetly to his beloved about marriage and the future and getting up at 3 each morning during the tea harvest to work backbreaking 20-hour days.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gentler Campaign Season
description: Democrats and Republicans in Somerset County have declared an end to mudslinging. At a ceremony today at Republican headquarters in Somerville, the county party chairman, Dale J. Florio, and his Democratic counterpart, William J. Iannone, will sign a "code of conduct" promising not to engage in negative campaigning in 1996.

title: Bolshoi Looks Ahead (and Back)
description: Although he is the new director of the entire Bolshoi Theater in Moscow, Vladimir Vasilyev is understandably paying special attention to its ballet company. The theater's opera and orchestra come under his jurisdiction as well. But in the 1960's and 70's, Mr. Vasilyev was the Bolshoi Ballet's greatest male star, a member of the same fabulous generation as his Leningrad counterparts Rudolf Nureyev and Yuri Solovyev.

title: The Third American Empire
description: President Clinton is depicting his decision to send 20,000 troops into Bosnia as a natural outgrowth of America's European alliance. But instead of seeing Bosnia as the eastern frontier of NATO, we should view the Balkans as the the western frontier of America's rapidly expanding sphere of influence in the Middle East.

title: Bosnia Bridge Just the First Headache
description: Not since World War II has crossing a river posed such a challenge to the United States military.

title: Pataki's Budget Plan in Brief: Amid Austerity, a Tax Break;Prisons
description: One of the few areas of increased spending in the Governor's budget would be for prisons. His plan calls for building three new maximum-security prisons by the year 2000, and adding 8,000 beds in existing prisons, at a total cost of $476 million.

title: Science Envisions. Technology Absorbs.
description: To the Editor:

title: NYC;In Washington, A Fight Hurts New Yorkers
description: AS usual, lots of lists have been drawn up looking back at the old year: top news stories, best books, worst films. The last thing we need is another list.

title: Pataki's Budget Plan in Brief: Amid Austerity, a Tax Break;Medicaid
description: The Governor is seeking to patch much of the hole in his budget with a $1.1 billion reduction in spending on Medicaid, the health care program for the poor. With Washington also scaling back Medicaid, the Pataki administration sees a chance to revamp a program that has long been the most expensive of any state.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Charles Smith Caught In No-Win Situation
description: The struggle continued last night for the Knicks collectively, and for Charles Smith in particular.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Natural Gas Prices Up Sharply As Cold Draws Down Supplies
description: Natural gas prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday as winter weather caused gas inventories to shrink.

title: U.S. and Albany Are Urged To Investigate Police Shooting
description: Leaders of black community groups have called for state and Federal investigations into a police shooting in Elmont, L.I., that killed a black man early Saturday morning.

title: Senate G.O.P. Votes to Reopen Offices Shut in Budget Impasse
description: Breaking ranks with their House counterparts, Republicans in the Senate agreed today to briefly reopen Government offices while Congress and President Clinton continue talks on balancing the Federal budget.

title: Anti-Immigrant Mood Moves Asians to Organize
description: Marty Shih is the kind of person who has earned Asian-Americans the widespread characterization as the model minority.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: FIESTA BOWL: THE BATTLE FOR NO. 1;Spurrier's Sorry Situation
description: Steve Spurrier is not the apologizing type, but that's what he was doing after tonight's 62-24 destruction of his Florida football team by Nebraska.

title: Firefighter Died in Building Once Marked as a Hazard
description: The Queens building where a firefighter died on Sunday had been marked as a potential hazard by the Fire Department, but word of that designation apparently never reached the city officials who could have taken action to deal with the building's condition.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Wildcat Strike Disrupts Fulton Market
description: A small group of workers at the Fulton Fish Market staged a wildcat strike early yesterday, disrupting the flow of seafood in a protest over the Giuliani administration's decision to oust two companies suspected of having connections with organized crime.

description: To the Editor:
