description: Old Navy Adds Its First Cafe

title: COMPANY NEWS;TENNECO ENERGY TO SELL ITS PIPELINE STAKE
description: Tenneco Energy, a unit of Tenneco Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 50 percent interest in the Kern River natural gas pipeline system to the Williams Companies for $205 million. Tenneco Energy, based in Houston, and Williams, based in Tulsa, Okla., are partners in the Kern River pipeline that runs from Opal, Wyo., to Bakersfield, Calif. The agreement was made on Dec. 31. Tenneco Energy said the timing would allow the company to retain about $10 million of net operating income accrued since September, when it announced the sale of its share to a subsidiary of the Questar Corporation of Salt Lake City for $225 million. Last week, Tenneco Energy and Questar terminated the deal after the Federal Trade Commission voted against it.

title: Monarch Butterflies Killed by Snow in Mexican Winter Home
description: The monarch butterfly may look fragile, but underneath those fine orange-and-black wings is one tough customer. Every year monarchs brave gales and downpours to waft from their summer haunts in Canada all the way across the United States to a winter refuge in central Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an error in transmission between computer systems, an article about the college bowl games in the Television section distributed in the metropolitan area on Sunday included four passages that were garbled by the inclusion of editing instructions. The affected passages should have read as follows:

title: Seattle Area Giving Natural Medicine A Chance to Come In From theFringe
description: Most of the time, the people who write the laws for the most populous county in the Pacific Northwest talk about tax increments and zoning variances. But for a few days over the last year, those people, the King County Council, have been rhapsodizing about garlic pills and the healing power of ginkgo tree extract.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CASINO AMERICA TO BUY ANOTHER RIVERBOAT CASINO
description: Casino America Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a riverboat casino for about $55 million. Casino America, which currently owns and operates four riverboat and dockside casinos on the Mississippi River, said it would buy the Grand Palais Riverboat from Hemmeter Enterprises Inc., a private, Denver-based gaming concern that filed for bankruptcy protection in November 1995. The $55 million price includes a package of cash, notes, stock, stock-purchase warrants and assumption of $10 million of Grand Palais Riverboat's existing liabilities. Casino America's stock rose $1, or 16 percent, to $7.125 a share in Nasdaq trading. Casino America, based in Biloxi, Miss., offered to pay 2.3 million in shares and warrants to buy another 500,000 shares at $10 a share.

title: Our Towns;Looking Back on Pesky Geese, Saved Pets, a Comeback and a Scam Victim
description: SOME important developments to report in several Our Towns columns of 1995:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;J. Walter Thompson Gets Zantac Account
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said yesterday that it had named J. Walter Thompson New York to handle advertising for an over-the-counter version of Warner-Lambert's Zantac prescription antacid.

title: Market Place;What's in a name? Wall Street chic, a network switch maker hopes.
description: THE name Xylan Corporation doesn't exactly trip off the tongue, but then neither did Netscape Communications. As Xylan's board meets in California today to choose an investment banker for the company's initial public offering, its founders and employees are hoping that the similarities with Netscape will go still further. Judging by the interest on Wall Street, they may not be disappointed.

title: Long, Costly Prelude Does Little To Alter Plot of Presidential Race
description: Contenders for the White House in 1996 have already spent at least $60 million in by far the costliest run-up to a Presidential campaign in history, and one of the most energetic. Their television commercials have flickered for months in battleground states. In Iowa alone, candidates have collectively devoted a record 379 days to courting supporters.

title: Priest Prays for Croats' Return to 'Cleansed' Town
description: The Rev. Dujo Ljevar, his labored breathing sending out small puffs of cloud in the frigid air, moved heavily through the piles of brick and mortar that were once the Petricevac Roman Catholic Church.

title: Kohlberg Kravis in Swap for 7.5% of Fleet
description: The Fleet Financial Group said today that the investment firm of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company had exchanged its preferred stock holdings in Fleet for 19.9 million shares of common stock, giving it a 7.5 percent stake in the financial services concern.

title: Real Estate;Conrail raises some money by selling odds and ends of properties at auctions in  four cities.
description: CONRAIL, the freight railroad based here, expects to raise $4 million from recent auctions of surplus properties

description: To the Editor:

title: In an About-Face, U.S. Says Alcohol Has Health Benefits
description: In a new set of dietary recommendations, the Federal Government acknowledged for the first time today that consuming some alcohol can be healthful.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bakery Closing Affects 500
description: The Interstate Bakeries Corporation, the maker of Wonder Bread and Hostess snacks, said yesterday that it would close its 30-year-old East Brunswick bakery. The closing will affect about 500 bakery production employees, some of whom will be offered jobs at other company bakeries, Interstate said.

title: Yale Aides Withhold Grades In Bid to Lift Union's Profile
description: More than 200 graduate teaching assistants at Yale University have withheld grades from fall semester courses to pressure the university into recognizing their union, the union said yesterday. Yale officials said it would take several days to assess the extent of the grade strike and its effect on undergraduates.

title: Senate Sends a Bill to Pataki On Cases of Police Discipline
description: Reacting to a court ruling that forces the Legislature to send the Governor bills it passes, the State Senate sent him legislation today that would remove the New York City police commissioner as the final arbiter in discipline cases.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BEACON PROPERTIES TO BUY ATLANTA REAL ESTATE
description: The Beacon Properties Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire a suburban Atlanta office complex for $336 million from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company of New York and Taylor & Mathis, an Atlanta real estate developer. Under the deal, Beacon, a Boston real estate investment trust, would acquire 32 buildings in Perimeter Center. The company would also have the option to buy adjoining land to develop another 1.6 million square feet of office space. The purchase would increase Beacon's property holdings nearly 50 percent, to about 10 million square feet of space.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Larkin and Reds Agree On a 3-Year Extension
description: BARRY LARKIN, the National League's most valuable player, and the Cincinnati Reds agreed yesterday to a $16.5 million, three-year contract extension through 1999 with a club option for 2000 that could make the deal worth $21.2 million.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;It's Strength vs. Strength And 49ers vs. the Packers
description: All last week, the 49ers figured they would be playing host to dangerous Green Bay this Saturday. So, it was simple when San Francisco installed its defensive game plan for the National Football Conference divisional playoff game.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TYCO INTERNATIONAL SELLS BRANDS TO BEIERSDORF
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Curad and Futuro brands of bandages to Beiersdorf A.G. of Germany for $165 million. Tyco, based in Exeter, N.H., said it would make the products for Beiersdorf under a long-term deal. Tyco said the businesses had annual sales of more than $100 million. The German company is established in the consumer health care sector with its Nivea and Eucerin skin lotions in the United States. Tyco's stock was unchanged, at $35.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Food Afoot For the Homebound
description: The men and women who deliver food each day to 35 homebound elderly people in Jackson Heights, Queens, fill a need for friendship as well as nourishment. The recipients are widowed or ailing, or both, and are no longer able to cook. In this program, the food is carried on foot by volunteers, so they call it Meals-on-Heels. Boris Iskhakov, above, took lunch the other day to Rose Castellblanco, right and below. The service is run through the Catherine Sheridan Senior Center, which is supported by the Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens, an agency supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. SARAH JAY

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;One Man's Curry Is Another's Sore Throat
description: There are many ways to reproduce the flavors of an Indian curry. Adjust the sweet spices, like cardamom and cloves, according to your taste for them. Use a lot of hot pepper flakes, or not so many, depending on your penchant for spicy food.

title: Coptic Church in U.S. Receives a Bishop
description: Visiting 10,000 households would be a prodigious task for even the most enthusiastic politician or energetic salesman, but that is the promise Bishop Serapion of the Coptic Orthodox Church in Southern California has made to worshipers.

title: Murder Inquiry in Mexico Wanders in a Labyrinth
description: After nearly two years of national anguish and conflicting investigations by four different prosecutors, the case of the murdered Mexican presidential candidate is filled with more confusion, contradictions and bizarre theories than ever, undercutting confidence in the struggling Government that has pledged to solve the case.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Traffic Deaths Are Down
description: Traffic deaths this holiday season were down from last year, state police said yesterday. Three people died on New Jersey roads during the New Year's weekend, the same number who lost their lives during the Thanksgiving and Christmas weekends.

description: In percent

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Jeffrey S. Mahl was named senior vice president for advertising sales at ESPN, New York, a unit of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., succeeding Jack Bonanni, who left. Mr. Mahl was previously senior vice president for sales and marketing at OCC Sports Inc., New York, part of ESPN. Chris DuCharme was named to the new position of media services director at Capener, Matthews & Walcher, San Diego. She was previously senior vice president and managing director at Western International Media, San Diego, a unit of the Interpublic Group.

title: Apalachicola Journal;Hard Times Afflict an Oyster Capital
description: These days, Ronnie Davis harvests, shucks and hauls oysters to restaurants all by himself. He used to hire workers at his Davis Seafood here, but his sales in 1995 were down by half, and so his business is now down to one.

title: From 3 Percent Candidate to 100-Percent-Cotton Fashion Statement
description: So far, Lamarwear is selling better than Lamar.

title: Stocks Gain As New Year Starts Strong
description: The stock market started 1996 the same way it finished 1995 -- with general optimism and a price rally.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADT MANAGEMENT GROUP BUYS AUCTION BUSINESS
description: ADT Ltd. said yesterday that it had sold its vehicle auction operations in Europe to Integrated Transport Systems Ltd., which was formed by an ADT management group, for L209 million, or about $325 million. ADT, a provider of electronic-security and vehicle-auction services, received L151.4 million at the sale's closing and has been promised an additional cash payment of L5.9 million in 60 days. The company also received L51.3 million in loan notes as well as an equity interest in Integrated Transport. ADT said the sale would reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by 19 cents a share, which would also include an increase from the sale of Actron Group. In the 1994 fourth quarter, ADT's net income was $26.7 million, or 20 cents a share.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Deon van der Walt;A Perfect Marriage Of Wine and Opera
description: DEON VAN DER WALT is counting with his fingers.

title: Executive Changes
description: CELGENE CORP., Warren, N.J., named Richard Morgan acting chairman and chief executive. He succeeded Richard G. Wright, who retired.

title: Mexican Stocks Leap 5.4%, Injecting Optimism
description: The Mexican stock market began the new year with a roaring start today by closing at an all-time high, giving a jolt of optimism to an economy that spent 1995 in deep recession.

title: Impurity of Olive Oil Is Raising Concerns
description: OLIVE OIL is promoted for its healthful qualities. But increasingly, the oil people buy has been adulterated with cheaper oils, which may not have the same nutritional benefits.

title: Heiner Muller, the Playwright And Social Critic, Dies at 66
description: Heiner Muller, widely regarded as Germany's leading playwright, died on Saturday in a hospital in Berlin. He was 66 and had lived for years in the eastern part of that city.

title: Shrink National Guard But Keep It Effective
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Ex-Knick Is Charged
description: KENNY WALKER, a former All-American at Kentucky who played five years for the Knicks, was arrested yesterday after the police charged him with assault in the choking of his wife.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOUISIANA-PACIFIC NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation named Mark A. Suwyn, an executive at the International Paper Company, as its chairman and chief executive officer yesterday. Mr. Suwyn, 53, will replace Donald R. Kayser, a member of the wood products company's board of directors who has been serving as interim chairman and chief executive since the resignation of Harry Merlo on July 31. Mr. Merlo was forced out by the board while the company, which is based in Portland, Ore., was facing class-action lawsuits over faulty house siding, shareholder lawsuits, regulatory problems, a federal criminal investigation involving emissions at a Colorado plant, and a sexual harassment lawsuit against Merlo by a former executive secretary. Mr. Suwyn had been executive vice president at International Paper since 1992. He previously worked at E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. from 1967 to 1992.

title: Prenatal Genetic Testing Doesn't Slight Ethics
description: To the Editor:

title: As Tory Majority Slips, British Election Looms
description: After nearly 17 years in power, Britain's Conservative Party has seen its once unassailable majority in Parliament reduced to a razor-thin margin, increasing the odds that the Government will have to call an election well before its five-year term expires in April 1997.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Inquiry on Renault Chief
description: The French auto maker Renault S.A. said yesterday that its chairman, Louis Schweitzer, had been placed under formal investigation in connection with a political wiretapping scandal that dates to the mid-1980's. According to a company spokesman, Mr. Schweitzer was placed under investigation by a judge in early November. Mr. Schweitzer is expected to be questioned on the matter at the end of January. Mr. Schweitzer was chief aide to Prime Minister Laurent Fabius in the 1980's. Dow Jones

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Lower Despite Weak Data
description: The price of Treasury securities ended lower yesterday, despite signs that the manufacturing sector was somewhat weaker than the credit markets had expected. A lack of progress in the budget talks in Washington contributed to the price drop.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Turnpike Bonds Downgraded
description: Fitch Investors Service yesterday became the third rating agency in two weeks to downgrade New Jersey Turnpike Authority bonds.

title: Kuwait-China Oil Project
description: The Persian Gulf nation of Kuwait has awarded a $391 million contract to a Chinese company to build two oil-gathering centers. The contract was signed between the Kuwait Oil Company and the state-owned China Petroleum Engineering Construction Corporation. An official of the Kuwaiti concern said the two gathering centers, to be completed in a little less than three years, would add 410,000 barrels a day to production capacity.

title: Business Travel;The Plaza Hotel's new owners plan some changes, but they're not about to tamper  with success.
description: LUMINARIES from Bill Gates of Microsoft and Daniel Brestle of Clinique to Michael Jackson of Hollywood are Plaza fans. With a hotel icon like that worth owning, it was not much of a surprise when Prince Walid bin Talal of Saudi Arabia and CDL Hotels International Ltd. of Singapore snatched the Plaza, arguably America's best-known city hotel, from the jaws of Donald Trump last July. Now the Prince's Fairmont Hotels of San Francisco, which specializes in managing grand lodgings, is running the show.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE place is La Colombe d'Or, where the conversation between two waiters is heard by Wayne Nish, one of the owners. Waiter No. 1 is an immigrant Bengali who is raising a family and has been working at the restaurant a couple of years. Waiter No. 2 is a young American who is recently out of school and has just started working there.

title: Slowdown Goes On, Purchasers Say
description: The manufacturing sector slowed in December for the fifth consecutive month while prices that manufacturers paid fell to their lowest level in more than four years, the nation's purchasing managers said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Open Skies in France
description: The Italian airline Alitalia flew its first flights between French destinations yesterday as French skies opened to competition, ending a virtual monopoly by Air Inter. Under a law that took effect on Monday, all French airlines may fly domestic routes without restriction, in a dress rehearsal for deregulation in 1997, when airlines of one European Union state will be able to fly domestic routes in another. Foreign airlines also won the right to fly French routes, but the aircraft must continue on to a destination outside France. Reuters

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Film Magazine Editor to Lead Disney's Development Efforts
description: The Walt Disney Motion Pictures Group has named Susan Lyne, editor in chief and founder of Premiere: The Movie Magazine, to the newly created position of executive vice president for acquisitions and development of intellectual material and new opportunities.

title: Schools' Computers Stolen
description: At least 13 computers were stolen from three elementary schools over Christmas recess, and the school district's burglar alarm failed to detect two of the break-ins, a spokesman for the Newark school board said today.

title: JOB CUTS AT AT&T WILL TOTAL 40,000, 13% OF ITS STAFF
description: The AT&T Corporation announced the biggest single job cut in the history of the telephone business yesterday, and one of the largest corporate work-force reductions ever, as the company braces for a new wave of competition in the communications industry.

title: Nigeria, Critized Over Executions, Releases 6 Political Prisoners
description: Nigeria's military authorities freed six political detainees on New Year's Day, local newspapers and the News Agency of Nigeria said today.

title: FIESTA BOWL: THE BATTLE FOR NO. 1;CBS Team In Rhythm
description: You can invest $82 million over six years in the Fiesta Bowl, as CBS Sports has, and you can get a matchup of the No. 1 and No. 2 teams. You may snare the only meaningful bowl of the season, but you can't guarantee a close game.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, acquired the global custody business of J. P. Morgan & Co. for an undisclosed amount.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;The Original American: Early Manhattan Whore
description: THE DROWNING ROOM By Michael Pye 252 pages. Granta Books (Viking). $22.95

title: World News Briefs;Mubarak Names Premier In Major Cabinet Shuffle
description: President Hosni Mubarak replaced a Prime Minister today for the first time in nine years after parliamentary elections that opposition leaders denounced as fraudulent.

title: At the Nation's Table: Austin, Tex.;A Little Bakery That Could
description: Dan Leader's flagship Bread Alone Bakery, a 13-year-old operation in Boiceville, N.Y., supplies rustic, country-style breads to tony Manhattan stores like Balducci's and Dean & DeLuca. But Mr. Leader says he's "really just a very small artisan baker at heart."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Miscellany
description: Elizabeth Arden Co., New York, owned by Unilever N.V., has signed the model Linda Evangelista to represent its Red Door fragrance. A campaign, to be created in-house, is to start in April or May. TBWA International, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group, acquired Frederick & Valenzuela, Santiago, Chile, which was renamed Frederick & Valenzuela/TBWA. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Even With Peace and Rain, Ethiopia Fears Famine
description: Ethiopia's farmers recently finished harvesting the biggest crop the country has seen in a decade. The rains were plentiful and, most important, there was peace and stability.

title: Buying Snake Oil With Tax Dollars
description: It goes by different names now -- biofield therapeutics, mental healing, homeopathy -- but magic has been used to treat the sick throughout history. The shaman shakes his rattles, the faith healer lays on hands -- sometimes patients die, some make surprising recoveries. The only thing that has changed is that the "healers" of today apparently have the endorsement of the National Institutes of Health.

title: D. O. Graham, 70, Leading 'Star Wars' Architect
description: Lieut. Gen. Daniel O. Graham, one of the leading architects of President Ronald Reagan's "Star Wars" missile defense system, died on Sunday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 70.

title: In Italy, Some Anchovies Never Get the Chance to Bristle
description: AS often as not, the anchovy is seen as an intruder, its name often uttered with the preface, "Hold the. . . ."

title: COMPANY NEWS;MEDAPHIS BUYS MEDICAL MANAGEMENT SERVICES
description: The Medaphis Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Medical Management Sciences Inc. for about $149 million in stock, or four million shares. Medical Management, based in Baltimore, provides business management services to about 1,700 radiologists and radiation oncologists. Medaphis said that Medical Management had 1995 revenues of about $20.5 million and about $7.7 million in earnings before taxes. Shares of Medaphis, an Atlanta provider of business management services to physicians and hospitals, rose 25 cents, to $37.25 a share in Nasdaq trading.

title: 2 Chip Makers Take Battle To U.S. Court
description: Texas Instruments stock tumbled $3 a share today, to $48.50, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange as the company and Korea's Samsung Electronics said they were suing each other, accusing one another of patent infringement, after talks to renew a semiconductor license agreement broke down.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;With Fact In Service To Drama
description: In the course of guiding Charlie Rose through the shadows of Richard Nixon's mind Monday night on PBS, Oliver Stone also allowed a glimpse of the shadows in his own mind that have found their way into his movies, notably the newest, his much-discussed "Nixon."

title: FIESTA BOWL: THE BATTLE FOR NO. 1;No. 1 Nebraska Rumbles Down Path to Glory
description: The words had belonged to Tommie Frazier. "The one thing that can put all this to rest," the quarterback of the Nebraska Cornhuskers said near the end of a perfect but painfully controversial season, "is if we go out and win a championship."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T to Cut 40,000 Jobs And Take $6 Billion Charge AT&T announced that it would eliminate 40,000 of its 300,000 jobs -- mostly through layoffs -- over the next three years and charge $6 billion against earnings as it prepared to split into three companies. The goal is to compete better as technological change sweeps the industry. [Page A1.]

title: The Safety of 2 Classes of Cholesterol-Cutting Drugs Is Debated
description: TWO physician-researchers who previously questioned the economic and medical wisdom of universal cholesterol testing and treatment are now questioning the long-term safety of the leading cholesterol-lowering drugs.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Falcons Drop Ross
description: Atlanta Falcons strong safety KEVIN ROSS has been let go by Coach JUNE JONES, who said that Ross's public airing of his disagreements with the coach contributed to the decision.

title: Bosnian Officials Say Serbs Abducted 16 Near Sarajevo
description: The Bosnian Government accused Bosnian Serbs today of seizing at least 16 civilians traveling through Serbian-held suburbs, calling the abductions a "serious violation" of the Dayton peace agreement.

title: Papandreou's Own Party Frozen By Refusal to Address Succession
description: While Greece's 76-year-old Premier lay in a hospital on life support, politicians haggled today over his party's refusal to even discuss a successor.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Big East Conference

title: Faraya Journal;In Snow Country, the Lebanese Rise Above It All
description: From here the Mediterranean glistens nearly 8,000 feet below, and Lebanon's mountains stand a world apart from the rest of the Middle East.

title: Do Artificial Flavors Spoil Us For the Taste of Real Food?
description: THROUGHOUT the country, people are chewing watermelon gum, applying strawberry-flavor lip balms and eating fruit-flavored candies. At the movies, Americans munch popcorn drenched with artificial butter. And at the supermarket, there are so many flavored seltzers it is sometimes impossible to find the plain variety.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Tough-Guy Teacher With Cash To Spare
description: Having its premiere on CBS tonight, the series "Matt Waters" might best be described as "Room 222" with condoms. In other words, this schoolroom drama has been updated, although the general idea remains very much the same.

title: The Struggle Against Secrecy
description: Too little has been made of a landmark victory for open government. Hundreds of millions of classified documents will soon become public thanks to Executive Order 12958, which came into force Oct. 15 and requires the automatic declassification of most U.S. Government files more than 25 years old. The struggle against obsessive secrecy is far from over, but President Clinton has honored his promise to let more sunshine in. It has begun to shine even at the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: The Association of Independent Commercial Producers, New York, elected Frank Stiefel, president of Stiefel & Co., Hollywood and New York, as 1996 chairman. Frank Scherma, partner and head of the Hollywood office of @radical.media, becomes vice chairman.

title: What Balanchine Might Have Created For Stravinsky
description: Choreographic possibilities were far from Charles Wuorinen's mind in 1975, when he transformed a handful of musical fragments that Igor Stravinsky had left unfinished at his death into a rugged 17-minute orchestral work. Mr. Wuorinen's brief was to pay tribute to the Russian master, and in "A Reliquary for Igor Stravinsky," he surrounded the fragments with new music that drew on certain of Stravinsky's harmonic, rhythmic and orchestrational mannerisms.

title: Sports of The Times;No Suspense, No Debates, No Contest
description: THE first sign was the flood of red shirts swarming over the desert this week. There were vastly more red Nebraska shirts than orange-and-blue Florida shirts in the narrow, outdated thoroughfares and sprawling shopping centers of the Phoenix area.

title: Trying to Stay Off The Grounded List;The Problems of One Tiny Carrier Are Typical for Start-Up Airlines
description: Mark W. McDonald felt like a man accursed. Almost from the day he began to challenge giant USAir in the Northeast with his new airline, Nations Air, bad luck always seemed to strike on Fridays.

title: BASKETBALL;With Ewing Sitting, the Knicks Are Sliding
description: The first time Don Nelson unveiled a three-guard rotation to open a game he fooled everyone, the Knicks executed perfectly and won on the road in their opener. With Anthony Mason openly questioning his strategy last night and his team beginning the New Year at its nadir, how long ago that surprising and satisfying debut in Detroit seems.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL ENERGY TO ACQUIRE ALEXANDER ENERGY
description: National Energy Group said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to acquire the Alexander Energy Corporation in a stock deal valued at $129 million, including assumption of about $48 million in debt. The Dallas-based National Energy has offered 1.8 shares of its stock for each Alexander share. National's president and chief executive, Miles Bender, said the two companies' oil and gas reserves, mainly in the Midwest, were complementary. Alexander, which is 8.7 percent owned by the New York investor Carl C. Icahn, looks for and develops oil and gas deposits in Oklahoma and Arkansas. National Energy's stock fell 12.5 cents, to $3.375, while shares of Alexander, based in Oklahoma City, edged up 12.5 cents, to $4.688, in Nasdaq trading.

title: No More Myths About Prisoner Lawsuits
description: To the Editor:

title: SOFTBALL;Softball League of Their Own
description: Near the end of "A League of Their Own," the 1992 film about female baseball players during World War II struggling in a professional league in the Midwest, a proud father is buying tickets to the playoffs to see his daughter, the star player. "My daughter's playing third base," says the proud dad, "the best on the team."

title: Essex Chief to Enforce '78 Residency Law for County Employees
description: For more than 17 years, Essex County has had a law on the books requiring employees to live within the county, but nobody paid attention. Today, the County Executive announced that he plans to enforce that law, giving hundreds of full-time and part-time employees the choice of moving by July or losing their jobs.

title: Notebook;Rangers Reassembling Their Lineup
description: Ian Laperriere, as it turns out, is in the Ranger lineup. Mike Richter found out last night that he will be out four weeks. Mattias Norstrom already knew he will be sidelined for at least six weeks. Ulf Samuelsson will probably return this weekend.

title: Our 2 Cents' Worth
description: Almost exactly a year ago, Congress passed the Congressional Accountability Act, a much ballyhooed measure that requires the House and Senate to abide by the workplace and civil rights laws they enact for the rest of us. Alas, like so many things in life, this long-overdue legislation turns out to be less than meets the eye.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Bank Chief Is Indicted
description: The former chairman and chief executive of the defunct Action Savings Bank of Atlantic County was indicted yesterday on charges of having used a business associate as a front to obtain a $4.2 million loan for a development project fraudulently, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;$1.56 Billion Offer For Gambro of Sweden
description: Incentive A.B., a Swedish holding company, has offered to pay about 10.3 billion kronor ($1.56 billion) to become the sole owner of Gambro A.B., a medical equipment company specializing in renal care. Incentive, which already holds 42 percent of the capital and 58 percent of the votes in Gambro, offered 155 kronor ($23.47) for each B share. It will also buy the A shares held by several foundations controlled by the Crafoord family, descendants of Gambro's founder, at 170.50 kronor ($25.82) each.

title: Psychiatrists Call Suspect Incompetent
description: Psychiatrists have determined that a homeless man charged with sticking a 6-year-old girl with a hypodermic needle on a subway train last month is mentally unfit to stand trial, a Manhattan judge said yesterday.

title: Mourning a Firefighter As Questions Remain
description: As firefighters went through the familiar rituals that accompany the death of one of their colleagues, the Fire Department said that the Queens building where Lieut. John M. Clancy died had been deemed a potential hazard before Sunday's blaze. But word of that designation apparently never reached the city officials who could have taken action like sealing or demolishing the structure.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Impostor May Be Sued
description: University of Texas officials say they may sue to recover a $4,000 scholarship awarded to RON WEAVER, the 30-year-old who pretended to be 23 and played under an assumed name, The Austin American-Statesman reported yesterday. Federal authorities also want to question Weaver about his stint as a player under the name JOEL RON McKELVEY, the newspaper reported.

title: Why Deaths of Firemen Touch Public
description: Almost two years have passed since the tragedy at Ladder Company 5 in downtown Manhattan, but Lieut. Michael Warchola still fields sympathetic smiles and tender condolences from strangers on the street.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transcription error, a report in the Currents column in the Home section on Thursday about a yurt, a tentlike structure the size of a small house, misspelled the name of a professional mountain biker who built one from a kit on her property in Durango, Colo. She is Missy Giove, not Giobe.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a cameo appearance by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in "Die Fledermaus" at the Metropolitan Opera misstated the date of the performance in some editions. It took place Sunday night, not Monday.

title: Keep Moving on Jury Reform
description: Starting this week, many New Yorkers will get their first taste of jury duty. A new law that took effect with the new year has ended the state's undemocratic tradition of exempting a long list of privileged professions from this fundamental civil obligation. The list has grown absurdly, embracing not only surgeons, lawyers and police officers but optometrists, pharmacists, podiatrists, embalmers and people who fit artificial limbs.

title: In Some Classrooms, Old News Proves Far Livelier Than History
description: Forget the grocery checkout counter. To history fans, the nation's most exciting tabloid may be one published in a 150-year-old brick farm house on the fringe of Amish country in Pennsylvania.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: When It Comes to Oysters, Some People Can't Play Favorites
description: NOW is the moment for oysters: cold water means peak flavor, and the waters in the best beds are as cold as they get.

title: Amid Pomp, Nassau County Inaugurates Its Legislature
description: In a ceremony that looked much like a Republican convention, the new Nassau County Legislature was sworn in this morning by the same Federal judge who had ruled its predecessor unconstitutional.

title: RECORD EARNINGS, BUT LESS SHARING
description: American companies, though awash in profits in 1995, decided not to make large increases in their payments to shareholders and workers. Instead they plowed more money back into their businesses and set aside a lot for a rainy day.

title: BASKETBALL;Kittles's Plan Paying Off for Villanova
description: When college basketball stars make news by leaving school after one year or two, Kerry Kittles made bigger news by staying around for four.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Glaxo Wellcome, Research Triangle Park, N.C., to Grey Direct, New York, part of Grey Advertising, as the first agency to handle direct marketing for Flonase nasal spray and an asthma medication. The billings were not disclosed. Continental Cablevision Inc., Boston, to Mullen Advertising, Wenham, Mass., to handle brand development and the creation of a brand television campaign. Advertising will continue to be handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;7,000 Fewer Jobs at AT&T
description: The AT&T Corporation announced yesterday the biggest single job reduction in the history of the telephone business, saying it would dismiss 40,000 of its 300,000 employees in the next three years.

title: SOCCER;Firmani to Coach MetroStars
description: Eddie Firmani, the most successful coach in the history of the Cosmos, the most famous soccer team in the world two decades ago, will be named coach of the MetroStars of Major League Soccer today at a news conference at Giants Stadium. Firmani, a native of South Africa who played in Italy and England, coached the Cosmos to North American Soccer League championships in 1977 and 1978.

title: Vermeer Exhibition Finds a Sponsor
description: The National Gallery of Art said today that it had received a promise of enough private money to keep open its highly popular show of the paintings of the Dutch master Vermeer during the Federal shutdown.

title: Slovakia Is Committed to Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Defense Does the Trick for Sluggish Nets
description: It was not pretty, artistic or close to being the best that the National Basketball Association has to offer. The drive home on snowy roads probably provided more excitement for the 6,000 or so fans who bothered to show up for the game. But to the Nets, their 81-72 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks tonight was plenty sweet enough.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;British Renew a Love Affair With Sondheim
description: Side by side in London this season are two inventive revivals of Stephen Sondheim musicals from the early 1970's, "Company" at the Donmar Warehouse and "A Little Night Music" at the Royal National Theater. Both are major critical and popular successes.

title: The Time Bomb in Governor Whitman's Tax Cut
description: When her 1993 gubernatorial campaign was faltering only two months before Election Day, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman turned to Steve Forbes, her neighbor and childhood friend and now a Republican candidate for President, for help. His advice? Call for a 30 percent cut in state income taxes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Serino Coyne Buys Comora Associates
description: Serino Coyne Inc. in New York, an advertising and public relations agency, has acquired Owen Comora Associates, a public relations agency in New York. The terms were not disclosed. Comora will become a unit of Serino Coyne's public relations division and will continue to operate under the Comora name. Owen Comora, the president of Comora, will continue in that role, while Pamela Johnson will continue to be president of the Serino Coyne public relations division.

title: Baby Bells Could Link Up To Compete With AT&T
description: When AT&T sneezes, the rest of the telephone industry does not necessarily catch a cold. But when the industry leader announces it will cut 40,000 jobs, as it did yesterday, that ought to send a shiver through telephone operators and cable splicers everywhere.

title: Facing Takeover, Board in Roosevelt Closes Troubled Public SchoolSystem
description: The school board of Roosevelt, L.I., closed the system's rundown and troubled schools yesterday just hours before the State Board of Regents was to vote on whether to remove the board for failing to take even small measures to improve safety and instruction.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WILMA MANKILLER, the former principal chief of the Cherokee Nation, arrives at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H., today to begin a nine-week appointment as a scholar in residence. In addition to teaching women's studies, Native American studies and law, she plans to hold informal dinner discussions and will give a public address, "Will Native Americans Enter the 21st Century on Our Own Terms?," on Jan. 23. This schedule may provide something of a respite for her.

title: Arthur Rudolph, 89, Developer Of Rocket in First Apollo Flight
description: Arthur Rudolph, the developer of the giant Saturn 5 rocket, which launched a crew of American astronauts on the first manned flight to the moon in 1969, died on Friday after he lapsed into a coma at his home in Hamburg, Germany. He was 89.

title: Tax Forms Are Coming
description: Federal income tax forms should be arriving in taxpayers' mailboxes this week, the Internal Revenue Service said today. The mailing of the forms, which occurs every year at about this time, has not been affected by the partial Government shutdown resulting from the budget impasse between President Clinton and Congress, a spokesman for the I.R.S., Wilson Fadley, said.

title: Mixture of Rain and Snow Means More Sloppy Winter
description: Any hopes that the new year might see a respite from an already snowy winter were undermined by the arrival of a storm that threatened to dump several inches of new snow today on the suburbs north of New York City.

title: Benefits Would Justify Walking to Taxi Stand
description: To the Editor:

title: The I.C.C. Dies
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission, the oldest surviving Federal regulatory agency, died on New Year's Eve at the age of 108. The causes of death were the rigidities of age, confusion about its proper constituency and the climate of deregulation. Initially created to protect farmers and communities from the monopoly power of railroad barons, the I.C.C. later ganged up on the consumers it was supposed to protect, siding instead with the industries -- especially trucking -- that it was supposed to regulate.

title: Big 3 Dispute Challenge Over New-Car Costs
description: One of the nation's top experts on measuring consumer sentiment warned today that car buyers were more concerned about prices now than at any time in the last decade, but top economists of the Big Three auto makers dismissed his contention.

title: Save Allegany State Park
description: Allegany State Park covers 100 square miles in western New York State, just north of the Pennsylvania border. Established in 1921, it contains a unique blend of old-growth hardwoods, including stands of ancient cherry unmatched anywhere else in the country. The state's Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation, Bernadette Castro, is considering a plan to open the forest to commercial logging. A similar plan floated in 1982 was rejected after a public outcry. This one should be rejected as well.

title: News Summary
description: International A2-7

title: New Hazard of Drinking in Pregnancy Is Found
description: A study of women who drank alcohol during the last six months of pregnancy has found that their babies had a tenfold increased risk of developing leukemia during infancy.

title: Coram Officials to Return Stock Options
description: Seeking to accelerate a company turnaround, the Coram Healthcare Corporation said today that its chairman and directors would return stock options representing about 10 percent of the company's outstanding shares.

title: Democrats Unveil Plan For Utilities
description: The Democratic leadership of the State Assembly today announced a plan to introduce competition into the utility industry in the hope of eliminating regional monopolies across the state.

title: Lands' End Sells Unit
description: Lands' End Inc., the catalogue seller of clothing and home products based here, said today that it had sold Montbell America Inc., which makes outdoor clothing and equipment, to a subsidiary of Outdoor Industry Group Inc. Outdoor Industry, a privately held company in San Francisco, owns several companies that sell technology-based outdoor clothing and equipment through stores nationwide and through catalogues. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: College Assesses Limits of Its Free-Speech Wall
description: Twenty years ago, students at Pomona College, a small liberal arts institution east of Los Angeles, began scrawling and painting their passions on a gray cinder-block wall, turning what had been built as a flood barrier into a free-speech forum and public art display.

title: At the Nation's Table: San Francisco;France and Japan Meet in a Bistro
description: When the chef Elka Gilmore left San Francisco for New York City (she's now executive chef at the Omni Berkshire Place on East 52d Street), the assumption was that the restaurant that bore her name, Elka, would roll over and die. But it is doing just fine under Michael (Lev) Leviton.

title: A New Teacher Struggles On In Newark;Challenges of Classroom Unchanging in Takeover
description: When Merrill S. Sgromolo learned that he was being downsized out of his insurance job last year, he decided to return to his first love: teaching public school. He stood in line among 1,400 other anxious candidates at a teacher jobs fair in August and was among 214 people hired by the Newark public schools. His assignment was to tutor remedial students in a high school wedged between a cemetery and a central Newark neighborhood.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CAMERON MACKINTOSH, the theatrical producer, became Sir Cameron and ELTON JOHN, the singer, and NICOLAS ROEG, the film director, became Commanders of the Order of British Empire when Queen Elizabeth II announced her New Year's honors list.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Favre Is the Straw That Stirs America's Dairyland
description: He walked into the news conference with a bright smile, that signature stubble on his face, eager to share his thoughts. This was a special day for Brett Favre, the swashbuckling quarterback with the rifle arm and the fancy footwork. He was meeting with reporters to talk about his latest accomplishment.

title: FILM REVIEW;The Life and Times of a Doomed Warhol Superstar
description: As sad as it is to watch someone endowed with beauty, talent and intelligence go down in flames, there is also something darkly reassuring in the drama of a golden being who willfully self-destructs. That voyeuristic fascination with doomed glamour is one of the guilty pleasures of Susanne Ofteringer's utterly haunting documentary film, "Nico Icon." Examining the unhappy life of Christa Paffgen, the German singer, songwriter, model and occasional actress who reinvented herself as Nico, the film locates the void at the heart of modern demi-celebrity.

title: At the Nation's Table: Chicago;Where's the Beef In Doubt No More
description: The lunchtime crunch starts shortly before noon at Mr. Beef on Orleans, just east of the Kennedy Expressway on the western edge of Chicago's River North gallery district. It's an eclectic, largely male crowd, and the dress code is as casual as the service.

title: Forte Moves To Thwart Granada Bid
description: Forte P.L.C., the British hotel company, began a further, aggressive effort today to thwart a hostile takeover bid by the Granada Group.

title: TV SPORTS;In the ABC Booth It's Also No Contest Between No. 1 and No. 2
description: Any measure of the qualitative abyss between ABC's No. 1 and No. 2 college football announcing pairings must include Exhibits A and B, from Monday:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Time Life Names President and Chief
description: Time Life Inc., the direct marketing unit of Time Inc. that sells books, videotapes and recorded music, yesterday named George Artandi to be president and chief executive. He will be based in New York and will continue as president and chief executive of another Time Inc. division, the Book-of-the-Month Club.

title: Crazy for You' Closing
description: Crazy for You," Ken Ludwig's Tony-winning musical with songs by George and Ira Gershwin, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street in Manhattan. The current leads in the show, which was directed by Mike Ockrent, are James Brennan, Karen Ziemba, Pia Zadora and Ann B. Davis. At its closing, the show will have had 1,622 regular performance and 21 previews.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;More Shellfish Harvesting
description: Cleaner coastal waters have enabled the state to open 817 more acres of ocean and bays for shellfish harvesting, officials announced yesterday.

title: TENNIS;Seles Is Set For Her '96 World Tour
description: Girded by three months of innovative physical therapy prescribed by her orthopedist, Dr. Richard Steadman, and with her mental mettle tweaked whenever necessary by Jerry May, her sports psychologist, Monica Seles, has pronounced herself ready for a full-time leap back onto the tennis circuit in 1996.

title: BASKETBALL;Mason Is Searching for Answers
description: Don Nelson has been mainly responsible for giving Anthony Mason life on the basketball court this season. The Knicks' forward, who leads the league in playing time with 44 minutes a game, is grateful for that. But he does not understand what his coach is conjuring up during the club's slump.

title: Former Interior Secretary Avoids Trial With a Guilty Plea
description: Former Interior Secretary James G. Watt pleaded guilty today to a single misdemeanor charge of trying to influence a Federal grand jury, thus avoiding a trial on 18 perjury and influence-peddling felony charges arising from his activities as a private housing consultant.

title: Old Acquaintance, Now Best Forgot
description: REMEMBER the fate of the kiwi? There was nothing inherently wrong with the once-novel fruit, but at one point in the 1980's it became so omnipresent it invited ridicule.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JOHNSON & JOHNSON GETS NEW PRODUCT APPROVAL
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it had won approval from the Food and Drug Administration to sell Renova, a prescription skin cream to reduce wrinkles, pigmentation and dryness in skin overexposed to the sun. It was developed by the Ortho Pharmaceutical Corporation, a Johnson & Johnson unit. Johnson & Johnson, based in New Brunswick, N.J., has made a big push into dermatology products in recent years, including the $924 million acquisition of the Neutrogena Corporation in 1994.

title: Bell's Palsy Is Linked With Herpes Infection
description: USING highly refined genetic techniques, medical researchers in Japan have identified the common cold sore virus, herpes simplex, as the likely cause of most cases of Bell's palsy, a debilitating facial paralysis for which there is currently no specific treatment.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Reeves Puts Cards On Table To Owners
description: The Giants' ownership and Coach Dan Reeves met yesterday afternoon to discuss the issues that have irritated Reeves and could cause a messy situation for the team. Before now, it seemed there was little doubt that an accommodation would be reached and Reeves would stay on.

title: World News Briefs;Drug Operation Seized By 1,500 Burmese Troops
description: About 1,500 Burmese troops have taken over the jungle headquarters of the leader of a drug operation in the opium-growing Golden Triangle, but the whereabouts of the man are not clear, civilian sources in town said today.

title: No Headline
description: In my personal view wine with meals in moderation is beneficial." -- DR. PHILIP LEE, of the Department of Health and Human Services. [C2:1]

title: Eating, Over the Last Million Years or So
description: THE evolution of the world's eating habits is documented in "The Food Chronology" by James Trager (Henry Holt, $40). Half the book is devoted to the 20th century, but the more compelling entries predate 1950.

title: Backing Natural Cures
description: The County Council in Seattle is setting up the nation's first government-subsidized natural medicine clinic. Page A10.

title: Ruling Expands Women's Roles in the Israeli Military
description: The image of the Israeli Army woman, in fatigues and sometimes carrying a gun, has long been viewed around the world as a sign of equality in the only country that drafts women as well as men.

title: S.E.C. Allows Priests' Bid for Vote on Nabisco Spinoff
description: In a tersely worded opinion supporting two small orders of Roman Catholic priests, the Securities and Exchange Commission has rejected an attempt by the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation to block their proxy resolution, which calls for a rapid spinoff of the company's food business from its tobacco operations.

title: Kerkorian's Plan for Chrysler: Buy Back $2 Billion a Year
description: Kirk Kerkorian's campaign for the Chrysler Corporation to give more cash back to shareholders called today for the auto maker to buy back $2 billion of its stock annually until the next recession.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOBIL PLANS TO LAY OFF 500 WORKERS AT U.S. UNIT
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that its Mobil Exploration and Producing United States unit would lay off about 500 workers by March 31 as part of a larger reorganization. The layoffs represented 15 percent of Mobil Exploration and Producing's work force of about 3,300 employees in 10 states and offshore in the Gulf of Mexico. The reorganization is expected to reduce fourth-quarter earnings by $21 million, Mobil said. In the 1994 fourth quarter, Mobil reported net income of $523 million. Mobil Exploration and Producing currently operates about 260 oilfields and gas fields in the United States and in the Gulf of Mexico.

title: The Customer's Right
description: To The Living Section:

title: Possible I.R.A. Front Claims Ulster Killing
description: A group suspected of being an I.R.A. front claimed responsibility today for the fatal shooting of a man as he sat in a car with his girlfriend southwest of Belfast.

title: 2 Daytime Talk Shows Are Canceled
description: Two daytime talk shows were canceled yesterday, the second and third since just before Christmas.

title: Journal;Angry White Woman
description: Tanya Melich began her Republican political career as a child, passing out leaflets for Wendell Willkie in her hometown of Moab, Utah. At the '92 G.O.P. Convention, she was a Bush delegate from New York. In between she's held almost every political job she could, short of running for office. "I cannot remember a time when the Republican Party was not part of my life," she writes in the opening sentence of a new book that Bantam is shipping to stores next week. She then goes on to explain just why she has bid the Republican Party goodbye.

title: INSIDE
description: Ex-Official Pleads Guilty

title: Younger Fingers Knit One, Purl Two
description: KNITTING, an activity that faded during the 1970's and 1980's, is coming back, especially among younger people.

title: Mother Charged in Assault Of Girl Found With Burns
description: The police have arrested the mother of a 7-year-old Brooklyn girl after a relative reported finding the child alone in an apartment, bruised and burned by cigarettes, officials said yesterday.

title: Personal Health
description: AMERICANS have a passion for trying to fix things with a pill. Many millions take pills daily to lower their blood pressure or their cholesterol levels. Millions more swallow vitamins and minerals and "nutritional" supplements in the hope of remaining healthy or slowing the progress of disease. And many believe that the pills will somehow render them immune to the damage wrought by unhealthy habits.

title: BASKETBALL;Jaspers' Center Is Sidelined
description: Manhattan College, which lost its senior starting guards, Ted Ellis and Keaton Hyman, for the remainder of the season when they were suspended last month for disciplinary reasons, was dealt another major setback on Monday when its starting center, Justin Phoenix, injured two fingers on his shooting hand.

title: World News Briefs;New Fighting in Liberia Threatens Cease-Fire
description: Fighting flared again in western Liberia today after a day-long truce in battles between guerrillas and African peacekeeping units trying to maintain a fragile accord to end years of civil war.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A New Age music company feels good about a campaign intended to give it a new image.
description: DEPENDING on your appreciation for Celtic melodies, synthesizers and piano solos, New Age is either soothing mood music for the millennium or the aural equivalent of a tepid bath. Now the company most closely identified with the genre is hoping to change its image.

title: Silicon Graphics' Stock Falls on Profit Outlook
description: Shares in Silicon Graphics Inc. tumbled 16 percent today after the company said it expected to report lower earnings for its fiscal third quarter.

title: A Store Manager Is Slain And 2 Men Are Wounded
description: A disgruntled former employee of an auto parts supplier entered his old workplace this morning and opened fire with an assault-style shotgun, killing the manager who had demoted him last year and wounding two other workers before wounding himself with a blast to the abdomen, the Westchester County District Attorney said.

title: Prenatal Genetic Testing Doesn't Slight Ethics;The Safe Thalidomide
description: To the Editor:

title: Civilian Effort for Peace In Bosnia Seen Lagging
description: While troops and equipment from NATO armies have been rolling into place under tough conditions in Bosnia, the civilians in charge of making peace meaningful through the rebuilding of daily life and political institutions have been conspicuously absent.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Casino Called Mixed Blessing
description: Mayor Fred Wager, who wants to bring casino gambling to this economically depressed city, says he is unfazed by a report suggesting that it could be a mixed blessing.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Falk Begins Talks as Anderson's Agent
description: Whether Kenny Anderson will remain with the Nets is as uncertain as it ever was. But at least now that David Falk has officially signed on as his agent, there promises to be some order to the negotiations instead of the chaos that has existed for the last month.

title: French Agency Accuses Rwanda of Theft
description: A French aid agency expelled from Rwanda last week accused Rwanda's army today of stealing the agency's vehicles, equipment and medicine.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;BBDO Wins Review For Paint Brands
description: ICI Paints in Slough, England, said yesterday that it had named BBDO Worldwide as worldwide agency of record for the two ICI international paint brands, Dulux and Glidden. The billings were estimated at $46.5 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. SHARES OF INSIGNIA SOLUTIONS FALL 55%
description: The shares of Insignia Solutions Inc. dropped 55 percent after the software company said that because of weak sales in the United States it had only broken even in the fourth quarter. American depository receipts of the British company fell $7.3125 yesterday, to $5.9375, in Nasdaq trading. Insignia said its fourth-quarter revenue was "significantly below" the third quarter's $16.3 million. Insignia writes programs that allow Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computers to run software written for the Microsoft Corporation's Windows operating system. Insignia, which has administrative offices in Mountain View, Calif., had an initial public offering in November.

title: Milwaukee Prelate Reaches the Top And Keeps Reaching
description: He certainly doesn't need the degree. At 68, as the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Milwaukee, Rembert Weakland has reached the top of his calling. Oh, there was talk for a time that he might become the first American Pope, but don't bet on that now that he has become one of the most eloquent spokesmen for the liberal wing of American Catholic bishops, a frequent thorn in the side of the Vatican establishment.

title: NATO Presses Serbs To Release Civilians
description: A day after denying that NATO had a responsibility to address the issue, NATO officers visited Ilidza, a Serbian-held suburb of Sarajevo, to press officials to release up to 18 Bosnian citizens who have been detained by the Bosnian Serbs.

title: No Headline
description: Democrats have always claimed that we wouldn't take control of the courthouse till hell freezes over. As you may have noticed, it is snowing." STATE REPRESENTATIVE JOHNNY L. CURRY, as 10 Alabama judges defected to the Republican Party. [A14:3.]

title: Dan Dorfman Is Dismissed By Magazine Over Sources
description: Money magazine announced yesterday that it had dismissed Dan Dorfman, the magazine's celebrity financial columnist, because he refused to confide to his editor the identity of the confidential sources cited in columns published in the magazine.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD;An Organized Life, Byte by Megabyte
description: SO it's the first week of the new year, and you have vowed to get organized. Really organized this time.

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTERNATIONAL PAPER PLANS TO ELIMINATE 1,300 JOBS
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that it would cut 1,300 jobs in the United States and Europe, resulting in a $70 million pretax charge against fourth-quarter earnings. The eliminated jobs represent 1.9 percent of International Paper's 70,000 employees at the end of 1994. George Adler, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc. in New York, said the moves by International Paper, the world's largest forest-products company, might be a response to reduced demand and lower prices for paper and cardboard boxes. The charge will reduce earnings by 17 cents a share, according to the company, which is based in Purchase, N.Y. A survey of 14 analysts by Zacks Investment Research before the announcement estimated that International Paper would earn $1.22 a share in the quarter.

title: A Copper Trader Is Charged in Chile
description: Chilean authorities brought tax fraud charges today against a former copper trader whose money-losing trades cost the Government's copper company, Codelco, about $175 million in losses in 1993.

title: Currents;With Tongue In Cheek
description: WHIMSY seems to be the new directive for lighting fixtures. Tom Johnson, an artist in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, concocts original shades for friends in the restaurant business, then sells copies to the public. The series he designed for Food Bar in Chelsea is called "Skyline Cruise," because each shade is in the shape of a New York skyscraper (the Chrysler Building, left, is $150). The shades simply clip on to light bulbs.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Airbus Sells 9 Jets To GATX, a U.S. Leaser
description: Airbus Industrie announced yesterday that it had sold nine A321-200 jets to the GATX Capital Corporation, a leasing company in Los Angeles, for $580 million. The planes are to be delivered in 1997, according to Airbus, a consortium of companies from four European nations. A day earlier, Airbus announced that Yemen Airways had bought two Airbus A310 planes.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Feeding of Pigeons Upheld
description: It is illegal here to do anything that "may become an annoyance or interfere with the comfort or general well-being of the inhabitants." But that does not mean you can stop someone from feeding pigeons, an appellate court ruled yesterday. Joan Guidi challenged the ordinance in 1994 after getting a summons for feeding pigeons. Her challenge was rejected by a municipal judge, but the appeals court agreed that the law as written was vague and overly broad, The Associated Press reported. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Palestinian Authority Detains Outspoken Critic for 24 Hours
description: An outspoken Palestinian critic of human rights violations by the Palestinian Authority was detained for 24 hours and then released late tonight by Palestinian security forces in the West Bank town of Ramallah.

title: Spreading Their Faith Wherever It Leads;Catholic Laity Is Increasingly Replacing Priests and Nuns as Missionaries
description: When Phyllis Lanier Sturtevant was 7, her parents took her to the Maryknoll missionaries' center on a leafy hilltop here and photographed her sitting under "the sending bell," the 13th-century Japanese gong that tolled farewell to priests and nuns heading overseas to win souls for the Roman Catholic Church.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Conoco in Venture For Vietnam Refinery
description: Petronas, Malaysia's state oil company, and Houston-based Conoco Inc. will take a 30 percent stake in a $1.2 billion Vietnamese refinery, Petronas officials said yesterday. The project will be at Dung Quat Bay, south of Danang, and will have a capacity of 130,000 barrels a day. The project is scheduled to be completed by 2000.

title: PATAKI'S MESSAGE: REACTION;Who Gets The Credit? Views Differ
description: Gov. George E. Pataki, who swept into office last year pledging to transform state government, said today that he had succeeded. He took credit for reducing crime, providing the biggest tax cuts in the nation, creating new jobs and removing tens of thousands of people from the welfare rolls.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUSA REPORTS 10% INCREASE IN SAME-STORE SALES
description: CompUSA Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter sales surpassed those of the corresponding period last year. The company, a computer retailer based in Dallas, said same-store sales for the quarter that ended on Dec. 23 rose 10.5 percent from a year ago. CompUSA, which operates 95 computer superstores, said the same-store figures referred to sales at the 80 stores open for more than a year. The company said total sales for the quarter increased 22 percent, to $931 million, from $762 million a year ago. The company's shares rose 75 cents yesterday, to $33.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS -- In West Texas;Closing Creates Texas-Sized Detour
description: Tom Buck's long-haul delivery route has become longer, and leaner, with the Federal shutdown.

title: Hospital to Release Patient Who Received Baboon Cells
description: The man who received a highly risky experimental bone marrow transplant from a baboon three weeks ago is expected to be discharged from a hospital in San Francisco today, his doctors said.

title: The Audio Book: A New Script for Actors
description: Larry McMurtry's novel "Dead Man's Walk" presents a densely populated world, which means the reader has the pleasure of meeting lots of new faces. For Will Patton, who read the novel for the audiotape version, the book was an actor's decathlon. "I was doing, I think, 57 characters, everything from little Scottish boys to Indian women," he said, describing the recording session. "There was one point where seven characters were talking to each other, none of them like me, and I stopped and said, 'This is insane.' "

title: Top Leader of the Bosnian Serbs Now Under Attack From Within
description: The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, is increasingly reviled and isolated among the one million Serbs he rules. Opposition figures and members of his own party have begun to denounce the war and the political leadership that directed it with an open ferocity that would have been unthinkable before the Dayton peace agreement.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Acquisition by Wavephore
description: Wavephore Inc. has acquired Mainstream Data Inc. for $31 million, consisting of $20 million cash and $11 million in stock. Mainstream Data had revenues of about $16 million last year, Wavephore's chairman and chief executive, David Deeds, said. Wavephore, based in Tempe, Ariz., develops technology for high-speed wireless data broadcasting.

title: Note Found at a Blast Site Hints Victim Was the Wrong Man
description: A note found at the scene of a bomb explosion here that injured an Episcopal priest has opened the possibility that the bomb was planted in error and that the target may have been a retired Federal agent who lived across the street.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: Holiday Tournaments

title: John Hancock Pays a Fine For Improper Sales Practices
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company has paid a $1 million fine to the New York State Insurance Department for a variety of improper advertisements and sales practices, the insurance department said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Gullikson Stays On as Coach
description: TOM GULLIKSON, who captained the United States to the Davis Cup title in 1995, will stay on the job another year. His reappointment was announced yesterday by the United States Tennis Association. The team opens defense of its title against Mexico Feb. 9-11 in Carlsbad, Calif. (AP)

title: After Court Order, Madonna Faces Accused in Stalker Case
description: Under a court order the singer and actress Madonna appeared in criminal court here today to testify in the trial of a man accused of stalking her.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ford Motor Venture Picks Site in India
description: The Ford Motor Company and Mahindra & Mahindra Ltd. of India have chosen the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu as the site of their planned multimillion-dollar plant to make Ford Fiestas, a Mahindra executive said yesterday.

title: AT HOME WITH: Edye Smith;To Rise Again From a Life in Ruins
description: SHE has received more than 10,000 letters since April 19, even the ones addressed to "The Red-Headed Lady I Saw on TV" and "The Mother Whose Blond Boys Were Killed in the Bombing." But not everyone knows Edye Smith.

title: HOUSE PROUD;Little House On the Brownstone
description: WITH name-brand folks like Tom Brokaw, Ralph Lauren and Jane Fonda all homesteading the wide open spaces of the Old West, what's a famous film maker in search of seclusion to do but put up his log cabin right in the heart of New York City?

title: A New Level of Tolerance for Adultery
description: NEARLY everyone talks about it and reads about it. More than half of all married men and more than one-third of married women in America claim they are guilty of it.

title: Essay;Stop the Giveaway
description: Television is going to be replaced by digivision. If the powerful broadcasters' lobby gets its way, media giants would be given tens of billions of dollars of the public airwaves free, while the individual viewer would be forced to junk his old television set and buy a new digivision set.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;HOUSE LAWMAKERS REJECT DOLE PLAN TO REOPEN OFFICES
description: As the Federal budget crisis plodded into a fourth month and a Government shutdown passed its 19th day, neither with any clear sign of resolution, Republicans in Congress descended further into a squabble over tactics today. And President Clinton moved quickly to exploit it.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELAINE PAIGE, who has had leading roles in Sir Andrew Lloyd Webber's shows for more than 15 years, will be the next Norma Desmond in the Broadway production of "Sunset Boulevard," the Press Association reported yesterday in London. Miss Paige, who is playing the role in London, will succeed BETTY BUCKLEY here starting on Sept. 5.

title: Nikkei Surges As Dollar Rises
description: Stocks surged here today, starting the year with a 3 percent rally to a 16-month high, as the dollar's climb against the Japanese yen brightened the outlook for exporters' earnings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: BASKETBALL;Exhausted Orangemen Fall Again
description: Syracuse's basketball team has been on the road since Dec. 23, including a trip to Hawaii, and tonight's stop was perhaps the most sobering. The unheralded Miami Hurricanes broke open a close game down the stretch to beat the Orangemen, 75-66, at Miami Arena.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Corrections
description: A picture with a theater review on Monday about "True Crimes" by Romulus Linney was published in error in some copies. It showed three people in a scene from the play, but the caption named two other people from the play. The three were Rebecca Harris, at left, and Fred Burrell, with Cheryl Haas standing behind them. In a later edition, that picture was replaced with a picture showing only two people. The man was identified correctly as David Johnson, but the woman was misidentified. She is Cheryl Haas, not Christine Parks.

title: HOCKEY;After a Tuneup, Ferraro Plays Like a Ferrari
description: Maybe it was only a warning from Coach Colin Campbell, a wake-up call of sorts. Whatever it was, it worked -- and the Rangers are now unbeaten in their last 18 games at home.

title: World News Briefs;At Least 20 Afghans Die As Rockets Hit Capital
description: Rockets that struck a southwestern suburb of Kabul on Tuesday killed at least 20 people, many of them children, witnesses and hospital officials said today. At least 48 others were wounded.

title: Arthur Spear, Who Led Mattel Through Fiscal Crises, Dies at 75
description: Arthur S. Spear, who as chairman of Mattel Inc. led the company, widely known for its line of Barbie dolls, through two crises, died on Sunday at the U.C.L.A. Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 75.

title: Wild Theory In a Slaying Dies in Mexico
description: A federal agent implicated in a wild theory that he assassinated the governing party's presidential candidate nearly two years ago and then himself was murdered showed up today in Mexico City and denied that he had been anywhere near the scene of the shooting in Tijuana on March 23, 1994.

title: The Ripple Grows
description: The budget impasse is leaving offices closed, phones unanswered and private contractors edgy.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the man accused of stabbing a girl with a hypodermic needle on the subway misidentified the judge in the case. She is Acting State Supreme Court Justice Laura E. Drager, not Barbara Newman, who is a Criminal Court judge in Manhattan.

title: L.B.J.'s 'Balanced' Budget Hid Deficits
description: To the Editor:

title: Prosecutor Tries to Make Trooper Talk On Tampering
description: Saying that a New York State trooper has withheld information about an evidence-tampering scandal, a special prosecutor has gone to court to try to force the trooper to cooperate with his inquiry.

title: POP REVIEW;A Mix of 6 Distinct Identities
description: The Blue Note All Stars' first set at Sweet Basil on Tuesday bristled with unpolished intelligence. Tunes changed meter, and in their harmonies and tempos they made the soloists work to sustain momentum. While the music never quite jelled, it was apparent that something good would be happening by the time the band went into the recording studio after the end of its stay at the club on Sunday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wells Rich Settles With Former Officer
description: For the second time in three weeks, Wells Rich Greene BDDP Communications in New York and a former top executive have reached an agreement settling their differences.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EUROPEAN AMERICAN BUYS LEASING COMPANY
description: European American Bank said yesterday that it had acquired the American Equipment Leasing Company, a leasing and finance company, for more than $200 million. The acquisition is part of a strategy by the bank, a unit of the Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding N.V., to expand its lending business by acquiring finance and leasing companies. European American, based in Uniondale, L.I., said the price included cash and the repayment of outstanding debt held by American Equipment, which is based in Reading, Pa.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: CHRONICLE
description: The audience at LEONIE RYSANEK's farewell performance on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera simply could not bear to let the soprano go. Applauding and chanting "LE-O-NIE," her admirers lured her back for more than 40 minutes of ovations after the curtain fell on Tchaikovsky's "Queen of Spades." They showered her with so many bouquets that she could barely step around them.

title: A Doctor Sees Hope for 'Hopeless' Patients
description: Doctors use a hopeless-sounding phrase for patients who are unconscious for more than a year: "permanent vegetative state."

title: FOOTBALL;Fiesta Ratings Boost CBS
description: Nebraska's 62-24 thrashing of Florida in Tuesday's Fiesta Bowl produced an 18.8 Nielsen national rating, leading CBS to a rare prime-time victory.

title: BASKETBALL;Rutgers Is Routed by B.C.
description: Rutgers Coach Bob Wenzel wasn't sure those were his Scarlet Knights who got steamrolled by Boston College, 95-67, tonight at Louis Brown Athletic Center.

title: A $2.50 Federal Case?
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.S. Draws Criticism for Delays
description: As the new tax-filing season begins, the Internal Revenue Service has been criticized by the General Accounting Office for last year's performance, being cited for delayed refunds and unanswered telephone calls.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;France Telecom Files Claim Against Poland
description: France Telecom, which owns 24.5 percent of the Polish cellular phone company PTK Centertel, accused Poland yesterday of breaching an agreement by denying it the right to obtain a license to provide digital cellular services. The French state-owned telephone company filed a notification of arbitration with the International Court in The Hague and estimated the "fair level of compensation" at $500 million. France Telecom contends it was promised a license to operate mobile systems.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS;Paralysis Brought On by Shutdown Begins to Seep to the Private Sector
description: As the Federal Government wound through the 19th day of its partial shutdown, effects of the budget impasse rippled across the country, closing state unemployment offices in Kansas, leaving complaints about workplace safety unanswered and causing the Environmental Protection Agency to suspend clean up operations at scores of toxic waste dumps.

title: David Weadon, 39, Liturgical Organist
description: David Weadon, an organist, conductor and teacher who specialized in liturgical music, died on Saturday at the Robert Wood Johnson Hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 39 and had homes in Manhattan and Freehold, N.J.

title: Storm Brought Little Snow, but Woe for Drivers and Teachers
description: The storm that ended yesterday was nothing spectacular in terms of snow or cold, but it left a crust of ice that hobbled transportation, put a strain on families and just possibly made it harder for schoolchildren to absorb history and geometry.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS -- In Kansas;No More Benefits For Unemployment
description: The Kansas Department of Human Resources, which distributes unemployment benefits across the state, put up signs on Tuesday at its eight district offices saying the offices would be closed until further notice, "due to the impasse in Washington." As a result, many out-of-work Kansans wanting to collect their unemployment checks are out of luck.

title: Babe' Is Chosen as Best Film By National Society of Critics
description: Babe," the popular family film about a plucky little pig who rebels against his assigned role in barnyard society and insists on a being a sheep dog, was named the best film of 1995 by the National Society of Film Critics yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Drive Spreads as 10 Alabama Judges Jump Parties
