description: In a region where courthouse politics has long been dominated by Democrats, 10 Birmingham judges today underscored the depth of political realignment in the South by staging a dramatic mass defection to Alabama's Republican Party.

title: Richmond Journal;Integration Must Wait On Dixie Heroes Avenue
description: The old Confederate capital, which hobbled Arthur Ashe on his road to glory, had hoped to reclaim him with a grand monument saluting both his tennis triumphs and the humanitarian and scholarly pursuits of his later days. But two years after Mr. Ashe's death, Richmond seems to have bungled that effort.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Up as Traders Seek Information
description: Expectations of a breakthrough in the Federal budget impasse were a principal factor in lifting the prices of Treasury securities yesterday, as the market, lacking hard economic data from the Government, searched for other sources of usable information.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Toshiba Introduces New CD Player Line
description: Toshiba America Consumer Products, a unit of the Toshiba Corporation of Japan, said yesterday that it would introduce the first two next-generation compact disk players today.

title: Gingrich Revolution Gives Polluters a Rebate on Cleanup Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Alcohol Found in Pilot's Remains in Colombia
description: Laboratory tests on the body of the captain of the American Airlines 757 that crashed near Cali, Colombia, on Dec. 20 found alcohol in the remains, the Federal Aviation Administration said early this morning, but it was not immediately clear whether the source was liquor or chemical processes that could have occurred after death.

title: SOCCER;Same Zip Code for Firmani But With a Different Team
description: Eddie Firmani returned to Giants Stadium this morning, brandishing the ring he earned as coach of the Cosmos in Soccer Bowl '77 and brimming with confidence over the challenge of being the first coach of the MetroStars of Major League Soccer.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Murderer Sues Jail and Wins
description: A man convicted of kidnapping and strangling a 9-year-old girl was recently awarded $21,250 after he sued the Cape May County Correctional Center for inadequately treating his ulcer and other medical problems in the early 1990's, his lawyer said yesterday. Kenneth E. Querns, who legally changed his name to Ken Mann, accused the jail's doctor, John J. Napoleon, of denying him medications for an ulcer that had been diagnosed before he was incarcerated, said his lawyer, Fredric Gross of Mount Ephraim. Mr Mann is serving a 45-year Sentence in Trenton State Prison for the 1991 murder of Samantha Jean Russ of Ocean City.

title: 6 Dead in New Delhi In Bombing Claimed By Kashmiri Rebels
description: At least 6 people were killed and 31 injured when a bomb exploded today in a crowded bazaar in New Delhi.

title: GOLF;On and Off the Course, Fine Time for Norman
description: Professional golf, the seemingly seamless season, begins again this week here at La Costa Resort and Spa with the Mercedes Championships (formerly the Tournament of Champions) for 1995 tournament winners only. Corporate sponsors might come and go -- wasn't it just yesterday that the very appropriate title of this tournament was the MONY Tournament of Champions -- but there is a comfortable sameness to the rhythms here at this hedonistic hideout for the buffed, fluffed and extremely well-heeled.

title: Executive Changes
description: JAMES RIVER CORP., Richmond, the maker of paper products including Brawny paper towels and Dixie paper cups, named Miles L. Marsh, its president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman. He succeeds Robert C. Williams, co-founder, who retired on Dec. 31 and will continue on the board until April, when his term expires.

title: Currents;Supply Dried Up, So They Made Their Own
description: IN 1986, Bob Winston, an American, and John David Hunter, a French Canadian, opened the Tulip Tree Collection in Washington Depot, Conn., specializing in pine Norman-style French Canadian antiques. When the supply dried up, they commissioned reproductions.

title: HOCKEY;Brodeur Is Closer to Perfection Than Roy
description: Playing against his idol brings out the best in Martin Brodeur.

title: PATAKI'S MESSAGE: THE OVERVIEW;Pataki Says Backing Spending Cuts Will Help State Thrive
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today urged a Legislature that is wary about spending cuts in an election year to back the austerity budget that he sent it last month, promising lawmakers that the state would flourish under his proposals to reduce government.

title: The Governor's Rhetorical Gloss
description: In his State of the State Message yesterday, Gov. George Pataki painted a sunny picture of a New York where jobs are growing, taxes are plummeting and government is shrinking to everyone's advantage. He linked his war against wasteful government to the fall of the Berlin wall and "freedom's victory over Fascism." Mr. Pataki was overselling his point. Perhaps more important, his less-is-more description of New York's future glossed over the pain and problems that lie ahead.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Hope Their Timing Is Impeccable
description: A few weeks ago the Nets did not appear to be in the same class with the Knicks. But when the two teams meet for the first time this season, tonight at Madison Square Garden, the Nets are sensing they could be catching the Knicks at the right time.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Patient Escapes From Ward
description: Authorities remained stumped yesterday as to how a patient managed to escape Monday evening from a locked ward for the criminally insane at Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital. Keys are required to get into the stairwell and out of the building, said John McKeegan, a spokesman for the State Department of Human Services. The patient, Lin Hong, 27, who was still at large yesterday, was ruled incompetent in 1989 to stand trial for the stabbing death of a West New York teen-ager, said Donald L. Gardner, an assistant Hudson County prosecutor.

title: Calendar: Exhibitions, Fashion Talks, Classes
description: Glass Works Heller Gallery, 71 Greene Street (Spring Street); (212) 966-5948.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jury Selection in Trooper Suit
description: Jury selection is scheduled to begin today in a lawsuit brought by a former state trooper who said he was subjected to racial slurs and harassment while stationed at the Newark and Flemington state police barracks between 1988 and 1990.

title: World News Briefs;Party Moves to Replace The Ailing Papandreou
description: The governing Panhellenic Socialist Party said today that it would take steps to replace Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, who remains in critical condition at an Athens hospital.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;After a devastating hurricane, the U.S. Virgin Islands is stressing American values for tourists.
description: FOR Todd Godwin and C. J. Waldman, it was like winning the lottery: whisked away from Manhattan to spend Labor Day weekend tooling around the United States Virgin Islands to brainstorm, ever so lightly, a tourism ad campaign.

title: Risk Seen in Mild Hypertension
description: Even a mild case of high blood pressure can be bad for the kidneys, according to a long-term study of men's health.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;Paradise Regrown
description: SOMETIMES, when you fall in love -- usually it's a person, but sometimes it's a place -- you get a sort of mysterious feeling that you might get what you want. Some people call it fate. Some call it dumb luck.

title: Prosperous New Year?Asia's Markets Hope for Revival
description: HONG KONG  Three years is a long time in the financial markets, and in Asia's volatile markets, it is an eternity.

title: U.S. Fines Agency On Power Plant Use
description: In a rebuke of the state agency that runs the nuclear power plant closest to New York City, Federal officials yesterday fined the New York Power Authority $50,000 for trying to restart its trouble-plagued Indian Point 3 plant in October with several backup safety systems turned off.

title: Economic Scene;Paying to pollute: a free market solution that's yet to be tested.
description: THE 1990 amendments to the Clean Air Act give electric power companies the right to pay to pollute, much the way sinners bought indulgences in the Middle Ages. Yet although the trading of sulfur emissions between utilities is now permitted, there is not much activity in this market, and prices of marketable permits are far below initial projections. Does that mean the system is not working -- that free market environmentalism is being sabotaged by myopic corporate executives or hostile state regulators?

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Dec. 26 about the impact of casinos on Atlantic City misstated the cost of a new high school there. It was $83 million, not $1.2 million.

title: FOOTBALL;Reeves Meetings Continue, As Do the No Comments
description: The meetings between Giants Coach Dan Reeves and team management are beginning to look like the Yalta Conference. However, they may soon come to an end and, barring some unforeseen disaster, Reeves will be back next season as coach of the team.

title: In AT&T's Attic, $1 Billion of Flops and Fumbles
description: The AT&T Corporation is coming to terms with its flops and fumbles, more than $1 billion worth of them.

title: Dozens Are Killed in Heavy Fighting in Liberia
description: Dozens of people have been killed in six days of fighting that has terrorized the northwestern Liberian countryside, military officials said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stalled Budget Negotiations Incite Republican Squabble As the Federal budget crisis plodded into a fourth month and a Government shutdown passed its 19th day, House Republicans squabbled over tactics, voting down a proposal by Senator Bob Dole to reopen closed offices briefly while budget talks continued. President Clinton moved quickly to exploit the differences, accusing Republicans of following a "cynical political strategy."

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education Page on Dec. 27 about college applications misquoted an essay question on the University of Pennsylvania's application form. The question reads, "If you could spend an evening with any one person, living, deceased, or fictional, whom would you choose and why?" not "If you were to spend an evening with anybody, real or fictional, deceased or living, whom would it be and why?" A Letter to the Editor on Sunday repeated the error.

title: Policy on Vacant-Building Fires Reviewed
description: The death of a firefighter on Sunday in a dilapidated Queens house illegally occupied by squatters has prompted the Fire Department to re-examine how it responds to fires at similarly troubled buildings throughout the city, department officials said.

title: Dr. Usim Odim, 72; Physician Tended To Biafrans in War
description: Dr. Usim Odim, a Nigeria-born psychiatrist who worked as a physician on the Biafran side to save civilian victims of the Nigerian civil war in the late 1960's, died on Dec. 25 at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 72.

title: Frederick King, 90, Cardiologist And a Professor at Mount Sinai
description: Dr. Frederick H. King, a cardiologist who established the first cardiac catheterization unit at Mount Sinai Hospital, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 90.

title: Pentagon Boss Walks in Footsteps of Peacekeepers
description: Secretary of Defense William J. Perry walked across the Sava River from Croatia into Bosnia today, saw a minefield being cleared from his helicopter and acknowledged bluntly that the peacekeeping mission, after two weeks, has been hounded by difficulties that may not get much better.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Mexican Stocks Gain, as Do Bonds and Peso
description: Mexican stocks rose sharply today for a second day, as benchmark one-month interest rates fell and the peso strengthened.

title: Arguments Begin In Killing of Father Of Michael Jordan
description: Opening arguments began today in the trial of a man accused of killing the father of the basketball star Michael Jordan.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3 Strikes and Drug Den Is Out
description: Two previous police raids on a heavily fortified drug den came up empty, so this time, the authorities said, they did not bother to knock before they broke through the door Tuesday night and smashed a window to get inside.

title: FOOTBALL;Game Plan for Eagles: Run Silent, Run Deep
description: Ricky Watters's feet will have to do the talking for the Philadelphia Eagles against the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday. For the Eagles' quarterback, Rodney Peete, is suffering from laryngitis, which could have a major impact on his ability to bark out signals in Texas Stadium, the noisiest open-air stadium in the National Football League.

title: BASKETBALL;Jordan's 38 Pace the Bulls
description: Michael Jordan scored 38 points and Chicago held Houston to only one field goal in the second quarter tonight as the Bulls defeated the Rockets, 100-86.

title: Top Bosnian Angry Over TV's Coverage Of New Year Revelry
description: President Alija Izetbegovic has criticized state television and radio for covering "licentious" New Year's Eve celebrations in Bosnia's first peaceful holiday in four years.

title: FOOTBALL;Osborne Savors Acclaim After Troubled Season
description: The voice has always sounded the same, regardless of the emotionally charged circumstances surrounding Tom Osborne or the public perception of Nebraska's private football coach and head of state. No matter what his Cornhuskers have accomplished or what people have thought of Osborne, in noble defeat at the 1984 Orange Bowl, after a heartrending loss on the same field a decade later, following a long-sought triumph last January or throughout an intensely scrutinized autumn, his tone has remained as flat as the plains, his thoughts as understated as many of its people.

title: Market Place;HFS is a fast-moving company whose share price has soared.
description: IF you think it was tough keeping up with the Joneses last year, consider how much tougher it was keeping up with HFS Inc., the franchise company whose hotel empire includes about 4,700 Days Inns, Howard Johnsons, Ramadas, Park Inns, Super 8's and Villager Lodges.

title: The Pop Life
description: It is not by choice but by necessity that critics' favorite albums of 1995 differed from the public's. Of last year's 10 best-selling albums, according to Billboard magazine, every one -- from "Cracked Rear View," by Hootie and the Blowfish, to "The Lion King" soundtrack -- was released in 1994. Though a few fresh faces appeared at the top of the pop charts (Alanis Morissette and Joan Osborne), 1995 was a year of artists new to success in 1994 (Green Day, Coolio and Ace of Base) returning with follow-up albums. Despite the lack of change in what was being sold, there was plenty to listen to. From trip-hop to Welsh pop, celluloid divas to saxophone achievers, here are the best pop and jazz albums of the year in the views of New York Times critics. NEIL STRAUSS

title: Jury Gets Directions in Maxwell Sons' Trial
description: The judge in the fraud trial of Kevin and Ian Maxwell told jurors today that they must decide whether the two, the sons of the media empire-builder Robert Maxwell, had deliberately put pension assets at risk.

title: Garden Q. and A.
description: Annual Gold Medal Winners

title: Metro Matters;'Elisa's Law' Evokes Unity For Legislators
description: ELISA'S LAW," a proposal to loosen the veil of confidentiality that has swathed child welfare cases in secrecy for a generation, is moving so quickly through New York's State Legislature that its sponsors predict it could pass in weeks.

title: PATAKI'S MESSAGE: THE POLITICS;Risky Time for Cuts
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's second State of the State address today reflected the quandary he faces in selling his budget for the coming fiscal year: in an election year his deep-cutting plan offers legislators little of the spending they think they need to win votes.

title: World News Briefs;Famine in North Korea Puts the South on Edge
description: President Kim Young Sam said today that national security must be South Korea's first concern, in light of reports of a possible famine in North Korea.

title: NATO Chiefs Press Serbs To Release 18 Bosnians
description: Only a day after denying that NATO had a responsibility to address the issue, NATO officers visited the Serb-held suburb of Ilidza today to press officials to release up to 18 Bosnians who have been detained.

title: PATAKI'S MESSAGE;Press Secretary Polished Pataki's Speech
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's second State of the State address was written mainly by the Governor's press secretary, Robert J. Bellafiore, in close collaboration with the Governor himself, administration officials said.

title: SKIING;This Season, Skiers and Snowfalls Are Drifting East
description: At Eastern ski resorts last season, a warm autumn and midwinter thaw turned a dearth of snow into slush. Not so this year, where piles of fresh powder and cool temperatures have turned a mediocre outlook in the Northeast into a record pace for the skiing industry there.

title: Liberties;You're So Vain
description: Carole Lombard said it best: "I live by a man's code, designed to fit a man's world, yet at the same time I never forget that a woman's first job is to choose the right shade of lipstick."

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Aston Martin Shown in Detroit
description: The Ford Motor Company introduced a new Aston Martin to the United States market today and said it expects to sell about 200 of the exclusive sports cars, made famous by the James Bond spy movie series.

title: Italian Settles Fraud Charges in MGM Deal
description: Giancarlo Parretti, the Italian financier and former owner of MGM studios, and two associates settled Federal securities-fraud charges today related to the 1990 takeover of MGM, without agreeing to financial penalties.

title: Central Asia Should Win the New 'Great Game';Who Coined the Phrase
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Is Ahead 16.62 on Day Of Big Swings
description: Stocks were mixed yesterday on heavy volume as the stalled Federal budget negotiations caused some sharp swings in trading.

title: Burst Pipe in Queens Leaves A Big Hole and Big Questions
description: A virtually new, 60-inch water pipe burst in Astoria, Queens, on Tuesday night, turning blocks into gushing rivers and confounding city officials, who said yesterday that they had never seen a break like it in such a new pipeline, even in a water system as accustomed to main breaks as New York City's.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS -- In Washington;Indirect Victims Of the Stalemate
description: When Constance Conrad died last month, the responsibility of running her management company passed to her 29-year-old nephew, Thomas. One of his first decisions was to furlough 20 employees, because the Federal agencies with which he has contracts had shut down.

title: Strike Threatened Today At 1,000 Office Buildings
description: The union representing elevator operators and maintenance workers at about 1,000 large New York City commercial buildings threatened yesterday to begin a strike today unless progress were made in contract talks.

title: CITY BALLET REVIEW;Romance of Broadway Through Classical Eyes
description: Somewhat like George Gershwin's American in Paris, George Balanchine was a Russian in New York who knew how to pay tribute to a city of dreams with an outsider's sense of wonder. That he chose 16 Gershwin songs to do so in his ballet "Who Cares?" was no accident.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WALDEN RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES INC., West Dallas, Tex., acquired three apartment properties, a total of 686 units, in the Dallas-Fort Worth area for $18.2 million in cash.

title: At State Department, Empty Pockets
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher spent much of today grappling with the latest foreign policy nightmare: trying to conduct diplomacy on behalf of a Government that has run out of money.

title: How To Avoid These Layoffs?
description: If the Federal Government is to do less, then the private sector will have to do more. But AT&T's stunning announcement on the first business day of 1996 that it would permanently lay off 40,000 employees raises profound questions about the private sector's ability to take on more responsibility for Americans' economic well-being.

title: FOOTBALL;No Plans for Inquiry Into Shift of Identity
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association said today that it is convinced that Texas officials had no idea a 30-year-old football player had changed his identity to extend his eligibility.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Group-Home Funds Sought
description: Advocates for the mentally retarded asked the state yesterday for $12 million to reduce the waiting list for places in group homes or adult day-care programs. Some 4,800 mentally retarded New Jerseyans living in state institutions or with their families are on the list, said the Arc of New Jersey, an advocacy group.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trailer Mishap Snarls I-95
description: The express lanes on Interstate 95 just off the George Washington Bridge were closed for five hours yesterday morning when a tractor-trailer skidded out of control, critically injuring the driver and leading to most of his 50,000-pound load of potatoes spilling onto the slippery roadway, the police said. The truck ended up on its side, straddling the concrete divider, and a second tractor-trailer sheared off the top of the trailer, spilling thousands of potatoes, said Trooper Al Della Fave, a spokesman for the state police.

title: Marriott Spinoff A Fait Accompli
description: The Host Marriott Corporation has completed the spinoff of Host Marriott Services, the nation's largest operator of restaurant and retail outlets at airports and arenas.

title: Time for Change in Saudi Arabia
description: Saudi Arabia is the world's largest oil producer, Washington's largest ally in the Persian Gulf and one of the world's last absolute monarchies. So when its ailing King steps aside and hands control of the country to his half-brother, Americans need to pay attention.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Nigeria Warned on Africa Cup
description: Nigeria was threatened yesterday with a six-year ban from the African Nations' Cup and given 48 hours to reverse its decision to withdraw from the Africa Cup in South Africa, which begins Jan. 13. Nigeria's Sports Minister, JIM NWOBODO, said last week that his country was pulling out because of fears that its players could be in danger in South Africa, which has led a campaign against Nigeria over the hanging in November of nine rights activists. (Reuters)

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about political shifts in Britain misstated the number of Labor Party members in the House of Commons. It is 272, not 372.

title: Currents;In Landscapes Made of Wool
description: A YEAR ago, Sarah Gayle Carter's aunt needed a new rug for Redlands, the Carter family homestead in Charlottesville, Va. Ms. Carter, a commercial artist and children's book illustrator, volunteered to design one, incorporating things that particularly captured the spirit of the 1,000-acre estate -- oak leaves and acorns, rabbits and prancing deer, in shades of bright red, green and yellow. She took her design to a small North Carolina manufacturer to make the rug in hand-tufted loop pile. The results looked so much like real needlepoint that Ms. Carter suddenly found herself in the rug business.

title: U.P.S. to Raise Its Prices And Revamp Rate Structure
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc. said today that it was raising prices for ground shipping of packages and changing the rate structure for domestic air delivery.

title: L.B.J.'s 'Balanced' Budget Hid Deficits;When Mills Balked
description: To the Editor:

title: A PROTEIN TELLS EATERS TO STOP
description: Scientists have found a protein that acts immediately to tell the brain when it is time for the body to stop eating. Rats that received injections of the protein as they nibbled ordinary food pellets suddenly appeared satiated and lethargic, as if they had eaten a rodent's equivalent of a big Thanksgiving dinner, researchers said.

title: Nine Slain in Sri Lanka
description: Tamil Tiger rebels carried out several raids against the Sri Lankan military today, leaving at least nine people dead, including three Government servicemen, officials said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTIAN BRANDO, the 37-year-old son of MARLON BRANDO, is to be released next week from the California Men's Colony, a prison in San Luis Obispo, after serving nearly five years for the shooting death of his half-sister's boyfriend, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: HOCKEY;The Host U.S. Isn't Warming to This Party
description: In the semifinals of the world junior hockey championships today, Canada played Russia in a match with historic resonance and international appeal. And the Czech Republic played Sweden in an intriguing pairing between traditional European powers.

title: John Wasmuth, 49, Researcher Who Sought Out Disease Genes
description: Dr. John J. Wasmuth, a biochemist and leader of a team of molecular researchers who tracked down genes responsible for inherited diseases like dwarfism and Huntington's disease, died on Friday at Mission Hospital Regional Medical Center in Mission Viejo, Calif. He was 49 and lived in Mission Viejo.

title: Offer to Buy REIT Stake
description: Black Bear Realty Ltd. has offered to buy 30 percent of American Industrial Properties REIT, a real estate investment trust, for $3 a share. A 30 percent stake would involve about 2.7 million shares. At $3 a share, the stake's value would be $8.1 million. Black Bear proposed that American Industrial name Richard Osborne, managing member of Black Bear, and two other nominees to American Industrial's board.

title: New York State Is Reopening Schools as It Takes Over District on L.I.
description: In the first such action ever in New York, state officials today seized control of the troubled Roosevelt school district and announced the reopening of schools that had been closed on Tuesday by the local school board.

title: With Placards and Slogans, Palestinians Face the Unknown: An Election
description: After many last-minute changes and much confusion, the Palestinian election commission today declared the campaign open to elect the first legislature and president the Palestinians have ever had.

title: Sports of The Times;Paths Part For Frazier And Phillips
description: IN the wake of Nebraska's stunning 62-24 victory over Florida in the Fiesta Bowl, Coach Tom Osborne offered career counseling to his two best backs.

title: Senate Approves a Nominee to the S.E.C.
description: The Senate has approved the nomination of a Utah lawyer, Norman S. Johnson, to the Securities and Exchange Commission but withheld action on a second nominee, Prof. Isaac C. Hunt Jr.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BMG Buys the Rest Of Windam Hill Records
description: A unit of Bertelsmann A.G. of Germany has bought the remaining 50 percent stake of Windam Hill Productions record label that it did not already own. The unit, BMG Entertainment North America did not diclose the terms of the purchase of the label that specializes in New Age music, which comes three-and-a-half years after BMG bought a 50 percent stake. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Taking Risk to Its 'Logical' Extreme
description: INTO THE WILD By Jon Krakauer Illustrated. 207 pages. Villard Books. $22.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GRAPHIC CONTROLS ENTERS $99 MILLION DEAL FOR DEVON
description: The Graphic Controls Corporation of Buffalo agreed yesterday to buy Devon Industries for $99 million. Both companies are closely held. The agreement includes up to an additional $7 million in deferred consideration that is based on Devon's future performance. Graphic Controls makes disposable medical products and industrial recording supplies. Devon, based in Chatsworth, Calif., makes disposable medical products used primarily in surgical procedures and infection control.

title: Anxiety at AT&T as Layoffs Loom
description: Lee Smith and Fred Dellanno shared lunch and anxieties today in the cafeteria at the AT&T Corporation's headquarters in the snowy woodlands of this quaint village.

title: Drug Approved; 2 Stocks Gain
description: The shares of Advanced Polymer Systems Inc. and Johnson & Johnson rose strongly today in the wake of the approval by the Food and Drug Administration of Johnson & Johnson's skin cream Renova.

title: Researchers' Finding Offers Insight Into How Cancer Develops
description: Scientists at Stanford University and elsewhere have gained an important insight into the basic biology that underlies the evolution of cancerous tumors. Their finding explains why many solid tumors are resistant to chemotherapy and radiation from they moment they are found, and why some cancerous cells can survive even in the center of tumors, where there is very little oxygen.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Mariners Land Paul Sorrento
description: The Seattle Mariners, who traded first baseman TINO MARTINEZ to the Yankees last month, signed his replacement yesterday. PAUL SORRENTO, who became a free agent two weeks ago when the Cleveland Indians did not tender him a contract, accepted the Mariners' offer of $1 million for 1996 and an option year at $1.5 million or a $100,000 buyout. Sorrento, a left-handed hitter, hit 25 home runs in only 323 at-bats compared with 31 hit in 519 at-bats by Martinez, whom the Mariners traded to the Yankees as a payroll-reduction move. Sorrento became expendable to the Indians because they signed JULIO FRANCO to play first. JEROME WALTON was another of the 48 players who were not tendered contracts by the Dec. 20 deadline. An outfielder with Cincinnati last season, Walton was pursued by about half a dozen teams and selected the Atlanta Braves, who will pay him a $500,000 salary next season and $550,000 or $600,000 if they exercise their option for 1997. Walton, the National League rookie of the year in 1989, hit .290 in 162 at-bats for the Reds.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, is selling $70 million in debentures due in 2003 through Lehman Brothers. The debentures are noncallable, carry an interest rate of 5.630 percent, paid semiannually, and are priced at par. * Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $45 million in bonds due in 2006 through First Tennessee Bank. The bonds are callable in one year, carry an interest rate of 6.730 percent, paid semiannually, and are priced at par. * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is selling $50 million in medium-term notes due in 2003 through First Tennessee Bank. The notes are callable in two years, carry an interest rate of 6.250 percent, paid semiannually, and are priced at par.

title: The Budget Scrum
description: For fans of political games, President Clinton put on a rip-roaring show yesterday as he charged right through the budget rift that has opened up on the Republican side between Newt Gingrich and Bob Dole. The new year thus dawns with the surprising spectacle of two archrivals, Mr. Dole and Mr. Clinton, trying to look like grown-ups while the Republicans in the House insist childishly that the only way to apply leverage on the President is to keep the Government closed. More and more it looks as if the zealous freshmen are calling the shots in the House.

title: A Gambino Goes to Jail In 1993 Case
description: Thomas Gambino never rose in Mafia circles to the legendary status of his late father, Carlo, who, as the so-called boss of bosses, was the pre-eminent mob figure in America when he died 20 years ago.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: New Blend Fights a Cancer Better
description: Taxol, a drug originally derived from the bark of the Pacific yew tree, helps those with ovarian cancer to live longer when it is combined with the drug cisplatin, a study has found.

title: Security a Top Issue in Municipal Pact
description: When hundreds of school crossing guards and school aides braved sleet and slush on Tuesday night to vote on the municipal employees contract, they viewed the labor agreement far more charitably than New York City's teachers viewed their roughly similar accord.

title: 95 Is Hottest Year on Record As the Global Trend Resumes
description: The earth's average surface temperature climbed to a record high last year, according to preliminary figures, bolstering scientists' sense that the burning of fossil fuels is warming the climate.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE LEGISLATION;House Fails to Override Veto of Spending Bills
description: With defections on both sides of the aisle, House Republicans failed today in efforts to override President Clinton's veto of the $256 billion military authorizations bill and the $27.3 billion budget for Commerce, State and Justice Departments.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VTEL'S SHARES FALL 40% ON REVISED EARNINGS PROJECTION
description: The shares of the Vtel Corporation dropped 40 percent yesterday after the company said late on Tuesday that it expected fourth-quarter revenue to be lower than expected. Vtel, a maker of multimedia conference systems that is based in Austin, Tex., said it now expected revenue of only $23 million to $23.5 million for the quarter that ended on Dec. 31. The company said it now expected a "slight" profit for the quarter before accounting for its previously announced one-time expense of 4 cents to 7 cents a share from its acquisition of the Integrated Communications Systems group from Peirce-Phelps Inc. Analysts surveyed by First Call Inc. had expected Vtel to earn 17 cents a share for the quarter. Vtel shares fell $7, to $10.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: COMPANY NEWS;JUDGE DISMISSES CAREMARK'S SUIT AGAINST CORAM
description: The Coram Healthcare Corporation said yesterday that a Federal judge in Chicago had dismissed a $117 million lawsuit filed against the company by Caremark International Inc. Coram said its lawsuit against Caremark, seeking damages resulting from its acquisition of Caremark's home drug-infusion business, was pending in a California court. Coram's shares rose 50 cents yesterday, to $5.375, on the New York Stock Exchange; Caremark was up 12.5 cents, to $18.75. Caremark sued Coram, contending that Coram concealed its planned merger with Lincare Holdings Inc. to lure Caremark into selling the home infusion business to Coram. Caremark contended that the deal, which later fell apart, reduced the value of Coram's shares. Caremark had received Coram shares in exchange for selling the infusion business. Coram's stock plunged from as high as $26 a share to $3.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;With Medication, Child Makes Progress in School
description: It used to be that 9-year-old Rodney Palacios could not be still for more than a minute. At home, he would fiddle with the VCR, pressing the fast-forward and rewind buttons, but never actually sit through a movie. At school, he was frequently jumping out of his chair and defying his teachers.

title: Melee Ends in Shots by Police
description: A romantic dispute between a New Jersey man and his Manhattan girfriend provoked a crowd wielding baseball bats and golf clubs to attack him in Washington Heights yesterday afternoon, the police said, and in the ensuing commotion two police officers fired their guns on a crowded stretch of Broadway.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Danish Food Deal
description: The Danish food and beverage company Danisco A/S said yesterday that it had bought a Netherlands-based frozen vegetables company, Groko B.V., from the Campbell Soup Company of Camden, N.J., for 254 million Danish crowns, or about $46 million. Danisco said the acquisition was intended to increase its share of the frozen vegetable market in northern and central Europe. Groko sells 35 percent of its products in the Netherlands, 45 percent in Germany and 20 percent in the rest of Europe. (Dow Jones)

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Gold Mine Cutback
description: The Buffelsfontein Gold Mining Company Ltd., one of South Africa's deepest gold mines, said yesterday that it would dismiss more than 63 percent of its work force in an effort to improve profitability. Buffelsfontein said it agreed with trade unions and employee associations that 2,000 miners would be rehired after the mine's 5,500-member work force was dismissed. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Guatemalan Family Refiles Suit Against Fuller Over Boy's Death
description: Lawyers for the family of a Guatemalan teen-ager who died in 1993 from the effects of sniffing glue have refiled a civil suit that accuses the H. B. Fuller Company, an industrial products manufacturer, of being responsible for the boy's death.

title: Less Transience May Enhance Family Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: 10 Alabama Judges Jump To the Republican Party

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gold, Soybeans and Natural Gas All Post Strong Price Increases
description: Gold prices rose yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York for a second consecutive session as traders bet that mining companies would defer sales of their gold production until later in the year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Media Director Rejects Yankees
description: ROB BUTCHER had the chance to return as the Yankees' media relations director after GEORGE STEINBRENNER offered him his job back last Friday, but yesterday Butcher said no.

title: Sarila Journal;Serenely, Maharajah Strolls the Democratic Land
description: Almost half a century has passed since India's independence began pushing the maharajahs into history, anchored in memory by images of pillared palaces and jewels the size of hen's eggs, by gold-plated Rolls-Royces and tiger hunts conducted on elephants' backs.

title: Bridge
description: Some of the most difficult deals in play or defense relate to control of the trump suit. Will the declarer be able to preserve his trumps, pull the opposition teeth in that department, and score his side-suit winners?

title: BASKETBALL;As Knicks Go Cold, So Too Does Mason-Nelson Relationship
description: The player did not say, "I want out," and the coach did not counter with, "We need to trade that malcontent." But the chumminess that Anthony Mason and Don Nelson have displayed so often this season is apparently on hiatus, set to resume only after two conditions are met:

title: PATAKI'S MESSAGE;Excerpts From the Governor's Address in Albany
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. George E. Pataki's State of the State Message yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: 2 Westinghouse Industrial Units Sold to Northrop for $3 Billion
description: In a further step to sharpen its business focus as well as to reduce debt incurred in its $5.4 billion acquisition of CBS Inc., the Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its military and electronics systems businesses to the Northrop Grumman Corporation for $3 billion in cash.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Drinking Tequila but Thinking Cognac, Maybe?
description: To most Americans, tequila is some kind of exotic Tijuana firewater that if not the drink of connoisseurs, never fails to hit the spot.

title: Why Israelis Fear A U.S. Military Pact
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents;At Botanical Garden, Letting the Sun Shine In
description: JAQUELIN T. ROBERTSON has designed a cafe for the New York Botanical Garden that refuses to compete with its two 19th-century neighbors, the Beaux-Arts museum building and the Victorian Enid A. Haupt Conservatory.

title: Kohlberg Kravis Group Set To Trim Stake in Safeway
description: A Kohlberg Kravis Roberts group said today that it planned to cut its stake in Safeway Inc. by selling stock in a secondary offering.

title: Fish Market Disrupted For 2d Day
description: For a second straight day, several hundred workers at the Fulton Fish Market staged a brief work stoppage early yesterday that delayed the delivery of seafood to some retail stores and restaurants.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FAMILY OWNERS AT LEVI STRAUSS CONSIDER STOCK BUYBACK
description: Levi Strauss & Company said yesterday that some of the family members who own 94 percent of the apparel maker were considering whether to buy back stock from employees and other family members at $250 a share. A spokesman for the company, a unit of Levi Strauss Associates Inc. in San Francisco, said that after adjusting for two stock splits in the 1980's, the $250 figure was roughly 50 times higher than the $50 a share paid when the company bought back stock in 1985. Morgan Stanley in November valued the stock at about $189 a share, a company spokesman said. There are 52.8 million shares outstanding.

title: The Art and Science of Alan Greenspan;How to Stay Popular in a Divided Washington, and Keep Inflation in Check
description: Sometime this winter, President Clinton will decide whether to give another term to Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve -- a Republican operating in a Democratic Administration whose decisions will play a key role in shaping the economy as the Presidential election approaches.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Skellyvision Inc., New York, to Lockhardt & Pettus Advertising, New York, to introduce Skelly, an air-cushion board game. The billings were not disclosed. * Dallas Burn to Levenson & Hill, Dallas, as the first agency to handle advertising, marketing and public relations for the new team, which will be part of Major League Soccer. The billings have not been determined. * FMC APG Specialty Products Group, Princeton, N.J., to Gillespie, Princeton, to handle advertising for the manufacturer of pest control products, previously handled in-house. The billings were not disclosed.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE EFFECTS -- In the Virgin Islands;Looking to '62 To Open a Park
description: In a ruling that reached back to the words of President John F. Kennedy in 1962, a Federal judge here issued an injunction today prohibiting the National Park Service from denying access to Buck Island National Park, despite orders from the Interior Department to close the park.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about potential job cuts in the telephone industry misstated a provision of a contract between the Bell Atlantic Corporation and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers. Bell Atlantic will pay lower wages to employees who install wiring in homes, not to those who install fiber optic cable in the telephone network.

title: G.M.'s Chief Sets a Target For Asia Sales
description: The head of General Motors said today that his company would try to capture 10 percent of the Asian car and truck market by 2005, an indication that American auto makers are increasingly focused on that fast-growing market.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CARSON PIRIE SCOTT DROPS BID FOR YOUNKERS
description: The Milwaukee department store chain Carson Pirie Scott & Company said yesterday that it was dropping its hostile bid for Younkers Inc. and that it would support a rival offer by Proffitt's Inc. Carson also agreed to buy two Younkers stores in Rockford, Ill., for $5 million. Carson announced in October 1994 that it had acquired 11.7 percent of the Younkers shares, and that it wanted to buy the Des Moines-based department store chain. Younkers resisted and later reached a deal with Proffitt's, which is based in Alcoa, Tenn. Carson said it would vote all of its Younkers shares in favor of the Proffitt's deal. The company said that it stood to make about $9 million on its Younkers stock, but that it had spent about $6 million trying to acquire the chain.

title: OLYMPICS;North Korea To Join World In Atlanta
description: North Korea agreed yesterday to send its athletes to Atlanta next summer, meaning that, for the first time in the century of the modern Olympics, all invited nations have agreed to participate in the Summer Games.

title: Ellington, Duke of Jazz
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TAIWAN CHIP MAKER SETTLES PATENT DISPUTE WITH INTEL
description: The United Microelectronics Corporation of Taiwan agreed yesterday to stop making versions of the Intel Corporation's 486 microprocessors to settle a patent dispute with the world's leading chip maker. United Microelectronics will pay "an agreed-upon sum" of less than $5 million to Intel to cover legal costs and damages. United Microelectronics also agreed to withdraw all challenges to Intel's patents. The dispute began in 1994, when United Microelectronics was marketing a version of Intel's 486 processor, which was marked as not for sale in the United States.

title: Crew Offers Top Post To Giuliani Budget Aide
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has met with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani almost every week since he took office last October. He supported the Mayor on a tentative contract negotiated with the leaders of the teachers' union, which the teachers later rejected. And he followed the Mayor's lead in recommending raises for more than 350 Board of Education managers.

title: Central Asia Should Win the New 'Great Game'
description: To the Editor:

title: First-Degree Murder Case
description: District Attorney Charles J. Hynes said yesterday that a grand jury had brought first-degree murder charges against a man accused of killing his ex-girlfriend.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Shooting the Moon' Julie Saul Gallery 560 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through Jan. 13

title: 3 Are Indicted in Sale of German Art Stolen by a G.I.
description: The brother and sister of the American Army lieutenant who stole the world-famous Quedlinburg treasures from their hiding place in a German cave in 1945 were indicted yesterday in Texas on Federal charges of illegally selling in 1990 two of the treasures, which they had inherited.

title: Stocks Slip in Japan
description: Stocks were retrenching a bit here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 177.20 points, or nearly six-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,500.80. On Thursday, the first trading day of the year here , the Nikkeisoared 749.85 points, or 3.77 percent, to 20,618.00, its highest finish since Sept. 2, 1994.

title: Mortgage Rates Fall
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.02 percent this week, the lowest in two years, according to a national survey issued today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Rates averaged 7.11 percent last week. This week's average was the lowest since Feb. 3, 1994, when rates averaged 6.97 percent. As recently as Dec. 15, 1994, rates were at 9.25 percent before they started falling. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.46 percent, down from 5.55 percent last week.

title: Art in Review
description: Tom Sachs Morris Healy Gallery 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea Through Jan. 14

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Arianespace Plans Rise in Launchings
description: To meet an anticipated surge of 30 percent in international demand for satellite launchings, the European space transportation company Arianespace said yesterday that it planned to increase its activity in the coming years.

title: Arbitration Bill Covering Police and Firefighters Is Voted Down inAssembly
description: Despite an intensive, last-minute lobbying effort, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman failed today to persuade the State Assembly to approve a bill she said would save cities and towns money by reining in salaries for police officers and firefighters.

title: Sports of The Times;The Stars Go Out At the Garden
description: FORGET Patrick Ewing's sprained ankle, and Anthony Mason's hard head. If things have appeared uglier around the Knicks, it is because there have been no recent Kim Basinger sightings at Madison Square Garden. She and the rest of the beautiful people are in retreat.

title: Giuliani Takes Issue With Pataki's Budget
description: Testifying in Albany, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that cuts planned by the state would cause pain for New York City, forcing him to slash city services further.

title: Standoff Over Red Hook Renewal;Businesses Fear a Plan to Remake a Neighborhood
description: Less than a year ago, Red Hook's ambitious plan to remake itself was hailed as a paradigm of late-20th-century urban renewal. City officials, residents and politicians spoke enthusiastically of the plan's scope and realism, its lack of ideology and its abundance of consensus.

title: Bonn Official Demands That Dutch Slow Drug Trade
description: A senior German government official, dropping diplomatic niceties, demanded Thursday that the Netherlands change its drug toleration policies to stem a tide of narcotics into Germany.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Stung By Former Teammate
description: New year. Old ghost.

title: Conviction In Bribery Thrown Out
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday overturned the 1993 bribery conviction of Richard Foley Jr., a five-term member of Connecticut's House of Representatives and the former chairman of the state's Republican Party.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Disney and ABC Shareholders Solidly Approve Merger Deal
description: Shareholders of the Walt Disney Company and Capital Cities/ABC approved a merger yesterday, and Disney executives said they expected the deal to clear the final hurdle of Government approval in the next few weeks.

title: No Supranational Control for the Internet
description: To the editor:

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon:

title: Gary Barnett Will Stay Put
description: Gary Barnett, who coached Northwestern to its first Rose Bowl in nearly half a century, rejected an offer to coach at U.C.L.A. and will remain at Northwestern, the school announced today.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Wolters Leads UConn Women
description: Kara Wolters scored 25 points tonight as No. 2-ranked Connecticut rebounded from its first Big East loss in two years to defeat Georgetown, 96-64.

title: ART REVIEW;The Stuff of Dreams And the Natural World
description: In Meg Webster's installation for "The Material Imagination" at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo, a series of branches leans inward to form a room-size spiral. The pine needles on some branches are still green, but the tiny deciduous leaves on others are brown and withered.

title: 5 Are Killed in Attacks in Southern Egypt
description: Attackers ambushed a police truck today in southern Egypt, killing the driver and a riot policeman. Security officials said Muslim militants were responsible.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ENRON UNIT BUYS A STAKE IN HANOVER COMPRESSOR
description: A unit of the Enron Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired a 10.5 percent stake in the Hanover Compressor Company, which leases gas equipment, and added that it would provide Hanover with a $100 million line of credit to help it expand. Enron Capital and Trade Resources paid $30 million for its stake in Hanover, a privately held company based in Houston. An investment partnership that includes the Pritzker family of Chicago and Daniel W. Lufkin, a founder of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, owns 44.8 percent of Hanover.

title: Clinton Leads Final Tribute To Navy Hero
description: President Clinton bade goodbye for the nation today to Adm. Arleigh A. Burke, praising the World War II hero as a selfless sailor who "gave nothing less than everything he had for his cherished Navy and beloved country."

title: Panel Doubts Gulf War "Syndrome" Is New
description: Soldiers who served in the Persian Gulf war do not appear to have any new or unique illness, but medical studies done so far cannot rule out mild or rare illnesses associated with service there, a panel of experts said yesterday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Parole Officer Dismissed
description: A veteran parole officer has been dismissed for neglecting his duties in his handling of Darnell Collins, the drug addict from Atlantic City who killed seven people and wounded two others last year during a rampage through two states, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Wildcat to Enter Draft
description: Kentucky's record-setting tailback, MOE WILLIAMS, announced yesterday that he would enter the National Football League draft instead of spending his senior season with the Wildcats. Williams broke or tied 15 school records during the season.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;LEADERS IN HOUSE DROP G.O.P. PLAN ON U.S. WORKERS
description: Weary of taking the blame for the continuing Government shutdown, House Republican leaders today abandoned their strategy of using closed Government offices as a lever to force President Clinton to agree to a seven-year balanced budget, but their rank and file revolted.

title: First-Class Freeloaders
description: It appears there will be plenty of time in the days ahead to hear more about Hillary Clinton and the purge of the White House travel office. But it would be a mistake to leave the holiday season without a review of those merry travelers from Congress and the Cabinet. There is not enough money to issue a renewed passport for the taxpayer or a paycheck for several hundred thousand Government employees. But that has not prevented some industrious officials from sprinkling the world's tourist spots with the public's money.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Osram Sylvania Chooses Mullen
description: Osram Sylvania Inc. in Danvers, Mass., a unit of Osram G.m.b.h. of Germany, said yesterday that it had named Mullen Advertising in Wenham, Mass., to handle advertising for its consumer specialty lamp and industrial commercial lighting divisions. The billings were estimated at $7 million. Mullen was awarded the account after a three-month review that was narrowed to that agency and the two incumbents: Poppe Tyson in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, which handled the specialty and industrial commercial division, and Leonard/ Monahan in Providence, which handled the consumer division.

title: Inside Art
description: Old Masters for Sale

title: Down on the Farm, a Donor;Breeding Pigs That Can Provide Organs for Humans
description: In the United States today, about 3,000 patients die annually waiting for an organ transplant. Some 100,000 more die each year never having qualified for a place on the waiting list. But in the near future, victims of organ failure may have a new alternative: a heart, liver, lung or kidney from a genetically altered pig.

title: Under Pressure by NATO, Bosnian Serbs Free Captives
description: Under mounting pressure from the United States and NATO, Bosnian Serb officials backed down from their most serious challenge yet to the Dayton peace agreement and late today released 16 Bosnians who had been detained while traveling through Serb-controlled suburbs of this city.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Shula Packing Up Victories and Leaving Dolphins
description: Don Shula, the National Football League's winningest coach, will resign on Friday after 26 years as head coach of the Miami Dolphins.

title: In Montenegro, an Indicted Soldier Is Still a Hero
description: During his rapid rise through the ranks, Lieut. Col. Veselin Sljivancanin was regarded as the paradigm of a fierce soldier in the Yugoslav Army.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Existential Anarchy And Scary Cereal
description: AND now it's time for breakfast with Richard Foreman, just the way to start the day when the world is seeming inscrutable.

title: At the Mercy Of Our Genes
description: This summer, in the course of research into my family's genetic history, I traveled into the heart of a largely unmapped landscape: the human genome, the tightly wound coils of DNA that form each one of us.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italian Government Sells Rest of Steel Unit
description: The Italian Government has completed withdrawing from the steel industry by selling its remaining 84 percent stake in Dalmine S.p.A. to a steel concern with operations in Italy and Argentina. Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale, the holding company that owns the Italian Government's interests in industry, said yesterday that its Ilva S.p.A. unit would receive 302 billion lire ($190 million) for the stake. It was acquired by the Italian-based Techint Finanziaria S.p.A. and Siderca S.p.A., both controlled by the Rocca family.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;London Stock Market Chief Ousted After Broker Feud
description: The London Stock Exchange, facing growing pressure from competitors at home and abroad, ousted its chief executive today after months of feuding with securities firms here over his plans to introduce a new form of share trading.

title: Atoms of Antimatter Created by Physicists
description: Atoms of antihydrogen have been created by scientists in a laboratory near Geneva, the first complete atoms of antimatter ever seen. Each atom consists of a negatively charged proton orbited by a positively charged electron, the reverse of the charges in ordinary matter. When more of it has been gathered, the antihydrogen should help studies of the nature of matter and the origin of the universe.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRESSTEK DISMISSES AUDITOR IN DISPUTE OVER REPORT
description: Presstek Inc. has dismissed its auditor after a dispute over how the company disclosed an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In a filing with the S.E.C., Presstek, a maker of printing equipment in Hudson, N.H., said its board voted to dismiss Deloitte & Touche, though it had no disagreements with the auditor over financial results. Presstek said in the filing that mentioning the investigation in a 1994 report was unnecessary because it was disclosed elsewhere in the report. Presstek later added the mention to the financial statement notes as well. In November 1994, the S.E.C. began an inquiry into possible manipulation of Presstek's shares. Officials for Presstek and Deloitte could not be reached for comment. Shares of Presstek fell $10.75 yesterday, to $83.5, before trading on the Nasdaq market was halted late in the afternoon.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE WORKERS;Added Bite For Many On the Job
description: Phil Glover was beside himself in anger and frustration.

title: Bad Tidings for the Hungry
description: The demand for free meals at New York City soup kitchens and food pantries is outstripping supply, even as Congress proposes to cut funds for emergency food programs and Gov. George Pataki gives every indication of following suit. The funds involved are not large. But they are essential to the soup kitchens and the daily nourishment they provide to hungry people. They support the very fibers of the social safety net. Cutting these funds is thus an especially cruel gesture.

title: G.M., in a First, Will Sell a Car Designed for Electric Power ThisFall
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would begin selling an electric car in selected areas of the West this fall.

title: Memo Places Hillary Clinton At Core of Travel Office Case
description: A memorandum by a former Presidential aide depicts Hillary Rodham Clinton as the central figure in the 1993 travel office dismissals, a politically damaging episode that the aide said had resulted from a climate of fear in which officials did not dare question Mrs. Clinton's wishes.

title: The Dow Declines by 20.23 In a Day of Wide Swings
description: The stock market was on a seesaw yesterday, pushed first up and then down by news of Washington's budget negotiations, and finally ending generally lower.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;New Yorkers at Heart, and in Charity
description: For 17 years, Florence M. Brill has lived in a village so small that she considers almost everyone her neighbor. But at night her thoughts drift back to New York, her former home.

title: Helena Leigh-Hunt Still-Life Painter, 64
description: Helena Leigh-Hunt, a realist still-life painter, died on Dec. 28 at Southampton Hospital in Long Island. She was 64 and had homes in Sag Harbor and Claverack, N.Y.

title: AT&T to End Its On-Line Service And Join the World Wide Web
description: Only a year after paying more than $50 million for the Interchange on-line service, the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would phase out the network and move its current offerings to the Internet's World Wide Web by midyear.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A Recessionary Feeling To Stores' Christmas Retailers reported their worst December sales since the 1990-91 recession period. While they gave all sorts of reasons, the weakness suggested that the economy was likely to grow slowly in the months ahead.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Repeal of Helmet Law Fails
description: Motorcyclists will still have to wear helmets in New Jersey now that a bill to eliminate the requirement was killed by the Assembly. The measure, which was approved by the Senate last month, got 20 votes yesterday -- 21 short of the number needed for passage. The helmet requirement has saved innumerable lives since it was approved in 1968, contended Assemblyman John V. Kelly, Republican of Nutley. "You'd have to be insane to vote for this bill," he added.

title: Clare Wofford, 69, College Official
description: Clare Lindgren Wofford, director of major gifts at American College in Bryn Mawr, Pa., died yesterday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. A resident of Bryn Mawr, she was 69.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing PAYTON COYNE RACING -- Signed Hiro Matsushita, driver.

title: Art in Review
description: 'En Route' Painting, Photography and Sculpture Art in General 79 Walker Street, TriBeCa Through Jan. 13

title: Peru Criticized on New Yorker's Trial
description: As the secret military trial of a New York woman accused of terrorism draws to a close here, lawyers for the woman, Lori Helene Berenson, and human rights groups have sharply criticized Peru's judicial system.

title: Richard Hornung, Costume Designer, 45
description: Richard Hornung, a costume designer whose work on the film "Barton Fink" brought him an Academy Award nomination in 1992, died on Saturday at Sherman Oaks Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 45.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Cold Spell in Mexico Threatens Coffee and Sends Prices Higher
description: Coffee prices surged on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York yesterday on concerns that cold weather in Mexico could cause frost damage to the country's crop.

title: Evan Esar, 96; Wrote Books on Jokes and Humor
description: Evan Esar, who devoted his life to writing and compiling books of humor, died on Dec. 9 at his home in suburban Los Angeles, friends reported last week.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARK HARMON, the television and movie actor, was a real-life hero on Wednesday evening when he rescued a teen-ager from a burning car near his house in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: New York Acts to Franchise Pay Toilets
description: To the Editor:

title: Egyptians Get a New Premier And Hopes for the Economy
description: A new Prime Minister and Cabinet were sworn in today in a shuffle that has raised hopes that Egypt will speed efforts to revitalize its stagnant economy.

title: Court Clears Way for Flight Attendants to Sue Tobacco Companies onSecondhand Smoke
description: In a ruling that depressed tobacco stocks, a Florida state appeals court said yesterday that airline flight attendants could mount a national class-action lawsuit against leading tobacco companies for causing smoking-related problems. Experts said they expected the ruling to spur future lawsuits against tobacco companies.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Surgery for Saberhagen May Cost '96 Season
description: A doctor has recommended that the Colorado Rockies right-hander BRET SABERHAGEN undergo a second operation on his shoulder, which could sideline the two-time Cy Young Award winner for the 1996 season.

title: As Russian Vote Nears, U.S. Fears for Fate of Reform
description: Senior Administration officials, once invariably chipper about President Boris N. Yeltsin, are taking a markedly more shaded and wary tone about him these days.

title: William Campbell, Wall St. Adviser, 64
description: William G. Campbell, a New York investment adviser and founding partner, chairman and chief executive of the Manhattan firm of Campbell, Cowperthwait & Company, died on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 64 and had homes on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Mr. Yeltsin's Dangerous Choice
description: The Russian economy teeters on the edge of recovery. Production has probably stopped falling and may start rising this year. Construction is booming in Moscow. Inflation is down from over 20 percent a month to about 8 percent. But in the wake of last month's electoral setback and his own plummeting popularity, President Boris Yeltsin is facing a dangerous temptation as he prepares for presidential elections in the spring. He has hinted that he may recklessly try to spend his way back to popularity, thus undermining economic reform and driving the Russian economy back toward hyperinflation and possible ruin.

title: President To Visit Troops
description: President Clinton will make a brief visit to the American forces in Bosnia, perhaps as early as next week, his press secretary said today.

title: Add Fertility Contol To Ethiopia Equation
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate;A couple with a binder on a house who lost their bid collect in a Connecticut small claims court.
description: SOME real estate agencies in Connecticut are re-examining their practices governing the period from the acceptance of a bid on a house to the signing of a formal purchase contract after a couple took a home seller and agency to small claims court and won a judgment for $495.

title: Haytaian Is Accused Of Harassment
description: A senior legislative assistant to Chuck Haytaian, the Speaker of New Jersey's Assembly and chairman of the State Republican Party, filed a lawsuit against him today accusing him of making repeated, unwelcome sexual advances in his State Capitol office.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Loving New York and New Yorkers
description: One of New York's most famous underappreciated artists is Rudy Burckhardt, the 81-year-old film maker and photographer who has been making delicate, evocative images of the city since the 1930's. A small but charming retrospective at the Tibor de Nagy Gallery offers a chance to understand why his quirky images have attracted such a devoted following.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;Jockey Denies Charge
description: The jockey COREY NAKATANI, under investigation by the California Horse Racing Board for supposedly whipping a horse past the finish line, said he did nothing wrong and acted professionally.

title: Market Place;Statistical Casualties in Battle of the Budget
description: On the first Friday of almost every month, the Government publishes statistics on employment, its single most important set of figures on the economy, watched by business people and ordinary workers as well as economists, bond and stock traders.

title: Mayor Calls Pataki's Cuts Too Painful for New York
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani intensified his criticism of Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget today, telling state legislators that its deep cuts would create pain for New York City residents and fiscal problems for city government.

title: Colleague's Funeral Is a Lesson in Firefighters' Vulnerability
description: The traffic was light and the course was simple: a straight shot east for about an hour on the Long Island Expressway, with a few quick turns off Exit 62 to get to the church.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Ron Sunshine

title: DESIGN REVIEW;When Craft Is Wedded to Machine Production
description: Cole Porter's "Anything Goes" should be the official theme song of "Craft in the Machine Age: 1920-1945," the third installment of the American Craft Museum's decadelong study of the history of 20th-century American crafts. This handsome if hopelessly scattershot show tries to trace the evolution of American crafts between the wars, years when the field was in tremendous flux. Like art, craft during the period was influenced by an array of modernist ideas and styles from Europe, some of them personally delivered by emigrating designers and architects. On the home front, it was drawn into a complex interaction with various kinds of workshop and factory production.

title: Physicists Manage to Create The First Antimatter Atoms
description: Physicists at the European Laboratory for Particle Physics announced yesterday that they had created, for forty-billionths of a second, the first complete atoms of antimatter ever made by human beings or seen in nature.

title: U.S. to Resume Reprocessing of Nuclear Fuel
description: The United States, which had given up recovering plutonium from spent nuclear reactor fuel and had urged Russia, Japan and others to do the same to help curb the spread of nuclear weapons, is about to resume the practice on a small scale.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;UMass Withstands Memphis Rally

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Two Big Investment Banks Report Increased Earnings
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. each reported strong quarterly earnings yesterday, benefiting particularly from their healthy investment banking businesses.

title: U.S. to Apply New Vigor in Policing Trade
description: The Clinton Administration plans to announce a broad initiative to enforce dozens of trade accords with China, Japan, Canada and other big trading partners, in a move that appears directed at protecting President Clinton from Republican accusations that his free trade agreements are costing jobs in the United States.

title: Dollar Rallies Against Yen, But Loses Ground to Mark
description: The dollar continued its rally against the Japanese yen yesterday, briefly rising to levels last seen 21 months ago before falling back on word from Washington of the latest breakdown in negotiations over the Federal budget.

title: Thomas G. Garth Is Dead at 60; Headed the Boys and Girls Clubs
description: Thomas G. Garth, the recently retired president of the Boys and Girls Clubs of America, under whose stewardship the number of youngsters served each year almost doubled to more than two million, died on Tuesday at his home in Roswell, Ga. He was 60 and had lived in Ridgewood, N.J., until the clubs moved their headquarters to Atlanta from Manhattan in 1994.

title: Edward Fenton, 78, A Children's Author Inspired by Greece
description: Edward Fenton, whose books for young readers included "The Refugee Summer" and "The Phantom of Walkaway Hill," died on Dec. 24 in Athens. He was 78 and had homes in Athens and in Galaxeidion in Greece.

title: Robert Johnson, 78, The Top Editor of Jet
description: Robert Johnson, for three decades the top editor at Jet, a leading magazine of black social and cultural affairs, died on Dec. 27 at his home in Chicago after a long illness. He was 78.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Trade Surplus
description: Germany's merchandise trade surplus widened to 8.5 billion marks ($4.6 billion) in October, from a revised 8.1 billion marks in September, the Federal Statistics Office said yesterday. In a provisional report, the office said exports rose to 65.6 billion marks in October, from a revised 62 billion in September. Exports were up 10.5 percent from a year earlier. Imports rose to 57.1 billion marks in October, from 53.9 billion in September. (AP)

title: HOCKEY;While on the Road, Devils Get Needed Lift
description: The 1-0 victory in Denver on Wednesday night against the Colorado Avalanche, one of the league's most productive teams and a strong challenger for the Stanley Cup, has brought some encouragement to the Devils in this winter of discontent. Scott Stevens and Martin Brodeur, who will start in the All-Star game later this month, were eager to point out the positive today.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;An Unlikely Cast of Characters Helps Knicks Halt Losing Streak
description: The ridicule directed at Charles Smith ended late in the fourth quarter last night when the slumping Knicks forward headed for the bench to the sound of a partial standing ovation.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "THE INTERIOR BEETHOVEN: HIS CREATIVE PROCESS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street. Discussion among Robert Martin, dean of graduate students and professor of philosophy and music at Bard College; Scott Burnham, assistant professor of music at Princeton University; Lukas Foss, the composer, conductor and pianist, and Richard Kramer, dean of humanities and fine arts and a professor of fine arts and music at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I. Tomorrow at 4:30 P.M. A performance of music by Beethoven follows at 7 P.M., featuring Mr. Foss on piano, Mr. Martin on cello, Krista Bennion-Feeney and Laurie Smukler on violin and Ira Weller on viola. Tickets: $25. Information: (212) 570-3949.

title: 2 Large Phone Companies Seek Higher Digital Rates
description: Two of the nation's largest telephone companies are asking for rate increases that would more than double the price of their consumer-oriented digital telephone services. The requests led critics to charge that the telephone industry was in danger of crippling a promising shortcut to the Internet.

title: Researchers Find Out Why Bacteria May Turn Deadly for People WithCystic Fibrosis
description: People with cystic fibrosis, who die in great numbers from lung infections, may be susceptible to the worst of those infections because of their cells' inability to swallow disease organisms.

title: 25 and Under
description: Frico Bar, a relaxed new Italian restaurant, is the second venture in the Theater District from Joe Bastianich, whose parents, Felice and Lidia, own Felidia on East 58th Street. Becco, his first restaurant, is a solid value with its offbeat prix fixe menu. Frico is an even better bargain.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Inchcape Sells Property
description: Inchcape P.L.C., an international services and marketing company, said yesterday that it had sold a Hong Kong property for L56.3 million, or $87 million (United States), to Pacific Century Group. Inchcape, based in London, said its 1995 earnings would be increased by L29 million as a result of the sale. The property was the Quarry Bay site of the Crown Motors Ltd. unit of Inchcape, one of its Toyota distributors. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: HOCKEY;Canadian Juniors Capture Fourth Gold Medal in Row
description: The sport's World Cup this autumn and the 1998 Winter Olympics will be a different challenge than this, perhaps more difficult. Those tournaments will match the top professionals of the National Hockey League and elsewhere from the many ice-producing nations of the world. The best, over all, will emerge.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South Korea's Trade Deficit Surges
description: South Korea's trade deficit surged 57 percent in 1995 from the previous year, to a record $9.9 billion, as the won's strength cut into exports, the Trade, Industry and Energy Ministry said yesterday. The ministry said exports last year rose 30.4 percent from 1994, to $125.23 billion, while imports rose 32 percent, to $135.11 billion. The 1994 trade gap was $6.3 billion.

title: 2 Republicans Claim Right To Challenge Dole in Primary
description: Two Republican presidential candidates said today that they had gathered enough signatures to enter the March primary in New York against the front-runner, Senator Bob Dole, but Mr. Dole's supporters promised to use the party's arcane election rules to force the challengers off the ballot.

title: No Headline

title: Home Video
description: As the acclaim rises for the Taiwanese director Ang Lee's film "Sense and Sensibility" (considered a strong candidate for several Oscars in March), one independent video distributor is poised for an Ang Lee ride of its own.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Reeves and the Giants Appear to Be Growing Apart
description: What once seemed to be a near certainty is no longer the case. As meetings continue between Giants Coach Dan Reeves and upper management, a portrait of their discussions is beginning to develop. And it seems that as more time goes by the chances of Reeves returning drop rapidly. And the theme of all the discussions can be summed up with one word: control.

title: Restaurants
description: The tables are flying past us. We duck as the top of a round eight-seater is lifted high above our heads. It is lowered and wheeled off, and we watch through a window into the kitchen as it disappears, rolling slowly down a flight of stairs.

title: Corrections
description: A photography review in Weekend last Friday about a retrospective of Arthur Leipzig's work at the Museum of the City of New York incorrectly described the former New York City newspaper PM, where he worked in the 1940's. It was published daily, not weekly.

title: Gumbel to Leave 'Today' After One More Year
description: Bryant Gumbel, who has been the anchor of NBC's "Today" show longer than anyone else in the program's history, announced yesterday that he would leave after one more year on the air.
