title: COMPANY NEWS;I.B.M. REPORTED READY TO REPLACE BUTTERFLY NOTEBOOK
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is considering abandoning its best-selling Butterfly notebook computer and replacing it with a new ultra-lightweight, much more powerful model, analysts and retailers said yesterday. The computer, a Thinkpad notebook that got its nickname for its two-part expandable keyboard, was introduced by the I.B.M. PC Company in March and racked up the most first-day sales of any product in the unit's history. "If you don't see Butterfly anymore, it'll be because you'll see something better," a company spokesman, Mike Corrado, said, adding that I.B.M. had not made a decision.

title: Rowland Plan Would Ease Early Adoption In Abuse Cases
description: In a plan to revamp Connecticut's child-protection system, Gov. John G. Rowland proposed legislation today to make it easier to remove children from troubled homes and put them up for adoption.

title: Disclosure on Ruptured Pipe's Installation Adds Bewilderment to anInquiry
description: The 60-inch water main that broke in Astoria, Queens, on Tuesday night, flooding a residential neighborhood, had been put into service only last summer, city officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OILFIELD EQUIPMENT COMPANY TO CHANGE HANDS
description: The Tuboscope Vetco International Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Drexel Oilfield Services, a maker of oilfield equipment, for stock valued at about $102.3 million at Wednesday's closing price. In a related transaction, SCF Partners, an investment group that is the largest shareholder in Drexel, will purchase Tuboscope stock and warrants for $31 million. SCF Partners will hold a 23 percent stake in Tuboscope after the acquisition of Drexel, which is privately held. L. E. Simmons, who founded Houston-based SCF Partners, is also chairman of Drexel, and he will become chairman of Tuboscope, which provides products and services for oil and gas pipelines. The shares of Tuboscope, which is based in Houston, were up $1.125, at $7.25, in Nasdaq trading. Tuboscope will acquire Drexel for 16.7 million Tuboscope shares.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Heileman Brewing Consolidates Work
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company in Rosemont, Ill., has consolidated the creative and media portions of its account at W. B. Doner & Company in Baltimore and Southfield, Mich. Though the billings were not disclosed, Advertising Age estimated them at less than $10 million.

title: Poland Seeks Compromise on Phones
description: Poland hopes to forge a compromise with the Ameritech Corporation and France Telecom in a dispute over plans for two cellular telephone networks, the telecommunications minister said today.

title: Mixed Results in December As Auto Sales Slip for Year
description: Auto makers ended 1995 with some surprisingly good and some surprisingly bad sales, capping a year that on the whole failed to live up to the industry's high expectations.

title: Israel Air Force Not for Her
description: An Israeli woman who won the right to become an air force pilot in a landmark court case has failed qualification exams for flight training, a military spokesman said today.

title: GOLF;The First Leader Is Corey Pavin
description: Since the opening round of the Mercedes Championship here at La Costa Resort and Spa today is the first official competitive golf of the new year -- now that the November/December Funny Money tailored-for-TV invitationals are over -- it seems appropriate to bring you a limited listing of official 1996 firsts.

title: HOCKEY;Brendan Byrne Arena Goes Continental
description: For nearly 15 years, it was officially the Brendan Byrne Arena. But that political homage to the former Democratic governor was covered forever today by a banner heralding the benefactor paying $29 million through 2007 as title sponsor of the arena: Continental Airlines.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHEVRON SAYS $800 MILLION CHARGE WILL RESULT IN LOSS
description: The Chevron Corporation said yesterday that new accounting standards for oil reserves and other assets would force it to take a charge of $800 million, resulting in a loss for the fourth quarter. About $680 million of the charge stems from the adoption of an accounting rule that changes the way corporations account for long-lived assets like oilfields. The rest of the charge stems from adjustments to other assets. The total charge amounts to about $1.23 a share. Chevron had been expected to report earnings of 73 cents for the quarter. The shares of Chevron were up $1.50, at $54.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Cunninghams Have Son
description: The Philadelphia Eagles backup quarterback RANDALL CUNNINGHAM and his wife, FELICITY, have a son.

title: DANCE REVIEW;The Games of Love, as Intricate as Chess
description: Irene Hultman transformed love and dance into games as intricate as chess in the works she offered on Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater. Her company, Irene Hultman Dance, was the opening attraction of Altogether Different, the Joyce's annual series of performances by up-and-coming choreographers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EARNINGS OUTLOOK IS CUT, HURTING TANDY STOCK
description: The stock of the Tandy Corporation, the consumer electronics giant, dropped sharply yesterday after the company revised its expectations for 1995 earnings, citing lower-than-expected computer sales at its Computer City and Incredible Universe stores in the final quarter of last year. The shares tumbled $4.75, to $35.125, a 52-week low, on the New York Stock Exchange. Tandy, which is based in Fort Worth, said its overall same-store sales, or those at stores open at least a year, were up 2 percent in December. Same-store sales at its Radio Shack chain increased 6 percent. But same-store sales fell 8 percent at Computer City and dropped 3 percent at Incredible Universe. Tandy said it expected profits for the full year to rise by 7 to 10 percent from $2.91 a share a year earlier.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Are Their Own Worst Enemy
description: The stares were those of disbelief and amazement. Somehow, the Nets had become their own worst enemy again, losing their composure along with their shooting touch and allowing the Knicks to steal a game the Nets were sure they could win.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Plummet On Delay in Budget Talks
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply late yesterday as budget meetings in Washington were unexpectedly postponed and investors grew wary about the progress of those talks.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE REPUBLICANS;Split and Bruised in Polls, G.O.P. Weighs New Tactics
description: As the partial Government shutdown limps toward its fourth week, Republicans on Capitol Hill have begun the search for an exit strategy, some way of breaking what looks increasingly like a stalemate that has badly shaken their unity.

title: Hootie Leads '95 Album Sales
description: In the executive suites of record labels, 1995 was the most turbulent period in the history of the industry. But on paper, it was yet another healthy year, with sales just slightly under last year's record-setting $11 billion. According to figures released yesterday by Soundscan, a company in Hartsdale, N.Y., that monitors retail sales, 714 million items of recorded music were sold this year, about 1.5 million less than last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A new survey seeks to gauge the research needs of American companies as they look abroad.
description: THE association representing companies that conduct marketing and opinion surveys for corporate America has conducted a survey of its own.

title: Hamburg Journal;Squatters Victorious! (A Checkbook Did It)
description: It's hard to tell if the squatters who are illegally occupying a block of buildings on the high-priced Hafenstrasse here are conventional middle-class families or hard-core radicals.

title: Ex-Officer Gets a 3-Month Term in Perjury
description: Still declaring his innocence, a former police officer from the corruption-plagued 30th Precinct in Harlem was sentenced to three months in prison for testifying falsely about a drug arrest.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Gadget-Mad America, Through Japanese Eyes
description: If you haven't devoted as much time as you might to contemplating the geriatric needs of the 21st century, don't fret. Katsuhiro Otomo, one of Japan's leading creators of animated films, has been hard at work studying the issues. And in his amusing futuristic morality tale, "Roujin-Z," he introduces a gadget designed to answer every need you could think of and some you could never imagine.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Limit on Hypnotic Testimony
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that testimony provided by a witness under hypnosis was not admissible in a 1969 murder case, the A.P. reported.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Steelers Drop Curtain On the Steel Curtain
description: The hottest topic around the Steelers a year ago was whether the defense was in the same class as the ones from the Steel Curtain era. Mention the defense now and you might as well be talking about the Iron Curtain.

description: The partial shutdown of the Federal Government is beginning to slow the nation's scientific efforts and hamper the operations of technical agencies that monitor everything from fisheries to earthquakes.

description: A yearlong study of a dozen leading health maintenance organizations serving the New York City area found that their quality and generosity vary widely and that company representatives frequently give wrong information over the phone.

title: Edgy U.N. Debates Sending Troops to Burundi
description: The Security Council, fearful that mounting violence in Burundi could be the prelude to widespread ethnic killings and the collapse of a fragile coalition Government, is struggling to find a way to prevent disaster, short of sending troops to the country.

title: Retailers Call Sales in December Worst Since '90-'91 Recession
description: In the culmination of a dismal year for retailers that may well lead to a further industry shakeout in the next few months, the nation's merchants reported the worst December sales figures yesterday since the 1990-91 recession.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Osborn to Buy Stations
description: The Osborn Communications Corporation agreed today to acquire radio stations KNAX-FM and KRBT-FM of Fresno, Calif., for about $7 million in cash and stock. The company said the transaction was subject to the approval of the Federal Communications Commission. Osborn said that pending closing of the transaction, it would manage the stations under a local marketing arrangement.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bill on Charter Schools Passes
description: New Jersey will become the 20th state in the nation to allow independent groups to set up charter schools -- schools financed by tax dollars and under the jurisdiction of the State Board of Education, but independent of the local school district. A bill to permit the establishment of 135 of these schools was sent to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday after the Assembly passed it by a vote of 66 to 8, and the Governor's office said she planned to sign it. "Charter schools promise to become the new laboratories of educational innovation," said the Assembly minority leader Joseph V. Doria, Democrat of Bayonne, and a sponsor of the legislation.

title: Eugene Underwood, 99, Admiralty Law Specialist
description: Eugene Underwood, a specialist in admiralty law who defended the owner of the Andrea Doria in a Federal court hearing arising from the 1956 sinking of the luxury liner, died on Monday at a nursing home in Orlando, Fla. He was 99.

title: S.E.C. Acts Against Two Brokerage Firms
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had revoked the broker-dealer registrations of F. N. Wolf & Company and L. C. Wegard & Company, and that it had imposed penalties totaling $6.4 million against them.

title: Workers Strike Office Towers In Manhattan
description: More than 30,000 maintenance workers at 1,000 large New York City office buildings went on strike yesterday after negotiations broke down over management's demand that new workers start at a far lower salary than current building workers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Marvel Reports Loss for Quarter
description: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. said yesterday that it would restructure its publishing and trading-card operations, resulting in 275 layoffs, a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $25 million and a loss for the quarter.

title: Alcohol Found in Pilot's Body in Colombian Crash
description: Tests in Colombia found alcohol in the remains of the captain of the American Airlines jet that crashed near Cali on Dec. 20, according to the Federal Aviation Administration, but it is not clear whether the pilot was drinking or the alcohol came from chemical processes that can take place after death.

title: Corrections
description: The Personal Computers column in Science Times on Tuesday about the PN-8500MDS Super Powernote computer from Brother International Corporation incorrectly described the device's ability to gain access to the World Wide Web. It is technically possible for the device to use software on remote computers to gain access to text, but no graphics, on the Web.

title: Abroad at Home;Anatomy of Disaster
description: How did Yugoslavia descend into the savagery that killed 200,000 people and made two million refugees? It is a question of signal importance, not just for history but as a key to seeing that it does not happen again, there or elsewhere.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE FALLOUT;Its Efforts Hampered, Agency Scrambles to Produce Flu Report
description: A day after President Clinton said the partial Government shutdown had impeded the collection of data on influenza, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued a report today, based largely on information gathered before the shutdown, that showed deaths from flu and pneumonia to be slightly above average in November and December.

title: Goldman Is Seen In Talks to Buy Bowling Giant
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company is negotiating to buy the AMF Corporation, the leader in the American bowling industry, for as much as $1 billion, people familiar with the negotiations say.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Agency to Foot Housing Bills
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency will pay for temporary housing for the people living in an artists' condominium complex in Hoboken that has apparently been contaminated by mercury, United States Representative Robert Menendez announced yesterday. Urine samples from 20 out of 29 residents of the 17-unit building showed hazardous levels of the chemical, which can cause kidney and neurological disorders. The building once housed a mercury vapor lamp factory. TERRY PRISTIN

Minneapolis-based Northwest will begin service with three flights a week in each direction. Northwest can increase that service to nine flights by 1998 under a United States-China agreement.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENERAL HOUSEWARES TO STOP MAKING SOME LINES
description: The General Housewares Corporation said yesterday that it planned to stop making cast-iron and cast-aluminum cookware in the first half of the year. The company said the brand names affected were Wagner's 1891 Original Cast Iron Cookware, Magnalite Classic Cookware and Magnalite Professional Cookware. The company said it was in talks with potential buyers for the lines and possibly for the plant where they are made, in Sidney, Ohio. General Housewares, based in Terre Haute, Ind., said it might record a write-down of assets in the first quarter. The businesses accounted for about 15 percent of General Housewares' sales last year.

title: Deaths at Hospital Said Not to Reflect Systemwide Flaws
description: New York State health investigators said yesterday that a cluster of deaths and serious injuries that occurred after surgery at Long Island Jewish Medical Center last spring did not reflect systemwide problems at the hospital, but they cited the hospital for delivering substandard care in some of the cases.

description: The Masco Corporation announced yesterday that Morgan Stanley Capital Partners had terminated its plans for a $1.1 billion purchase of the company's home furnishings division.

description: Compuserve Inc. said yesterday that it planned to restore access to 200 sexually oriented Internet discussion groups as soon as it found a way to block them from subscribers in Germany. Last week, Compuserve, a unit of H & R Block, blocked all access to the groups after German prosecutors said the material violated the country's pornography laws. The company, whose subscribers get access to the Internet by paying monthly fees, said it did not have the capability to screen out German subscribers. The discussion groups are places on the Internet where computer users can post messages for all to see.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Acquisition
description: Philips Electronics said yesterday that it had acquired a majority stake in Holland Advertising Nieuwe Media B.V., a Dutch electronic media company. Philips said its media division had bought the 51 percent stake in Holland Advertising as part of its plan to expand in new electronic media and cable networks. The company gave no financial details of the transaction. Holland Advertising is one of the country's largest providers of cable news text and electronic information services, according to Philips. (AP)

description: On Piano

title: NYC;Going by Foot, And Searching For Respect
description: HERE'S this New Yorker, not overly adventurous, who nonetheless has seen his share of armed conflicts up close while overseas. Now he's returned safely, but is haunted by visions of dying violently on the sidewalks of his hometown: not gunned down, but run over by a bicycle rider making deliveries for a Chinese restaurant. And if the deliveryman doesn't finish him off, the courier coming up silently from behind on his bike surely will.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Impostor a Bettor, Too
description: An impostor on the Texas football team may have placed bets on sports events for a small number of other players on the team, the Texas athletic director, DeLOSS DODDS, said yesterday.

title: G.O.P. Dropout's Party History Is Wrong
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Adobe Stock Plunges 23% as Earnings Trail Wall St. Expectations
description: The shares of Adobe Systems Inc. tumbled 23 percent in after-hours trading today after the company reported a loss for the fiscal fourth quarter and operating income that was well below Wall Street analysts' expectations.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Vote to Ban Toy Guns
description: Bringing a toy gun to school would be a crime under a bill that was passed yesterday by the Assembly and sent to Governor Whitman. Violators would face six months in jail and a $1,000 fine.

title: Wait a Second! That Was a Leap Day
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ORDERS BEAT EXPECTATIONS, BUT DELIVERIES SLIP
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it had won 346 orders for new airplanes, worth $31.2 billion, last year, exceeding its projection and giving it 69.7 percent of the world market. Boeing, the world's largest maker of commercial airplanes, said the total included new orders for 85 airplanes that had not been previously announced or that had been announced only as intended orders. The company said it delivered 36 commercial jets in the fourth quarter, bringing its total for the year to 206. That was down from 271 deliveries in 1994. Boeing executives had planned to deliver 65 planes in the fourth quarter, but that figure was reduced because of the 10-week strike by the machinists' union.

title: New Faces in Grammy Nominations
description: There will be plenty of new faces at the 38th annual Grammy Awards ceremony this year, which is shaping to be a duel between two new female singers, Alanis Morissette and Joan Osborne.

title: To Control the Media: Click the 'Off' Button
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage, and Off
description: The Story So Far

title: FILM REVIEW;When Models Have Sex, The Lighting's the Thing
description: Sex without sweat. Sex without playfulness. Sex without expression, unless you call the sullen come-hither attitude of a Calvin Klein model an expression: Zalman King's newest soft-core romance is a fashion shoot pretending to be an erotic film. Although the movie, which was adapted from Anais Nin's novel "Delta of Venus," is filled with pretty people shuffled into an array of inviting sexual tableaux, it doesn't have a trace of passion.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOBILE TELECOMMUNICATION SAYS CHIEF WILL STEP DOWN
description: The shares of the Mobile Telecommunication Technologies Corporation, which provides paging service, fell yesterday after the company said Bernard Puckett would step down as chief executive. On Wednesday, after the close of trading, Mtel said Mr. Puckett would leave the company for "personal considerations" and would become a consultant to Mtel. John N. Palmer, the chairman, will become acting chief executive. Mark Roberts, an analyst at Alex. Brown, cut his rating on Mtel shares to "buy" from "strong buy." Mtel's shares fell $1.6875, to $19.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: BASEBALL;Awaiting the Word From Washington
description: The shutdown of the Federal Government, triggered by the kind of negotiating failure familiar to Major League Baseball, is being felt in baseball as well as other more obvious sectors of society.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Several months ago, JOHN C. WHITEHEAD, a former Deputy Secretary of State who was named this week to be chairman of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, began thinking how to shrink the United States' debt to the United Nations.

title: HOCKEY;Canada's 'Big Tree' Has Bright Future
description: In the Yoruba language of Nigeria, the family name Iginla -- means "big tree." This is according to the father, Elvis Iginla, whose first name means "king of rock and roll" in the cultural language of North America.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Panel Backs Measure on Jobs
description: Two bills backed by the Whitman administration that would offer companies incentives to create new jobs in New Jersey cleared the Assembly Budget Committee yesterday. One bill would give grants to businesses that create new jobs; the other would enable companies to recover up to half of their relocation costs.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;Another Winter at Work for Cruguet
description: It was 18 degrees when Jean Cruguet stepped from the jockeys' quarters into the paddock at Aqueduct race track yesterday and joined half a dozen other riders for the third race of a day fit for neither man nor beast. Nor, for that matter, for senior citizens like Cruguet, who is 56 years old and still riding race horses 19 years after he rode Seattle Slew to his sweep of the Triple Crown.

title: Diner's Journal
description: When Lundy's closed 16 years ago in Sheepshead Bay, it was one of Brooklyn's best-loved institutions. When it reopened (under new owners) just after Thanksgiving, the response was immediate. Although the restaurant seats 400 people, a sign on the door read, "Reservations necessary during December."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Ex-Kidder Trader Is Expected to Face Limited Sanctions
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission will soon bring civil fraud charges against Joseph Jett, the former Kidder, Peabody trader accused of creating $350 million in phantom profits, people familiar with the case said yesterday.

title: U.S. Likely to Issue Transit Visa for Taiwanese Official
description: Despite the risk of touching off new protests from China, the State Department appears likely to issue a transit visa sought by Taiwan's Vice President.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Hating The Sin. Hating A Sinner More.
description: British television excels at political thrillers, the exquisitely devastating kind like "A Very British Coup." The latest example can be found, beginning tomorrow at 9 P.M. on PBS, in a two-part, three-hour production imported for "Masterpiece Theater." It's "The Politician's Wife," starring Juliet Stevenson as Flora Matlock, wife of philandering Duncan (Trevor Eve), who just happens to be the Conservative Party's Minister for the Family.

title: School Safety Divides Giuliani and Crew
description: In their first squabble since Rudy Crew became Schools Chancellor in October, he and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani disagreed sharply yesterday over whether the Board of Education or the Police Department should bear ultimate responsibility for insuring safety within the city's more than 1,000 public schools.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LAZARD SAID TO BE IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE A FIRM
description: The investment firm of W. R. Lazard & Company is in talks to acquire another firm, according to the newsletter P & I Daily. Melvin Neal, Lazard vice president, told P & I the discussions were in the early stages but he would not name the other firm. P & I said Smith, Graham Asset Management was rumored to be the other party, but both Mr. Neal and Ladell Graham, chairman of Smith Graham, denied it. Lazard, based in New York, is Wall Street's largest black-owned firm. Graham is also minority-owned. Mr. Neal confirmed that his firm was in the early stages of acquisition talks with another firm. He said the other firm was engaged in the equities business but declined to specify the name of the firm or any other details.

title: A Park Worth Millions, and He Can't Give It Away
description: It is a gift worth $19 million that William Rutherford wants to make to the public: a 2,000-acre wildlife park inhabited by bison, bobcats, otters, eagles, badgers and other animals, with trails for hiking and viewing, and lodging and banquet accommodations.

title: 2 Rappers Charged in Death of Policewoman
description: Two Philadelphia rap performers and a third man have been charged with killing a policewoman this week in a botched bank robbery.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Boy Made to Drink Ammonia
description: An Englewood man forced his 3-year-old son to drink ammonia while arguing with the child's mother over visitation rights early yesterday, the authorities said. The child, Vaughn Henry, was hospitalized in critical condition. After brandishing a knife and forcing the boy to drink the ammonia, the father, Darien Henry, 38, drank a quantity himself and died, the Bergen County Prosecutor's office told the A.P.

title: Yeltsin the Politician Agrees To Let Top Liberal Aide Go
description: In the first major concession of the presidential race, President Boris N. Yeltsin accepted the resignation today of his Foreign Minister, Andrei V. Kozyrev, one of the last liberals in his increasingly hard-line Cabinet.

title: K-Rock Updates Its Music
description: Station WXRK (or K-Rock, at 92.3 FM), the only one in the New York metropolitan area still playing classic rock, switched its format yesterday to alternative and modern rock.

title: Scenes From the Strike: Angry Faces, Jobs Undone
description: Sporadic picket-line violence was reported, some garbage went uncollected, scores of packages were not delivered and a food bank for the poor was unable to pick up many donations yesterday as a strike by 30,000 maintenance workers against 1,000 office buildings in New York City went through a second day.

title: New Yorkers Are Finally Getting Their Promised Tax Relief;More $ to Love N Y
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Voucher Program Advised
description: An advisory panel on school vouchers recommended that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman consider a $5 million pilot project to help subsidize tuition for private and parochial schools. The state would offer vouchers for up to $3,500 for each selected student over five years during the pilot project. Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean is head of the panel, which recommended that the program be tried out in one district in each county.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Faulk to Miss Playoff Game
description: Knee surgery will keep the All-Pro running back Marshall Faulk of the Indianapolis Colts out of Sunday's American Conference playoff game against the Chiefs.

title: Surrender to Burmese Troops May End Opium Baron's Rule
description: The 30-year reign of one of the world's most notorious opium barons, Khun Sa, appears to have come to an end with his surrender this week in Myanmar in return for a promise of amnesty.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;What's in an Arena Name? Plenty, Nets Claim in Lawsuit
description: The New Jersey Nets have asked a state court to halt the implementation of the $29 million deal to rename Brendan Byrne Arena for Continental Airlines, charging it violates the National Basketball Association team's advertising rights in the facility.

title: On Briefings, Clinton Lets Tradition Lag
description: Has the prime-time Presidential news conference gone the way of Tyrannosaurus rex?

title: Leon Schwab, 85, Co-Founder Of Hollywood Drugstore of Stars
description: Leon Schwab, co-founder of the Sunset Boulevard pharmacy that was a meeting place for Hollywood stars and would-be stars from the 1930's through the 1950's, died on Thursday in Harbor South Medical Center in Los Angeles County. He was 85.

title: Elusive Papers of Law Firm Are Found at White House
description: After nearly two years of searches and subpoenas, the White House said this evening that it had unexpectedly discovered copies of missing documents from Hillary Rodham Clinton's law firm that describe her work for a failing savings and loan association in the 1980's.

title: Subpoena Issued in Travel Office Inquiry
description: The Congressional panel investigating the White House travel office dismissals today subpoenaed a former Presidential aide to testify next week about a newly discovered memorandum saying that Hillary Rodham Clinton was much more deeply involved in the ousters than the White House had acknowledged.

title: Equestrian Officials Accept State Terms
description: International equestrian officials today reluctantly accepted Georgia's terms for allowing horses infected with a tick-borne virus to compete in the Summer Olympics.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF DURACELL FALL ON EARNINGS WARNING
description: Shares of Duracell International Inc. dropped sharply yesterday after the company, the nation's largest maker of alkaline batteries, said profits for the latest quarter would be disappointing. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Duracell closed down $3.875 at $47.875. The company said earnings in its second quarter, which ended on Dec. 30, were hurt by a weak United States retail environment during the holiday season. Duracell said it would release its second-quarter earnings on Jan. 25.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;High-Level Talks In Labor Dispute
description: The chief labor representatives of the owners and the players will meet Monday to find out where they stand in the virtually nonexistent talks in baseball's labor dispute.

title: Divorce, New York Style
description: Invoking Section 170 of New York State's domestic relations law, each year some 28,000 unhappy husbands and wives bring their marital and family disputes to the New York State Supreme Court.

title: William Lockhart, 89, a Constitutional Scholar
description: William Bailey Lockhart, a scholar who helped formulate the constitutional underpinnings of early civil-rights legislation and headed a Presidential commission on pornography, died on Monday at University Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 89 and had lived in Sandy, Utah.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Money Move
description: The Bundesbank set the stage yesterday for declines in German money market rates by lending banks extra funds in an unexpected move. The central bank lent 3 billion marks ($2.1 billion) under five-day securities repurchase agreements at a rate of 3.75 percent to prevent a shortage in the money market from pushing rates up. Economists said the cash infusion, only the second unscheduled round of credits in the last year, would keep a downward bias on money rates when the Bundesbank allots its regular credits to banks next Wednesday. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Andre Dawson Signs
description: ANDRE DAWSON, who finished last season as the fourth most senior player in the major leagues, reached agreement with the Florida Marlins yesterday on what he has said will be his last contract. Dawson, a 41-year-old free agent, agreed to a contract that technically is for the minor leagues but will pay the outfielder $500,000 when he wins a job with the Marlins, for whom he batted .257 in 79 games last season.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SWING-N-SLIDE CORP., Janesville, Wis., a maker of wooden playground equipment, said that Greengrass Holding had agreed to buy up to 59 percent of its common shares outstanding for $6.50 each in a tender offer valued at $22.8 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRESSTEK CANCELS OFFERING AND SWITCHES AUDITORS
description: A executive of Presstek Inc. said yesterday that the company had canceled a sale of unregistered stock to international investors. "We have since canceled it," said Dick Williams, Presstek's corporate secretary. The company did not give a reason for canceling the offering, and it declined to elaborate. Shares of the printing equipment maker closed up $3.25, at $86.75, in Nasdaq trading. On Thursday, the company said it had dismissed Deloitte & Touche as its auditor. That day, its shares closed down $10.75.

title: Competition to Begin for Local Phone Calls, Ending a Monopoly
description: By the end of the month, if things go as state officials hope, the era of the monopoly telephone company will end in Connecticut.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Small Family-Run Stores in Spain Are Fighting to Limit the Hypermarkets
description: At lunchtime, Angel Pena closes his little grocery store on the narrow street behind the Spanish Parliament in order to enjoy a leisurely meal and a short siesta.

title: New' Rules for Midwives Are Standard Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;A New-Look Lee Janzen Grabs Second-Round Lead
description: At first glance, see if this doesn't look like a formula for disaster: A golfer has the most successful year of his career, winning three tournaments and $1.37 million on the PGA Tour, and then decides to go through a few changes. So he switches management companies, changes his clothing endorsement, plays a new ball and gets different clubs.

title: New' Rules for Midwives Are Standard Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Premier Resigns in Sign Of a Party Shift
description: The abrupt resignation today of Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama stunned Japan and triggered a political struggle that will lead not only to a new prime minister but perhaps also to a major political realignment.

title: Port of Spain Journal;Star Batsman Lashes Out, Sending Cricket Reeling
description: Imagine that after breaking the season record for home runs, baseball's top power hitter suddenly quits his team on the eve of the World Series, complaining of his manager's inability to maintain discipline. In retribution, the commissioner's office fines him 10 percent of his salary, and fans erupt in anger against management.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FED APPROVES MERGER OF CHASE AND CHEMICAL
description: The Federal Reserve Board approved a $10 billion marriage of the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation. The merger would create the nation's largest bank. The Fed's decision is just one of several steps required before the two banks can merge. The deal still requires approval from New York banking regulators. The banks said they planned to merge on March 31. The Fed's approval came after a closed meeting, a board spokeswoman said. Details were not immediately available. The merger would create a bank with $297 billion in assets and 2,000 offices.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Rising Prices of Oil and Gold Drive Up Index of Commodities
description: Crude oil prices rose above the psychologically important level of $20 a barrel yesterday for the first time since May 1995 on reports of supply restrictions.

title: Observer;Fun for Politics Junkies
description: It must delight Democrats to watch the Republicans play cutthroat in the budget quarrel. The man Republicans are out to get is, after all, their own leading contender for the Presidential nomination, a.k.a. Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.

title: Vexed By Eurotunnel, They Slash Fares : Ferry Companies Get Cross
description: LONDON  Spurred by increasingly stiff competition from Eurotunnel, the operator of the Dover-Calais undersea rail service, the ferry companies that ply the English Channel are slashing back.

title: New' Rules for Midwives Are Standard Practice
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Bob Flanagan, 43, Performer Who Fashioned Art From His Pain
description: Bob Flanagan, a performance artist and poet whose writing and bizarre, sadomasochistic performances centered on his lifelong battle with an incurable illness, died on Thursday at Long Beach Memorial Hospital in Long Beach. He was 43 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RETAILER'S DEBT RATINGS MAY BE RAISED
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's debt ratings may be raised by the Standard & Poor's Corporation after the retailer's holiday sales outshined those of its big rivals. S.& P. said yesterday that it was reviewing its "BBB" rating on Sears's senior unsecured debt and preferred stock for a possible upgrade. On Thursday, Sears said its December same-store sales jumped 6.8 percent, helped by the first $1 billion sales week in its 103-year history. The retailer said sales were strong in fine jewelry, shoes, consumer electronics and home-improvement goods. The shares of Sears closed yesterday up $1.50, to $42, their highest point in at least 15 years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CIRCLE K STOCK POSTS 18 PERCENT DROP
description: The stock of the Circle K Corporation fell 18 percent yesterday after the convenience-store chain said it expected its third-quarter earnings to be less than Wall Street's expectations. Circle K, based in Phoenix, said its profit margins from gasoline sales had been below seasonal expectations for the quarter. But the company expects to offset a part of that through higher merchandise profits and lower operating expenses. Circle K said that gasoline margins were returning to normal and that its margins for the full year would be "in line with expectations." Circle K stock closed at $20.125 a share, down $4.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mr. Murayama Departs
description: Japan's Prime Minister, Tomiichi Murayama, who resigned yesterday, was a weak and transitional political figure. Little of lasting significance, either domestically or internationally, was accomplished during his 18 months of rule. Yet he made a potentially important contribution to the future of Japanese democracy by weaning his Socialist Party from its outdated program of rigid opposition to the basic foreign policies of postwar Japan.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants' Brown Has Surgery
description: While Giants quarterback Dave Brown is sure to be an attractive free agent in the off season, it's the least of his concerns. Brown will have surgery to repair cartilage in his knee, and although it should not prevent him from attending training camp, the recovery time could be from two to four months.

title: Israel and Syria Upbeat as Early Talks Close
description: Israeli and Syrian negotiators today concluded six days of preliminary talks on a possible peace agreement that Secretary of State Warren Christopher said were marked by "a new sense of pragmatism" and a "mutuality of purpose" that were missing in the past.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday reported concerns about the sale of impure olive oil in the United States. But the article considerably overstated the extent of the problem, to a degree that undercuts its basic premise.

title: On-the-Job Training For a Prosecutor;Neighborhood Mobsters Learn She's No Longer a Novice
description: Leslie R. Caldwell was in over her head. As a relatively new Federal prosecutor, she had been thrust into a major role in the prosecution of one of New York City's most notorious drug-trafficking rings and "I didn't know what I was doing," she said, recalling a sensation of drowning.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Finding Nature, and Inspiration, at a Summer Camp
description: Kharisma Gray, 13, was just 5 when the police took her from her abusive mother.

title: Republicans' Boomerang
description: Republicans in Congress insisted on Friday that by abruptly ending a Government shutdown, they were only regrouping their forces for a long and dug-in battle with the White House over how to balance the Federal budget.

title: One Type of Bond Fund That May Have Crested
description: After five years in which hundreds of single-state municipal bond funds have been started, mutual fund companies are quietly closing or consolidating some. This is a result of a lack of interest from investors, and, in some states, a scant supply of municipal bonds.

title: Gang Members Held in Drug Deals
description: Law enforcement officials have arrested more than a dozen members of two loosely connected drug gangs that are charged with selling heroin near City College in upper Manhattan. The gangs are believed to have killed eight people, including a building superintendent who tried to organize tenants against drug dealers.

title: The Way to a Budget Compromise
description: Now that Government offices will be open in a fashion, perhaps Congress and the White House can resolve the issue that has shut down Government twice already and threatens to do so again in three weeks: a seven-year deficit-reduction plan. The two sides are not nearly as far apart as their election-year posturing would pretend. There is one principled difference -- whether Medicaid should be Federally guaranteed -- but the other disagreements are overwhelmingly rhetorical.

title: U.S. Rights Group Asserts China Lets Thousands of Orphans Die
description: A New York-based human rights organization asserted today that thousands of children have died in China's state-run orphanages from deliberate starvation, medical malpractice and staff abuse.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Sadness, Praise, Relief From Dolphin Faithful
description: The way Manny Fernandez sees it, Don Shula would still be the Miami Dolphins' coach if not for the barrage of criticism cluttering the airwaves on South Florida talk radio this season.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Venezuela Plans Sale
description: Venezuela said yesterday that it expected to sell four state-owned hotels in 1996. The Venezuelan Investment Fund, the agency in charge of selling state assets, said it planned to sell the Humboldt Hotel in Caracas, Posada de Sanare in the western state of Lara, the Bella Vista Hotel on Margarita Island and the Aguas Calientes Hotel in the southwestern state of Tachira. The agency also wants to sell a cable car operation that connects the capital with the seaport of La Guaira. Officials said they expected to raise at least 3 billion bolivars ($10.3 million).

title: Simpson Again Granted a Delay In Testifying in a Civil Lawsuit
description: O. J. Simpson won another reprieve today from his deposition that was scheduled to begin on Monday in the wrongful-death lawsuit brought against him by the families of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: POP
description: Another Face for the Blues With a Lap Steel Guitar Sonny Rhodes

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Lose Large Lead But Pull Out The Victory
description: What looked to be an easy rout turned into another character test for the Nets tonight. But whereas on Thursday night they crumbled under the second-half pressure applied by the Knicks, the Nets held up tonight against a less formidable foe, the Dallas Mavericks.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;In Rebound From Weak Year, Chinese Stocks Are Surging
description: Shares in Chinese companies have been surging on world markets since the year began, a marked contrast to their weakness in 1995. While analysts and fund managers say that some of the stocks are likely to maintain their gains, they warn that other issues have been merely pulled up in the excitement and could fall sharply if corporate earnings weaken.

title: Stocks Revive After Move In House to End Shutdown
description: Stock prices were whipsawed yesterday, with stocks recovering in the afternoon after the House moved to end the partial Government shutdown.

title: Excerpts From the Report On Policing the Schools
description: Following are excerpts from the report of the Mayor's Investigatory Commission on School Safety urging that the police take over the Division of School Safety:

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: COMPANY NEWS;NOVATEK TO BUY MEDICAL PRODUCTS FOR $72 MILLION
description: Novatek International Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Medical Products Inc. for $72 million in cash, debt and stock. Novatek, a building materials company based in Boynton Beach, Fla., said that the acquisition would raise its revenue because Medical Products holds a license to distribute and market diagnostic kits in South America. Medical Products distributes kits made by Universal Health Watch of Columbia, Md. Universal Health holds patents to 12 home-test kits for detecting diseases including cholera, herpes and H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, within 10 minutes. Novatek makes building materials like steel wall supports and concrete panels.

title: Ramon Vinay, 83, a Chilean; Tenor and Baritone Sang at Met
description: Ramon Vinay, a Chilean-born singer best known for his performances of Italian and German heroic-tenor roles, died on Thursday at a home for the elderly in Puebla, near Mexico City. He was 83.

title: Checks and Balances
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL -- Coached Make the Calls: Reeves Stays, Shula Goes;Giants Coach Finally Accepts The Status Quo
description: Giants Coach Dan Reeves is staying put as the head coach, his decision ending what was probably one of the rockiest weeks in his life, and in the life of the team as well. How he came to the decision was a wild ride that was almost as unexpected as the decision itself.

title: Bridge
description: There have been many fathers and sons who were star players, but star fathers and daughters are rarer. Nicola Smith of England has won two world titles, and her father, Nico Gardener, just missed winning one. Billy Seamon won five national titles, and his daughter, Janice Seamon, has four. Morris Elis won six major titles, and his daughter, Judy Tucker, has won four.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Chargers Let O'Neal Go
description: The San Diego Chargers said goodbye to defensive end LESLIE O'NEAL and third-down specialist Ronnie Harmon yesterday, just two of several moves that will reshape a team that fell far short of defending its American Football Conference championship.

title: Palestinian Believed to Be Bombing Mastermind Is Killed
description: The man most wanted by Israel, a Palestinian known as "The Engineer" who was believed to be behind a series of suicide bombings targeting Israelis in recent years, was killed today in the Gaza Strip, according to some reports with a booby-trapped cellular phone.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China Says Growth and Inflation Eased in 1995
description: Chinese economic growth slowed slightly last year, the State Statistical Bureau said today, but that was in keeping with the Government's efforts to curb inflation, which slowed considerably.

title: No Headline
description: We're going to have to buy toilet paper. What will we tell our clients? 'Hi, how are you, here's some toilet paper?"

title: Two Cousins Fatally Shot; Police See It As Revenge
description: In a suspected revenge slaying, a 21-year-old man and his 15-year-old cousin were gunned down early yesterday in the lobby of an apartment house in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Robley Evans, Radioactivity Pioneer, Dies at 88
description: Dr. Robley D. Evans, a nuclear physicist who helped persuade the Government to allow the use of radioactive isotopes in medical research in the 1940's and who helped set the standard for permissible human exposure, died on Sunday in Paradise Valley, Ariz., where he lived. He was 88.

title: Editorial Notebook;Small Theater
description: An evening at the theater in New York does not always mean an evening on Broadway. Instead it can mean a night in a loft, a garage, a church or a space with an indefinable provenance, often on a street unknown to all but the most committed explorers. For countless theater folk, these modest stages are where it all began. But if these little theaters are places in which big dreams come naturally, the budgets with which to realize them are usually minuscule. "It's really hand to mouth," Albert Harris says, "with companies like mine."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Dutch Publisher Seeks Entertainment Concern
description: The Dutch publisher Wegener N.V. is in talks to acquire all the shares of the entertainment company Arcade Beheer B.V., the two companies said yesterday. The merger would create a company with assets in publishing, multimedia and entertainment. Arcade's divisions include CNR Music and Vanguard Classics, both record companies, and Arcade TV, a television and marketing concern. (Dow Jones)

title: School Safety Battle
description: Mayor Giuliani and Chancellor Crew disagreed sharply over whether the school board or the police should be in charge of school safety.

title: Office Space Gets Tighter
description: The average vacancy rate in North America's stock of office properties fell last year to 14.3 percent from 16.2 percent in 1994, according to Oncor International, an organization of commercial real estate firms.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INSIDE
description: Hamas Member Is Killed A Palestinian known as "The Engineer," who was believed to be behind a series of attacks against Israelis, was killed in the Gaza Strip. Page 3.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST NATIONWIDE RAISES BID FOR LOMAS FINANCIAL
description: First Nationwide Bank has increased its offer for assets of the Lomas Financial Corporation by $7.75 million, or 5.2 percent, to $157.75 million. Lomas disclosed the higher offer in a filing in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., where the Dallas-based mortgage-servicing company filed for Chapter 11 protection on Oct. 10. First Nationwide is offering more money for less of Lomas Financial. The original bid was for the entire company. Now First Nationwide is not bidding for Lomas's insurance business. Last month, Judge Peter Walsh sided with Lomas's creditors and allowed them to seek bidders other than First Nationwide.

title: Long Bond Ends Lower in Day of Mixed Prices
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the longer maturities moving lower.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MIRAGE RESORTS SEES HIGHER-THAN-EXPECTED EARNINGS
description: Mirage Resorts Inc. expects to report higher-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings in "the mid-40's cents per share," helped by December winnings of $61 million, the chief financial officer, Daniel Lee, said. The results would exceed Wall Street analysts' estimates of 42 cents a share, based on the average estimate of 17 analysts surveyed recently by Zacks Investment Research. Mirage, the owner of four casino resort hotels in Las Vegas, Nev., earned 34 cents a share a year ago.

title: Haiti Asks U.N. to Extend Troop Presence

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Van Sought in Hit-Run Case
description: The state police said yesterday that they were looking for information about a light-colored mini-van that struck a trooper who was pushed into traffic by a woman stopped for suspected drunken driving. title: H.M.O. Gag Rules
description: Health maintenance organizations have come under heavy criticism for imposing two types of "gag" rules on conversations between doctors and patients. Some H.M.O.'s forbid primary care doctors from disclosing bonuses that they are paid by the H.M.O. for holding down costly referrals to specialists. Some H.M.O.'s forbid doctors from criticizing the plan to their patients or advocating treatments that the H.M.O. will not approve.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHEMICAL CONCERN TO TAKE $83 MILLION IN TWO CHARGES
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it would take two fourth-quarter charges totaling $83 million for an accounting change and for remaining liabilities in a class-action lawsuit. The company, a chemical and energy concern, said it would take a charge of $38 million, or 7 cents a share, to cover its liabilities in a recently settled nationwide class-action lawsuit related to reportedly defective plumbing systems. Du Pont, based in Wilmington, Del., also said it would take a charge of $45 million, or 8 cents a share, to cover a change in the method of accounting for long-lived assets, primarily relating to the write-down of North American and European petroleum assets.

title: Cut Another $100 Million, Giuliani Tells His Aides

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fire Disrupts Commuter Lines
description: More than 1,000 rail commuters got snagged on their way to work yesterday as firefighters from seven towns dragged hoses across tracks to battle a large fire at a self-storage warehouse off Route 202. New Jersey Transit said 16 trains were delayed or canceled on the Port Jervis and Main lines. Service was suspended for about two hours at nine stations, from Mahwah to Port Jervis, N.Y., beginning at 6:15 A.M., as workers dug trenches to thread fire hoses under the tracks.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Police Get Reinforcements

Call it "When Bad Exhibitions Happen to Good Ideas." My list has just acquired a new leader, "Painting Outside Painting," the 44th Biennial Exhibition of contemporary American painting at the Corcoran Gallery of Art here, a show that didn't have to be the way it is.

title: The Most Dangerous Game
description: IT'S THE SUNDOWNER HOUR IN THE DESERT OF northern Kenya, and Richard Leakey, the famed paleoanthropologist, has arrived at his camp's mess tent dressed for dinner: his beige polo shirt is tucked neatly into a brightly striped African sarong, which skims the tops of his safari boots. This get-up might look affected on some men, but Leakey, 51, wears it with the aplomb of a native. His face is ruddy from a day in the sun, and with a rocking gait he swings toward a small knot of friends and family gathered in a semicircle of camp chairs. By tacit agreement, the center chair is reserved for him -- the lord of this desert castle. He grasps the chair by both arms, then, with a frown of concentration, settles his bulk. "There, that's better," he says, as his daughter Louise, 23, offers to fetch him a drink. He stretches out his artificial legs -- replacements for the ones he lost in a plane crash two years ago -- and smiles.

title: The Price Is Right
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article "World Class Shopping" (Dec. 3). The picture of the musk melons that cost about $300 a pair finally clarified a problem for me. In 1966, my husband and I were walking along the Ginza when I stopped to look at a basket of melons that cost $20 each. My husband had walked on and when I told him how much the melons cost, he said that I had converted the yen incorrectly. Over the years of many travel adventures, he has always teased me about my math. Now, I am absolutely certain that the melons were in fact $20 apiece, and perhaps even $30 at that time. What a difference 30 years can make. Thanks for helping me say I was right. PEGGY POPOVITCH Seaside, Calif.

title: BOOKEND;The Book That Ruined Melville
description: TWO or three years ago the news from the land of literary readers was all about the death of the canon. This fall has witnessed a curious reverse: a return to works by classic authors, driven by developments extraneous to the books. Jane Austen's "Persuasion" has become an object of brisk interest again in the wake of the film adaptation. ("Filmed without a single anachronism!"the taped phone message at my local movie house crowed.) "Othello"and "Sense and Sensibility" are catching similarly reflected interest from their film derivatives, and television has done comparable favors for Edith Wharton's "Buccaneers." Somewhere, someone may even be reading "The Scarlet Letter" and wondering why the book leaves so much out.

title: How Does a Novel Grow?
description: A GARDEN STORY By Leon Whiteson. 168 pp. Boston: Faber & Faber. $18.95. LEON WHITESON'S book belongs to a genus that is coming back into fashion after a dormant spell: the miniature memoir, almost an extended essay, partial but intense, more rumination than narrative. It is not unusual for a book of this type to have a presiding metaphor or resonating motif. The writer tours himself, and takes the reader with him, while ostensibly looking out from that self onto its preoccupations. "In Patagonia," by Bruce Chatwin, is a model of the type, fabulously self-absorbed but exhilaratingly inclusive.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;An Unstill Life
description: The life and work of the Italian photographer Tina Modotti (1896-1942) have become fodder for such a variety of causes that Sarah M. Lowe's vow to write Modotti's "cultural biography" and "dislodge her from the center of her legend" may cause cynics' eyebrows to arch in suspicion. Yet, as the author's intelligent introductory essay to the 150 elegant duotone photographs reproduced in TINA MODOTTI: Photographs (Philadelphia Museum of Art/Abrams, $45) soon makes clear, Ms. Lowe means what she says. She has done extensive research about the political, social and cultural contexts of Modotti's many whereabouts. Tina Modotti was an uneducated working-class girl in turn-of-the-century Italy and a sophisticated actress, muse and femme fatale in Hollywood before spending the years from 1923 to 1930 in Mexico, where she became an increasingly political photographer; later, among other activities, she was a relief worker in the Spanish Civil War. Ms. Lowe, an art historian and curator, puts the facts of Modotti's life in illuminating perspective, tracing the artist's esthetic development, her ties to the Modernist movement and her awareness of the conflict between making art and making politics. If "Experiment in Related Form" (1924) -- a double exposure of five glasses of differing sizes whose rims seem to float, intersect and shine all at once -- means freedom from the austere esthetic of Edward Weston, Modotti's lover and teacher of photography, the sea of sombreros in "Workers Parade" (1926) marks Modotti's first expression of her disappointment with the unfulfilled promises of the Mexican revolution and her commitment to a new social order. From portraits of Aztec mothers with their infants to "Mella's Typewriter" (a close-up of a Communist lover's instrument of intellectual and political activity), Modotti's tight cropping and still-life esthetic excelled at melding Mexican culture and Modernist photography. CHRISTINE SCHWARTZ HARTLEY

title: Sunday January 7, 1996: INVENTION;Aw, Shucks!
description: If necessity is the mother of invention, frustration is its father. Take Yves Renaut and his fil a huitre, or oyster thread. Fed up with countless close shaves with the knife, Renaut decided there had to be a better way to open an oyster. So one day about a year ago, this unemployed native of Rennes threaded a small metal ring on some fishing line, waited for an oyster to gape and looped the line around its valve muscle so that the ring protruded from the shell's two halves. Voila, mechanized oysters. One good idea deserves another, and Renaut discovered that oysters, when plunged into a saline solution, become sleepy and yawn -- long enough for the oyster thread and tab to be harmlessly slipped into place. His ringed oysters went on sale in France at Christmastime and seem to have been well received. The world, as they say, is now Renaut's oyster. But by the time it hits our shores, it'll be his oyster six pack.

That morning, there were no somber rallies along Elmhurst's bustling Broadway, no artful commemorations of the lives claimed by the epidemic. There was just Ms. Li, 34, a vivacious immigrant from China, offering the gospel of safe sex over buckets of tart dried plums at the Kam Lun Market.

It used its own industry and dealt with its own people, then it fell into decline. New ideas invigorate its changed circumstances, but now there are competitors nearby: large, fierce and distinctly urban ones, all competing for the same shrinking resources.

Then she established a winning tradition, and the Stags (no longer the Lady Stags) began to draw spectators -- about 200 per home game in the early 90's.

The artifacts disguise the building's origin as a produce warehouse with stables, but not completely. You can still see the well used to water the horses in the middle of the floor.

But traveling to them can be expensive and time-consuming, and in an era of cost-cutting, personal interviews are becoming a luxury that some companies can ill afford.

What is great about buying, she says, is also great about returning: you experience the emotional rush of handing over your charge card and you end up with a nice shopping bag. Unshopping provides something else. Unshopping rewards you with a credit so that you can shop some more.

But not until yesterday did she dive into the notoriously treacherous waters of the Manhattan art world.

Spa Tique, which opened Nov. 19 at 3248 Sacramento Street in the city's Presidio Heights area, sells various products from 11 spas in California, Utah, Hawaii and Mexico, including the Golden Door and La Costa. It also offers customers who are thinking of a spa vacation a chance to compare amenities at those spas, and reservations can be made for any of the spas. Customers can also sample some of the treatments offered.

Vintners there and the New York Farm Bureau said the proposal, which would have permitted shipping two cases a year to customers in the 12 states that allow out-of-state deliveries, would have benefited premium-wine producers and helped tourism and the economy.

But the future of the roughly 2,000 acres of land that they occupy, along with undeveloped land in the north central part of the state, is uncertain.

description: One can usually tell when something is going on in the Giants' offices by the number of closed doors. Last week, as the Giants were deciding the fate of Coach Dan Reeves, there were so many closed doors it was as if the Giants thought their offices were being spied upon.

title: HERS;Doing The Right Thing
description: THERE WERE ONLY SEVEN REGISTERED Democrats in the small Massachusetts town where I grew up. The night Jack Kennedy was elected President, all seven of them got drunk and did the twist at the railroad station, so I naturally thought that, aside from having better notions about the role of government, Democrats had more fun than Republicans. That insight alone turned me into a Democrat, and in my numerous recountings of the episode, I can't imagine why it didn't work for my daughter, Caitlin.

title: Turbulence
description: HARD LANDING The Epic Contest for Power and Profits That Plunged the Airlines Into Chaos. By Thomas Petzinger Jr. Illustrated. 520 pp. New York: Times Business Books/Random House. $30. AS the invective grew louder between labor and management at Eastern Airlines in 1983, Frank Borman heard a frightening rumor. Mr. Borman, the chief executive of Eastern and former astronaut, received information that someone had put out a contract on his life. The F.B.I. advised Mr. Borman to wear a bulletproof vest. He also strapped a 9-millimeter automatic pistol to his ankle and began a crash course in how to use it. Over the next few days, he went everywhere with a young man whose presence alongside him, he was told, would deter a mob hit.

title: Sri Lanka Offers Tamils More Power
description: A month after the Sri Lankan Army took control of the city of Jaffna from Tamil rebels, the Government is preparing an ambitious political offensive that could decide whether the island nation southeast of India returns to peace after more than a decade of ethnic warfare.

title: FROM THE INTERACTIVE ENCYCLOPEDIA, 2015 EDITION: WELFARE, END OF
description: DeParle's "back to the future" look at the United States in 2015 contends that Aid to Families With Dependent Children is the glue that holds this country together and that in its absence chaos will ensue. However, a look at the past 20 years hardly suggests that A.F.D.C. has solved the problems of the poor. If anything, the increases in single-parent families, teen-age pregnancies, teen-age unemployment and crime, child abuse and other markers of social decline seem to indicate just the opposite.

title: MARKET WATCH;Divine Right Of REIT Kings
description: The question of who really owns a company has long been important in American capitalism. It has been more than six decades since Adolf Berle and Gardiner Means argued that real control of major businesses was vested in managers who owned few shares.

He is expected to be succeeded by Ryutaro Hashimoto, an unusually strong-willed politician who is now the Trade Minister and who has regularly crossed swords with American officials during his career.

It was a pursuit, like hang gliding or bungee jumping, that primarily attracted young men, a group that I've always felt had an imperfect capacity to assess risk.

title: An Icebreaker Through The Antarctic
description: AFTER all I had heard about Antarctica's windblown hostility, it was a pleasure to find that in January the icecap can be more blush than bluster. The summer sun, which takes increasingly shorter naps the farther south you sail, often washes the icescape with a surprising, peach-sherbet light. And when the coast's ruddiness is reflected in a glassy bay, the resulting play of pastel blues and pinks, punctuated with jagged scraps of floating ice, looks like something out of a Monet.

description: LYTTON STRACHEY: The New Biography By Michael Holroyd. Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $17. A substantial revision of a two-volume work published in the 1960's, this book includes new material that shows to what extent Strachey and the other members of the Bloomsbury group were victims of their own experiments. "The multitude of voices we hear in letters and diaries gives a remarkable new life to Mr. Holroyd's narrative," Angeline Goreau said here last year.

title: Q and A
description: Three Weeks in Germany Q. My husband and I and our niece and nephew plan to spend at least three weeks in or around Garmisch-Partenkirchen in April or May. We would like to stay in a pension or private home. Where could we get such information? -- Nina Peacock, Plant City, Fla. A. The 120-page Garmisch-Partenkirchen 1996 hotel guide offers hundreds of reasonably priced accommodations ranging from hotels, inns and boarding houses to hostels, guesthouses and apartments. April and May are the off-season, so many lodging houses offer discounts at that time, especially for travelers who stay for more than a week.

So Ms. Elliott pursued, albeit miserably, a career as a psychologist. Then in 1994, while completing her master's in psychology at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, she spotted a flier offering paid teaching internships for minority students.

title: Corrections
description: An article about Malawi in the Travel section last Sunday referred incorrectly to the safety of Lake Malawi. An epidemiological investigation conducted in 1993 by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that the lake was not free of the parasitic infection schistosomiasis, also known as bilharzia. Of the 1,000 resident expatriates and travelers in Malawi who had swum in the lake and were given blood tests, the C.D.C. found, 33 percent had evidence of infection.

What has become equally important is prisoners wearing beads and tatoos of crowns, shamrocks and No. 7's. These symbols are not just the trappings of thieves, they also signify membership in street gangs like the Almighty Latin Kings Nation, the Five Percent Nation and the Aryan Brotherhood.

Mr. Young, my dry cleaner, applauded merrily when I accused him of shrinking my pants. Yoga had become risky; jackknifed in the plow position, I was almost suffocated by my pillowy stomach. title: BLACKBOARD;Exploring Men's Emotions, on Video

A 45-minute videotape, it features five male undergraduates at Haverford College in Haverford, Pa., discussing topics like date rape, drinking and relationships. Michael Klein, 27, a graduate student in clinical psychology at Rutgers University, in New Brunswick, N.J. made "Adam's Mark" and is now marketing it as a teaching and therapy tool. So far, 70 colleges and three Army bases have bought the $99 tape, which Mr. Klein feels offers a non-threatening approach. A guy can think, 'Oh, I can watch a video,' " Mr. Klein said. "It's not like being shrunk by a shrink." L.G.

The I.R.S. already has most of the information we have to enter on numerous forms and schedules. If the United States followed the lead of Britain and many other European countries, most of us could avoid this annual burden. At the same time, the Government would pick up more revenue at less expense.

Perhaps he also thinks that the hundreds of gauges and controls we see in the cockpit as we exit a plane are there to impress the passengers.

title: Potato Surprise
description: When potatoes were introduced to Europe in the 16th century, they were greeted with considerable apprehension. Potatoes had figured prominently in the diet and rituals of the Incas, who measured time by how long it took to cook them. But the Europeans were less kindly disposed toward the ugly root, which they ate raw and believed (understandably) to be poisonous. It was left to Antoine Parmentier, a French pharmacist, to illuminate the tuber's nutritional value. His tract, "A Chemical Examination of the Potato," might have gone unsung, if not for France's starving politically volatile masses.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Buildings Born of Dreams and Demons
description: THIS IS NOT A STORY ABOUT a new movement in architecture. It's a story about an old art movement that has resurfaced in contemporary architecture with startling vigor. Surrealism, which flourished between the world wars, was largely driven by Freud's theories. Surrealist painters, writers and film makers hoped to transform culture by injecting it with the powerful energies generated by subconscious mechanisms. The irrational, the erotic, the controlling, devouring, conflicted and repressed: artists like Breton, Miro, Bunuel, Magritte and Dali sought to draw into the daylight the primitive impulses Freud tried to understand through the interpretation of dreams.

title: THE WORLD;Europeans Redefine What Makes a Citizen
description: CHILDREN born on French soil to foreign parents used to acquire French citizenship automatically, but since 1993 they have had to apply for it before their 18th birthdays. Like the rest of Western Europe, France has tightened citizenship rules to discourage immigration. Nearly three million people in France, immigrant and native alike, are unemployed, and extreme-right political movements have persuaded 15 to 20 percent of the electorate that unemployment would vanish if the immigrants went home.

title: Stranded in Milan
description: To the Editor: On my way to Milan International airport I was robbed. It was at 8:15 A.M. Nov. 23, Thanksgiving Day, a business day in Milan. I was passing the train station on my way to the airport shuttle bus. Within 50 feet of the bus, several people called my attention to something on my back and luggage. One man started to wipe off my baggage, then a woman passed by, commenting on the "spots" on my back, then another man came up pretending to help. My mistake, of course, was in stopping. In turning around, I lost my focus on my backpack/purse, which was promptly taken from me. I was left with no currency, passport, credit cards or airline ticket.

Thousands of Burmese come in from all over the countryside to participate in her "free speech" meetings. They bring their children. They take tape recorders and video cameras. Though Suu Kyi explains such concepts as freedom of the press and the right to assembly in the most elegant Burmese, certain English phrases seep through: "social contract," "Martin Luther King," "it's not fair."

description: It's a beautiful day for fishing," said Kenneth Luhman, a bearded, thoroughly bundled-up man who stood in the middle of the Muscoot Reservoir in this Westchester village this morning, drilling a hole in the 10-inch-thick ice with a blue-bladed auger.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Ibarra and Beyond
description: If it is evil to care too much for things that have neither mind nor heart, then I am evil," Harriet Doerr writes in the first of the 15 pieces of memoir and short fiction in THE TIGER IN THE GRASS: Stories and Other Inventions (Viking, $19.95). This is far too hyperbolic a statement. Ms. Doerr does have a sure and elegant hand when it comes to describing flora and fauna and the houses in California and Mexico where she has lived. But with her keen attention to detail in matters of character and emotion, she demonstrates a compassionate spirit that is anything but evil. Using an episodic structure similar to those in her novels, "Stones From Ibarra" and "Consider This, Senora," this new book allows Ms. Doerr to contemplate certain events from the nearly nine decades of her life, even as she returns us to the locales made familiar in her fiction. Writing with admirable simplicity, she recalls spending sublime childhood summers at the beach, knitting a muffler for an American soldier in France (who sent her a much-cherished thank-you note) and going off to Smith College in 1927. There are also memories of being widowed at 65 after 42 years of marriage and then going back to college, and of helplessly standing by as her son began to succumb to cancer. Several of the short stories, set in Ibarra, reacquaint readers with Sara and Richard Everton, who were introduced in Ms. Doerr's first book. Others explore different parts of rural Mexico. Like the matilija poppies of Ms. Doerr's youth, "whose crushed tissue-paper petals unfolded every June into white flowers as big as a child's face," these previously uncollected short works are strikingly pure and radiant. RUTH COUGHLIN

title: The Good Servant
description: JACKSON'S DILEMMA By Iris Murdoch. 249 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95. GIVEN her lifelong preoccupation with philosophy, you might almost conclude that Dame Iris Murdoch's 26th novel, "Jackson's Dilemma," means to raise anew the old debate about whether an artwork's content and form are separable. Can the what-is-said and the saying-of-it truly be isolated? Whatever ultimately may be the answer to that durable riddle, the effect of "Jackson's Dilemma" is to leave the reader divided over content and form. The story is a psychologically rich tale of romances thwarted and revived. The writing is a mess.

Three streets -- Christopher, Grove and Waverly Place -- converge at five points at the triangular intersection, making it difficult for cars and pedestrians to navigate. title: A One-Windmill Town
description: THE DROWNING ROOM By Michael Pye. 252 pp. New York: Granta Books in association with Viking. $22.95. WHEN we first meet Gretje Rey niers, the heroine of Michael Pye's novel "The Drowning Room," she is holed up in one of several houses she owns in icebound New Amsterdam, a one-windmill mid-17th-century village, trading post and fort. Gretje is a brand-new widow; the frozen body of her sailor husband, surnamed Janssen but known as Anthony the Turk, is lying in a coffin in the yard. She shares her breakfast of bread and warm milk with a pet cockatoo, to stop it from screaming; it has recently arrived from Curacao and is, with reason, suffering from climate and culture shock. Gretje's attendant is Tomas, a sallow, speechless youth. We will shortly discover how he literally lost his tongue.

Newspapers eulogized him as a "pop crooner," an "easygoing crooner" and a "happy-go-lucky pro." His persona was that of the drunkest and coolest member of the Rat Pack, those avatars of a moment when smoke, booze, broads and plenty of linguine on the side were all of life worth living.

title: ON THE STREET;Fashion That Speaks for Itself
description: The glorification of the label belongs to the 20th century. One hundred years ago, a few Paris fashion houses discreetly stenciled their names on the inside waistbands of their clothes, a practice considered vulgar by many clients (who had them removed). After World War I, labels began to appear on inside seams, and the company logo finally gained status with the initials of Louis Vuitton. By mid-century, Chanel, Gucci and Hermes were initialing suit buttons, handbags and scarves. As the century closes, the shouting of logos has reached a high pitch. For many, the logo is more important than what it is printed on.

The tiny 102-year-old school owed $12.5 million, and in June it was forced to declare bankruptcy. After Upsala closed, a bankruptcy trustee took on the task of selling its assets, from the 37-acre campus to dormitory beds and library periodicals. So far the trustee, Charles M. Forman, has raised about $900,000 to pay some of Upsala's bills. Sunday New Jersey asked his lawyer, Walter J. Greenhalgh of Newark, how one goes about selling a college piece by piece. So Madonna, the pop superstar, failed to persuade a Los Angeles Superior Court judge that her desire to avoid fulfilling the fantasy of the man charged with stalking and threatening to kill her outweighed his right to share time in the courtroom with her. As a result, she reluctantly went to court and testified last week against Robert Dewey Hoskins, who faces criminal charges of stalking, making terrorist threats and assault. She had asked that the defendant be removed from the courtroom or that she be allowed to testify from a remote location, but the judge said either course might prejudice the jury. SHEILA MUTO

After leaving the Reagan Cabinet in 1983, he traded on his standing, lobbying top HUD officials to obtain millions for his clients. In return for pleading guilty to a single misdemeanor charge of misleading a grand jury, the independent prosecutor investigating the housing agency dropped 18 perjury and influence-peddling charges against the once high-profile figure, who had compared environmentalists to Nazis and tried to ban the Beach Boys from performing on the capital Mall.
