Moving right along from tongue to ear to eyeball in this surreal series, THE SKIN PALACE (Mysterious Press/Warner, $21.95) tells the separate but equally nightmarish stories of Jakob Kinsky, a would-be film maker, and Sylvia Krafft, a would-be photographer, who are obsessed with recording human experiences they have been unable to live for themselves.

"No one is comparing Rebecca Lobo to Michael Jordan," she said, "no one is wondering how UConn would do against the Bulls. It's so much better than hearing, 'Well, yes, women can run fast, but compared to men. . . .' "

title: Mae K. Tighe, Thomas Bronner
description: Dr. Mae Kelly Tighe, the daughter of Joan and John Tighe of North Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Thomas James Bronner, a son of Diana and Francis Bronner of Cary, N.C. The Rev. Dr. Herbert J. Ryan performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York.

title: BASKETBALL;Williams, at 37, Is the Big Guy Again

title: SPOTLIGHT;Frontier Justice
description: Leave it to big John Wayne (above) as John Elder, a part that fits him with bullet precision, to find out who it was that killed his father years ago and who swindled his recently buried, sainted mother. Henry Hathaway's gory little western THE SONS OF KATIE ELDER (1965) is the story of four brothers -- three outcasts and another -- who confront a hostile prairie community. The tale is told with authentic settings and excellent color. It has the benefit of fine acting by James Gregory as an obvious villain and Martha Hyer, Jeremy Slate, Paul Fix and John Doucette in neat character vignettes -- SATURDAY at 3 and 11 P.M on AMC.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;Jungle on Eighth St.
description: When Honi Klein, head of the local business improvement district, looks along Eighth Street, she sees light poles, signposts, fire hydrants and mailboxes -- and too little room for pedestrians. The B.I.D. wants to replace the 111 parking meters between the Avenue of the Americas and Broadway with as few as six "pay-and-display" machines. A driver deposits coins in a machine and gets a receipt to displayed on the dashboard.

title: ON POLITICS;Congressional Deadlock As a Campaign Tool
description: A little more than a year ago the Republicans were campaigning against Democratic gridlock on Congress, and we all know what happened: the Democrats got creamed.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Barcelona Gets Museum Of Contemporary Art
description: FOR a city that has strong associations with such modern masters as Picasso, Dali and Miro, it always seemed odd that Barcelona did not have its own museum of contemporary art. True, it has a fine Picasso Museum and a hilltop foundation containing a collection of Miro's works, while Barcelona's most famous living painter, Antoni Tapies, also created a foundation to display his works and shows by other artists. But contemporary art as such had no home.

title: ON THE MAP;A Room for Quiet Meditation in Keyport
description: In the 15 years since Theodore J. Miller declared his historic 18-room Keyport house open to the public, the house has become a mecca for art and culture lovers in central New Jersey. They admire its eclectic decorations, Federal architecture and large, informal garden.

title: Dec.31 - Jan. 6;A Traveler in Danger
description: The monarch butterfly, that orange-and-black-winged friend, is a remarkable voyager, migrating every year from Canada to a winter home in central Mexico. But a rare snowfall in the last days of December froze millions of the butterflies in their favorite fir-tree stands in Government-protected reserves in the states of Mexico and Michoacan. A leading Mexican environmentalist estimated the kill-off at as much as one-third of the population, although Government environmental officials said that was exaggerated.

Last week, she lost two more family members: her nephews Glennis (Weeda) Saunders, 15, and Dwayne (Butter) Boone, 21, below. They were the latest victims in the undeclared urban war that each day costs the life of another young black man. About New York, Page 31.

title: Valve Work May Have Put Strain on Pipe That Broke

title: Stocks Slip in Japan
description: Japanese stocks were trading slightly lower here today. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 60.40 points -- a little less than three-tenths of 1 percent -- to stand at 20,608.63. On Friday, the Nikkei index rose 51.03 points.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: KNICKS NOTEBOOK;Time in Gym Pays Off for Davis

title: THEATER REVIEW;Seeing, in Brian Friel's Ballybeg
description: Brian Friel has been recognized as Ireland's greatest living playwright almost since the first production of "Philadelphia, Here I Come!" in Dublin in 1964. In succeeding years he has dazzled us with plays that speak in a language of unequaled poetic beauty and intensity. It makes no difference that some of the plays have been box office hits and some of them flops. The talent has been consistent. Such dramas as "Translations," "Dancing at Lughnasa" and "Wonderful Tennessee," among others, have given him a privileged place in our theater.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;While Holocaust Witnesses Remain
description: There have been many documentaries about the Holocaust, and most of them have been moving, but none more so than "Survivors of the Holocaust." These memories of childhoods darkened by loss and cruelty are drawn from interviews gathered by Survivors of the Shoah Visual History Foundation. Created by Steven Spielberg and growing out of his work on "Schindler's List," the foundation is making a worldwide effort to capture, while witnesses remain, what the Nazis' Final Solution meant for Europe's Jews.

title: Advertising;Trying to lure media buyers, Nickelodeon asks a multiple-choice question with only one answer.

And "Duh!" has become a popular exclamation among commercial actors, as in "Dude, you are so totally wasting my time."

title: BOXING;A Restless Jones Keeps Fighting While Harboring Hoop Dreams

title: Managing in the Cold
description: New York City officials and the American Red Cross offered this advice for coping with the storm: * Limit 911 calls to life-threatening emergencies. For other emergencies, call the police command at (212) 374-2303. * Limit street parking to side streets, leaving emergency snow routes (highways and main arteries marked with snow route signs) clear to traffic. * Limit driving. Do not drive on emergency snow routes without radial tires or chains. Carry a blanket, flares and water. * Avoid being outdoors early in the morning and late at night, the coldest times of the day. When outdoors, leave as little skin as possible exposed to the wind and cold. Wear a hat and dress in layers. * To care for frostbite, handle the affected area gently. Never rub an affected area, which can cause further damage to soft tissue. Warm the affected part gently by soaking it in warm water, at about 105 degrees Fahrenheit. Loosely bandage the area with dry, sterile dressing. Get professional medical attention as soon as possible. If fingers or toes are frostbitten, use cotton or gauze between them and bandage loosely.

Somehow the promoters of New Amsterdam (and the English who came later) overlooked the blizzards, the frozen bay, the ice that kept ships and food out of the settlement. "In winter," the geographer de Laet reported in 1625, "superior turkey cocks are taken, very fat." He simply left out the rest.

description: Bill Guerin of the Devils belongs among that large group of hockey players that allow their minds to play all kinds of games and affect the way they perform. title: TELEVISION REVIEW;At an Age of Anxiety, Whining Is for Laughs
description: Champs," a new ABC series, has its premiere tonight in the exceptionally comfy 9:30 time slot between "Home Improvement" and "N.Y.P.D. Blue." Pedigree is clearly a major factor. "Champs" is the creation of Gary David Goldberg, the writer-producer whose credits include "Family Ties" and "Brooklyn Bridge." This television series, produced in association with Mr. Goldberg's Ubu productions, is also the first to emerge from Dreamworks, the company formed by David Geffen, Jeffrey Katzenberg and Steven Spielberg.

title: Second Thoughts on India;Enron Project on Track, but Policy Doubts Remain

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996;Impressed? You Should Have Been There in '47
description: The great storm of Dec. 26, 1947, which draped Central Park in 26.4 inches of white powder, more than any other, struck almost without warning. In the days before weather satellites, it swept in off the Atlantic, from a point where there were no weather observers. Its path was almost identical to that of the Blizzard of '88.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A World Of Shapes Governed By Design
description: Kevin Wynn is as much an architect as a choreographer at heart. Or so the program presented by the Kevin Wynn Collection on Thursday night at the Joyce Theater as part of the Altogether Different festival suggests.

title: A Less Harmful Budget
description: The budget proposal released by the White House over the weekend answers critics who have harshly, though accurately, accused President Clinton of stalling on his promise to deliver a plan that would balance the budget in seven years using Congressional scorekeeping.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Abbott, Dunston Sign New Deals
description: Pitcher JIM ABBOTT and the California Angels agreed to a $7.8 million, three-year contract minutes before last night's deadline of midnight, New York time. Abbott, 28, was 5-4 with a 4.15 earned run average in 13 starts with the Angels and 11-8 overall with a 3.70 e.r.a. in 30 starts for the Angels and the Chicago White Sox.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHANTAL PHARMACEUTICAL STOCK FALLS ON NEWS REPORT
description: The stock of the Chantal Pharmaceutical Corporation fell more than 62 percent yesterday after Barron's, the financial weekly, published a report that questioned Chantal's dealings with a Los Angeles distributor and the claims of Chantal's lead cosmetic product, Ethocyn anti-wrinkle cream. Chantal shares plunged $11.8125, to $7.3125, in Nasdaq trading of nearly 7.7 million shares. The Barron's article raised issues about Chantal's option to acquire Stanson Marketing, the chief distributor of Ethocyn. It also discussed lawsuits against Stanson's president, Frederick Reinstein, and challenged claims that Ethocyn could reduce skin wrinkling. Officials of Chantal were not immediately available to comment on the Barron's report.

title: Lockheed to Acquire Loral In a Deal Worth $10 Billion
description: In a startling move that accelerates the consolidation of military contractors and is likely to lead to more layoffs, the Lockheed Martin Corporation announced today that it planned to acquire most of the Loral Corporation in a complex deal that is valued at more than $10 billion.

Department stores, shopping malls, specialty shops and local merchants pulled down the gates and went home, some as early as Sunday afternoon, as blustery winds swept shoppers and millions of their dollars from the troubled industry.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUPERCUTS STOCK FALLS ON CREDIT PROBLEMS
description: Supercuts Inc. said yesterday that it may be out of compliance with a covenant of its bank credit facility, which would constitute default of the company's bank credit line. After the news, the company's stock plummeted $2.25, or 29 percent, to $5.625, in Nasdaq trading. Supercuts, a chain of hair-cutting salons, said it had been advised by its lending banks that money issued under the credit line will require waivers, and the banks have already waived an advance of $1 million. Supercuts, which is based in San Francisco, said it might not comply with the covenant concerning minimum earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for last year.

Pronet, a paging concern, said it bought Page One of Georgia for about $19.7 million, which will add more than 30,000 subscribers. It bought Sun Paging of Florida Inc. for about $2.3 million in cash. That purchase will add more than 12,000 subscribers. And it also bought Signet Paging of Raleigh Inc. for about $8.7 million. The purchase of the North Carolina-based company adds more than 13,000 subscribers.

description: For most Americans, the Persian Gulf war was a fireworks of images, many courtesy of CNN: the spectacular nighttime bombing of Baghdad; the flaming Kuwaiti oil wells; the Iraqi air raid shelter destroyed by an American bomb and the American barracks destroyed by an Iraqi missile; President Saddam Hussein patting the head of a young hostage; a battered American prisoner speaking into an Iraqi camera; the hundreds of thousands of troops massed in the desert; the pathetic surrenders of stunned Iraqi soldiers; the carnage along the "highway of death" back to Iraq; the briefings that made instant television stars of Colin L. Powell and H. Norman Schwarzkopf.

Unwashed, unfaded stiff blue jeans.

description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that it would appoint Frank Reed as non-management chairman and Dennis Foster as president and chief executive of its Sprint Cellular subsidiary after the unit's expected spinoff early this year. Mr. Reed, 60, was president and chief executive of Corestates Philadelphia National Bank, a unit of the Corestates Financial Corporation. Mr. Foster, 65, joined Sprint as a senior vice president of operations for the company's local telecommunications division and earlier served as president of GTE Mobilenet, a cellular subsidiary of the GTE Corporation. Sprint, the No. 3 long-distance telephone company behind AT&T and MCI Corporation, proposed the spinoff of Sprint Cellular on June 14.

The driver rammed the metal teeth on the loader's blade into the front wall of the bank, scooping out glass, bricks and the night depository box, said Officer John Jimmarino, a police spokesman.

title: The Legacy of Francois Mitterrand
description: Francois Mitterrand, who died yesterday at age 79, was, with Charles de Gaulle, one of the two dominant French political leaders of the postwar era. Though Mr. Mitterrand served longer than de Gaulle as President -- longer, in fact, than anyone in the history of France's five republics -- his legacy was more ambiguous.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Detour for the Pinafore
description: The blizzard did not deter a good-size audience from attending Sunday afternoon's opening of the New York Gilbert and Sullivan Players' "H.M.S. Pinafore" at Symphony Space. For those seeking diversion and a chance to hear a timeless score ably performed, the colorful production delivered.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996;Car Deal Falls Short
description: Close, but no free Cadillac. The Potamkin Auto Center -- which promised to pick up the tab for every car it leased between Christmas and New Year's if more than four inches of fresh snow fell in Central Park between 10 A.M. and 10 P.M. yesterday -- appeared to squeak by last night as the blizzard let up after leaving behind just over three inches within the designated time frame.

title: Man Is Found Guilty of Stalking Madonna
description: A man accused of stalking and threatening to kill the singer and actress Madonna was convicted on all counts today by a jury that did not buy defense characterizations of the pop star as lacking credibility.

title: On My Mind;Death for Chinese Children
description: Thousands of Chinese children die in orphanages every year from deliberate medical neglect and starvation. This is policy, part of Beijing's technique of controlling the increased number of children abandoned by parents who either could not feed them or feared the regime would cut the rations for the whole family for the crime of having more than one or two children.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Family Tradition Plays On
description: Jeanne Mallow represents the third generation of the remarkable string-playing Fuchs family. Her grandmother Lillian Fuchs, who died in October, played viola before her; her great-uncle Joseph Fuchs is a violinist; her mother, Barbara Mallow, a cellist, and her aunt, Carol Stein Amado, a violinist. She is a worthy successor to this tradition, playing with dusky, aristocratic tone, exacting intonation and a kind of conversational musicality that seems second nature. She employs generous portamento and rubato, but nothing is forced or mannered.

title: Musicland Plan To Sell a Stake
description: The Musicland Stores Corporation plans to sell 30 percent of a unit, the Suncoast Motion Picture Company, in an initial public offering that is expected to raise $41 million.

description: The nation's capital glistened under a brilliant afternoon sun today, but the city's post card appearance was a grand deception.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Morgan Stanley Plans Hotel Deal in Mexico
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that it and the Mexican hotel operator Grupo Posadas S.A. planned to spend $200 million in a joint venture to buy and develop hotels in Mexico and elsewhere. The investment would be the first foray by a large United States corporation into Mexico's troubled real estate market since the peso collapsed in December 1994.

description: HE'S listed at 320 pounds, but in his hooded gray sweatshirt with "61" on the front, Nate Newton appeared at least an ounce or two more. At left guard and earlier at right tackle, he has started more Cowboys games, 146, than anybody else on their offensive unit. He has also started more conversations.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOECHST AND RHONE-POULENC COMBINE PLASMA UNITS
description: Hoechst A.G. and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that they had combined their plasma protein businesses in a new 50-50 venture known as Centeon. Based in King of Prussia, Pa., Centeon becomes the world's largest provider of plasma protein products, which are used to treat immune deficiencies, bone marrow transplants and neurological disorders. Centeon will have yearly sales of about $1.2 billion. Germany's Hoechst contributed the plasma protein division of its Behringwerke A.G. business. Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, the United States business of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., contributed the plasma protein assets of its Armour Pharmaceutical Company unit.

The drug will be marketed in conjunction with Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, Elan said. On the New York Stock Exchange, American depository receipts of Elan rose $1.875, to $50.625, while shares of American Home rose $1.75, to $97.125.

title: Guatemalan Who Pledges to 'Avoid Excesses' Is Narrowly Elected asPresident
description: In a surprisingly close vote that demonstrated the persistence of deep class, ethnic and regional divisions in this war-torn Central American country, Guatemalans have elected Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen, a conservative businessman and politician who had promised to "avoid excesses" if he became their new President.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN FINANCIAL TO SELL UNIT TO MANAGEMENT
description: The American Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Buckeye Management Company unit for $63 million. American Financial reached the agreement with an investment group that consists of members of current management and employees of the company. American Financial, a property and casualty insurance concern based in Cincinnati, did not disclose further information about the buying group. The company announced in November that it was trying to sell Buckeye, which owns a 2 percent general partnership interest in, and is the managing general partner of, Buckeye Partners L.P., a petroleum pipeline operator.
