title: COMPANY NEWS;OLYMPIA & YORK REACHES DEAL TO SPLIT ASSETS
description: The Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.) reached an agreement yesterday to split its real estate assets between two creditor groups as part of a debt restructuring. One creditor group is led by the financier Leon Black and the other is led by the Bronfman family. The Bronfman-led group will get the keys to buildings holding 12 million square feet of a total of 15 million square feet of Manhattan real estate that Olympia & York (U.S.A.) owns. The buildings include the World Financial Center, One Liberty Plaza and 245 Park Avenue. Mr. Black's group will get control of office towers at 277 Park Avenue and 1290 Avenue of the Americas. The agreement allows Olympia, a unit of Olympia & York Developments Ltd. to restructure almost $5 billion in debt. Olympia will seek bankruptcy court approval.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-5

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AROUND THE REGION;Conquering the Drifts On Land and Near Sea
description: Rockville Centre, L.I. Hunters End Up As the Catch

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADFLEX BUYS A DIVISION OF XYRATEX FOR $56 MILLION
description: Adflex Solutions Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired a division of Xyratex Ltd. which supplies interconnect products for computers. Adflex paid $56 million in cash, debt and stock. Adflex Solutions, of Chandler, Ariz., said the division of Xyratex, a British company, had revenues of about $72 million in 1995. Adflex supplies flexible circuit-based interconnect products to the computer, communication and consumer electronics product industries. As part of the agreement, Xyratex, a maker of computer disk drives, communications systems and test systems, will acquire a 15 percent stake in Adflex. Adflex's stock slipped 75 cents, to $24.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;NEW YORK SHUT BY WORST STORM IN 48 YEARS; EAST IS BURIED, VIRGINIA TO MASSACHUSETTS
description: The historic Blizzard of '96 broke off its ghostly assault on the citadels and hamlets of the Northeast yesterday, leaving behind a New York metropolitan region and 10 states, home to more than 63 million people, buried and paralyzed under 18 inches to three or more feet of snow.

title: Ford Says More Buyers Behind On Automobile Loan Payments
description: The number of Americans who are behind on their car payments is rising, a senior executive at the Ford Motor Company said tonight.

title: Let New Jerseyans Spend to Bolster Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Tandem Computers Names Chief Executive
description: Tandem Computers Inc. named Roel Pieper yesterday as its president and chief executive as part of an effort to find a new focus in a computer market that is increasingly based on commodity software and hardware.

title: World News Briefs;Bangladesh Again Delays Parliamentary Elections
description: The Government postponed parliamentary elections for a second time today, apparently in response to a nationwide opposition strike.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AROUND THE REGION;Conquering the Drifts On Land and Near Sea
description: Manhattan Bridge A Shantytown Sticks Together

title: 2004 Games: Not in China
description: The International Olympic Committee has received notification from China that it will not bid to be host of the 2004 Games.

title: TV SPORTS;To Fox's Matt Millen, N.F.L. Is One Big Hit
description: Fox's mischievous Matt Millen -- the former Raider, 49er and Redskin linebacker -- loves a tough and nasty hit. That appreciation is evident in his Madden-like arsenal of sound effects and in his lusty focus on the concussive impact of cornerbacks jamming receivers, linebackers nailing tight ends and defensive tackles challenging an offensive lineman's weak ankle.

title: Nonstop Coverage (Between Commercials)
description: It was like a party line with pictures: dire forecasts and remarkable records (star time for the weatherfolk); useful information (everything was closed); questionably informative interviews (a transportation spokesman somewhere announced excitedly that he could see a bus moving on his television screen); businesslike appearances by governors, mayors, borough presidents; cautions (don't drive, shovel or throw snowballs, and check on the welfare of old people and pets), appreciations, compliments, weak jokes and inanities. One anchorwoman, asking for a snowball to the mouth, suggested spending a pleasant day at home playing with the kids.

title: Endangered Condors to Soar at Grand Canyon
description: CALIFORNIA condors, the largest land birds in North America, may soon be soaring over the Grand Canyon. As the second major step in the United States Fish and Wildlife Service's recovery plan for the endangered condor, biologists proposed last week to release nine captive-bred birds in the Vermilion Cliffs area just north of the canyon in April.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE WORKERS;The Call of Duty Is Heard Clearly in Howl of Storm
description: Dr. Guy Shochat spent an hour and a half yesterday morning trying to dig his car out of the snow before giving up and cross-country skiing across Prospect Park and through Flatbush to his job in the emergency room at Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about a retreat by the AT&T Corporation from several business ventures misstated the status of an investment in General Magic. AT&T continues to hold a stake in the company. AT&T is dropping General Magic software from its Personalink advanced message service.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Banks in Taiwan Under Investigation
description: The Justice Ministry in Taiwan is investigating whether foreign banks violated rules by helping local residents set up accounts in overseas banks during a recent rise in political tension between Taipei and Beijing. Industry executives say Taiwan residents moved several billion dollars into offshore and overseas bank accounts after China began a series of military tests near the island in mid-1995. The tests followed a visit by President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan to the United States in June.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE AIRPORTS;Stranded Travelers Find Ways to Beat Boredom
description: There were perhaps 100 hardy travelers left in La Guardia Airport's main terminal yesterday, the second day that La Guardia -- like the region's other two major airports -- was closed by the blizzard. And while the Northeast's transportation system was in a temporary crisis state, many of those stuck at La Guardia managed to pass the time creatively.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Little Changed in a Shortened Session
description: Bond prices showed little change yesterday in a short trading session as the blizzard in the Northeast prevented many traders and investors from getting to work.

title: Cholesterol and Diet
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AROUND THE REGION;Conquering the Drifts On Land and Near Sea
description: Montclair, N.J. Chauffeurs For Nightingales

title: San Francisco Journal;A Time To Rejoice In Mantle Of Power
description: Willie Brown is a famous clothes horse, a man known to be late for meetings because of last-minute wardrobe changes. So it was not surprising that one of the most eagerly awaited decisions from Mr. Brown, this city's new Mayor, was which $3,000 suit he would wear today to his swearing-in.

title: Let New Jerseyans Spend to Bolster Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Memo;Sniping at Dole Turns Nasty in New Hampshire
description: It's warts time," said former Gov. John H. Sununu. He was not referring to his complexion but to how the other Republican Presidential candidates are trying to blemish Senator Bob Dole.

title: COLLEGES;N.C.A.A. Puts Major Powers And Presidents In Command
description: Overwhelmed by an increasingly cumbersome legislative process and pushed by the continuing force of an academic reform movement in college athletics, delegates at the 90th National Collegiate Athletic Association convention voted today to overhaul and simplify the structure of the organization.

title: U.S. Health Agency Isn't Pushing Alternative Medicine
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Forte Files Suit
description: The battle by the British hotel company Forte P.L.C. to fight off a hostile bid by the Granada Group turned increasingly bitter yesterday as Forte filed a lawsuit against Granada's finance director, Henry Staunton. Forte filed suit against Mr. Staunton over a report published yesterday in The Times of London in which Mr. Staunton was quoted as saying a Forte defense document had been "designed to mislead." Officials of Granada, the British television and leisure concern, declined any comment on the lawsuit, noting it was in the hands of the lawyers. (Reuters)

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AROUND THE REGION;Conquering the Drifts On Land and Near Sea
description: 11th Avenue Losing a Race Against Nature

title: Patterns
description: An Overhaul for Jaeger

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Acer Says Sales Surge
description: The Acer Group of Taiwan tallied revenues of $151.1 billion (Taiwan), or $5.54 billion (United States),in 1995, surging 77.5 percent from the preceding year on robust sales of personal computers and memory chips, the company said yesterday. Acer's chairman, Stan Shih, predicted the company's total revenue would reach $200 billion (Taiwan) this year, buoyed by growing sales of Aspire, a home-use personal computer introduced in the United States last year. (Dow Jones)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Dazed and Confused On a Strange Planet
description: Let's face it; at times we all feel like aliens on Earth. There are days when we look around and wonder, "Who are these people?" and spaced-out moments when the most mundane tasks seem bizarre. Few of us react with the comic flair of Sally Solomon (Kristen Johnston), a statuesque young woman learning to make her first meatloaf. She takes her hamburger-filled fingers out of the bowl and stares at them. "I have dead cow on my hands?" she shrieks, running from the kitchen in horror.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Graf's Father Refuses to Testify
description: STEFFI GRAF's jailed father, Peter, has refused to testify before a panel investigating allegations that officials in Germany knew taxes weren't being paid on millions of his daughter's earnings.

title: POSTPONEMENTS;The Scoreboard Stays Blank
description: When the Orlando Magic's plane was rerouted from Philadelphia on Sunday night to Allentown, Pa., it made for a riveting social scene in the Eastern Pennsylvania steel town.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Morgan Stanley in Partnership To Acquire Hotels in Mexico
description: In a move that some investors believe is a sign that the Mexican economy is turning around, Morgan Stanley & Company and the Mexican hotel operator Grupo Posadas announced plans today to invest roughly $200 million over the next 18 months to buy a number of Mexican hotels.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AT HOME;Diagnosis: Acute Cabin Fever. Rx: Just About Any Diversion.
description: For all but the most adventurous or the most unlucky, home is where snow days are spent, and so with two feet or more of snow blocking doorways and driveways across the region, the ingenuity of parents and the energy of children tested each other today as another day off from school began to seem as inviting as an extra week of a rainy family vacation.

title: POP REVIEW;Romance and High Anxiety
description: Earnestness and irony split the triple bill at the Knitting Factory on Friday night, because Papas Fritas, the headliner, had some of both. By their sound alone, Papas Fritas's songs should be effervescent pop, with nothing more on their mind than the next infatuation. Their transparent arrangements hark back to Mersey-beat bands and the lighter songs of the Replacements; bass and guitar riffs are neatly placed, and there are plenty of nonsense-syllable hooks, from "na-na-na-na" to "bop-ba-dop."

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Envoy to Burundi Says Massacres Are Rife
description: Massacres and other "terrible things" are rife in Burundi and its own political leaders recognize that a civil war is raging, a senior United Nations envoy said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Nov. 21 about the lost city of Urkesh in what is now Syria referred imprecisely to the time and means of the Metropolitan Museum's acquisition of an ancient bronze lion from that site. The lion was bought by the museum in 1948, from a dealer in New York. Dr. Giorgio Buccellati, an archeologist who conducted excavations at the site in the 1980's, uncovered artifacts near the place where the lion was originally found. It was not he who excavated the lion. This correction was delayed by the need to reach Dr. Buccellati.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: ASSESSMENT;When Political Failure Becomes Too Tough to Admit
description: After a year of dominating Washington politics, the balanced-budget issue has become too volatile to work with, and too explosive to drop.

title: Wine Talk
description: AUBERT DE VILLAINE has a miserable cold. He sniffs, coughs and dabs at his nose. At this time of year, it's a wonder that there are any people here in Burgundy who don't have colds. The brown leafless vineyards are often wreathed in clammy fog; an arctic wind regularly roars down from the Alps; even the fabled cellars, cool havens in summer, are chilly and inhospitable.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Is Looking For Trims at Grundig
description: The Dutch giant Philips Electronics N.V. wants to cut at least 1,000 jobs this year at its unprofitable German consumer electronics company, Grundig A.G., Philips said yesterday. The cuts will come on top of 10,000 jobs that were eliminated at Grundig the last four years. Grundig employed 11,600 people at the end of last year.

title: From Lives Begun in a Lab, Brave New Joy
description: A few years ago, when Elizabeth Carr's class was learning how an egg combines with sperm in the mother's body to create a child, she felt compelled to interrupt.

title: Bad Weather? Just Wait
description: As the Northeast bowed before an extraordinary blizzard, southern Californians basked in record-breaking heat. Some speculated that this freakish weather was further evidence of long-term global climate change. But focusing on individual events would be a mistake. Unusual weather conditions have always been normal.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Will Travel as Deep as Bench
description: At times, the Knicks played as if they were still trudging through snow last night. But thanks in part to a lift from their bench, the Knicks stayed even with a bad Celtics team, until New York's starters finally took control in the final five minutes of a 98-93 New York victory.

title: Correction: Chess
description: The diagram and table of moves were omitted from the Chess column in some copies of Science Times yesterday. They are reprinted here.

title: AT BREAKFAST WITH: Godfrey (Budge) Sperling Jr.;Politicians and the Press, Once Over
description: PASS the jampacked evasions and refried platitudes. It's time for another Sperling Breakfast, the symbiotic feast of question and answer shared for decades here by politicians on the make and political reporters on the make-and-break.

title: Lone Balloonist Aided by Strong Winds
description: Stronger-than-expected winds at his back, Steve Fossett and his Solo Challenger balloon swept over the eastern United States yesterday, survived a crisis that threatened to end his effort to circumnavigate the globe and headed out over the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Slaying Blended Technology and Guile
description: At about 9 A.M. last Friday, a cellular phone rang in the plain cinder block dwelling where Yahya Ayyash was hiding in this warren of muddy lanes and ramshackle houses near the northern edge of the Gaza Strip.

title: White House Says President Would Like to Punch Safire
description: The chief White House spokesman told reporters today that President Clinton would like to punch the New York Times columnist William Safire in the nose because of a column on Monday in which Mr. Safire wrote that the President's wife, Hillary, had shown herself to be "a congenital liar."

title: DANCE REVIEW;3 Works by Balanchine To Chase Winter's Blues
description: A blizzard swirled around the New York State Theater on Sunday afternoon, but inside it was summer. The New York City Ballet presented three bright and warmhearted works by George Balanchine, chasing the winter blues away.

title: Food Notes
description: Chickens Outpace Eggs

title: Ex-Congressman Mike Synar, Oklahoma Liberal, Dies at 45
description: Mike Synar, a liberal Democrat who served eight terms in Congress from the generally conservative state of Oklahoma, died of brain cancer today at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 45.

title: Mary A. Fisk, 78, an Advocate Of Tutoring in Primary Grades
description: Mary Averell Fisk, who championed early-childhood education in 45 years as a volunteer in the New York City public schools, died on Saturday at her country home in Arden, N.Y. She was 78.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Hot Start by UConn's Allen Freezes Villanova
description: Forced to wait an extra day because of the snow, Villanova found itself caught in another blizzard tonight, this one caused by the squall of baskets from Connecticut's Ray Allen.

title: Editorial Notebook;The Unfulfilled Bargain
description: Russian voters, scared by economic turmoil and furious about Government corruption, turned last month against President Boris Yeltsin's reform Government and toward Communism and nationalism. A nervous Mr. Yeltsin responded by replacing his pro-Western Foreign Minister, Andrei Kozyrev, with Yevgeny Primakov, a former spy chief. Perhaps these events will not slow Russia's traverse to democracy and markets. Perhaps there will be no resurgent militarism. But if democracy and markets thrive, that virtuous outcome will have occurred despite Western bungling.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: First Fidelity Securities Settles Kickback Charges First Fidelity Securities of Newark agreed to pay $2.3 million to settle charges by the S.E.C. that it paid secret kickbacks to a former New Jersey county official to get lucrative bond underwriting business. The firm neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing. The action is the first S.E.C. case brought against a broker-dealer firm rather than individuals for such payoffs.

title: Personal Health
description: When Julie Miller began trying to have a baby through in vitro fertilization, she had a plan. She would give it a year -- four tries. Then, if that did not result in a successful pregnancy, she and her husband, Jesse, would seek to adopt a child.

title: Dexter Leen, 85, Theater Angel And Philanthropist to Libraries
description: Dexter B. Leen, a Cape Cod shoe store operator who devoted much of his wide-ranging philanthropic work to ceaseless efforts to give everyone a chance to share his love of books, died on Saturday at his home in Cummaquid, Mass. He was 85 and was known on Cape Cod as Mr. Library.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;TALKS ON BUDGET ARE PUT ON HOLD AMID UNCERTAINTY
description: President Clinton and Republican leaders in Congress suspended their talks on the budget again today with a promise to resume bargaining next week. But it seemed less certain than ever that there was much left to talk about.

title: Italy Begins Trial of Ex-Premier on Mafia Ties
description: As Giulio Andreotti, seven times a Prime Minister of Italy, sat hunched between his defense lawyers scribbling notes, the Mafia turncoat whose testimony led to his indictment asked confidently that a screen set up to shield him from photographers and television cameras be removed.

title: Albert H. Swanke, 86, Architect And a Restorer of Monuments
description: Albert Homer Swanke, a prominent architect known for his restoration of Government monuments from the Capitol to the Statue of Liberty, died on Monday at Mercy Baptist Hospital in New Orleans. Mr. Swanke, who was an architect and planner at a number of New York firms, made his home first in Savannah, Ga., and then in New Orleans after retiring in 1982 as senior partner in Swanke Hayden Connell Architects in Manhattan. He was 86.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Many Asian-Americans Want Immigration Cut
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF MEDALIST DOUBLE AFTER IT AGREES TO PURCHASE
description: The shares of Medalist Industries more than doubled yesterday after Illinois Tool Works Inc. agreed to buy the company in a transaction worth about $56.5 million in stock. Medalist's shares will be valued at $14.50 each in the transaction, announced after the close of trading on Monday. The shares of Medalist, a maker of industrial fasteners in Milwaukee, were up $7.015625, to $13.765625, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Illinois Tool Works, based in Glenview, Ill., fell $1.625, to $55.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Medalist shareholders will get one Illinois Tool share for every four Medalist shares they own.

title: No Headline
description: The President, if he were not the President, would have delivered a more forceful response to that on the bridge of Mr. Safire's nose."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Kellogg tries to get cereal lovers to look beyond breakfast.
description: YEARS after Florida citrus growers tried to convince consumers that orange juice was "not just for breakfast anymore," the Kellogg Company hopes to stimulate similarly unconventional thoughts about cereal.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Seton Hall

title: Jail for Raucous Air Passenger
description: An Englishman was sentenced today to 30 days in jail for his part in a food fight aboard a jet liner when flight attendants refused to serve him and 17 countrymen more liquor.

title: Biotechnology Companies End Joint Project
description: Sugen Inc. and Amgen Inc. said today that they had agreed to end their collaboration research one year sooner than planned.

title: Judge's Death Clouds Suit Over Tobacco
description: The giant class-action lawsuit against the nation's seven largest tobacco companies faced new uncertainty yesterday after the death of Okla B. Jones 2d, the judge in the New Orleans Federal District Court who was presiding over the case. Judge Jones, who was 50, died on Monday of leukemia.

title: Governor Whitman's Challenge
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey cut taxes even faster than she promised when she ran for office in 1993, and without making comparable cuts in spending. Her popularity has soared as a result. But a series of actions and hints in recent weeks suggest that some of the consequences can no longer be ducked. Her State of the State address tomorrow and her budget message later this month are therefore likely to emphasize austerity, testing her formidable political skills.

title: Stars Rise and Fall in New Mobil Guides
description: ARE the ice cubes in your restaurant too large, too small, not uniform? Are some dishes on the menu too alike in height, color and texture? Then you can forget the top five-star rating in the Mobil Travel Guides for 1996. If there is no selection of bottled waters, you can kiss your three stars goodbye. And without some vegetarian or health-oriented dishes, two stars is out of reach.

title: U.N. May Get Reinforcements From NATO
description: The United Nations peacekeeping force that is expected to disarm the last region of Croatia still held by Croatian Serbs will be strengthened by military support from NATO, diplomats said today. The decision to add to NATO's tasks in the Balkans beyond Bosnia will be spelled out in a Security Council resolution before Jan. 15.

title: HOCKEY;Messier's All-Star Berth Eases Pain
description: The Rangers play host to San Jose tonight and they aren't certain whether their captain, Mark Messier, will be available to play.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Mitterrand's Cancer:An 11-Year Secret
description: PARIS  Francois Mitterrand was diagnosed as having prostate cancer soon after his election in 1981, butthe secret was kept from the nation for more than 10 years, Le Monde said Wednesday.

title: World News Briefs;Oil Pipeline in Colombia Shut by Rebels' Dynamite
description: Dynamite attacks by leftist rebels shut down an oil pipeline in northeastern Colombia this week, a spokesman for the state oil company Ecopetrol said today.

title: Boeing Wins Malaysia Order
description: The Boeing Company won a $4 billion contract today to supply 25 airplanes to Malaysia's national carrier, beating out Airbus Industrie for a major Asian order for the second time in three months.

title: Expectations of Weak Earnings Contribute to Plunge in the Dow
description: The stock market fell sharply yesterday, pulled down by a selloff in technology stocks and wide-scale worries about corporate profits.

title: Business Travel;Disruptions stemming from the big Northeast blizzard could extend into next week.
description: THIS week's great Northeast blizzard landed an equal opportunity migraine on millions of Americans, disrupting lives, jobs and vacations. What is notable about the storm's impact on business travel is that its fury landed just as such travel was returning to normal after its usual holiday hiatus.

title: New Digital Camera Priced Below $1,000
description: The Eastman Kodak Company introduced a digital camera today priced at less than $1,000 and aimed primarily at real estate agents, insurance adjusters and other professionals in the fast-growing market serving small offices or home offices.

title: New York Leads List of Westinghouse Science Semifinalists
description: By the time students make it to the semifinals of the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, they have spent countless hours bent over a marine specimen or staring into a computer screen to study technical data. But many of them have also, at age 14 and 15, persuaded scientists at prestigious laboratories or research universities to let them work with them on their own turf -- sometimes teaching the established scientists a thing or two.

title: Court Backs a City on News-Box Removal
description: An architectural commission has the right under state law to ban newspaper vending machines from the historic Beacon Hill neighborhood, the state's highest court has ruled.

title: Our Towns;With Shovels, Snow Turns Into Windfall
description: THE blizzard entrepreneurs started arriving before sunrise, much to John Stachewski's unhappy surprise.

title: Eating Well
description: AMERICANS say they don't have enough time to eat, so they snack on things that make them feel guilty, like potato chips and candy.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FIGURE SKATING;Bobek to Compete
description: The United States figure skating champion NICOLE BOBEK, nursing an ankle injury, still plans to defend her title next week.

title: Investment Loss Turns 2 Prominent Friends Into Foes
description: When Clark M. Clifford, the former Defense Secretary and adviser to Presidents, was first entangled in a banking scandal in 1991, Pamela C. Harriman, Washington's pre-eminent hostess, rallied 400 members of the city's establishment to his side with a party at her Georgetown home to celebrate the publication of his memoir. As the party drew to a close, the aging Mr. Clifford emerged and made his way past waiting television cameras, clutching Mrs. Harriman's hand.

title: As Manatees Are Being Killed More Often in Florida, Concern GrowsAbout the Species
description: They can be spotted on thousands of Florida motorists' license plates, on T-shirts and in the many marine theme parks around the state. Yet manatees are becoming increasingly hard to find in the wild here.

title: Group Urges an Internet Ban On Hate Groups' Messages
description: Citing "the rapidly expanding presence of organized hate groups on the Internet," a leading Jewish human rights group yesterday began sending letters to hundreds of Internet access providers and universities asking them to refuse to carry messages that "promote racism, anti-Semitism, mayhem and violence."

title: BOOK NOTES;Publisher Retaliates For Attack
description: When the American Booksellers Association announced last week it was slapping Random House with a lawsuit alleging antitrust violations, the publishing house recoiled angrily.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AND MANAGEMENT CO., Denver, a real estate investment trust, acquired eight multifamily apartment properties with a total of 1,940 apartment units for $65.3 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAN RATHER almost made it back without incident to New York from Kuwait on Monday in the blizzard. Almost, but not quite.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE NEGOTIATOR;Senate's Chief Undertaker Of Republican Initiatives
description: When President Clinton and Republican House and Senate leaders first agreed to face-to-face meetings about the budget, the Republicans saw no role for other Democrats. Neither Senator Tom Daschle nor Representative Richard A. Gephardt had any power, they argued, so who needed them?

title: Clinton Sets Bosnia Visit
description: President Clinton will visit American troops in Bosnia this weekend.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EL PASO ELECTRIC MAY EMERGE FROM BANKRUPCTY
description: The El Paso Electric Company's bankruptcy reorganization plan won court approval yesterday, although the judge withheld a final decision on a multimillion-dollar compensation plan for departing company executives. The endorsement of the plan by Federal Bankruptcy Court Judge Frank Monroe could allow El Paso Electric to emerge from four years of bankruptcy proceedings by the end of the month. El Paso Electric became only the second utility to seek bankruptcy court protection since the Depression when it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in January 1992. The plan will give unsecured creditors 85 percent of the company's stock.

title: Nature Chews the Scenery
description: When New York's blizzard of the century was in full swing on Sunday, I was stuffed in a big auditorium in Lower Manhattan with a thousand or so fellow Russian-Americans.

title: Real Estate;A new information technology center in lower Manhattan has so far leased a third of its space.
description: WHEN the Rudin Management Company announced early last summer that it was spending $15 million to renovate a vacant office building at 55 Broad Street and turn it into the New York Information Technology Center, some real estate people were skeptical that enough tenants could be found to fill the building's 400,000 square feet.

title: Sarajevo Grenade Leaves One Dead And 19 Wounded
description: One man was killed and at least 19 other people were wounded today when a grenade slammed into a Sarajevo streetcar in the worst violence since NATO arrived to enforce the peace here.

title: INSIDE
description: Nod to Turkish Muslim Party The leader of a Muslim party that won the largest bloc of seats in Turkish parliamentary elections last month was formally invited to form a coalition government, despite qualms of other parties. Page A2.

title: Caldor President To Leave Post
description: The Caldor Corporation said yesterday that Marc I. Balmuth, its president for nine years, would not renew his contract when it expires this summer.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE NEIGHBORHOOD;One Brooklyn Block Mirrors Millions of Ups and Downs
description: There were three congregants at the 6:45 A.M. Mass at Holy Innocents Roman Catholic Church, and the one woman among them offered her prayers with a shovel in hand.

title: Berlin Orchestra to Open 1996-97 Carnegie Season
description: A gala benefit concert by the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra and the pianist Maurizio Pollini will open the 1996-97 season at Carnegie Hall on Oct. 3. With Claudio Abbado conducting, the all-Brahms program will mark the orchestra's first New York appearance since 1993.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Beijing Makes Change In Output Statistic
description: The value added of China's industrial output amounted to 1.79 trillion yuan, or $215.87 billion, in 1995, a rise of 13.4 percent from 1994, according to figures released yesterday by the State Statistical Bureau through the New China News Agency.

title: Ethiopian Peace Eludes Minority
description: To the Editor:

title: California Chief Proposes School-Choice Plan
description: Gov. Pete Wilson has proposed a limited voucher system in which the state would pay a large part of the costs for students from the state's worst schools to attend the public, private or religious school of their choice.

title: The Storm and Its Impact
description: SCHOOLS

title: A Guilty Verdict for East German Spy Trader
description: A German court today sentenced East Germany's most prominent lawyer, a spy trader who arranged passage from Communism to the West for nearly a quarter of a million people, to a two-year suspended prison term for committing perjury and cheating five former clients out of money and property.

title: Shuttle Is Warmed Up for a 9-Day Mission
description: NASA engineers worked today to keep unusually cold Florida weather from delaying the launching of the space shuttle Endeavour early Thursday.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Come Up Short, in Players and Score
description: Jon Koncak, the Orlando Magic's backup center, looked around his team's locker room before tonight's game against the Nets. "Do we have enough guys to play?" Koncak said.

title: Market Place;A reorganized SCEcorp faces California deregulation plans.
description: SCECORP and its electric utility subsidiary, Southern California Edison, rang in the new year by reorganizing themselves to prepare for the deregulation of California's $20 billion electric utility industry. The move prompted an upbeat reaction from Wall Street analysts, but many continue to hedge their predictions for the coming year, waiting for clearer signs of what a competitive market will look like in California.

title: Hey, New York, Relax. It Does Melt.
description: To the Editor:

title: Fidelity Limits Fund Managers' Comments on Stocks
description: Fidelity Investments, the country's largest mutual fund company, has barred its fund managers from discussing specific companies or stocks in press interviews in response to recent controversy surrounding Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of the $53 billion Magellan fund, and Harry Lange, manager of two other Fidelity funds.

title: Mexico City Journal;Mexico's Robbers Diversify: Nobody's Safe Now
description: Amalia Garcia knew a lot about the soaring crime rate in this capital from the figures she gathered while serving as president of a Mexico City Council committee that monitors public security.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Mrs Baird's Bakeries, Dallas, to Dieste & Partners, Dallas, as the first agency to handle advertising aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers. The billings were not disclosed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Few Takers For Japanese Finance Post
description: The job of running the world's second-largest economy is about to become vacant, and nobody seems to want it.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Avalanche Blanks Bruins

title: Rush Not to Heap Scorn on Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;CBS Pulls Wright Off the Air
description: CBS Sports banished Ben Wright as a golf analyst yesterday, eight months after Wright was quoted by a Delaware newspaper reporter as making pejorative remarks about the impact of lesbianism on the women's golf tour.

title: Bristol-Myers Forms a New Generic-Drugs Unit
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company's generic-drug business, Apothecon, has formed a division to focus on development as part of an effort to become the world's largest producer of generic drugs.

title: A Short School Day for Many Violates Law, Board Is Told
description: The State Department of Education said yesterday that New York City school officials were violating the law by allowing a quarter of the city's high school students to attend class for less than five and a half hours a day.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE AIRPORTS;Laboriously, the Ports Get Back the Air Part
description: For Dave Barger, Continental Airlines' man in charge at Newark International Airport, 48 hours of plowing and de-icing gave way to a single moment of satisfaction this morning as an airplane bound for Florida rose off the runway, snow dust at its tail. Defying gravity is one thing, but watching a plane rise above the blizzard was sweet revenge on nature.

title: Rose Bowl May Join Alliance
description: The Rose Bowl could be incorporated into the college football bowl alliance after the 1998 season, if officials of the Big Ten and Pacific-10 conferences are willing to become involved, the president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association said today.

title: Deep-Fried Foods Find Their Way Back Into the Kitchen
description: IN these fat-free times, people run from the fryer," Michael Romano said from the kitchen of the Union Square Cafe in Manhattan, where he is the executive chef. "But if deep-fat frying is done correctly, I think it's a technique that should be in the repertory of every good cook."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCA Acquires Control of Label
description: MCA Inc. said today that it had acquired the remaining stake in Rising Tide Records from Doug Morris, chairman and chief executive of MCA's Music Entertainment Group.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A royal nursery in Connecticut? Crown Prince PAVLOS, son of the deposed king of Greece, and his wife, Crown Princess PAVLOS (the former MARIE-CHANTAL MILLER), who live in Greenwich, Conn., announced yesterday that they are expecting a baby in late July.

title: William Bloor, 86, Columbia University Treasurer
description: William Bloor, who arrived at Columbia University as a freshman in 1928 and retired in 1979 as its treasurer, overseeing a portfolio of $500 million in securities and real-estate investments, died on Monday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 86 and a longtime resident of the New York Athletic Club on Central Park South.

title: Rush Not to Heap Scorn on Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Admits Illegal Apartment Entries
description: A rogue police sergeant from the corruption-plagued 30th Precinct testified yesterday that the precinct's commander and his top aide led him on a drug raid of a building in which they illegally entered apartments by breaking down doors to gain entry -- a practice that came to be known as "booming."

title: World News Briefs;Rebels and Angola Agree To Resume Peace Effort
description: The opposition movement Unita said today that it had agreed with the Angolan Government on a new timetable to put the country's derailed peace effort back on track.

title: Sports of The Times;Ben Wright Has 4 Years To Get It
description: THE wages of stonewalling are bountiful. Ben Wright so vigorously denied making nasty remarks about women's golf last spring that CBS rewarded him with a new four-year contract.

title: Assuring Olive Oil's Purity
description: To The Living Section:

title: Passing The Toque: For a New Generation, Hospitality Is Destiny
description: WITHOUT scientific proof it may be foolhardy to speculate that the restaurant gene is passed from parent to child as surely as eye color, and that the gene is so strong it conquers all attempts to subdue it.

title: So You Thought Tea Was Just a Bag In Some Hot Water
description: THE afternoon tea in New York City was once the province of buttoned-up hotels on the Upper East Side, catering mostly to Anglophiles who saw the custom, replete with its tiny sandwiches and ceremony, as their civilized pleasure.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COMMUTERS;For Commuters, That Trek To Work Seemed Endless
description: Lawyers, stock clerks and dozens of others who consider themselves essential to 20th-century commerce stood in the waterlogged lobby of the Long Island Rail Road station here this morning, chatting, reading, sipping coffee. It was a scene of suburban civility and restraint.

title: Stocks Slip in Japan
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 70.36 points, or a third of 1 percent, at 20,581.72. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 88.50 points.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PEPSICO SAYS ACCOUNTING CHANGE WILL REDUCE EARNINGS
description: Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings would be reduced by $384 million, or 48 cents a share, because it was adopting new accounting standards. Pepsico, the beverage and food company based in Purchase, N.Y., said the new standards set by the Financial Accounting Standards Board changed the way it valued certain assets in its restaurant segment.

title: Unlucky Art Show Is Off, On, Off And, It Hopes, On
description: On a Monday night in November -- one blizzard and two Government shutdowns ago -- Arthur K. Wheelock Jr., a senior paintings curator at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, sank onto a museum bench and allowed himself a moment of celebratory reflection.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;The Worst Week for the Four Best Teams
description: Twenty-six National Football League teams are down; four are up. Twenty six are extinct; four are alive. That is what the conference championship games give us -- a quartet full of aplomb, a quartet of survivors, a quartet of the fittest.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Countrywide Unit Picks Kovel Kresser
description: The Countrywide Home Loans unit of the Countrywide Corporation in Pasadena, Calif., has named Kovel Kresser & Partners in Santa Monica, Calif., to handle the direct-marketing portion of its account, which for the last eight months had been at the Wunderman Cato Johnson/Los Angeles unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. The billings were estimated at $10 million. Kovel Kresser was awarded the account without a review. Lord, Dentsu & Partners in Los Angeles, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Y.& R., continues to handle the advertising portion of the account.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SPRECKELS TURNS DOWN BID AND SAYS IT'S NOT FOR SALE
description: Spreckels Industries said yesterday that it had rejected a takeover offer of $11 a share, or $67 million, from American Enterprises L.L.C., a Richmond investment firm. American Enterprises, which was formed last year, already owns about 20 percent of the company. But Spreckels, a maker of hoists and lifts that is based in Charlotte, N.C., said it was not for sale. Spreckels also said it expected a loss for the year related to the sale of its Spreckels Sugar unit and related assets to the Imperial Holly Corporation of Sugar Land, Tex. Spreckels said late on Monday that it had agreed to sell the unit for about $24 million, subject to adjustments. Spreckels posted a loss of $2.1 million, or 35 cents a share, on sales of $357 million for the year that ended on June 30.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAIN CAPITAL'S DEAL TO BUY ELLEN TRACY COLLAPSES
description: The sale of the Seventh Avenue design house Ellen Tracy Inc. is off, according to Herbert Gallen, the owner and chairman of the sportswear company. The company signed an agreement in October to sell a majority interest to Bain Capital Inc., an investment concern based in Boston, for undisclosed terms. But Mr. Gallen said yesterday that the deal had fallen apart because of an inability to settle on terms. The company produces two collections: Linda Allard for Ellen Tracy and Company, and Ellen Tracy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COLUMBIA/HCA INTENSIFIES ITS ACQUISITION PLANS
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation plans to step up its acquisition strategy this year and is "working on 150 individual transactions," a company official said yesterday. Victor Campbell, senior vice president at the Nashville-based company, said at a Hambrecht & Quist health care conference in San Francisco that the company was in discussions with individual hospitals and groups of hospitals. Todd Richter, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds, said a third of the talks could result in acquisitions. Columbia/HCA, the largest for-profit hospital company in the nation, bought 41 hospitals in 1995. It owns 339 hospitals and 118 clinics.

title: The Specter In Guatemala
description: The closest election in Guatemalan history has given this Central American country a new President but left a familiar and disconcerting presence looming larger than ever in the background: Gen. Efrain Rios Montt, the country's mercurial former military dictator.

title: Rush Not to Heap Scorn on Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Rush Not to Heap Scorn on Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rite of Passage in France
description: To The Living Section:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOWLING;Aulby Is Honored
description: MIKE AULBY edged DAVE D'ENTREMONT in one of the closest votes in recent years and won the Professional Bowlers Association's player of the year award for a second time. BILLY MYERS JR. was the near unanimous choice as rookie of the year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASEBALL;Two Cubans Prepare to Choose Teams and Cash In
description: The Cuban lottery is nearing a close, and Livan Hernandez is apparently about to win big. The only unknown piece of the lottery is which team will hold the winning ticket.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italian Power Plant
description: Asea Brown Boveri said yesterday that it had received an order worth $470 million to build a 260-megawatt power plant in Italy. The plant will be at an oil refinery in Falconara that is owned by Anonima Petroli Italiana. The order was placed by Api Energia, a 50-50 joint venture between ABB. and Petroli Italiana. The plant will produce electrical power from oil refinery residues. (Associated Press)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;This Novel Got the Author Stabbed
description: CHILDREN OF THE ALLEY By Naguib Mahfouz 448 pages. Doubleday. $24.95

title: To Our Readers
description: The blizzard prevented the International Herald Tribune from printing Tuesday editions in New Yorkfor distribution in North and South America. We apologize for any inconvenience this may have caused.

title: The Neediest Cases;The Political Climate Sways Some Who Aid the Poor
description: Even before this week's blizzard made this winter one for the history books, Jane W. Cooper was remembering those less sheltered than herself, and doing her part to help them. Last month, she sent a $60 check to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, along with her annual note. "To the bitter winds blowing from Washington, Albany and City Hall," she wrote, "are added the chill winds of an early winter."

title: S.E.C. Charges Former Trader For Kidder
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Joseph Jett, a former senior bond trader at Kidder, Peabody & Company, with perpetrating fraud, and it charged that two of his bosses, Melvin Mullin and Edward A. Cerullo, had failed to supervise him adequately.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Unemployment in Germany Rose to 9.9% in December
description: Germany endured a barrage of negative economic news today -- in particular, that unemployment soared in December -- creating a sense of gloom that has not been seen since the country began to climb out of its worst postwar recession more than two years ago.

title: Toll Road Promises Pollution Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Rush Not to Heap Scorn on Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Silent Snow, Lethal Snow
description: Among the certain accompaniments to a storm like the Blizzard of '96 is death. People die of hypothermia (though not, so far, in New York City), in automobile accidents, in falls on the ice. Many suffer fatal heart attacks simply because they were trying to be good citizens by shoveling the snow off their sidewalks, their front steps or their cars.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AROUND THE REGION;For Some, Adventure. For Others, Survival.
description: It was the most elegant of winter retreats, the King Cole Bar of the St. Regis Hotel. A couple from England sat sipping drinks as they waited to catch a flight home, savoring the unexpected experience of being here during New York's great blizzard.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Stars Hire Hitchcock To Replace Gainey
description: KEN HITCHCOCK took over as head coach of the slumping National Hockey League Dallas Stars yesterday, replacing BOB GAINEY. Gainey stepped down Monday, saying the team needed a change. He will remain as general manager and vice president of operations.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUNTORY IN ACCORD TO BUY BOTTLED WATER RIVAL
description: The Suntory International Corporation reached a $290 million deal yesterday to buy the Hinckley & Schmitt Bottled Water Group, a unit of the Anjou International Company. Suntory, the United States subsidiary of Suntory Ltd. of Japan, said the acquisition would lift it to second place from fifth among bottled water producers in the United States. dHinckley & Schmitt, a 107-year-old business based in Chicago, is the third-largest bottled water company in the nation, with annual sales of more than $175 million. Hinckley & Schmitt will operate autonomously from the Suntory Water Group, which sells water under several brand names, including Belmont Springs, Crystal Springs, Kentwood and Polar. Anjou is the Unites States holding company of Compagnie Generale des Eaux of France.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, the diagram and table of moves with the Chess column in Science Times yesterday, about a match between Vladimir Kramnik and Aleksandr Belyavsky, were omitted from some copies. They are printed today on page C14.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Florida's Fashion Statement
description: A dispute in Florida over the right of high school girls to wear skintight uniforms in track-and-field events and cross-country meets illustrates the problems faced by young female athletes who seek autonomy in areas traditionally dominated by men.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CPC EXPECTS CHARGE AS RESULT OF KRAFT BAKING PURCHASE
description: CPC International Inc. said yesterday that it expected to reduce fourth-quarter earnings by $34 million, or 23 cents a share, to account for the cost of integrating the recently acquired Kraft baking operations into its existing baking business. CPC International, of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., said the charge included the costs of eliminating duplicate administration, warehouses, business systems and jobs. The consolidation will include the closing of CPC's baking business headquarters in Fairfield, N.J. CPC earned $136.5 million, or 90 cents a share, in the 1994 fourth quarter. It bought the Kraft baking operations for $865 million from the Philip Morris Companies in October.

title: New York City Newsstand Proposal Won't Fly
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996:;Leaflets Dropped in Snow Rescue Effort
description: Borrowing a technique used behind enemy lines in wartime, park rangers in helicopters dropped leaflets over Shenandoah National Park today in search of eight groups of hikers who are feared stranded in 47 inches of snow.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;Snow-Clogged Region Stirs Back to Life As Novelty Fades and Frustrations Mount
description: The New York region rolled up its sleeves yesterday and tackled the gigantic task of coming out from under the Blizzard of '96 as airports and roads reopened, business resumed and people at least tried to return to work.

title: Killing of Bomb 'Engineer' Unites Palestinian Factions
description: Few politicians in the Middle East mourned the slaying of the master bomb-maker known as the Engineer, but leaders of all Palestinian political and religious leanings lined up outside the Palestine Mosque on Saturday to express their condolences for his death.

title: John Gronouski, 76, Kennedy-Era Postal Chief
description: John A. Gronouski, a rumpled economics professor who parlayed an academic tax study and his ethnic background into a public service career that included stints as Postmaster General and Ambassador to Poland, died on Sunday in a hospital in Green Bay, Wisc. He was 76 and had lived in Green Bay since retiring in 1989 as a professor at the Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs at the University of Texas.

title: Sports of The Times;Few 'Podnuhs' Root For This Cowboy
description: IF he wore a Cowboys cap, it wouldn't have a peak. In circumventing the National Football League's team payroll cap of $37.2 million, Jerry Jones spent $62 million in salaries and bonuses this season, nearly a third as much as most teams did. His maverick deals with Nike and Pepsi inspired a $300 million litigation by the N.F.L., which he is now suing for $750 million.

title: Court Rejects Move to Delay Clinton Case
description: A divided Federal appellate court panel today dealt President Clinton a defeat by ruling that he had no constitutional basis to delay a potentially seamy trial in which he would have to defend himself against sexual harassment charges by a former Arkansas clerical worker.

title: Rush Not to Heap Scorn on Mrs. Clinton
description: To the Editor:

title: Expectant Lawmaker Won't Run This Fall
description: Representative Blanche Lambert Lincoln, Democrat of Arkansas, said today that she would not run for a third term this November because she is expecting twins in July.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: Trenton;For Constitution, Snow Was Nothing
description: The State Constitution said the 206th session of the New Jersey Legislature had to end at noon, and nothing, not even a little bit of snow, could change that.

title: Welfare Bill Vetoed
description: President Clinton vetoed a Republican plan to overhaul the nation's welfare system, saying the bill made excessive spending cuts and did "too little to move people from welfare to work." Page B7.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: VICTIMS;19 Deaths in the Region Are Attributed to the Blizzard
description: As many as 19 deaths in the metropolitan region were attributed yesterday either directly or indirectly to the blizzard, officials said, including at least 7 people who died from heart attacks while clearing snow and an 11-year-old boy who was killed by a plow as he played in the snow.

title: AIDS and Advertising
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Spy Chief Named Foreign Minister
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin today nominated Yevgeny M. Primakov, director of Russia's foreign intelligence service and a member of the powerful Russian Security Council, to replace Andrei V. Kozyrev, the President's longtime Foreign Minister. Mr. Kozyrev was ousted on Friday after prolonged criticism that he was too accommodating to the West.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Forte Cool To New Offer By Granada
description: The Granada Group P.L.C. increased its hostile takeover offer for Forte P.L.C. by 15 percent today by adding a special dividend, but the target company continued to spurn the approach.

title: Chicago Journal;Believe It or Not, Voting Is Almost Free of Fraud
description: In the days of the fabled Democratic Machine here, it was hardly a secret that some votes were being cast by the dead. The typical Chicagoan did not lose sleep over this subtle election irregularity. Indeed, to plenty of loyal Democrats, it made more sense than someone who was alive voting for a Republican.

title: New Jersey Firm and S.E.C. Settle Case in Bond Inquiry
description: The First Fidelity Securities Group of Newark agreed yesterday to pay $2.3 million to settle charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it paid secret kickbacks to a former New Jersey county official to get lucrative bond underwriting business. The firm neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing.

title: Foreign Affairs;Hafez Answers Chris
description: Sunday's column was about how Secretary of State Warren Christopher should address Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, when they meet in Damascus tomorrow. Here's what Mr. Assad would answer if he were speaking candidly:

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: PLOWING;Despite Plowers' Efforts, Not All Streets Are Clear
description: On Monday evening, Sanitation Commissioner John J. Doherty was brimming with confidence.

title: Journal;Let 'Em Eat Vermeer
description: Bad Joke Dep't.:

title: Dun & Bradstreet to Split Into 3 Public Companies
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation said late yesterday that it intended to transform itself into three publicly traded companies, joining a wave of corporations that are taking steps to give more value to shareholders.

title: To Stretch or Not to Stretch: Exercisers' Debate Continues
description: MARK ALLEN never does stretching exercises. In October, he won the Ironman Triathlon in Hawaii (2.5-mile swim, 112-mile bike ride and 26.2-mile run) for the sixth time.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The pink security wall that WALTER H. ANNENBERG had constructed around his desert estate has some of his Rancho Mirage, Calif., neighbors seeing red, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: The Practice Bubble Of Giants Collapses
description: The Giants' indoor practice facility collapsed from heavy snow and wind on Sunday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EARNINGS RESULT IN A SPECIAL DIVIDEND AT ALCOA
description: The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it would pay shareholders a special cash dividend of 43 cents a share because 1995 earnings exceeded $3 a share. The company, the world's largest aluminum maker, pays a special dividend of 30 percent of the amount exceeding annual per-share earnings of $3, said Al Posti, a company spokesman. On Monday, Pittsburgh-based Alcoa posted net income for the year of $790.5 million, or $4.43 a share, the company's best results since 1989. The bonus dividend is in addition to Alcoa's regular quarterly dividend of 22.5 cents a share.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Alcoholic Beverage Assignments Made
description: Two marketers of alcoholic beverages announced agency assignments yesterday.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Drop On Impasse Over Budget
description: The bond market fell sharply yesterday, posting its biggest decline in three weeks, after President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders broke off their negotiations on the Federal budget.

title: Brown Has Minor Surgery
description: Good news for Giants quarterback Dave Brown: The unrestricted free agent had minor surgery on his left knee yesterday and the procedure revealed that he will not need more extensive surgery to repair damaged cartilage.

title: Whitman Wins Last-Minute Passage of Arbitration Changes
description: In an unexpected victory for Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, the State Senate gave final approval today to most of her plan to overhaul the system that resolves pay disputes involving members of police and fire unions.

title: 2,500 a Pound for Tea
description: DONALD R. WALLIS drinks 20 to 30 cups of tea a day. These are not ordinary teas; they are virtually unknown outside China. He said that in 1994 he sipped the entire world's supply of the highest-grade dragon well green tea from Zhejiang province in central China.

title: Duane Hanson, 70, Sculptor Of Super-Realistic Figures, Dies
description: Duane Hanson, an artist whose super-realist sculptures of blond cheerleaders, beer-bellied tourists and other ordinary Americans earned him vast popular acclaim, but also disdain in some art circles, died on Saturday at Boca Raton Community Hospital in Florida. He was 70.

title: State Universities Raise Their Standards, and Enhance Their Appeal
description: For a lot of Florida parents who went to college here, the only thing more frightening than an enormous lineman from the University of Nebraska is a thin envelope from the University of Florida.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COST;Some Businesses Get a Windfall, But More Suffer With the Snow
description: Mohammad Iqubal measures the blast of this week's record-book blizzard not in inches, but in dollars.

title: About New York;A Tepee Comes Down, and Hackles Are Raised
description: CHRIS RAMOS wants his tepee back on Rockaway Parkway. And his sweat lodge, too.

title: South Korean President Admits to Slush Fund
description: President Kim Young Sam admitted today that he had engaged in "wrong practices" of accepting donations for an apparent political slush fund, but he insisted that he had stopped taking gifts by the time he became President.

title: BASKETBALL;Ewing's Return Energizes Knicks
description: There was no small placard posted at the entrance of Madison Square Garden that read, "Playing the role of Patrick Ewing this evening will be. . . ." For the first time in almost two weeks, Ewing was there. On the floor, in the paint and sometimes above the rim.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Merrill Is Seeking To Acquire Spanish Firm
description: Merrill Lynch & Company is negotiating to acquire all or part of F. G. Inversiones Bursatiles, Spain's biggest independent brokerage firm, people familiar with the talks said yesterday. Merrill Lynch's Madrid office would not comment on a news report that an agreement was at hand.

title: World News Briefs;Bahrain Opposition Says Police Fired on Protesters
description: A Bahraini opposition group said today that police in the Gulf Arab state fired live bullets and tear-gas to quell large anti-Government demonstrations.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Monster Mom and Dim Daughter Amid Mystical Mists
description: Let us sing the ways of mother in Off Broadway drama these days: M is for the mess you made of my life; O is for the child you overlooked; T is for your touch-me-not demeanor. . . .

title: First Capote Award Goes to Alfred Kazin
description: The first Truman Capote Lifetime Achievement Award in Literary Criticism, worth $100,000 and given by the author's estate, was awarded yesterday to Alfred Kazin. Mr. Kazin helped make American literature a subject of serious study with his first book, "On Native Grounds," published in 1942, and has since written numerous works of criticism and memoirs. His most recent book is "Writing Was Everything."

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Abuse of the Retarded By Their Caretakers
description: Abuse of the mentally retarded is an investigative perennial. Expose is followed by reform is followed by expose in a dismaying round that leaves one feeling that nothing much can be done to protect the most vulnerable among us from the violence or neglect of their keepers.

title: Islamic Party in Turkey Is Asked to Form Coalition
description: Necmettin Erbakan, leader of the party that won the largest bloc of seats in parliamentary elections here last month, was formally invited today to form a coalition government, despite the avowed refusal of other political parties to cooperate with his pro-Islamic group.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: NEW YORK'S GOVERNOR;Pataki Gathers Praise for Aid Without Stepping Into a Drift
description: Governor George E. Pataki missed the region's biggest snowstorm in half a century -- he was stuck in Albany on Monday, where not a flake fell -- so today he set out to tour New York City. But he never once stepped through a snowdrift.

title: Chechen Raid Again Captures Many Russians
description: In an audacious repetition of one of Russia's worst military humiliations, a band of Chechen rebels stormed a large hospital in the center of this southern Russian city on Tuesday, taking an estimated 2,000 hostages, leaving scores dead and promising to leave only when Russian troops withdraw from Chechnya.

title: HOCKEY;Isles Happy to Keep Up With Blackhawks
description: Thankful for small favors, the Islanders salvaged a 3-3 tie against the Chicago Blackhawks tonight after gaining an off-the-ice victory during the day.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: Manhattan Bridge;Braving The Elements
description: On Sunday night, the Coalition for the Homeless served 744 turkey-salami sandwiches to homeless people still on the streets. On Monday night, the group handed out 700 bowls of hot chili.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Lean Days Saltimbocca
description: The traditional version of saltimbocca calls for veal, but that was from the days when veal was less expensive than chicken.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Technology Stocks Tumble, Pulling Down Wider Market
description: Technology stocks plunged yesterday, taking much of the stock market with them, as investors acted on fears that the sector's quarterly earnings reports, to be released over the next few weeks, would not meet expectations.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Earnhardt Stays On
description: Moving to quiet speculation about his possible retirement, DALE EARNHARDT yesterday agreed to a contract extension that commits him to driving on the Winston Cup circuit through 2000.

title: HOCKEY;The Devils Find a Way to Solve Keenan
description: Mike Keenan played musical chairs with the Blues goaltenders tonight, but it was the Devils who left on a winning note.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Brazil Government Changes Rules for Creating Indian Reservations
description: Brazil, trying to resolve a dispute between businessmen and Indians over land, rewrote the rules today for creating reservations over the protests of Indian activists who say their homelands are at risk.

title: Lawsuits to End All Lawsuits;Settlements May Limit Victims' Future Right to Sue
description: Imagine you are diagnosed with a disease linked to a toxic substance, but then discover you can't sue its manufacturer. The reason: A lawsuit settled years earlier limited your ability to do so, even though you never heard about the deal or met the lawyers who made fortunes supposedly representing you.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE LEGISLATION;Clinton Vetoes G.O.P. Plan To Change Welfare System
description: President Clinton tonight vetoed a wide-ranging Republican plan to overhaul the nation's welfare system, saying the bill did "too little to move people from welfare to work" and made excessive cuts in spending on welfare.

title: Ford, in a Shift, Is Offering Rebates to Increase Sales
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had started offering $600 rebates and discount financing on nearly all its vehicles in an acknowledgment that it had miscalculated the strength of the market.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF HCC INSURANCE UP 14% AFTER ACQUISITION DEAL
description: The shares of HCC Insurance Holdings Inc. rose nearly 14 percent yesterday after the company agreed late on Monday to buy LDG Management, an insurance underwriting management company, in a stock transaction worth $92.2 million. HCC's shares were up $5.125, to $42, on the New York Stock Exchange. LDG, based in Wakefield, Mass., had 1995 revenue of about $27 million, mainly from management fees. LDG's operations in London will help HCC's overseas expansion, the company said. HCC, a Houston-based property and casualty insurer, had revenue of $59.9 million in 1994. HCC is to pay 2.5 million common shares of its common stock for LDG.

title: Borough President Stands on Her Record
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AT HOME;Who's at Home With the Baby? Snow Worsens Couples' Woes
description: The snow-shrouded roads around their house were finally clear enough to allow them to drive to work, so Robin and Robert Gaines today faced the problem that haunts most working couples: Who stays home with the children?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rolls Sales Up 10%
description: Vickers P.L.C. said yesterday that it had sold 1,556 Rolls-Royce cars in 1995, up 10 percent from 1994. The biggest increases were in North America and South America, where sales rose 25 percent, to 420 cars. In the British market, sales rose 7 percent, to 493 vehicles. This equaled the 7 percent rise on the Continent, where 230 cars were sold. In Japan, Vickers sold 121 cars, up 4 percent. The only drop was in the Middle East, down 5 percent, to 71 cars. (Reuters)

title: Swimmer Dies After a Meet
description: A star swimmer for the University of Massachusetts died of a heart attack today after collapsing during a meet at Dartmouth College.

title: Man in the News: Ryutaro Hashimoto;A Japanese Unafraid of the Summit
description: Japanese Prime Ministers have tended to be weak and faceless, men who stand forlornly at the edge of the group photograph when world leaders gather and whose policies are soon forgotten even by their own countrymen after they leave office.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAUSCH & LOMB LAYOFFS AND EARNINGS CHARGE
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. said yesterday that it would consolidate its sunglasses business, closing a plant in Oakland, Md., and eliminating about 800 jobs by the end of the year as part of a three-year reorganization plan. The maker of optics and health products, based in Rochester said that plant's 600 jobs would be eliminated and 200 jobs would be cut this year at a Rochester frame-making plant. The company plans to take a $27 million charge for the reorganization, which is expected to reduce fourth-quarter and 1995 earnings by about 30 cents a share. The company's chief executive, Daniel E. Gill, retired last month amid investor discontent and investigations into company sales and marketing practices.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;On the Road With a Hustler of an Elegant Game
description: PLAYING OFF THE RAIL A Pool Hustler's Journey By David McCumber 367 pages. Random House. $25.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE FORECAST;The Respite For Shovelers May Be Brief
description: Heads up: here comes the next winter storm. But forecasters say its bite will be nothing like that of the blizzard that deposited more than 20 inches of snow on New York and upwards of two and a half feet on parts of the metropolitan region on Sunday and Monday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Fuel-Spill Refugees Go Home
description: About 75 refugees from a fuel spill went back home yesterday after a sleep over at the local high school. The residents were evacuated from their homes Tuesday after a freight train hit a tanker truck stuck at a snowy crossing in this Bergen County community.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: METRO-NORTH;Angry Crowd Packs Grand Central
description: A shortage of working Metro-North Commuter Railroad trains during last evening's rush hour left thousands of commuters stranded in Grand Central Terminal, where they endured long waits, and the occasional arrival of a train caused virtual stampedes to already overflowing cars.

title: Dow Plunges 97.19 Points And Drops Below 5,100
description: Stock prices plummeted yesterday, spurred by the budget impasse in Washington and rising interest rates.

title: Under Tubes and Tents
description: WHEN Sigeru Ban, the architect of the Paper Dome Takatori in Kobe, learned that many of the Vietnamese immigrants in the Nagata Ward were still holed up in tent camps seven months after the earthquake, he took on another task. He used his paper-tube technology to build homes.

title: Gold-Rush Town Tries To Survive on History
description: A year after gold was discovered here in 1863, the population swelled to more than 7,000 and this mountain-ringed town became Montana's capital.

title: High Court Hears Arguments For Census Alteration by Race
description: A long-running dispute over whether the 1990 census figures should be statistically adjusted to correct a racially disparate undercount finally reached the Supreme Court today.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: SHOVELING;As Sidewalks Are Cleared, Mountains Meet Lakes
description: While New York City's snowplows worked overtime clearing streets, building managers, store owners and homeowners were rushing to meet Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's deadline to have a path cleared on their sidewalks by 11 A.M. yesterday or face a $50 or $100 fine.

title: M. L. Lawrence, Entrepreneur And Ambassador, Is Dead at 69
description: M. Larry Lawrence, who rose from poverty to become a wealthy entrepreneur and then Ambassador to Switzerland, died Tuesday in Bern at the age of 69.

title: Market Place;Stocks Dive, Reflecting Wall St. Ire Toward Washington
description: The stock market plunged yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping 97.19 points, capping the largest two-day decline in more than four years.

title: Dagana Journal;Where Proud Moors Rule, Blacks Are Outcasts
description: Gazing across the broad blue expanse of the Senegal River into Mauritania, Alassane Watt, a stubble-bearded 72-year-old farmer, recently saw for himself what neighbors had been telling him about for months.

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks Lack Defense, and Nets Take Advantage
description: The Knicks may have their big man back, but they continue to search for the one ingredient so elementary in the franchise's success.

title: H.M.O. Gag Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: American Home Dropping Infant Formulas
description: Wyeth-Ayerst, a division of the American Home Products Corporation, has decided to phase out its United States infant-formula business, resulting in a plant closing and the loss of 550 jobs.

title: World News Briefs;Death Toll Rises to 350 In Air Crash in Zaire
description: Officials said today that they found the flight recorder from a Russian-biult cargo plane that crashed into the central market here on Monday, and the aid group Doctors Without Borders put the death toll from the crash at more than 350.

title: Home Sweet Elsewhere
description: WHAT is the latest status symbol of the ultra rich? A spectacular residence they purchase for millions, reconfigure with the world's leading architects and interior designers for even more millions, then elect not to live in.

title: Civilians Can't Enforce Bosnia Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Prayers Answered With Paper
description: LAST Jan. 17, the world looked on in horror at images of Kobe's devastating earthquake. Among the casualties was the Takatori Catholic Church, a plain wooden structure that was leveled by a fire that followed the quake, leaving the congregation of 600 Vietnamese immigrants, ethnic Koreans and poor Japanese with little hope of restoring their sanctuary.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: RELIEF;Snowed-In States Seek Federal Disaster Aid
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency said today that the blizzard that buried the East Coast this week prompted New York and Maryland to make an unusual request -- that they be declared disaster areas despite having sustained little damage.

title: New Admissions Policy Offered
description: The San Francisco Superintendent of Schools has proposed a new admissions policy for the city's best high school that would require all students to meet the same academic standard.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Princeton Is the Top Giver
description: Princeton is No. 1 when it comes to donations to candidates in the 1996 Presidential race. In the latest reports from the Federal Election Commission, Princeton ranked first in New Jersey on the fund-raising lists of President Clinton and several of his Republican challengers, including Senators Bob Dole, Phil Gramm and Richard Lugar and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee.

title: A City Firefighter's Funeral, in Agonizing Replay
description: For the mourners in dark uniforms who gathered today in the Church of St. Lawrence the Martyr, the rituals of death had become painfully familiar: a bagpipe's shuddering notes, a red fire truck reserved for funerals and the New York City Mayor paying tribute to yet another firefighter killed on the job.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: St. Lawrence

title: Now Bring Democracy to Bear on Corporate Downsizing
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Less Than Full Faith
description: By vetoing the first balanced budget in a quarter century, President Clinton did more than leave the country without a spending plan. He simultaneously torpedoed the Congressionally approved increase in the $4.9 trillion limit on the national debt, thereby risking default on outstanding Treasury obligations. The Administration's unprecedented decision to continue borrowing without authority, thereby avoiding default, may soon precipitate an even more serious crisis.

title: Bosnian Mine Is Thought to Hold Evidence of Mass Killings
description: The vast open-pit iron mine, the hulks of ore-processing machinery and the bulldozers lie blanketed in snow, but the scene is not abandoned. Outside the gates of the complex, closed for four years, heavily armed soldiers patrol and the dirt roads leading to the heart of the mine are blocked with land mines.

title: Teen-Ager Becomes Youngest On Death Row in Arkansas
description: A 17-year-old Arkansas man was sentenced to death on Tuesday night by a jury that convicted him of rape, robbery and murder in the death of an 85-year-old woman one year before.

title: Flat Tax Is Simple Only for the Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Savoy Hotel Says Profit Jumped in 1995
description: Savoy Hotels P.L.C., the London luxury-hotel company that is 68 percent owned by Forte P.L.C., said yesterday that it expected to post a big gain in pretax profit for 1995 and promised to double its dividend.

title: Celebrating a Little-Known Influence on Art Deco
description: A LOT of people know that Picasso and Modigliani collected African masks, which inspired their paintings during the 1930's. Fewer realize there was also a significant influence on architecture and design by African-Americans during the Art Deco era, the 1920's and 30's.

title: Calendar: An Auction, An Exhibition, a Tour
description: A Piece of History Russian Tea Room, 150 West 57th Street; 212 427-2730.

title: Mavericks' Harris Stays on Sidelines
description: The Dallas Mavericks placed the already ailing guard Lucious Harris on the injured list today and replaced him on the roster with forward Reggie Slater, who was signed to a 10-day contract.

title: Clinton Signs Law Barring Some State Tax on Retirees
description: President Clinton signed legislation yesterday that gives a tax break to tens of thousands of people who have retired to states with no income taxes or lower rates than the states where they lived during their working lives.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Budget Block Knocks Down Bond Prices
description: Bond prices fell sharply yesterday, hurt by the gloomier outlook for budget talks in Washington. The drop sent yields on long-term Treasury issues back up to the levels of three weeks ago, before the Federal Reserve cut interest rates.

title: Richard Schoenherr, 60, Scholar Who Showed a Decline of Priests
description: Richard A. Schoenherr, a professor of sociology whose study of the decline in the number of Roman Catholic priests helped to raise public awareness of that trend, died on Tuesday at his home. He was 60 and lived in Madison, Wis.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COST;Experts Call It a Billion-Dollar Blizzard
description: This week's blizzard could end up costing the New York region more than $1 billion, economists said yesterday after roughly calculating the costs of storm damage and cleanup and the economic activity that was lost because of the storm.

title: Russia's Jews Organize, With Swiss Caterer's Help
description: For 70 years, Communism all but extinguished Jewish life and religious instruction in the Soviet Union.
