Since Communism's collapse, many Russian Jews who have chosen to stay here have been rediscovering their roots and opening schools, synagogues and community centers. But Jewish philanthropy and high-profile leadership have not flourished.

title: Hussein and Christopher Make Twin Visits to Israel
description: Israelis reacted with considerable excitement today to a visit by King Hussein of Jordan and the arrival of the American Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, who began a new round of Middle East shuttle diplomacy to try to bring peace between Israel and Syria.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: PHILADELPHIA;Plows Shun 900 Miles of Narrow Streets
description: Somewhere under that mound of snow on Venango Street was Eddie Morris's Chevrolet Cavalier.

title: German Official Calls for Security Surveillance of Scientologists
description: In the long-running duel between the German authorities and the Church of Scientology, a senior Government official urged today that it be placed under surveillance by the same internal security agency that tracks terrorists and political extremists.

title: Shutdown Affecting Rate Policy
description: Alan Blinder, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, said last night that the temporary halt in the Government's release of economic reports had made it more difficult for the Fed to set interest-rate policy. The Government has stopped publishing the reports as a result of the partial shutdown.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Gloomy Astra Outlook
description: The stock of the Swedish drug company Astra tumbled 4.7 percent yesterday after the company said investors' expectations for 1996 and 1997 profits were on the high side. Astra said investors had not taken into account the effect of the strong Swedish krona in forecasting profit. (Reuters)

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Asking Inmates to Buy Meals
description: Morris County's Sheriff, Edward V. Rochford, thinks inmates in his jail should be required to pay for their meals.

title: OPERA REVIEW;A Russian Makes Debut In 'Boheme'
description: Forced by the snowstorm to cancel Monday night's performance of "The Makropulos Case," the Metropolitan Opera returned as scheduled on Tuesday with "La Boheme." A hardy audience filled about two-thirds of the house for this popular Franco Zeffirelli production. The main interest for a reviewer was the Met debut of a Russian tenor as Rodolfo and two cast changes.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Growing Pineapples

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Reckitt Consolidates Its Global Accounts
description: Reckitt & Colman P.L.C. said yesterday that it would consolidate the assignments for products sold around the world, like Airwick and Wizard air fresheners and Dettol antiseptic, at McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Georgia Tech Stuns Carolina
description: Drew Barry hit two free throws with 2.5 seconds remaining tonight as Georgia Tech survived a late comeback to beat No. 10 North Carolina, 80-77, at the Omni.

title: Fertility Treatment Has Good Success Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: Motion to Replace Papandreou Fails
description: Greece's Socialist Government early today defeated a censure motion submitted in Parliament by the conservative opposition to press the governing party to quickly replace the ailing Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Why Dun & Bradstreet Is Different From Disney
description: Splitting big companies into smaller ones has been the norm in American business recently -- witness the breakup of corporate brand names like AT&T, ITT and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing.

title: Early Ally of Suicide Doctor Now Faces the Ultimate Decision
description: Dr. Jack Kevorkian was virtually unknown back in 1989, when Janet Good essentially started Michigan's "right to die" movement by founding a chapter of the Hemlock Society in her suburban living room.

title: Economic Scene;A study shows bias against the ugly. Should they have recourse?
description: IS prejudice in hiring ever justified? Most Americans agree that discrimination on racial, sexual or religious grounds is wrong. But what about against people who just happen to be ugly?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Henderson Investigation
description: The Internal Revenue Service is apparently investigating RICKEY HENDERSON, baseball's stolen base leader.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Omnicom Agrees to Buy Ketchum Communications
description: The omnivorous Omnicom Group, the parent of giant agencies like BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide, devoured another independent shop yesterday by agreeing unexpectedly to acquire Ketchum Communications.

title: Snow Ho!
description: SNOW is swirling outside the window, caking up on the screens and whisking off the roof. It's times like these that it's nice to seek shelter by the fireplace and watch the storm from indoors.

title: Saint-Gobain in Georgia
description: The Saint-Gobain Group, a French conglomerate that is one of the world's largest glass makers, is building a $40 million plant in Newton County, Ga., to make perfume bottles. Construction is expected to begin later this month on 36 acres. The plant manager, William Leahy, said that hiring to fill about 125 jobs should start after the Atlanta Olympics in July and August. Saint-Gobain clients include Estee Lauder, Calvin Klein, Elizabeth Arden and Tiffany.

title: Currents;Silver Chalices Spin Out Modern Myths
description: THERE are no shrinking violets among the dried flowers at Melonie de France, a store that specializes in dried flower arrangements and that opened in November. The flowers, whether red roses or lavender, are vivid. And their presentation -- often tied up with silk or raffia -- is similarly bold and graphic. The designs are made in France.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Germany Trims Money Market Rates
description: The German central bank trimmed money market rates yesterday, in what may be the start of cuts that analysts said were needed to stimulate flagging economies in Germany and across Europe. The bank cut its chief money market rate, the securities repurchase rate, by 2 basis points, to 3.73 percent from 3.71 percent. Belgium followed with a 5-basis-point reduction in its central rate, to 3.70 percent.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Tribute to Chaliapin by Young Russians
description: Saturday's vocal concert at Carnegie Hall was billed as "A Tribute to the Legendary Russian Bass Feodor Chaliapin," but the real idea seemed to be to showcase a group of young professional singers from the former Soviet Union.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS ;U.S. to Withhold Sanctions In Tricontinental Banana Rift
description: The Clinton Administration will not immediately impose sanctions against Costa Rica and Colombia in a trade dispute involving bananas, officials said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MELVILLE CUTS DIVIDEND DURING REORGANIZATION
description: The Melville Corporation, the struggling retailer whose chains include CVS and Kay-Bee, cut its quarterly dividend 71 percent yesterday to 11 cents a common share from 38 cents. The company said it would pay the new dividend on Feb. 1 to shareholders of record as of Jan. 23. Melville, based in Rye, N.Y., has been closing stores and cutting jobs and had announced plans to split into three independent retailing companies: a drug chain, and footwear and toy businesses. In addition, Melville's senior vice president and chief financial officer, Gary L. Crittenden, resigned yesterday to join Sears, Roebuck & Company as an executive vice president. Melville said Carlos E. Alberini, a company vice president, would serve as acting chief financial officer.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 234.40 points, or 1.14 percent, at 20,377.92. On Wednesday, the Nikkei closed down 39.76 points.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE SNOW;Cold Comfort: It Was Lighter On the Shovel
description: It may seem improbable to anyone who has spent the last two days digging out his car, but scientists say this week's snowfall was unusually fluffy.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;Calibrating Just How Tough an Inquiry Should Be
description: One of the few things still at work in the heart of the Federal Government today was the pursuit of scandal.

title: Rickel Home Centers Seeks Chapter 11 Protection
description: Rickel Home Centers Inc. sought bankruptcy protection today, after announcing in December that it was having difficulty repaying its debts.

title: Israel Frees 800 Arabs
description: Israel freed 812 Palestinian prisoners to jubilant relatives in the West Bank and Gaza today, 10 days before the first Palestinian national elections.

title: A Mitterrand Legacy:Fall-Off in Relations With U.S.
description: PARIS  Perhaps the least publicized legacy of former President Francois Mitterrand was a poisonous estrangement from Washington in the 1990s that constricted attempts to forge a new trans-Atlantic deal on Western security.

title: Mr. Vallone's Brave Proposal
description: The physical condition of New York City's schools is a municipal disaster. Exploding enrollment has left children going to class in hallways, gymnasiums and even bathrooms. Meanwhile, leaking roofs, crumbling window frames and 19th-century heating systems are destroying existing buildings faster than the city can put up new ones. The present generation of New York officials has been painfully aware of the problem for a long time. But until now, no one has had the courage to tackle it.

title: A Threat to Journalism
description: Journalism will not thrive robustly if reporters are made to disclose confidential sources and the byproducts of newsgathering, like their notes or unused footage of videotaped interviews. That is the reason for the protection such material enjoys under the First Amendment and the New York State Shield Law. It is also why an impending Federal court showdown in a case involving NBC's "Dateline" program bears close watching.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Red Sox Get Expos' Cordero
description: The Montreal Expos traded infielder WIL CORDERO to the Boston Red Sox for the left-hander RHEAL CORMIER yesterday, swapping a rising star for a local hero with a much cheaper price.

title: Judge Allows Gay Bias Suit Vs. Big Board
description: A former employee of the New York Stock Exchange has been allowed to push ahead with a lawsuit accusing the exchange of dismissing him because he is a homosexual.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about the trial of a former Italian Prime Minister, Giulio Andreotti, misstated the progress of the case. As noted in the article, the trial began in September, not this week.

title: 2 Indicted in Attempt To Bomb Tax Office
description: Two men accused of trying to blow up an Internal Revenue Service office here with a 100-pound homemade bomb were indicted today by a Federal grand jury.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Does the Name 'Barkley' Fit on Garden Marquee?
description: It was another one of those nights when the Knicks leave little doubt as to which direction they are headed. They walked into Continental Airlines Arena and were more or less shut down like the three metropolitan area airports on Sunday night. They scored 79 points, 65 of which came in the first three quarters. Do the math, and what you come up with is one Knick star and many fractions that do not add up to the running mate Patrick Ewing still has never had.

title: World News Briefs;At Least 60 Peacekeepers Killed in Liberia Fighting
description: More than 60 soldiers of the Liberia peacekeeping force died during battles with guerrillas in the town of Tubmanburg last week, residents said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The partial shutdown of the Federal Government may have ended for now, but its effects are reverberating in, among other places, a New York jazz club.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: PLOWING;Snowbanks Aside, the Sanitation Department Declares a Victory
description: The declaration was of triumph, if not total independence: Sanitation Department officials, conceding that the gargantuan amounts of snow in the city still posed enduring problems, said nonetheless that every street in the city had been plowed by yesterday -- except for the several dozen streets blocked by abandoned cars.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRIMECO TO BUY VIBROPLANT U.S. FOR $67.5 MILLION
description: Primeco Inc. said yesterday that it would purchase Vibroplant U.S. Inc. from Vibroplant P.L.C. in a deal valued at $67.5 million, including the payment of existing debt. Primeco is owned by Investcorp S.A., a privately held merchant bank in New York. In conjunction with the transaction, Investcorp agreed to invest an additional $10 million in Primeco. Dallas-based Vibroplant U.S. is a heavy-equipment rental business, also known as American Hi-Lift Corporation, and has annual revenue of about $50 million. Vibroplant P.L.C. said in July that it would sell American Hi-Lift to focus on its British operations. Primeco supplies equipment to construction and industrial markets in the United States and has 72 rental outlets.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Volvo Considering U.S. Vehicle Assembly
description: The Swedish vehicle maker Volvo said today that it was considering building cars in the United States and that manufacturing and delivery costs, rather than incentives offered by local authorities, would be given the most weight in a decision.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Johnson Is Set to Receive Rich Deal From Dolphins
description: Barring an unexpected hitch, Jimmy Johnson is expected to be named the Miami Dolphins' head coach Thursday afternoon.

title: Robbery on Rikers Island, Over the Phone, No Less
description: Jail is supposed to be a place where criminals are kept away from temptation. But an inmate on Rikers Island apparently saw it as a path to riches, robbing people on the outside through use of the jail's public phones, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRACOR INC., Austin, Tex., a military-electronics concern, said it had lowered its bid for AEL Industries of Lansdale, Pa., to $24.50 a share from $28, citing AEL's third-quarter loss of $1.1 million. The offer now is valued at $99.4 million.

title: Editorial Notebook;When Winter's Reality Hits Home
description: This week was bad enough, but no blizzard has inflicted more physical or psychic devastation on New York City than the three-day storm that started in the early hours of Monday, March 12, 1888. The snowfall in that famous "Blizzard of '88" was three-quarters of an inch more than the 20.2 inches measured in Central Park this time, but came as a complete surprise, with hurricane-force winds. Added to the awful human toll was the stunning blow to society's cocky self-confidence at the dawn of the age of modern invention.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AT&T SEEKS BUYER FOR ATLANTA OFFICE PROPERTY
description: The AT&T Corporation is seeking a buyer for the 38-story Promenade Two office tower in Atlanta, which houses part of its Southeastern regional headquarters, company officials said yesterday. The building is the second regional headquarters property AT&T sold or put up for sale in recent weeks. The 780,000-square-foot office building is owned by AT&T in partnership with the real estate company Faison Associates. The partnership hopes to receive more than $160 million, according to an industry newsletter Thrift Liquidation Alert. The company, which has been trying to trim billions in expenses, would remain a tenant in the building.

title: Design Mecca Takes Shape In TriBeCa
description: HAS the sun set on SoHo as a shopping destination for discriminating and artistic palates?

title: Judge Dismisses Suit by Iacocca
description: An attempt by Lee A. Iacocca, the former chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, to exercise $40 million in stock options has been dealt a setback by a judge here, who dismissed his suit against the company.

title: Fertility Treatment Has Good Success Rate;On Donating Eggs
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Raises Loss Estimate, In a Surprise To Wall Street
description: Apple Computer Inc., which warned last month that it might report a loss for the quarter, put a number next to that prognosis today, and it was twice as bad as most analysts had expected.

title: World News Briefs;Tribunal Asks Belgium To Give Up 3 Rwandans
description: A United Nations tribunal investigating the slaying of a half-million Rwandans in 1994 asked Belgium today to extradite three suspects, the first to be publicly named by the court.

title: Rock Artist of a Different Sort
description: MAINE farmers start smiling when Lew French shows up on their back 40's. So do farmers in New Hampshire and the Berkshire Hills, because for a dozen years Mr. French, a 38-year-old stonemason, has paid them good money -- $10 a ton -- for the privilege of hauling away the plow-breaking, back-wrenching rocks their ancestors cursed. Two-hundred-year-old loose-laid walls, granite pumpkin piles camouflaged under brambles in pasture corners and the odd elephant-size boulder midfield are trophies for Mr. French. Rocks patterned with green lichen are particularly prized quarry.

title: SKIING;Women Are Courted By Makers of Snow Boards
description: If you're a woman, and you snowboard, chances are likely you will hear yourself called Betty or Betty Shredder now and again. It is a term of camaraderie shown by a mostly Generation X group of male snowboarders who dominate the sport.

title: Seat Sells for $605,000
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that a full seat had sold for $605,000. The price was a $30,000 increase from the price of the last sale, $575,000. The owner of a full seat has the right to trade in any market at the Board of Trade and has a full vote in exchange elections. The Board of Trade provides trading in futures and options.

title: On a Star' Is Closing
description: Swinging on a Star," a musical written and directed by Michael Leeds with lyrics by Johnny Burke, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Music Box Theater, 239 West 45th Street, Manhattan. The show will have had 97 regular performances and 19 previews.

title: High Court Is Cool To Census Change
description: A coalition of major cities led by New York City argued its case for making statistical adjustment to the 1990 census to offset a racially skewed undercount before the Supreme Court. But whatever the merits of statistical adjustment, not a single Justice seemed receptive to the arguments put forward in the suit against the Commerce Department.

title: Currents;Architecture Loses A Progressive Voice
description: LAST year, there were three national architecture magazines in the United States: Progressive Architecture, Architectural Record and Architecture. This year, there are two: a determined voice of the future has been stilled.

title: Market Drop Grabs Notice Of Both Sides
description: Through the months of budget arguments between President Clinton and the Republican leadership, both sides have kept a wary eye on the markets, at once amazed that Wall Street considered a political deal inevitable and fearful of the moment that investors might discover that was not the case.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Jonah Gitlitz, president and chief executive of the Direct Marketing Association in New York, said yesterday that he would retire from the association in January 1997.

title: Yale's Labor Woes, In and Out of Class;With Spring Semester Opening, Unions Threaten Shutdown
description: Four years ago, unionized employees at Yale University pledged solidarity with graduate teaching assistants, vowing to strike if Yale refused to recognize a union the students had formed. The result was a symbolic one-day walkout, after the workers settled their own contracts, and Yale's continued refusal to recognize a graduate student union.

title: Chrysler Offers More Rebates
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced $300 rebates today on three car models with sluggish sales, and it extended a rebate program for pickup trucks.

title: Sports of The Times;Searching For a Lost Frontier
description: For most of the 13 years I have attended St. John's basketball games there has seemed to be an expectation on the part of St. John's that it was entitled to miracles. No cause was totally lost, no game out of reach.

title: Chinese Company Sues Lehman Brothers
description: Lehman Brothers Inc. has been sued by China's Sinochem (U.S.A.) Inc., which is seeking to recover $20 million in losses the company says Lehman caused through unauthorized trades.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN GENERAL TO POST $140 MILLION CHARGE
description: The American General Corporation said yesterday that it would post a one-time fourth-quarter expense of about $140 million, or 67 cents a share, as its consumer finance unit has increased the amount of money set aside to cover bad loans. American General, a Houston insurance and financial services company, said its unit, American General Finance Inc., based in Evansville, Ind., would raise its allowance for losses on finance receivables by $216 million in the fourth quarter. At the end of 1995, that allowance stood at about $492 million, compared with $226 million at the end of 1994. American General reported net income of $35 million, or 18 cents a share, on revenue of $2.06 billion for the fourth quarter that ended on Dec. 31, 1994.

title: Dole Steps Up Criticism Of Telecommunications Bill
description: Denouncing what he called "corporate welfare," Senator Bob Dole, Republican of Kansas, said today that a House-Senate conference committee should not approve the big telecommunications bill until the committee changes a provision that would give television broadcasters a chunk of the nation's airwaves worth tens of billions of dollars.

title: Shutdown Is Hurting Bystander
description: The continuing brawl over the Federal budget, combined with the three-week furlough of tens of thousands of Federal employees, has not only crippled efforts by the District of Columbia government to straighten out its chaotic finances, but raised further doubts whether the capital will ever be able to manage its own affairs.

title: The Neediest Cases;As Family Falters, a Father Worries
description: Five-year-old Luis Arnold Muller was building a castle, stacking blocks one by one. Then, as easily as he built his creation, he toppled it. Then he started the cycle over.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Blizzard Delay for Taxpayers
description: Taxpayers in New Jersey and 14 other states walloped by the weather this week are getting a break from the Internal Revenue Service. An I.R.S. spokesman, Frank Keith, said that the estimated quarterly tax payments due Jan. 16 would be considered timely if mailed by Jan. 22.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN EXPRESS BANK, New York, a unit of the American Express Co., named John Ward chairman and chief executive, succeeding Steven Goldstein, who resigned to pursue other opportunities.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Celebrations of the Virgin
description: Early music may be less plentiful in New York than its adherents would like, but its fans are too hardy to let a little snow -- or even a lot of it -- get in the way of a performance. The Music Before 1800 ensemble offered a program of Italian Baroque keyboard and vocal music at Corpus Christi Church on Sunday, and if the audience was smaller than usual for this popular series, it was respectable.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Fire Destroys Warehouse In Elizabeth
description: A trucking company's warehouse collapsed and burned in a huge fire that began this evening and continued late into the night, possibly releasing dangerous chemicals into the air, Fire Department officials said.

title: Three Black Members Quit AIDS Organization Board
description: Charging that the Gay Men's Health Crisis was not sufficiently attuned to the needs of minority groups, three black members have resigned from the board of New York City's leading private AIDS organization.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;A. J. Foyt Is Suing CART
description: A. J. FOYT has filed an antitrust suit against Championship Auto Racing Teams, the Indy-car circuit that plans to boycott the Indianapolis 500 to protest new qualifying procedures.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Two Choreographers In Homage to Their Art
description: Jacqulyn Buglisi and Donlin Foreman have had long and honorable careers in modern dance, principally with the Martha Graham Dance Company. They collaborate with two of Graham's most celebrated dancers, Terese Capucilli and Christine Dakin. And it was refreshing to see choreography and performing that treat the art of dance with reverence on Tuesday in a program presented by Buglisi/Foreman Dance at the Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater. But there was too often an eerie vacuum at the heart of the dances.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Tracking Bills by Computer
description: A new law will make it easier for the public to keep track of legislation. The measure will make New Jersey one of only five states to provide free computer access to legislative information, including the progress of bills.

title: 17 Police and 4 Officials Arrested in Mexican Peasants' Killings
description: Seventeen police agents and four high-ranking government officials, including the former state head of security, were arrested today in the southern state of Guerrero and charged with staging and then trying to cover up an ambush last June in which 17 peasants were killed on a back road near the Pacific Coast.

title: Gramercy Sold To Polygram
description: Polygram N.V. has assumed full control of Gramercy Pictures, buying the 50 percent stake in the studio held by the Universal Pictures unit of the Seagram Company.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;St. John's Finally Gets A Victory in Big East
description: These 20 minutes were the way it was supposed to be from Day One -- from the time two summers ago when Felipe Lopez and Zendon Hamilton decided they were going to stay at home and attend St. John's.

title: Metro Matters;Real Lessons On Politics From a Movie
description: ENOUGH snowflake counting. Back to reality: Hollywood.

title: No Headline
description: It's not the process that Senator Helms objects to, but what I said about the mean-spirited, anti-poor, anti-immigrant, anti-working-class mood of the debate taking place in the Congress today. It's the message he's attacking."

title: Ouellette Voted Driver of Year
description: Luc Ouellette, a 30-year-old native of St. Augustin, Quebec, was voted 1995 driver of the year today by Harness Tracks of America, a consortium of harness track owners in North America that uses a formula measuring national rank in money won, races won and performance average. Ouelette finished eighth ($5,014,167), second (726) and first (.415), respectively, in those categories.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Thyssen Returns to Profit
description: Germany's biggest steel company, Thyssen Stahl A.G., said yesterday that higher prices and expanded sales volume returned it to profit in the fiscal year that ended on Sept. 30. Thyssen said its net income soared to 651 million marks ($450.4 million) from a loss of 448 million marks the year before. Sales rose 9 percent. The company had losses the three previous years. (Reuters)

title: CHRONICLE
description: AUSTIN PENDLETON is an actor, director and playwright who moves from one stage to another in the course of a day.

title: U.N. Says Peacekeepers Will Remain in Haiti
description: Acknowledging that some problems are likely to persist in Haiti after a new President is sworn in next month, the United States, the United Nations and Haiti have agreed to retain a small peacekeeping force in the country after February.

title: Modern Plans Its Own Brancusi Show
description: The Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday that it would open a special exhibition of Brancusi masterworks next week, including 14 sculptures from the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris that will probably never be lent as a group again. Those works were part of the blockbuster Brancusi retrospective last year at the Pompidou Center and at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, where it closed on Dec. 31.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;News Corporation Seeks European Broadcast Rights for Olympics
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation is negotiating to buy the European rights to broadcast the Olympic Games from 2000 to 2008 for a reported $2 billion.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PETRO-CANADA SELLS CREDIT-CARD BUSINESS
description: Petro-Canada, the country's third-largest oil and gas producer, said yesterday that it had sold its personal credit-card business to GE Capital Canada for $110 million (Canadian), or $80.6 million (United States). Petro-Canada, based in Calgary, Alberta, said it would retain its commercial credit-card business. The company said that the sale of the personal-card business would eliminate 60 jobs but employees "will be given preferential consideration for employment opportunities with GE Capital Canada," Petro-Canada said. GE Capital Canada is a unit of GE Capital Services, a wholly owned subsidiary of the General Electric Company, based in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Court Upholds State's Bid To Use California Car Rule
description: New York State's right to adopt California's clean-car program was upheld yesterday by a Federal appeals court, which rejected the auto makers' contention that the state had overstepped its authority under the Federal Clean Air Act.

title: Connecticut Wants Hydrants Shoveled
description: Since the blizzard, firefighters around Connecticut have resorted to using metal detectors or hiring contractors to uncover fire hydrants buried under mountains of snow.

title: President Will Honor Dr. King in Atlanta
description: President Clinton will travel to Atlanta on Monday for the Federal holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., the White House said today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Education page yesterday about semifinalists in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search misidentified the school with the third-highest number of semifinalists. It was Midwood High School, in Brooklyn, with nine; Montgomery Blair High School in Silver Spring, Md., had eight.

title: Anti-U.S. Bomb Baffles Saudi Officials and F.B.I.
description: Nearly two months after a car bomb here killed seven people, including five Americans, the authorities have made little progress in identifying the attackers, Saudi officials and Western diplomats say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Giant Omnicom Ad Agency Agrees to Buy Ketchum The Omnicom Group agreed to buy Ketchum Communications, the 25th-largest American advertising agency, with more than $1 billion in billings. Ketchum is perhaps best known for introducing the Acura line of luxury cars and the Orville Redenbacher popcorn products. The agency has 1,100 employees and offers a range of marketing services.

title: But What Happens If the Furnace Breaks Down?
description: LAST fall, within a week after Paula D. Barnett moved into a 24-year-old Colonial-style house in Haddam, Conn., her stove, freezer and water heater broke down.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRSTAR TO ACQUIRE AMERICAN BANCORPORATION
description: The Firstar Corporation of Milwaukee said that it had reached a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire the privately held American Bancorporation of St. Paul and its parent, the Jacob Schmidt Company, for $220 million in stock and cash. Of the total price of $220 million, Firstar agreed to pay 80 percent in stock and 20 percent in cash -- if the stock is trading between $36 and $44 at the time of closing. If Firstar is trading higher than $44 a share, the stock portion will gradually increase to 100 percent, and the transaction value will gradually increase to a maximum of $225 million. If Firstar is trading lower than $36, the transaction value will gradually decrease to a minimum of $215 million. Firstar was unchanged yesterday at $37.50.

title: Now Bring Democracy to Bear on Corporate Downsizing
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Upholds Convictions in Bombing Plot
description: Saying there was no proof that constitutional rights were violated, a Federal judge rejected yesterday a motion to throw out the indictments and convictions of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and nine others on charges of waging a terror-bombing and assassination conspiracy in New York.

title: Small Steps in Baseball Talks
description: Under cover of raging apathy over the state of baseball's labor dispute, the chief labor representatives of the owners and the players met yesterday to figure out where they are and where they are going.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Technology Stocks End Day Mixed
description: Semiconductor stocks were mixed yesterday as the sector seemed to search for at least a temporary bottom after Tuesday's broad selloff.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-15

title: 2 G.I.'s Are Injured In Bosnian Accident
description: An American military fuel tanker overturned on a road in northern Bosnia today, injuring two American soldiers.

title: The Pop Life
description: At the Ball

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;No-Shows, No Band, But No Loss
description: When Seton Hall emerged from the tunnel that leads to the playing floor of Continental Airlines Arena today, they found the atmosphere more conducive for a wake than a Big East Conference basketball game with the Miami Hurricanes.

title: Currents;Going One Better Than Brownstone
description: MIKE BERG, a Manhattan artist, usually works on pieces of wood or paper, some as small as 6 by 8 inches. But in November, he found himself painting the side of a building that is 60 by 55 feet. The motif he chose was a stylized flower, in cobalt blue shadowed in umber.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COMMUTERS;Snow Buries Third Rail And Hopes Of Travelers
description: With commuters flooding back to the railways yesterday, the Long Island Rail Road, Metro-North Commuter Railroad and subway lines in southern Brooklyn still provided far less than their usual service, and riders' frustrations climbed. But across the Hudson, many New Jersey Transit trains operated as if nothing had happened.

title: Republicans Woo Middle For a Budget
description: Frustrated at the White House, Republican leaders in Congress have abruptly begun to pursue a new route to a balanced Federal budget: a deal with middle-of-the-road Democrats in the House and Senate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 3 about the prelude to the Presidential race overlooked an exception to the record of Republican Presidential choices since Dwight D. Eisenhower's nomination in 1952. Unlike other nominees since then, Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona, the choice in 1964, had not previously run for President or Vice President or been nominated or served.

title: Liberties;Let the Comedy Commence
description: To snow" has two meanings. 1) To fall as a shower of snow crystals. 2) To deceive, persuade or charm glibly.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE CITYSCAPE;After Blanket of Snow, the Fading Quietude of a Different City
description: The first thing to go was the silence. The snow will be around for what seems like forever, if current weather predictions are to be believed, but the silence has already disappeared. And that was what really transformed the city -- not the whiteness of the snow but the silence of the streets. It was not until the buses and trucks and taxis were gone that you realized how automatically you tune out their din. White noise, replaced by white stuff. Take away the sound, and the city not only felt different, it also looked different, the way a silent movie looks like another thing altogether from a feature film without its soundtrack.

title: BUDGET FOES SEE FIGHT CONTINUING TILL THE ELECTION
description: A day after President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders suspended their budget talks, the Republicans sounded increasingly pessimistic today about the chances of reaching a deal, and both sides spoke more openly than ever about fighting out their philosophical differences in the November elections.

title: Balloonist Is Forced to End Global Effort
description: Chased by the blizzard that blanketed the Northeast with snow this week and unable to rise above it, Steve Fossett, a 51-year-old American commodities broker, was forced yesterday to land his balloon on a frozen lake in Canada, abandoning his effort to be the first balloonist to fly non-stop around the world.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls Top the Sonics

title: AT&T Acquisition, Soon to Be Spun Off, Regains NCR Name
description: Four years after it was gobbled up by the AT&T Corporation for $7.5 billion and renamed, the NCR Corporation got its name back yesterday -- the first step toward being cut loose from what has turned out to be a disastrous relationship.

title: Shannon Rodgers; Fashion Designer For Stars Was 85
description: Shannon Rodgers, who dressed movie stars, first ladies and many others in the 1960's and 70's as the designer for the Seventh Avenue business Jerry Silverman Inc., died on Tuesday at Robinson Memorial Hospital here.

title: Youth, Crime, Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;76ers' Coleman Still Hurting
description: Philadelphia 76ers forward DERRICK COLEMAN, hobbled by a sprained right ankle for the past month, will miss at least another week after his ankle was put in a cast yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: Farewell to a Firefighter For the second time in a month, the Fire Department mourned one of its own who had died on the job. This time, the service was interrupted by the wails of the dead firefighter's 2-year-old son. Page B1.

title: Ex-Warner Music Chief Forms Venture
description: The former chairman of Warner Music Group, Robert J. Morgado, has formed a company that hopes to raise $200 million to $300 million to invest in music and entertainment ventures overseas, according to Richard Esposito, a partner in the venture.

title: Vallone Pledges to Fight G.O.P. Policies
description: Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, vowed in his annual address to the Council yesterday that he and the Council will begin serving as a strong Democratic counterweight to Republicans in New York and in Washington.

title: With Both Hands, Leon Fleisher At the Piano
description: Leon Fleisher is preparing to do something he has not done in a New York concert hall for 30 years: play a piano concerto with both his hands. With the Orchestra of St. Luke's supporting him and Andre Previn on the podium, he is to play the Mozart Concerto in A (K. 414) on Saturday evening at Carnegie Hall. Over the last nine months, he has performed the work in Washington, Cleveland and at Tanglewood.

title: After 37 Years in Prison, Inmate Tastes Freedom
description: On the last of his 13,695 days in the Louisiana State Penitentiary, Moreese Bickham went to a funeral.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;86 Bills Signed by Whitman
description: New Jersey has 86 new laws today, thanks to the flying pen of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Seeks British-French Aid
description: Eurotunnel, the British-French operator of the Channel tunnel linking the two countries, appealed yesterday for the French and British Governments to intervene to relieve its financial burden. Patrick Ponsolle, co-chairman of Eurotunnel, did not specify what form intervention should take. The appeal came at a news conference at which the tunnel operator announced that its 1995 sales would exceed expectations and that traffic on its passenger trains rose 21 percent in December. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: COMPANY NEWS;TWO CABLE TELEVISION COMPANIES TRADE ASSETS
description: Tele-Communications Inc. and Continental Cablevision Inc. announced yesterday that they had agreed to trade assets of cable television systems with subscribers in three states. The swap gives Continental Cablevision, which is based in Boston, the assets of Tele-Communications cable systems that serve about 100,000 customers in eastern Massachusetts. In return, Tele-Communications, the nation's largest cable company, which is based in Englewood, Colo., will acquire the assets of Continental systems serving about 100,000 customers in Illinois and Missouri. The deal is subject to regulatory approval. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: A Letter to Religious Leaders Lands Ambassador in Trouble
description: The State Department's inspector general has recommended that the Ambassador to the Vatican be reprimanded because of a letter he sent to 1,000 American religious leaders last April contrasting Pope John Paul II's concern for the poor with Congress's efforts to rein in spending on Federal antipoverty programs.

title: Jordan Marsh To Be No More
description: Jordan Marsh, the department store familiar to New Englanders for 145 years, will vanish this spring and be replaced by Macy's, the name made famous in New York.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 31 about the drop in violent crime in New York City referred incorrectly to the corresponding rates in Hartford and Newark. While the number of all crimes in those cities increased during the first six months of 1995 over the same period a year earlier, according to Justice Department figures, the number of violent crimes decreased.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;This Time, Bennett Aims to Bring Dallas Down to Size
description: The Dallas Cowboys have slapped the Green Bay Packers silly in their last six meetings, including by 27-17 in the 1993 playoffs and by 35-9 in last season's playoffs. Why, just last October, in a regular-season ruckus at Texas Stadium in Dallas, the Cowboys ripped the Packers again, this time by 34-24.

title: Felix Gonzalez-Torres, 38, A Sculptor of Love and Loss
description: Felix Gonzalez-Torres, whose modest yet evocative sculpture and photographs about love and loss were often inspired by AIDS, died yesterday at his home in Miami. He was 38 and had homes in Manhattan and Miami.

title: Helen W. Benjamin, Philanthropist, 91
description: Helen Weil Benjamin, a longtime benefactor of the Mount Sinai Medical Center and the Whitney Museum of American Art, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91.

title: Chairman Is Removed in an Abrupt Shake-Up at Smith Barney
description: Smith Barney Inc., the country's second-largest retail brokerage firm, yesterday installed James (Jamie) Dimon as its chairman and chief executive, abruptly displacing Robert F. Greenhill, the famed deal maker the firm snatched away from Morgan Stanley & Company less than three years ago.

title: Connecticut Makes Changes at Fund
description: The operation of the $12.6 billion state pension fund, one of the nation's worst-performing public funds, has been overhauled in a bid to make it a top performer, State Treasurer Christopher Burnham said today.

title: China's Horrific Adoption Mills
description: Criticism came from two quarters last week when Human Rights Watch reported that thousands of children in China's state-run orphanages have died from starvation, medical malpractice and abuse. The Chinese Government, of course, denied the findings and impugned the report's sources. More surprisingly, a leading association of American families with adopted Chinese children also denied the accusations and praised the Chinese orphanages.

title: POP REVIEW;Solidarity, High Spirits and Rock Sisterhood
description: Something that a good rock-and-roll show may be able to do better than any other kind of entertainment is to reinvigorate the hoariest cliches about sharing, feeling good and staying young at heart. Once you've seen Merry Clayton, Darlene Love and Marianne Faithfull perform a program of 20 rock-era standards at Rainbow and Stars, chances are that slogans like "Sisterhood is powerful" or "Rock-and-roll will never die" won't seem quite so shopworn.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE SCHOOLS;To Many Parents' Relief, School Is Back in Session
description: On the streets surrounding the schools that reopened yesterday, only the winter caps and the heads of children were visible, bobbing along behind the snow banks. Those heads, still dancing with memories of the unexpected furlough, of baked goods and videos and oh, so much snow, were not exactly focused on being back in a classroom.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Dec. 30 about the closing of three Broadway shows misidentified the director of "The Heiress." He was Gerald Gutierrez, not Andre Bishop.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;The Songs of Carl Loewe
description: If the songs and ballads of Carl Loewe are relatively unknown in America, it's not because he has lacked a prominent advocate. The great baritone Hermann Prey has been a consistent champion of this prolific German composer, who was born in late 1796, just two months before Schubert, but who lived much longer, until the age of 73. Mr. Prey devoted his recital on Saturday night at the 92d Street Y to 14 ballads by Loewe. The performances, with the superb pianist Michael Endres, were revelatory. Loewe's neglect never seemed more inexplicable.

title: Deputy Is Charged With Raping Teen-Ager
description: A sheriff's deputy in Missouri has been charged with the statutory rape of a 15-year-old girl in his custody on Monday night.

title: Now Bring Democracy to Bear on Corporate Downsizing
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Price of Gold Surpasses $400 First Time in Nearly 2 1/2 Years
description: The price of gold rose above $400 an ounce for the first time in nearly two and a half years yesterday, pushed higher in part by speculative demand from investors fleeing, at least temporarily, the stock and bond markets.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption from The Associated Press yesterday about a grenade attack on a Sarajevo streetcar misstated the sex of the victim. The person killed in the attack was Mirsada Duric, a 55-year-old woman.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Behind a Clowning Exterior, The Heart of a Modernist
description: Doug Elkins seems to have designated himself the class cutup of New York modern dance. But Mr. Elkins may be out of that job if he is not careful. A program of new and recent dances presented by the Doug Elkins Dance Company on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater suggested that an increasingly serious choreographer is pushing through that clownlike surface.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bayer Fined in Europe
description: The European Union fined the German drug maker Bayer A.G. $3.9 million yesterday for violating European antitrust law. The union's year-round executive arm, the European Commission, ruled that Bayer had held back supplies of Adalat, a drug used in cardiovascular treatments, to Spanish and French wholesalers to prevent them from exporting the drug to Britain, where it commands higher prices. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERISOURCE HEALTH TO BUY GULF DISTRIBUTION
description: The Amerisource Health Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Gulf Distribution Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash. Gulf Distribution, of Miami, is a wholesale drug distributor with annual revenue of about $180 million, excluding certain bulk shipments to customers. Amerisource, of Malvern, Pa., is a national wholesale distributor of pharmaceuticals and related health care products that had revenue of about $4.7 billion in the year ended Sept. 30.

title: I.R.A. Says Impasse on Disarmament Could Endanger the Truce
description: A ranking political leader of the Irish Republican Army said today that the impasse over disarmament of the I.R.A. in Northern Ireland could lead to a breakdown of the cease-fire the outlawed organization has observed for more than 16 months.

title: CHECHEN RAIDERS GIVE UP HOSPITAL AND ARE FIRED ON
description: For a while it appeared that the crisis was easing: the Chechen rebels who had seizednearly 2,000 hostages on Tuesday at a small hospital in southern Russia were permitted to flee Wednesday morning -- still with 130 of their hostages -- and head toward their homeland.

title: Italy Coalition Moves Closer To Elections
description: The bonds of pragmatism and fiscal urgency that have held together the year-old Government of Prime Minister Lamberto Dini appeared to be slipping today as the leader of the leftist party that is its main legislative support said he could no longer rule out early elections.

title: Bridge
description: Both annual New York titles, for Player of the Year and Team Player of the Year, were won by Jim Krekorian, but he had to work hard in the closing days of the year to clinch them. At the Winter Regional Championships he won the Bracketed Knockout Teams early in the tournament, making sure of the Player of the Year title ahead of Robb and Linda Gordon. On the final day he finished second in the Swiss Teams, squeezing past Brian Glubok, who did not compete in the tournament, to take the Team Player title.

title: San Diego Orchestra in Peril
description: The San Diego Symphony Orchestra's concerts this weekend may be the final performances in its 68-year history. Facing a $3 million deficit, the orchestra's board voted on Tuesday to declare Chapter 7 bankruptcy on Jan. 16 if money was not found to cover the debt, said Yoav Talmi, the orchestra's conductor since 1990.

title: 2 Big Hospitals In New York City Pursue a Merger
description: St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center and Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center announced yesterday that they were actively negotiating a partnership, which, if the talks succeed, would create by far the largest hospital in New York City and one of the largest in the country.

title: A Family Album of Intrigue;Kansas City Tale of Inside Deals and Outside Investors
description: The volatile real estate markets of the 1980's produced plenty of tales of intrigue, many spiced with corruption, greedy executives and skewered investors. In the more stable 1990's, though, few stories have been more fascinating than that of the J. C. Nichols Company, a venerable Kansas City, Mo., developer that was jolted last year by a bitter struggle between its top management and outside investors.

title: Israel to Compensate Family of Moroccan Slain in Norway in '73
description: Israel agreed today to negotiate a financial settlement with the family of a Moroccan waiter gunned down in Norway in 1973 after he was misidentified as the mastermind behind the killing of 11 Israeli athletes during the Summer Olympics in Munich, Germany, in 1972.

title: G.O.P. Filing Challenges To Candidates' Petitions
description: The state's Republican leadership moved today to block anyone but Senator Bob Dole of Kansas from entering New York's Republican Presidential primary, saying that it would challenge the nominating petitions of two other candidates.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Management Shifts For 3 Companies
description: Three large agency companies have announced changes involving top managers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEXAS REGIONAL TO BUY 2 TEXAS BANK COMPANIES
description: Texas Regional Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that its Texas State Bank subsidiary had agreed to buy the First State Bank and Trust Company, based in Mission, Tex., and Border Bank, based in Hidalgo, Tex., in separate deals totaling about $100 million in cash. Texas Regional, of McAllen, Tex., said it would acquire First State Bank for $79 million and Border Bank for $20.5 million.

title: The Rich Won't Give Block Grants
description: Today's budget-cutting Republicans, like those of the Reagan era, argue that private philanthropy can fill the gap caused by reductions in Federal social spending. Their assumption that charitable institutions can take over the safety net and manage it more efficiently than Washington leaves the impression that the nation can enjoy the financial benefits of smaller government without inflicting further suffering on the needy.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers' Stars Come Out At Garden
description: In a show that displayed the looseness and sloppiness of an All-Star Game, the Rangers' three All-Stars piled up the points. Mark Messier and Pat Verbeek each scored twice and Brian Leetch netted the game-winner as the Rangers beat the San Jose Sharks, 7-4, last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: GOLF: LIFE IN THE ROUGH -- Rookies on the pro golf tour.;One for the Middle Ages: This PGA Rookie Is 47
description: The big man walked up the stairs of the clubhouse, taking the steps slowly and methodically until he reached the veranda where the security guard sat, arms folded. The sign on the wall next to the guard said, "PGA Tour Players Only," and so the big man, Allen Doyle, pushed his shirt up from where it was bloused over his waist to reveal the shiny silver player's badge he wore on his belt.

title: As Serbs Toast Americans, Vodka Is Just One More Minefield
description: On this strategically valuable, Serbian-held mountaintop that was pummeled by NATO planes only a few months ago, Serbian commanders broke out a bottle of lemon-flavored vodka today and toasted American Army officers who ascended a steep track thick with mud to establish a post here.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Phoenix Returns to Lead Manhattan Past Rutgers
description: Injuries, embarrassment and adversity already have made Manhattan wonder if this season will ever be memorable for positive reasons. Tonight, the Jaspers located a positive and took one tiny step toward discovering more with an 81-76 victory over Rutgers.

title: Essay;President As Pugilist
description: Everybody I know has been calling to get ringside tickets to the fight. Sorry, guys; direct your requests to the promoter, White House press secretary Mike McCurry.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Husband and Wife, Primordial Enemies
description: WHEN the lights come up on the first scene, the Captain, ramrod-straight in the spotless uniform of a 19th-century Swedish cavalry officer, stands at the left of the stage as if frozen in mid-gesture. He appears to have no idea where he is or what he's about to do. His anxiety quickly passes, but it's an indelible moment. It's also enough time for Frank Langella to suggest what soon turns out to be stunningly true: his complete command over one of the most difficult and complex assignments in the modern theater. That is, the role of the obsessed husband and father in August Strindberg's mesmerizing and ferocious marriage play, "The Father."

title: FILM REVIEW;Equal Opportunity in Games of Love
description: In a topical variation on the old farmer's-daughter joke, a traveler in "French Twist" becomes stranded in a household featuring a beautiful, neglected wife. Handy with plumbing, the visitor fixes the sink and is asked to stay for dinner. Wine flows, the mood is intimate, and the husband conveniently happens to be away for the evening. And the visitor becomes increasingly smitten with Loli, the hostess. But here's a novel touch, at least for frothy sex farce at the movies: the plumber is a woman named Marijo.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Whitman Signs School Bill
description: She's at it again.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Raise Standards, Not Money
description: In her second annual message to the Legislature, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said yesterday that New Jersey's plan to equalize education between rich and poor districts would be achieved by rewriting the rules of education, not by writing checks. The Governor said the problem with New Jersey's schools is not lack of money but lack of core standards for student achievement. Once those standards are set, she said, the state can help schools define the programs, materials and staffing needed to meet those goals. [Page A1.]

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: TRASH;Garbage Piled Atop Snow But Pickup May Start Soon
description: Almost a week after a historic blizzard, as mounds of snow are moved and melted, discarded Christmas trees and bags and bags of garbage -- about 50,000 tons of it -- are piling up on sidewalks and in gutters.

title: Bradley Backs Clinton on Affirmative Action
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey issued a strong defense today of affirmative action in a state where the government has all but rolled it back, and he offered a timely endorsement of President Clinton's stands on race relations while excoriating most Republicans on the issue.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the resignation of some black directors of the Gay Men's Health Crisis misstated the size of the board. After 3 members resigned on Monday, 26 remained, not 29.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE OVERVIEW;PRESIDENT URGES A RENEWED EFFORT ON A BUDGET DEAL
description: Insisting that a balanced budget plan was "within our grasp," President Clinton called on Congressional Republican leaders today to renew the drive for an agreement. But he was instantly rebuffed by Speaker Newt Gingrich, who accused him of misleading the public in "a political game."

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Papandreou to Meet Greek President
description: The ailing Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, broke his seven-week silence in a hospital today to say that he wants to see the President, raising speculation that he may be ready to resign or name an official deputy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GOLF ENTERPRISES SAYS IT IS IN PRELIMINARY SALE TALKS
description: Golf Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it was in preliminary talks with an undisclosed potential buyer, under which the company would be sold for about $12 a share, or $77.9 million in cash and stock. Golf Enterprises, which operates golf courses in 17 states, went public in July 1994 with an initial offering of 2.35 million shares at $13.50 each. It has 6.49 million shares outstanding. The shares of Golf Enterprises, which is based in Dallas, jumped $2.25 yesterday, to $11, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Legislation Would Allow Judges To Order H.I.V. Tests for Suspects
description: Gov. George E. Pataki announced today that he would introduce legislation giving judges the authority to order H.I.V. tests for people charged with a range of offenses, from violent felonies to disorderly conduct, if victims request them.

title: FILM REVIEW;Get Mad? Yes, Then Be Sure To Get Even
description: At the McCann household, preparations are under way for 6-year-old Megan's birthday party. That means purple ribbons, a large ice sculpture and a cake baked in the shape of a Barbie doll's skirt. Then, with no warning, a fiend rings the doorbell and suddenly rapes and murders 17-year-old Julie McCann. Unless you count the ice sculpture, there is no known provocation for this heinous crime.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sears of Britain Closing Shoe Stores
description: The British retailer Sears announced yesterday that it would close or sell its 111 Saxone and 124 Curtess shoe shops. The company, which is not related to United States retailing giant Sears, Roebuck & Company, put aside L30 million ($46.4 million) to cover the cost of this withdrawal. Its sales were hit by a downturn at its British Shoe division, which reported a 10.9 percent fall in sales.

title: Hilton Plans Chain of Budget Business Inns
description: Hilton Hotels has decided to open a chain of 100 inns for budget-conscious business travelers, the company said today.

title: Whitman Says Schools Need Tough Standards
description: In her annual message to the Legislature, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said educational inequalities in New Jersey should be addressed not by funneling more money to troubled schools, but by setting uniform standards for students.

title: Egidio Ortona, Italian Envoy to U.S., Dies at 85
description: Egidio Ortona, a veteran diplomat who nurtured the postwar revival of Italy's close relationship with the United States and served as the Italian Ambassador to Washington, died here on Wednesday. He was 85.

title: Michael Pollon, 82; Led Music School
description: Michael Pollon, a former executive director of the Westchester Conservatory of Music in White Plains, N.Y., died on Tuesday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 82.

title: Samuel Rosenberg, 85, Explorer Of Secrets of Sherlock Holmes
description: Samuel Rosenberg, a photographer, author and raconteur who turned his voracious reading habits, prodigious memory and hyperactive imagination into a subsidiary career as a literary psychosleuth, died last Friday at the New York Hospital Medical Center in Queens. He was best known for "Naked Is the Best Disguise," his 1974 study of the literary and libidinous wellsprings of the Sherlock Holmes canon.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Win by Not Quitting 42d Street;Milstein Brothers at Last Get In on Renewal Plan
description: For 15 years, a stretch of property facing the Port Authority Bus Terminal has been part of the widely heralded and richly tangled effort to rehabilitate Times Square. Although the site is now a parking lot, it is expected soon to become much more. Behind this plain plot of land is a classic tale of New York development, and the story of two tough and shrewd brothers, Seymour and Paul Milstein.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BETTY SCRIPPS, the chairwoman of the International Red Cross Ball in Palm Beach, Fla., on Jan. 27, was determined to find a British guest of honor for the occasion with links to the Red Cross in Britain. First she invited the Princess of Wales, but, Mrs. Scripps said yesterday, "This was not a good time for her."

title: Newsstand Rental Plan Exacts Radical Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;FEDERAL-MOGUL PLANS TO CUT ABOUT 500 JOBS
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate about 500 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to increase its profits. Federal-Mogul, an automotive supplier based in Southfield, Mich., said last month that it would record a one-time expense of $52 million in the fourth quarter to account for cost-saving measures, including plant closings and the sale of assets. The expense also includes the job cuts. Federal-Mogul has also said that its earnings will be increased by about $10 million in the fourth quarter from the sale of its stake in Westwind Air Bearings Ltd. The net result will be an overall charge against earnings of about $42 million. In the corresponding quarter a year earlier, Federal-Mogul had net income of $11.8 million.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;Willis to Enter Draft
description: TERRELL WILLIS, Rutgers's career leader in rushing and all-purpose yardage, will forgo his senior season to enter the National Football League draft, Coach TERRY SHEA announced yesterday. The 6-foot, 200-pound Willis has racked up 3,143 career rushing yards, 5,340 all-purpose yards and 21 touchdowns in his Rutgers career. (AP)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: CHRONICLE
description: Ever since Gen. COLIN L. POWELL announced two months ago that he would not run for President, he has been courted by philanthropies and corporations that want him to join their boards. He has chosen only two: the Children's Health Fund and the Boys and Girls Clubs of America.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;2d Chance for Sitting Ducks
description: Sanctimonious earth-watchers with their stern utopian agendas would seem to be ideal sitting ducks for a raucous movie satire with a junk-food heart.

title: Woman Tied To Daughter Is Admitted For Overdose
description: A woman under court order to keep her teen-age daughter tethered has been hospitalized for a drug overdose. Her husband assumed responsibility for holding his stepdaughter's leash.

title: COMPANY NEWS;320 JOB CUTS IN EUROPE AND $40 MILLION CHARGE ARE SET
description: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $40 million charge and eliminate 320 jobs in a revamping of part of its European operation. The job cuts bring the number of jobs that Mobil, the energy giant based in Fairfax, Va., has said it plans to eliminate by the end of the year to 5,550. The additional charge also raises to at least $548 million the total of the charges against earnings that Mobil will take in the fourth quarter. Mobil shares closed up $1.50 yesterday, at $112.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Get the Waders. Slush Is Coming.
description: The storm heading up the East Coast today could bring two or three more inches of snow to the metropolitan area, but the accumulation is likely to be canceled out by warmer temperatures and sleet changing to rain, meteorologists said yesterday.

title: Chechen Standoff Festers, With More Arms at the Ready
description: The man with the wool mask covering his face and the Walkman dangling from his neck was once again demanding freedom for the Chechen people. His dangerous eyes were green, a perfect match for the silk strip of the Islamic warrior that he wore across his hooded head.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: POLITICAL MEMO;Campaign Consultants Find Benefits in Budget Impasse
description: There was little mourning among political consultants when the budget talks were suspended this week.

title: Bagels Deal With Hess
description: The Manhattan Bagel Company has reached a co-branding agreement with the Amerada Hess Corporation to lease space within Hess Mart convenience stores and Hess gasoline stations. Manhattan Bagel, which runs 151 bagel shops, will lease space for kiosks that will bear its name and sell nine varieties of its bagels. The company expects the first kiosk within a Hess Mart to open early this year in Bayville, N.J.

title: Italian Premier Quits as Coalition Unravels; Election Is Likely
description: Prime Minister Lamberto Dini resigned tonight to avoid defeat in a no-confidence vote, leaving Italy facing the possibility of fresh national elections and the near certainty that any Government that follows will not survive for long.

title: Sylvester Garrett Is Dead at 84; Labor Mediator in Steel Industry
description: Sylvester Garrett, a law professor and pioneer labor mediator who helped shape the landscape of industrial relations in the United States in the post- World War II era as the chief arbitrator between the United Steelworkers Union and the nation's steel producers for 28 years, died Thursday in Pittsburgh after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Bosnian Serbs Flee Homes In Sarajevo
description: Cars and trucks driven by Bosnian Serbs and loaded with baggage and bedding streamed out of Sarajevo today, part of an exodus that Bosnian Serb leaders said could turn violent. NATO troops said Bosnian Serb families were taking their belongings out of the Bosnian capital for safekeeping in Serb-held territory.

title: Economists Fear for Exports, Growth and Jobs : Overvalued Mark Squeezes Germany
description: PARIS  As more evidence mounted Thursday of the increasingly anemic state of the German economy, two leading banks warned that the overvalued Deutsche mark was threatening German and Pan-European economic growth.

title: Bienvenido Santos, Filipino Author, 84
description: Bienvenido N. Santos, a novelist who grew up in Manila's slums and then moved to the United States and wrote about the pain of Filipino exiles there, died Sunday at his family home in Legaspi near the Mount Mayon volcano in the northern Philippines. He was 84.

title: The Pendulum of Policies on Child Abuse
description: For most of the century, social workers, public policy makers and researchers have been debating a subtly nuanced question, one that can sometimes have life-and-death consequences for young children: When should a child be removed from an abusive family and when is it more important to keep a family intact?

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Are Being Sued by Childs, Who Charges Contract Fraud
description: The Nets played hardball with the reserve guard Chris Childs last fall by offering him a one-year contract for the minimum $350,000. Now Childs is playing his own brand of hardball by filing a civil lawsuit against the National Basketball Association team seeking compensatory damages.

title: Trooper Charged With Rape Kills Himself
description: A sergeant dismissed by the California Highway Patrol apparently killed himself a month after he was arrested on charges that he had raped a woman in his cruiser, the authorities said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lonrho May Spin Off Its Mining Interests
description: The British conglomerate Lonrho P.L.C. said yesterday that it was considering spinning off its mining business. Lonrho's chief executive, Dieter Bock, said the company's stock price has not reflected the underlying value of the company's businesses. There had been speculation that Lonrho might get rid of its hotels business. No timetable was given for the spinoff.

title: U.S. to Propose Instructions on Icing for Turboprop Pilots
description: The Federal Aviation Administration plans to propose rules next week for instructing the pilots of turboprop planes how they can identify a dangerous icing condition and requiring them to immediately steer away from areas where it is encountered.

title: Art in Review
description: Michael Byron Baron/Boisante Editions 50 West 57th Street Manhattan Through Jan. 27

title: COMPANY NEWS;2 CALIFORNIA BANK COMPANIES AGREE TO A MERGER
description: CU Bancorp has agreed to merge with Home Interstate Bancorp, creating a bank with more than $810 million in assets and 22 branches in Southern California. CU Bancorp, the holding company for California United Bank, will exchange 1.409 of its shares for each share of Home Interstate, which is the parent of Home Bank. Home Interstate shareholders are expected to hold about 52 percent of the combined company. The deal was disclosed after the close of stock trading on Wednesday. CU's stock rose 75 cents yesterday, to $10.375, and Home Interstate shares rose 62.5 cents, to $13.875. Both closing prices were 52-week highs. CU Bancorp is based in Encino, Calif. Home Interstate is based in Signal Hill, Calif.

title: Kmart in Pact On Some Debt
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that it had reached tentative agreements with banks and nonbank institutions on a crucial deal affecting about $550 million worth of real estate-related debt.

title: Host Marriott to Buy Interest in Hotels
description: The Host Marriott Corporation said today that it would acquire controlling interests in the San Diego Marriott Hotel and Marina, two hotels in Mexico City and the Pittsburgh Hyatt.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: At Georgetown, Literature Loses to Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: NYC;A Bull Market For Cynicism On Wall Street
description: WALL STREET laid an egg or two this week, as Variety once might have put it, but the Dow Jones bounced back nicely yesterday, staying within range of the record levels it has enjoyed for months. Too bad this enthusiasm is not shared on the street itself.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Rise, Retaking Some Ground
description: Prices of Treasury securities regained some ground yesterday in choppy trading after a big decline on Wednesday. Traders cited a number of positive factors, including the belief by many investors that a balanced budget agreement can be reached.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;2 Charged in Fatal Shooting
description: Two Camden women have been charged with murder in a New Year's Day shooting death. The county prosecutor's office said that the Jan. 1 shooting of Wanda Clayton Turner was the only slaying reported so far this year in Camden, which ended 1995 with a record 60 homicides.

title: Elderly's Suicide Rate Is Up 9% Over 12 Years
description: After declining for four decades, the suicide rate among elderly Americans rose by 9 percent from 1980 to 1992, the Government said today.

title: The Neediest Cases;For Many Donors, the Aim Is to Help the City's Elderly
description: Richard and Betty Salzer of Scarsdale, N.Y., who are in their 70's, want their $100 donation to help elderly Jewish people. Charlotte Salomon of Manhattan said that her $25 check should go to an old person who is alone. Abbie R. Snyder of Manhattan gave $50 in memory of her parents.

title: Art in Review
description: Stephen Greene David Beitzel Gallery 102 Prince Street, SoHo Through Feb. 10

title: COMPANY NEWS;BENTON OIL AND GAS PLANS TO SELL LOUISIANA OPERATIONS
description: The Benton Oil and Gas Company said yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent to sell its business in Louisiana to Shell Offshore Inc., an affiliate of the Shell Oil Company, for $35.4 million. Benton, an oil and gas exploration and production company based in Carpinteria, Calif., said that if the transaction was completed, it expected to record a pretax gain of about $10 million. Benton Oil said the sale would provide it with capital to speed the development of its business in Venezuela. The sale will also let the company repay about $10 million in debt. Shell Oil is a subsidiary of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group.

title: Art in Review
description: Alice Aycock 'Some Stories Are Worth Repeating: Projects 1973-1995' John Weber Gallery 142 Greene Street, SoHo Through Feb. 3

title: Washington Journal;The Capital Goes Back to Work, but Not Easily
description: Gridlock assumed a more literal form in the nation's capital today, and to many people it seemed a lot more troublesome than any old legislative battle.

title: World News Briefs;Cali Drug Leader Escapes in Bogota
description: One of the top three leaders of the Cali drug cartel escaped today from a prison in Bogota. The cartel leader, Jose Santacruz Londono, apparently sneaked out of Bogota's La Picota prison today, said Miller Rubio, spokesman for the Prisons Institute.

title: Richard Vancil, 64, an Expert In Selecting Corporate Leaders
description: Richard F. Vancil, a longtime professor at the Harvard Business School who was considered an expert on how corporations pick chief executives, died on Wednesday at a nursing home in Madison, Conn. He was 64 and had homes in Belmont, Mass., and Madison.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Father James Royce, Addiction Expert, 81
description: Father James E. Royce, a professor emeritus of psychology and addiction studies at Seattle University who spent decades counseling people in books and lecture halls about alcoholism and other substance abuse, died last Saturday at Providence Hospital in Seattle. A resident of Jesuit House in Seattle, he was 81.

title: Rio Journal;Live, in Brazil (Again): The Reincarnated Dr. Fritz
description: Fernando de Souza Pinheiro leaned forward in his wheelchair, ready to receive the knife of a German known by the name of Dr. Fritz, who died in a World War I field hospital.

title: Sports of The Times;A Ride Down The Johnson Expressway
description: IS today the day Jimmy Johnson calls Dan Marino into the office and asks, "Have you ever thought of taking a year off? Spend quality time with your family. Rest your body. Go fishing. Borrow my boat. The tank is full."

title: Security Chief In Israel Loses His Cover
description: Breaking a tradition of secrecy, the Israeli press has identified the designated new head of the Shin Bet security service as well as his predecessor, who is stepping down.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: AT&T Insider Case Is Settled by Two Men
description: Two men charged in the AT&T Corporation insider-trading case have settled civil charges by agreeing to pay about $43,000 in penalties, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Petroleum To Drop 3 Refineries
description: British Petroleum P.L.C. said yesterday that it would close or sell three refineries, resulting in a $1.1 billion charge in a move that highlights the three-year overcapacity crisis in the oil-refining industry. The company plans to sell refineries at Lima, Ohio, and at Lavera, France, and to close the Pernis section of the Nerefco refinery near Rotterdam in the Netherlands. The measures will trim capacity by about a third and follow earlier worldwide industry restructurings to raise prices for refined products.

title: Community Work for Tree Killer, But Penalties Will Stiffen Today
description: A year ago, people who illegally chopped down trees in New York City got off with nothing more than a perfunctory fine. But yesterday, Andrew Campanile, who gained notoriety as the tree killer of Astoria, Queens, got a taste of the city's growing resolve: He was sentenced to 500 hours of community service for destroying seven trees in a case of "premeditated arborcide."

title: Art in Review
description: Ellen Gallagher Mary Boone Gallery 417 West Broadway (near Spring Street), SoHo Through Feb. 24

title: Home Video
description: With all the video guides available, two newcomers have carefully picked their niches. One, "Facets Nonviolent, Nonsexist Children's Video Guide," carves its own finely delineated path through the wilds of kid-vid. The other, "Mark Satern's Illustrated Guide to Video's Best," is a general film reference with an individual twist.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: HORSE RACING;Lukas and Mott Big Winners in Eclipse
description: Champions were crowned in thoroughbred racing yesterday, and horses trained by D. Wayne Lukas won three Eclipse Awards as the best in their class. But Bill Mott, nonetheless, was elected trainer of the year and his star of stars, Cigar, was named on all 306 ballots as the best older horse.

title: For Youths, Fear of Crime Is Pervasive and Powerful
description: Fear of violence and crime is affecting the behavior, expectations and school performance of teen-agers around the country, according to a study issued yesterday by organizations that work with youths on crime prevention.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PREPRESS SOFTWARE BUSINESS IS SOLD BY ADOBE
description: Adobe Systems Inc., the producer of software for desktop publishing, said yesterday that it had sold most of its prepress computer software business to the Luminous Corporation, a privately held company in which Adobe owns a stake. Financial terms of the transaction were not disclosed. The prepress software is used to prepare documents for professional printing. Adobe said the deal would allow it to focus on less specialized software for graphic artists. Luminous is based in Seattle; Adobe is based in Mountain View, Calif.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.B.A.;Davis to Be in Contest
description: HUBERT DAVIS's ability to put the ball in the basket from beyond the 3-point arc was rewarded yesterday when the Knicks guard was selected to compete in the long-distance shootout at the National Basketball Association's All-Star weekend next month.

title: For Children
description: Martin Luther King Jr. Weekend Children's Museum of Manhattan 212 West 83d Street (212) 721-1223 Recommended for all ages Saturday, Sunday and Monday
