title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Haselrig Sentenced
description: Jets guard CARLETON HASELRIG pleaded guilty yesterday in Pittsburgh to driving his four-wheel-drive vehicle across the grounds of a Pittsburgh seminary in December 1994.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Riley Sounds Off At the Referees
description: Now more than ever, Pat Riley believes that the referees are out to get him and his Miami Heat.

title: BOXING;Garden Is Using Jones As Headache Remedy
description: It's not the Knicks or the Rangers or the circus or the ice show or the Christmas Show although it incorporates features from each. But the return of boxing has given Madison Square Garden as many headaches as a full season's worth of traditional attractions.

title: 25 and Under
description: Blini to Go

title: Roger Crozier, 53, a Hockey Goaltender
description: Roger Crozier, a former goaltender who was the National Hockey League rookie of the year with the Detroit Red Wings in 1964, died Wednesday night in Christiana Hospital. He was 53.

title: Long Fight Looms in Buildings Strike
description: Building owners and union leaders gave every indication yesterday that the eight-day strike by maintenance workers in New York City's office buildings would last a long time.

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;When It Comes to 'D', Colts Score an A
description: Conventional wisdom says the Indianapolis Colts should not be a victory away from the Super Bowl. But conventional wisdom never had to tackle a 240-pound fullback running at full steam or oppose a ball-hawking defense.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: Sculley Buys Stake in Software Company
description: John Sculley, the former chief executive of Apple Computer Inc., has taken an equity stake in a small California photo software concern, where he is also serving as a part-time chief executive.

title: Bratton Challenges Testimony
description: Police Commissioner William J. Bratton yesterday rebutted a rogue police officer's court testimony that the 30th Precinct's rampant corruption was encouraged and initiated by the precinct's two top commanders.

title: The Spoken Word
description: THE REV. DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING JR. TRIBUTE, State Office Building, 163 West 125th Street, Harlem. A screening of the film "Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. -- A Historical Perspective," by Tom Friedman, will be followed by a lecture by Abiola Sinclair, the media editor of The Amsterdam News. Sunday at 2 P.M. Free. Information: (212) 749-5298.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trafalgar House in Talks
description: Trafalgar House P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in talks with Persimmon P.L.C. that could lead to the sale of its British home building unit, Ideal Homes, for at least L151 million ($234 million). Trafalgar said it aimed to cut debt and reorganize its engineering and cruise line businesses. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Rebounds From Its Two-Day Debacle Stocks bounced back from the debacle of Tuesday and Wednesday in what one analyst called "a reaction to the oversold condition." The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index jumped 20.89 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,011.10, while the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 32.16 points, to 5,065.10.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Improvisations With a Smile
description: The last show of the night is usually the one in which jazz musicians take off their coats and ties and relax a bit. At the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night, for its second set, the Wycliffe Gordon and Wessell Anderson group unwound, and had the music been recorded, it might have sounded odd, full of unexpected silences, out-of-tune melodies and strange reconfigurations of harmonies. But in a club, where the musicians' intent is signaled partly by body language, by smiles and sideways glances of awe and surprise, the set was the work of improvising musicians dedicated to having fun.

title: Tough Draw For Sampras
description: Worse than the flu, Pete Sampras was hit today by the toughest draw among the top-seeded players in next week's Australian Open as he tries for a third straight Grand Slam tournament title.

title: Bernard Glaser, 81, War Crimes Lawyer
description: Bernard Glaser, a retired public relations executive and former lawyer for the Department of the Treasury who investigated war crimes in Germany after World War II, died on Dec. 21 at John Muir Hospital in Walnut Creek, Calif., where he had a winter home. He was 81 and lived in Chalfont, Pa.

title: Shrugging Off the Cold, Shuttle Sets Off on a Satellite Hunt
description: The space shuttle Endeavour today began an orbital chase of a large Japanese satellite that it is to capture and bring back to Earth as the highlight of an ambitious nine-day mission.

title: Robert Amendola, Instructor to Blind And a Sculptor, 86
description: Robert F. P. Amendola, a sculptor and former teacher who spent much of his life in the service of the blind, died on Jan. 4 at a nursing home in Natick, Mass. He was 86 and lived in Hopkinton, Mass., where he also had a studio.

title: Real Estate;A residential real estate chain is getting into the home repair business as the  industry diversifies.
description: CENTURY 21 REAL ESTATE, the national residential real estate franchise chain, is expanding the services it offers to home buyers to include home repairs, in another illustration of diversification efforts in the brokerage industry.

title: Chubby Wise, 80, a Fiddler Who Wrote 'Orange Blossom'
description: Robert Russell (Chubby) Wise, a leading bluegrass fiddler who collaborated on the showpiece "Orange Blossom Special," died on Saturday in Bowie, Md. He was 80 and lived in Glen St. Mary, Fla.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Whitman's Legislative Message
description: Following is an excerpt from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's address to the Legislature yesterday, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: INSIDE
description: Shuttle Launched in Cold A space shuttle took off in the coldest temperatures during a launching since the freeze that led to the Challenger disaster in 1986. Page A12.

title: Colombian Faults Pilots in the Fatal Air Crash
description: A Colombian aviation official said today that readings by investigators of navigational and recording data on an American Airlines flight that crashed near Cali on Dec. 20 indicated that it was pilot error rather than a failing by air traffic controllers that caused the crash.

title: For City Council
description: Residents of Manhattan's East Side are being asked to trudge through the snow next Tuesday to vote in a special election for the Fifth District City Council seat. Two aides to local politicians are vying to replace Charles Millard, a Republican who resigned to become head of the city's Economic Development Corporation.

title: No Headline
description: She's just another one of those liberal, naive gringas who thinks she has been appointed by God to save the world. I don't feel sorry for her."

title: A Change in Japan? Style, Not Direction
description: Ryutaro Hashimoto pledged "reform and creativity" upon becoming Japan's new Prime Minister on Thursday, but he appointed a Cabinet that is likely to continue existing policies in many areas.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;One Sweeping Tragedy: Journalism in Pictures
description: Over the last two decades Gilles Peress has developed an intensely personal brand of photojournalism that violates important assumptions about how to present news stories in pictures. Mr. Peress performs with distinction the central function of photographic reportage: he is on the scene, an eyewitness recording often horrifying events in striking photographs. Moreover, he brings a strong critical awareness and a surprising degree of esthetic sophistication to his task.

title: Art in Review
description: City Folk' Holly Solomon Gallery 172 Mercer Street, SoHo Through Jan. 20

title: Fear of Mad-Cow Disease Spoils Britain's Appetite
description: For centuries, beef has held pride of place at the British table. Whether it's served with Yorkshire pudding in a roadside cafeteria or trotted out on a silver-domed trolley at a quiet club on Pall Mall, the meat seems quintessentially British, so much so that the French call people on this side of the Channel "les rosbifs."

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about "La Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera on Tuesday night misstated the nationality of Vladimir Grishko, the tenor who sang Rodolfo. He is Ukrainian, not Russian.

description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;Magellan Shifted From Technology In November
description: Reinforcing his reputation of being as astute a trader as he is a stock picker, Jeffrey N. Vinik, manager of the $53 billion Fidelity Magellan fund, cut the fund's investment in technology stocks nearly in half in November while causing barely a ripple through the stock market.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Senior Newsweek Editor to Head Little, Brown Adult Trade Unit
description: After more than a month without a publisher for its adult trade division, Little, Brown & Company said yesterday that Sarah Crichton, an assistant managing editor at Newsweek magazine, would take over the post beginning next month.

title: A New Governor Acts to Halt Affirmative Action
description: Gov. Mike Foster signed an executive order today to halt affirmative action programs in Louisiana government, but he acknowledged that his move would have little practical effect unless the Legislature backed him up.

title: Ending Statistical Drought, Fed Reports on Debt
description: Ending a four-week void in official economic figures, the Federal Reserve reported today that consumers added to installment debt at a substantial 10.4 percent annual rate in November.

title: At Whitewater Session, a Struggle to Recall
description: In five hours of testimony before the Senate Whitewater committee, a lawyer at Hillary Rodham Clinton's former law firm said today that he could not remember events of 11 years ago clearly enough to support the First Lady's account of how the firm came to represent a troubled Arkansas savings and loan.

title: City Opera Appoints a Director
description: Paul Kellogg, an opera administrator who built the Glimmerglass Opera in Cooperstown, N.Y., into a major attraction on the summer opera circuit, has been appointed general and artistic director of the New York City Opera, the company announced yesterday.

title: Stop Genetic Robbery
description: To the Editor:

title: The President and the Law
description: The Constitution's Framers could not anticipate that a President would be slapped with an awkward sexual-harassment lawsuit alleging pre-Presidential misconduct. But in rejecting President Clinton's claims of immunity in the Paula Jones case, a Federal appellate court this week affirmed a bedrock constitutional principle. No citizen, even a sitting President, is above the law.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Miller Brewing Co., Milwaukee, a unit of the Philip Morris Cos., to Scaros & Casselman, Stamford, Conn., to introduce Miller beer, a full-calorie brand that will be sold at premium prices. The introductory spending was estimated at $50 million to $100 million. Martin Paints, Jamaica, Queens, to J. Friedman Associates, Florham Park, N.J., to handle advertising for the home improvement retailer, previously handled by Top Line Advertising, Ronkonkoma, L.I. The billings were estimated at $1.6 million.

title: 1.5 Million Trader Theft Is Charged
description: In an unusually swift cooperative action, Federal prosecutors and securities and commodity market regulators charged a New Jersey man yesterday with misappropriating at least $1.5 million from commodity pool accounts he managed for more than 100 investors.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Chief Defends Hospital's Care
description: Since last summer, Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital has been battered by one problem after another: four employees charged with sexually assaulting female patients, two employees indicted for harassing a nurse who tried to stop the beating of a patient, and an escape by a patient considered dangerous.

title: HOCKEY;Keenan Is Next Ex-Coach to Visit Garden
description: Under most circumstances, a trip to Philadelphia and a Saturday game with the Flyers would be the focus of the Rangers' weekend. There would be no looking past such a confrontation. The Flyers are a divisional rival, 6 points behind the first-place Rangers, and the team that eliminated the Rangers last spring in the second round of the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Art in Review
description: Fred Wilson 'Collectibles' Metro Pictures 150 Greene Street, SoHo Through Jan. 20

title: On My Mind;Will We Learn, at Last?
description: Hafez al-Assad, President of Syria, and Saddam Hussein, President of Iraq, are separated by one dramatic difference. Mr. Hussein has a bigger mustache.

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;For Reggie White, Racism Is Hardest Foe
description: While preparing for the biggest game of his 11-year National Football League career -- Green Bay vs. Dallas on Sunday with the winner earning a berth in Super Bowl XXX -- Packers defensive end Reggie White has had his attention diverted from football to arson to racism.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Missing Ingredient for Winning a Title: A Trade
description: As each day passes, the clock keeps ticking for the Knicks. The alarm will go off Feb. 23, the day after the trade deadline. If the Knicks have not made a deal, their chances of winning a title will all but disappear. Getting past either Orlando (26-7) or Chicago (29-3) in the playoffs would be a major feat. Beating them both would be mission impossible.

title: Man in the News: Nicholas Scoppetta;Advocate With a Heart
description: Nicholas Scoppetta has been both a state and Federal prosecutor. He served as a deputy mayor and Commissioner of Investigation under two mayors -- one a Republican and the other a Democrat. He investigated police corruption for the Knapp Commission in the 1970's. He has taught law and, as a partner in his own law firm, represented clients as notorious as the Mayflower Madam.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE SPEAKER;With Talks Suspended, Gingrich Stumps
description: It was Newt Gingrich's kind of crowd, the sort to take his mind off those frustrating budget talks and an unsuccessful strategy to force concessions from President Clinton by shutting down the Government.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan Names A Socialist as Finance Chief
description: Japan's new Prime Minister, Ryutaro Hashimoto, surprised the financial community today by naming a former high school history teacher to the nation's most prestigious Cabinet post of Finance Minister.

title: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET;Excerpts From President's News Conference on Impasse in the Budget Talks
description: Following are excerpts from the opening statement and the question-and-answer portion of President Clinton's news conference, held today in the East Room of the White House. It was provided by the Federal Document Clearing House, a private transcription service: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Bronx Officer Dies In Apparent Suicide
description: An off-duty police officer died last night in the Bronx of a gunshot wound to the head, which the police said appeared to be suicide.

title: Whitman Puts Standards Above Money For Schools
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman today told a Legislature with no cash to spare that New Jersey would achieve educational fairness between rich and poor school districts by rewriting the rules of education, not by writing new state school-aid checks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;URS ACQUISITION OF GREINER IS PUT AT $73.5 MILLION
description: The URS Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire Greiner Engineering Inc. for $73.5 million in cash and stock. The deal creates one of the nation's five largest transportation engineering concerns. Under the deal, URS will pay $13.50 cash and 0.298 share of URS stock for each of Greiner's 4.7 million shares outstanding. URS, which is based in San Francisco, and Greiner disclosed the plan for the acquisition last month. URS offers a range of services in infrastructure and environmental projects. Greiner, which is based in Irving, Tex., provides engineering, planning, architectural, environmental and program management services. The shares of URS closed at $7 yesterday, down 12.5 cents, and Greiner stock closed at $14.625, up 75 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: GIULIANI IS FORMING A NEW CITY AGENCY ON CHILD WELFARE
description: Declaring the protection of children a paramount priority for the second half of his term, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday pulled the troubled Child Welfare Administration out of New York City's welfare bureaucracy and created a new department to be run by a close friend who will report directly to him.

title: Thatcher Hammers Major, Saying Only the Right Makes Might
description: Once again pulling the rug out from under her successor, former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher hammered home criticism of John Major's Government today. She asserted that Conservatives were unpopular because they had lost support of the middle classes and had strayed from the Thatcherite principles of less spending, less government and loose ties with the rest of Europe.

title: FILM REVIEW;Radioactive Fish Lips In a Junk-Filled World
description: It would take an insatiable taste for performance art to admire "Fresh Kill," an extended conceit involving self-serving walk-ons and easy satirical targets, presented in the scattershot format of video art. The film maker, Shu Lea Cheang, is well regarded for her earlier video installations, but the demands of the feature-film format turn her methods repetitive and arch. The film maker's eye for cool blue light, haunting images and eccentric compositions is much more interesting than the hip, untethered ravings that turn 80 minutes into an interminable running time.

title: A Democrat Wins in Guatemala
description: Even after discounting for a slim margin and a low turnout, it is encouraging that Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen, a democrat, defeated a stand-in for Efrain Rios Montt, a former military dictator, in Guatemala's runoff presidential elections this week. Guatemalan democracy, however, remains perilously insecure. It is threatened by Mr. Rios Montt's ambitions, by the army and by the grievances churned in 35 years of civil war. Mr. Arzu's promised efforts to rein in the military and strengthen constitutional rule deserve strong American support.

title: Scientists Report the Discovery of a Brain 'Switch' That Brings OnSleep
description: Scientists report that they have found a master switching mechanism for sleep.

title: HOCKEY;Edmonton Trades Ranford to Boston
description: Goaltender Bill Ranford, one of the last vestiges of the Edmonton Oilers' Stanley Cup era of the 1980's, was traded today to the Bruins for right wing Mariusz Czerkawski and the junior league defenseman Sean Brown.

title: TURMOIL AT BARNEYS: THE DIFFICULTIES;Barneys Is Seeking Bankruptcy, Citing Fight With Partner
description: The parent company of Barneys New York, the store that grew from a small men's suit merchant in lower Manhattan to an international chain that embodies a decidedly New York view of chic shopping, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday in a nasty dispute with its Japanese partner.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;In a Quest for More Rings, Johnson Joins the Dolphins
description: DAVIE, Fla., Jan. 11

title: New Yorker Is Given Life Sentence in Peru
description: Lori Helene Berenson of New York was convicted of treason by a secret Peruvian military court and sentenced to life in prison for aiding a Marxist guerrilla group.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Lincoln Kirstein, a co-founder of the New York City Ballet who also wrote the text for a book about Civil War sculpture, referred incorrectly to the black Civil War regiment that was the subject of the film "Glory." That regiment, from Massachusetts, was not the first such group. It was formed shortly after another black regiment, the First South Carolina Volunteers.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Toxic Traces Were Present After Fire At Warehouse
description: Environmental officials monitoring the air quality in the path of a fire that destroyed a large warehouse Wednesday night said today that they had found small traces of toxic chemicals but not enough to cause health concerns.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: TRACK AND FIELD;High School Senior Faces Stiff Test
description: The 18-year-old George Washington High School senior had just arrived at the Armory Track & Field Center on 168th Street and Broadway on Wednesday afternoon for a workout, slightly out of breath. She is often slightly out of breath, to be sure, since she is the defending National Scholastic Indoor 800-meter champion and the Junior Olympic record-holder.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SKIING;Kjus to Be Sidelined
description: The injured World Cup leader, LASSE KJUS, will be out of action for at least two weeks, Norway's Alpine skiing coach said yesterday in Kitzbuhel, Austria.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HOCKEY Matteau's Two Goals Help Blues Tie Flyers

title: Dole To Mount Counterattack Against Ads by Steve Forbes
description: Fearful that Steve Forbes was emerging as Senator Bob Dole's most potent rival for the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Dole's campaign said today that it would forcefully respond in a television advertisement beginning as early as Friday.

title: Court Reverses the Removal Of Duke Estate's Executors
description: New York State's highest court yesterday reversed a surrogate's decision to remove Doris Duke's butler and the United States Trust Company as executors of her $1.2 billion estate.

title: Diner's Journal
description: It's run by three brothers," the woman next to me confides. She points around the bright, lively room. "See, there they are: Mario, Marco and Mauro." The woman does not point out their mother, Egidiana, also a partner in Osteria del Circo (pronounced CHEER-co), but she's here too.

title: ART REVIEW;Painful Views of the Body, From Postwar Vienna
description: Vienna is a city deeply involved with the self, the body and its interior recesses," writes Konrad Oberhuber in a brief essay accompanying "Freud's Children," an exhibition of drawings by Arnulf Rainer, Hermann Nitsch and six other Austrian artists from the decades after World War II. For Mr. Oberhuber (director of the Albertina Museum in Vienna and a distinguished Poussin scholar), these artists are the true heirs of Gustav Klimt, Egon Schiele and Oskar Kokoschka, the towering figures of pre-World War I Viennese modernism.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE OVERVIEW;Now Comes the Challenge Of Snowbanks and Trash
description: Eight slushy, mucky Manhattan blocks after she started out yesterday morning, Winnifred White was close to perfecting her stroller calisthenics.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE COMMUTERS;Overoptimism Cited for Chaos At Metro-North
description: With Metro-North still reeling from a shortage of working trains three days after this week's snowstorm, its president said yesterday that the railroad contributed to its own problems by sending too many trains into action too soon, and that it had not warned its increasingly angry customers how chaotic service would be.

title: Restaurants
description: The waiters at Bouterin all look as if they could be cast in a Marcel Pagnol film. One night our waiter was an older gentleman with a humorous face who looked exactly as I picture Fanny's kindly suitor, Panisse. The man with the large ears who took our order another time could easily play the sailor Marius, her boyfriend. And the owner, Antoine Bouterin, who comes from St.-Remy-de-Provence, has that mischievous Pagnol look; it is easy to imagine him hiding a stone under a hat and waiting for someone to come along and kick it.

title: In America;Coast-To-Coast Blues
description: It was too brief, the majesty and ferocity of the storm, and the subsequent beauty and quiet of the city. Now it's back to the gritty madness of everyday life, and a look at the new year.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;New Diet Coke ads emphasize the 'Coke' rather than the 'Diet.'
description: THE Coca-Cola Company is playing up the "Coke" in Diet Coke and playing down the "Diet" in a campaign that tries to present the product as a delicious soft drink without calories rather than a beverage to be consumed in medicinal doses by dutiful weight-watchers.

title: Peru Sentences New Yorker to Life in Prison
description: Lori Helene Berenson of New York was convicted of treason today by a secret Peruvian military court and sentenced to life in prison for aiding Marxist guerrillas who prosecutors said were planning to seize the Peruvian Congress and take hostages.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;State Seeks Federal Storm Aid
description: Representative H. James Saxton made the point by walking the beaches yesterday. New Jersey's other Congressmen wrote a letter to the White House. And Governor Whitman reinforced the argument in Trenton: They all said the state needs Federal aid to recover from this week's storm. The Governor sounded confident that President Clinton would come through, saying: "It's going to be pretty easy to justify that this was an extraordinary event and we're going to need some extra help to deal with it."

title: HOCKEY;Things Looking Up at Nassau Coliseum
description: Don't look now, but the Islanders, that ragtag bunch of not-exactly household names, are starting to make a little noise from their spot in the basement of the National Hockey League's Atlantic Division.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VENTURE PLANS TO CLOSE 10 STORES AND CUT 1,200 JOBS
description: Venture Stores Inc., a general-merchandise retailer based in O'Fallon, Mo., said yesterday that it would close 10 stores and eliminate 1,200 jobs as part of a plan to transform itself into a family merchandise chain. The retailer cited poor sales and earnings performance for the stores involved, two in Chicago, two in Houston, one in Champaign, Ill., and five in Indianapolis. About 120 workers will be cut from each of the stores, or about 7 percent of the company's total work force of 17,000, a spokesman, Randy Myers, said. Venture will keep 105 stores open. The plan will save the company $22 million and is not expected to result in a charge against earnings, Mr. Myers said.

title: BOXING;Young Heavyweight Is the Stuff of Dreams
description: If Roy Jones Jr. is indeed "the next chapter in boxing history" then we can call Michael Grant the best-seller being written at night, the CD-Rom being developed part-time in the garage. Jones, famously gifted, smart, handsome, is the headliner in tonight's Madison Square Garden show. Grant, unknown, is a name on the undercard. Jones has been called, with justification, pound for pound the best boxer in the world. But there is always a faint damning in such praise if you only weigh 168 pounds. Call him Sugar Roy, if you like, but there is still a lid on Jones's possibilities. Grant is 6 feet 7 inches tall and weighs 250 pounds, a very heavyweight, the right size for boxing dreams.

title: Who's Who of Money Moguls in '96 Race
description: When Ernest and Julio Gallo set out in 1992 to remake the blue-collar image of their California wines, they turned for help to a reliable friend, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas.

title: World News Briefs;Cousteau Research Ship Sinks in Singapore
description: Jacques Cousteau's ship, the Calypso, which carried the oceanographer around the world during his research since 1950, has sunk in shallow waters off the port of Singapore.

title: HOCKEY;Terreri Thwarts His Former Teammates
description: In six full seasons with the Devils, whether as the starting goaltender or the backup, Chris Terreri provided solutions for New Jersey. Tonight, in his first visit to New Jersey since he was traded Nov. 15, Terreri provided one for the San Jose Sharks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRAXAIR AGREES TO SELL 4 PLANTS IN CBI DEAL
description: The Federal Trade Commission said yesterday that Praxair Inc. had agreed to divest itself of four production plants it will acquire in the $2 billion purchase of CBI Industries, to settle antitrust concerns about the deal. Praxair, the largest supplier of industrial gases in the United States, confirmed that the settlement had been reached and said its tender offer of $33 a share for CBI, a maker of industrial gases based in Oak Brook, Ill., would proceed. The F.T.C. had contended that the acquisition would reduce competition and would raise prices for certain gases. Praxair, which is based in Danbury, Conn., agreed to divest itself of CBI plants in Vacaville and Irwindale, Calif.; Bozrah, Conn., and Madison, Wis., within 12 months.

title: GOLF;Three Strokes Off Lead Is a Big Victory for Pohl
description: For Dan Pohl, this could not have been a more perfect day. The desert sky was high, the wind was calm, the sun was warm and Pohl was back playing golf for a living. When a man nearly has his livelihood sliced away by yet another surgeon's scalpel, he learns to appreciate things like this.

title: Teen-Ager Is Charged in Death of Newborn
description: A newborn girl was found dead in a plastic garbage bag in the Bronx early yesterday and a 16-year-old girl, identified by the authorities as the mother, was charged with murder, the police said.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: THEATER REVIEW;Girls, Girls: Love Gives A Fatalist The Willies
description: If Dobie Gillis had come of age in the 1990's, he would probably resemble Linus Worth, the wistful, girl-addicted hero of "Wonderful Time," Jonathan Marc Sherman's wisp of a play at the WPA Theater.

title: Perfect Days for Playing in Snow
description: THE keen of eye might have noticed that a few snowflakes settled on New York City last weekend. The storm had a name, Ginger, and its light but unrelenting touch managed to clog streets, shut down airports and more or less paralyze the region. It's been bad, bad news for a lot of people. But not for everyone.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEW YORK STATE APPROVES CHASE-CHEMICAL MERGER
description: The $10 billion merger between the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Chemical Banking Corporation was approved yesterday by New York State regulators, removing the last regulatory hurdle to the deal, which will create the nation's biggest bank. The merger will result in a bank with $297 billion in assets, 2,000 offices and a leading position in consumer banking, mortgages, credit cards, corporate lending and other services. The combination is also expected to result in the elimination of 12,000 jobs and 100 branches.

title: Fixed Mortgage Rates Up
description: Interest rates on 30-year fixed mortgages averaged 7.08 percent this week, up from 7.02 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the highest average rate since Dec. 28, when rates averaged 7.11 percent. Last week's average was the lowest since Feb. 3, 1994, when it was 6.97 percent.

title: Data-Secrecy Export Case Dropped by U.S.
description: In a case that had been closely watched for its possible impact on free speech and privacy, the Justice Department said today that it had decided not to prosecute a computer programmer after a long investigation into the export of data scrambling software.

title: TURMOIL AT BARNEYS: THE DISPUTE;A Match Not Made In Heaven
description: For the last six years, Barneys New York has been the envy of the retail industry.

title: The Divine Write-Off;Republicans Tiptoe Around the Mortgage Deduction
description: The Republican flat-taxers' vision of an income tax so simple that it could be filed on a postcard, with everyone paying the same rate, is about to run into the middle class's devotion to its single-biggest tax break: the deduction for home-mortgage interest.

title: Study Backs Balloons for Clearing Arteries
description: A laser is no more effective than a balloon in opening blocked coronary arteries, according to a Dutch study to be published today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Hill, Holliday Agrees To Buy Altschiller
description: Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston said yesterday that as expected it had agreed to acquire Altschiller & Company, a small New York agency known for its creativity that is owned by the Omnicom Group. The terms were not disclosed.

title: Not-Guilty Plea on Bomb
description: Two men accused of trying to blow up an Internal Revenue Service office building here with a 100-pound homemade bomb pleaded not guilty to Federal charges today.

title: Abroad at Home;Budget Myths
description: From the public's perspective, the budget conflict seems to rest on a number of unchallengeable economic truths. In fact, they are myths.

title: Sturdy Advance by Stocks Halts a Two-Day Selloff
description: The stock market rebounded yesterday from the debacle of the previous two days, despite three rounds of computer-guided sell orders.

title: EXPLORING;With Only the Wind for Company
description: It has been a year since Don and Margie McIntyre courted civilization. Marooned by choice since last January in a small, isolated hut in Antarctica, the couple from Australia have survived a year alone in the windiest place on Earth.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;J. P. Morgan's Net Income Surged 90% in 4th Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that net income jumped nearly 90 percent in the fourth quarter -- well above expectations -- as profits surged from trading, investment banking and other nonlending businesses.

title: Vacco Joins in the Scrutiny of Mrs. Clinton
description: State Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco has opened an investigation into payments allegedly made by a nonprofit, state-financed organization based in Rochester to Hillary Rodham Clinton and her Arkansas law firm between 1990 and 1992, aides said today.

title: ART REVIEW;A Neo-Surrealist Show With a Revisionist Agenda
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art's "Altered and Irrational" show is the latest attempt by a New York museum to arrange related works from its permanent collection into something resembling a temporary theme exhibition. As the show's title implies, the orientation here is Surrealist, with works from the 1980's and early 90's grouped with sympathetic efforts from the 1960's and 70's.

title: Pascual Perez Back on the Mound
description: Pascual Perez returned to pro baseball after a three-year absence, pitching two perfect innings and striking out three tonight to lead the Licey Tigers past the Escogido Lions in the Dominican League's semifinals.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will be observed on Monday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Seeking Salvation On the Silver Screen
description: IN THE BEAUTY OF THE LILIES By John Updike 491 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.95. YEARS ago, in one of his glittering essays, John Updike wrote of his admiration for novels that "give us, through the consciousness of characters, a geography amplified by history, a chunk of the planet."

title: With a Mea Culpa And Some Tinkering, ABC Defends Lineup
description: In July, television network executives are full of bravado, confidently talking up the new shows they have scheduled for the coming season. By January, some are still crowing, while some are eating crow.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Tax on Comics To Be Lifted In California
description: A San Francisco cartoonist who challenged an attempt by California to tax the sale of cartoons and comic strips won an appeal yesterday over his disputed tax bill and regulators voted to end the practice.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Growth at 1.9%
description: German economic growth slowed to a crawl last year, and the Government warned yesterday that there was little hope that 1996 would be any better for Europe's largest economy. The economy grew just 1.9 percent in 1995, the Government's statistics office said, a slowdown from 2.9 percent in 1994. The German Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, forecast that the expansion would continue at a weak pace this year and could be less than 2 percent. (Reuters)
