description: To the Editor:

title: World's Leaders Bid Farewell to Mitterrand
description: In flowing African robes, Arab headdresses and sober mourning clothes, the high and mighty of France and the world bade farewell today to former President Francois Mitterrand at a Requiem Mass in Notre Dame Cathedral while his family quietly laid him to rest in the town where he was born.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Combining Nationalities And Styles
description: Sungsoo Ahn's ability to blend many types of movement and music made it possible to hope that his Sungsoo Ahn Pick-Up Group would give a surprising, stimulating and possibly even provocative program on Wednesday night as part of the Altogether Different series at the Joyce Theater. Instead, the evening was bland.

title: Art in Review
description: Robert Rauschenberg Sonnabend Gallery 420 West Broadway (near Spring Street), SoHo Through Feb. 3

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Snow Is Not a Hit

title: FILM REVIEW;A Trained Orangutan With Larceny in Its Heart
description: Few movie sights are more primally satisfying than a frisky animal or hyperactive child laying waste to a snooty grown-up social event. Near the end of "Dunston Checks In," an orangutan let loose in an elegant New York hotel succeeds in seriously disrupting a fancy-dress ball. At least one table is overturned, and several formally attired revelers wind up sprawled and kicking in the foot-deep icing atop a giant pink cake.

title: Irene Arnold, 88; Lawyer and Teacher Helped the Retarded
description: Irene Arnold, a lawyer and teacher who spent her life in the service of the retarded and other victims of circumstance, like war and persecution, died on Jan. 4 at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. A Clinton resident, she was 88.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;Slippery Tactics Denied by Cowboys
description: There is no question that the Dallas Cowboys have the best offensive line in football. Four starters were named to the Pro Bowl. They gave up the second-fewest number of sacks in the league with 18. They have some of the biggest, smartest and most athletic players in the league.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Labor Fight Looms in Rutgers
description: It's almost spring at Rutgers University. At least it's almost spring semester.

title: Girl Runners Should Suit Themselves
description: To the Editor:

title: Divorce Cases Proceed Despite Judge Rotation
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Drops Charge on Ignored Confession
description: A New York City police officer has recanted his charge that several detectives refused to hear a murder confession from a man who was later accused in last month's slaying of five people in a Bronx shoe store, the police said yesterday.

title: The New, Improved Mayor
description: Yesterday's State of the City speech may have been one of the most important of Rudolph Giuliani's career. New York City's Mayor has already earned enormous credit for reducing crime, cutting costs and making the city more livable. But he has not given much attention to social services on which the poorest New Yorkers depend. Furthermore, even his supporters worry about the Mayor's lack of diplomacy, his unwillingness to tolerate disagreement. Yesterday, he gave signs he is moving to correct both these failings.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 90.30 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,287.62. On Thursday the Nikkei closed down 234.40 points.

title: Her Family Is Devastated, Striving for Hope
description: As their 26-year-old daughter stood accused by a secret Peruvian military tribunal of aiding a band of Marxist terrorists, a 30-year sentence hanging over her head, Rhoda and Mark Berenson had steeled themselves for bad news.

title: Whitewater Affair Distracts From Real Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Directors and Investors at Odds Over Pay
description: Are shareholders barking up the wrong tree when they pressure companies to pay board members in stock, not cash?

title: Reptile Menagerie Discovered
description: Animal rescue officials called to a Brooklyn apartment on Wednesday found a menagerie of abandoned exotic reptiles: two caimans, a 15-foot Burmese python, a 10-foot anaconda and a Nile monitor lizard.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saab Sales Rise 11%
description: Saab Automobile A. B., a Swedish car maker jointly owned by the General Motors Corporation and Investor A. B. of Sweden, said sales in 1995 rose 11 percent, to 98,700 cars. In the United States, Saab's largest market, sales increased 18 percent, to 25,500 cars, even as the total market declined 4 percent, Saab said. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;2 Held in Extortion Attempt
description: Two Plainfield men have been accused of trying to extort money from a McDonald's restaurant in North Plainfield and planting a fake bomb, officials said yesterday. One of the suspects, Charles Lamont Brown, had a stolen cellular phone in his apartment that was used to place a call to the restaurant last November demanding $3,000, said Melaine Campbell, an assistant prosecutor for Somerset County.

title: Living Wages,' Fewer Jobs
description: New York City is trying to repeal the law of supply and demand. A bill supported by a majority of City Council members would require companies with city contracts to pay their employees a minimum of $12.10 an hour. The proposal, which proponents call "living wage" legislation, would do to the labor market what rent control has done to the housing market: drive up prices and destroy opportunities for the poor.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Tomjanovich Is Rewarded
description: The Rockets' owner, Leslie Alexander, has showed his appreciation to Coach Rudy Tomjanovich for the team's back-to-back National Basketball Association titles by extending his contract through 2000. Tomjanovich would not discuss the deal's financial terms, but Houston's KRIV-TV quoted sources today as saying the coach received a two-year extension to his contract.

title: Fed's Policy Is Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: WOMEN'S BASKETBALL;Rebecca Lobo Is Named Female Athlete of '95
description: REBECCA LOBO, who helped take women's basketball to new heights of popularity with her playing skill and charm, was named yesterday as the Associated Press female athlete of the year for 1995.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Gtech Chairman Sues Head of Virgin Atlantic
description: The chairman of the Gtech Corporation, Guy Snowden, sued the chairman of Virgin Atlantic Airways, Richard Branson, yesterday, accusing him of defamation for contending that Mr. Snowden tried to bribe him to pull out of the bidding to run Britain's national lottery. "I have taken this action to restore my good name," said Mr. Snowden, whom Mr. Branson accused last month of trying to pay him off over lunch at Mr. Branson's office on Sept. 24, 1993, as the two discussed bidding for the lottery contract.

title: Inside Art
description: An Array of Works From Two Estates

title: Key Executive At Citicorp Plans to Retire
description: Pei-Yuan Chia, the vice chairman of Citicorp who led its profitable growth in global consumer banking, will retire this year, the bank said yesterday.

title: Paul A. Gorman, 88, Executive Who Ran Bell's Western Electric
description: Paul A. Gorman, a past president of Western Electric, the former Bell System's manufacturing arm, who later ran the Penn Central Transportation Company and the International Paper Company, died on Thursday in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 88.

title: Broadus Butler, 75, Ex-Tuskegee Airman And College Leader
description: Broadus Nathaniel Butler, a retired college administrator, Federal education official and current president of the East Coast chapter of the Tuskegee Airmen, died on Tuesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. A Washington resident, he was 75.

title: BASEBALL;Cuban Pitcher Is Offered A Record Signing Bonus
description: A 20-year-old pitcher who defected from Cuba last Sept. 25 has been offered a $3.5 million signing bonus as part of a three-year, $4.6 million contract, an executive of one of the teams in the bidding said last night.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about the Senate Whitewater Committee reported on the testimony of Richard Massey, a lawyer in the Rose Law Firm in Little Rock.

title: Iran Is Good Neighbor In Persian Gulf Region
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Strengthening Patrols Along the Mexican Border
description: Just one week after Congress increased its budget by 24 percent, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it was beefing up enforcement along the Southwestern border to prevent any increase in illegal immigration that might be caused by Mexico's severe economic problems.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Astacio, Blowers Sign
description: PEDRO ASTACIO, a right-handed pitcher, and third baseman MIKE BLOWERS, the two Los Angeles Dodger players eligible for arbitration, agreed yesterday to one-year contracts.

title: Bridge
description: The Brazilian team, which has regularly been a factor in world championships and has won twice, suffered a severe disappointment at the 1995 world championships in Beijing in October when it barely failed to reach the playoff stage. But the Brazilian players soon bounced back and went back to work. A few days after returning to Rio de Janeiro, the veteran star Gabriel Chagas found a clever way to create an illusion.

title: Trade Publisher for Sale
description: Advanstar Holdings Inc. said today that it had hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to find a buyer for the company, a publishing and marketing concern. Advanstar Holdings' operating company, the Cleveland-based Advanstar Communications Inc., publishes 55 business magazines and professional journals ranging from Managed Healthcare to Video Store News. It also produces 54 trade shows and conferences, including the International Motorcycle Show.

title: Why Alter the Lyrics of Those Age-Old Hymns?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mora Will Be Back As Coach of Saints
description: Jim Mora, who overcame an 0-5 start and speculation nearly all season that he would be dismissed, will return for his 11th year as coach of the New Orleans Saints.

title: Federal Agency Issues a Mild Caution on a Hyperactivity Drug
description: Government scientists have uncovered a sign that the widely used children's drug Ritalin might cause cancer in mice. But they say parents should not stop giving their children the drug, used to treat hyperactivity, based on such weak findings.

title: Jane Miller MacRae, Artist and Author, 89
description: Jane Miller MacRae, an artist who wrote and illustrated children's books, died on Tuesday at her home in Hobe Sound, Fla. She was 89.

title: About New York;In Brooklyn A Message For Mourners
description: HUNDREDS of flowers, a fragrant collage in red and yellow, seemed out of place along Atlantic Avenue's snowbank-snarled traffic on Thursday. More incongruous was where they had just been: by the coffins of Dwayne (Butter) Boone and Glennis (Weeda) Saunders.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Isetan Sues Barney's,Calls Attitude Deplorable

title: High Court to Rule On Antidrug Tactic
description: The Supreme Court agreed to take up the growing legal debate over the Government's antidrug strategy: whether the Constitution allows prosecutors to seek a criminal conviction for a narcotics violation and forfeiture of a defendant's property.

title: Proposed New Heliport Finds Home at West Side Car Pound
description: The Giuliani administration is planning to build a new heliport on Pier 76 on Manhattan's West Side, displacing the pound for towed cars that has been the unsought destination for more than 90,000 vehicles a year.

title: INSIDE
description: Heliport to Oust Car Pound

title: Mayor Sees More Cuts if Rate Plan Fails
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday he might have to make deeper cuts in spending in response to Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi's decision earlier this week to refuse to approve a plan to reorganize New York City's debt for an infusion of cash.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day on Tuesday about Donald J. Trump's latest casino plans misidentified the period in which, Mr. Trump asserted, he owed $8.8 billion. It was 1991; the assertion was made last fall.

title: State Weighs Wider Use Of a Landfill In Parkland
description: Over protests from environmentalists and landowners in the Adirondack Park, the Pataki administration is considering a plan that would, for the first time, allow garbage to be trucked into the century-old, 6 million-acre preserve from a city outside the park boundary.

title: Sports of The Times;Nice to See Standards Somewhere
description: Nothing happened. That's what it looked like on the surface. Not one player was voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame this week.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE PUDDLES;Getting to the Other Side: Not a Task for the Dainty
description: Sam Lewallen, 9, approached the water's edge gingerly, stuck in one toe and then took the plunge, screaming all the way: "It's deep! It's cold!"

title: Shuttle Is Forced to Maneuver Around an Abandoned Satellite
description: The space shuttle Endeavour made an unexpected maneuver today around a piece of space junk, illustrating the increased vigilance required to avoid a growing amount of space debris.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of production delays caused by the weather, some home delivery subscribers will not find The Times Magazine today in the package of Sunday sections delivered in advance. Those subscribers will receive the magazine tomorrow.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE SPORTS;Bias Found at L.S.U. In Title IX Ruling
description: Louisiana State University violated the civil rights of female athletes with "arrogant ignorance" of their needs, a federal judge ruled yesterday, ordering the university to come up with a plan to remedy the discrimination within 20 days.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Man Admits a Killing
description: George H. Hemenway, of East Windsor, admitted that he shot and killed a man during a rendezvous arranged through a computer on-line service, Timothy McNamara, the assistant Mercer County Prosecutor, told a Superior Court judge. Mr. Hemenway is being held on charges of murdering Jesse M. Unger, 39, of Hamilton Township, as an unidentified 15-year-old boy watched on Jan. 4 at Mr. Hemenway's house. JOE SHARKEY

title: New York City Plans Market In Its Tax Bills
description: In a bid to raise $125 million quickly from New York City's huge backlog of unpaid property taxes, the Giuliani administration is moving to market the tax bills in the same way that Wall Streets sells securities, investment bankers in New York and Philadelphia said yesterday.

title: Harvard Must Correct Women's Tenure Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Beware Cars That Want to Play Tag With You
description: To the Editor:

title: Word at Aqueduct: Canceled
description: For the third time this week, racing at Aqueduct was canceled yesterday even before more wintry weather reached New York.

title: Berlin Journal;Exoneration Still Eludesc An Anti-Nazi Crusader
description: During his turbulent life, Carl von Ossietzky, winner of the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize, did not lack for enemies.

title: Coke Drops 'Domestic' and Goes One World
description: Now, the Coca-Cola Company could adopt the song "We Are the World" as its corporate motto.

title: BOXING;Jones's Dazzling Show a Smash Hit on Broadway
description: Roy Jones Jr. became a New Yorker last night, giving cheering Madison Square Garden fans a spectacular, brutal and educational show in halting Merqui Sosa in the second round.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOECHST UNIT IN PACT WITH ALLIANCE PHARMACEUTICAL
description: The Hoechst Marion Roussel unit of Hoechst A.G. of Germany and the Alliance Pharmaceutical Corporation entered a worldwide license agreement yesterday to develop and market Alliance's Liquivent, a drug designed to treat acute respiratory failure. Hoechst Marion will get exclusive manufacturing and worldwide marketing rights to the product in return for providing funds for development of the drug, which is in clinical trials. Hoechst Marion will pay Alliance a license fee and make certain royalty payments after the drug is brought to market. Hoechst Marion will also buy a minority-stake interest in Alliance, which is based in San Diego. The total value of the transaction was not disclosed.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Childs Says He Is Focused
description: After five seasons in the Continental Basketball Association, after battling a problem with alcohol that nearly derailed his career, Chris Childs is certainly not going to let his lawsuit against the Nets make him lose his focus on establishing himself as a legitimate player in the National Basketball Association.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Gains Tax Defeated in Taiwan
description: The Parliament defeated legislation today that would have imposed a capital gains tax on profits from stock transactions, easing worries that institutional investors would withdraw from the stock market.

title: Kitty Hart Resigns As Head Of Arts Council
description: After 20 years as the state's premier campaigner for rural string quartets and inner-city dance troupes, Kitty Carlisle Hart submitted her resignation yesterday as chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts, a move widely expected since the election of Gov. George E. Pataki more than a year ago.

title: Don't Criticize Peru for Battling Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel-Syria Talks to Reopen, Focusing on Military
description: Syrian and Israeli negotiators will resume their negotiations near Washington on Jan. 24 with a renewed mandate and the help of ranking military experts, Secretary of State Warren Christopher announced today after a meeting with the Syrian President, Hafez al-Assad.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Take A Step Back With Loss To 76ers
description: They used all the miserable adjectives they could think of: "humiliating," "embarrassing," "terrible," "unprofessional." Somehow they still didn't describe how poorly the Nets played tonight against the lowly Philadelphia 76ers at the Meadowlands.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday, with the continuation of a front-page article about the bankruptcy filing by Barney's Inc., misstated the location of the interior of the Manhattan store shown. It was Barney'sdowntown store, at Seventh Avenue and 17th Street, not the one at Madison Avenue and 61st Street.

title: U.S. Sees Bosnia Role Widening To Protect War Crimes Inquiries
description: Signaling that NATO will soon broaden its duties in Bosnia, and clarifying American policy on a sensitive topic, Defense Secretary William J. Perry says that beginning later this month, American and other alliance troops will provide security for human rights investigators looking into evidence of war crimes in Bosnia.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices of Heating Oil Tumble On Warmer-Weather Outlook
description: Heating oil prices fell yesterday for a third day, as forecasts for warmer weather and a report of rising inventories signaled weakening demand.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Food Scam in Prison
description: Two food services officials at the State Department of Corrections were suspended without pay after an investigation found that they billed for large amounts of prison food that were never delivered, a department spokesman told the A.P. yesterday. The two officials oversaw about $5 million in food purchases annually for about 4,200 inmates in three South Jersey prisons. Officials would not discuss details of the investigation or say whether criminal charges are pending.

title: THE 1996 ELECTION: THE DARK HORSE;Republican Newcomer Gets His Rivals' Attention
description: No longer dismissing Steve Forbes as a short-lived political sensation, campaigns of other candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination now view the multimillionaire publisher as a significant threat who could place well in, and even win, crucial early contests.

title: Japan Retailer Files $168 Million Suit Against Barney's
description: The Isetan Company, the upscale fashion retailer in Japan that bankrolled the recent expansion of Barneys New York, strongly suggested today that it had been misled by the Barneys management and filed suit against the owners of Barneys.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: Knight-Ridder Plans to Shed Main Financial News Unit
description: After years of trying to transform its electronic financial news service into a leading competitor, Knight-Ridder Inc. threw in the towel yesterday, saying that it would put the service up for auction this spring.

title: Why Alter the Lyrics of Those Age-Old Hymns?
description: To the Editor:

title: America's Small-Town Team;Packers Play for Touchdown Not for Profits
description: Most football fans know who owns the Dallas Cowboys -- the ultra-aggressive Jerry Jones, a one-time oil wildcatter who bought the team and Texas Stadium for $140 million in 1989, hired and then fell out with Jimmy Johnson as his coach, won two Super Bowls and stars in Pizza Hut commercials with Deion Sanders.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article yesterday about a Dutch study comparing the effectiveness of lasers and balloons in opening blocked coronary arteries, in the procedure known as angioplasty, omitted one paragraph and part of another in some editions. The affected passage should have read:

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996;Worker Suspended in Plowing Case
description: A New York City snowplow driver was suspended yesterday after the Sanitation Department received photographs that were said to show him clearing a private parking lot during Monday's storm when he was supposed to be digging out a SoHo firehouse.

title: How To Save Children
description: Prompted by the death of 6-year-old Elisa lzquierdo, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is revamping the New York City agency that handles child abuse. At the same time, legislation to lift the veil of secrecy from child abuse cases -- by authorizing the release of confidential agency information -- is on a fast track in Albany. Both changes should make the workings of the child welfare system more visible and thus help the public understand why so many Elisas are left in dangerous homes.

title: Clinton Insults France
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Agassi Eyes Olympics
description: The world's second-ranked player, ANDRE AGASSI, said yesterday in Melbourne, Australia, that he was prepared to sacrifice playing in the Davis Cup in pursuit of an Olympic gold medal for the United States in Atlanta.

title: Whitewater Panel Suspends Subpoenas
description: Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas and the former Whitewater business partners of President Clinton will not have to respond to subpoenas from the Senate Whitewater Committee until after their criminal trials, a Federal judge announced today.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Into a Democracy of Jazz
description: Halfway through the first tune of the night, the tenor saxophonist Don Braden started a repeated figure that eventually turned the set into an occasion. Playing it again and again, Mr. Braden sucked the band into its rhythms, forcing the music to take a new structure. It was band democracy in action, and it was exciting.

title: GOLF;Mickelson Finds His Confidence And Game
description: For most of last year, the best young golfer in America was just another touring pro under a visor. Phil Mickelson, 25, won the Nortel Open in the season's third event last year and then seemed to lose interest. He didn't win again, and it wasn't until his fine performance in the Ryder Cup matches that he reasserted himself as one of the game's top players.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volkswagen Gains In European Market
description: Volkswagen A.G. grabbed a larger slice of the Western European auto market in 1995, giving it the largest market share there for the 10th consecutive year, the company said yesterday. Volkswagen said deliveries to customers in Western Europe climbed 4.6 percent, to 2.1 million vehicles last year, giving it a 16.8 percent share of the market, up from 15.8 percent a year earlier.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EL PASO NATURAL GAS TO CUT WORK FORCE BY ONE-THIRD
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company, which owns one of the nation's largest natural gas transmission systems, will cut up to a third of its work force, company officials said yesterday. The company, which has approximately 2,400 employees, expects to eliminate between 600 and 800 jobs through layoffs and attrition. A company spokeswoman, Norma Dunn, said the company was shifting some of its emphasis beyond merely transporting gas to local utilities and other customers and would be phasing out some departments. Most of the reductions are expected to take place by the end of the first quarter.

title: Snow and Chaos for Commuters
description: When a blizzard walloped New York two years ago, the Long Island Rail Road's response was so abysmal that its president was forced to resign and promises were made that next time would be different. This week the L.I.R.R. performed reasonably well in the face of an even bigger storm, but its sister commuter line, Metro-North, did not. In fact, Metro-North, which serves Westchester County and Connecticut, seems to have repeated some of the very mistakes made by L.I.R.R. executives in 1994, including a failure to keep commuters informed. The storm was an act of nature, but the public needs answers about apparent mismanagement in the response of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: William Jennings Dyess, Former Ambassador, 66
description: William Jennings Dyess, a former Foreign Service officer and specialist in European affairs who retired in 1983 as Ambassador to the Netherlands, died last Saturday of cancer at his home in Washington. He was 66.

title: At Yale, a Decent Life Is a Radical Idea
description: The first baby-boomer administration at Yale is reliving its radical youth -- but this time as the Establishment.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;No More Free Lunches in Jail
description: Asserting that felonious freeloaders are overburdening taxpayers, the Cape May County Sheriff, James T. Plousis, said yesterday that prisoners in the county jail would be charged $40 t0 $45 a day for room and board starting next month. "A lot of people think, in jail, they'll get three meals a day and it's warm," Sheriff Plousis said. "If they have to pay, they'll think twice about coming in." Those who cannot come up with the money will be billed, he said. Earlier this week, the Morris County Sheriff's Office announced a proposal to charge inmates for meals.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FOOD LION INC., Salisbury, N.C., which operates a supermarket chain, will acquire the assets of Food Fair of North Carolina Inc., Winston-Salem, N.C. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Art, in the End, Transcends
description: The Metropolitan Opera is a place where life imitates art on the grandest of scales. Where in Verdi does one find a moment to match the dramatic horror of Richard Versalle literally dying before our eyes on Friday a week ago? What plot could offer up the grotesque poetry of his circumstances: a tenor who sings "You can only live so long" and then suffers the heart attack that substantiates his words? Given its largely self-generated income, the Met cannot afford to cancel performances, but on this occasion it sent its patrons home. Janacek's "Makropulos Case" in a new production would have to wait until Monday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Bounty for the Strong
description: As more snow piled up yesterday, the city of Orange put out a new call for able-bodied day workers who want to earn $6 an hour shoveling snow from places that municipal plows cannot reach. "All they have to bring is a shovel, and be at City Hall at 8:30 A.M. on Monday," said Mayor Robert L. Brown. Yesterday morning, about 40 workers showed up to help clear Orange's sidewalks and pedestrian bridges.

title: Back on the Beat In Her Hoboken, An Identity Later;After 45 Years as a Man, Officer Tackles a New Life
description: The woman was threatening to kill herself. She had locked herself in her car and was refusing to speak to anyone when police Lieut. Janet Aiello approached and rapped on the window. The woman looked up at the beefy hand and saw behind it a face she recognized from television and newspapers.

title: SOCCER;Politics Plays a Role At the African Cup
description: The war of words between South Africa's President, Nelson Mandela, and Nigeria's leader, Gen. Sani Abacha, has escalated. They are throwing soccer balls.

title: Gingrich Promises Solution on Debt Ceiling
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich promised today to avoid more uncertainty about the nation's borrowing during the impasse on the Federal budget, saying, "We will find a way to take care of the debt ceiling."

title: Last Days of Mitterrand
description: The former President, Francois Mitterrand, ended his own life by halting the drug treatment against the cancer that killed him, friends and associates said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;K-TEL SALE OF CONSUMER ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESS IS OFF
description: K-Tel International Inc., which sells recorded music, said yesterday that an agreement to sell its consumer entertainment business had been ended. Last July, K-Tel's board approved selling the consumer entertainment business to a group led by K-Tel's president, Mickey Elfenbein, for $25 million. Among other factors, the proposed sale was subject to the closing of a related transaction involving K-5 Leisure Products Inc., the purchasing group and Mr. Elfenbein. Details of that transaction were not disclosed. K-Tel said that it had received written notice on Thursday that K-5 had terminated the related transaction. K-5 is owned by K-Tel's chairman, Philip Kives, who also holds a roughly 66 percent stake in K-Tel.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: AROUND THE NATION;Less-Powerful Storm Makes Things Worse
description: The second winter storm of the week covered the capital with another five inches of snow today, enough to shut down the Federal Government just a day after it had opened for the first time in nearly a month.

title: Fannie Mae Increases Its Mortgage Limit
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association has raised the limit on the size of the mortgages it buys.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: The birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. will be observed on Monday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;No Exemptions for Journalists
description: Stop the presses: News reporters and photographers are not "essential" workers who qualify for exemptions from orders like Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's emergency decree banning travel on state roads during the blizzard, the state police said.

title: Put More Killers Away for Life
description: Some killings are so brutal that a sentence of life without parole is the only appropriate punishment, if the death penalty is not applicable. Yet under New York State law, such life sentences are only an option in cases of first-degree murder --

title: For Mexico Indians, New Voice but Few Gains
description: When skies clear after a storm, Indian women still gather on the edge of the highway here to wash clothes in the rainwater that collects in culverts that they blocked with stones and mud.

title: 2 Convicted in Killing Over Confederate Flag
description: Two black teen-agers were found guilty of murder today and sentenced to life in prison in the shooting of a white man who was flying a Confederate flag on his pickup truck. A third black teen-ager was acquitted.

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: THE DAMAGE;At Least 14 Hurt as Snow's Weight Brings Down the Roof of an L.I. Supermarket
description: At least 14 people were injured, one seriously, when half the sprawling roof of a Waldbaum's supermarket in Massapequa, L.I., collapsed late yesterday, dumping a mountain of snow, slush and debris among the nearly deserted aisles of foodstuffs and household goods. The store appeared to be a total loss.

title: Stocks Off in Volatile Day; Earnings Reports Awaited
description: Stocks inched lower yesterday in a volatile trading session, as the market prepared for the flood of fourth-quarter corporate earnings reports expected to begin next week.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Drug Hearing Delayed
description: A hearing for JESSICA FOSCHI, the 15-year-old swimmer from Long Island accused of using performance-enhancing steroids, was postponed yesterday to allow an expert on sports doping to testify.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Saab Plans to Cut Auto Production
description: Saab, the Swedish car maker jointly owned by the General Motors Corporation and the Swedish investment firm Investor A.B., said yesterday that it planned to cut production because of fewer orders. "It is bad now and, therefore, we are planning several days of stoppage," a spokesman, Olof Wallen, said. "The year has not got off to a good start, and so we have to slam on the brakes."

title: Why Alter the Lyrics of Those Age-Old Hymns?;Respect for Epiphany
description: To the Editor:

title: Surgical Supplies Discarded in U.S. Help Save Lives Overseas
description: Fresh from an operating room at the Rose Medical Center here, a 55-gallon trash bag contained a valuable trove of never-used surgical supplies: sutures, Ace bandages, surgical marking pens, drape sheets and rubber gloves.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Layoffs at Kiwi Airlines
description: More layoffs are on the way. Kiwi International Airlines, grooming its balance sheet for a public stock offering on Wall Street, announced a "surgical cost reduction" yesterday. About 60 of the airline's employees at its Newark headquarters and in Atlanta, Chicago and Florida would be laid off. In addition, 25 to 30 other workers would leave voluntarily and a dozen other, highly paid employees would see smaller paychecks, said the airline, which has 1,200 employees and operates 15 jet aircraft. Founded 3 1/2 years ago, Kiwi wants to cut costs by 10 percent as it plans for an initial stock offering as early as next month, The Associated Press reported.

title: Party-Line Battle For Nonpartisan Seat
description: Tuesday's special election to fill the seat for City Council District 5, representing the Upper East Side of Manhattan and Roosevelt Island, is officially a nonpartisan choice. In fact, the City Charter forbids candidates to use the names of established political parties -- an effort to minimize the impact of parties in special elections.

title: 43 Million Award in Malpractice Suit
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday awarded $43 million to a New Jersey woman and her retarded 7-year-old son in a medical malpractice case that centered on the mother's treatment before and during the boy's birth at Beth Israel Medical Center.

title: HIGH SCHOLL BASKETBALL REPORT
description: Christ the King

title: BOXING;Botha Fails Doping Test
description: The news came as a shock even in the hurly-burly world of fighting: Frans Botha, who won the vacant International Boxing Federation heavyweight title last month in Germany by beating Axel Schulz, has tested positive for anabolic steroids.

title: Tale of a Treasure
description: The tale of the Quedlinburg treasure, which began over 50 years ago, is finally coming to an end. Along the way it has resembled a wartime drama and a mystery story about people who tried to make money from stolen artworks. Now, with the Federal indictment of the brother and sister of a soldier named Joe Tom Meador, it may no longer be a monument to crime without punishment. They, along with a lawyer, John S. Torigian, have been charged under the National Stolen Property Act with trafficking in stolen goods.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sony Official Says Stock Sale Of U.S. Units Is Still Far Off
description: The president of the Sony Corporation, Nobuyuki Idei, said today that he envisioned selling stock in the company's American entertainment and electronics operations to the public, though not in the immediate future.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Thursday, about the new film "City Hall," misstated the dates of Ken Lipper's service as Deputy Mayor for Economic Development in New York City. Mr. Lipper, who wrote the first version of the screenplay, served from 1983 to 1985, not 1985 to 1987.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;Williams's Offense Is No Small Matter
description: When you first see Kevin Williams, he doesn't look like a professional football player. He is about 5 feet 9 inches tall and if he weighs 195 pounds, as the Cowboys news media guide says, then he must have an anchor tied around his neck.

title: Roger D. Foley, 78, Longtime U.S. Judge
description: Roger D. Foley, a former Federal judge who occasionally castigated prosecutors from the bench, died on Sunday at his home in Las Vegas, Nev. He was 78.

title: Journal;The Capital Gang
description: If there's one book certain to provoke Washington journalists to fisticuffs this year -- with each other, not with Bill Clinton -- it's "Breaking the News," an inside view of their own profession by one of their own kind. But don't expect its author, James Fallows, to be welcome as a guest on "The Capital Gang," "This Week With David Brinkley" or "Crossfire" as his book hits the stores this month.

title: THE 1996 ELECTION: THE IOWA DEBATE;Race Is Still a Blur, With a Month to Focus
description: The nun came to play "You Are My Sunshine" on her accordion before Senator Phil Gramm spoke at a chili supper in Dubuque on Thursday night. But that did not mean she supported his candidacy -- or anyone else's, for that matter.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COURT APPROVES OFFER FOR LOMAS FINANCIAL
description: First Nationwide Bank's $157.75 million offer for the Lomas Financial Corporation's mortgage servicing portfolio was approved by a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday. Lomas had filed for protection from creditors under bankruptcy law on Oct. 10. An objection to the sale could still be raised by the Pima County, Ariz., Industrial Authority at a hearing scheduled for Jan. 26.

title: Currency Plan For Hong Kong
description: The Hong Kong dollar will remain pegged to the United States dollar after Britain hands over the territory to China in 1997, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: Justices to Decide Legality Of Drug Property Seizures
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to settle a growing legal debate surrounding the Government's antidrug strategy: whether the Constitution permits prosecutors to seek both a criminal conviction for a narcotics violation and forfeiture of the defendant's property.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the naming of a Russian Foreign Minister referred incorrectly to his status. The appointee, Yevgeny M. Primakov, serves at the pleasure of President Boris N. Yeltsin and is not subject to confirmation by Parliament.

title: Gunman in Classroom Standoff Is Convicted
description: A man who held a college class at gunpoint was convicted yesterday by a jury that found him legally sane and responsible for his actions in less than two hours of deliberation.

title: Why Alter the Lyrics of Those Age-Old Hymns?
description: To the Editor:

title: Andrew McKinley, Versatile Tenor, 92
description: Andrew McKinley, an operatic tenor who also taught violin at the Juilliard School of Music and founded the Usdan Center for the Creative and Performing Arts in Huntington, L.I., died on Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 92 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Police Say They See a Link In Series of Gay Bar Robberies
description: The Police Department said yesterday that it had discerned a pattern in a series of armed robberies at gay bars in Manhattan and Queens in recent months, and gay advocates have cautioned patrons that they may be in danger.

title: Beware Cars That Want to Play Tag With You
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;OVERNIGHT SHIPPER SEES AN EARNINGS SLIP
description: The Federal Express Corporation, reeling from severe winter weather and a weak international package-delivery market, said late yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter earnings would be significantly below analysts' estimates. A snowstorm that shut down 18 airports in the Northeast early this week could mean a $20 million loss in revenue for the quarter ending Feb. 29, said the chief financial officer, Alan Graf. The company has incurred additional costs to deliver packages in the days since the storm, he said. The Northeast accounts for 25 percent to 30 percent of total delivery volume, Mr. Graf said. Analysts expected Federal Express to earn 98 cents a share in its third quarter, according to a survey of five analysts by Zacks Investment Research. In last year's fiscal third quarter, earnings were $1.12 a share.

title: The Unwinnable Chechen War
description: Thousands of Russian troops now surround a small band of hostage-holding Chechen guerrillas in a small town near the Chechen border. Each side clings to uncompromising positions. A bloody clash seems likely. In such circumstances military victory would be meaningless, and the biggest price would be paid by innocent civilians.

title: Corrections
description: The matchups chart in the sports pages yesterday for the National Football League conference championships carried an incorrect byline. The writer was Timothy W. Smith.

title: BASKETBALL;Celtics Can't Handle Ewing, Healthy or Not
description: He said he still is not 100 percent, but as Patrick Ewing kept pouring in points and rejecting shots by the Boston Celtics back to the Fleet Center floor, one had to wonder what a full recovery would mean.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Units Drop in Heavy Trading
description: Units of Eurotunnel S.A., the British-French Channel tunnel operator, fell yesterday in heavy trading after France and Britain rejected the debt-ridden company's appeal for help. Eurotunnel units -- the equivalent of one share in Eurotunnel and one in its British sister company -- fell to 6.05 francs ($1.20), down 30 centimes, with 2.6 million units changing hands on the Paris Bourse.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RETAILER TO CLOSE 17 STORES AND CUT 71 JOBS
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. reported sharply lower December profits yesterday and said it would close 17 underperforming stores by early March and eliminate 71 jobs at its headquarters in Rocky Hill, Conn. The discount retailer, which operates 307 stores in 14 Northeastern states, said it would take a $20 million charge in the fourth quarter to pay for the cost-cutting measures. Ames said its profits fell to $30.4 million for the five weeks ended Dec. 30 from $34.6 million in the corresponding period in 1994. But the company said this was better than the $28.6 million that it had expected.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;A 2d Suitor Is Pursuing Maybelline
description: A German cosmetics company indicated yesterday that it wanted to offer a "materially higher" bid for Maybelline Inc., the American cosmetics company that recently agreed to a $660 million takeover offer from L'Oreal S.A. of France.

title: In Finland, an EU Aide's Salary Goes Over the Top
description: BRUSSELS  Call it a testament to Europe's economic and social disparity. Or perhaps to the ability of Europe's bureaucracy to attract controversy.

title: Snowfall Profiteering: There Ought to Be a Law

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;A Danger for the Frail
description: Last weekend's blizzard contributed to at least 34 deaths in New Jersey, the A.P. reported yesterday after surveying county medical examiners. Half of the deaths were attributed to shoveling; four people froze to death, three had heart attacks while out in the cold, and one died from a car accident. "Each time you shovel, it is like lifting and moving at least 15 pounds," Sindy Paul, state senior public health physician, said. "This is not an exercise program for people at this age."

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEXGEN SEES A QUARTERLY LOSS OF AT LEAST $25 MILLION
description: Citing price pressures in the semiconductor market and a substantial inventory write-off, Nexgen Inc. said yesterday that it would post a loss in the quarter that ended in December. The company, which is merging with Advanced Micro Devices Inc., said the loss would be at least $25 million to $30 million and could top $50 million. During the quarter that ended in September, the company reported a loss of $20.5 million. Year-ago figures are not available because Nexgen was a private company until last May.

title: S.& P. Lowers Kmart Bond Rating to Junk Status
description: Standard & Poor's lowered the Kmart Corporation's bond rating to junk status today, a move the retailer said was "excessively severe" but unlikely to cause any immediate cash problems.

title: Rig Count Falls by 7
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States dropped by 7 this week, to 704, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. In the corresponding week a year ago, there were 757 rigs operating nationwide. Of the rigs running this week, 406 were exploring for natural gas and 290 for oil. Eight rigs were listed as miscellaneous. The rig count represents the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and natural gas.

title: Liz Williamson, 76, Jazz Dance Authority

title: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;2 Teams' Opposite Directions
description: The Rangers and the Devils, winners of the last two Stanley Cups, traveled to Philadelphia and Boston, respectively, yesterday, heading in opposite directions geographically as well as figuratively. Both teams play matinees today.

title: FILM REVIEW;Questions, Questions: 'Are You My Daddy?'
description: Slap the plots and characters of "Boyz N the Hood" and "Menace to Society" into a frying pan, heat to a high sizzle, then spray with laughing gas and you get "Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood," a free-for-all comic spoof that brings the "hood" genre of Hollywood films full circle. Crude and chaotic, the movie stridently stands every serious theme and anguished emotion from those two groundbreaking films on its ear.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HERCULES TO BUY BACK MILLIONS OF ADDED SHARES

The company, a specialty chemicals maker, said that in the last five years it had authorized the buyback of as many as 48 million shares. To date the company has bought nearly 47 million of those shares. Hercules now has about 110 million shares outstanding, according to a company spokeswoman. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Hercules closed up 62.5 cents at $56.25.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NEWMONT RAISES $250 MILLION IN STOCK SALE
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation said yesterday that it had sold 4.65 million shares for $53.75 each to raise $250 million to develop its mining projects. Newmont Mining, which is based in Denver, will pass the proceeds on to its main operating unit, the Newmont Gold Company, by purchasing 4.65 million of the unit's shares. Newmont Mining shares fell $2.50, to close at $51.25, with almost six million shares changing hands. Newmont Gold shares closed down $1.625 at $50.375. "That's to be expected when that much goes on the market at once," said Doug Hock, a Newmont spokesman. Newmont sold the shares to Salomon Brothers Inc. of New York, which in turn sold them to investors. Salomon's head of trading, Terry Fitzgerald, said the entire offer was sold in two hours.

title: Doomed in Bombay
description: THE MOOR'S LAST SIGH By Salman Rushdie. 435 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $25. SALMAN RUSHDIE'S new novel, his first since the infamous fatwa issued by the Iranian Government in 1989 as punishment for putatively blasphemous passages in his satire "The Satanic Verses," comes heavily attended by certain inevitable questions. How is Mr. Rushdie holding up after six years in hiding? What kind of story is the world's most famous living author, in this extraordinary situation, going to tell us and, of course, himself? Is this another book that will give offense, and to whom? Will this book comment, directly or otherwise, on the dogma-driven expansion of censorship and persecution affecting writers in so many parts of the world? It's only when we've worked through this vanguard of questions that we're free to ask what we can take from this novel, as opposed to all the novels it competes with -- serious novels whose ambitions are to show us what we urgently need to know or feel in this threatening moment, when alarms and grim forewarnings crowd in on us, making so many of our innocent pastimes feel difficult to justify, fiction reading itself not excepted.

title: Corrections
description: An article about Malawi on Dec. 31 referred incorrectly to the safety of Lake Malawi. An epidemiological investigation conducted in 1993 by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that the lake was not free of the parasitic infection schistosomiasis, also known as bilharzia. Of the 1,000 resident expatriates and travelers in Malawi who had swum in the lake and were given blood tests, the C.D.C. found, 33 percent had evidence of infection.

title: What Makes a Woman a Woman
description: "FEMINISM IS NOT THE STORY OF MY LIFE" How Today's Feminist Elite Has Lost Touch With the Real Concerns of Women. By Elizabeth Fox-Genovese. 275 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $23.95. WHEN we last left Elizabeth Fox-Genovese, at the end of "Feminism Without Illusions," she was deploring people who "find it easy to blame feminism for some of the most disturbing aspects of modern life: divorce, latchkey children, teen-age alcoholism, domestic violence, the sexual abuse of children." Five years later, it seems she has become one of the people she warned us about. It seems she's had a conversion experience.

A brasserie, on the other hand, is more of a destination. It is louder and showier than a bistro, and its ambiance is dependent on the crowd that is there at any given moment. It is a place you can go to be completely alone or deeply intimate with strangers.

Some days she seems more frail than others, and it is on these melancholy days that she begins to muse. Her eyes fill with doubt and she says things like: "Why? Why are the scientists breaking their brains to get us to live longer? I want to know, what's the point?"

For generations of students before her, research meant spending hours getting acquainted with encyclopedias and the Dewey decimal system of library classification. But all Ms. Lund required to get started was a jaunt through the World Wide Web.

But they also call her a "dreaming," "boundless" "pure beauty" and "goddess." Which raises the questions: Just who was Nico? And, in the 49 years she lived, did anybody really know her?

Deem's favorite mummy stories is of grave robbers in the 1800's in Egypt who opened a tomb, found a large jar of preserved honey and, hungry, began to dip their bread into it. Only after a few swallows, did they notice hair in the jar, and eventually the preserved body of a tiny child. The robbers, said Mr. Deem, "got their just desserts."

It serves "snacks," or, if the flight is long enough and covers a meal period, "substantial snacks." But, according to Karla Villalon, a spokeswoman, "We're not calling them meals."

But this Portuguese colony, on the south China coast about 40 miles from Hong Kong and preparing to revert, with Hong Kong, to Chinese sovereignty in 1999, has something new designed to lure visitors and business travelers: the Macao International Airport.

No one needs AOL (or Compuserve or MSN) because no one really needs the services they peddle: the "chat" groups that have taken over where the CB radio fad of the 1970's left off; the superficial "news"; the games that no kid with a Nintendo will bother with once the novelty wears off.

title: A Snowstorm Alters Life's Rhythms

title: Bangladesh Facing an Election Crisis
description: This South Asian country of 120 million people faces a deadline next week that may determine whether the shaky parliamentary democracy that has prevailed for the last five years continues or yields once more to the autocracy, military rule and political violence that have been Bangladesh's lot for 15 of its 25 years as an independent country.

title: Attack of the Microbiologists
description: In a lab at the University of Massachusetts in Amherst, Arthromitus bacteria, fungi, slime molds and the fossilized remains of 2-billion-year-old microorganisms surround the biologist Lynn Margulis. It's lunch time and she slides a petri dish aside to unpack a container of homemade soup. Here in germ microbe, a setting that would make the Future Homemakers of America flee in horror, Margulis, 44, calmly halves bagels with a knife that she has wiped on her black slacks. "There are no TB cultures here, no pathogens," she shrugs. No, but there are four-inch-long flying cockroaches in terrariums, the carcass of a Madagascan fire millipede above the microwave oven and several cubic inches of termites, whose hindguts Margulis will later slice up to study under a microscope.

description: From Alfred Kazin to the Hermitage.

title: JANUARY 7-13;Report Shows Setbacks For Women Lawyers
description: In less time than it takes to resolve some lawsuits, women lawyers have swept from near invisibility to national prominence. But bias against women still pervades the legal profession, an American Bar Association panel said in a report last week, citing steep gender disparities in pay, promotion and power. The problem is a sticky floor as much as a glass ceiling: The income gender gap opens up within the first year of practice, and among top legal officers of corporations ranges as high as 35 percent. And tougher times for lawyers have meant fresh setbacks for women. From law schools, where nearly half the students are female but the faculty remains overwhelmingly male, come reports that the performance of some women is suffering because of a resurgence of overt male hostility. In law firms, women's already lower rates of promotion to partner have dropped more sharply than men's in the recessionary 1990's.

Tapped last year for a new program to interest black and Hispanic students in becoming teachers, the Yorktown High School 11th grader has surprised himself with his own talents and won a bevy of fans.

Australia is a famously casual country, but it does have its share of grand dining experiences, and at these three restaurants in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide, the anticipation is handsomely rewarded.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;Faces of Brazil
description: In the mid-1930's, a young French ethnographer named Claude Levi-Strauss ventured by rail, truck, canoe and horseback into the Brazilian interior to document the cultural habits of tribal groups whose numbers and customs were still somewhat protected by their relative isolation. Equipped with a Leica and "an oval-shaped miniature 8-mm. camera whose name I have forgotten," the anthropologist, feeling ambivalent about the use of photography in such a setting, nonetheless created a rare visual record of archery contests, funeral rites, face painting and other traditional customs, some of which have long since been abandoned. The photographs of the Nambikwara, the Bororo and the Caduveo form the centerpiece of Mr. Levi-Strauss's SAUDADES DO BRASIL: A Photographic Memoir (University of Washington, $39.95), skillfully translated from the French by Sylvia Modelski. There are also images of Sao Paulo in the 1930's when it was a frontier city of "singular beauty" and not yet one of the industrial capitals in the world, and of pristine Brazilian landscapes that now, in large or small part, bear the scars of mining and logging as well as other ravages of modernization. The reader might be surprised at the remarkable, if rueful, candor with which the renowned anthropologist introduces the volume: "The photographs leave me with the impression of a void, a lack of something the lens is inherently unable to capture." Although Mr. Levi-Strauss, a chief architect of structural anthropology, declares that he is not a photographer, "not even an amateur," the images here are skillful and compelling. But it is not the quality of the photographs he is apologizing for; it is history. And his apology is not directed at us so much as at the ghosts of his tribal subjects, "the last escapees from the cataclysm" of European colonialism and its aftermath. SUZANNE MacNEILLE

title: Missed By Snow, A Trucking Firm Still Got Stuck
description: For most Midwesterners, the snowstorms that have slammed the East are someone else's problem. But those distant storms have made nearly as vivid an impression here at the headquarters of Schneider National, one of the nation's biggest trucking firms, as if they had actually roared through this thoroughly winterized northeastern corner of Wisconsin.

title: JANUARY 7-13;Teen-agers Adapting To a Fear of Crime
description: When people think of teen-agers and crime, the context is usually that of youthful offenders. But a study released last week served as a reminder that those most vulnerable to and affected by crime and violence are teen-agers themselves. A poll of 2,000 teen-agers around the country conducted by Louis Harris & Associates found that 1 in 8 youths -- and almost 2 in 5 in high-crime neighborhoods -- report carrying a weapon for protection. Almost half said they had changed behaviors -- from changing groups of friends to avoiding parks to missing school -- as a reaction to fears of crime. Teen-agers overwhelmingly said they were willing and eager to take part in activities or programs aimed at combatting crime. The poll served as another reminder that, if the transition from childhood to adulthood has never been easy, it is especially difficult now. PETER APPLEBOME

description: Besides the usual hazards of driving a rental car in a strange city (fiddling with unfamiliar switches, trying to read a map while driving), there is the distraction of twisting the radio dial to find the right kind of music.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE;A Pledge of Homes, Half Kept
description: When a failed co-op building in Park Slope was scooped up in 1994 by a nonprofit agency to house the mentally ill, it was the target of vociferous protest by neighborhood residents and local politicians. But then a compromise was reached: half the apartments were to be occupied by mentally ill men and women, and the other half was to be turned over to the city for subsidized low-income housing.

title: A Sleuth Gets His Suspect: Shakespeare
description: Back in 1983, when he was working toward his doctoral degree, Donald Foster came across a little-known Elizabethan elegy, bound as a 21-page pamphlet and stored in the Bodleian Library at Oxford. The printing was done in 1612 by Shakespeare's publisher. The text itself referred to the author as a successful poet. And it was signed with initials: W. S.

title: MUSIC;Classical Guitarists In Recital
description: WOMEN of the guitar and men of the keyboard shine in several concerts this week. This afternoon at 2 the Connecticut Classical Guitar Society is offering a program of music, film and visual arts devoted to "Women and Their Guitars."

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;American Originals
description: Tired? Bored? Is the monotony of everyday life leaving you dead? HOLDING ON (Norton, $25), a collection of profiles of more than 50 American characters, will either cheerfully remind you that somewhere creative people pursue offbeat passions or leave you annoyed that you are not among them. Take Robert Shields, the author of the world's longest diary, a minute-by-minute account that comprises more than 34 million words; or Dewey Chafin, a snake handler in West Virginia who says, "Why I do it is because the Bible says to do it, and that's just the bottom line." Many of the people interviewed in "Holding On" are included not because of their personal peculiarities but because they are walking and (thankfully) talking bearers of history -- like Sylvia (Ray) Rivera, a drag queen, and Seymour Pine, a retired police officer, who faced off against each other at the 1969 Stonewall riots; or Geneva Tisdale, a cook at the Woolworth's lunch counter in Greensboro, N.C., who recalls the student sit-ins there in 1960. The radio producer David Isay, who wrote the text, and Harvey Wang, who took the photographs, respect the distinctive lives they document in the book. As the novelist Henry Roth says in his foreword: "Exercising creativity helps us preserve one of our proudest, most noble, most precious possessions: dignity. As far as I'm concerned, dead, it doesn't matter whether we did or didn't preserve it. Comes to the same thing. . . . We're talking about being alive." ALEXANDRA HALL

title: JESUS BEFORE HE COULD TALK
description: Miles's article on the infant Jesus was so elegantly and intelligently written that I am constrained to write you in thanks for making it a centerpiece of your Christmas issue. More focus by the Magazine on such scholarly and fetching religious matters would be greatly welcomed.

title: Hotels, Hotels
description: To the Editor: "Shifting Rates of Hotel Rooms" by Suzanne Carmichael (Dec. 10) brought to mind a recent incident. Annually, for almost 20 years, I have stayed four or five days at the Breidenbacher Hof in Dusseldorf, now part of the Rafael chain. In May, I sent a fax requesting a double room for four nights beginning June 2, adding that I looked forward to returning to the hotel. I received a faxed confirmation quoting a daily rate of 520 German marks -- $385 at the time, with the mark at 1.35 to the dollar -- "instead of 610" with a notation that the hotel looked forward to welcoming me again.

title: A PARK OF HISTORY AND POETRY
description: SEVENTY years ago, on Australia's Snowy Plain midway between Sydney and Melbourne, stood a lone weatherboard hut amid glowing spinifex grass and twisting gum trees. Davey Williamson spent his summers there along with his wife, children, some rabbits and a whole lot of cows, just around the bend from craggy Mount Kosciusko. Other settlers followed, and watched their cows grow fat on the land after each lean, cold winter.

title: COPING;My Neighbor and His Renter's Sensibility

But he isn't really there anyway, so it probably doesn't matter. Sometimes I think I could collapse in the elevator and he would say, "Hey, howareya," as he stepped over me and out the door. This is not to say the Shadow is a bad guy. I have no idea. He's just a shadowy neighbor.

Where are those heady nights on Beekman Place, those working days on lower Fifth, those underpaid trust-fun girls with the clacking Smith-coronas and the clicking low-heeled pumps from I. Miller? Where are Bennet Cerf's entrepreneurial seeds, Maxwell Perkins's worshipful authors, Mary McCarthy's well-red bedfellows? Where are the editorial assistants lunching frenetically at the Oyster Bar counter? Where are the pneumatic tubes running directly from Vassar and Smith to Viking and Scribners, sucking young English majors down their channels and depositing them at chewed wooden desks with tins of lemon drops in the top drawers and manuscripts towering over the "in" boxes? Alas, lament entry levelers everywhere, the 30's are gone. So are the 40's, 50's, 60's and 70's for that matter.

title: Sunday January 14, 1996: SIC TRANSIT GLORIA;The El's Distant Rumble
description: The most ideal way of getting about in the world" was how one character in a novel by William Dean Howells described the Third Avenue El in 1890. Peering into the tenement windows along the route, another opined, "was better than theater." The El was completed in just 14 months, opening in 1878, but its clackety-clack outlasted Manhattan's other three elevateds, which were mostly abandoned by 1940 in the name of progress. (The Sixth Avenue El underwent an unfortunate reincarnation, its steel having been sold as scrap to Japan in the late 30's.) A canopy formed by the Third Avenue El's spindly girders plunged the pubs and antiques stores below into perpetual twilight. Its tracks could not accommodate the newer (and faster) trains, but the El continued to rumble until 1955, when Ann Shanks preserved its final months with these and other vivid photographs that will be exhibited at the New York Transit Museum in Brooklyn from Jan. 21 through March 24. At the El's demise, its replacement by a new Second Avenue line seemed assured. It wasn't. Only a mile of the Second Avenue subway was bored before the city ran out of money in the mid-70's, though the tunnels are still maintained because they help support Second Avenue. Meanwhile, a task force charged with improving mass transit on the East Side has been exploring, among other possibilities, a new elevated line.

title: SPOTLIGHT;A Gothic Romance
description: In 1847 Charlotte Bronte introduced a new kind of hero and heroine to English fiction with JANE EYRE. Her tale of a shy and intense orphan who becomes a governess in a mysterious Victorian household is told with particularly romantic extravagance in Robert Stevenson's 1944 film version -- WEDNESDAY at 10 P.M. and WEDNESDAY-THURSDAY at 2 A.M. on AMC. Orson Welles presents the torrured Rochester as a man of studies arrogance. Joan Fontaine plays the grown Jane, with Peggy Ann Garner ("A Tree Grows in Brooklyn") as the child. Rounding out the cast are Margaret O'Brien, Agnes Moorehead and Henry Daniell.

What really distinguishes the 777 from its smaller, older siblings, according to Karl Sabbagh's "21st-Century Jet: The Making and Marketing of the Boeing 777," is the manner of its gestation and birth.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ARISTOCRATS: Caroline, Emily, Louisa, and Sarah Lennox, 1740-1832 By Stella Tillyard. Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $16. Women's part in history was often enacted in the wings, but this author has moved it center stage in her story of the daughters of a powerful British duke. Drawing on their correspondence, she shows that their lives, though largely domestic, were nonetheless dramatic. She "has devised a form of history in which character has the depth of fiction," Lyndall Gordon said here in 1994.

title: 42d Street Diner Seeks a Place at the Table
description: The air is redolent of hot grease as the burgers sizzle on the old grill. A tattered sign says not to let the door slam, but everyone does. Another implores "No Spitting." People greet one another, inquiring about health and mutual acquaintances.

title: BASKETBALL;Richmond Lights Up The Knicks In Fourth
description: Don Nelson, who once traded Mitch Richmond away, was asked how many different defenders he used to try to stop the most accomplished shooting guard west of Chicago last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Space Shuttle Snatches Craft From Its Orbit
description: The space shuttle Endeavour's astronauts captured a four-ton Japanese science satellite today but only after trouble with the satellite's two solar panels prompted ground controllers to jettison them.

title: Commercial Property/Looking Back, and Ahead;Outlook: Cloudy, With Silver Linings
description: BACK when 1994 was ending, any real-estate executive predicting a less than stellar 1995 was drowned out by the sound of champagne corks popping, as a euphoric industry toasted the end of five years of woe.

title: FILM: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Two on the Lam (Plus a Matisse)
