description: YOU'RE SOMEONE SPECIAL

title: Concert Thrives In Hard Times
description: THERE was an atmosphere of pride and elation at Pepsico here one recent morning when representatives of 17 social service groups met to discuss MusicAmerica IV. The concert, to be presented Friday at 8 P.M. by the Westchester Philharmonic at the Performing Arts Center of Purchase College, will benefit the 17 groups.

title: FILM: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Two on the Lam (Plus a Matisse)
description: Two if by Sea Denis Leary, Sandra Bullock, Yaphet Kotto, Stephen Dillane Directed by Bill Bennett R 97 minutes

title: THEATER: SUNDAY VIEW;Tapping the Funny Bone of American Comics
description: CULTURES ARE AS PSYCHOLOGICALLY recalcitrant as individuals; generation after generation (instead of year after year) they display the same traits; adapted, reshaded, newly proportioned, but indelible and intransigent.

title: For Many Japanese, Changes in the Government Seem to Bring No RealChange
description: As the Japanese political system tries to absorb its eighth Prime Minister in seven years, the biggest challenge in the long run may come from unassuming young people like Kumiko Uematsu.

title: Budget Crisis' Defined
description: The stalled negotiations over the Federal budget run the risk of creating significant instability in the financial markets.

title: In Kansas and Elsewhere, G.O.P. Freshmen Face the Music, Sweet andShrill: Washington; The Right Place For a Maverick
description: As one of only 17 members of Congress to vote against reopening the Government after budget talks failed a week ago, Representative Linda Smith would seem likely to have a district-full of questions to face at home.

title: Internet Hate Speech Shouldn't Be Banned
description: To the Editor:

title: Does a Sugar Bear Bite?
description: Suge Knight, the 29-year-old C.E.O. of Death Row Records, nearly always wears a large diamond-and-ruby ring that spells M.O.B. When you ask him what the letters stand for, he says, "M . . . O . . . B." "M-O-B?" you repeat. Suge (pronounced shug, as in sugar, as in Sugar Bear, his childhood nickname) is a big man -- 6 foot 4, about 315 pounds. But he has the face of a cherub and a soft, almost musical voice. He replies again, "M.O.B." He will not explain. He assumes you will understand.

title: Press Faces Repression In Africa
description: When this country opened the way for an independent press at the turn of the decade, the blossoming of newspapers of nearly every political persuasion was widely hailed as a critical stepping stone toward true multiparty democracy.

title: IN THE MUSLIM CITY OF BETHLEHEM
description: Anyone who is bewildered as to why the land of Israel is being taken away from the Jewish people need look no further than to the author of this article: a Jew who fondly recalls his childhood Christmas trees and then lights a taper in the Church of the Nativity.

title: WEDDINGS;Lisa T. Tawil, Jonathan Kolodny
description: Lisa Tina Tawil, the daughter of Nancy and Moise Tawil of London, is to be married today to Jonathan Avram Kolodny, the son of Dr. Nancy Kolodny and Dr. Gerald Kolodny of West Newton, Mass. Rabbi Aharon Bina is to perform the ceremony at the Western Marble Arch Synagogue in London.

title: Who Are the Real Perverts?
description: FETISH Fashion, Sex and Power. By Valerie Steele. Illustrated. 243 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35. PEOPLE think "the pervert is always someone else," Valerie Steele writes. But only some of them are right.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Hmm . . . Salaries Are Unchanged
description: In trying to determine the direction salaries have taken this off season, consider the raise Al Leiter received in moving from the Toronto Blue Jays to the Florida Marlins, $795,000 for one year to $8.6 million for three years. On the other hand, consider the cut Jose Oquendo took in remaining with the St. Louis Cardinals, from a four-year, $8.5 million contract to a minor league contract that will pay him $250,000 in the majors.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: MOTT HAVEN Day of Celebration For a Dominican Legend

title: Where Sydney Turns Victorian
description: SO great is the pull of Sydney's harbor that visitors might never think to venture away from the high-rises and landmarks and shopping of the central business district, and toward the innumerable ridges and valleys that make up this city of nearly four million. The onetime shantytown whose first residents were convicts, and their guards, has since acquired a distinct, even elegant style of architecture that adapts European elements to the very different Australian temperament.

title: Hotels, Hotels
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Margo Kaufman's article "Bells and Whistles in the Bathroom" (Dec. 10) about the range and creativity of bathroom amenities. I think one of our recent experiences tops hers. In Zurich, we found in our charming bathroom basket of soap, shampoo, bubble bath, shower cap, etc. -- a supply of condoms! Now, that's what I call thoughtful.

title: Kenneth Owen Jones, 77, Presbyterian Minister
description: The Rev. Kenneth Owen Jones, a longtime minister at New York's largest Presbyterian church who was particularly noted for his devotion to his parishioners, died of a heart attack in his office on Jan. 7. He was 77.

title: SOAPBOX;Why Do Dogs Love Snow?
description: IN the heat of July two years ago I walked into a pet shop in Manhattan. Like everyone else in the store, I had no intention of buying a dog. I just wanted to look.

title: GOVERNMENT;Road Proposal Carries A Cargo of Controversy
description: As road projects go, it is a small one: a five-mile, $30 million bypass that would divert traffic from Ringwood Avenue, the only north-south route in this quiet residential borough along the east bank of the Wanaque Reservoir.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS;Of Pinpoints and Cameras: The Science of Vermeer's Art
description: THERE is an extraordinary hush in the packed rooms of the National Gallery of Art where the first Vermeer exhibition in history has been holding its own against Government shutdowns and blizzards. To look at these 21 paintings of the 17th century Dutch artist, even in the midst of a crowd, is to be drawn into a private realm. A woman in blue is silently absorbed in reading a letter by the window. Another woman, her head reverentially draped in white cloth, delicately holds a miniature balance by the tip of her fingers and is poised in reflection. A third gazes into a mirror, frozen in dreamy repose, as she admires her pearl necklace. A viewer is almost embarrassed, as if intruding on some intimacy, disrupting a slender instant of time captured by an act of painterly photography.

title: Oscar, You're Being Upstaged (Again)
description: WHEN MOVIE STARS gather, there is a potential television audience. That simple equation has brought the Golden Globe Awards ceremony, a celebrity-studded bash that previously appeared on TBS, to the attention of NBC. And so, for the first time, NBC will broadcast the three-hour ceremony, live, at 8 P.M. next Sunday.

title: POP MUSIC: Three Women and Their Journeys in Song;A Poet With a Piano, And a Lot of Bravado
description: SINCE I WAS A LITTLE GIRL, I've been a musician first," says Tori Amos, who is about to release her most musically adventurous album yet. "I wasn't just an extension of the piano; I was the piano. That's how people looked at me."

title: FOOD;Legume Soups to Chase the Cold
description: SOUPS made from legumes like dried beans or lentils make warm, filling meals for a cold day. And one way to get your quota of green vegetables as well is to do as the Italians do and swirl them into the soup just before serving it.

title: Cheers for Cautious Saving
description: To the Editor:

title: West Didn't Fail Russian Market Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BLIZZARD OF 1996: A Winter Wonderland Wears Thin;Age-Old Woe: Getting Rid Of the Snow
description: Times change, but the task of cleaning up after a snowstorm remains as daunting as ever. Historical photographs show some of the contraptions tried by previous generations of New Yorkers.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;The Guides' Guide, Champion of Truth in Touring
description: New York's 700 licensed tour guides are often looked upon as little more than frustrated actors who dispense soporific, sometimes specious information to hapless tourists.

title: Hotels, Hotels
description: To the Editor: Ms. Carmichael reported an inconsistency in Hyatt's quoted room rates. I would like to assure readers that Hyatt Hotels Corporation policy is always to quote the same rates in inquiries made to either the hotel or our central reservation office. Room rates are set at the local hotel and then entered into hotel and central reservations computers simultaneously.

title: BASEBALL;Marlins Sign Cuban Pitcher
description: The Florida Marlins, playing in an area that is home to the largest Cuban population outside Cuba, won the race for a 20-year-old Cuban pitcher yesterday, agreeing to pay him a record $2.5 million signing bonus in a four-year major league contract worth $4.5 million.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;Reminiscing With Dr. Aubrey Maynard: On Saving Dr. King
description: On Sept. 20, 1958, Martin Luther King Jr. was at Blumstein's Department Store on 125th Street signing copies of his new book, "Stride Toward Freedom," when a woman lunged toward him and stabbed him in the chest with a letter opener. He was rushed to Harlem Hospital, where a surgeon named Dr. Aubre Maynard saved his life. In an interview , Dr. Maynard, who is 94 and lives on the Lower East Side, recalled the day:

title: In Israel, Fertile Ground For Foreign Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: The Triumph of Liberalism
description: THE AMERICA I HEARD SINGING WHEN I WAS a teen-ager in the late 1950's forced homosexuals into hiding, ignored or derided the disabled, withheld rights from suspects of crimes and kept women in their place, which was usually the kitchen and sometimes an abortionist's back room. It foisted prayers on schoolchildren, paid no attention to the health needs of the impoverished or the elderly, endangered endangered species and threw people out of work because they held an un-American ideology. In certain places, it denied black Americans the right to sit where they wished to on a public bus, to drink from a public water fountain, to eat in restaurants, stay in hotels, go to public schools with whites or vote.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER U.S. Tops Trinidad Joe-Max Moore's free kick in the second half gave the United States a 3-2 victory over Trinidad and Tobago in the Concacaf Gold Cup soccer tournament in Anaheim, Calif., yesterday.

title: Angry, and We're Not Going to Take It Anymore
description: To the Editor:

title: The Big City;Save the Flophouses
description: ON A BITTERLY COLD NIGHT IN December, I went down to the Bowery to see what kind of accommodations were available in the old flophouses. A woozy man on the corner of Houston Street directed me to a few -- the Sunshine, the Andrews and the Prince -- where a bed ranged from $5 to $12, but there were no vacancies. Finally, at another grandly named institution, the White House Hotel, on the Bowery near Bond Street, the clerk behind the cage at the front desk looked me over and nodded.

title: Francisco Ahumada, Student, 12
description: Francisco Ahumada, whose 18-month illness prompted many expressions of charity in his Long Island community, died Jan. 6 at Nassau County Medical Center, where he had been treated for cancer. He was 12.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 10 about the pressures faced by college football players misstated the legal status of a University of Nebraska player who pleaded no contest to misdemeanor assault and trespassing charges. The player, who was not named in the article, was sentenced to a year of probation and ordered to attend a domestic-violence prevention class, and to pay restitution fees. He is not awaiting sentencing. The sentence was handed down after the article was prepared for publication, but before the Magazine was published.

title: The Tenacity of Pain
description: A WOMAN IN AMBER Healing the Trauma of War and Exile. By Agate Nesaule. 280 pp. New York: Soho Press. $24. IT is now over 50 years since the end of World War II in Europe, but the survival stories keep coming as if they were breaking news. In a way, they are. The deprivations and dislocations in Eastern Europe in particular have sattered so many national and ethnic groups that the mosaic of misery is still being assembled.

title: Correction: A Retirement Portfolio
description: A table last Sunday in the Mutual Funds Quarterly Report, listing five model retirement portfolios, did not include revisions for the first quarter by Eric M. Kobren. He is dropping Fidelity Canada from his portfolio, which contains Fidelity funds exclusively. Citing a prefernce for growth and small stocks, especially in the finance and health care industries, and an interest in Japan, Mr. Kobren is adding the Pacific Basin and Small-Cap Stock funds.

title: Liberties;The State of the Fish
description: During the '92 campaign, I had dinner with Hillary Clinton at a revolving restaurant in Kentucky. (She had not yet revolved into Hillary Rodham Clinton.) She ordered a glass of white wine with an auspicious appellation -- the White House.

title: It's a Long Trip to the Orchestra Pit
description: THEY go to more Broadway shows each year than just about anyone else, yet they never get to see what is happening on stage. They are the Broadway musicians, and their view from the orchestra pit gives them an interesting perspective.

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: Literally and figuratively, movies strut their stuff this week in a lineup that boasts brass bands and golden Oscars in numbers almost sufficient for a baseball team.

title: VIEWS;It Isn't the Main Event, but for These Boxers, It's 9 Rounds in the Limelight
description: THROUGH a smoky haze and a hum of voices, the ring announcer yells out the names of two journeyman boxers. This is it. The big time. The lights, the glitter, the dream. And the money -- for most of the boxers, a purse of $500.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Heavy D, the C.E.O.
description: LIKE any business, the hip-hop world has its particular way of doing things, its own rites and rituals. The product -- the newest sound, the right mix -- can be found in the long link of relationships found on street corners, basketball courts, parties, pool halls, basements and clubs. Blood ties help. Producers and scouts are towering figures. They are inundated with cassettes and stopped on the street by aspiring artists begging them to listen to their tapes. Pager numbers are coveted.

title: Japanese Suicide Linked To Nuclear Plant Leak
description: The official in charge of investigating a possible cover-up of Japan's worst nuclear power accident committed suicide today by jumping from the roof of a Tokyo hotel, the police said.

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;The Jackie Onassis Trust, and a Variation on It
description: Q. If Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis was able to leave money to her children tax free, why can't I do the same? Margaret Trumbell Columbus, Ohio

title: BENEFITS
description: For the Urban League TODAY -- The New York Urban League will benefit from a reception at the Plaza Hotel from 11:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tickets, $125 at the door. Information: (212) 926-8000, extension 77.

title: THE WORLD;In Peru, Un-American Justice
description: WHEN Lori Helene Berenson was convicted of treason in Peru last week and sentenced to life in prison for her association with Marxist terrorists, the reaction in the United States held to an American principle: the conviction should not stand because the New York woman, guilty or innocent, did not receive a fair, open trial.

title: STONE-FACED
description: Thanks for the beautiful article on John Yang's photographs of the stone faces that decorate the buildings and brownstones in New York ("Stone-Faced," by Julie V. Iovine, Dec. 24). It is so fitting for this time of year -- and just generally a delight.

title: L.I. VINES
description: Select Reserve Palmer Vineyards, Aquebogue, 1991. About $20.

title: WHO NEEDS AMERICA ONLINE?
description: Does Ted Leonsis truly believe that "when you go to a cocktail party and America Online diskettes are being used as coasters, you know you've become mainstream"? I get about four mailings a year, with one or two diskettes, from America Online, likewise from Compuserve and Prodigy. Sometimes the diskettes are inserted into magazines. I don't even know which recycling bin to use to discard this item of junk mail. It seems to me that the party givers are being more innovative than just going "mainstream." Leonsis should take a lesson.

description: Music

description: Advocates for American Indians in Montana filed a lawsuit on Friday contending that the state's new legislative districts dilute Indians' voting power.

description: We have patients who are being born. You can't stop that."

title: Cholera Vaccine
description: To The Editor: In "Uganda Struggles Back" (Dec. 31) Jonathan Black says that travelers to Uganda "will need" cholera vaccinations. However, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the World Health Organization do not recommend routine cholera vaccination for travelers to any country, and neither Uganda nor any other African country requires cholera vaccination for entry.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Buenos Aires Gets A Cultural Center
description: The Centro Cultural Borges, housed in four wings of the 1889 Galerias Pacifico, opened in Buenos Aires in October. The building, which also houses an upscale shopping mall, underwent extensive renovation.

title: THE NATION;Why a Budget Deal Isn't Really a Big Deal
description: SO go figure: For more years than anyone can remember, Wall Street has been screaming that America's budget deficit is dangerously high, and the only way to save the nation from financial ruin -- and high interest rates -- is to balance the budget.

title: GARDENING;The Many Faces of the Ubiquitos Begonia
description: THE begonia appetite can be insatiable. It forms with a plant collector when he or she gets beyond simple introductions and learns that there are 1,000 or more true species in the family. Not to mention the thousands of hybrids that magnify the challenge of trying to create a representative, never mind inclusive, sampling.

title: BASKETBALL;Now Nets Are Crumbling On Their Own Court, Too
description: Desperate teams are prone to take desperate measures, and right now the Nets are a desperate team. That's why Chris Childs, a reserve guard, stepped forward tonight after the Nets lost their second straight game -- this one by 91-80 to the Detroit Pistons -- and suggested that the players hold a team meeting on Monday morning.

title: Angry, and We're Not Going to Take It Anymore
description: To the Editor:

title: COVER STORY;An Austen Tale of Sex and Money In Which Girls Kick Up Their Heels
description: William Bennett, take heart. Jane Austen has displaced Joe Eszterhas as the hottest script factory in the entertainment industry. Last year, without benefit of a single nude scene or sizzling lesbian smooch, "Sense and Sensibility" and "Persuasion" whipped "Jade" and "Showgirls." This year, Austen rolls on with a three-part "Pride and Prejudice" that begins tonight at 8 on A&E.

title: IN BRIEF;A Coalition Helps Lakewood Bind Accident Wounds
description: An accident that happened in Lakewood nine months ago could have torn the community apart, but a group that took shape in the aftermath now seems to be pulling it together.

title: Car-Pool Tales
description: Car poolers sail on the highways of commerce. Like real seafarers, they can veer off course, start mutinies, follow their own odd rules of conduct and even engage in hostile action against other vessels. If you have a story of car-pool adventure -- whether the Love Boat or the Titanic -- send it to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send it by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Sports of The Times;Unitas and Company Sever Ties With the Present
description: THERE are no sentimental tugs for Johnny Unitas when he turns on the television and sees the famous horseshoe on the side of the helmet. No flashbacks to Yankee Stadium, 1958.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SUNSET PARK;Cold Days for Finnish Society
description: Imatra Hall, a two-story, mustard-colored clapboard house on 40th Street in Sunset Park, once flowed with immigrants from Finland. Patrons from the surrounding area, once known as Finntown, crowded the dark wood bar, the dance floor and the downstairs sauna and in the summer enjoyed the barbecue and beach chairs on the front lawn.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Friday and in some editions yesterday of schedules for the Martin Luther King holiday tomorrow gave incorrect information about the stock markets and New York City garbage collection. The stock markets will be open; there will be regular Monday trash collection. A corrected holiday schedule appears today on page 28.

title: INVESTING IT;A Little Insurance for Worried Technology Investors
description: UNDECIDED what to do about the recent bruising of technology stocks? If you sell, you think, you may miss out on more gains. But if you hold and stocks fall, you worry that you may get walloped.

title: JANUARY 7-13;The Killers of Trees
description: Trees, by their size, longevity and sheer majesty, make a powerful statement about humans' relative insignificance. Something about the wanton destruction of trees makes human skin crawl as happened in 1989 when a deranged man poured a powerful herbicide on a 500-year-old live oak tree in Austin, Texas, nearly killing it.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: CUTTINGS;With Nary a Seed in Sight, Birds Need Help Now
description: I was down on the Maryland farm last weekend during the blizzard, and as soon as it stopped I shoveled a path through two feet of snow to the bird feeder.

title: THEATER;Shakespeare for Children It Isn't, but They Like It
description: SO, YOU WANT TO INTRODUCE several thousand New York City schoolchildren to the joys of Shakespeare and demonstrate the relevance of yet another dead white male poet to their modern lives. Which play do you choose? "Julius Caesar"? They might even recognize some lines. "Hamlet"? The ghost, fights and blood should get their attention.

title: Three Men, Three Plans To Rebuild the Schools
description: After years of neglect that have left New York City's public schools with leaky roofs and 28,000 fewer seats than students, virtually every major politician with a stake in the city is looking for ways to raise money for renovation and construction.

title: Segregated Schools Can Do Students No Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Croats and Muslims Said to Clash in Bosnia
description: Artillery exchanges were reported today between Croats and Muslims, nominal allies under the Bosnia peace agreement.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 On the court with Kerri-Ann McTiernan, the first female coach of a men's college basketball team.

title: EARNING IT;Volunteer Resumes Get Harder to Sell
description: CHERYL BURNS of Sewell, N.J., wanted a job and thought she had a solid resume. She had years of experience as a social worker, and even though she had been out of the work force for 10 years while she raised her four children, she had kept her skills sharp by doing extensive volunteer work.

title: Love Beneath the Gallows
description: THE MANUSCRIPT FOUND IN SARAGOSSA By Jan Potocki. Translated by Ian Maclean. 631 pp. New York: Viking. $27.95.

title: In Kansas and Elsewhere, G.O.P. Freshmen Face the Music, Sweet andShrill
description: There were balloons and cake, speeches and a rendition of "God Bless America" at the 50th anniversary ceremony of the Colmery-O'Neil V.A. Medical Center here. But for one invitee, Representative Sam Brownback, a freshman Republican, there were also angry questions. All of the 1,200 workers had their paychecks held up when the budget impasse recently shut down parts of the Federal Government.

title: Streetscapes/17 East 57th Street;Last Survivor of a 'Chateau' Row
description: AT this late date, it's barely a building, more like the scrap of a fragment, with only a hint of what the five-story structure looked like 125 years ago.

title: Can the Winter of '96 Get Any Worse Than This?
description: AFTER a mild winter last year, this winter has gotten off to a snowy, icy and frigid start, as the Blizzard of '96 brought Long Island to a standstill. Snow that started early last Sunday morning and continued until late Monday afternoon left accumulations of more than two feet in some areas and drifts of up to eight feet.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Tarpley Off to Greece?
description: ROY TARPLEY, banned from the National Basketball Association for drug and alcohol abuse, has reportedly agreed to return to Greece. The Athens sports daily Sportime said yesterday that Tarpley would return with the first-division team Iraklis Salonica in an 18-month deal for $2.3 million. Club officials were unavailable to confirm the report.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Lloyd Harbor, L.I., referred incorrectly to the current use of the former Marshal Field 3d mansion. It is more than occasional; the Queens College Center for Environmental Teaching and Research gives courses there for schoolchildren and other groups.

title: MUSIC;The Man Who Led an Orchestra to Stardom
description: THE St. Louis Symphony Orchestra doesn't have a corner on the market for American and Eastern European repertory. It just seems that way after 17 pivotal years under its music director, Leonard Slatkin.

title: ART;The 20th Century by Masters of the Print
description: WHILE emphasizing that it is not a school but a workshop, the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center in Norwalk nevertheless offers a variety of courses in all types of printmaking, including papermaking and bookbinding. And the center, which opened last July in the carriage house of the former Lockwood-Mathews Museum, is purveying art history in its current exhibition. The miscellany of prints by 23 masters of the 20th century is a fine overview of both techniques and thematic concerns.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Following the Fleet
description: SINCE 1915 there has never been a minute of the day or night when jitneys haven't barreled down the streets of Atlantic City. These buses have parted traffic, and sometimes water, in floods, hurricanes and even last week's blizzard, when jitneys were the only vehicles moving in a city paralyzed by a record snowfall and cut off from the mainland by unseasonably high tidal waters.

title: POSTINGS: Crowning an Apartment Building;Two Toppers On Fifth Ave.
description: An eight-story apartment tower and a row of triplex apartments would rise from the roof of a six-story neo-Georgian Manhattan building under plans filed with the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ANASTASIA, ABSOLUTELY By Lois Lowry. 119 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12) LIBRARIANS and critics have been speaking ill of series books for children since the turn of the century, when the Stratemeyer Literary Syndicate began spewing out its endless adventures of the Rover Boys and Tom Swift, all distinguished by a faithful adherence to formula, shallow characterization and reader-comforting predictability. Today we would call the Stratemeyer Syndicate a "packager," and Tom Swift has made way for R. L. Stine's "Goosebumps" books, not to mention a zillion "Sweet Valley High" spinoffs (and knockoffs), but the critical disdain remains the same. And usually with good reason.

title: DRIVING;Trouble Spots to Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;Attack of the Unsung Defense
description: This goose-bump Packers season has been full of accolades for the quarterback (Brett Favre) and the new, tricky, fleet receiver (Robert Brooks) and all that they have done for the wonderfully efficient Green Bay offense. It is the offense that has received attention as the Packers tackle the Dallas Cowboys this afternoon in the National Football Conference championship game.

title: Challenge To H.M.O.'s Maternity Limits
description: WHEN Allison Bissar had her first child 18 months ago, she was determined not to enter the hospital before midnight.

title: Pataki and Giuliani: It's Saturday Night
description: There was a time when Governor George E. Pataki didn't return Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's phone calls. And though relations thawed somewhat after the election, the two are not exactly on the best terms these days, with Mayor Giuliani once again critical of Governor Pataki's budget plans, which he says slight New York City.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: GREENWICH VILLAGE;A Piece of Cake, and Maybe It's a Champion
description: It's a gourmand's dream or a dieter's nightmare: tables laden with 17 award-winning varieties of breads and pastries, prepared by America's most talented pastry chefs and bakers, ready to be sampled.

title: Hotels, Hotels
description: To the Editor: Though I am one of the "other half" who has never stayed at the Carlyle, I have experienced in a small way the friendliness and warmth of the hotel.

title: Danger in Malawi
description: To the Editor: We are writing to express our concern about the article "Glittering Lake Malawi" (Dec. 31), which stated that Lake Malawi is "free from bilharzia parasites." Our research and the experience of physicians in the United States, Europe and Africa indicate this is not the case.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: UNDERWATER;Submarining to a Wreck
description: Anyone looking for an underwater adventure more exciting than the Lincoln Tunnel may want to visit the town of St.-Pierre on the Caribbean island of Martinique. Most of the ships in that town's harbor burned when Mont Pelee erupted in 1902, but a few sank intact to the harbor floor. Now, the Mobilis, a 50-seat submarine with large portholes, takes passengers 450 feet down to see the wreck of the Tamaya, a three-masted cargo ship built in 1862. (But because of the ash emitted by the volcano, the views of aquatic life are not very good.)

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with an article about five hypothetical retirement portfolios included incorrect listings for the first-quarter portfolio of Eric M. Kobren, president of Insight Management in Wellesley, Mass. A corrected table appears today on page 7.

title: HOCKEY;Another Ex-Devil Gets Best of Old Team
description: Two days after Chris Terreri beat the Devils in his first visit to New Jersey since his trade two months ago, another former Devils goaltender, Craig Billington, stole a victory from the Stanley Cup champions this afternoon. Billington registered 35 saves, some of the spectacular kind, and helped the Bruins to a 3-2 triumph over the Devils at the Fleet Center.

title: Foreign Affairs;Sell Pols, Buy Bonds
description: The tug-of-war between President Clinton and Newt Gingrich over a balanced budget entered a new, and fascinating, phase last week.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Guides to Theaters And Arts in London
description: Visitors to London have two new publications to help guide them through the city.

title: Supporters Of the U.N. Find It Hard To Be Heard
description: The United Nations Association of the United States, a citizens' foreign affairs forum and support group as old as the world organization itself, is in trouble.

title: WEDDINGS;Evelyn Tompkins, David P. Mandy
description: Evelyn Winthrop Tompkins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Powers Tompkins of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday to David Paul Mandy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Mandy of New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Cushman performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. Msgr. Robert M. O'Connell took part in the service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 31 about the closing of a the 60 East Club misstated the occupation of Larry Maran, who was quoted on its role in the real-estate world. He is a real-estate investor, not a broker.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;State Court Affirms Ruling To Confine Troubled Man
description: Francis Stuart, who has been compared to Larry Hogue because of his long odyssey with New York's mental health and criminal justice systems, has lost his latest bid for freedom. The State Court of Appeals affirmed a lower court decision that Mr. Stuart continue to be confined at the Kirby Forensic Psychiatric Center on Wards Island.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Jaspers Off to a Flying Start in M.A.A.C.
description: Fran Fraschilla had cast his Manhattan team in the role of the underdog yesterday. These were not the same Jaspers who had pounded St. Peter's by 21 and 23 points in their two regular-season meetings last season. And these were the same Peacocks -- to a man -- who had upset the Jaspers in the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference title game by a bucket in overtime.

title: POP VIEW: Three Women and Their Journeys in Song;Too Feminine for Rock? Or Is Rock Too Macho?
description: WHEN THE ROCK-AND-Roll Hall of Fame has its 11th annual induction ceremony on Wednesday at the Waldorf Astoria, one figure who will be conspicuously missing is Joni Mitchell. The Canadian-born singer and songwriter widely regarded as the most talented and influential white female rock performer ever has twice been nominated and both times been passed over by the 800-member voting body of journalists and record-company insiders. This year, her name wasn't even on the list of 15 nominees.

title: Priest Helps Youths Take the Stage
description: ASPIRING actors usually set their sights on places like Juilliard, Purchase College or the Yale School of Drama when it comes time for training.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 6/ Betting on spinoffs can be profitable, but it requires careful study. By Anthony Ramirez.

title: DIARY
description: BANKRUPTCIES A Surprise Filing Barneys, whose lack of punctuation is just one small part of its cachet, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. Its executives said that sales were strong, that stores would remain open and that the filing was just part of a larger struggle to alter their relationship with Isetan, the Japanese partner that financed Barneys' expansion. Isetan responded with a lawsuit, seeking to recover $168 million in short-term loans, and said, "The attitude of Barneys' management up to this stage is totally deplorable."

title: In the Region/New Jersey;A New Attraction for the Six Flags Neighborhood
description: FOR the last 25 years the owner of a 55-acre wooded site in the northwestern corner of Jackson Township in Ocean County had let its property lie fallow while considering its best use.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hotels, Hotels
description: To the Editor: Betsy Wade is undoubtedly correct that "reservations guaranteed on travelers' credit cards get room assignments early" ("Negotiating a Hotel Room," Practical Traveler, Dec. 10). Yet recently the reverse worked to my advantage.

title: AT THE GATE;No High-Tech High Jinks With Hoists and Chains
description: AFTER last week's market turbulence, investors who scout out new offerings may be particularly wary of technology stocks. For them, there is a promising new issue for a company that is about as far from high technology as can be: it makes chains.

description: How Events Shape Five-Year Records

title: F.Y.I.
description: Midtown Avalanche?

title: Top Target in Iowa Debate: Forbes, the No. 2 Candidate
description: In a telling display of how Steve Forbes has rattled the Republican Presidential field, the multimillionaire publisher emerged today as the central attraction and target in a nationally televised candidates' forum.

title: Defending the Faith
description: With Congress in recess, first-term House Republicans find themselves having to explain to some constituents why ordinary citizens should bear the consequences of the party's hard-line budget stance. A look at four freshmen.

title: MUSIC;Benefit Marks Women's Club's 70th
description: TO mark its 70th anniversary, the Bronxville Women's Club is giving a benefit concert today at 3 P.M. at 135 Midland Avenue in Bronxville. On the program will be works for combinations of flute, mandolin, violin, guitar and harp by Ibert, Handel, Beethoven and Hans Werner Henze, among others. The players, faculty artists of the Mozartina Musical Arts Conservatory in Tarrytown, are the harpist Susan Jolles and the Amici Musicae Trio: the flutist Nadine Scharman, the guitarist Gregory Baker and Joyce Balint, who plays bothviolin and mandolin. Tickets at $15 will be on sale at the door.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY
description: IF THE TIGER By Terry Farish. Steerforth, $21.

title: Sunday January 14, 1996: MUTANT MUSEUM;The Last Laugh
description: It's the house the Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles built, though Swamp Thing lives there, too. In fact, a gazillion cartoon figures room at the Words and Pictures Museum of Fine Sequential Art, a.k.a. the Comic Book Museum, which just celebrated its first birthday at permanent quarters in the middle of Northampton, Mass. (413-586-8545).

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Penn Extends Ivy Streak to 46
description: Ira Bowman scored 20 points and Penn survived a Yale rally in adding to its Ivy League-record winning streak with a 66-56 victory over the Bulldogs on Saturday.

title: Mud Wrestling
description: GOING NEGATIVE How Attack Ads Shrink and Polarize the Electorate. By Stephen Ansolabehere and Shanto Iyengar. Illustrated. 243 pp. New York: The Free Press. $24.

title: Million-Dollar Houses, Old and New
description: FOR sale: A brand new 7,500-square-foot country home on nearly 67 acres in Washington with commanding views of the Litchfield County sunsets from the south and west. Price tag: Just under $2 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: INVESTING IT;Future Spinoffs: When Less Becomes More
description: Is there another Dun & Bradstreet out there, a big company with a laundry hamper full of businesses that Wall Street would like better if they were spun off into simple piles? It is not an idle questions. When the publishing company announced Tuesday that it would reorganize into three publicly owned companies, its stock price rose from $63.5 to $65.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about the coming expansion of cable service around the state referred incorrectly to a dispute between North Brunswick and its cable operator, TKR Cable Company. TKR is seeking renewal of its North Brunswick franchise before the State Board of Public Utilities, which referred the matter to the Office of Administrative Law; the company did not take the township to court.

title: Lilco Proposing Gas Competition
description: GAS customers on Long Island will soon have a chance to buy their gas from a company other than the Lilco.

title: FILM;The Comeback Kid Tries Again
description: THE LAST TIME Richard Dreyfuss was anybody's choice for best actor, Jimmy Carter was wearing sweaters in the White House and John Travolta, a rising newcomer, was wearing tight pants in the movie "Grease." The acclaim for Mr. Dreyfuss was over his portrayal of a struggling actor in "The Goodbye Girl," a performance that won him the Oscar in 1978. In those years he was at the top of everyone's A-list, winning raves for his work in such 70's hits as "American Graffiti," "Jaws" and "Close Encounters of the Third Kind."

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/The Far West Village;Bohemian, With Hudson Breezes
description: OPEN-SKY vistas that stretch to the river and beyond provide a serene contrast to the Village on the east side of Hudson Street. On the west side of Hudson, every day feels like a Sunday.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;A Reversal: St.John's Has Cause To Cheer
description: If it had happened on a sleepy night in Alumni Hall, maybe no one would have noticed. But this was center court at Madison Square Garden, with a national television audience, and the symbolism of Zendon Hamilton's small mistake could not be missed. As Hamilton stepped into the circle, there was one small problem with his white jersey. The front said HAMILTON, the back said ST. JOHN'S.

title: The Neediest Cases;When Giving Is a Gift, And a Family Tradition
description: Lauren and Emily Redmerski of Rye, N.Y., got some good stuff for Hanukkah last month. Lauren, 10, received a Rangers jersey and a new watch. Emily, 8, a horse-lover, got some model horses she was hoping for.

title: JANUARY 7-13;Tax Break for Retirees
description: President Clinton and Congress joined in classic style last week to hand out another tax break. A new law prohibits New York, California and other states with high income tax rates from imposing "source taxes" on the pensions of former residents who retire to places like Florida and Nevada, which have no state income tax, or states with lower income tax rates.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Ottawa
description: When Queen Victoria chose Ottawa as the capital of the dominion of Canada in 1857, she had little idea of how severe the winters get. For several months a year, ice and snow virtually severed Ottawa from the rest of the country. Left to their own devices, the 10,000 Ottawans of the day learned to turn the terror of winter into joy. They gave sleigh parties, ice-skated to music, organized curling competitions and sing-alongs, built snowmen and ice palaces. A century later those traditions have evolved into Winterlude, North America's largest winter festival.

title: Internet Hate Speech Shouldn't Be Banned
description: To the Editor:

title: DINING OUT;In Tarrytown, Meat Eaters Hold Forth
description: NO surprise, well-marbled beef doesn't make the current list of foods for health and fitness, but even the most prudent diners will order a steak once in a while, the way they will on occasion have ice cream, not just as one scoop of plain vanilla, but as a towering hot fudge sundae. For the time being extra-lean gets the go-by in favor of extra-thick, extra-juicy porterhouse broiled by a master.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 24 about Vienna's ball season and an accompanying listing of lodgings and places to eat misspelled the name of an Austrian state. It is Steiermark, not Steiermarkt.

title: ABOUT LONGISLAND;There's Quite a Bit of Life Left in the Old Schooolhouse
description: THE old red schoolhouse is just that for Sadie and Irving Meyrowitz. An old red school is now their house. The Meyrowitzes and 50 other retirees recently moved into the former Main Street School in Port Washington. "I drive up, I say, 'I can't believe it,' " Mrs. Meyrowitz said. "What am I doing living in a school? But I got to tell you, I love it. I mean the views. I've got such big windows!"

title: Sunday January 14, 1996;QUESTIONS FOR: Phil Jackson
description: Q: Is it tough to persuade your guys to be aggressive, but not violent, when they're regularly getting clocked?

title: Sunday January 14, 1996: C'MERE KID;Gonna Make You a Star
description: Roll over Kurt Cobain and tell Leadbelly the news. The venerable American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers is signing up the rock stars of tomorrow. The 68,000-member music-licensing organization wants to erase any notion that it's for "serious" songwriters only, that the legacy of Gershwin and Porter is somehow sacrosanct. Thus its new recruitment campaign featuring ads in Spin magazine, college seminars and campus talent scouts.

title: Sports of The Times;The Fight for Quality, Without All the Chaos
description: BOXING at Madison Square Garden is undefeated in its first two outings.

title: Lost and Found
description: To the Editor:

title: G.I. Who Hails Tour of Duty in Bosnia
description: WHEN Anthony Avallone was 12 he was stricken with cancer, which ended his dreams of becoming a marine. During the Gulf War the Army relaxed its medical requirement, enabling him to join the military police. What could have been a career of checking locked doors and gates on a sleepy post in the Middle West ended up being the assignment of his childhood dreams. He is now escorting convoys of the First Armored Division through the mine-infested zone of separation in northeastern Bosnia.

title: PORTRAIT;How One Mother Joined the Ranks of the Homeless
description: KAREN JARRETT had arrived at the church shelter the evening before, lugging clothes, bottles and her 7-month-old son, Khari.

title: POP MUSIC: Three Women and Their Journeys in Song;A Sweet, Songful Life Lost As It Was About to Start
description: NANCY LaMOTT FINALLY HAD everything she'd always wanted.

title: THE WORLD;Shhh! That's a (Not Very) Secret.
description: THIS past week, several Hebrew newspapers made a revolutionary announcement: Prime Minister Shimon Peres had nominated Ami Ayalon, a former commander of the Israeli Navy, to be head of the General Security Service, the legendary Israeli secret service better known as Shin Bet.

title: JANUARY 7-13;Extended Family in Mourning
description: Former President Francois Mitterrand of France, who died Monday of prostate cancer at age 79, masterfully set the scene for his own death and burial.

title: Nongolfer Meets Putter Challenge
description: JOHN J. McNAMARA has three claims to golf glory. He broke 87 once the first time he played. He caddied for Joe Louis. He invented a radically different kind of putter. He hopes the third deed will make him rich.

title: I.R.A. Branch Eases Stance On Disarming
description: Irish and British officials said today that Sinn Fein, the political arm of the Irish Republican Army, has shown a new flexibility in recent days that could end the impasse in the Northern Ireland peace effort.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;St. Joe's Had It From the Start
description: No. 18 Arizona had canceled, but that didn't stop St. Joseph's from pretending the game was still on today.

title: STYLE;A Historical Footnote
description: For as long as the habit has existed, Frenchwomen have sneered at their American counterparts for mating street clothes with sneakers. To these stylish Parisians, there is nothing more loathesome, more crass, more unspeakably tacky, than dressing to the nines from head to ankle and then slipping on a pair of Reeboks. Who cares about practicalities? Comfort? Mais non! As any Frenchwoman will tell you, it is the total look that counts, shoes included.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;A Portrait of the Antichrist As a Young Composer?
description: TAKE THE ORGIASTIC sexuality, formalist complexity and delirious excess of a Peter Greenaway film, cross it with the caustic political commentary of a Bertolt Brecht play, and you will have a point of reference from which to approach "Resurrection," an opera by the English composer Peter Maxwell Davies, now resident in Scotland. Begun in the early 1960's but not performed until 1987, "Resurrection," with music and libretto by Mr. Davies, is one of the fiercest works of social criticism ever to come from the pen of a classical composer.

title: Team Loses Appeal on Briefs
description: Gulliver Preparatory School in Miami, disqualified from a cross-country event because of the team's high-cut briefs, yesterday lost its appeal to get its third-place finish restored.

title: ON THE STREET;What Becomes a Blizzard Most?
description: Fashion's many layers added to Manhattan's metamorphosis from hard-edged streetscapes to marshmallow fluffiness during last week's blizzard. Many New Yorkers affected a bundled-up style, clambering over snowbanks on Fifth Avenue. The covered-up famous face in the background bottom right was Rita Gam's.

title: An Old Stab At Soldiers Opens Battle In Germany
description: In an article published 65 years ago, the German satirist Kurt Tucholsky wrote, "Soldiers are murderers." A court absolved him of charges that he had slandered the military, but his famous phrase is once again the subject of bitter debate among German lawyers, judges and politicians over the limits of free speech.

title: Bleeding the Schools
description: Gov. George Pataki was wrong to suggest that the education cuts in his budget proposal could come out of bureaucratic bloat, with no damage to classroom instruction. Five years ago there was still a good bit of bloat to sacrifice. But after a crushing series of state and city cuts -- compounded by a funding formula that denies the city its rightful share of state education aid -- the schools are suffering personnel and supply shortages and classroom overcrowding that seriously undermine education. The city's legislative delegation needs to fight hard, not just to beat back the cuts but to win the city its rightful share of aid.

title: Betting on Rails in the Realm of Cars
description: Robert Dziubla and his co-workers at his Los Angeles law firm may represent the best hope for the success of this county's $75 billion transportation program -- and the reason it could fail.

title: Bridge
description: A tip from experts in a new book: If the contract is simple, assume the worst, and vice versa.

title: Astronauts Practice Construction in Space
description: Two astronauts stepped outside the shuttle Endeavour early today to practice orbital construction techniques 200 miles above Earth.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;New AT&T to Start Layoff Notices
description: Beginning tomorrow, in one-on-one meetings with staff members, AT&T supervisors will deliver layoff notices that will ultimately affect 13 percent of the company's work force.

title: Japan Wonders if Premier's Tie to Rightists Is Ended
description: Yoshie Akimoto prays every morning and night at the Buddhist altar in her home that honors her husband, who was killed in World War II. Normally polite and soft-spoken, she takes umbrage at suggestions that the cause for which her husband died is something Japan needs to apologize for.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Insignia Solutions, Mountain View, Calif., to Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco, to handle advertising for the computer company, previously handled by Elliott/Dickens, San Jose, Calif. The billings were estimated at more than $5 million. * Carvel Corp., Farmington, Conn., to DeVito/Verdi, New York, to handle its account, previously at TBWA/ Chiat Day, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group. The billings were estimated at $5 million. * Block Drug Co., Jersey City, to Publicis/Bloom, Dallas, a unit of Publicis S.A., to handle advertising for its newly acquired Nature's Remedy laxative. The account, with billings estimated at $3 million, had been inactive under the brand's previous owner, SmithKline Beecham.

title: Dr. King Sought Affirmative Action
description: To the Editor:

title: Retired American Troops to Aid Bosnian Army in Combat Skills
description: United States civilian contractors are to begin training Bosnian Muslim soldiers in the next 60 days, Clinton Administration officials say, as the first step toward insuring they can defend themselves after NATO peacekeepers leave.

title: Drop in Crime Is Reported
description: Standing in a precinct that had for years been the city's bloodiest, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton announced yesterday that the city had seen a 27.4 percent drop in the number of major felonies committed in the two-year period ending midnight, Dec. 31.

title: House Member Is 33d to Step Down
description: Representative Pat Williams, a liberal Democratic voice in the United States House for nearly 18 years, has decided against running again, becoming the 33d member of Congress who is not seekin re-election.

title: Plans May Balance, but Budget May Not
description: As President Clinton and Republican leaders prepare for yet another grapple this week over whose detailed, Government-certified plan will best balance the Federal budget in seven years, weary fiscal experts are starting to raise an often overlooked point:

title: HOCKEY;Rangers (and Fans, Too) Get Even With Keenan
description: Playoff memories blended with playoff intensity last night at Madison Square Garden when Coach Mike Keenan returned. His current team, the St. Louis Blues, met his previous team, the Rangers, in a gritty, thrilling game filled with nasty collisions and many loud sounds from the crowd. Both teams earned a grueling point in a 3-3 tie.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about New York City's plans to offer a new kind of security backed by unpaid tax bills misstated in some copies the amount to be raised and the value of the bills being used as collateral. The city hopes to raise $125 million, not $200 million; the collateral is $200 million, not $1.5 billion.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Choreographer Who Plays With Words, Mysteriously
description: The titles were filled with wordplay. Heather Dunbar's costumes and set designs were often extravagant. And Pedro Alejandro's choreography was flamboyant. As a result, when Pedro Alejandro Dance and Dancers presented "En Masse, Unmasked" on Thursday night at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio, this program of premieres resembled a collection of comic strips come to life.

title: POP REVIEW;Disruption For Guitar, But Also Bossa Nova
description: In rock music, when musicians feel stagnant or in need of a change, they often find a new band to work with. But in the avant-garde, it is a new context that musicians seek. On Thursday night at the Knitting Factory, Arto Lindsay played familiar sounds: the dissonant improvisations and short-order rock that he has been pushing since the late 1970's in such bands as DNA, and the funky pop and Brazilian-music hybrids that marked his 12-year-old group the Ambitious Lovers.

title: Drawing Dares to Compete In a Revitalized SoHo Gallery
description: Exactly 40 white spaces. Thirty-nine black lines. And each line must be exactly 11 feet 9 3/4 inches tall. For three days the installers at the Drawing Center on Wooster Street in SoHo have been pasting up tape to mark lines for a wall drawing by the French artist Tania Mouraud.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Korea Sends Reactor Gear to North
description: The first shipload of equipment for use in construction of two light-water nuclear reactors in North Korea left the South Korean port of Pusan today.

title: Agency Tests a New Kind of Public Hearing
description: In a nationwide multimedia experiment that redefined the limits of a public hearing, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission linked its new World Wide Web site with the video conferencing system of four Kinko's copy shops around the country on Jan. 5 for a session on fire protection rules at nuclear power plants. The session married two media: the Web, in a real-time dialogue, and the video conferencing at Kinko's, whichallowed people in different cities to see and hear each other and interact. It was an experiment that the commission was not committed to repeating, but which it had hoped would be a milestone for a new way to conduct business.

title: Easing Is Urged On Encryption
description: The Commerce Department will recommend easing export controls on encryption software after a study by the department and the National Security Agency found that American companies are being hurt, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said last week.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Snow Debris Will Wash Up
description: Clean Ocean Action, a Monmouth County-based environmental organization, is looking beyond the snow blanketing the beaches.

title: Power Couple
description: In the waning years of the last century, Americans were preoccupied with industrial mergers, urban chaos and unrest in the Philippines and Cuba. Only a few military strategists predicted the real threat to the global status quo -- the rise of Germany and Japan.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Transportation Grant Issued
description: Intermodal freight movement and seamless connection passenger travel." That's fancy transportation talk for moving goods and people. The New Jersey Institute of Technology will be studying ways to do those tasks with a $1 million research grant awarded by the Federal Transportation Department.

title: Does China Have the Will to Starve Orphans?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Modest Gifts to the Poor Can Be the Most Generous
description: Elaine Lampert was supposed to be a doctor. She was accepted to a combined pre-med and graduate program at Columbia University, she says, but she could not afford the tuition. Instead, she attended Brooklyn College and majored in education. She was 19 and an only child, but she worked her way through school while supporting her widowed mother.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Tributes to King in the State
description: Martin Luther King's birthday will be observed today as a Federal and state holiday. Here is a sampling of some of the dozens of events that will mark the day in New Jersey. One of those who worked closely with Dr. King, the Rev. Fred L. Shuttlesworth, a leader of the Birmingham civil rights movement, will speak at a scholarship breakfast at Rowan College. A parade will begin at 1 P.M. from Community Baptist Church of Love in Paterson. Governor Whitman will attend a special service at Calvary Baptist Church in Morristown. Students, parents and staff members from the Cherry Hill public schools will participate in community projects in Camden. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Australia to Push Warship Plan
description: SINGAPORE  Prime Minister Paul Keating of Australia, as part of an official visit to Malaysia this week, plans to press for an early decision on whether the countries will jointly build a fleet of new warships.

title: THE NEXT WONDER: A special report.;Cracks Show Early in China's Big Dam Project
description: From horizon to horizon, the ancient landscape here has been sundered, scored and stripped by the big steel blades of countless front-end loaders. Dust storms rise from monster truck caravans hauling a million boulders across a riven plain to the place where the Three Gorges Dam is to emerge, eventually, to mount and tame the timeless and often devastating flood of the Yangtze River.

title: An Antibacterial Accord
description: Cubist Pharmaceuticals Inc. said last week that it had reached an agreement with Pfizer Inc. to develop and sell antibacterial drugs. The terms were not disclosed. Cubist, a closely held biotechnology company based in Cambridge, Mass., said it would work with the New York-based drug maker to develop drugs to treat bacterial infections that are resistant to existing medicines. As part of the agreement, Pfizer will finance research at Cubist to develop the compounds and will have the option to make an equity investment in the company. In return, Pfizer will get the worldwide right to sell any products developed by the collaboration.

title: Fee Buildup In Malpractice Stirs Debate
description: A decade ago, when jury awards skyrocketed in medical malpractice cases, causing insurance rates to double and doctors to threaten to leave the state, New York came up with what seemed like a reasonable solution.

title: Many Markets Remain Open
description: Most banks and the Treasury bond market will be closed in the United States today in observance of the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr. The stock market and the commodity markets will be open, although the Chicago Mercantile Exchange will end trading on most contracts at noon. Japan's financial markets are closed today for Adult Day.

title: Extend the Debt Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: VW to Hire 1,000 At German Plants
description: Volkswagen A.G. says it will add 1,000 high-technology positions at its German factories this year.

title: No Space Like Shared Space
description: In the Northeast we had a test last week of whether people really wanted to stay home to get work done or to come to the office. In most cases, the office won.

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS: NEWS ANALYSIS;Saving the Best Game for Last
description: Can we bottle this and pop the cork on Jan. 28? Could this possibly be a prelude to a competitive and fun Super Bowl XXX?

title: Daniel S. Weiss, 86, Judge And Foe of Tammany Hall
description: Daniel S. Weiss, a former New York City Criminal Court judge and a City Councilman who bucked the powerful Tammany Hall political machine, died yesterday. He was 86.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: John R. Puglisi, executive vice president and managing director at William Douglas McAdams Inc., New York, was promoted to president and chief operating officer, succeeding Thomas Lom, who left. * Steve Aaron was named vice president and publisher at Premiere, New York, succeeding Mark Furlong, who left. Mr. Aaron was previously associate publisher at Elle Decor, New York, which is owned by the Hachette Filipacchi Magazines unit of the Lagardere Group. Premiere is owned by a joint venture of Hachette Filipacchi and the New World Communications Group.

title: Paul Borsky, 75; Studied Effects Of Sonic Booms
description: Paul Borsky, who studied the effects of aircraft noise on people just when the term sonic boom was entering the common vocabulary, died last Tuesday at his home in Plainview, L.I. He was 75.

title: China Says Exports Slumped Last Month
description: China's exports slumped in December, leaving a monthly trade deficit for the first time in 19 months, according to Customs Administration figures.

title: Decades Later, Still Pondering The Dream
description: The Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., who, with a preacher's eloquence, sounded a message of brotherhood from the streets of Birmingham to the steps of the nation's Capitol, would have been 67 today. The country will celebrate his life with speech and song. And some will commemorate his birth by reflection. A number of authors, scholars and modern-day activists ponder this question: Is Dr. King's dream for an integrated, color-blind society attainable? CHARISSE JONES Henry Hampton producer of the documentary "Eyes on the Prize."

title: GOLF;One More Time, Mickelson Shows He Is the Master of His House at Tucson National
description: When Phil Mickelson steps onto the premises at Tucson National, he is like a man walking through the front door of his house. He flops down into the easy chair, puts his feet up, grabs the remote control and glides right into his comfort zone.

title: Technology: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Three companies are preparing fast-action games for the slow-motion internet
description: IT would be hard to find a medium less suited than the Internet for playing twitch-finger, fast-action video games. You can die a thousand virtual deaths in a video game if you bang on your fire button and nothing happens. Yet "nothing happens" has become the chant of anyone who spends time mouse-clicking buttons on the Internet's World Wide Web, which is slow and unpredictable on a good day.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Bloomberg Business News in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about a debt restructuring of the Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.) misstated the address of a Manhattan office tower that will be taken over by a creditor group led by the financier Leon Black. It is 237 Park Avenue, not 277.

title: Sports of The Times;Falling a Mere Step Shy of Improbable Glory
description: ONE more step, Lamont Warren said, and he surely would have had the first down. He would have been in the clear, on his way to the Super Bowl. One more step, and his good college friend Kordell Stewart would have been the one going home to live with the pain of the conference title game that got away.

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;TV Analysts Cross Studios
description: Wondering why Fox's studio analysts appeared on NBC yesterday at halftime of the Colts-Steelers game? Watching NBC's Joe Gibbs jokingly ask Fox's Jimmy Johnson for a loan seem jarring?

description: As time expired and it became crystal clear that the Dallas Cowboys were going back to the Super Bowl, quarterback Troy Aikman walked over to Barry Switzer and handed him the game ball. "I thought he might appreciate it," Aikman said shyly.

title: Sports of The Times;Blissful Forgetfulness in the Stands of the Garden
description: Somewhere in the darkest recesses of their cunning minds, as both had made their final preparations and steeled themselves for their inglorious returns to Madison Square Garden, Mike Keenan and Pat Riley must have felt, like the old scribbler Erasmus, that, yes, "The multitude of the gross people is a beast of many heads."

title: Managed Care Has Trouble Treating AIDS, Patients Say
description: When Michael Donaldson joined a health maintenance organization in April, he was H.I.V.-positive and healthy. But as his health declined, he said, the Health Insurance Plan of New York came to seem less his ally than his enemy.

title: Will Ontario Wrap Doctors in Red Tape?
description: In a bid to rein in rising health care costs, Ontario's new Conservative Government wants the authority to control almost every aspect of doctors' working lives -- from where they set up a practice to the finer details of the care they prescribe. Most doctors in the province have reacted with anger, calling the plan an unprecedented intrusion by government into the workings of the medical system.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Snow Day Nursery Is Popular
description: When it snows, schools close. The Chubb Group of Insurance Companies does not. In response to employee requests after the 17-storm winter of 1993-94, the company started a day-care program for snow days. But it did not snow enough last winter to shut schools.

description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A /Pierre Averbuch and Harry Bernas : 2 French Scientists Debate Tests
description: France's decision to resume nuclear weapons testing in the South Pacific not only aroused worldwide protest, but also opened an unprecedented breach in the French scientific community. Two leaders of the positions for and against testing, Pierre Averbuch and Harry Bernas, both senior phycisists, debated the issue in Paris last week. Barry James of the International Herald Tribune reported their views.

description: The Nassau County District Attorney's office is investigating a series of harassing phone calls made to a campus group calling for the resignation of Adelphi University's president, Peter Diamandopoulos, whose lavish salary and perks have made him the target of an inquiry by the State Attorney General.

description: Christian conservatives in legislatures across the nation have begun promoting a "parental rights amendment" to state constitutions, which critics call an effort to cloak an inflammatory agenda in an innocuous name.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Miscellany
description: * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, reported magazine advertising pages in December rose 1.5 percent from December 1994, to 18,367. For 1995, ad pages rose 5.1 percent from 1994, to 208,378.

title: Guatemalan Indians Return From Exile, Warily
description: Deep in the jungle here, makeshift settlements of wood logs and plastic sheets are springing up everywhere, their population swelling monthly. Driven from their villages by the Guatemalan military more than a dozen years ago, thousands of Indian peasants are cautiously returning from exile to till the lands their people have known since the time of the Maya empire.

title: Lotus Notes And I.B.M.: Still Happy Together?
description: Finally, I.B.M. can begin gauging whether it got its money's worth in paying $3.5 billion for the Lotus Development Corporation last year.

title: In Bookstore Chains, Display Space Is for Sale
description: One of Lynn Snowden's bleakest times as an author was a grim 20 minutes she spent sobbing at a Barnes & Noble counter in midtown Manhattan.

title: FILM REVIEW;Hackers and Mad Scientist In a Cyber-Nightmare
description: Twenty-five minutes to global interface," a computerized voice announces in "Lawnmower Man 2: Beyond Cyberspace," a peppy if silly special-effects movie that imagines a countdown to cyber-Armageddon. As the clock ticks, it becomes increasingly likely that the world will be controlled by a virtual reality technology so sophisticated that it accesses all five senses and can kill people. Pulling the strings is Jobe (Matt Frewer), the vindictive cyber-demon who was presumed dead in an explosion at the end of "The Lawnmower Man," the surprise science-fiction hit of four years ago.

title: Bush Says He Erred in Assuming Hussein Would Fall After War
description: Former President George Bush says he underestimated the political staying power of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq after the Persian Gulf war, and regrets that the allies did not do more to undercut his authority.

title: Peekskill Teacher Is Killed in Apartment
description: A 48-year-old kindergarten teacher was shot to death in her apartment by an irate neighbor who was complaining of noise, the state police said Saturday.

title: G.O.P. Talking of Abandoning Weapon in Budget Battle
description: The chairman of the House Budget Committee, John R. Kasich, said today that Republicans would restore the Government's authority to borrow money, thereby abandoning what is potentially their strongest weapon in their drive to force a budget agreement with the Clinton Administration on Republican terms.

title: BALLET REVIEW;Alienation, Minimalism, Solidity And Ritual
description: Jerome Robbins's "Glass Pieces" and William Forsythe's "Behind the China Dogs," two ballets with a contemporary tone, were given by the New York City Ballet for the first time this season on Friday night.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a review about a New York City Ballet performance of "Jeu de Cartes" misattributed the choreography. The work is by Peter Martins, not George Balanchine.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Socialist Wins Portugal's Presidency
description: The Socialist candidate, Jorge Sampaio, was elected today to succeed Mario Soares as President of Portugal.

title: Metro-North Expects Runs Near Normal
description: After a week of breakdowns, stalled and phantom trains and stranded riders angrily milling in stations, blizzard-plagued Metro-North promised its 70,000 commuters near-normal weekday service for today and tomorrow, although they were warned to expect shorter, more crowded trains and minor delays.

title: Policewoman Killed By Gunshot Wound
description: An off-duty police officer died early yesterday three hours after suffering a gunshot wound on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: POLITICS: A MAJOR ISSUE;Gun Owners No Easy Audience for Candidates
description: Although several Republican candidates tried hard here today, appealing to conservatives -- even those who share a fear that the Government is reaching for their firearms -- can be tricky.

title: U.S. at Least Breaks the Ice With North Korea on M.I.A.'s
description: After four days of intense talks that ended this morning in Honolulu, the United States and North Korea came close to agreeing on a joint mission to recover the remains of thousands of American servicemen killed in the Korean War, United States officials said.

title: James E.B. Breslin, 60, Poetry Professor, Dies
description: James E.B. Breslin, an English professor and modern American poetry specialist who jumped the academic track to produce an acclaimed biography of the painter Mark Rothko, died on Jan. 6 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 60, and at the time of his death he was both a professor of English and acting chairman of the Art Practice department at the University of California at Berkeley.

title: In America;A Living Legacy
description: You can walk just a block and a half and trace the entire life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. For in that remarkably tiny area near downtown Atlanta is the house in which he was born, the church in which he preached and the tomb with the eternal flame in which he is buried.

title: Bosnia Foes Begin Pullback
description: Several thousand Bosnian Government, Serbian and Croatian troops withdrew from their front-line trenches and bunkers across central and northeastern Bosnia today, ahead of the deadline to create buffer zones between the forces.

title: TENNIS;Agassi Emerges Winner After a Five-Set Scare
description: It is a rare day when Roscoe Tanner and Andre Agassi are mentioned in the same paragraph. Tanner, a Tennessean, relied on his serve to win tennis matches during his heyday in the 1970's. Agassi, a Las Vegan, relies on his return of serve and groundstrokes. Tanner had bangs into his 40s. Agassi is bald, partly by his own design, at age 25.

title: Today's TV Listings
description: Television and radio news, listings and advertising appear today on pages B6-7.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Second Wind or Winding Down?
description: On tonight's episode of "Murphy Brown," the star reporter gets a luscious assignment: a live interview with a pop star who reportedly sleeps in an abandoned missile silo and has a Ferris wheel and a petting zoo on his estate, Happytime Ranch. Diane Sawyer and Michael Jackson should feel free to take things personally. But while it's amusing to see the intrepid Murphy (played by the equally intrepid Candice Bergen) ride around Happytime on an elephant, the episode is disappointing.

title: A Chagall Is Stolen From a Tel Aviv Gallery
description: A Marc Chagall painting, "Jacob's Ladder," has been stolen from a Tel Aviv art gallery, the owner said today. Shaya Yariv, the owner of the Gordon Gallery, said the painting had been displayed prominently when the gallery opened on Friday morning. But 20 minutes later, when a visitor asked directions to the Chagall, the only thing visible was a bent nail where the picture had hung.

title: Editorial Notebook;A Good Word for Dandyism
description: It is well worth wading through seasonal slush to visit a show called "The Butterfly and the Bat" at the Frick Collection. It deftly celebrates a much-maligned and misunderstood attainment: dandyism. Here, spread through five galleries, are memorabilia associated with two elegant dandies, the American expatriate artist James McNeill Whistler and the French poet and boulevardier Count Robert de Montesquiou-Fezensac

title: CHRONICLE
description: Their husbands were out of town on business Friday night, so HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON and TIPPER GORE took advantage of the chance to go out for what would once have been called a girls' night out.

description: There was an agency "re-merger" last week as well as an agency "de-merger."

title: Patents;On the horizon: digital videocassette recorders and the promise of sharper videotapes
description: MOST people know that computers are digital machines. Many also realize that telephone equipment and radio signals are going digital. Some have even heard that television is supposed to be next on the horizon. Manufacturers in those industries have certainly received the message and are moving quickly to design components that operate with the ones and zeroes of computer code.

description: If only it was always this easy.

description: Four marketers have made agency roster changes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about a meeting between local politicians and officials of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad gave an incorrect surname for the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. He is Marc V. Shaw. The article also misstated the number of cars out of service. About one-third of Metro-North's 690 electric cars were affected; its non-electric cars remained in service. And it misstated the railroad's schedule for today. It will operate on a normal weekday schedule, not a holiday schedule.

title: Grand Jury Is Investigating Flamboyant Movie Producers
description: Andrew J. Vajna, one of Hollywood's more flamboyant producers, is under investigation by a Federal grand jury in Los Angeles that has been examining his tax returns, his production company, Cinergi Pictures Entertainment Inc., disclosed Friday night.

title: POLITICS: THE ASSESSMENT;Forbes: Newcomer in Perot's Clothing
description: He is a pampered rich man who is too removed from ordinary Americans to be President. He does not have a clue how to make things happen in Washington. And he has some, well, crazy notions about the economy.

title: Kenneth O. Jones, 77, Minister Devoted to Presbyterian Church
description: The Rev. Kenneth Owen Jones, a longtime minister at New York's largest Presbyterian church who was particularly noted for his devotion to his parishioners, died of a heart attack in his office on Jan. 7. He was 77.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the scheduled firing-squad execution of an inmate in Utah misstated, in some editions, the record of executions in Texas. The state has executed 92 criminals since the return of the death penalty in 1976, not in 1995 alone.

title: Syria Wobbles Toward Peace
description: The many strands of Middle East diplomacy crossed paths last week. Jordan's King Hussein drew an enthusiastic greeting from ordinary Israelis in Tel Aviv. Palestinians prepared for their first self-rule election. Secretary of State Warren Christopher nudged forward the negotiations between Israel and Syria.

description: When a reporter approached some Army sergeants huddled around a kerosene stove for warmth recently, trying to engage them in conversation, the reception was as chilly as the weather they were trying to ward off.

description: George Soros, the financier, announced plans today to finance a new project for developing the Internet in Russia, and also said he would begin investing selectively here again after pulling out of most of his holdings in 1994.

description: This is how the week was for Barry Switzer.

description: Death, or at least a nostalgia for the dead, seems to be enjoying a renaissance in Britain these days. Or maybe it's just undergoing a commercial vogue.

description: The Superfund, the long troubled 15-year-old program to clean up the nation's most seriously polluted toxic waste sites, is now in nearly complete disarray, a victim of political indecision and fiscal gridlock.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Formal Charges Lodged In Killing of Rabin
description: Yitzhak Rabin's confessed assassin, Yigal Amir, and two other Israelis were formally charged today with conspiring to murder the Prime Minister.
