description: A task force on special education will present its report on how the state can more effectively serve special education students on Wednesday at the State House. The panel, which includes parents and members of groups representing retarded and disabled adults and children, studied the costs of schooling in and out of state, according to Senator John H. Ewing, Republican of Peapack and the chairman of the Senate Education Committee.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Linking New Sounds to Old Formulas in an Eccentric Atmosphere
description: Most sounds echoing through the downtown avant-garde music zone in Manhattan are now at least two decades old. Conviction, clarity and wit are needed to give them new life. Wit might be most important. Nothing makes the heart sink more quickly than the humorless sneer on the face of a would-be experimenter preparing to foist brute noise or blank repetition as a thunderous novelty on a jaded Lower East Side audience.

title: BASKETBALL;Frustrated Abrams Picks His Head Up
description: The look on the big man's face was all you needed to know. The clock was ticking past eight minutes in the second half, Boston College was 7 points behind Seton Hall and Danya Abrams's afternoon was hitting a new low. A long lead pass found him about 25 feet from the rim, headed toward the goal, guaranteed of a breakaway dunk worthy of "Plays of the Week." Until the ball slipped through his hands. A timeout took Abrams back to the bench, wearing a look of disgust all the way.

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;Waiting to Exhale: Steelers Win as Pass Fails
description: As soon as Colts quarterback Jim Harbaugh released his last-second desperation pass, the Steelers players and their fans here at Three Rivers Stadium were gripped with the fear that they were about to be struck by lightning twice in the same spot.

title: Marilyn Horne Concert
description: Marilyn Horne is to present several young singers in her birthday concert tomorrow night at 7:30 at Tully Hall. Janet Williams (soprano), Michelle DeYoung (mezzo-soprano), Bruce Ford (tenor) and Rodney Gilfry (baritone) will sing works by Bellini, Debussy, Handel, Mahler, Rodgers and Hammerstein, Strauss and Villa-Lobos. Ms. Horne will sing Copland's "At the River." There will be a surprise guest from the Metropolitan Opera. Tickets, at $20, are available at the box office. Information: (212) 875-5050.

description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. The reports were delayed by the partial shutdown of the Government.

title: Denise Grey, French Actress, 99
description: Denise Grey, a theater and film star whose career spanned nine decades, died on Saturday at her home in Paris. She was 99.

title: News Analysis;High-Stakes Strike
description: The 11-day strike by building janitors that has left office workers to clean their own toilets and empty their own trash in 1,000 Manhattan office towers is casting a shadow that reaches far beyond New York City.

title: Fortune Attacks Rival Forbes And Its Editor
description: In an unusual direct attack on a competitor, Fortune charged in a cover story today that some large advertisers in Forbes magazine had been "exempt from tough editorial criticism."

title: In Small-Town Texas, the Sewing Stops
description: Pale green and beige sewing machines line the floor, seven neat rows of ghosts at the Ca-Ce-Len Manufacturing Company, a two-room garment factory in this small farm town in central Texas. The factory, set inside a whitewashed brick building on Granger's main street, closed last month, depriving 50 longtime workers of jobs that paid $5 to $8 an hour and marking one more small shift in how and where Americans' clothes are made.

title: Holding Compuserve Responsible
description: Germans often describe Munich as the country's largest village -- the picturesque Baroque capital of Bavaria with a million residents, home to BMW and the electronic giant Siemens A.G., but with no real pretensions to being an international metropolis.

title: Essay;Rise Of 'The Stepson'
description: Ordinarily, when a former columnist makes it to the top in politics, I get a warm feeling. But the emergence of Yevgeny Primakov as Russian Foreign Minister should send a chill throughout the West.

title: Live From New York, It's . . . Alphonse and Gaston
description: There is real tension in the best comedy, and if "Saturday Night Live" had really wanted to get a few belly laughs out of pairing Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on this weekend's show, it might have played off the fact that the two men share no great love for each other.

description: From the moment Bill Clinton took office as President, Republicans set out to destroy his legitimacy. Their method was to attack his honor, principally through charges about the long-ago land deal known as Whitewater.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

description: A Magazine Attacks

title: BASKETBALL;Camby Remains Stable After Pre-Game Collapse
description: Marcus Camby of the University of Massachusetts, leader of the top-ranked team in the nation and a strong candidate for national basketball player of the year awards, was in stable condition in an Olean, N.Y., hospital last night after collapsing before his team's game at St. Bonaventure.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Success Story, With Unhappiness as Coda
description: THE GOOD LIFE AND ITS DISCONTENTS The American Dream in the Age of Entitlement, 1945-1995 By Robert J. Samuelson 293 pages. Times Books. $25.

title: In King's Name, Miles of Memories
description: Along the nation's streets named for Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., people and places reflect his dream. Marrishia and Steven Reed, above, play after kindergarten. A sign, right, commands nonviolence. Paschal's restaurant, below, a favorite of civil rights leaders in the 60's, remains popular. Below right, one can view mountains or the skyline from the avenue honoring him.

title: Silicon Valley's Economy Called Strong
description: An annual survey of the economic health of Silicon Valley, to be released Monday, shows that the nation's leading high-technology region has resumed its strong growth and is both renewing its strength in manufacturing chip-making equipment and is increasingly becoming an industrial and software design center as well.

title: Final Victim of Colombia Jetliner Crash Is Found
description: Rescuers found the remains of a 9-year-old New Jersey boy today, the last missing victim of an American Airlines plane crash that killed 160 people, a Red Cross official said.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Glittery Puccini Favorite Comes Back to the Met
description: Franco Zeffirelli's opulent production of Puccini's "Turandot" has been a favorite with Metropolitan Opera audiences since it was unveiled in 1987. So it has been revived regularly, even though the opera presents formidable casting challenges. These challenges were again apparent when the production returned on Friday night.

title: No Headline
description: On my way to the next meeting in the next town, I drive by the fishing holes, but can't cast my line. I drive by the hiking trails and want on them." -- REPRESENTATIVE PAT WILLIAMS, Democrat of Montana, saying he will not seek re-election. [A14:4.]

title: Spring? No, But a Thaw Is Sure Nice
description: A brilliant sun banished a week of daylong dusks, reflecting off expanses of snow, water and glass and luring New Yorkers, blinking and almost giddy, into the light yesterday.

title: Video-Rental Company's Books Disputed
description: The Hollywood Entertainment Corporation uses accounting practices that "may materially impact the fairness" of its 1995 financial statements, Coopers & Lybrand, the company's former accountants, contend.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Whew! It's a Big Sigh Of Relief in Pittsburgh
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers gave "Waiting to Exhale" new meaning this afternoon.

title: Sports of The Times;The Rev. Reggie White Delivers a Sermon on the Block in Texas
description: THE man known as "the Minister" was preaching fire and brimstone, loud and clear. And in his sermon, Reggie White was hoping that the National Football League was listening, loud and clear, in its Park Avenue offices.

title: Fleisher Plays Mozart, Both Hands on the Keys
description: Leon Fleisher has been understandably reluctant to describe his recent performances of a Mozart piano concerto as a comeback. The injury that disabled his right hand for more than 30 years is still a problem, though of late he has been undergoing some promising rehabilitation. Last year he felt encouraged enough to perform Mozart's Piano Concerto No. 12 in A with several orchestras and ensembles. On Saturday night he played the work with the Orchestra of St. Luke's at Carnegie Hall, where in 1944 at the age of 16 he made his stunning debut with the New York Philharmonic.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Passion Amid Trills and Decorum
description: Radical revisions of early music become easier the farther back in time we go. Knowing less, interpreters have freer hands. Ignorance unburdens them from all the pesky facts that would otherwise have to be argued over. Such is the case with "L'Incoronazione di Poppea," Monteverdi's last opera, first produced in 1643. It has traveled light through history and lost some baggage along the way; indeed, its methodology, its instrumentation and even a lot of its authorship remain unresolved.

title: Media;In Taking Over CBS News, Andrew Heyward has to fix what's broken, and leave the  rest alone.
description: WITH the broadcast news industry tramping forward into new frontiers as the next century approaches, Andrew Heyward has a more difficult trail to bushwhack than most.

title: N.F.L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIPS;Packer Coach Seriously Hurt
description: Gil Haskell, the Packers' wide receiver coach who was knocked unconscious on the sideline during the National Conference championship game, was listed in serious condition tonight at the Baylor Medical Center. "I'm told that there will be further evaluation tomorrow," said Lee Remmell, the Packers' public relations director.

title: Advertising;True North Announces Acquisition As Agencies Reveal Vast Accounts
description: A wild week along Madison Avenue came to a frenzied end as three advertising giants each made a month's worth of news on one frantic Friday.

title: Los Angeles Magazine Gets a Serious Look
description: Michael J. Caruso's former boss at Vanity Fair, Tina Brown, subscribes to the cocktail party theory of magazine excellence, which holds that a disparate mix of articles will be as enticing to readers as an intriguing get-together. Now Mr. Caruso is putting her theory into practice as the new editor of Los Angeles magazine, once a consistently profitable crown jewel in the $1 billion publishing division of Capital Cities/ ABC Inc.

title: Behind the Scenes;Computer Critters: Way Beyong Mr. Ed.
description: It takes several years of training to teach a lion to not bite the trainer's head off while it is in the animal's mouth. During the filming of a movie, most animals can memorize only one to two tricks at a time.

title: BASKETBALL;Consistency Continues to Elude Knicks
description: The Knicks are becoming a one-step-forward, two-steps-back team. They show a semblance of cohesion one night and the molecules quickly split the next. It is enough to concern even Derek Harper, the veteran point guard who continually insists, "This is not time to push the panic button."

title: Metro Matters;In a Vital Corner, Hearing The Call on Child Abuse
description: THE effort to change New York's child abuse laws gained a vital convert yesterday. Speaker Sheldon Silver of the State Assembly said he no longer favored destroying most records of suspected child abuse, and would support legislation requiring that most remain on file, so that caseworkers can more easily detect patterns of abuse.

title: 50,000 to Be Moved For Vietnam Dam
description: Vietnam has announced plans to move at least 50,000 people from a remote northern province to make way for a big hydroelectric power project.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Panel Nomination Renewed
description: Paul Donnelly will be starting a new job tomorrow as special assistant in the Attorney General's office.

title: Kenneth S. Halpern, 51, Planner and Architect
description: Kenneth S. Halpern, a force for planning in New York City who helped design the South Street Seaport, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 51.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Banco Popular Profit Up
description: Banco Popular S.A. of Spain, often ranked among the world's most profitable banks, said yesterday that its 1995 profit rose 5.2 percent, which was less than had been expected. Many analysts had predicted that profit would rise as much as 7 percent at Popular, which is Spain's sixth-biggest commercial bank in terms of deposits. Popular, known as Spain's most conservative bank, finished the year with a profit of 57.4 billion pesetas ($472.8 million). (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Chess
description: In tennis, if you make a bad shot, the most you can lose is one point. Then you go on to the next point, starting fresh. Chess, however, is unforgiving; an error can plague you for the rest of the game, try as you may to make up for it.

title: Flying With a Swoosh, Hornbills Help Indonesian Rain Forest
description: AN ecologist studying a spectacular fruit-eating bird, the red-knobbed hornbill, in Indonesia has found that it seems to play an important role in maintaining and regenerating the rain forest.

title: Health Research, Once Facing Big Budget Cut, Gets an Increase
description: While cutting the budget for most other agencies, Congress has given the National Institutes of Health an increase of 5.8 percent, after Republicans concluded that biomedical research was an engine of economic growth.

title: Ex-Orange County Official in Settlement
description: The former assistant treasurer of Orange County, Matthew Raabe, has agreed to a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, his lawyer said today.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;For Troubled Knicks, Missing Letter Is 'D'
description: The Knicks have been losing games, but they have also lost part of their identity.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Bill on Hemophilia Suits
description: An effort has been revived to win more time for hemophiliacs to file suit if they contracted AIDS from tainted blood-clotting products in the 1980's.

title: Closings at Anchor Glass
description: The Mexican glassmaker Vitro S.A. said today that its United States subsidiary, the Anchor Glass Container Corporation, would close its factories in Cliffwood, N.J., and Houston to lower costs. Anchor, based in Tampa, Fla., a supplier of glass bottles and jars, will transfer some workers to other plants and provide job counseling to others. Information on the number of workers affected was not immediately available. The company employs about 5,800 people at 18 United States sites.

title: Ellis Communications Seeks Sale or Merger
description: Ellis Communications Inc. has hired Goldman, Sachs & Company to explore a sale or merger of the closely held television company, its chief executive, Bert Ellis, said yesterday.

title: Russians Pounding Rebels Who Hold 100 Hostages
description: With a furious aerial and artillery bombardment that turned the crisp mountain air black for miles, Russian troops this morning assaulted the southern town where Chechen separatist rebels have held more than 100 people hostage for nearly a week.

title: Black Churches Forming a For-Profit Group
description: Five of the United States' largest African-American church denominations announced today that they were forming a for-profit organization to pool their resources to provide health insurance, home mortgage loans, credit cards, education, food and durable goods to black Americans.

title: Dakar Journal;Children of Islam, Piously Seduced Into Begging
description: Aboure Aboridiale's daily routines are as fixed as his beatific gaze. With his morning prayer completed, the wispy-bearded young man sets out early dressed in rags for a day of begging that will end only with the dark of night.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SMITH'S FOOD AND DRUG CALLS OFF MERGER TALKS
description: Smith's Food and Drug Centers Inc. of Salt Lake City said yesterday that it had terminated merger talks with Smitty's Super Valu Inc. The company also said it had ended its plan to buy back up to 50 percent of its stock. Smith's, which operates supermarkets in the West and Southwest, said it was still considering a sale or a significant buyback of stock. The merger discussions were announced last week. Smitty's, a Phoenix-based supermarket operator, is controlled by the Yucaipa Companies of Los Angeles. Smith's shares rose $2.125 yesterday, to $28.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Building Diversities On a Thematic Base Emanuel Ax Alice Tully Hall

title: Mayor Seeks $400 Million For Airports
description: In a new turn in the often stormy relationship between the Port Authority and the Giuliani administration, New York City is pursuing a legal claim for $400 million in back rent for the city's two major airports. But as with many of the recent fights over spending at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the dispute goes much deeper.

title: Words of Peace and Protest on King Holiday
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, arriving at the Brooklyn Academy of Music yesterday to deliver remarks in memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., instead found himself caught up in a daylong public argument with the Rev. Al Sharpton over the right to use the city's roadways -- and over which man was betraying Dr. King's memory.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Home Sweet Home Page
description: Why did it take the violet almost 60 years to secure its status as official state flower? What is the ZIP code for Cinnaminson? How about the fax number for the Beneficial Insect Laboratory in the Department of Agriculture?

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Former Syracuse Guard Goes South
description: Michael Lloyd, the point guard who left Syracuse under a cloud of eligibility questions, has enrolled at Auburn-Montgomery, an N.A.I.A. school, and is waiting for clearance to play.

title: 8 Killed in Crash of a Corporate Plane in Idaho
description: A corporate plane carrying four Coca-Cola bottling executives to a sales meeting crashed and burned in a canyon early today, killing all eight people aboard.

title: Why Limits on Egg Donors Are Prudent
description: To the Editor:

title: Today's Sale of Treasury Bills Is Only U.S. Auction This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. The auction, usually held on Mondays, will be today because the credit markets were closed yesterday for the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Shift by Company Will Bring in More Outsiders
description: Responding to widespread criticism of insider domination of the company's board, the directors of the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company yesterday unanimously approved a series of proposals that would turn majority control of the board over to a group of outside directors, according to company officers and a member of the board.

title: Why Limits on Egg Donors Are Prudent
description: To the Editor:

title: Separating Crack Mothers From Children Does More Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Four Players Sign New Contracts
description: On the eve of a three-day owners' meeting in Los Angeles and one day before the deadline to file for salary arbitration, four players signed contracts yesterday, leaving 74 eligible to file today. Players and teams will exchange figures on Friday, and hearings will be scheduled for Feb. 1-20.

title: Trip to U.S. Is a Total Loss
description: Talk about a losing effort.

title: U.S. Infantrymen Begin Drawing Lines in the Bosnian Soil
description: Sgt. Manuel Ortiz speaks English, Tagalog, Arabic, some Spanish and, with the help of language tapes, enough Serbo-Croatian to get the point across for the NATO-led peacekeepers: Those five artillery pieces pointing due west at a Muslim pocket have to be removed by this Friday, he told two Serbian soldiers manning the position on a frost-covered ridge early this morning.

title: Pennsylvanian Says He'll Leave Congress
description: Representative William F. Clinger, a leading Republican investigator into the affairs of the White House and top Administration officials, said today that he would not seek re-election to a 10th term.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Operation Bosnia Valentine
description: I figure there's not a Hallmark store in Sarajevo," said Jean McMullan, a pastor at Sussex United Methodist Church.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Clinton Teams Shine At King Day Meet
description: DeWitt Clinton of the Bronx won three events each in boys' and girls' competition yesterday in the Martin Luther King Relays at the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan. Clinton's boys and girls teams also qualified for the Millrose Games 1,600-meter relay finals on Feb. 2 in Madison Square Garden.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Traders Focus on New Data And Fresh Talks on Budget
description: While the markets for Treasury securities were closed yesterday for the holiday honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., traders began looking forward to a greater clarity in trading this week.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;If DVD Is the Medium of the Future, Just When Will that Future Arrive?
description: I HOLD in my hands an iridescent artifact from a civilization of the future. The civilization, or so the global entertainment, electronics and computer industries would have us believe, is our planet's, just 11 months from now. The artifact, which I acquired 10 days ago at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, looks for all the world like a compact disk. But no CD or CD-ROM player can decipher the information on it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OPPENHEIMER OPENING A BROKERAGE BUSINESS IN ISRAEL
description: Oppenheimer & Company, the New York brokerage and investment banking firm, said yesterday that it would establish a brokerage business in Israel by recruiting Eddy Shalev and his staff from the Tel Aviv office of Oscar Gruss & Son. Mr. Shalev, 48, and his staff of 18 have built a significant brokerage business executing trades for Israeli institutions in the shares of American companies. Oppenheimer has longstanding ties to Israel and is a leading underwriter in the United States for securities offerings by Israeli companies. Nathan Gantcher, Oppenheimer's president, said that by acquiring a securities brokerage business in Israel, the firm expected to broaden its business both in brokerage and investment banking. Robert J. Mittleman, chief executive of Oscar Gruss, said his firm was negotiating with several people to establish a replacement arrangement in Israel.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;From Bellicose to Bucolic
description: The New York Virtuoso Singers, conducted by Harold Rosenbaum, gave a virtuosic display of music of war and peace on Saturday evening. In the hall's friendly acoustics, the 16-voice chorus produced a vibrant sound in a program that spanned nearly five centuries.

title: HORSE RACING;Horse Killed in Fire at Belmont
description: In a barn fire that could have been disastrous, one horse was killed at Belmont Park yesterday but 20 others were safely led from their stalls.

title: Police Face Criticism in Child Abuse Cases
description: The reluctance of the police to make arrests for child abuse is another one of the failures of the child protection system in New York State, Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross said today.

title: Vote Deadline At RJR Nabisco
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that March 12 had been set as the deadline for shareholder voting on a proposal the company has opposed, to spin off its food business into a separate company.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;After Anorexia, Recovery And Intensive Job Search
description: The anorexia began in 1987 during a cruise in the Bahamas. Pamela M. befriended a fellow passenger who appeared enviably thin and begged to know how she did it. The secret, the woman said, was to eat nothing but vegetables.

title: Mexico Arrests A Top Suspect In Drug Trade
description: Federal authorities arrested a man accused of being one of the hemisphere's most powerful and murderous drug lords and promptly expelled him to the United States, where he is on the F.B.I.'s 10 most-wanted list, the Mexican Government announced today.

title: Q & A
description: Snow Fleas

title: Dwayne's World;Influence of Archer-Daniels Is Wide as Well as Deep
description: Lately, Dwayne O. Andreas and the Archer-Daniels-Midland Corporation have been through a hailstorm of bad news -- price-fixing investigations, corruption charges, shareholders' wrath. But the agricultural giant's feisty chairman pays it no more mind than a Kansas farmer does a passing squall.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Airways Plans To Buy Up to 60 Jets
description: British Airways said yesterday that it was inviting five airplane makers to bid for an order of up to 60 regional jets worth $1 billion. The airline said some of the planes would replace 13-year-old Boeing 737-200's now used on domestic routes within Britain as well as routes to continental Europe from regional airports in Birmingham, Edinburgh, Glasgow and Manchester.

title: NBC President Criticizes Dole On Telecom Bill
description: Robert C. Wright, the president of NBC, said today that recent comments by Senator Bob Dole about changing the telecommunications bill to include an auction for broadcast spectrum rights make it far more likely that NBC and other broadcasters will drop their support of the bill

title: Salman Rushdie, Ever Elusive, Arrives for Dinner and a Show
description: Salman Rushdie slipped into New York City this week, continuing his tentative return to public life with plans for dinner at a downtown restaurant, a semipublic reading and a taped appearance on the "Donahue" show.

title: Perfect Weather to Patch a Thousand Potholes
description: The Metro-North commuter line managed to run all but one of its 123 trains during the morning rush. All of the Long Island Rail Road's 144 trains made their scheduled weekday morning runs. New York City sanitation workers picked up garbage.

title: Franklin G. Bishop, Executive And Philanthropist, Dies at 75
description: Franklin G. Bishop, a businessman and philanthropist who delighted in blending capitalism with left-of-center politics, died on Sunday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 75.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Shares Plunge; Fake Message Cited
description: The stock of the beleaguered Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. tumbled by a third yesterday but rebounded after the company accused speculators of crudely forging a facsimile message purporting to show that the company's losses were worse than expected. The hoax fax was sent over the weekend to the daily newspaper De Volkskrant on the letterhead of Fokker's parent, Daimler-Benz Aerospace.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Charles M. Davis was named to the new position of senior vice president for marketing at Disney Online, Burbank, Calif., part of the Disney Interactive unit of the Walt Disney Co. He was previously senior vice president for circulation and consumer marketing at TV Guide, New York, which is owned by the News Corp.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Loss in the Caribbean, From Birth On
description: THE AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF MY MOTHER By Jamaica Kincaid 228 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $20.

title: Bill Goodstein, 56, A Representative For Baseball Players
description: Bill Goodstein, the lawyer who fiercely represented two of the most prominent New York baseball players of the 1980's, Darryl Strawberry and Dave Righetti, died Saturday after collapsing at his Manhattan office. He was 56.

title: Burlington Northern Will Eliminate 2,600 Jobs
description: The Burlington Northern Santa Fe Corporation said today that it would take a pretax charge of $585 million in its fourth quarter to cut about 2,600 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, and shed thousands of miles of little-used track.

title: Samsung Plans Plant, Again
description: Samsung Electronics will announce plans on Tuesday to build a $1.3 billion semiconductor fabrication plant in Austin.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Jordan Ignites Final Quarter
description: The injury-depleted Washington Bullets were three quarters of the way to defeating the Chicago Bulls today, when Michael Jordan decided that he had seen enough.

title: Prisoner Exchange Put Off
description: Demanding an explanation of the fate of thousands of Muslims missing in Serbian-held parts of Bosnia, the Bosnian Government today postponed one of the largest scheduled exchanges of prisoners of war.

title: HOCKEY;Lindros Reaches a Milestone as the Flyers Win
NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Sterling Forest Payment Urged
description: So the House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, wants to spend 20 million Federal dollars to buy the New York portion of Sterling Forest? Great, New Jersey Republicans say. Just don't forget the people who have already laid out money to preserve the land on the New Jersey side.

title: Editorial Notebook;Here We Go Again
description: F. Scott Fitzgerald said that there are no second acts in American lives, but the Republican Party aims to give it a try. The G.O.P. wants to recreate the glory days of 1981, when President Reagan pushed a budget through Congress by rallying enough conservative Democrats to his side to get a majority. Now the Republican Congressional leaders say they will attempt to persuade a handful of Democratic senators and at least 55 Democratic House members to provide a two-thirds majority for their seven-year balanced budget plan that could withstand a veto from President Clinton.

title: Flawed Diamond Is Clue To Rock's Hellish Journey Through Deep Earth
description: A BLEMISHED diamond, worthless as a gem, is reinforcing the idea that the earth's crust can plunge down hundreds of miles into the planet's hellish interior and re-emerge, recycled and transformed.

title: CHRONICLE
description: GLADYS KNIGHT and the Pips performed a concert at the Pine Knob Amphitheater in Detroit on July 27, 1974; the concert, unbeknown to Ms. Knight, was taped. A single record was produced -- a combination of "The Way We Were" and "Try to Remember" -- and then the recording went into oblivion in a warehouse, even as the group's popularity continued to soar.

title: N. F. L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIP;Cowboy Says Rules On Blocks Can Change
description: The man who made the block heard round the playoffs, Dallas offensive tackle Erik Williams, reiterated again today that his block on Green Bay nose tackle John Jurkovic Sunday was legal. But Williams acknowledged that the league should consider changing some of the blocking rules.

title: Two '60's Army Defectors Are Alive in North Korea, U.S. Says
description: At least two American soldiers who fled their bases in South Korea more than three decades ago are alive, apparently well and living in North Korea, Pentagon officials said today.

title: N. F. L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIP;Monday Matinee in Steelers' Camp: The Surreal Meets the Super Bowl
description: A day after the Steelers defeated the Colts for the American Football Conference championship, the team's headquarters was transformed into the setting of a Fellini movie.

title: William P. Tavoulareas, 75, Former Mobil President, Dies
description: William P. Tavoulareas, former president and chief executive of the Mobil Corporation, whose libel suit against The Washington Post in the early 1980's caused concern about whether journalists could continue to write aggressive investigative stories, died on Saturday at Boca Raton Hospital in Florida.

title: Science Times E-Mail
description: Science Times has an electronic mail address for comments from readers about published articles and suggested areas of coverage: scitimes

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Arjo Will Cut 690 Jobs
description: Arjo Wiggins Appleton P.L.C., a British paper and pulp company, said yesterday that it would cut 690 jobs in Britain and continental Europe and would dispose of its specialty paper unit in Germany. The cutbacks will result in special expenses of L62 million ($96 million), the company said. Arjo will cut 260 jobs in Britain, 235 in France, 180 in Belgium and 15 in Germany. More than half of the cuts will be in the carbonless and thermal paper operations. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Support Case Father Is Seeking Welfare
description: Jeffrey Nichols, an investment adviser who was imprisoned on Rikers Island for not paying child support, said he has applied for Vermont welfare benefits as he tries to restart his precious metals consulting business.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Health Problems Over, Runner Set for Millrose
description: In the fall of 1992, when Brandon Rock was a good but not great 800-meter runner for Taft (Calif.) Junior College, he suffered a kidney infection. Doctors prescribed the steroid prednisone. His weight ballooned. He ran badly. And that was only part of it.

title: Patterns
description: New Liz Claiborne Lines

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Chastened by High Jobless Data, Paris and Bonn Seek a Solution
description: With both France and Germany staggering under the burden of chronically high unemployment, President Jacques Chirac said today that he and Chancellor Helmut Kohl had discussed the idea of coordinating measures to stimulate flagging economic growth throughout Europe.

title: Girl, 9, Kidnapped While Riding Bike
description: The police searched today for a 9-year-old girl who was reported to have been dragged screaming off her bicycle on Saturday by a man driving a pickup truck.

title: TV SPORTS;Three Men in a Booth Give NBC a New Voice
description: After teaming Dick Enberg with Merlin Olsen, Bill Walsh and then Bob Trumpy, NBC must have realized that two analysts were needed to match the mirthful power of Fox's John Madden. Paul Maguire long deserved the No. 1 slot beside Enberg. But Phil Simms had never spent a minute in a game booth.

title: McCall Faults Job Agencies Under Cuomo
description: The Pataki administration has found an unlikely partner in its efforts to portray former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's job development agencies as mismanaged: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, New York's top elected Democrat.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Jerry & Ketchum Wins 2 Accounts
description: Jerry & Ketchum in New York has been awarded assignments from the Collagen Corporation and the Block Drug Company. The billings were not disclosed.

title: Practicing Space Work
description: Two spacewalking astronauts manhandled a 250-pound beam, laid cable and read warning labels in the dark void today, breezing through a series of training exercises for building the international space station.

title: Ivory Tower Eluded Baby-Boom Academics;Yale Helps Students
description: To the Editor:

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Loyola Halts Tired Jaspers
description: Heavy traffic delayed the arrival of Loyola of Maryland team bus to Draddy Gymnasium by 30 minutes last night. But once the Greyhounds stepped onto the floor against Manhattan, they put their act in high gear and sped past the Jaspers for a 59-54 victory.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;A Very Bad Week for Mac Lovers
description: INOPPORTUNITY knocks, too, and few companies have been answering the door in recent months as frequently as Apple Computer Inc.

title: For Peter Brook, 'Hamlet' as Starting Point
description: For Peter Brook, theater is much like an expedition into the unknown; a text may serve as a map but does not define the objective. The director must decide how to use the map and what route to take. Yet even then, only by trial and error, by probing one road and then another, does the destination come into sight.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Delving Anew Into the Works of a Familiar Old Master
description: Beethoven's "Archduke" Trio will undoubtedly spin on the turntable of the mind come 7 P.M. on Saturday. It has, after all, been engraved there in each of the last two weeks: first on Jan. 7 in a Beethoven program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and last Saturday in a daylong marathon that was part of a festival, "Beethoven: A Few Days in New York," sponsored by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center.

title: Richard N. Reuben, Neurologist, 75
description: Dr. Richard N. Reuben, a professor of clinical neurology at the New York University School of Medicine, died on Sunday at White Plains Hospital. He was 75 and lived in White Plains.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Browns to Present Case to N.F.L.
description: ART MODELL will present his case for moving the Cleveland Browns to Baltimore in meetings today in Atlanta before two National Football League committees and again tomorrow with all 30 N.F.L. owners. Cleveland Mayor MICHAEL R. WHITE will also speak to the owners.

title: By Design;Dressed for City Skiing
description: Maybe designers know more than meteorologists. Ski-inspired clothes were a major theme in many collections for this winter, and nothing could be better for braving the fierce weather. Snug-fitting jersey ski pants, a turtleneck sweater and a parka have become the uniform of choice for countless people with no intention of hitting the slopes.

title: HOCKEY;On the Ice, Peluso Spares No One
description: Mike Peluso wears his emotions on his sleeve, probably near the top of his left arm where he has a large tattoo of the Stanley Cup. He may be the biggest pugilist on the Devils but he is one of the most likable hockey players off the ice.

title: In Atlanta for King Day, Clinton Hears the Cheers
description: The official Martin Luther King Jr. Day celebration here today was by turns solemn commemoration, musical tribute and raucous political rally for President Clinton, who told the supportive audience that were King alive today he would probably applaud the nation's peacekeeping efforts abroad and progress toward social equality at home while insisting that it was "not nearly good enough."

title: N. F. L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIP;Packer Coach Is Improving
description: Gil Haskell showed improvement today, a day after the 52-year-old Green Bay Packers assistant coach fractured his skull when slammed to the ground during a sideline accident in Sunday's National Football Conference championship game with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: King of Tiny Land Circled by South Africa Dies in Car Plunge
description: King Moshoeshoe II of Lesotho, a tiny nation surrounded by South Africa, died early today when his car plunged off a cliff, the Lesotho Government announced.

title: Prisons Are a Bargain, by Any Measure
description: All 30 Republican governors elected or re-elected in 1994 promised to get tough on crime. Most, like George Pataki of New York, are keeping their word. But several, like Tommy Thompson of Wisconsin, who has said he would build no more prisons, are quietly promoting plans to put more convicted criminals back on the streets.

title: COMPANY NEWS;J. C. PENNEY SELLING ITS CREDIT-PROCESSING DIVISION
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would sell its credit card processing division to Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe, a New York investment firm. Welsh, Carson will pay more than $100 million for the unit, called J. C. Penney Business Services Inc., according to a person close to the negotiations. J. C. Penney would not comment on the terms. The unit, which processes credit cards for petroleum and retail companies, is said to have annual revenue of about $100 million. J. C. Penney said it expected to see a small gain when the sale is completed.

title: Louis W. Tordella, 84, Who Helped Break German Military Code in World War II
description: Dr. Louis W. Tordella, a mathematician who helped break the German military code in World War II, and later spent 16 years as the deputy director of the National Security Agency, died last Tuesday at the Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 84 and lived in Kensington, Md.

title: Civilians Flee Guerrilla Attacks in Liberia
description: Ships of an African peacekeeping force have evacuated more than 100 civilians from a port in southwestern Liberia because of attacks by guerrillas.

title: George Smith, Basketball Coach, 83
description: George Smith, who coached Jack Twyman in the early years and Oscar Robertson in his last years as he helped guide the University of Cincinnati's basketball program to national prominence from 1952-60, died of cancer on Sunday night. He was 83.

title: N. F. L. CONFERENCE CHAMPIONSHIP;Cowboys Are Steeled Against Every Obstacle
description: One of Troy Aikman's finest qualities is that he seems to always have a certain calmness about him. He is dependable and steady, and though he will go through his ups and downs as the season progresses, in the end he will always be there.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nelson's Moves and Ewing's Misses Sink Knicks
description: The players made crucial mistakes, including Patrick Ewing, who missed two pressure free throws. The coach made questionable decisions. And the Knicks continued their disturbing swoon.

title: New Protections for Abused Children
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani gave child welfare center stage in his State of the City address on Thursday. He said he would not only shake up New York City's much-criticized bureaucracy -- separating the Child Welfare Administration from the Human Resources Administration -- but that he would also take strong action against abusive parents to protect their children.

title: Colorado Tries College Aid Based on Need, Not on Race
description: As states reconsider their race-based scholarships after a Supreme Court decision last May suggested they are unconstitutional, Colorado is beginning to give preference based on class, not race, in granting state-financed college scholarships.

title: On Deadline, Yale Students End a Strike
description: Facing the loss of teaching jobs for the semester that began today, graduate students at Yale University who had withheld grades from classes they taught last fall gave in and ended their grade strike.

title: If We're So Tired, Why Aren't We Rich?
description: An idea has been gaining currency lately that goes something like this. The source of frustration and anxiety for so many Americans today is that they simply expect too much. Although the income gap may have widened and real wages fallen over the last couple of decades, most people are still much better off than their grandparents or great-grandparents were. Even in the Roaring 20's, almost everyone worked longer and harder than they do today, comparatively few had pensions, people readily died of minor diseases and half the population didn't even have indoor plumbing. Americans simply became accustomed to an artificially high standard of living during the postwar era that can no longer be sustained.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When CAROL BUCKLEY began writing her memoirs, "I was only half revealing, and it didn't work," she said, adding, "I had to go the whole way or not at all."

title: Dog Census Is Proposed
description: The state's Agriculture Commissioner has proposed making a count of all dogs in New York State in hopes of compelling more people to get their animals licensed and vaccinated against rabies. Commissioner Donald Davidsen, a veterinarian, said he would like to see the first enumeration of the state's dog population since 1982. At that time, about 1.1 million dogs were counted in the state. Only about 560,000 dogs are now being licensed in New York each year, Mr. Davidsen said.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Texas Family Will Acquire Omni's Hotels in the U.S.
description: The Omni Hotels Corporation said yesterday that the Rowling family of Texas had agreed to buy its hotels in the United States from Wharf (Holdings) Ltd. of Hong Kong for about $500 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAPCO TO SELL A 75% STAKE IN ITS COAL UNIT
description: Mapco Inc. said yesterday that it planned to sell a 75 percent stake in its Mapco Coal Inc. unit for $232.5 million in cash to focus on its gas businesses and on selling gasoline and propane. Mapco, based in Tulsa, Okla., will contribute its coal operations, valued at $310 million, to a company that will be 75 percent owned by the Beacon Group Energy Investment Fund L.P. The investor group is a $658 million equity limited partnership, affiliated with the Beacon Group, a private investment partnership based in New York.

title: Fidelity Deal In Britain
description: Fidelity Brokerage Services Inc., a British unit of the mutual fund giant FMR of Boston, said today that it was in talks to buy Hambro Clearing Ltd., the futures, options and bond clearing business of the British merchant bank Hambros P.L.C.

title: Israel and Price of Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Shepard Is Chosen As Focus Of Season
description: What the Signature Theater Company has already done for Horton Foote and Edward Albee, it now plans to do for Sam Shepard. Officials of the five-year-old Off Off Broadway company, which devotes its entire season to the works of a single living American playwright, announced yesterday that Mr. Shepard's work would be the subject of their 1996-97 season.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Camby Facing Myriad Tests on Day After
description: Doctors at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center began to conduct tests today in an effort to find an explanation for the longest 10 minutes of the UMass basketball season, the collapse of Marcus Camby on Sunday afternoon, when his coach and teammates wondered whether he would live or die.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DOWELANCO MAKES DEAL FOR LUBRIZOL'S STAKE IN MYCOGEN
description: Seeking a 46 percent stake in the Mycogen Corporation, Dowelanco will pay $126 million to acquire the 9.5 million Mycogen shares that are held by the Lubrizol Corporation, the companies said yesterday. San Diego-based Mycogen will issue about 4.5 million common shares to Indianapolis-based Dowelanco in exchange for its United Agriseeds business and $26.4 million in cash. Lubrizol, based in Wickliffe, Ohio, is Mycogen's largest stockholder. Mycogen also agreed to reacquire certain rights in oil seed technology from Lubrizol's specialty oils unit for $8 million. In the end, Dowelanco, which is a joint venture of Dow Chemical and Eli Lilly , will hold about 14 million of Mycogen's 30.4 million common shares.

title: Guardian Company Stake
description: The Guardian Industries Corporation said today that it had acquired 70 percent of the Automotive Moulding Company of Warren, Mich., The value of the transaction was not disclosed. Automotive Moulding makes both plastic and metal exterior body components for the automotive industry at four plants in Michigan and Georgia.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Holocaust: Blame and Guilt
description: Out of the enormity that was the Holocaust, profound questions arise. Some of them are raised in the ambitious new play "The Gray Zone," by Tim Blake Nelson, which runs through Jan. 27 at MCC Theater, 120 West 28th Street, Chelsea.

title: Old-Style Ward Politics Won For Turkey's Islamic Party
description: In its campaign to win votes on the back streets of this provincial Anatolian city, Turkey's pro-Islamic Welfare Party left little to Allah and nothing to chance.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday by The Associated Press about the discovery of the last missing victim of the crash of an American Airlines jetliner near Cali, Colombia, described an investigation of the role of Colombian air traffic controllers in the crash incorrectly. The inquiry is being conducted by the office of the Colombian Attorney General, not the United States Attorney General.

title: After Retreating From Politics, Ferraro Is Talking About Another Try
description: More than three years have passed since the Democratic Senate primary in which Geraldine A. Ferraro lost a bruising contest in a quest to become the first woman to be a United States Senator from New York. The former Vice-Presidential candidate walked away from that race hurt, embittered and shunning elective politics.

title: Mrs. Dole Breaks Her Arm in Fall on Ice
description: Elizabeth Dole, the wife of Senator Bob Dole, broke her arm when she slipped on ice while walking the couple's dog near their home on Sunday, the Senator's Presidential campaign said today.

title: When Can Killers Claim Sleepwalking As a Legal Defense?
description: IT is the stuff of television movies and pulp fiction:

title: Ivory Tower Eluded Baby-Boom Academics;Elite but Affordable
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pillsbury Pasta Purchase
description: The Pillsbury Company, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., agreed yesterday to acquire the Pasta House business of the Australian conglomerate Pacific Dunlop Ltd. for about $75 million. Pasta House makes pasta and sauces under the brand names Latina and Leggos' Dorato. Pillsbury, based in Minneapolis, will make an additional payment to Pacific Dunlop depending on earnings of the Pasta House business in the next three years. (Dow Jones)

title: Review/Fashion;Walking Backward to Carnaby Street
description: There was a gantlet of girls leading into Gianni Versace's show last night, teen-age girls holding either a sign that said something like "Robbie, You're the Best Forever!" or a parent's hand. The Robbie in question is Robbie Williams, formerly with the British teeny-bop band Take That, and with Oasis, one fan explained, until he was expelled after baring his rump in a pair of trousers with the back cut out.

title: Mrs. Dole to Resume Career Even if She Is the First Lady
description: Elizabeth Dole, who is carrying the flag for her husband's Presidential campaign across the country, has asked each of her hosts at each of her stops to introduce her with the same set piece.

title: NYC;Needle Attack Muddies Issue Of H.I.V. Tests
description: KNOCK wood, his daughter Colete seems in good health, Sigifredo Lopez was saying. Colete agreed, shyly nodding when asked if she was O.K. as she and her big sister, Nicole, played with Barbie dolls on the living-room couch.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ACCUSTAFF AGREES TO BUY ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL SUPPORT
description: Accustaff Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Additional Technical Support Inc., another provider of temporary employees. Terms of the deal, which is expected to be completed on March 1, were not disclosed. Additional Technical, which is based in Waltham, Mass., had revenue of $106 million for the year that ended on July 31. Accustaff, based in Jacksonville, Fla., had 1994 revenue of $137.1 million. Its shares were up $2 yesterday, to $43.50, in Nasdaq trading. Additional Technical provides employees in information technology, software engineering and other areas.

title: Stray Bullet Wounds Boy, 14, in His Home
description: A 14-year-old boy was critically wounded last night when a stray bullet entered his family's apartment in Brooklyn and struck him in the head, the police said.

title: Legal Brief Is Said to Dispute Philip Morris Over Nicotine
description: A legal brief under seal in a Virginia state court argues that secret Philip Morris documents indicate that the company runs a "tobacco extract factory" that adds nicotine to cigarettes in precise measurements.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GLOBAL INDUSTRIAL TECHNOLOGIES INC., Dallas, a maker of industrial tools, acquired Corrosion Technology Inc., Green Bay, Wis., a developer of copper-refining technology, for about $36 million.

title: Observer;Blink and You'll Miss It
description: It is often said that 37 people decide who will be President of the United States. The number seems a bit on the low side. I know experts who think it takes as many as 250, give or take the odd dozen.

title: Tests Show No Evidence of Drinking in Crash
description: The captain of an American Airlines Boeing 757 that crashed near Cali, Colombia, on Dec. 20 was not drinking, the Colombian authorities have told the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Peru Mocks Due Process
description: Lori Helene Berenson of New York City may indeed have conspired with violent terrorists, as the Peruvian Government claims, helping them obtain weapons, rent safe houses and gather information for guerrilla attacks. Or Ms. Berenson's activities with the Tupac Amaru revolutionary movement may have been strictly nonviolent, as she insists. A fair trial might have determined the answer. But a fair trial is exactly what she did not get.

title: Space Telescope Reveals 40 Billion More Galaxies
description: As if peeking through a keyhole on the inner sanctum of the universe, the Hubble Space Telescope focused for 10 consecutive days last month on one especially narrow sector of the sky, taking long-exposure photographs deeper into space than ever before achieved and recording a bewildering number and variety of galaxies stretching back toward the beginning of time.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;North Castle Hires a Castle
description: North Castle Partners Advertising in Stamford, Conn., said it expects to have someone named Castle working at the agency.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;ABC Says Its Name Is Fine the Way It Is; 2 Hits Agree to Return
description: NBC has surged past ABC this season as the network leader, and now NBC's top executive is talking about ABC disappearing altogether within the next 18 months.

title: Polygram to Buy Plant
description: The music and entertainment company Polygram said today that it had agreed to acquire the PDO compact disk plant in northern England from Philips N.V. No financial details were available. Polygram, 75 percent owned by Philips, said the plant employed 300 people and produced 60 million CD's, CD-ROM's and interactive CD's a year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Belle Admits He Chased Teen-Ager
description: The Cleveland Indians slugger ALBERT BELLE has admitted knocking down a Halloween vandal with his pickup truck while chasing the youngster across a muddy field.

title: Grand Jury Reviews Discovery Of First Lady's Billing Record
description: The White House aide who said she discovered copies of billing records that disappeared from Hillary Rodham Clinton's former law firm has been called to testify this week before a Federal grand jury in Little Rock, Ark., said Congressional investigators and witnesses who have been questioned by Federal officials.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Market Weakens, Particularly in Technology The stock market weakened, particularly in technology issues, in sluggish holiday trading, as investors worried about earnings shortfalls and Washington's continued failure to reach a budget agreement. Intel, the most actively traded stock, fell 3 1/4, to 53 3/8, as traders awaited today's earnings report.

title: POP REVIEW;Recalling the Grateful Dead's 'Blues for Allah'
description: For the last two months, news of Joe Gallant's orchestral reworking of the Grateful Dead's "Blues for Allah" album, which was planned for three nights at the Knitting Factory and ended on Sunday, was traveling fast. With the help of the Internet, the Grateful Dead underground is a busy place. And now that the band has called it quits, after the death of Jerry Garcia in August, the group's countless followers are looking to find the Dead's legacy in places they might not have looked before. Hence three sold-out shows by Mr. Gallant, an obscure bassist and bandleader on the downtown scene.

title: 2 Rivals, Worlds Apart, Vie for Packwood's Seat
description: They have been arguing about guns and taxes, salmon and jobs, abortion and homosexuals.

title: TENNIS;Seles Puts Her Mind to It And Keeps Perfect Mark
description: Perhaps Janet Lee should have realized it was not to be her day when she walked on Center Court at the same time as her opponent and the only thing announced over the loudspeaker was, "Would you please welcome back Monica Seles."

title: POP REVIEW;Doom and Destruction Above the Urban Fray
description: The impersonal clatter and sensual throb of an urban dystopia -- "where everybody's heading, but where nobody belongs" -- drive the music of Moonshake, an English band that performed on Sunday night at the Mercury Lounge. Dave Callahan, the band's main songwriter, uses a corrosive singsong voice to sketch lives on the fringe -- prostitutes and wanderers, gamblers and tranquilizer addicts -- in music that compresses multiple strains of English rock into darkly propulsive vamps.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 279.65 points, or 1.38 percent, at 20,567.07. The market was closed on Monday for a national holiday.

title: Ailing Papandreou Resigns, Asking Quick Election of Successor
description: Greece's Prime Minister, Andreas Papandreou, a towering political figure whose two-month hospitalization has paralyzed both his Government and his ruling Socialist party, resigned tonight.

title: Big Bonus Seen For Loral Chief
description: The chairman and chief executive of the Loral Corporation, Bernard L. Schwartz, is expected to receive a bonus payment of $18 million as a result of engineering the sale of his company's military businesses to the Lockheed Martin Corporation.

title: A Bitter Eviction of Hebron-Area Jewish Settlers by Israel
description: In the latest Israeli psychodrama arising from the wrenching transition to Palestinian self-rule, about 100 screaming Jewish settlers were forcibly evicted today from apartments near here that they had occupied illegally. The Israeli Government intends to use the apartments to house Israeli police officers who will remain here after much of the area is handed to the Palestinians.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Reebok's new campaign champions the athlete's will to win.
description: REEBOK INTERNATIONAL LTD., beset by competitors both larger and smaller, is hoping to reverse a serious slump in market share by substituting an exploration of inner space for a celebration of outer space.

title: Despite State Law, Freddy's Owner Had Not Insured Workers
description: State investigators have found that the owner of a clothing store on 125th Street in Harlem where seven workers died last month had not insured his employees against injury or death on the job, as required by state law.

title: Shell Refineries Get Autonomy
description: The Shell Oil Company said today that it would make separate corporations out of five refineries, making it easier to attract the cash of outside investors in a business plagued by weak operating margins.

title: Why Limits on Egg Donors Are Prudent
description: To the Editor:

title: Archeologists Rally to Defense of Flawed Giant
description: HEINRICH SCHLIEMANN, the wealthy German entrepreneur and driven excavator of ancient Troy and Mycenae, epitomized the heroic age of archeology in the 19th century. His discoveries were public sensations, seeming to solve intriguing mysteries about antiquity and bringing to light glittering treasures of gold and bronze. His most celebrated excavations in the 1870's established that the Troy of Homer was not a mythical place, but a real city whose ruins he had uncovered in Turkey.

title: On My Mind;The Poisoned Babies
description: From their first breath they are abused children -- thousands of American babies poisoned in the womb by their own mothers. When they leave the hospital, the mothers take with them the babies to whom they gave this natal gift.

title: Peter Carleton, 60, Headmaster And Executive of Fresh Air Fund
description: Peter Frelinghuysen Carleton, a member of the board and former executive director of the Fresh Air Fund in New York, died Saturday at a hospital in Seattle, where he was on a family visit. He was 60 and lived on a family farm in Dublin, N.H.

title: TENNIS;Agassi Hobbles to Victory
description: For a man who once maintained that image is everything, the explanation Andre Agassi gave for the bandage on his right knee today at the Australian Open was less than flattering.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Home Streak Comes to End For Huskies
description: Ten minutes into Connecticut's game with Georgia today, the Huskies were in trouble. They had missed 8 of their 11 shots, they had turned the ball over 8 times and they trailed the Lady Bulldogs by 11 points, 20-9.

title: Ivory Tower Eluded Baby-Boom Academics
description: To the Editor:

title: Blame Factory Farming for Mad-Cow Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Budget Growls in the Wings
description: Those Federal budget watchers who cringed last year at the thought of a political train wreck between the White House and Congress over the 1996 spending bills are not going to want to hear this.

title: Technology Stocks Drag Market Down, and Dow Falls 17.34
description: The stock market weakened yesterday in sluggish holiday trading, as investors remained worried about earnings shortfalls and the absence of a budget agreement in Washington.

title: Yeltsin's Assault on Chechens Meets Critics on Left and Right
description: If President Boris N. Yeltsin hoped that a last-minute show of force in the six-day hostage crisis in southern Russia would somehow quell his critics, he miscalculated.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Moments in the Rise and Rise of Newt Gingrich
description: The Long March of Newt Gingrich" follows the 1995 political cover boy from a lonely and precocious childhood through a dim career in the backwaters of academe into Congress and American history. Revelations are short, but the program hits the big moments and produces a believable if not particularly attractive portrait of a man whom Peter Boyer, the "Frontline" guide, calls "a ruthless romantic, a political pit bull who has cast himself as the savior of American civilization."

title: IN PERFORMANCE;DANCE
description: Deadly Power Struggles And Transient Glory 'Seduction' Manhong Kang, choreographer La MaMa E.T.C. Theater Breath 4323

title: Sports of The Times;Super Bowl's Instant Risk: No Replays
description: TWICE in two weeks, the Pittsburgh Steelers have been awarded a touchdown they didn't deserve. And they've parlayed those two touchdowns into a Super Bowl XXX date with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Jones's Tale of the (Ticker) Tape
description: The undefeated world champion ROY JONES JR., considered by many the best pound-for-pound fighter in the world, will be taking on Wall Street, for charity.

title: Britain Approves North Sea Oil Projects
description: The British Petroleum Company, the Exxon Corporation and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group received British Government approval today to develop jointly new North Sea oilfields worth L1.6 billion ($2.47 billion).

title: Democrats vs. Clinton?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;PARKER HANNIFIN TO BUY PNEUMO ABEX AEROSPACE UNIT
description: The Parker Hannifin Corporation of Cleveland said yesterday that it was buying the aerospace assets of Abex/NWL, a division of the Pneumo Abex Corporation, for $193 million in cash. Abex/NWL is an international producer of aerospace hydraulic equipment, engine thrust-reverser actuators, hydraulic pumps and other devices. The division had sales of about $200 million in 1995, evenly split between commercial and military sales. Abex/NWL, which is based in Kalamazoo, Mich., employs 1,290 worldwide. It will become a part of the Parker Bertea Aerospace Group.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Escalator Deal by Krupp
description: Fried. Krupp A.G. Hoesch-Krupp will buy a majority stake in the escalator-making portion of Orenstein & Koppel A.G. for 225 million marks ($155 million), clearing the way for sale of the rest of O.& K., Krupp said yesterday. Krupp, which owns 75 percent of O.& K., announced previously that it wanted to sell the company, primarily a maker of mining and construction equipment. O.& K. will be easier to sell without the escalator unit, Krupp said. O.& K. had 1995 sales of about 1.5 billion marks ($1.04 billion), including 300 million marks ($208 million) from the escalator unit.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;High School Ceiling Collapses
description: Students at Wayne Valley High School got a fair-weather snow day yesterday after part of the school's ceiling collapsed. The Wayne police said that about 20 tiles fell shortly after 8 A.M., presumably because of leaks caused by snow on the roof. No one was injured, but the building's architect decided that several classrooms were too dangerous to use. After making an unsuccessful attempt to rearrange the day's schedule, educators sent students home. Classes will resume today.

title: Child-Care Concern Delays Sentencing in Armored-Car Case
description: More than a year after they were convicted of stealing $35 million from some of the nation's largest banks, Robert and Susanna Scaretta, the former owners of an armored car company based on Long Island, have yet to be sentenced.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Health Care Money Depleted
description: Today, the state bank account that pays for hospital care for the poor is officially empty. This month's checks were dated yesterday, Jan. 15.

title: Market Place;The market predicts the Super Bowl and vice versa, so they say.
description: THE bull market is good for another year, no matter which team wins this year's Super Bowl. And that is just as well, because the stock market right now sees the game as very close, although last week's sharp fall in share prices has given the Dallas Cowboys a small edge.

title: German Developer Accepts Extradition
description: Jurgen Schneider, the fugitive German property developer arrested in Miami last May, has agreed to be extradited to Germany, his German lawyers said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CARGILL CREDITS FOOD DEMAND FOR EARNINGS INCREASE
description: Cargill reported earnings of $506 million yesterday for the first half of the fiscal year, up 57 percent from the same period a year ago. It was the first time in its 130-year history that the Minnesota-based food-processing giant released financial data in the middle of its fiscal year. "We were releasing it to our employees, and it was finding its way into the public anyway," Garland West, a company spokesman, said. "It's easy for misinformation to creep into the process." Robert L. Lumpkins, a Cargill vice president, attributed the strong earnings for June through November 1995 to a growing global food demand. Cargill, the world's largest privately owned agriculture and trading company, posted earnings of $671 million during in the 1995 fiscal year.

title: Lockheed Martin Cuts
description: Lockheed Martin's Manned Space Systems, which builds the external fuel tank for the space shuttle, said today that it would cut up to 200 jobs in New Orleans this year. The reductions are the result of a shrinking NASA budget and the movement of a lighter-weight external tank from development to production, the company said. As of Jan. 1, 2,565 workers were employed at Lockheed Martin's plant in New Orleans.

title: Tests of Malaria Drug From China Bring Hope and Cautionary Tales
description: THE apparent success of a malaria drug being tested in Africa has given rise to both hope and cautionary tales about the development of new drugs for this ancient disease.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOUSE OF FABRICS TO CLOSE 86 OF ITS 361 STORES
description: House of Fabrics Inc., which is operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, said yesterday that it would close 86 of its sewing and crafts stores and its distribution center in Mauldin, S.C., to raise cash. Gary L. Larkins, the chief executive, said the proceeds of inventory-liquidation sales would be used to reduce bank debts. That, he said, should allow House of Fabrics to emerge from Chapter 11. The company, based in Sherman Oaks, Calif., operates 361 company-owned stores in 34 states. It employs about 8,000 people.

title: Pogorelich Cancellation
description: The pianist Ivo Pogorelich has canceled his performances tomorrow and on Jan. 28 at Avery Fisher Hall because of illness. Tickets may be exchanged for other concerts in the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series, or refunds obtained at the Avery Fisher Hall box office. Information: (212) 875-5030.

title: Detectives Search for Clues In Off-Duty Officer's Death
description: Detectives used metal detectors and police dogs yesterday to search for clues in the shooting death of an off-duty police officer in Brooklyn on Saturday night and said they still had not determined whether the death was a suicide, a homicide or an accident.

title: Buses Using Natural Gas Do Well in Pilot Program
description: New York City buses have long been notorious for the black soot many of them spew out of their exhaust pipes. Now, as the Transit Authority is starting to convert the fleet to run on cleaner-burning fuels, several state legislators and environmentalists say the efforts fall far short of what is needed.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Expansion Raptors The Cure for Ailing Nets
description: The struggling Nets looked more divided than ever today when they couldn't decide whether a players' meeting was necessary to help them refocus and salvage the first half of their season.

title: Ferry in Nyack? Villagers Wary;Plan to Quicken Commute To Manhattan Arouses Ire
description: Four decades ago, this quaint riverfront village and the rustic landscape around it endured one of those seismic events that forever change an area's character.

title: Investigator Shoots A Man in Robbery
description: An investigator for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office shot and wounded one of two people trying to rob him in downtown Brooklyn yesterday, the police said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHECKFREE PLANS TO ACQUIRE SERVANTIS SYSTEMS
description: The Checkfree Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Servantis Systems Holdings Inc., a provider of electronic banking services and electronic commerce software, for cash and stock. Checkfree, a provider of electronic bill-paying services based in Columbus, Ohio, expects the price for Servantis to be $43 million in cash plus $122 million to $131 million in stock. Checkfree shares were up $1.625 yesterday, to $21.50, in Nasdaq trading. Servantis, formerly known as Stockholder Systems Inc., is based in Norcross, Ga., and had revenue of $61 million in the year that ended on June 30.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Continue To Gain Momentum
description: Slowly but surely, over the last six weeks, the Islanders have been playing good hockey. They are beating teams that have always given them trouble. They are making Nassau Coliseum a difficult place in which to play.

title: Talks Continue on Possible Sale of Prodigy
description: Like the child of a couple considering divorce, the Prodigy Services Company is struggling to maintain life as usual, even while its parents, I.B.M. and Sears, haggle.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;DANCE
description: Opening and Closing Fans, With a Flourish of Toes Wendy Osserman Dance Theater Workshop

title: Warm Resorts Fill As Cabana Fever Grips Icy Easterners
description: Last week's great blizzard has spurred a great exodus as East Coast residents seek refuge in the Sun Belt and other warm-weather destinations in record numbers for this time of year.

title: No Headline
description: We now find there are as many galaxies in the sky as there are stars in our own galaxy." DR. ANDREW FRUCHTER, an astronomer, on the latest discovery made withthe Hubble Space Telescope. [C10:3.]

title: INSIDE
description: Defector Mystery Unfolds

title: Chevron Plans More Spending
description: The Chevron Corporation expects to invest about $5.3 billion in 1996 on capital and exploration spending, up about 5 percent from such spending in 1995, the company said today.

title: Health Care Acquisition
description: The Standish Care Company said today that it had agreed to be acquired by Integrated Health Services Inc. of Owings Mills, Md., for $5 a share, or about $23 million. Standish develops assisted-living communities, while Integrated is a diversified health care company. Standish said that its headquarters would probably remain in Burlington and that it expected that its executives would stay with the company. Shares of Standish were up 37.5 cents, or 10 percent, at $4.125 each, in Nasdaq trading.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Net Up 10% at Tomkins
description: The British conglomerate Tomkins P.L.C. said yesterday that it had a 10 percent rise in six-month pretax profits despite lower overall sales. Profit at Tomkins, whose products include Murray lawn mowers and bicycles and Smith & Wesson firearms, said that for the half-year through Oct. 28. it earned L126.1 million ($194 million), up from L114.5 million in the period a year ago. Sales were L1.73 billion ($2.67 million), down from L1.79 billion. (AP)

title: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;Gretzky Can't Lose Under New System
description: A year ago, when the National Hockey League lockout ended, management celebrated victory over labor. Despite failing to force a salary cap or a luxury tax, team owners seemed assured that other provisions of the agreement would lessen wage inflation while increasing their control over the players.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DISNEY DEAL WITH CAPITAL CITIES/ABC ADVANCES
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division said yesterday that it had approved the Walt Disney Company's $19 billion purchase of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., after Disney agreed to sell the Los Angeles television station KCAL-TV. The department was investigating whether Disney's ownership of both the KCAL-TV and KABC-TV stations in Los Angeles would reduce competition. The deal still requires approval from the Federal Communications Commission. Disney agreed to the appointment of a trustee to sell KCAL-TV; it has nine months to reach an agreement for the sale. Federal law does not allow broadcasters to own two VHF stations in a single market. Disney had filed an application seeking a temporary waiver of the rule.

title: Sidney Ratner, 87; Scholar Specialized In Economic History
description: Sidney Ratner, a professor emeritus at Rutgers University who specialized in economic history, died on Jan. 9 at the Princeton Medical Center in Princeton, N.J. He was 87.

title: Today, 2,000 Fewer AT&T Employees
description: John Thomas's boss called him in at 9:30 this morning and handed him a thick blue folder that told him what his pension would be. So ended Mr. Thomas's 40-year career at AT&T.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A fire Monday night destroyed the Sherman, Conn., country home of PETER MARTINS, artistic director of the New York City Ballet, and his wife, DARCI KISTLER, a principal dancer with the company, who are expecting their first child.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Taiwan to Privatize Telephone System
description: The Parliament of Taiwan passed legislation yesterday to privatize the huge Government telecommunications monopoly in five years. The Directorate General of Telecommunications, whose revenues exceeded 100 billion Taiwan dollars, or $3.6 billion, last year, will initially become the state-run Chinese Telecommunications Company. The company will then re-employ 36,000 employees as it prepares for privatization.

title: HOCKEY;Gretzky's Future Is Still Uncertain
description: Wayne Gretzky's future in Los Angeles remained uncertain today after his agent and the team owners discussed a contract extension that would keep him with the Kings.

title: Trash May Outlast Snow
description: Even though sanitation workers resumed picking up garbage more than two days ago, piles of refuse are still a common sight throughout the city, and officials said yesterday that it would take at least two weeks to catch up.

title: The High Court Confronts Sex Bias
description: The Justice Department's six-year-old challenge to Virginia's policy of excluding women from the Virginia Military Institute will finally be heard today in the Supreme Court. The case is not only a reminder of the bias that still hinders women but also a chance for the Court to strengthen constitutional prohibitions against sex discrimination.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Essex Workers Get a Reprieve
description: Yesterday had been the deadline for Essex County employees to reveal their home addresses, but they are getting an extension until Friday because of last week's blizzard. The County Executive, James W. Treffinger, announced two weeks ago that he would enforce a 1978 law requiring employees to live in the county.

title: In Bonn Visit, Israeli Leader Reaches Out
description: In a speech heavily laden with emotion and the burdens of history, President Ezer Weizman of Israel thanked Germany today for its support of Israel during the last 40 years.

title: Helen Wilson, 82, Advocate for Rights Of Hospital Patients
description: Helen Wilson, a staunch advocate of patients' rights as administrator for the Association of the Attending Staff at Mount Sinai Medical Center, died yesterday at the hospital. Mrs. Wilson, who lived on the Upper East Side, was 82.

title: Fourth-Quarter Results Cap Off the Best Year Ever for the Nation's BigBanks
description: The nation's biggest banks capped off their best year ever -- reporting sharply higher operating profits yesterday for the fourth quarter -- as nearly everything went right. Revenue from loans and fees rose faster than costs, while the levels of bad loans continued to be relatively low.

title: Class Notes;On Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday, a memorable and fun lesson in civil rights.
description: The schools here were open on Martin Luther King Day, but far from intending any slight to Dr. King's memory, teachers and students chose to celebrate his life in their own whimsical ways.

title: Senator Cohen, G.O.P. Centrist, Plans to Retire
description: The corps of Senate moderates dwindled further today with the unexpected announcement by Senator William S. Cohen of Maine that he would not run for a fourth term this year.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There is an award given in New York for every accomplishment, or so it seems. And now, there are awards for people who wage war against cigarette smoking.

title: TENNIS;Becker Wins A Close One
description: The Canadian turned Briton Greg Rusedski brought back memories of last year when he gave the fourth-seeded Boris Becker a serious fright before losing by 6-4, 3-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3 today. Rusedski, an improving player who has one of the fastest serves in tennis, would not have been the first to upset Becker in this tournament.

title: Travelers Deal Cleared
description: Travelers Group Inc. said this week that the Federal Trade Commission had cleared its planned $4 billion purchase of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's property and casualty unit. Aetna agreed in November to sell the business to Travelers, which would create the fourth-largest United States property and casualty insurer. The transaction is expected to be completed in March.

title: Businessman Is Sentenced For Bilking Space Agency
