description: A Federal judge sentenced a Houston businessman today to two years in prison and ordered him and his companies to pay the Government nearly $12 million for running an elaborate, 12-year-long scheme defrauding the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Salman Rushdie;Sentenced to Death but Recalled to Life
description: Having lunch with Salman Rushdie means being prepared for the unexpected. First, there's the caller from Scotland Yard who arranges the meeting but refuses to mention the author by name, simply instructing you to bring a copy of The New York Times to a rendezvous in the lobby of a London hotel.

title: FOOTBALL;Williams May Be Beat, but He Is Never Beaten
description: Amid the smiles and handshakes and celebrations following the Dallas Cowboys' victory over Green Bay last Sunday, one player simply sat at his locker, wearing a look of satisfaction. Erik Williams may have wanted to jump up and scream, but he was too tired. He had just taken on Reggie White -- and won.

title: CBS Studies Racism Charge
description: CBS began an internal investigation yesterday to determine whether a high-level executive in its entertainment division made racist remarks at a meeting with a comedy troupe called the State, as asserted in an article in Details magazine.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Changes at Sony
description: The Sony Corporation announced yesterday that it would restructure its research and development organization and its headquarters operations, expanding the 8-company structure to 10. The company also created a new executive board, consisting of its president, Nobuyuki Idei, and four others, which will develop corporate strategy. (AP)

title: Rushdie Out of Hiding, on 'Donahue'
description: Well, guess who's here!" Phil Donahue crowed to his studio audience yesterday afternoon, his eyebrows leaping, his snowy forelock flapping as he executed the talk-show equivalent of a rabbit trick.

title: CHECHEN REBELS WIDEN RESISTANCE, HIJACKING A FERRY
description: As a band of vastly outgunned Chechen separatists held off thousands of Russian troops in the smoldering remains of a settlement near here for a third day, Chechen militants widened their campaign of hostage-taking against Russia on Tuesday, commandeering a Black Sea ferry and, reportedly, abducting the staff of a Russian electrical station.

title: Phillips Buys Fields
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company has bought three oil and gas fields in Louisiana from the Mobil Exploration and Producing Company. The three fields are in Terrebonne Parish, La., near Houma. They produce 300 barrels of oil and 11.3 million cubic feet of gas a day, Phillips said.

title: A KEY REFORMER RESIGNS IN RUSSIA
description: Distancing himself from the economic reforms that are the hallmark of his presidency, President Boris N. Yeltsin today accepted the resignation of Anatoly B. Chubais, a pillar of economic reform and the last liberal in his increasingly hard-line Cabinet.

title: No Headline
description: I've had to downsize people myself, and now it's happening to me. It's not pleasant. I tried to accept it with class, but I went through a lot of emotions -- sadness, worry, concern. Now I have a headache. -- JOHN THOMAS, dismissed after 40 years at AT&T. [B1:3.]

title: CHRONICLE
description: When HILLARY RODHAM CLINTON arrives at Borders Books in Ann Arbor, Mich., this morning to sign copies of her new book, she will be greeted by members of the Ann Arbor Hillary Rodham Clinton Fan Club. Mrs. Clinton is on a 10-city tour promoting her book, "It Takes a Village: And Other Lessons Children Teach Us" (Simon & Schuster).

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Intel's Earnings Fall Far Short Of Expectations
description: The Intel Corporation reported fourth-quarter earnings today that fell well below the estimates of Wall Street analysts, creating the potential that technology stocks could come under pressure on Wednesday, despite market gains among computer issues today.

title: Mayor Far Outpaces Rivals in Fund Raising
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani raised $1.4 million in campaign contributions in the last six months, bringing to $4.6 million the amount he has raised for his next race, according to reports filed yesterday. That places the Republican Mayor far ahead of any of his potential Democratic rivals.

title: Found: Most of Missing Matter Lost Around Edges of Universe
description: Scientists think they have identified what may account for at least half of the missing mass of the universe, the mysterious and invisible matter that shapes galaxies and keeps them from flying apart.

title: U.S. Court Hears Case Concerning Gay Troops
description: In the first appellate test of the Pentagon's two-year-old policy on homosexuals, a Government lawyer yesterday defended the constitutionality of the "don't ask, don't tell" regulations, arguing that they are necessary to preserve order and discipline in the ranks.

title: Executive Changes
description: CS FIRST BOSTON, New York, a unit of CS Holding A.G., named Laurence S. Grafstein to head its telecommunications practice as a managing director.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Gathering of Narcissuses in Full Bloom in the Hamptons
description: Without actually substituting a potato field for a cherry orchard, Henry Jaglom strikes as Chekhovian a note as he can with "Last Summer in the Hamptons." He supplies all the necessary elements: a big and tangled family, a beloved homestead about to be sold, much airing of private doubts and endless occasions for the actors to express their longings. Mr. Jaglom's resort-pastoral new film also comes with outright apologies to Chekhov, James Joyce and Jean Renoir. These apologies are well deserved.

title: What Charities Need Is a New Model
description: To the Editor:

title: 700 Jobs, Some From Jersey, Moving to Lower Manhattan
description: In a modest sign that New York City's effort to revitalize lower Manhattan is bearing fruit, the New York Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it would move 700 employees to a building in the shadow of the World Trade Center. In doing so, the company will receive $6.5 million in tax incentives.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HARNESS RACING;Filion Is Arraigned
description: HERVE FILION, the sport's winningest driver, was arraigned yesterday in White Plains on upgraded criminal charges stemming from allegations that he and three other drivers were involved in a race-fixing scheme at Yonkers Raceway.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: China Detains U.S. Attache and Seeks Recall
description: In yet another diplomatic dispute between Beijing and Washington, China has demanded the recall of an American military attache whom it detained for 19 hours last week, the State Department said today.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;When Someone Zigs Instead of Zags
description: MORALITY PLAY By Barry Unsworth 206 pages. Doubleday/Nan A. Talese. $22.50

title: Iraq Seeking U.N. Talks On Oil Sales
description: After nearly a year of rejecting a Security Council offer that would allow Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil to pay for emergency civilian needs, the Government of President Saddam Hussein is ready to discuss putting the plan into effect, United Nations officials and diplomats said today.

title: At the Nation's Table: Philadelphia;Our Lady Of the Snows
description: Last week, when Philadelphia was being smothered in 30-plus inches of snow, Michel Notredame, the owner of Cuvee Notredame, a cozy European bistro, decided it was his civic duty to keep his business open.

title: FOOTBALL;A Team Player on a Solitary Quest
description: For most of the season, Ray Seals of the Pittsburgh Steelers has been consumed by two pursuits. One was the quest to reach the Super Bowl. The other was the solitary search for truth and justice.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Leisure section on Jan. 7 and the Taking the Children column in that section last Sunday carried an outdated opening schedule for the film "Once Upon a Time . . . When We Were Colored." The film did not open on Friday; it is to open on Jan. 26.

title: Bran and Calcium May Fight Cancer
description: Scientists have uncovered more evidence that a diet high in wheat bran or calcium may lower the risk of colorectal cancer, by soaking up acids that doctors believe stimulate growth of the tumors.

title: Mr. Yeltsin's Conversion
description: The violent firefight between Russian troops and Chechen rebels in the southern Russian village of Pervomayskoye is more than the latest skirmish in a war that neither side appears willing to end. The attack by Russian forces, intended to free hostages seized last week by the Chechen fighters, seems to be Boris Yeltsin's convulsive way of preparing to run for re-election as President.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Town's Credit Rating Drops
description: Standard & Poor's said yesterday that it was lowering the credit rating on some of West New York's debt from triple B-plus to triple B, which is still investment grade. S. & P. also downgraded the town's rating outlook from stable to negative. Mayor Albio Sires said he was not surprised. "I've been screaming about the finances of the town for years," said Mr. Sires, who took office in May after defeating Anthony DeFino, who had been the Mayor for 24 years. Richard Turner, town administrator, said the S. & P. decision was based on an evaluation that ended on June 30, 1994. He expressed confidence that Standard & Poor's would react positively to the new administration's economic programs.

title: Yale Student Strike Points To Decline in Tenured Jobs
description: The restructuring of the American work force has come to campus, and at Yale University it is fueling a bitter labor dispute over the making of one of the nation's most arcane products: Ph.D.'s.

title: SUNY and CUNY Heads Differ in Reactions to Cuts
description: In unusual budget testimony, the Chancellor of the State University of New York told the Legislature today that to comply with Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed cuts, the university would have to raise tuition by at least $250 a year, but he he did not ask legislators for more money to avert this.

title: Dateline' to Challenge '60 Minutes' on Sundays
description: NBC announced today the long-awaited expansion of its news magazine program "Dateline" to a fourth night, Sunday, where it will mount a direct challenge to CBS's "60 Minutes," starting March 17.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Packer Coach Improves
description: GIL HASKELL, 52, the Green Bay Packers' receivers coach, has made significant improvement after fracturing his skull in a sideline mishap during Sunday's National Football Conference championship game with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: TENNIS;With All Eyes Upon Him, Tarango Stays Cool in Loss
description: Jeff Tarango was grumbling at the chair umpire again while his good friend Jim Courier watched impassively from the other side of the net. But on this Grand Slam occasion, there would be no coming to a boil. All Tarango would do during his narrow, four-set loss in the second round of the Australian Open today was simmer, complaining about a line call here, asking a sarcastic question there and glowering in Courier's direction after a winning drop shot.

title: BASEBALL;Majors' G.M.'s Meet, Greet and Then Retreat
description: Baseball's general managers stepped tentatively into a new phase of their off-season schedule today, uncertain what they should expect but leaning toward nothing.

title: Aide to Rep. Maloney Wins A Special Council Election
description: A. Gifford Miller, a top aide to Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, won a special election last night for the City Council seat representing the Upper East Side and Roosevelt Island.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;One Dead as Gang Fires On Police in Haiti Slum
description: An armed gang opened fire on police officers today, killing a resident and wounding four officers, Radio Metropole reported.

title: Enron Says India State Offers To Revive Big Power Project
description: The Dabhol Power Company has received a formal offer from the government of Maharashtra state in India to revive a canceled power project worth $2.8 billion, the Enron Corporation said here today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST BANK BID FOR FIRST INTERSTATE CLEARS A HURDLE
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it would not challenge the proposed friendly takeover of First Interstate Bancorp by First Bank System, because the two banks had agreed to shed about $170 million in deposits by selling Wyoming and Montana branches. But Wells Fargo & Company has made a competing hostile offer for First Interstate, which is based in Los Angeles. First Bank's operations overlap First Interstate's in a few Western states. Wells Fargo conducts retail banking only in California and competes with First Interstate in many markets there.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;13 Selected for Hall
description: AARON PRYOR, whose brilliant career was ended by drug problems and a detached retina, and WILFRED BENITEZ, the youngest fighter (at 17 years 5 months 23 days) ever to win a world title, lead the class of 1996 into the International Boxing Hall of Fame.

title: Europe Approves Deal by Kimberly-Clark
description: The European Commission said today that it would allow the Kimberly-Clark Corporation to buy the Scott Paper Company, removing the last obstacle to creation of the world's largest tissue paper company.

title: What Charities Need Is a New Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Hours Before Execution She Sought, Illinois Woman Is Given Clemency
description: Shortly before 10 A.M. today, Guinevere A. Garcia was told that her long fight to be put to death was over. The Governor of Illinois, acting hours before Ms. Garcia's scheduled execution for the 1991 murder of her husband, commuted her sentence to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

title: Fund Operator And U.S. Settle
description: An investment group that had asserted that $10,000 could be made to grow to $39.2 million in 12 years settled charges of false advertising today and agreed to pay $300,000 in penalties, the Securities and Exchange Commission said.

title: Ex-Speaker to Head Board
description: President Clinton today named former Speaker Thomas S. Foley to be the chairman of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board.

title: Museums for Minors
description: Some of the toddlers playing at the Children's Museum of Manhattan one snowy morning last week were discovering how the ear works by navigating a Brobdingnagian mock-up of one. On another floor, visitors to the World of Pooh were learning about differing sizes by putting carrots in the appropriate holes in a carrot patch.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Woman Is Charged in Death
description: A 39-year-old Westfield woman has been charged with aggravated manslaughter in the death of her 2-year-old foster daughter, Union County officials said yesterday. Last week, the woman, Janine Berreman, took the girl to a hospital, saying she had fallen. Ms. Berreman was first charged with assault; charges were upgraded after the child, Jamilia Esposito-Elfilali, died on Saturday.

title: Johnny Johnston, 80, a Big-Band Singer
description: Johnny Johnston, a popular big-band singer in the 1940's and 50's, died on Jan. 6 at his home in Cape Coral, Fla. He was 80.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CALIFORNIA ANGELS -- Invited Kevin Flora, outfielder, to spring training as a non-roster player.

title: 5th Avenue Still Has Highest Retail Rents
description: Fifth Avenue in Manhattan from 49th to 57th Streets still represents Tiffany-like tastes in the retail real estate market, according to the Hirschfeld Group, a New York consulting firm. In the group's seventh annual survey of how much retailers pay for the privilege of a prestigious address, Fifth Avenue remained the world's most expensive street.

title: Dr. Benjamin Pasamanick, 81, An Educator and Psychiatrist
description: Dr. Benjamin Pasamanick, a retired educator and psychiatrist who focused much of his research on the mental and physical development of fetuses, infants and young children, died on Friday at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 81 and had lived in Schenectady since moving from the suburbs of Albany in 1992.

title: Guatemala's Democracy Is Only Skin-Deep
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Street Cave-In Nearly Swallows School Bus
description: A 12-foot-deep crater appeared yesterday at a Brooklyn street corner where century-old sewer and water lines come together, nearly swallowing a small school bus carrying eight special-education children in East New York.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BARNEY'S SAYS IT HAS LESS THAN $1 MILLION CASH
description: In an indication that the bankruptcy filing by Barneys Inc. might have been precipitated by more severe financial troubles than the retailer initially indicated, the company's chief financial officer said yesterday that Barney's had less than $1 million in cash on hand. "The company essentially has no operating cash at this point," Irvin Rosenthal, the company's chief financial officer, said during a court hearing at which the company sought court approval for the first part of a $100 million credit line from the Chemical Banking Corporation. Federal Bankruptcy Judge James L. Garrity Jr. objected to the request, saying that the company had failed to provide him and its creditors with copies of the loan agreement until just before yesterday's hearing. He scheduled another hearing for today. The Isetan Company, the Japanese partner of Barney's, objected to the terms of the loan agreement.

title: K. F. Montgomery, 92, Lawyer Who Established Scholarships
description: Kenneth F. Montgomery, a Chicago lawyer who backed his belief in education by providing scholarships to several leading colleges and universities, died on Sunday at his home in Northbrook, Ill. He was 92.

title: BASKETBALL;Nelson Seeks Answers As the Knicks Slide
description: Instead of characterizing his team's poor play as a natural disaster, Coach Don Nelson prefers to think of the Knicks as being in the midst of a storm. At any rate, he planned to sift through the rubble tonight during an impromptu practice at the Los Angeles Sports Arena.

title: Ex-Chairman of United to Take Over at USAir
description: Stephen M. Wolf -- the former chairman of UAL, the parent of United Airlines -- apparently prefers the smell of jet fuel to roses.

title: Wine Talk
description: WITHIN the last three years, several Burgundy wine shippers have discreetly added two words to their labels: pinot noir.

title: Drive-By Shooting Near Hebron Kills Israel Army Doctor and Driver
description: Palestinian gunmen ambushed and killed two Israeli soldiers tonight north of Hebron, apparently in revenge for the assassination of Israel's most wanted terrorist 11 days ago.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State of the State's Money
description: On Jan. 27, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman will release her budget for the next fiscal year. State Treasurer Brian W. Clymer announced yesterday how well he had done on revenue predictions so far this fiscal year. According to The Associated Press, he said the state had taken in $7.3 billion through Dec. 31 -- about $42 million, or 0.6 percent, below projections.

title: Ex-Executive Pleads Guilty in Fraud Case
description: Peter T. Caserta, the former chief executive of Spectrum Information Technologies Inc., pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges of conspiracy and mail fraud and agreed to pay $1 million in fines and restitution.

title: BASKETBALL;Hurting Suns Fire Westphal
description: Paul Westphal was fired as coach of the Phoenix Suns today, becoming the fall guy for an injury depleted team that has struggled to a 14-19 record three years after reaching the National Basketball Association finals.

title: Paris Journal;The Secret Mitterrand Couldn't Take With Him
description: In death even more than in life, former President Francois Mitterrand has brought France face to face with questions of personal and political morality that go to the heart of what it means to be French.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about the exhibition of Vermeer paintings at the National Gallery misidentified a work that the Louvre declined to lend. It is "The Astronomer." ("The Geographer" was lent by the Stadelisches Kunstinstitut in Frankfurt.)

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Dolphins' Johnson Will Also Be G.M.
description: The Miami Dolphins' new coach, Jimmy Johnson, got the title of general manager today to go with two new assistants who confirmed that they would join his staff.

title: Cooking And Dating: A Guy's View In the Kitchen
description: COOKING GUYS are different from Young Women.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Bucs Like Dungy
description: TONY DUNGY, the Minnesota Vikings' defensive coordinator, has emerged as the leading candidate for the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' coaching job.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Biggest Banks Report Their Best Year Ever Profits soared at the nation's biggest banks for the fourth quarter, capping off their best year ever. Revenue grew for loans and fees, and bad loans remained relatively low. But in 1996, analysts said, the banks' fortunes may fade somewhat, because of falling interest rates and increased losses on consumer loans.

title: Cookbooks That Pup Ole! In the Kitchen
description: FOR those who would like to put some Latin American spin on home-cooked meals, there are new cookbooks to consult.

title: Two Brothers on Trial in Officer's Killing in Cycle Shop
description: Both the prosecution and the defense agree that Vernon and Lavonne Smith set out for Frenchie's Cycle World in Canarsie, Brooklyn, in December 1994 intent on stealing bicycles. Both say that the brothers, their uncle and a friend were buzzed into the store one frigid afternoon and set in motion a robbery that went violently awry, ending with the fatal shooting of a 26-year-old police officer, Raymond R. Cannon Jr.

title: Guatemala's Democracy Is Only Skin-Deep
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. Man Is Charged In Killing of Wife
description: A 31-year-old man was charged today in the stabbing death of his estranged wife, whose body was found in a pool of blood in her Hempstead apartment on Monday night with her five children weeping nearby.

title: FILM REVIEW;3 Paul Bowles Stories And a Hint of Hitchcock
description: Coolly enigmatic, with hooded eyes, a patrician accent and an air of unbreachable hauteur, the author Paul Bowles suggests a highbrow Alfred Hitchcock in his introductions to the film adaptations of three of his short stories in the movie "Halfmoon" at the Film Forum.

title: Book Notes
description: Tiny Volumes

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES A BILL REGULATING CHILDBIRTH STAYS
description: With the passage of a bill by the Assembly today, the Legislature is close to adopting a law providing newborns and their mothers the option to stay in the hospital for at least 48 hours after birth, siding with doctors who have complained that in many cases mothers are being discharged too quickly.

title: Sports Authority Extends Chief's Pact
description: Robert Mulcahy, the chief executive of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority since 1978, will have his contract extended through January 1998.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ex-Premier to Lead Socialists in Japan
description: Tomiichi Murayama, who stepped down as Prime Minister last week, was re-elected today as head of the Socialist Party, the second-biggest partner in the country's three-party coalition.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;30-Year Bond Yields 6.05% After Rally
description: Prices of Treasury securities surged yesterday, supported by a stronger dollar, which makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors; by lower oil prices, and by reports of weak retail sales.

title: Subway Bombing Suspect Prepares Court Defense
description: As jury selection began yesterday, lawyers for Edward J. Leary said he never intended to hurt anyone in a lower Manhattan subway firebombing that injured 48 people. Rather, they said that he was suffering from a mental defect at the time brought on by Prozac and other drugs prescribed to him.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: McKECHNIE P.L.C., London, an automotive concern, agreed to buy Thompson International Inc., Troy, Mich., a wheel-trim maker, for $50.4 million and the assumption of $14.6 million in debt.

title: Europe Clears Lufthansa-S.A.S. Link
description: The European Commission cleared a cooperation pact today between Lufthansa of Germany and Scandinavian Airlines System on the condition that the airlines take steps to insure the link does not turn into a monopoly.

title: Personal Health
description: IN years past, doctors were taught, and the public generally assumed, that people who walked, talked, wet the bed, screamed in terror or thrashed about in their sleep had severe emotional disorders that needed psychiatric attention. Now many doctors say that while psychological stress can certainly touch off such sleep problems in a susceptible person, the fundamental cause is a slip-up in the brain mechanisms that regulate the stages of sleep.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Justices Reject Challenge Of Patent for AIDS Drug
description: The Supreme Court today refused to hear a case challenging an exclusive patent that has prevented lower-cost, generic versions of the leading AIDS medication from entering the market.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KLOSTER CRUISE TO CLOSE ROYAL CRUISE LINE
description: Kloster Cruise Ltd., the United States unit of Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings A.S. of Norway, said yesterday that it would close its Royal Cruise Line unit and transfer the ships to its Norwegian Cruise Line fleet between March and May 1996. Royal Cruise Line's offices in San Francisco and Athens, Greece, will be closed, Kloster said. Kloster, based in Coral Gables, Fla., plans to change its name to Norwegian Cruise Line Ltd. After the consolidation, Norwegian Cruise will operate eight ships, with nearly 10,000 berths, the company said.

title: Friendly South American Dining in New York
description: Ruth Reichl offers thumbnail reviews of some popular Manhattan restaurants with a Latin influence.

title: 14 Arrested in Nicaragua Church Bombings
description: The Nicaraguan police said today that they had arrested 14 suspects in connection with a string of church bombings that have unsettled authorities as the nation prepares for a visit by Pope John Paul II on Feb. 7.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKWELL TO SELL ITS PRINTING PRESS DIVISION
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Goss printing press business, which it said had held back its profits. Rockwell said it wanted to sell the Rockwell Graphic Systems division, a newspaper and commercial printing-press unit that manufactures the Goss presses used by two of every three daily newspapers in the country. The graphics unit, based in Westmont, Ill., had sales of about $700 million for the year that ended on Sept. 30. The company, a maker of the United States space shuttles and the B-1 bomber, also reported that its net income rose 16 percent, to $192 million, in its fiscal first quarter, compared with $165 million a year earlier.

title: FOOTBALL;New League Is Planned by Former Stars
description: Plans for All Star Football, a projected professional league with teams in New York and 15 other cities, were announced yesterday. The league intends to play on Sundays at 3 P.M., New York time, in direct competition with the National Football League, and it plans to have its games nationally syndicated for television.

title: BIG EAST REPORT
description: Rutgers

title: Childless By Choice
description: This year, the first wave of the baby boomers turns 50. For many of the 38 million women born during the baby boom, the biological clock so many watched anxiously is winding down forever.

title: POP REVIEW;Joe Cuba and His Sextet, Bilingually
description: The mood at Joe Cuba's show at S.O.B.'s on Monday night was relaxed amiability. Mr. Cuba, a conga player, had a series of cross-cultural hits in the 1960's -- "Bang Bang" was the biggest -- and since then has been quietly leading his sextet. His small group is a road band that makes dance music, and like many another good band of this sort, it is capable on occasion of reaching a kind of dance transcendence.

title: FOOTBAL;Modell's Emotional Plea Moves Owners
description: Art Modell arrived quietly to plead his case before his National Football League brethren. Seeking their votes to approve moving his Cleveland Browns to Baltimore, Modell entered an airport hotel meeting room tonight to talk to 12 fellow owners, unseen by a clutch of news media.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ITT ANNOUNCES HOTEL AND CASINO DEALS
description: The ITT Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the Sheraton Skyline Hotel at Heathrow Airport in London, which it had managed since 1971, and a resort in Cancun, Mexico. Terms of the acquisitions were not disclosed. The Sheraton Cancun Resort and Towers was bought from Grupo ICA of Mexico, the company said. ITT also said it had been selected by Athens Casino and Resorts S.A., a consortium of Greek businesses, to operate what would be the only private casino in Athens.

title: Blinder Plans To Leave Post As Fed's No. 2
description: Alan S. Blinder has told the White House that he will leave as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve when his term ends in two weeks, Fed officials said yesterday.

title: Persian Gulf Security
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SOUTHAM ANNOUNCES CHARGE AGAINST EARNINGS
description: Southam Inc., based in Toronto, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge against 1995 earnings of $120 million (Canadian), or $88.1 million (United States) as part of a three-year plan to cut 750 jobs and reorganize Canada's largest daily newspaper publishing company. Southam said the elimination of 750 of its 7,800 jobs would cost the company $80 million (Canadian). Southam said the rest of the charge, or $40 million, reflected the accounting for redundant assets at its Pacific Press, partly because of the move into new facilities. Southam earned $44 million on revenues of $1.2 billion in 1994.

title: Yes, Worry About the Budget Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Nation's Table: Terlingua, Tex.;Dinner Out, In the Desert
description: In remote Terlingua, Tex., in the mountainous Chihuahuan desert near the Mexican border, where basic amenities like indoor plumbing are not taken lightly, dinner matters. That's why "What's tonight's special?" usually refers to the Starlight Theater among the mix of locals, Rio Grande rafters and the on-location film crews who frequent this restaurant that was once a movie theater.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Risotto and Mushrooms, Flavored by Red Wine
description: Using red wine to enhance the flavor of mushrooms turns this usually white risotto dish a lovely shade of rose. With green peas, it is as pretty as it is delicious. Serve it with a salad of arugula and oranges.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Market Place;Energy Conversion Devices hopes to ride electric cars.
description: WHEN the General Motors Corporation announced earlier this month that it would be the first of the Big Three auto makers to market electric cars in four Western cities, the stock prices of eight companies whose primary business is electric cars rose sharply. But that does not mean that this is necessarily the time to buy them.

title: The Talk of Hollywood;At MGM, Doubts Cloud Successes
description: Metro Goldwyn Mayer has endured a cruel fate over the last three decades. Once Hollywood's greatest studio -- "MGM has more stars than there are in heaven," the saying went in the 1930's -- it has in more recent years been crippled by corporate takeovers, financial defaults and the sale of its film library. In 1970, it held what amounted to a gigantic fire sale in which such items as Judy Garland's white dress from "Meet Me in St. Louis" and Johnny Weissmuller's loincloth from the "Tarzan" movies were auctioned off. MGM was given up for dead.

title: HOCKEY;McInnis's Journey to Center Ice
description: Marty McInnis has played a lot this season because of his defensive abilities. That might sound a little strange for someone who scored 25 goals two seasons ago.

title: Real Estate;Providence, R.I., is getting a $375 million shopping mall after nine years of planning.
description: THE development of a regional shopping mall in downtown Providence, nine years in planning, has moved into the site-preparation phase after final approval from the city.

title: Journal;Cut To the Chase
description: God forgive me, but I was on the verge of taking Alfonse D'Amato, grand Whitewater inquisitor, seriously. Then, on last Thursday's "Nightline," Ted Koppel came to the rescue by asking the Senator the following: "What if you can prove the worst of what you suspect? What's going to happen? . . . You don't impeach a First Lady. None of these things appears to be an indictable offense. Where will it all lead other than to some kind of political effect in this upcoming election?"

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks rose slightly here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 3.19 points, or two one-hundredths of 1 percent, at 20,570.26. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 279.65 points, or 1.38 percent.

title: Food Notes
description: Six-Course Benefit

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Utility Seeks Shift on Rates
description: New Jersey's biggest utility company asked state regulators yesterday to change the way its rates are set, anticipating the day when consumers -- especially big ones -- can pick their power supplier.

title: Mayoral Aide Lowers Estimate on Property Tax Revenue
description: The Giuliani administration's rosy projections of an increase in property tax revenues turned grayer yesterday, increasing New York City's budget gap for the coming fiscal year and raising the likelihood of still deeper cuts in city spending.

title: BASKETBALL;The Tests and Questions Are Continuing for Camby
description: As Marcus Camby, UMass's star center, continued to have tests in an attempt to determine why he collapsed before a game on Sunday, his coach prepared to deal with the unsettling possibility that a specific explanation might not be found.

title: Data on Croatia's Rights Violations Lost in Theft
description: Most of the data on human rights violations in Croatia gathered by the United Nations in the last four years have been stolen, United Nations officials said today.

title: Earle Swensen, 83; Led Ice Cream Chain
description: Earle Swensen, who founded an ice cream chain that once boasted 400 shops around the world carrying his name, died on Saturday at California Pacific Hospital. He was 83.

title: As Fellow Traveler of Other Illness, Depression Often Goes in Disguise
description: Depression, which experts say is an often underdiagnosed and untreated mental disorder afflicting millions of Americans, has another overlooked dimension. The ailment is also an unrecognized complicating factor in other mental and physical illnesses, specialists say.

title: One First Lady to Another
description: Until recently, Eleanor Roosevelt was unrivaled as the most criticized, ridiculed and reviled First Lady. Every speech, every step and every new hairstyle was held up for scrutiny and judgment. Every penny she made was counted and condemned.

title: BASKETBALL;Anderson to Benefit Most From Switch by the Nets
description: With Kevin Edwards on the injured list nursing a sore knee as well as his fragile confidence, Chris Childs gets his chance to show what he can do as a starter. But the real beneficiary of the switch could be Kenny Anderson, who won't have to carry the entire burden of being a floor leader, scorer and penetrator for the Nets.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Executive Joins Publicis/Bloom
description: Tony DeGregorio, who has long been a leading creative director at New York agencies, said yesterday that he would join the New York office of Publicis/Bloom in the new position of president and chief creative executive.

title: Business Travel;Executives on the go are the main buyers of portable computers.
description: IT may be post-Christmas bargain time for desktop computer buyers, but not for executives browsing the PC market for portable machines. Toshiba's Satellites, Apple's Powerbook 5300, the LTElite from Compaq and the I.B.M. Thinkpad 755 are just a handful of the hottest sellers, according to Kimball Brown, vice president of mobile computing at Dataquest Inc., a leading market-research firm that tracks information technology.

title: Mormon Leaders in West Virginia Accused in Suit on Child Abuse
description: A lawsuit filed today accuses local Mormon leaders of contributing to the repeated sexual abuse of two children by failing to report it to the authorities.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cuts by British Brewer
description: The British brewer Scottish and Newcastle P.L.C. said yesterday that about 1,600 jobs would be lost and two of the country's biggest breweries would close as part of its integration of the Courage beer business. Scottish and Newcastle, which acquired Courage from the Australian company Foster's in August for L550 million, or $850 million, said it would close breweries in Halifax and Nottingham by October. (Reuters)

title: Pataki Brokers Timber Deal, Pleasing Longtime Foes
description: For the second time in two months, Gov. George E. Pataki has brought together longtime antagonists on an environmental issue and produced a plan that everyone appears to like.

title: ON GOLF;All Mickelson Needs Is a Little Motivation
description: It was at the Ryder Cup last September that we got the renewed sense that there was something very special about Phil Mickelson. It wasn't merely that he seemed impervious to the pressure, that he coolly worked over the European competition and was 3-0 in his matches. That was impressive, but the most telling point was that Mickelson was upset, quite miffed actually, when he didn't play in every match.

title: Doctors Tell of International Resurgence in a Variety of InfectiousDiseases
description: Infectious diseases are on a global rebound, surviving potent antibiotics and killing thousands more Americans a year than they once did, a coalition of doctors warned today.

title: A Godmother Of Politics For Giuliani
description: Mary Sansone has often said that if her basement walls could talk, she and her husband would be in jail. "Well, maybe not in jail," Mrs. Sansone amended, making it clear that she has always worked against gangsters, not for them. "But we'd end up dead."

title: HOCKEY;Devils Search for a Better Half At the Season's Halfway Point
description: The bulletin board in the Devils' dressing room underscored the status of the defending Stanley Cup champions going into the All-Star break. Although the Devils do not play again until next Tuesday, the message announced that there would be practice 12 hours after tonight's game with the Boston Bruins.

title: Sex-Abuse Fugitive Arrested in N. Carolina
description: A former New Jersey man who fled from sexual-abuse charges a decade ago, symbolizing the difficulty of apprehending interstate fugitives, has been arrested after an acquaintance read about his case in a magazine.

title: Intensifying Debate On a Fat Substitute
description: THE Food and Drug Administration will decide soon whether to approve the use of the fat substitute olestra in snack foods. But in the two other countries where approval of olestra is being sought, Britain and Canada, the information provided so far has not satisfied Government scientists.

title: Supreme Court Deadlocks In Key Case on Software
description: A closely watched Supreme Court case that was expected to define the boundaries of copyright protection for computer software fizzled today as the eight Justices who heard the case last week deadlocked 4 to 4.

title: Morty Corb, 78, Jazz Bass Player
description: Morty Corb, a jazz bassist who performed with Louis Armstrong, Ella Fitzgerald, Pearl Bailey and Nat King Cole, among others, died on Saturday at a Las Vegas hotel. He was 78 and lived in Studio City, Calif.

title: Pataki Backs Commuter Rail Refunds
description: Gov. George E. Pataki recommended last night that both Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road offer refunds to monthly ticket holders "for the severe inconvenience they experienced" after last week's blizzard.

title: Shuttle Crew's Trophies: 2 Walks and 2 Satellites
description: The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour snatched another satellite from orbit today and prepared for a second space walk in subzero temperatures, this one even colder than the first.

title: When a Chef Parent Meets a Child's Taste
description: THERE it was again, that Jeanne Moreau pout. My 4-year-old daughter's equivalent of a thumbs down. Once again, dinner was rejected and I was crushed.

title: Wall Street Looks to Information Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary last Wednesday about Mary Averell Fisk, who championed early-childhood education in 45 years as a volunteer in the New York City public schools, misstated the name of an organization she helped found. It is the New York School Volunteer Program, not the New York City Volunteer Program.

title: Turning Two Historic Theaters Into One Big One
description: Seeking his own remedy for the housing crunch facing new Broadway musicals, the producer Garth H. Drabinsky detailed a plan yesterday to turn two historic Times Square theaters into a single 1,839-seat auditorium. This would become not only one of the largest theaters on Broadway, but also the New York stop on an unusual four-city circuit of musical theaters that Mr. Drabinsky is establishing.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Czech Dissident Wins Exoneration in Spy Case
description: A Prague court has vindicated a former member of Parliament who was fighting allegations that he had collaborated with the secret police during the Communist era. The ex-legislator, Jan Kavan, had taken legal action to clear his name after he was accused of collaboration in 1991.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMOCO PLANS $380 MILLION EARNINGS CHARGE
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $380 million charge against net income in the fourth quarter for a required accounting change. In the fourth quarter that ended on Dec. 31, 1994, Amoco reported net income of $536 million, or $1.08 a share. The new accounting standard would change the way the company determines and measures the impairment of long-lived assets, or oilfields, used in its business. Amoco said it would write down the value of these assets to their current fair value, rather than writing down the value of the impaired asset over a period of years. About 80 percent of the charge was related to oil and gas producing properties in North America, Amoco said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Graf May Pay Fine
description: The ZDF television network reported yesterday that STEFFI GRAF would pay a multimillion-dollar fine to end a tax-evasion investigation that has centered on her and her father.

title: About New York;Preschoolers, His Fountain Of Youth at 87
description: AT 87 years of age, Max Mandell is convinced that standing outside his Upper West Side town house in the cold, rain or snow is good for his health.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Israelis Killed in Ambush Palestinian gunmen ambushed and killed two Israeli soldiers north of Hebron, apparently in revenge for the killing 11 days ago of a suspected terrorist wanted by Israel. Page A3.

title: Sports of The Times;Goodstein's New York State of Mind
description: HE never did see the triplets, Kandice Righetti said, tearfully. He had pictures from every stage of their 4 1/2 years, but Bill Goodstein never made it out West to hold them in his arms.

title: Terms That May Be Helpful at a Bodega or Market
description: Though a number of the ingredients essential for Latin American cooking, like plantains and jicama, have been sold in supermarkets for years, some items are just beginning to find distribution beyond ethnic neigborhoods. Here is a guide to some popular ingredients.

title: Lessons Amid the Slush
description: The Blizzard of 1996 is for all practical purposes over, uncollected garbage and mounds of dirty ice notwithstanding. The neighborhoods that got plowed last naturally complained about not being higher on the priority list. But in general the Department of Sanitation and its Commissioner, John Doherty, should be commended for performing a long, hard job well. Mr. Doherty is one of the few city commissioners in recent history to be promoted from the ranks of his department. His evident expertise reflects well on the city's often beleaguered public employees.

title: 3 Clinton Aides Deny Improper Actions
description: Three White House officials told the Senate Whitewater committee today that there was nothing improper about a 1993 meeting that Senate Republicans have sought to portray as part of an effort to meddle with investigations involving the Clintons.

title: Guatemala's Democracy Is Only Skin-Deep;Peru to Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Beware Phone Solicitors
description: If someone calls soliciting money for the New Jersey State Police, hang on to your checkbook and hang up the phone. That advice comes from Col. Carl A. Williams, the State Police Superintendent, who issued an alert yesterday about callers who invoke his agency's name. "The New Jersey State Police does not engage in any fund-raising activity," he said.

title: Guatemala's Democracy Is Only Skin-Deep
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An answer in the Q&A column of Science Times yesterday, about calculations of the length of the year in the Middle Ages, referred incorrectly in some copies to the beginning of spring. It is the spring equinox, not the solstice.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Remy's Net Rises; Operating Profit Falls
description: Remy Cointreau S.A. said yesterday that its profit rose for the six months ended Sept. 30, but its operating profit dropped 45 percent after a price increase that hurt sales of Cognac. The company also expects operating profit to drop for its full year, which ends March 31. Remy Cointreau attributed the lower operating profit to price increases for Cognac of 3 to 15 percent.

title: Foreign Affairs;NATO Or Tito
description: President Clinton took a well-deserved victory lap in Bosnia last weekend. The broad cease-fire his Administration negotiated is taking hold, and with NATO troops fanning out, the prospect of renewed large-scale warfare, or mass murder of civilians, is nil.

title: James Plaut, 83, Museum Founder
description: James Sachs Plaut, a founder and the first director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston, died on Saturday at New England Baptist Hospital in Boston. He was 83 and lived in Westwood, Mass.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Separatist Kurds Kill 11 In Ambush, Turkey Says
description: Turkish Army officials said today that separatist rebel Kurds had killed 11 people in an ambush, breaking their five-week-old unilateral cease-fire.

title: A Flawed Flat Tax and the Way Out
description: The flat tax of Steve Forbes seems to have been rooted in the dictum that "what's good for Bohemian Grove is good for America." Indeed, it appears to have been drafted on the back of a menu, after a bibilous evening, with the boys down at the yacht basin.

title: S.E.C. Close to a Settlement With 2 Orange County Aides
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is close to an agreement to settle Federal charges against two former top officials of Orange County, Calif., stemming from the county's bankruptcy.

title: In Greece, Battle to Lead Goes Public
description: The battle to succeed Andreas Papandreou as Prime Minister formally opened today as several top members of his Socialist party declared candidacies in a race that until Monday had been kept under wraps.

title: A New Source of Cookbooks for Collectors
description: JOANNE HENDRICKS, at 488 Greenwich Street (near Spring Street), is a new source for out-of-print, used and rare cookbooks and food books. She has about 700 books now and is in the market for collections. She can be reached at (212) 925-4697 and also welcomes browsers to the first floor of her house, built in 1814, where she sells the books.

title: L.I. Broker Sued Over Teachers' Loss
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued a Long Island broker yesterday, contending that he had stolen retirement money from at least five teachers. The S.E.C. charged that the broker, Wayne T. Drinkwine, had told the teachers that their money would be invested in trusts that did not exist.

title: An Offering To the U.S.: The Head Of a Fugitive
description: For years, the authorities say, Juan Garcia Abrego was one of Mexico's billionaire drug traffickers, operating freely and shielded in his stronghold south of the Texas border by a private army and millions of dollars in monthly bribes.

title: Surprise Witness in the Jordan Case
description: A surprise witness in the trial of a man accused of killing the father of the basketball star Michael Jordan linked the accused man today to a luxury car that the authorities say was stolen in the slaying.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Military Ruler Ousted By Army in Sierra Leone
description: Army officers ousted Sierra Leone's military leader in a coup today, six weeks before elections to restore civilian rule.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MULTICARE AGREES TO BUY CONCORD HEALTH GROUP
description: The Multicare Companies agreed yesterday to acquire the Concord Health Group Inc. of Williamsport, Pa., for about $130.5 million, which includes the assumption of $46 million in debt. Both companies provide long-term health care. Multicare said it would make a tender offer to acquire Concord's shares for $7.35 each, or a total of $84.5 million. The company also said it would buy Concord's warrants for $1.85 each. Concord's shares rose $1.25, to $7.125, in Nasdaq trading yesterday. Concord owns 15 long-term care facilities with about 2,600 beds, all of which are in Pennsylvania. If the Concord deal and one other are completed, Multicare will own 100 long-term care facilities.

title: Talks Said to Break Off on Link Between McDonnell and Boeing
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation and the Boeing Company have broken off discussions, at least for now, about a possible merger or a combination of some of their businesses, people with knowledge of the talks said today. But Wall Street still expressed hope that a deal could be put together.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;TRAVELERS GROUP (TRV,N)
description: Travelers Group Inc. reported a jump of nearly 82 percent in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, citing sharp gains at its brokerage and insurance businesses.

title: In Iowa, It's Organizing vs. Advertising
description: Presidential politics may have lost its romance, but the Iowa caucuses are still the stuff of legend.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Tokyo Sees Pickup In Economic Growth
description: The Japanese said yesterday that the economy appeared to be gaining momentum after a four-year recession. The Economic Planning Agency said in its latest monthly report that Japan's real gross domestic product will grow 2.5 percent in the next fiscal year, up from estimated growth of 1.2 percent in the current fiscal year, which ends in March.

title: YACHT RACING;Big Boats and Top Sailors in Key West
description: Sailing's newest offshore racing class, the One Design 48, appeared on a race course for the first time this week. But its coming-out party, which was at the Mount Gay/Yachting Race Week in Key West, Fla., had a no-show among the five sister ships expected on the start line.

title: Peter Neidig, 53, a Psychologist Known for Abuse Therapy, Dies
description: Dr. Peter Neidig, a psychologist who went against the professional grain by championing a long-shunned form of therapy for spouse abuse, died on Thursday at his home in Stony Brook, L.I. He was 53 and had been a research psychologist at the State University there since 1991.

title: BASEBALL;Interleague Play Gets a Boost
description: Major League Baseball's executive council tonight unanimously supported the introduction of interleague play for the 1997 season.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Jan. 3 about Arthur Rudolph, developer of the Saturn 5 moon rocket, misstated the given name of a former Justice Department official who headed a Federal unit that investigated the World War II activities of people like Mr. Rudolph who had worked in Nazi Germany. The former official is Neal M. Sher, not Fred.

title: Citing Security, China Will Curb Foreign Financial News Agencies
description: Citing national security, China's Government announced on Tuesday night that it would further restrict the flow of information into the nation by more closely regulating international agencies that supply financial news to China.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL Big Half for Kentucky Second-ranked Kentucky set a school record with 86 points in the first half on its way to the highest-scoring road game in its 93-year history, a 129-97 romp over L.S.U. last night in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Stocks Advance, Spurred by a Rally in Bonds
description: Stocks seesawed yesterday, but firmed in late trading following a sharp rally in the bond market.

title: Yes, Worry About the Budget Deficit
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Granada Buys Stake In Forte Hotel Concern
description: The Granada Group bought 9.2 percent of the shares of Forte P.L.C. yesterday in the open market in an apparent show of confidence that it will succeed in its bid of L3.8 billion, or $5.9 billion, for the British hotel company.

title: FIGURE SKATING;Presumed Skating: Juggling Marriage, a Comeback and the Law
description: Women's figure skating has become a misnomer. It is less a sport of adults than of restless teen-agers who routinely leave school and change coaches the way they change costumes.

title: Gifts to Needy, Eulogies for the Beloved
description: Not a day goes by that Judith Dickstein Remondi does not think about Grandpa Jack. He died 11 years ago last month, but Ms. Remondi can hear his voice as if they had spoken yesterday.

title: New York's Wage Bill Violates No Principle
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: MEN'S BASKETBALL Big Half for Kentucky Second-ranked Kentucky set a school record with 86 points in the first half on its way to the highest-scoring road game in its 93-year history, a 129-97 romp over L.S.U. last night in Baton Rouge, La.

title: Vietnam Air Leases Jets
description: The state-owned Vietnam Airlines said this week that it would lease 10 Airbus A320's and three Boeing 767's in the next year. Financial terms were not disclosed. The airline said it would lease the Airbuses from Aerostar Leasing, a subsidiary of Region Air Ltd., a Singapore aviation company. It will lease the Boeings through GE Capital Aviation Services, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Wilkinson Found Guilty
description: Cincinnati Bengals defensive lineman DAN WILKINSON was found guilty yesterday of striking his pregnant girlfriend during a Sept. 13 argument but evaded jail when the judge gave him a six-month suspended sentence.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;$445 Million Bergen Budget
description: Bergen County taxes would fall and actual spending would also drop slightly under a 1996 budget unveiled yesterday by County Executive William P. Schuber. The $445.9 million budget -- which the Board of Freeholders must approve -- is based on one key assumption: that nearly 4,000 county employees whose contracts expired on Dec. 31 will agree to a wage freeze in 1996. "The only alternative would be layoffs," said Mr. Schuber, a Republican who is in his second four-year term.

title: What's on the Menus, From Arepas to Tostones
description: Here are some basic menu terms:

title: Insulation Is Out at USG
description: The USG Corporation said today that it would leave the insulation manufacturing business by selling its domestic line and closing its Canadian plant, actions that will reduce earnings in the fourth quarter by $24 million.

title: Dole Campaign Accuses Forbes Aides of Fraud
description: The Presidential campaign of Senator Bob Dole of Kansas charged today that aides to Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire businessman who has established himself in recent polls as Mr. Dole's most serious challenger, had engaged in widespread fraud in his effort to enter New York's Republican primary.

title: Latin Flavors Go North With Gusto
description: FOR many years, Jackson Heights, Queens, was the epicenter of Latin American cuisine in New York. But in the last year or so, new establishments in the Flatiron district, SoHo and other parts of Manhattan have started serving arepas, churrasco, mojo sauces and empanadas, often interpreted with vibrant flair or haute cuisine finesse.

title: Housing Gains as Economic Data Rebound
description: The first in an avalanche of statistics on the economy showed today that home building was buoyant in November throughout much of the country. But in the Northeast, building slumped to its lowest pace in nearly two years.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Stolen Computers Replaced
description: Teachers were devastated when 13 computers were stolen from three Newark elementary schools during the Christmas recess, but there is a happy ending. Today, Joseph Hardiman, the president of the Nasdaq Stock Market, will visit the Franklin School to present 25 computers with color monitors. They will be locked to desks with brackets, a spokesman for the schools said. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESSA Car Buyer's Heaven In a Borderless Europe; When Lira Falls, Savvy Shoppers Win, But Car Makers Hope for One Currency
description: One reason Europe's leaders are struggling to introduce a single currency in the next couple of years is evident in Johann Lanz's car showroom here.

title: Washington AIDS Case Highlights a Rare Cause
description: After keeping it to herself for nearly a year, Washington State's top educator, Judith Billings, said today that she was suffering from AIDS after trying to become pregnant through artificial insemination with donor sperm.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-8

title: COMPANY NEWS;WORTHINGTON TO ACQUIRE DIETRICH INDUSTRIES
description: Worthington Industries signed a definitive agreement yesterday to buy Dietrich Industries for $146 million. Worthington, a maker of metal and plastic products based in Columbus, Ohio, said that under the terms of the stock purchase agreement, it would assume $30 million of Dietrich's debt. Pittsburgh-based Dietrich manufactures metal framing for the commercial and residential construction markets and had 1995 revenues of $285 million, Worthington said. Worthington said that after the acquisition, it expects to have annual sales of about $1.8 billion. In Nasdaq trading, Worthington fell 50 cents, to $19.25.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Helen Gurley Brown Leaving; Cosmopolitan Names Successor
description: Helen Gurley Brown, who took over a failing magazine called Cosmopolitan in 1965 and turned it into an industry legend, will step down as its editor in chief in 18 months. Her successor will be Bonnie Fuller, founding editor in chief of the United States edition of Marie Claire, who was named deputy editor of Cosmopolitan yesterday.

title: Offer for Mountasia Rises to $97 Million
description: Mountasia Entertainment International Inc. said today that a group led by a former director, Hisham Araim, had increased its offer to buy the company to as much as $97 million.

title: BASKETBALL;Syracuse Upset By W. Virginia
description: Gordon Malone scored 22 points as West Virginia held on to a late lead to knock off No. 12 Syracuse, 90-78, tonight for its first Big East Conference victory.

title: BASKETBALL;Bulls Tie Team Mark For Victories at Home
description: For one night, Dennis Rodman took over the title of Mr. Do-It-All for the Chicago Bulls.

title: With Resolve, First Lady Lays Out Defense
description: With lawyerly precision, flashes of humor and a determined resolve, Hillary Rodham Clinton has popped up all over the news in the last week, once again rebutting, dismissing, explaining and defending her role in the Whitewater and White House travel office affairs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Prudential's new campaign suggests that the best person to handle your finances  is . . . you.
description: THE words "Be your own rock" sound as if they might have been an exhortation offered by a hard-headed coach like Vince Lombardi or a positive-thinking preacher like the Rev. Norman Vincent Peale. But the phrase is actually the centerpiece of a campaign that seeks to use the popular notion of empowerment to polish the tatty image of the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Daily Briefing column in New Jersey copies on Saturday about Kiwi Airlines misstated its plans for a stock offering. Kiwi said an initial public offering could be made after the company has had several profitable quarters, not next month. A spokesman said the airline hoped to get cash from an outside investor as early as next month.

title: At the Nation's Table: Stamford, Conn.;All About Pastry? Got Half a Century?
description: At 80 years old, Dorothy Costas is certainly among the oldest full-time pastry chefs around. Mrs. Costas, who works at Kathleen's, a two-year-old restaurant in Stamford, Conn., could also be called the restaurant's consulting chef: Many of its most popular savory dishes, from meatloaf to lobster salad, are from her recipes, the result of a cooking career going on 60 years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Kraft Foods, Northfield, Ill., a unit of the Philip Morris Cos., to Ogilvy & Mather Chicago, owned by the WPP Group, to handle its consolidated network radio-buying account, previously divided among Ogilvy and three other agencies. The billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;For Knicks, the Game Is Won, but Oakley Is Ailing
description: Charles Smith was playing as well as he had all season. Derek Harper was hitting clutch 3-pointers as he had a month ago. When the game ended, there were even reports that Patrick Ewing was smiling.

title: Sorting Out Blizzards and 'Mild' Winters
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;A New Chief For National Geographic
description: Gilbert M. Grosvenor, head of The National Geographic Society, will retire in May as president and chief executive, to be succeeded by Reg Murphy, a former newspaper publisher who joined the society in 1993 as executive vice president.

title: Ralph J. Stolle, 91, an Inventor Who Made Pop Tops Practical
description: Ralph J. Stolle, a prolific inventor and businessman, died on Jan. 13 at his farm near Lebanon, Ohio. He was 91 and had cancer, said Nelson Schwab Jr., his lawyer.

title: Exchange Re-elects Chief
description: The board of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange re-elected John F. Sandner as exchange chairman at an organizational meeting held late on Tuesday. The Merc, a marketplace for the trading of futures contracts in various agricultural commodities and financial instruments, said Mr. Sandner had served a total of 12 years as exchange chairman, though not consecutively. Mr. Sandner is chairman, president and chief executive of RB&H Financial Services.

title: 2 Officers Charged in Drug-Related Break-In
description: Two New York City police officers were arraigned on burglary and drug charges yesterday after cash and simulated cocaine were stolen from an apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn during a sting operation, police officials said.

title: Market Place;USAir investors prove to be optimistic about new leadership.
description: THE day after USAir Group named Stephen M. Wolf, the former chief executive of the UAL Corporation, as its new chairman, USAir's share price rose $1.875, to $14.50, in trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The news of Mr. Wolf's appointment even lifted the American depository receipts of British Airways, which owns a 24.6 percent stake in USAir, to a new high of $78.375, an increase for the day of 87.5 cents.

title: It's Been an Uphill Battle to Sell Windows 95
description: As the editor of the newsletter Release 1.0, host of the industry conference PC Forum and chairwoman of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a public policy group, Esther Dyson is one of computing's elite. So shortly before Microsoft's Windows 95 went on sale last August, Ms. Dyson was an obvious choice to appear on the PBS talk show "Charlie Rose," offering her expert commentary on a new-product introduction that seemed part marketing extravaganza and part social phenomenon.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NOVELL SAYS DEAL TO SELL WORDPERFECT IS NEAR
description: Novell Inc. has narrowed the field of potential buyers for its Wordperfect unit to two and hopes to announce a deal on Jan. 26, Don Chapman, the general manager of Novell Canada Ltd., said yesterday. Novell has been offering Wordperfect, which it acquired in 1994, for some time. Mr. Chapman declined to identify the concerns in the running to buy the unit. The Corel Corporation said on Tuesday that it was interested in Wordperfect, but Mr. Chapman said Corel's comments meant that that company was among an earlier field of 10 suitors for Wordperfect. He declined to say whether Corel was still in the running now that the group had been reduced to two.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;New Coach, Same Result
description: Shaquille O'Neal scored 18 of his 35 points in the third quarter tonight, helping the Orlando Magic beat Phoenix, 113-95, and spoil Cotton Fitzsimmons's debut in his third stint as coach of the Suns.

title: Phil Donahue Announces Retirement From TV
description: Phil Donahue, the man who created the audience-participation television talk show, announced his retirement yesterday, just a half-season away from his 30th year wielding the microphone.

title: Gramm Adds Voice to Calls In the G.O.P. for Flat Tax
description: Formally joining the Republican chorus calling for a flat tax, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas today proposed taxing income at 16 percent, edging a rival Presidential candidate, Steve Forbes, by one percentage point.

title: Market Closes Lower in Erratic Trading Day
description: The stock market zigzagged yesterday, declining late in the day, in a session marked by concern over the budget impasse in Washington and the state of the economy but buoyed by the continuing strength of the bond market.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Queen Elizabeth II seems not to be feeling too kindly toward her daughters-in-law these days. After urging the Prince and Princess of Wales to obtain a rapid divorce last month, the Queen took the extraordinary step of announcing publicly yesterday that she would not bail out the DUCHESS OF YORK, who is reportedly about $1.5 million in debt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;How do you get your message across among the Times Square throng? Try turning up the steam.
description: AND now, the newest steamy special-effects sign in Times Square: a giant cup of instant soup. The 60-foot-high, red neon advertisement, for Nissin Cup Noodles, will inhabit a prime space in the middle of the north face of One Times Square.

title: Governor Pataki's Scorecard;Right on Adirondack Logging
description: New York State's Adirondack Park has long needed a champion in the Governor's office. Maybe it finally has one in George Pataki. His intervention in a bitter dispute between landowners and environmentalists has now produced a salvage-logging plan that pleases both sides. The plan would allow private landowners to harvest thousands of acres of trees damaged in a freak windstorm last July. But the plan also contains strict controls designed to safeguard valuable wetlands and protect lakes and streams from erosion.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Keep Up Battle and Subdue Hornets
description: Contrary to popular belief and even their own self-doubts, the Nets proved tonight that they can actually hold together during the tense moments of a basketball game instead of falling apart and turning potential victories into frustrating defeats.

title: Company Briefs
description: FTP SOFTWARE INC., North Andover, Mass., has agreed to merge with Firefox Communications Inc. San Jose, Calif., in a stock swap valued at $80 million to $100 million that will make Firefox a wholly owned unit of FTP. Both companies make computer networking software.

title: William R. Geiler, New York Judge, 79
description: William Richard Geiler, a retired New York State Supreme Court justice and former Republican leader of Huntington, L.I., died on Saturday in a nursing home in Dallas. A longtime Huntington resident, he was 79.

title: China Defends Expulsion of U.S. and Japanese Military Attaches
description: Explaining its expulsion of two foreign military attaches, one American and one Japanese, China said today that the officers had been warned about taking pictures in restricted military areas on Jan. 8 only to be discovered three days later on an air base in another part of southern China.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAYBELLINE GETS HIGHER OFFER, FROM BENCKISER
description: Maybelline Inc. said yesterday that Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H., the German maker of cosmetics and detergents, had offered $37 cash a share in a takeover bid, topping an offer from L'Oreal S.A. of France. In a letter released by Maybelline, the cosmetics maker based in Memphis, Benckiser said it might increase the offer to an amount "materially higher" than $37 under certain conditions. The offer is below Maybelline's closing price yesterday of $39.50. Maybelline agreed in December to a takeover by L'Oreal valued at $36.75 a share. The price, a total of $660 million, includes the assumption of about $150 million in debt. Benckiser said it would make the higher bid only if Maybelline prohibited L'Oreal from buying Maybelline shares beyond the 29 percent stake it has agreed to buy from Wasserstein Perella & Company.

title: SENIOR CLASS;Inside Prison, Too, a Population Is Aging
description: SINCE 1984, Remus Nixon's home has been a 5-by-7-foot cell in New Jersey's Trenton State Prison, where he is serving a life sentence for aggravated sexual assault. At age 53, this tall, rugged man with a mane of grizzled hair says he can "handle things" for now, but he fears what will happen as he ages and becomes more vulnerable.

description: SHOULD Marcus Camby stay in basketball?

title: Josephine Patterson Albright, Colorful Journalist, Dies at 82
description: Josephine Patterson Albright, who flew the mail, shot tigers in India, covered Chicago crime in journalism's colorful "Front Page" era, ran an Illinois dairy and pig farm, bred horses in Wyoming, wrote a column about her family and helped establish a foundation for journalists, died on Monday at her home in Woodstock, Vt. She was 82.

title: Railroads Plan Ticket Rebate Over Blizzard
description: Prodded by Gov. George E. Pataki, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority ordered the Metro-North and Long Island railroads yesterday to reimburse riders for service that was suspended or bungled during the blizzard last week.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Window Wit And Wisdom;What a Fancy Border And Some Paint Can Do
description: GREG JORDAN once designed a set of curtains that cost $75,000 for a Park Avenue client. For one room.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MAY DEPARTMENT STORES TO SPIN OFF PAYLESS SHOE CHAIN
description: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that it would spin off its Payless Shoe Source chain and take a $70 million charge in the fourth quarter. As part of the spinoff, the company expects to close or relocate about 450 of its 4,557 Payless stores. Payless, based in Topeka, Kan., is the largest chain of self-service family shoe stores in the nation, with sales last year of more than $2.1 billion. It has about 25,000 employees.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AVIA ATHLETIC-SHOE UNIT TO BE SOLD BY REEBOK
description: Reebok International Ltd. said yesterday that it planned to sell its Avia subsidiary, which makes athletic shoes. The company also predicted that its profit for 1995 would be lower than expected, because of markdowns at the end of the year. Reebok, the second-largest American maker of athletic footwear, behind Nike Inc., said it would take a charge of $34 million, or 44 cents a share, in the fourth quarter to write down the value of Avia. Many analysts have called on Reebok to shed the unit, which the company bought for $181 million in 1987 and which accounts for about 4 percent of Reebok's sales.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Trade Group Orders U.S. To Alter Law For First Time
description: In its first major ruling as the international arbiter, the World Trade Organization determined today that a key section of the Clean Air Act discriminated against foreign oil refiners. It ordered the United States to develop a plan to change its rules on imported gasoline or face unspecified sanctions.

title: BASEBALL;Thompson Anxious to Rededicate Himself
description: In the coming weeks, the Mets will be all about selling themselves. As a contender. As a team again worth the price of admission. To do that selling, they have enlisted some of the best and brightest prospects in their organization and advertised them as the future.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Alasdair Ritchie, chairman of TBWA UK, London, a unit of the Omnicom Group, was named to the additional position of president of TBWA Europe, succeeding Mike Camesasca, who was named to the new position of director for new agency development.

description: Europe has long been ahead of North America in its ability to stage invitational events restricted to world-class players and providing substantial cash prizes. The first in 1996 is the Volmac World Top tournament, beginning today in The Hague, the Netherlands.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Westin Hotels Changes Agency
description: Westin Hotels and Resorts has selected DDB Needham Chicago to handle its account after five years at Cole & Weber in Seattle, according to advertising executives who spoke yesterday on the condition of anonymity. The billings were estimated at $16 million.

title: Trial Begins for Doctor Accused of Violating Drug-Safety Rules
description: Opening arguments began here today in the trial of a a pioneering transplant surgeon accused of conspiring to violate Federal drug-safety laws for more than two decades.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Lloyd's to Tighten Its Self-Regulation
description: In a move toward greater "honesty and integrity," Lloyd's of London's regulatory board said today that it would revise disciplinary procedures and adopt a new registration requirement for about 5,000 directors and senior managers who operate in the market.

title: Palestinians Trying Out Elections, Warts and All
description: Awash in vivid campaign posters and banners, this city north of Jerusalem seems gripped by election fever these days, its crowded streets the picture of a carnival of democracy.

title: Another State-Run French Giant Deeply in Debt
description: PARIS  In one of the worst business catastrophes for a state-run industry of its size in France, the government disclosed Wednesday that a leading defense company  with a monopoly on tanks and artillery  was, in effect, bankrupt.

description: Italian newspapers have less to say about clothes this week than about bickering among the Milan designers, the elites who for this city carry the combined clout of Washington's politicians, Hollywood's movie stars and Wall Street's Masters of the Universe.

title: TENNIS;A Russian Ousts Pierce In Australia
description: Mary Pierce played remarkable and explosive tennis when she swept to the Australian Open title a year ago without dropping a set. But that memorable performance is looking increasingly like an anomaly rather than a harbinger of great things to come.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Lloyd States His Case
description: GREG LLOYD was unaware he was on live national television when he uttered an expletive in the Pittsburgh Steelers' locker room Sunday. Steelers Coach BILL COWHER supported Lloyd, saying technical difficulties had interrupted a trophy presentation ceremony and the players did not know they were on TV.

description: With her husband confined to a hospital bed, and her rivals competing for the power he relinquished only two days ago, Dimitra Liani-Papandreou, the 40-year-old wife of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou, is feeling alone and exposed.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOWER EARNINGS EXPECTED BECAUSE OF SLOW SALES
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that it expected earnings for the fourth quarter to be lower than a year earlier, even before a charge related to the spinoff of some operations, because of weak sales in December. The company's shares fell $3.50, to $63.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. The businesses to be spun off, including the computer floppy-disk manufacturing operation, were among those with the weakest sales, the company, known as 3M, said. The continuing operations, which include Post-It Notes, Scotch adhesive tapes and Thinsulate insulating fabric, are expected to have been about as profitable as a year earlier.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Republican Leaders Call Off Budget Talks With Clinton Republican Congressional leaders abruptly called off the budget talks scheduled at the White House and said they would not resume them until President Clinton produced a budget proposal that moved in their direction.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Sandoz Buys Product Rights
description: Sandoz A.G. said today that it would pay up to $37.5 million to Organogenesis Inc. for the licensing rights for Graftskin, a product containing living tissue to replace damaged skin.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Campaign Finances Assailed
description: Campaign-financing reform is a popular topic this week with Democrats.

title: F. Don Miller, 75, U.S. Olympic Committee Chief
description: Col. F. Don Miller, whose leadership in 1980 twice helped save the United States Olympic Committee from extinction, died last night in Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs. He was 75.

title: PRO BOXING;Young Turks on Ring Card
description: While George Foreman continues to give HBO and Madison Square Garden agita over whether his scheduled Feb. 29 fight against Michael Moorer really is his farewell, six fighters with a combined 138-3 record, including 107 knockouts, yesterday proclaimed themselves the future.
