title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Gain Despite Budget Block
description: Against a backdrop of fresh economic data and on-again, off-again budget negotiations, prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, especially in the long maturities.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Economic Weakness Stirs Gloom in Europe
description: Grim economic reports that include soaring unemployment, bigger budget deficits and lower economic growth, have many in Europe wondering, for the first time in more than two years, whether the Continent is once again heading toward a recession.

title: Overhaul of Rules Is Proposed For Savings-and-Loan Industry
description: The Office of Thrift Supervision proposed a major overhaul of lending rules today for savings and loan associations to bring the regulations in line with other banking regulations.

title: Parents' Suit On Classes Is Rebuffed
description: A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a lawsuit by a Brooklyn parents' organization that accused the state Commissioner of Education of illegally permitting tens of thousands of immigrant children to spend up to six years in bilingual education classes.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a Federal appeals court test of the Pentagon's two-year-old policy on homosexuals in the armed forces misstated the novelty of the case. It is not the first of its kind. Another, involving Lieut. Paul Thomasson, a Navy pilot, was heard last month in Richmond, and a decision is pending.

title: With Help of 'Seinfeld,' Legend in His Own Time;The Real Kramer Tries to Capitalize
description: Seven years ago, when the comedians Jerry Seinfeld and Larry David were sitting in Mr. David's apartment creating a television show about a single comedian in New York, they based a character on the lanky bachelor living across the hall, an affable guy named Kenny Kramer who had no visible means of support and a lot of free time to spend on projects that didn't work out exactly as planned.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;COMPUTER ASSOCIATES INTERNATIONAL (CA,N)
description: Computer Associates International Inc. reported yesterday an unexpectedly strong 30 percent profit rise for its fiscal third quarter on continued strong sales of its corporate software.

title: Barbara Jordan Dies at 59; Her Voice Stirred the Nation
description: Barbara Jordan, the black Congresswoman and scholar who stirred the nation with her Churchillian denunciations of the Watergate abuses of President Richard M. Nixon, died today in her home state of Texas at the age of 59.

title: With Tight Races Likely, Campaign Coffers Fill
description: Campaign committees for state legislators in both parties today reported receiving record contributions in 1995, suggesting that party officials expect many hotly contested races for the Legislature this year.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Special Education Backed
description: A commission formed to look into how much the state pays to educate disabled and retarded students has concluded that the costs are not excessive. In fact, the legislative task force said yesterday, the state should pick up even more of the costs.

title: Some Trucks Will Add a Fifth Firefighter
description: Reversing a move made by the Koch administration to save money, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has agreed to place a fifth firefighter on about half of the city's pumper trucks, a measure he said would enhance public safety at a cost of about $15 million a year.

title: Paul Gillette, 58; Wrote 'Play Misty'
description: Paul Gillette, a novelist and scriptwriter whose best-known work was "Play Misty for Me," died on Jan. 6, The Los Angeles Times reported today. He was 58.

title: Lawyer's Investment Plan Is the Target of Two Inquiries
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Manhattan District Attorney's office are conducting inquiries into an investment scheme run by a New York lawyer that may have bilked dozens of lawyers, businessmen and others of up to $100 million.

title: Jail Term in Naval Case
description: A Naval Academy midshipman who pleaded guilty to drug charges in a court-martial on Jan. 4 was sentenced today to 42 months in jail and dismissal from the Navy.

title: Pleas for Mercy, Statements of Defiance
description: By turns contrite, self-righteous and defiant, the men sentenced yesterday in the nation's largest terrorism conspiracy case seized the occasion as a kind of final public forum for their passionate beliefs -- proclaiming their innocence and denouncing the trial as a condemnation of Islam itself.

That was the news from the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Nev., earlier this month.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Charts Plans To Shut Down AEG
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. disclosed plans yesterday to swallow up the remains of its ailing AEG rail and engineering unit, marking the end for AEG, once Germany's biggest industrial company. Subject to shareholder approval, AEG will close out its 113 years next Jan. 1. Union officials said thousands of jobs would be lost.

title: Ernst Morch, 87, an Inventor And Leading Anesthesiologist
description: Dr. Ernst Trier Morch, an inveterate Danish-born tinkerer who applied his wide-ranging ingenuity to everything from advancing anesthesiology with a jerry-built respirator to rescuing Danish Jews with cocaine and rabbit blood, died on Saturday at the Manhattan home of his daughter Sys.

title: Break in Old Sewer Caused Bus-Engulfing Crater
description: The 12-foot-deep crater that nearly engulfed a small school bus in Brooklyn was caused by a break in a 100-year-old sewer pipe 14 feet below ground, a spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: In a Death-Penalty Trial, 2 Are Convicted of a Killing
description: Two men awaiting trial in the slaying of a Manhattan artist were convicted today of another killing five days earlier. As a result, they could be the first people executed for crimes in New York since the Federal Government adopted a death penalty in 1988.

description: SANDRA NUNNERLEY, a New Zealand-born decorator in New York, says that lately she has preferred the drape of wool for curtains.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Roche Sales Are Flat
description: The Swiss pharmaceutical company Roche Holding Ltd. said yesterday that its 1995 sales were unchanged at 14.7 billion Swiss francs ($12.7 billion) compared with a year earlier. But Roche said it expected to report a rise in consolidated net profit. Sales rose 11 percent when expressed in the currencies of countries where the company operates, but were flat when converted into Swiss francs because the currency gained strength in 1995. (AP)

title: Purchase by Dollar Tree
description: Dollar Tree Stores Inc. said today that it would pay $53 million for the privately held company Terrific Promotions Inc. The purchase of the 136-store chain would solidify Dollar Tree's position as the nation's largest operator of stores that sell all merchandise for $1. The combined company would have 636 stores in 26 states with annual sales of about $425 million. Shares in Dollar Tree rose $1.50, to $31, in Nasdaq trading.

title: U.S. Trade Gap Narrowed Again in October
description: The nation's trade deficit fell to $8.04 billion last October, the lowest level in 10 months and the fourth straight monthly decline, the Commerce Department said today in a delayed report.

title: Anita Diamant, 78; Was Literary Agent
description: Anita Diamant Berke, a literary agent who nurtured the career of V. C. Andrews, the best-selling novelist, died on Saturday at her home in Weston, Conn. She was 78.

title: BASEBALL;Brewers Get Mets' Stinnett
description: Four weeks after they obtained Brent Mayne from Kansas City, the Mets traded their 1995 backup catcher, Kelly Stinnett, to the Milwaukee Brewers today for a minor league pitcher.

title: Trade Organization Rules Against U.S.
description: The World Trade Organization ruled that a key section of the Clean Air Act discriminated against foreign oil refiners and ordered the United States to develop a plan to change its rules on imported gasoline or face trade sanctions. It was the first major ruling by the body, which acts as the international arbiter of trade. The decision involved a complaint filed by Brazil and Venezuela on the Clean Air Act's standards for "reformulated" gasoline.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Viacom Chief Ousted; Paramount's Performance a Factor
description: Viacom Inc. ousted its president and chief executive, Frank J. Biondi Jr., yesterday, sundering a nine-year partnership between Mr. Biondi and the entertainment company's billionaire chairman, Sumner M. Redstone.

title: Beyond Hills of Snow, Mountains of Garbage
description: Most days, Mario Gallegos, a superintendent at an Upper West Side apartment building, leaves the business of tossing bags of refuse onto garbage trucks to New York City sanitation workers. But yesterday, he grabbed a few himself and flung them on the collection truck of Richard L. Bryant and Gene Dalton. Together, the three men loaded about 150 plump, black plastic bags of garbage in less than 20 minutes.

title: Astronaut in Frigid Space Walk Gives Praise for Thermal Gear
description: The weather outside was frightful nearly 100 degrees below zero -- but a Navy officer, Comdr. Winston E. Scott, stayed delightfully warm today as he walked in space for the first time.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MONEY MANAGER RAISES HIS COMPANY'S STAKE IN DIAL
description: The Heine Securities Corporation, the investment company controlled by the money manager Michael Price, has raised its stake in the Dial Corporation to 8.8 percent from 1.33 percent of the common shares outstanding. Heine bought almost 6.6 million Dial common shares between Dec. 19 and yesterday at $27.62 to $32.47 each, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Dial shares closed yesterday at $32.75, up $1.625. Dial, which is based in Phoenix, makes Dial soap, Brillo pads and other household products.

title: Lotus Notes to Get Harder to Crack Abroad
description: The security technology in the international version of Lotus Notes software will be stronger than is normally allowed by American export laws, after I.B.M., which owns Lotus, reached a compromise with the United States Government.

description: I was wandering through the Dolce & Gabbana racks, puzzling over the existential meaning of the Barneys bankruptcy.

title: When Victims Need to Know

description: A single faulty gene appears to cause a significant share of breast cancer in young women, especially Jews, in whom it may trigger more than one-fourth of all such cases under the age of 40.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Glimpses of Embarrassment
description: Tere O'Connor is a choreographer people love to love or hate. There seems to be no middle ground, although it may be that his work needs time to settle into itself. "Notes on Shame," presented by Tere O'Connor Dance on Tuesday night in the Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater, looked a great deal better a year after its premiere at Dance Theater Workshop. But the two newer pieces on the program were disappointing.

title: On Book Tour, First Lady Courts Public
description: She is no longer 4 years old with a pink ribbon in her hair, but today Hillary Rodham Clinton reached back to the lessons of her childhood to deliver a pointed message about the controversies that have nearly overwhelmed her book tour as a first-time author.

title: Life in Space? 2 New Planets Raise Thoughts
description: In a stunning discovery of new worlds far out in the universe, two California astronomers today reported the detection of two planets orbiting Sun-like stars. The temperatures of the planets appear to be warm enough for water to exist in liquid form, a condition conducive to chemical processes that could, just possibly, be producing extraterrestrial life.

title: Essex Freeholder Is Cleared on School-Building Charges
description: After less than six hours of deliberations, a Federal jury today acquitted an Essex County freeholder and his business partner on charges they tried to hide a financial interest in a building leased to the Newark Board of Education.

title: Paine Webber Nears Deal With S.E.C. in Partnership Case
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. has reached an agreement in principle with the Securities and Exchange Commission in which it may pay $25 million to $50 million to settle charges that it misled investors in the sale of risky limited partnerships during the 1980's, people with knowledge of the agreement said late yesterday.

title: U.S. Doctors Aid Rwanda War-Crime Panel
description: To bolster the Rwanda war crimes tribunal, volunteers led by an American physicians' organization is to exhume bodies from mass graves over the next three weeks and conduct autopsies to gather evidence of massacres that left hundreds of thousands of Rwandans dead in 1994, the group said today.

title: Sale Suggestion Lifts Helene Curtis Shares
description: Shares of Helene Curtis Industries soared $6.625 on the Big Board today, to $40.75, after Shamrock Holdings of California Inc. asked the company to put itself on the block.

title: Executive Changes
description: ALUMINUM COMPANY OF AMERICA, Pittsburgh, named Robert F. Slagle president for Alcoa World Alumina, responsible for the strategic, commercial and operational activities of Alcoa's global bauxite and alumina activities. Mr. Slagle is now a vice president of Alcoa and managing Director of Alcoa of Australia. He will be based in Pittsburgh and report to Alain Belda, Alcoa's vice chairman.

title: Economic Scene;When economists talk, few listen if the subject is health policy.
description: WHEN it comes to public policy, does anyone listen to economic experts anymore? Judging from the rise and fall of the Clinton national health care plan -- the Edsel (this is the 90's: make that the "Waterworld") of public policy rollouts -- the answer is discouraging. And economists may have only themselves to blame. Indeed, economic professionals appear to pay little attention to the most knowledgeable people within their own ranks.

title: Essay;State of the Union
description: President Clinton and a small cadre of aides are feverishly finishing the State of the Union address for presentation to an opposition Congress next Tuesday.

title: New Federal Judge Is Appointed To Oversee Large Tobacco Suit
description: Helen Ginger Berrigan, a nonsmoking former criminal defense lawyer who worked briefly as a journalist and later headed the American Civil Liberties Union of Louisiana, has been assigned to oversee a giant class-action lawsuit against the nation's largest tobacco companies.

title: France Says It Is Willing to Discuss Its Nuclear Role in NATO
description: France, spelling out details of its plan to return to closer military cooperation with NATO after 30 years at arm's length, said today that it was willing to discuss the role its independent nuclear deterrent could play as part of a strengthened European pillar within the alliance.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Export Fraud Admitted
description: A warehouse operator who obtained millions of dollars in discount-priced merchandise with the understanding that it would be sold overseas admitted yesterday in Federal court that he had stored the goods in New Jersey so they could be sold for regular prices domestically.

title: Scourge on Yeltsin
description: To show what he wanted to do to Chechen rebels holding hostages in southern Russia this week, President Boris N. Yeltsin struck his palm with his fist, signaling brute force that would smash the rebels like flies.

title: Rule Will Require Rear Guard Device On All New Trucks
description: New trucks and truck trailers will soon be required to have a guard in back to prevent cars from sliding under them in crashes, the Transportation Department plans to announce on Thursday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sidelined with the flu, GEORGE BURNS missed his 100th birthday party Tuesday night but marked the occasion by making a substantial gift to Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles, The Associated Press reported yesterday. The comedian requested that the specific amount not be divulged.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Front Office Allows A Team to Go Stale
description: Don Nelson's up-tempo, share-the-ball offense was an absolute stroke of genius when the Knicks were 12-2. When they lost 11 of their next 21, the players were a bunch of chucking, whining brats.

title: Washington Claims Victory But the Snow Is Still There
description: In a city famous for its inability to cope with snow, traffic still crawls, and dozens of snow-covered streets remain barely touched 10 days after the first flakes of the Blizzard of '96.

description: The State Emergency Management Office has received hundreds of requests from municipalities for Federal aid to help pay the costs associated with the recent blizzard.

title: SHEIK SENTENCED TO LIFE IN PRISON IN BOMBING PLOT
description: Despite a defiant declaration of his innocence, Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman was sentenced yesterday to life in prison for plotting a series of bombings and assassinations that prosecutors said was intended to force the United States to end its support for the Governments of Israel and Egypt.

title: Michigan Moves to Untie Joblessness and Welfare
description: Gov. John Engler, a darling of Congressional Republicans for his efforts to pare welfare rolls, announced tonight an experimental project seeking to eliminate unemployment among welfare recipients in six areas of Michigan.

title: Currents;Oh, Splendid Restoration
description: WHEN the Puritan rigor of Oliver Cromwell gave way to the Restoration of Charles II in 1660, English courtiers eagerly reclaimed their splendor, as the new movie "Restoration" shows. But none did so more successfully than the avaricious Duke of Beaufort. A talk about his Gloucestershire house, Badminton (which had to be bigger and grander than anyone else's), opens the spring lecture series at the John Jay Homestead State Historic Site in Katonah, N.Y., on Feb. 12. Information: (914) 232-5149.

title: Ex-Premier Goes on Trial In Milan For Bribery
description: Former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi went on trial in Milan today on charges of corruption that he says were fabricated to destroy his political career.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Corporate Cuts Examined
description: Two days after AT&T handed out 2,000 layoff notices, Representative Robert G. Torricelli will address the subject of how corporate cutbacks affect communities and families. Mr. Torricelli, a Democrat who is running for the Senate, will speak at 1 P.M. today at Rutgers University's Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Panel Proposes a Flat Tax But Fails to Specify the Rate
description: A private commission on tax reform created last year by Republican leaders in Congress today stepped into a central issue in the campaign for the Republican Presidential nomination and recommended that the wages and salaries of all Americans, from corporate magnates to manual laborers, be taxed at a single, low rate.

title: Report Urges Ousting Leaders of San Gennaro Feast
description: A former Federal prosecutor appointed to examine last year's Feast of San Gennaro recommended yesterday that the nonprofit group that runs it be banned from future festivals, saying that the annual event is mismanaged, if not corrupt, and operated to benefit a small group of Little Italy insiders.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Reynolds Metals Shifts to Saatchi
description: The Reynolds Metals Company, the maker of aluminum and plastic wraps, yesterday named Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide in New York to handle its account, which had been handled for the last 23 years by the J. Walter Thompson New York unit of the WPP Group. The billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: Kagga Kamma Journal;Endangered Bushmen Find Refuge in a Game Park
description: It is 10 A.M. and, breakfast over, the tourists are waiting for the morning's activity. A young boy pulls on the arm of a guide here and asks impatiently:

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNC AGREES TO BUY GARRETT AVIATION SERVICES
description: UNC Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Garrett Aviation Services, a privately held company with estimated 1995 revenues of $330 million, for about $150 million. Garrett, which is based in Phoenix, was formerly a part of Allied Signal Inc. and was sold to an investor group organized by senior managers in 1994. UNC said that upon completion of the deal, it expected the combined company to have annual revenues approaching $1 billion. Both Garrett and UNC repair aircraft engines and provide other services to the aviation industry. Garrett has about 1,000 employees nationwide, while UNC, which is based in Annapolis, Md., has 5,900 employees. UNC's stock rose 87.5 cents a share yesterday, to $6.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Schemes Seen In Marketing School Supplies
description: The nation's largest teachers union is urging its members to examine lesson plans supplied by businesses, special interest groups and foreign governments before using all or part of them.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SWIMMING;Hearing Date is Set
description: JESSICA FOSCHI, the 15-year-old swimmer placed on probation for failing a drug test, faces a hearing Feb. 11-12 that could result in a ban from competition for two years.

title: World News Briefs;Mexican Ex-Official Sues U.S. on Deportation
description: A former Mexican deputy attorney general facing deportation from the United States sued top American officials today, charging them with pursuing an unconstitutional course.

title: Currents;Willow, Weave for Me
description: FOR centuries, woven willow fences (right), known as hurdles, partitioned the English countryside. Thousand-year-old examples have been recovered from peat bogs, making them among the oldest known farm enclosures.

title: More Prisons Won't Solve the Crime Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Apple Plans 1,300 Layoffs And Takes Loss
description: Apple Computer Inc., reporting a loss for its first fiscal quarter, said today that it would lay off about 1,300 employees as part of a restructuring.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EXXON TO GET $300 MILLION IN A PARTIAL SETTLEMENT
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it would receive $300 million from Lloyd's of London and about 250 other underwriters in a partial settlement of a lawsuit to recover expenses from the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. Exxon had sought more than $1 billion from its insurance companies and underwriting syndicates for the tanker accident and oil spill. The insurers refused to pay, saying the accident was caused by the company's negligence. The company, based in Irving, Tex., still has $250 million in unresolved claims pending with Lloyd's and other underwriters. Exxon spent $3 billion to clean up the spill and to settle lawsuits.

title: SKIING;Happy Trails for Minnesota Farmer
description: Forget the vitamin supplements. Ignore the protein shakes. If you want to build strength and aerobic endurance, eat strawberries. And read a little German poetry while you're at it, preferably Goethe. That's what the reborn United States Nordic ski champion, John Bauer, said were among the things he turned to for better race results.

title: The Burial Grounds of Bosnia
description: International investigators believe that the bodies of thousands of victims of Bosnian Serb "ethnic cleansing" are buried in some 15 to 20 mass graves in Serbian-held areas of Bosnia. These grave sites and the evidence they may contain could be crucial to the prosecution of Serbian officials for war crimes. The sites must be preserved.

title: Transit Clerk Guns Down Co-Worker, Kills Himself
description: An early-morning argument between a man and woman on a subway train turned deadly yesterday when he shot her on a crowded platform on the Upper East Side, then walked two dozen blocks to his apartment and killed himself after spurning pleas to surrender, the police said.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 226 issues was down 200.22 points, or 0.97 percent, at 20,370.04. On Wednesday, the Nikkei rose 3.19 points.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Health Care Provider Selects Martin
description: The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the health care service provider, has named the Martin Agency unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in Richmond as the first agency to handle its national advertising account. Though the billings have not been determined, Adweek this week estimated them at more than $20 million.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AMR Posts 78.4% Increase From Operations in Quarter
description: The parent of American Airlines, the AMR Corporation, posted a 78.4 percent rise in its operating profit for the fourth quarter today, but after taking $372 million of charges, it had a net loss of $281 million.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;A Shocker In Big East: Seton Beats Villanova
description: All of that seasonlong agony and frustration, all of those losses in games it could have won, ended for Seton Hall tonight. The Pirates shot well when they had to, kept driving on the basket, played tight defense and outrebounded Villanova, 48-30. That all gave the Pirates 78-73 upset victory in a Big East Conference battle between one basketball team that is ranked with the national elite and one that thought it still might be.

title: AT HOME WITH: Olga Hirshhorn;The Thrill of Art, Both Fine and Flea
description: Olga Hirshhorn's normally cheery countenance was gloomy as she peered at the driving rain outside the window of her tiny carriage house in northwest Washington. Her regular Sunday excursion to the Georgetown flea market would have to be scuttled.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profit at Air France
description: Air France said yesterday that it swung to a profit in the six months that ended on Sept. 30, reporting net earnings of 232 million francs ($46 million) after a loss in the comparable period a year earlier of 477 million francs. But the airline said it expected to report a loss for the full fiscal year that ends March 30 of 1.2 billion francs, not including a charge to be taken for job cuts through early retirement and attrition. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Saying Hostages Are Dead, Russians Level Rebel Town
description: Conceding that they have failed in their attempts to rescue scores of hostages from a small band of Chechen guerrillas in the village of Pervomayskoye near here, the Russian Army today withdrew its soldiers from the battleground and began flattening the hamlet with devastating missiles.

title: Currents;Papering the House (If These Old Walls Could Only Talk)
description: COMPANIES specializing in reproducing historic wallpaper tend to price it at more than $150 a roll and put it in trade-only venues, insuring that only decorators and architects buy it. At Thibaut Wallcoverings and Fabrics,a Newark company that has been making wallpaper since the 19th century, things are blessedly egalitarian. Its designs are $15 to $20 a roll, and all are welcome, said Lori Reagle, its art director.

title: World News Briefs;New Leader Pledges Vote in Sierra Leone
description: Sierra Leone's new leader, who took over in a bloodless coup on Tuesday, is committed to holding multi-party elections on Feb. 26, as planned, a Government spokesman said today.

title: When AIDS Patients Confront the Managed-Care System
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Vote Is Delayed on Browns' Relocation
description: The Cleveland forces trying to persuade National Football League owners to keep the Browns from moving to Baltimore sounded conciliatory today, even implying that compromise was possible.

title: Justices Appear Skeptical of V.M.I.'s Proposal for Women
description: Virginia's defense of its all-male military college in a Supreme Court argument today met a skeptical response from the Justices, who appeared to be giving serious thought to ordering the admission of women to the 157-year-old Virginia Military Institute.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Huskies Look Like Pros In Squashing Red Storm
description: St. John's desperately needed a dependable effort against Connecticut tonight to restore some sanity to its troubled season. A victory could have temporarily shifted the focus off Brian Mahoney, given the Red Storm some needed confidence and dispatched a message to the Big East. But the Huskies spoiled St. John's grandiose plans and delivered the only messages of the evening.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about a Federal appeals court test of the Pentagon's two-year-old policy on homosexuals in the armed forces misstated the novelty of the case. It is not the first of its kind. Another, involving Lieut. Paul Thomasson, a Navy pilot, was heard last month in Richmond, and a decision is pending.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fed Survey Sees 'Modest Pace' of Growth
description: The economy was growing at a "generally modest pace" at the turn of the year, a Federal Reserve survey showed today, but an index intended to predict turning points in the economy suggested an increased possibility of a downturn this year.

title: The Neediest Cases;Former Marine Finds a Helping Hand
description: Twelve and a half years ago, when Mark King was 19, he searched for an escape from the violence and poverty in his South Bronx neighborhood. He found his prayers answered when he joined the Marines.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Caesarean Birth Rate Dips
description: New Jersey hospitals performed first-time Caesarean section births slightly less often in 1994 than in 1993, but the decline was not enough to satisfy the New Jersey Hospital Association.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Take a Break About a Game Too Soon
description: Something like this was bound to happen; the Islanders were simply playing too well.

title: Wal-Mart Predicts First Slide In Earnings; Stock Falls 9.4%
description: For the first time in more than 25 years as a public business, Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's largest retailer, will report lower quarterly earnings, the company said yesterday in a terse statement. Its shares fell $2.125, or 9.4 percent, to $20.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Sense of Where He Is and Why He Stays There
description: TIME PRESENT, TIME PAST A Memoir By Bill Bradley Illustrated. 442 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $26.

title: Bond Will Face Trial in Australian Case
description: Alan Bond, the one-time billionaire who bankrolled Australia's America's Cup victory in 1983, was ordered today to stand trial for what prosecutors say is the country's biggest corporate fraud case ever.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: NOTEBOOK;It's a Mean Regime for Joe Greene
description: Miami Dolphins Coach Jimmy Johnson dropped Joe Greene as defensive line coach and replaced him with Cary Godette, one of three new assistants he hired yesterday.

title: Lightness of Being: Designs That Soar
description: ON winter mornings, as the sun rises over the Alps in Switzerland, a jewel-like object resting in the snow at an altitude of 13,000 feet captures the gleam of first light. To expert skiers swooshing by, it may appear like an abandoned helicopter, glass encased in a red aluminum frame. But it is a little mountain hut created by Richard Horden, a British architect with a visionary's imagination.

title: U.S. Officials Muffle Criticism of Russian Attack
description: Though they are watching the carnage in Chechnya with a mixture of apprehension and revulsion, top United States military and diplomatic officials have avoided publicly criticizing Russia's leadership for its assault on hostage takers and hostages alike.

description: PRO BASKETBALL Heat Tops Bullets in Fight-Marred Game

title: Clinton Aide Takes Blame for Ousters
description: Denying that Hillary Rodham Clinton directed or ordered him to purge the White House travel office in 1993, a former Presidential aide told a House committee today that he alone ordered the dismissals of the seven employees.

title: Anxious Vigils For Chinese Babies
description: EVERY day, Carol and Stephen Forslind and their 4-year-old daughter, Victoria, stand in the kitchen of their home in Nashua, N.H., and talk to an enlarged color photograph on the refrigerator door. The photograph is of Wei Juan-Juan, the daughter who awaits them in a Chinese orphanage.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Taiwan Changing Rule On Stocks for Foreigners
description: Taiwan plans to exclude investments by foreign individuals from its current 15 percent ceiling on purchases of shares by overseas financial institutions on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, a central bank official said yesterday.

title: Chicago Officials Complain of Too Many Sting Operations
description: With yet another crackdown on corruption in this city long famous for brazen political thievery, some Chicago aldermen are starting to complain that the Federal Government is picking on them.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;First Lady as Star of the TV Talk-Show Circuit
description: For all the talk about character these days, the issue on television is image. Character is uncomfortably complicated for the small screen; it strains prime-time patience. Even the simple proposition that one might be deeply dedicated to the care of children while being careless about how one deals with adults gets in the way of the all-or-nothing plot lines of packaged entertainment.

title: Serbs in Bosnia See No Peace for Their Dead . . .;. . . And Are Angry at Leaders and Themselves
description: In this rural town, which before the war was part of a successful regional economy and a place where ethnic minorities lived peacefully, many Serbs say they are ashamed of what they have done.

title: Council Works on Proposal To Outlaw Three-Card Monte
description: With the blessing of the Giuliani administration and City Council leaders, a Council committee yesterday took the first steps toward outlawing three-card monte games on the city's streets.

title: HARNESS RACING;Filion, Facing Charges, Calls Life a 'Nightmare'
description: After spending another day in court and another day away from the race track, Herve Filion returned home on Tuesday evening tired, confused and nervously contemplating his future.

title: Burmese Heroin Trafficker Surrenders but Is Negotiating With Junta
description: The generals who govern Myanmar, formerly Burma, have claimed victory over one of the world's most notorious opium traffickers, but they are remaining silent about what will happen to a vast drug empire that supplies much of the heroin found on the streets of American cities.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Chickens in Russian Pots
description: When Victor Spivak joined forces in 1993 with two other immigrants from the former Soviet Union, their export trading company was little more than a cramped studio apartment in New York.

title: Clinton's Winning Hand
description: It's only human for Republicans to sulk now that the President has outmaneuvered them by pressing for a balanced budget deal while attacking their "excessive Medicare cuts" -- which are similar in size to savings he had previously proposed. But the G.O.P. should put frustration aside and realize that the good of the country and its own political survival argue for a deal largely on his terms.

title: Serbs in Bosnia See No Peace for Their Dead . . .
description: This morning Nikola Ljesic went to the Vlakovo cemetery for the last time. He carried with him several yellow candles, a small parcel of food and a piece of brown wrapping paper filled with nails.

title: Condemn All Atrocities in Balkan Conflict
description: To the Editor:

title: POP REVIEW;In a Night of Shouts and Whispers, a Lifetime of Bluesy Mastery
description: In the late 1940's in Memphis, when B. B. King, then a local disk jockey, was starting to perform as a musician, he made a series of self-conscious decisions. He wanted the sound of a gospel quartet, but since the line between secular and religious music hadn't been crossed, he settled for a horn section to play the role. He combined the music of his four favorite guitarists, Django Reinhardt, Charlie Christian, Lonnie Johnson and Blind Lemon Jefferson, into a distinct improvisational style. He invoked, rhythmically and with the instrumentation of his small band, the sound and power of the best big bands. In his borrowing, he came up with the perfect sound for a postwar America, that of rural culture moving to the city, sophisticated and urban with mud on its boots.

title: Excerpts From Jordan's Address in 1976
description: Following are excerpts from the keynote address to the 1976 Democratic National Convention by Representative Barbara Jordan of Texas:

title: Window Wit And WisdomTIMOTHY JACK WARD
description: WINDOWS have their couturiers, too. For many interior designers, custom draperies are a place to strut their stuff, where fabric connoisseurship, opulent detailing, engineering ingenuity and high theatrics are brought to play.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: New Inductees Into the Rock Hall of Fame
description: At the 11th annual induction ceremonies for the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame last night, some performers insisted that hits aren't everything. Before an audience of music-business executives in formal dress who had paid up to $1,500 each for a seat in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel's Grand Ballroom, John Cale of the Velvet Underground declared, "Sales are not the be-all and end-all of rock-and-roll." The Velvet Underground, which barely reached the charts in its four-year career, was inducted along with David Bowie, Gladys Knight and the Pips, the Jefferson Airplane, Little Willie John, Pink Floyd and the Shirelles.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Nothing is forever -- not even the familiar packaging on Oreo cookies.

title: A Director's Debt To a Hereford Cow
description: Art sometimes moves in mysterious ways. For the film and television director John Frankenheimer, the muse took the unlikely form of a registered Hereford cow.

description: To the Editor:

title: Mme. B. Tangles With th Curtians
description: FAIRY tales have happy endings. This is not a fairy tale.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Additional Work On Jack Daniel's
description: The Brown-Forman Beverages Worldwide unit of the Brown-Forman Corporation in Louisville, Ky., said yesterday that it had named Simmons, Durham & Associates in St. Louis to handle additional responsibilities for Jack Daniel's Tennessee Whiskey and other brands like Jack Daniel's 1866 Classic Amber Lager. The billings were not disclosed. Simmons, Durham will introduce products in markets into which Brown-Forman is expanding like Malaysia and Thailand as well as introduce Jack Daniel's and Cola, a premixed cocktail beverage, in Australia and New Zealand. The agency already handles advertising for products in the United States and in overseas markets like Britain and Japan.

title: U.S. Falters on Slavery in Mauritania
description: To the Editor:

title: Failings of the Flat Tax
description: A commission appointed by the Republican leadership in Congress endorsed the idea of a flat tax yesterday, but ducked proposing anything specific. That allowed the commission to accentuate the positive, sidestep the negative and give voters a distorted prism through which to view its idea.

title: More Prisons Won't Solve the Crime Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: Europe has long been ahead of North America in its ability to stage invitational events restricted to world-class players and providing substantial cash prizes. The first in 1996 is the Volmac World Top tournament, beginning today in The Hague, the Netherlands.

title: HOCKEY;Devils' Practice Is Imperfect
description: Devils Coach Jacques Lemaire staged a 65-minute practice here this afternoon, his way of punishing the Stanley Cup champions for the way they have performed in recent games.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Campanella Jewelry Found
description: ROXIE CAMPANELLA says she was "overwhelmed" to learn that a cherished 1955 World Series pendant given to her by her late husband, Roy, has been recovered by the Irving, Tex., police. "I was so happy, I can't really express my feelings," said the widow of the Hall of Fame catcher, when reached at her Los Angeles home yesterday.

description: To the Editor:
