description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: ALUMINUM COMPANY OF AMERICA, Pittsburgh, named Robert F. Slagle president for Alcoa World Alumina, responsible for the strategic, commercial and operational activities of Alcoa's global bauxite and alumina activities. Mr. Slagle is now a vice president of Alcoa and managing Director of Alcoa of Australia. He will be based in Pittsburgh and report to Alain Belda, Alcoa's vice chairman.

title: Window Wit And Wisdom;Curvy Lines, Metal Mesh and Plenty of Shimmer
description: MARY BRIGHT, who studied fashion design and millinery in Leeds, England, is perhaps the leading avant-garde drapery designer in New York.

title: BASEBALL;D.H. Complicates Interleague Play
description: With club owners on the verge of approving regular-season games matching teams in the American League against teams in the National, the issue of the designated hitter threatened today to undermine the revolutionary concept before it can be implemented.

title: World News Briefs;4 Norwegians Guilty In Theft of 'The Scream'
description: Four Norwegian men were convicted today of the theft of the painting, "The Scream" by Edvard Munch, which was stolen from the National Gallery here on Feb. 12, 1994.

title: Intel Sets Record In Nasdaq Trade
description: The shares of the Intel Corporation set a record yesterday for the most actively traded stock on a single day ever on the Nasdaq market.

title: McDonald's Looks Abroad
description: Facing stiff competition in the United States, the McDonald's Corporation is looking overseas for growth.

title: Currents;In the Comfort Of Flowers
description: WHEN she's not en pointe or putting a corps de ballet through its paces, the ballerina and choreographer Lois Bewley paints fruits and flowers onto silk-covered pillows (below). Inspired by 18th-century botanical prints or the real thing, she paints her pillows with colorfast acrylics. Hand-washable, they cost from $125 for a 12-inch square to $200 for a special order. (Her clients have included Mary Tyler Moore.) Stores haven't discovered her, but she'll show samples at her home or yours. Information: (212) 752-7573.

title: Governor Pataki's Scorecard;Wrong on Rail Reimbursements
description: Gov. George Pataki has engineered a $5.5 million reimbursement for suburban rail commuters inconvenienced by the blizzard. If Mr. Pataki wanted to curry favor with mass-transit users, he had ample opportunity when the fares were being raised as part of an ill-advised new five-year borrowing plan. Since he stayed silent then, his latest gesture seems hollow. Worse, it will cost the strapped mass-transit system money it can ill afford.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Heart Problem Is Ruled Out For the UMass Star Camby
description: Extensive tests on Marcus Camby, the University of Massachusetts basketball player, have so far failed to reveal a precise cause for his frightening 10-minute loss of consciousness on Sunday afternoon. But John Calipari, the Massachusetts coach, spoke tonight of Camby's return to play in the most optimistic terms since the player collapsed before a game against St. Bonaventure and was rushed to a hospital in Olean, N.Y.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FLEET FINANCIAL PUTS FINANCE UNIT UP FOR SALE
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. said yesterday that it had put its Atlanta-based Fleet Finance unit up for sale. Fleet Financial said the unit had a loan portfolio of $1.5 billion and generated more than $500 million in new loans in 1995. The unit offers consumer loans, real estate loans and other financing. The size of Fleet Finance's fees came under fire several years ago but a spokesman for Fleet Financial said that the company had fulfilled most settlements with consumer groups and the Georgia Attorney General and that the company would stand by the remaining commitments. Fleet Financial said in its earnings report for 1995, which was posted yesterday, that it took an after-tax charge of $112 million in the fourth quarter for costs associated with the planned sale of Fleet Finance and certain nonperforming assets from the company's banking business.

title: Ex-Officer Changes Confession Account
description: Charging that his previous recantation had been forced out of him by strong-arming interrogators, a former New York City police officer is again insisting that Bronx detectives ignored a murder confession by a man who later killed five people in a shoe store.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;2 Die in Plainfield Fire
description: The city's third fatal fire in six weeks claimed two people yesterday, bringing the number of recent deaths to six.

title: Fatal Accident Results in 2 PATH Dismissals
description: PATH officials have dismissed two supervisors after an investigation into a Dec. 2 train accident that killed two workers and injured a third while they were repairing a track near Harrison, N.J., an official of a rail workers union said today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Councilwoman Drops Charge
description: A council member who said an audio tape of her vote on a police contract was doctored has withdrawn her complaint, which a prosecutor found to be without merit. Atlantic County Prosecutor Jeffrey Blitz used the word "erroneous" in describing the accusation by Anne Phillips, the only independent on a council dominated by Republicans. Mayor Philip Guenther chose stronger language, The Associated Press reported, saying the charges were "preposterous and outrageous" from the beginning. He has called on Councilwoman Phillips to resign; she says she will not.

title: Door of T.W.A. Jet Opens Above Texas
description: The tail stairwell door on a Trans World Airlines passenger jet dropped open during flight late Tuesday, but a crew member secured with a rope was able to close the hatch without incident before the plane landed safely.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Rockies Infielder Injured
description: Colorado Rockies second baseman ERIC YOUNG will be sidelined two to three months after breaking a bone in his right hand, team officials said yesterday. Young, who hit .317 and stole 35 bases last season, broke the bone while taking batting practice during an off season workout and will undergo surgery tomorrow, the Rockies said. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;ILLINOIS CENTRAL TO BUY OPERATOR OF 2 RAILROADS
description: The Illinois Central Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy CCP Holdings Inc., a privately held railroad company based in Waterloo, Iowa, for $139 million. Illinois Central, which is based in Chicago, said it would also assume about $18 million in equipment leases. CCP Holdings operates two railroads, the Chicago, Central & Pacific Railroad and the Cedar River Railroad, with track that totals about 850 miles. Illinois Central owns the Illinois Central Railroad, which operates a 2,700-mile freight railroad. Its stock gained 25 cents yesterday, to $37.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Soccer Title to Juventus
description: Gianluca Vialli scored in the 32d minute Wednesday night, giving Juventus of Turin a 1-0 victory over Parma in the Italian Super Cup. It was the first Super Cup title for Juventus, which won the Italian League last season and beat Parma in the Italian Cup final.

title: Beijing Clarification On Financial News
description: China said today that its plan to monitor foreign financial news services would also include on-line trading systems. It added that the services, which will be subject to the approval of the official New China News Agency, would not be permitted to upgrade their technical systems for the time being.

title: Man Sentenced for Clinton Campaign Role
description: A former banker who concealed cash transactions on behalf of President Clinton's 1990 campaign for Governor of Arkansas was sentenced today to two years' probation.

title: Muslims Resurrect A Village
description: There were strange sounds in this small mountain village today -- the sounds of life.

title: About Real Estate;An Awkward Storefront Seeks Style in an Upward Expansion
description: On the southeast corner of Madison Avenue and 65th Street -- a location any real estate agent in the city would call a choice site -- is a vacant and cavernous storefront where the homeless congregate.

title: As Russians Bicker, Communists Take the High Road
description: The political mood remained angry and bitter today as President Boris N. Yeltsin struggled to declare victory in the smoldering Chechen hostage crisis.

title: Break for Astronauts
description: With the hard work behind them, the astronauts on the space shuttle Endeavour were given a half-day off today. A Japanese crewman, Koichi Wakata, and Dr. Daniel Barry spent part of the day playing a Japanese board game, Go.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 4.28 points, or 0.02 percent, at 20,365.76. On Thursday, the Nikkei fell 200.22 points or nearly 1 percent.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Flood Warning Is Issued
description: The National Weather Service has issued a flood watch today for much of the state. Temperatures could reach the low 50's, which will melt many snow piles left from the blizzard, and heavy rains are predicted as well. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the death of King Moshoeshoe II of Lesotho referred incorrectly to the son who ruled the tiny southern African country during the King's exile from 1989 to 1994. It was Moshoeshoe's older son, Crown Prince Letsie David Mohato -- not his younger son, Prince Simeone Seeiso -- who ruled briefly as Letsie III.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;General Electric Reports Increase in Earnings
description: Led by its NBC broadcasting network and its finance and plastics divisions, the General Electric Company yesterday reported stronger earnings for the fourth quarter.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A. Bulls Struggle Before Beating Raptors

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Richard Pousette-Dart 'Paintings From the 40's and 50's' Knoedler & Company 19 East 70th Street Manhattan Through Feb. 3

title: A Cornucopia Of Americana
description: WHEN the Winter Antiques Show began 42 years ago, there was nothing to compare to this patriotically American event and nothing else on the calendar to entice collectors to visit Manhattan during the bleak days of January.

title: FILM REVIEW;Enough Blood to Feed The Thirstiest Vampires
description: The vampire western "From Dusk Till Dawn" raises more than the usual curiosity about who will come back from the dead. Quentin Tarantino, last seen doing himself serious harm in "Four Rooms," wrote this film's screenplay and plays a starring role. Robert Rodriguez, who made the only watchable "Rooms" segment after the fiery but uneven "Desperado," tries directing his most ambitious feature.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;AT&T Wireless Chooses McCann
description: A strong January for McCann-Erickson Worldwide continued yesterday as AT&T Wireless Services named the McCann San Francisco office to handle its consolidated national and local advertising and direct marketing accounts, with billings estimated at more than $40 million. AT&T Wireless said last summer that it would combine those assignments, which had been handled by more than 20 agencies, at a single shop.

title: No Benefit Is Found From Beta Carotene
description: A vitamin supplement taken by millions of Americans in hope of avoiding cancer or heart disease has fallen short under rigorous scientific examination.

title: SUPER BOWL;Erhardt and Steelers Taking Flight
description: Strange how perceptions are shaped in the National Football League. The Giants' 1990 Super Bowl championship team was a model of power football, an earth-shaking offensive line and a pair of battering-ram running backs.

title: BASEBALL;Union Is Not Bowled Over
description: The reaction appears mixed from Donald Fehr, head of the baseball players' union, regarding the new proposal for a collective bargaining agreement that the owners gave the players Nov. 15.

title: BOXING;Foreman-Moorer Rematch Derailed
description: George Foreman's so-called last fight -- which was starting to sound suspiciously like the first stop of a farewell tour -- has been called off. For now. At least as of yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RAYCHEM SHARES JUMP 18 PERCENT ON IMPROVED EARNINGS
description: The shares of the Raychem Corporation rose 18 percent yesterday after the company reported late on Wednesday that it had a 21 percent increase in second-quarter earnings and said it had reached an agreement that would eliminate future losses from its venture with L. M. Ericsson Telefonaktiebolaget of Sweden. Raychem, a Menlo Park, Calif., electronics and telecommunications company, said the Ericsson agreement would eliminate its exposure to the venture, the Ericsson Raynet Corporation. Raychem also raised its dividend 25 percent, and Merrill Lynch & Company raised its investment rating on the company yesterday. Raychem's stock was up $9.50, at $62.75 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;The Road to Louisville Starts at Gulfstream
description: It is more than three months and many twists of fortune away, but the road to the Kentucky Derby will open tomorrow with the Holy Bull Stakes at Gulfstream Park in Hallandale, Fla., featuring Cobra King, the most accomplished 2-year-old colt in California last year.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;2 Admit Liquor Kickbacks
description: Two liquor store owners admitted in court yesterday that they took more than $2 million in illegal kickbacks from alcohol wholesalers from 1990 to 1994. As part of their plea agreement, Saul Leighton, 58, of Clark, and Harry Hammer, 64, of Holmdel, pledged to cooperate with what state officials describe as one of the biggest investigations ever of the New Jersey liquor industry. The A.P. said the men also agreed to pay more than $2.3 million in fines and penalties and to sell their business, Bayway Liquors in Elizabeth.

title: Fidelity Shifts Policy on Distressed Securities Market
description: Fidelity Investments, which in the last five years has dominated such high-profile bankruptcy cases as those involving Federated Department Stores and R. H. Macy & Company, abruptly announced yesterday that it was "discontinuing its aggressive style" of investing in the stocks, bonds and bank debt of weak and insolvent companies.

title: A Report on 25 Child Deaths Finds 25 Agency Failures
description: In an 18-month stretch of 1994 and 1995, 25 children in New York City died in cases in which the city's child welfare agency failed to conduct adequate investigations, monitor abuse cases or provide needed services, according to a study conducted by the Public Advocate's office.

title: Life and Death Choice Splits a Family
description: Soon after he found out that his mother had been in contact with Dr. Jack Kevorkian about his father, a 69-year-old retired obstetrician ravaged by Alzheimer's disease, Chip Klooster began a battle that has split his family and thrown into high relief the ethical and legal issues surrounding assisted suicide.

title: BASKETBALL;This Year, Williams Steers Clear Of Trouble
description: If Jayson Williams needs a working theme to inspire his 1995-96 season with the Nets, it should be "Don't Blame Jayson."

title: China Arrests Brother of Doctor Who Told of Orphanage Abuses
description: Zhang Shuyun, the doctor who accused an orphanage here of deliberately starving children in its care, said today that her brother had been arrested and charged with subversion, apparently in retaliation for her decision to publicize her allegations of abuse.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hongkong Bank Reports a Fraud
description: Hongkong Bank, a unit of HSBC Holdings P.L.C., a British-based banking and finance company, said yesterday that it was trying to locate $34.2 million it lost in a fraud in Indonesia. On Jan. 3, the bank, which is Hong Kong's largest, detected corporate fraud involving a fake transfer of funds at its branch in Jakarta, the company said. Of the 97 billion rupiahs, or $42 million, it lost, 18 billion have been traced, it said.

title: Mr. Dole Fights A Big Giveaway
description: Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, has threatened to hold up the telecommunications deregulation bill in conference because it contains an offensive giveaway to broadcasters. Candidates for the Presidency often shy away from controversy, but Mr. Dole is taking the right action to protect taxpayers.

title: CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;Mystery at the Presidential Mansion
description: Senator Lauch Faircloth, never one to shy from sleuthing in matters Whitewater, invited the nation to join him today in a fresh game of Clue.

title: Navy Pilot Is Killed In Collision of 2 Jets
description: One Navy fighter pilot was killed on Wednesday and another survived with minor injuries after their FA-18 Hornet jets collided over the central Nevada desert.

title: Investment by Tribune
description: The Tribune Company has invested $25 million in Baring Communications Equity (Asia-Pacific) Ltd. Fund, a private equity fund specializing in media and communications companies in the Asia-Pacific region. Tribune will have the option to co-invest directly in many of the businesses. The fund was formed through a partnership of Baring Venture Partners, a division of Internationale Nederladen Groep N.V. of the Netherlands, and Communications Equity Associates Inc. of Tampa, Fla.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;His Place Among the Moguls
description: Perhaps it is fitting that MTV will begin its coverage of the 1996 Presidential campaign with an interview tomorrow of Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader. In recent weeks, Senator Dole has figured prominently in the thoughts of Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of MTV's parent company, Viacom Inc.

title: Punishing Terror, Under Law
description: The sentencing of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman and nine co-defendants to long prison terms for seditious conspiracy and related crimes completes the legal response, pending appeals, to one of the most frightful terrorist conspiracies ever uncovered in the United States. Challenged to protect public safety and the constitutional rights of the defendants, the American legal system performed credibly on both fronts.

title: BOXING;Rejuberation! It's a New Vitality
description: This could be the Year of Rejuberation: The teams we love to love, the Cowboys, Bulls and Rangers, are back on track; the sport we love to hate, boxing, may be coming back again, and the Olympics have discovered a new money-making religion, money. Baseball, the sport of the 20th century, may have found its wedge into the 21st, interleague play.

title: SOME FOES ESCAPE
description: After a wild battle that raged through the night and left bodies scattered across the snow-covered plains, President Boris N. Yeltsin said tonight that the Russian Army had finally managed to overcome a group of Chechen rebels who had been trapped in a village near here and to free many of their hostages.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FILENET AGREES TO BUY TWO SOFTWARE MAKERS
description: The Filenet Corporation of Costa Mesa, Calif., agreed yesterday to acquire the Saros Corporation, a privately held supplier of document management and Internet software, for stock valued at about $102 million. Filenet, a maker of client-server and document imaging software, will exchange 2.2 million shares, which will include directly issued shares and options to purchase Filenet stock. Saros, based in Bellevue, Wash., will operate as a Filenet business unit. Separately, Filenet said it had agreed to acquire the New York-based software developer International Financial Systems Ltd. for an undisclosed amount of cash. Filenet shares were up $2, at $48.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRAXAIR SELLS RIGHTS TO LINDE NAME TO LINDE A. G.
description: Praxair Inc., based in Danbury, Conn., said yesterday that it had sold the North American rights to the Linde name and trademark to Linde A. G. of Wiesbaden, Germany, for $60 million. Praxair, an industrial gases company, will discontinue use of the Linde name in North America beginning in 1999. Praxair also reported a 20 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings, bolstered by gains in both its industrial gases and surface technologies businesses. The company reported net income of $66 million, or 45 cents a share, on sales of $807 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31. In the fourth quarter of 1994 the company earned $55 million, or 39 cents a share, on sales of $722 million.

title: Mayor Says 5 Firefighters Will Be Safer
description: The city will be a safer place now that a fifth firefighter will be added to many of the city's pumper engines, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani asserted yesterday. But neither the Mayor nor top fire officials were able to cite any deaths or specific safety problems that could be linked to the six-year practice of having four-member crews.

title: On My Mind;Eleanor and Hillary
description: Three years ago this week they were dancing and singing and telling happy jokes at all the balls and parties given for them in Washington.

title: BASEBALL;The Yankees Look to Add McDonald
description: The Yankees have already remodeled their pitching rotation for 1996 by signing the free agents Kenny Rogers and Dwight Gooden and by having David Cone available for a full season. Now, they are considering making another addition and are seriously courting the free agent Ben McDonald.

title: FILM REVIEW;Growing Up Grim in English Racing
description: When Billy Hogg (Darren Bell), a furtive, glowering youth with a history of petty crime, leaves his mother's home in Newcastle, England, to live with his father in County Durham, he finds it difficult to adapt to his new hardscrabble existence. Billy's weather-beaten father, Hoggy (Brian Hogg), whom he hasn't seen in 10 years, lives in a trailer and breeds horses for harness racing. Ill-prepared for his new environment, Billy at first cuts a pathetic figure stumbling furiously around in the wintry slush in his sneakers with headphones glued to his ears.

title: Bangkok Journal;The Guilty Suitcase: Good Fiction or Bad Luck?
description: In his days as a big-city television reporter, Stephen Roye would probably have found the story irresistible:

title: Peres Under Pressure to Call an Early Election in Israel
description: Pressure is increasing on the Israeli Prime Minister, Shimon Peres, to call an early election that could significantly slow American-mediated negotiations with Syria for a comprehensive peace.

title: SOCCER;Late Own Goal Foils U.S. Team
description: The United States national soccer team was unable to avenge its World Cup elimination to Brazil tonight as it suffered a 1-0 loss in the semifinals of the Gold Cup before a crowd of 22,038 at the Los Angeles Coliseum.

title: Blaze Kills 10 at German Home for Foreigners
description: At least 10 people, including four children, died early today when fire roared through a home for foreigners seeking asylum in Germany. The authorities said they could not exclude an arson attack by rightists.

title: The Assault on Pervomayskoye
description: As the smoke lifts from the rubble of Pervomayskoye, the Russian village all but obliterated in the latest battle of the Chechen war, Boris Yeltsin is claiming a victory against terrorism and insurrection. But even if the Russian leader is right in reporting that dozens of Russian hostages held by Chechen fighters survived a withering Russian military attack on the village, this violent confrontation can be a source of no honor to Mr. Yeltsin or anyone else involved in the crisis.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;UNION CARBIDE CORP. (UK,N)
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported stronger-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, fueled by growth in its specialty chemicals and intermediates business.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Other View of 'Wonderland'
description: Paula Josa-Jones has nerve. Or maybe things are different in Boston, where the choreographer is based. Sets, props and narrative are out these days in New York modern dance, but all three are featured in "Wonderland," presented by the Paula Josa-Jones/Performance Works company on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater. Unfortunately, Ms. Josa-Jones also used text, a favorite device here and almost always a mistake.

title: No Headline
description: There's nothing in the Constitution of the United States that prevents that."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Twelve Named to Hall
description: The former Southern Cal running back CHARLES WHITE, winner of the 1979 Heisman Trophy, and JERRY TUBBS, an ex-Oklahoma center-linebacker who won the 1956 Walter Camp Award, head a group of 11 players and 1 coach selected to the National Foundation and College Hall of Fame yesterday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Waterworld 1995. MCA/Universal. $100.71. Laser disk, $44.98. 136 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Prince Brat and the Whipping Boy 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $95.92. Laser disk, $34.95. 96 minutes. Closed captioned. G. Release date: Tuesday.

title: U.S. Reminds Yeltsin To Play by the Rules
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher said today that Russia must play by the rules of international law and democratic institutions if it wants full acceptance by the Western world.

title: He Spoke Up for Law, and Died for It;Officials Say Agency Failed to Move a Family in Time
description: It is on the nights when gunfire echoes through the courtyards of the Cypress Hills Houses or when the telephone rings and no one is on the other end that Joyce Delfyette remembers: she still lives with the people who the police think shot her son.

title: Jobless Claims Fall and Blizzard Is Cited
description: New claims for jobless benefits plunged by 67,000 last week, when the blizzard kept many government offices closed. The drop was the largest in more than two years.

title: Book Buyers Line Up to Make First Lady Feel at Home in Her Adversary'sState
description: After the tete-a-tete with Oprah and the heart-to-heart with Barbara, Hillary Rodham Clinton cautiously ventured yesterday into New York State, the home territory of her chief political adversary, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Sheik's Followers Say He Won't Be Silenced
description: Followers of Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, who was given a life sentence Wednesday for his role in bombing and assassination plots in the United States, said yesterday that prison would become a new pulpit for his attempts to replace the government of President Hosni Mubarak and make Egypt an Islamic state.

title: A World With Only 2 or 3 Booksellers?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADVO TO DROP 500 WORKERS IN COST-CUTTING MOVE
description: Advo Inc. said yesterday that it would dismiss 500 white-collar workers and eliminate a layer of management in an effort to cut costs amid declining profits. The company has 4,600 employees. Advo, the nation's largest direct-mail company, is also close to the sale of its Marketing Force unit. Advo's general counsel, David Stigler, declined to provide a price range or identify the buyer. Advo shares tumbled $3.375 yesterday, or 14 percent, to $20.625, in New York stock Exchange trading of 1.1 million shares. Advo also posted lower-than-expected first-quarter earnings and said it would take a second-quarter charge to pay a special $10-a-share dividend.

title: Art In Review
description: Lucio Fontana Barbara Gladstone Gallery 99 Greene Street SoHo Through Feb. 10

title: FIGURE SKATING;Tough, Crafty and Unpredictable
description: As news conferences go, this one had an entourage and a swagger more closely resembling boxing than figure skating. Nicole Bobek followed her coach, her mother and her agent into the room and announced, "If you don't know who I am, you should leave, now."

title: Genesis Health Plans Sale
description: Genesis Health Ventures Inc. said today that it would sell four Indiana nursing homes and a related pharmacy to Hunter Acquisition L.L.C. for $22.3 million. The four homes operate about 635 skilled nursing beds and have annual revenue of about $21 million, Genesis said.

title: Giuliani Fights For Alternative On Arbitration
description: A bill to change the way New York City settles police and fire contract disputes, which Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani contends would significantly increase the city's labor costs, is on a fast track to passage in the State Legislature and could reach Gov. George E. Pataki's desk by the end of the month.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;BEAR STEARNS COS. (BSC,N)
description: The Bear Stearns Companies said yesterday that its earnings in its second quarter more than tripled as trading, investment banking and commission revenue soared.

title: For Stranded Commuters, a Better Payback
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Free Agency: Brown Could Switch Uniforms but Not Stadium
description: The Jets, still uncertain who their quarterback will be next season, have not ruled out going after the Giants' Dave Brown when the free-agent auction begins on Feb. 16.

title: Columbia Gas Names Head For Pipelines
description: Columbia Gas System Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy last November, said yesterday that Catherine Good Abbott, a 45-year-old executive experienced in the turmoil caused by the growing competition in the natural gas industry, would become head of its interstate pipeline systems.

title: BASEBALL;In '97, Let the Games (Between the Leagues) Begin
description: Continuing to change the game of baseball as it has been played in the major leagues this entire century, club owners today unanimously approved interleague play for the 1997 season, creating a schedule format that will have each team playing 15 or 16 games against teams in the other league.

title: ON TV SPORTS;In Roberts, ABC Has Wide World of Talent
description: If some talent decisions in sportscasting are too baffling to comprehend, then credit ABC for having the sense to name Robin Roberts host of "Wide World of Sports." Roberts's ascent atones for ABC's putting the underwhelming Julie Moran in the host's chair in 1994 and 1995.

title: L'Oreal Sweetens Offer for Maybelline on Heels of Benckiser Bid
description: L'Oreal S.A., the world's largest cosmetics company, increased its offer to buy Maybelline Inc. to $41 a share yesterday in what is expected to become a bidding war between L'Oreal and Joh. A. Benckiser G.m.b.H. of Germany for the American cosmetics concern.

title: P.S.C. Orders Nynex to Give Credit Rebates
description: About 5 million telephone customers in New York City, Long Island, and Westchester and Rockland counties will get refunds averaging nearly $10 because Nynex's installation and repair services were found to be too slow.

title: Hello, Out There!
description: To the Editor:

title: E. D. Lustbader, 49, Cancer Researcher
description: Dr. Edward David Lustbader, an expert in biostatistics at the Fox Chase Cancer Center in Philadelphia, died last Thursday at Abington Memorial Hospital. He was 49 and lived in Maple Glen, Pa.

title: BASKETBALL;With Oakley Sidelined, Knicks Look Smith's Way
description: Earlier this season, Charles Smith said the only thing he and Charles Oakley had in common were their first names. Smith might want to amend his opinion.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dolphins' Johnson Fires Two More Assistants
description: Heads continue to roll in Miami. For the third straight day, JIMMY JOHNSON, the Dolphins' new head coach, dismissed an assistant from the DON SHULA regime. This time, it was the defensive coordinator, TOM OLIVADOTTI, a lightning rod for criticism during a disappointing season.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Strong Microsoft Profit Exceeds Wall St. Estimates Microsoft earnings exceeded Wall Street estimates for the latest quarter. Profits came in at $575 million, or 90 cents a share, up 54 percent from $373 million, or 60 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Wall Street analysts had forecast a profit of about 84 cents. On a day when technology stocks rose sharply, Microsoft was up $2.75, to $87.625. [Page D2.]

title: Executive Changes
description: AT&T CORP., New York, named Alex J. Mandl, formerly head of long-distance services, to the positions of president and chief operating officer of the new AT&T, which will run long- distance and wireless operations. John D. Zeglis, currently AT&T's chief legal counsel, was named to the new position of senior executive vice president of policy development and operations support. Harold W. Burlingame was named executive vice president of human resources and Marilyn Laurie was named executive vice president of public relations and employee information. LIFE MEDICAL SCIENCES INC., Princeton, N.J., named John Spitznagel, formerly president of Reed & Carnrick Pharmaceuticals, Jersey City, a division of Block Drug Co., to the positions of chief executive and president, succeeding Herbert Moskowitz, who continues as chairman.

title: Body of Kidnapped Texas Girl Is Found
description: Early this morning, five days after the Arlington police say a stranger seized a screaming 9-year-old from her bicycle and stuffed her into a black pickup truck, local officials said that a body recovered on Wednesday night was that of the missing girl.

title: On a Smooth, U.S.-Style Run for Palestinian Council
description: Before Hanan Ashrawi began speaking today in this village near Jerusalem, there was a moment that seemed taken from an American election campaign.

title: TENNIS;Muster Wins Despite Twisted Ankle; Agassi and Chang Reach 4th Round
description: It was 4-3 in the second set of his third-round match at the Australian Open today, and Thomas Muster was on his back, screaming in pain and grabbing his twisted right ankle.

title: Peru's Sentencing And a Daughter's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: Chenoweth on Forests
description: To the Editor:

title: In Uneasy Time, Saudi Prince Provides a Hope of Stability
description: Every Tuesday they come, petitioners by the hundreds -- bearded sheiks, tribal elders, impoverished Saudis and some of the country's elite -- to seek out the man who is poised to become the next king.

title: Rubin Sees the Big Powers Focusing on Effect of Slump
description: With growth slowing in the United States and Europe and anemic in Japan, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin said today that a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations this weekend would focus on what to do if economic weakness worsened.

title: MCA Interested In Interscope
description: MCA Inc. has been negotiating to acquire a 50 percent stake in Interscope Records for roughly $200 million, several people familiar with the discussions said today.

title: The Accuser Is Now Accused in Cemetry Case
description: The former head of the California State Cemetery Board, hailed last year as a hero for helping people deal with mismanagement at local cemeteries, has now been accused of mismanagement himself.

title: BASKETBALL;Doctors Optimistic as Camby Leaves Hospital
description: Marcus Camby left the hospital today, taking the optimism of doctors that he will soon resume his college basketball career, but no more certain of what caused his 10 minutes of unconsciousness last Sunday than he was when he arrived on a stretcher at the University of Massachusetts Medical Center on Monday.

title: Market Place;For contrarians and risk takers, Apple's woes may be good news.
description: IT is not an investment strategy for the weak of heart, but buying Apple Computer Inc. at its lows has historically been one way to make nice returns. So, are there any buyers?

title: Barbara Jordan's Ideals
description: She left Congress after only three terms, a mere six years. No landmark legislation bears her name. Yet few lawmakers in this century left a more profound and positive an impression on the nation than Barbara Jordan, the eloquent and savvy Texan who died this week at the age of 59.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Wenda Gu In Kahn Gallery 415 West Broadway (near Spring Street) SoHo Through Feb. 15

title: Clinton and 7 G.O.P. Candidates Make Their Appeals to Elderly
description: President Clinton and seven of the Republicans who want his job outlined starkly different proposals today on Medicare, Social Security and other issues of particular concern to elderly people.

title: One Year Later: New Canvas, Same 'Tag'
description: After a year away from the limelight of New York's subway stations and bridge underpasses, the paroled graffiti vandal known as DESA unveiled his latest creation on the side of a Brooklyn firehouse yesterday, the police said.

title: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:
description: LINDEN FREDERICK, Tatischeff & Company, 50 West 57th Street (through Jan. 27). Mr. Frederick drives a stake through the heart of one of the great Symbolist tropes, showing how twilight can transfigure even the dreariest industrial parks, highways and shopping malls. Makes you want to go home and turn on the television before it gets dark (Pepe Karmel).

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Generale des Eaux Loss
description: Generale des Eaux S.A., France's biggest water supply and construction company, suffered the first annual loss in its 142-year history in 1995 because of real estate and construction woes in France and Germany. Generale des Eaux said it lost between 3 billion and 3.5 billion French francs, or $600 million to $700 million, in 1995, compared with a profit of 3.34 billion francs in 1994. Revenue rose to 165 billion francs, from 155 billion. Bloomberg Business News

title: Regents, at Unruly Meeting, Vote to Retain Policy on Bias
description: At a raucous meeting here today in which 11 students were arrested, the University of California's Board of Regents voted to stand by its decision last July to stop admitting students, hiring professors and awarding contracts on the basis of race and sex.

title: Transit Officer Slain in Brooklyn Dispute
description: An off-duty police officer was shot and killed last night in a dispute in a Brooklyn apartment, the police said.

title: On Trade, Buchanan Strikes a Chord
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Budget Battle Comes Home
description: The Federal budget fight came to New Jersey yesterday.

title: HOCKEY;New York Could Field Full Team In All-Stars
description: Three of them are defensemen, so they probably won't be on the ice at the same time. Nevertheless, the three New York area teams could supply a full sextet of players, goalie included, when the Eastern Conference plays the West on Saturday night at the Fleet Center in the National Hockey League All-Star game.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: 25 and Under
description: What's in a name? Quite a bit of marketing power if it's the name of a restaurant.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about one Republican Presidential candidate's proposal for a flat tax misspelled his surname in some editions. He is Senator Phil Gramm, not Graham.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Tom Baril and Rocky Schenck Bonni Benrubi Gallery 52 East 76th Street Manhattan Through Feb. 24

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Health Board Eases the Rules
description: A state health-care board acted yesterday to streamline approval for a variety of new medical services.

title: Woe to Those Displaced by China Dam Project
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: 'The Paper Bag Players on Top of Spaghetti' Kaye Playhouse, Hunter College 68th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues (212) 772-4448 Ages 3 to 9 Through March 3

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Reading the Sorrow of Africa in Individual Faces
description: One of the most remarkable photographic projects in recent years is the series of images made by Fazal Sheikh, an American photographer, in refugee camps in the troubled countries of Central and East Africa. These pictures, most of them portraits, have received wide acclaim since Mr. Sheikh began making them in the early 1990's. Now a show at the International Center of Photography presents an extensive selection of these photographs under the puzzling title "A Sense of Common Ground."

title: 3-Year Term In '90 Killing Of Prize Horse
description: A champion horseman and son of one of the richest men in the United States was sentenced yesterday in Chicago to almost three years in prison for his role in the killing of a show horse for insurance money.

title: Company Briefs
description: PLATINUM TECHNLOGY INC., a maker of software products, will acquire Prodea Software Corp., Eden Prarie, Minn., for $36 million in a stock deal.

title: OPERA REVIEW;New Cast In Rossini's 'Barbiere'
description: The set for the second scene of Rossini's "Barbiere di Siviglia" snagged and collapsed on the Metropolitan Opera's revolving turntable near the end of the opening scene on Wednesday evening. No one was hurt, and after a 20-minute delay, the performance proceeded without further incident.

title: Harlem Gang Leader Will Not Face Death
description: Federal prosecutors have decided not to seek the death penalty against a man accused of running a Central Harlem gang and carrying out 10 murders.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HELENE CURTIS TO CONSIDER SEEKING A BUYER
description: The shares of Helene Curtis Industries rose yesterday after its directors said they would consider the recommendation of Shamrock Holdings of California Inc. that the personal-care products company seek a buyer. Shamrock, the investment manager for members of the family of Walt Disney, made the recommendation in a letter to Helene Curtis dated on Tuesday. Shamrock, which holds a 7.6 percent stake in Helene Curtis, also called for the dismantling of the company's dual-class shareholder structure. Shares of Helene Curtis, the maker of Suave shampoos and Degree deodorant, closed up $1.25 at $42, and have risen 38 percent in the last week.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Very Seamy Side of Life
description: There comes a point when art that strives to reveal the sordid truth goes so gleefully overboard that the degradation it exposes becomes a laughable caricature. Such is the unfortunate case with Paul Morrissey's 1982 movie adaptation of Alan Bowne's play "Forty-Deuce." Although illuminated by the young Kevin Bacon's convincingly scuzzy portrayal of a stringy-haired male prostitute and junkie, the movie is a hyperkinetic mess. The film, whose title is slang for 42d Street, opens today as part of the Morrissey retrospective at Film Forum.

title: U.S. Imposes Rules on Tobacco Sales to Minors
description: The Federal Government yesterday issued rules governing how states should enforce a 1992 law that forbids the sale of tobacco products to anyone under the age of 18.

title: Mayor Compares Sharpton To a Former Klan Leader
description: After first trying to brush aside new questions about his relationship with the Rev. Al Sharpton, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani instead escalated his criticisms yesterday, comparing Mr. Sharpton to David Duke, the former leader of the Ku Klux Klan who ran unsuccessfully for Governor of Louisiana and the United States Senate.

title: 160 Inmates Hurt in Brawl
description: Brawls among up to 2,000 black and Hispanic inmates at a Los Angeles County detention center left about 160 prisoners hurt and forced the authorities to lock inmates in their cells today. It took nearly 600 deputies using nonlethal bullets and grenades to stop the fights, in which inmates used broom handles, broken light fixtures and other weapons.

title: Lois Shapiro, Publishing Executive, 57
description: Lois Shapiro, a publishing executive who helped handle best sellers like "The World According to Garp" by John Irving, "Faces at the Bottom of the Well" by Derrick Bell and "Passages" by Gail Sheehy, died on Wednesday at New York Hospital. She was 57 and lived on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Ex-Kmart Official Indicted in Bribery
description: A former Kmart Corporation executive has been charged with receiving kickbacks and bribes totaling more than $750,000 as a part of a scheme involving the sale of some Kmart properties.

title: INSIDE
description: Drug Suit Settlement Seen Thirteen big drug makers are said to be near agreement on a huge cash settlement in a class action brought by thousands of pharmacies that contend they pay too much. Page D1.

description: To the Editor:
