description: Jade

title: Wrecking Ball Looms For Boys' Leafy Retreat
description: Clark MacMillan's and Garrett Rioux's tree house was the biggest and fanciest for miles around. It had wall-to-wall carpeting, a television set, stereo, refrigerator, sofa, table, chairs and two lamps -- and room for perhaps 15 high-school boys to sleep.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Arnaldo Pomodoro Marlborough Gallery 40 West 57th Street Manhattan Through Feb. 10

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the United Nations Association misattributed the quotation "We are looking for a difficult combination to find: a person who can lead a public outreach organization and command respect, and have enough familiarity with the U.N. to deal with issues in a significant way. The president also has to be a fund-raiser and a developer." The speaker was William J. vanden Heuvel, chairman of the association's board of governors, on the search for a successor to James Leonard, the group's president. The speaker was not Mr. Leonard himself.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ramapoughs Are Rejected
description: Once again, the Federal Government has ruled that the Ramapough Mountain People have failed to prove they are an Indian tribe. The group's lawyer described the decision as an election-year sop to the casino industry, which is worried about competition from Indian casinos.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Teacher Who Once Had Dreams
description: Maybe there are strong souls who don't quake at the prospect of Richard Dreyfuss in a latter-day "It's a Wonderful Life." Maybe not. Mr. Dreyfuss's taste for grandstanding could easily sink a tale of simple virtues, especially one about a music teacher who is often seen marching, dancing, conducting or otherwise registering emotions aimed at the bleacher seats. But in "Mr. Holland's Opus," Mr. Dreyfuss gives a warm and really touching performance. He's firmly in control of the film's comic moments and just as comfortable delivering the film's calculatingly Capraesque payoff: a good cry.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Higher Results Are Reported By Microsoft
description: The Microsoft Corporation reported today that its earnings rose 54 percent in its fiscal second quarter. The results exceeded Wall Street estimates and set the stage for a continued rally in the technology stocks.

title: Abroad at Home;For Want of a Nail
description: The military aspects of carrying out the Dayton peace agreement for Bosnia have gone impressively well so far. But the harder, civilian part of the job is just beginning. And there problems have arisen in three areas.

title: Chevron-Texaco Deal
description: The Chevron Corporation and Texaco Inc. said this week that their jointly held affiliate, Amoseas Indonesia, would build a 70-megawatt power plant in the Darajat area of western Java at a cost of $125 million. Darajat currently taps its energy from a volcano on the so-called Ring of Fire, the world's most active volcanic zone, which rings the Pacific basin.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Coleman Rejoins 76ers
description: When DERRICK COLEMAN walked into practice in Philadelphia yesterday after a two-week absence with an ankle injury, his 76ers teammates erupted into applause.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Shares Tumble After Bailout Talks Stall
description: The stock price of Fokker N.V. plummeted yesterday after reports that talks between the Dutch Government and DASA of Germany over a bailout for the aircraft maker are deadlocked. Fokker shares closed off 1.7 guilders, or 19 percent, at 6.9, in Amsterdam.

title: Musings by a Poet of Choral Togetherness
description: THE music world can produce few better, more consistent examples of a well-oiled machine these days than choral events presided over by Robert Shaw. True to form, Mr. Shaw's sixth annual choral workshop sponsored by Carnegie Hall, this year dealing with Verdi's Requiem, "Ave Maria" and "Stabat Mater," began like clockwork on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Manhattan Center in midtown.

title: Insurer Buys Policies
description: The Protective Life Corporation said today that its main operating subsidiary, the Protective Life Insurance Company, had agreed to acquire a block of insurance policies for $31 million from the Calfarm Life Insurance Company. Protective Life will acquire about 38,000 policies for $2.7 billion of insurance. The Birmingham-based insurer will receive annual premiums of about $17 million from those policies.

title: Sports of The Times;It's Time To Realign Leagues, Too
description: MARGE SCHOTT had voiced skepticism about interleague play, the newfangled notion baseball owners have just approved unanimously, and which had been a consideration in one form or another for only about 90 years.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Love and Human Remains 1993. Columbia Tri-Star. $97.51. 100 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Michiko Kon Robert Mann Gallery 42 East 76th Street Manhattan Through March 2

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Earlier Warning for Students
description: TRENTON The first "early warning" test for students in New Jersey -

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Toshio Shibata Laurence Miller Gallery 138 Spring Street SoHo Through Feb. 24

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Cuts in European Interest Rates Spur Broad Gains by the Dollar
description: The dollar rose yesterday against most major currencies, bolstered by interest-rate cuts in Europe.

title: CHRONICLE
description: LISA MARIE PRESLEY and MICHAEL JACKSON are planning to divorce.

title: With the G.I.'s in Bosnia: Money Wins Serb Hearts
description: Vladimir Lazic, 33, a Serbian carpenter who has worked little since the war began, said he and his friends were taken by surprise when Company C set up camp in a cornfield outside town. No one knew they were coming, he said, and there was plenty of suspicion.

title: That Voice You Hear Might Be Your Taxi's
description: As if Midtown traffic were not enough to make taxi passengers question their sanity, they may soon be hearing voices. The city's chief taxi regulator envisions a future in which every trip in a yellow cab would end with a recorded reminder not to leave anything behind.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Shifts Position On Currency Exchange
description: China will let foreign investors buy hard currency with their Chinese yuan in banks on a limited basis, a central bank official said yesterday. The move is China's first major currency change since it allowed domestic companies to buy foreign currency at banks in January 1994, and it marks a step toward convertibility of the yuan.

title: Hello, Out There!
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Ailes Steps Down as Head Of CNBC Cable Channel
description: Roger Ailes resigned yesterday as president of CNBC, the cable business news channel owned by NBC, and the network announced a restructuring of the channel's management.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;A Net Loss For Quarter At McDonnell
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported a net loss in the fourth quarter yesterday, citing a $1.12 billion charge, but said that its profit from operations rose 13 percent, exceeding analysts' expectations.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;PFIZER INC. (PFE,N)
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings from continuing operations rose 24 percent, bolstered by strong sales of its new drugs, including the blood-pressure drug Norvasc and the antidepressant Zoloft.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The wall is a woven lattice, so when you sit in the second dining room at Buddha Green, you get the sense of being in a giant basket. Another dining room has beautifully lighted bamboo trees just outside the window. No matter where you sit in the spare restaurant, a soft-spoken waitress is likely to come and explain the menu to you.

title: Greek Party Chooses Rival To Replace Papandreou
description: In a break with the legacy of its founder and longtime leader, Andreas Papandreou, Greece's governing Socialist Party today elected one of his chief critics, Costas Simitis, 59, as the country's new Prime Minister.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARY ALICE, the star of a new production of James Baldwin's play "The Amen Corner," says she knew there was something unusual about the opening-night audience on Wednesday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.

title: Two Exchanges Post Drops In Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales decreased on the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange in the most recent period, the exchanges reported yesterday.

title: Hijackers Seem to Ease Their Threat to Blow Up Turkish Ferry
description: A Turkish ferry seized by hijackers who support the anti-Russian rebels in Chechnya approached Istanbul today, with the hijackers seeming to pull back from threats to blow up the vessel along with themselves and more than 200 passengers.

title: City Shares in Humanities Grants
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities announced the awarding of $17.3 million in grants yesterday, most of them $30,000 fellowships to support the work of individual scholars. The largest single grants, for $575,000 each, went to two institutions in New York City: the American Academy in Rome and Columbia University. Both were challenge grants, which require the institutions to raise $2.3 million on their own.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;BBDO West goes out on a limb, at least a little bit, in commercials for Sheba cat food.
description: FOR years, advertising for pet food has relied on gimmicks like miniature chuck wagons or singing cats. In its first campaign for Sheba cat food, BBDO West takes a different tack.

title: Fixed Mortgage Rates Fall
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 7.02 percent this week, down from 7.08 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. The rate matched the 7.02 percent average of the week that ended on Jan. 4. That was the lowest since Feb. 3, 1994, when rates averaged 6.97 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.48 percent, up from 5.45 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 6.53 percent this week, down from 6.59 percent a week earlier.

title: Fiat to Cut Production
description: Blaming a continuing crisis of the European auto market, Fiat, the Italian auto maker, said this week that it planned to put thousands of workers on temporary layoffs to curtail its production in February. Fiat said it would produce 21,000 fewer vehicles next month, but it did not disclose how many cars it would have produced without the cutback. Under a temporary state-supported unemployment program, 26,800 workers will be laid off in the week between Jan. 29 and Feb. 4 while 12,000 will be affected in the week of Feb. 5-11. Fiat said that the cutback would affect older models; newer models, like the midsized Bravo and Brava, would proceed as scheduled.

title: Hepatitis Virus Passed to Hemophiliacs in Clotting Compound, HealthOfficials Say
description: Federal health officials reported yesterday that they had documented the transmission of the hepatitis A virus through the blood-clotting substances given to hemophiliacs to stop their bleeding.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHAIRMAN RESIGNS AT MICRON TECHNOLOGY
description: Micron Technology Inc. of Boise Idaho, a leading chip maker, said yesterday that Steve Appleton had resigned as chairman, chief executive, president and director, a little more than a year after he assumed control. Mr. Appleton was replaced by Tyler Lowrey, formerly the vice chairman and chief technical officer. Mr. Appleton's resignation comes after Micron shares skidded 66 percent from a high of $94.375 in September as prices fell for the company's dynamic random access memory chips. Micron shares closed at $32, down 25 cents, yesterday. Mr. Appleton was named chairman in September 1994 after Micron's biggest shareholder, the Idaho potato magnate J. R. Simplot, grew disenchanted with previous management's cautious approach to expansion.

title: Killer on Parole Fires Gun At 2 Officers in the Bronx
description: A paroled killer, who was released in August after five years in jail for fatally stabbing a woman when he was 15, shot two police officers last night at a Bronx housing project, seriously wounding one of them, the police said.

title: F. Don Miller, 75, Ex-Head Of U.S. Olympic Committee
description: Col. F. Don Miller, whose leadership in 1980 twice helped save the United States Olympic Committee from extinction, died on Wednesday night in Penrose Hospital in Colorado Springs. He was 75.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Guinness Adds Charge Because of Japan Sales
description: Guinness P.L.C., the British brewer and distiller, said yesterday that it would take an added charge of L39 million, or $60 million, in 1995 and warned that profit from its Japanese spirits operations did not meet expectations. The London-based company, which makes Dewar's Scotch, said that a further deterioration in the Japanese liquor market would cause 1995 profit from the region to fall L10 million short of expectations, which previously ranged from L35 million to L40 million.

title: Baseball Approves Interleague Play
description: Major League Baseball owners, continuing their efforts to change the way the game has been played in this century, yesterday approved interleague play for the 1997 season.

title: ART REVIEW;Seeming So Sweet That the Bite Goes Unnoticed
description: Correction Appended

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Parole Board Denies Freedom to Steinberg
description: Joel B. Steinberg, the convicted child killer whose trial in the late 1980's heightened awareness of domestic violence, was denied release yesterday by the New York State Board of Parole after serving the minimum portion of his 8 1/3-to-25-year sentence.

title: For Stranded Commuters, a Better Payback
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;4th-Quarter Comeback For I.B.M.
description: Delivering some welcome news to edgy technology investors, I.B.M. reported a 39 percent increase in fourth-quarter earnings yesterday, surpassing Wall Street forecasts and sparking a rally in its stock price.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions yesterday about the testimony of David Watkins, a former White House aide, on the dismissal of White House travel office employees in 1993 misidentified the Congressional committee that heard him. It was the House Government Oversight and Reform Committee, which is investigating the dismissals, not the Senate Whitewater committee.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Paine Webber Is Settling Fraud Counts
description: Paine Webber Group Inc., the parent of the nation's fourth-largest brokerage firm, said yesterday that it had agreed to settle charges that its brokers misled investors in selling risky limited partnerships. The company said it would provide $175 million to settle the claims.

title: Strong Profits Push Stocks Up Sharply
description: Stocks climbed yesterday as surprisingly strong fourth-quarter earnings reports overcame traders' pessimism over the stalled budget negotiations in Washington.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Roman a Clef to Recent Politics
description: PRIMARY COLORS A Novel of Politics By Anonymous 366 pages. Random House. $24.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FOUNDATION HEALTH TO BUY MANAGED HEALTH NETWORK
description: The Foundation Health Corporation signed an agreement yesterday to buy the closely held Managed Health Network Inc. in a stock-swap valued at about $45 million. Foundation Health, a managed health care company, said it did not expect the acquisition to have any impact on its 1996 earnings. Los Angeles-based Managed Health has branches in 12 states and annual revenue of about $44.4 million. The company provides employee-assistance and behavioral-health programs to more than 350 corporate, government and union clients. Foundation Health, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., will combine Managed Health's operations with its own behavioral health unit.

title: Charity Marketplace Can Fill Federal Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanitation Workers Look To Sunday for Day of Rest
description: At 7 A.M., as fog hovered over the shore of the Hudson River one day earlier this week, Michael Murphy stood in a rambling garage trying to rally his troops. He told them he knew they were tired but they had to continue cleaning up after last week's blizzard.

title: Missing Records Were on a Table In the White House, Aide Testifies
description: The Clinton aide who said she had discovered copies of long-sought records of Hillary Rodham Clinton's former law firm testified today that she had found the documents in a room in the White House living quarters to which only she, the Clintons, their house guests, White House maids and butlers, and Mrs. Clinton's clothing and makeup assistant had access.

title: For Stranded Commuters, a Better Payback
description: To the Editor:

title: Lockheed Picks Russian Engine
description: Lockheed Martin's Astronautics Space Systems plans to use a Russian engine on its new Atlas rockets.

title: FIGURE SKATING;Galindo's Show Goes Unrewarded
description: When his tragic, unfulfilled career ebbed last year, Rudy Galindo left the ice for eight months before returning because the 1996 national championships would be held here in his hometown.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: WINTER SPORTS;Woman Disqualified
description: A British woman hoping to break into an all-male sport has been barred from racing in next month's world skeleton championship in Canada, the British Bob-Skeleton Association said yesterday.

title: SKATING REVIEW;This Time, It's an Ice Road to Oz (With Jitterbug)
description: Baum for winter-weary souls is being dispensed with a liberal hand through Sunday at Madison Square Garden, where Dorothy, the Munchkins and all sorts of familiar characters (even Toto) are skimming through a lavish, colorful version of "The Wizard of Oz on Ice."

title: KEEP IN MIND
description: A Quiz Show, a Boy on the Run: The Most-Rented Films of '95 Some videophiles may be surprised to learn that Frank Darabont's "Shawshank Redemption" finished No. 1 on Billboard's 1995 best-renter list. Here are some other titles from the Top 20.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Diamond Multimedia
description: The shares of Diamond Multimedia Systems Inc. plummeted 37 percent yesterday after the company disclosed on Wednesday in its fourth-quarter report that it had more than $2 million of missing inventory, leading to an adjustment of 7 cents a share. The maker of sound cards and other multimedia products for PC's said it did not know what happened to the inventory. Diamond's shares finished down $9.813, at $16.438, the biggest loser yesterday in Nasdaq trading.

title: The Neediest Cases;Employees On Wall St. Give $87,730 To Neediest
description: Six Wall Street firms and their employees this week gave $87,730 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, exceeding their gift from last year and also helping the fund's total contributions outpace last year's.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ELECTRIC BOAT TO LAY OFF 1,500 EMPLOYEES THIS YEAR
description: Electric Boat, which has been steadily reducing its work force because of a decline in submarine orders, said yesterday that it will lay off 1,500 employees this year, most of them by the end of September. Electric Boat, a unit of General Dynamics, employs about 14,000 at its shipyard in Groton, Conn., and its plant in North Kingstown, R.I. The submarine builder currently has a backlog of only five craft, with two scheduled to be delivered to the Navy this year. Electric Boat has said it plans to reduce its work force to 7,000 by the end of 1998. Jobs are also being eliminated through attrition, including retirements, the company said.

title: REPUBLICANS LACK CONSENSUS ON HOW TO BAR SHUTDOWN
description: United in disdain for President Clinton's latest budget proposals and convinced that no deal is in sight, Congressional Republicans acknowledged today that they had not agreed on how to keep the Government open and avoid defaulting on its bonds.

title: Art Foundation Sues, Claiming Discrimination
description: The Barnes Foundation, home of one of the world's most renowned Impressionist art collections, filed a civil rights complaint today accusing the local township of racial discrimination.

title: In America;Separation Anxiety
description: The euphemism of choice for the corporate chopping block is downsizing, but variations abound. John Thomas, a 59-year-old AT&T employee, was told on Tuesday that his job was "not going forward." One thinks of a car with transmission trouble, or the New York Jets offense, not the demise of a lengthy career.

title: Thousands Flee Rwandan Refugee Camp
description: About 10,000 Rwandan refugees who have been camped in northeast Burundi fled across the border into Tanzania today after fighting erupted near their camp, United Nations officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KEYSTONE TO CUT JOBS AND GET RID OF SOME ASSETS
description: Keystone International Inc. said yesterday that it would cut about 260 jobs, or about 6 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring intended to streamline operations and divest itself of underperforming assets. Keystone, a maker of flow-control products, also said its fourth-quarter earnings, before one-time expenses associated with the restructuring, should be about the same as last year's results, which would put them below Wall Street estimates. The company, which is based in Houston, will divest itself of certain assets, including several small businesses and one product line, which total about $13 million in annual sales.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;More Talks on Browns
description: After three days of talks in Atlanta about the Cleveland Browns' proposed move to Baltimore, National Football League Commissioner PAUL TAGLIABUE yesterday said owners would meet again Feb. 8-9 in Atlanta or Dallas.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Florida Citrus Narrows a Review
description: The Florida Department of Citrus in Lakeland, Fla., has narrowed a mandated review for its orange juice and grapefruit juice advertising accounts, with billings estimated at $27 million, to 4 finalists from 10 semifinalists. One agency eliminated was the Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York, which had handled the accounts for the last 25 years.

title: Minnesota Fats, a Real Hustler With a Pool Cue, Is Dead
description: Rudolf Walter Wanderone, the charming, slick-talking pool hustler who labored largely in obscurity until he reinvented himself in the 1960's by claiming to be Minnesota Fats, died yesterday at his home in Nashville. He was 82, or perhaps 95.

title: ART REVIEW;A Window Into French Character
description: The French Portrait, 1550-1850" at Colnaghi's has a high ambition: nothing less than a concise history of French portraiture from the heyday of the French Renaissance to the beginnings of Impressionism.

title: N. T. Rama Rao, 72, Is Dead; Star Status Infused His Politics
description: N. T. Rama Rao, a former movie star who served three tumultuous terms as Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh, the southern state, died today at his home in Hyderabad, the state capital. He was 72.

title: Peru's Sentencing And a Daughter's Fate
description: To the Editor:

title: ART REVIEW;An Encore For Sculptures By Brancusi
description: It should happen this way all the time. The great Brancusi retrospective, which closed in Philadelphia on New Year's Eve, is making an unexpected curtain call, of sorts, at the Museum of Modern Art. Some months back the Modern had the brainstorm to ask the Pompidou Center in Paris if it would send the Brancusis it was lending to Philadelphia to New York before returning them to France, where the sculptures will go into storage anyway: the center is rebuilding Brancusi's studio and plans to put the works there when the renovation is finished, maybe this fall. Pompidou said yes, but everyone involved stayed mum about the idea until last week so the Modern's small coup wouldn't detract from Philadelphia's big show.

title: As Some Leap, Four Are Killed In Chicago Fire
description: Flames fanned by 40 mile-an-hour winds engulfed a 10-story apartment house today, killing four people, including a woman who tried to jump to safety as heat and smoke spread panic among occupants.

title: The Spoken Word
description: "THE MAKROPULOS CASE," Metropolitan Opera Guild, Kaplan Penthouse, Rose Building, 70 Lincoln Center Plaza. Janacek's opera will be discussed by Dr. Harlow Robinson, an author and professor at the State University of New York at Albany. Tomorrow at 11:30 A.M. Tickets, $12. Information: (212) 769-7021.

title: Western Digital Buyback
description: The Western Digital Corporation said today that it planned to buy back five million of its common shares from investors over the next 18 months. The amount is nearly 10 percent of the company's 48.4 million outstanding shares. Western Digital, a maker of computer components based here, said that under a previous program, it had purchased 5.8 million of its shares for about $91 million since February 1995.

title: 13 Drug Makers Ready to Settle Pharmacist Suit
description: Thirteen big drug manufacturers are close to agreement on a huge cash settlement in a class action lawsuit brought by thousands of retail pharmacies, according to lawyers familiar with the case. The pharmacies have accused the drug makers of overcharging them in violation of Federal antitrust laws.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Josephine Patterson Albright misstated the role of her father, Joseph Medill Patterson, at The Chicago Tribune. He was co-editor and co-publisher; he was not a founder.

title: ART REVIEW;A Hellenistic Epic In Stone Panels
description: THE Great Altar of Pergamon, or part of it, has come to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which is a little like saying that part of Chartres or Notre Dame has been packed up and shipped to New York from France. If the altar doesn't immediately come to mind, perhaps you dozed through the slides on ancient Greece and Rome that day in Art History 101. A massive pile of baroque sculptural extravagance, it is the textbook definition of Hellenistic art, with the famous Gigantomachy frieze on the outside of it; the Gigantomachy is an amazing, tangled relief, more than 300 feet long, that depicts gods battling giants. The show at the Met focuses on fragments from another frieze, which tells the story of Telephos, the mythical ancestor of the Pergamene kings.

title: Arafat's Justice
description: The state of Palestine declares its adherence to U.N. principles and goals, and to the principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. -- Palestinian Charter of Independence, November 1988.

title: Restaurants
description: My first three meals at Kokachin began with the most wonderful breadsticks. They were crisp and soft, slightly warm, studded with sesame seeds and absolutely irresistible. Then, sometime in mid-December, they were replaced by tough rolls. "We decided people wanted something more substantial," the waiter said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Thyssen Unit 'Positive'
description: Thyssen Industrie A.G. said yesterday that firmer prices make the outlook for its current fiscal year "altogether positive." The capital goods unit of Thyssen A.G. posted a 21 percent drop in new orders for the first quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, though this was largely because of one large shipbuilding order a year ago. First-quarter sales rose 1 percent to 1.8 billion marks, the company said. Bloomberg Business News

title: Hilton Will Not Spin Off Gambling From Hotel Unit
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation's indecision over whether to split itself into separate hotel and gambling companies might finally have been settled yesterday when the company said it would not proceed with the planned spinoff of its gambling operations.

title: Clinton Urges Budget Talks To Continue
description: A day after Republican Congressional leaders broke off budget talks with the White House, President Clinton sought to portray himself as the conciliator, saying he would keep the door open to a deal that "is clearly within our grasp right now."

title: Out of the Cold: U.S. and Russian Spies Share Cloaks in Bosnia
description: United States intelligence services, forced to cooperate with one another and with their Russian counterparts in the muddy fields of Bosnia, are creating an espionage network of dozens of spies, electronic-eavesdropping devices and sophisticated computer systems.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Casino Helps in Home Loans
description: From the beginning, casinos made the promise that the rest of Atlantic City would share in their wealth. Many neighborhoods are still waiting.

title: Talks Are Held On Reopening Of Alien Unit
description: Six months after a melee closed a privately run detention center for undocumented aliens in Elizabeth, N.J., the Immigration and Naturalization Service is in the final stages of negotiations to reopen the center with a different, more experienced private contractor, officials said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF HENRY HOLT TO STEP DOWN
description: After nearly eight years as president and chief executive of Henry Holt & Company, Bruno A. Quinson said yesterday that he would resign from those posts effective March 31. Mr. Quinson, 58, who will keep an office at the publishing house, was named to Holt's board. He has been credited with a successful expansion by the publisher, which is owned by the German media conglomerate Holtzbrinck. Mr. Quinson is to be replaced by Michael Naumann, the publisher of Rowohlt Verlag, one of Germany's largest general publishing houses, which is also owned by Holtzbrinck.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Papp's Never-Ending Festival

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain, in a Surprise, Cuts Interest Rates
description: The Bank of England unexpectedly cut the cost of borrowing yesterday by a-quarter of a percentage point. The central bank pushed its base lending rate down to 6.25 percent from 6.5 percent, creating an identical cut in the minimum lending rates charged by the nation's commercial banks. The reduction lowered the base rate to its level at the end of 1994 and rallied the stock market. British shares soared to a record high, with the Financial Times-Stock Exchange index of 100 issues gaining 44.5 points to close at 3,748.7.

title: Company Reports Unlocking Genetic Code of Dangerous Germ
description: Human Genome Sciences Inc., a biotechnology company in Rockville, Md., said yesterday that its scientists had determined the chemical sequence of 99 percent of the genome of the bacterium Staphylococcus aureus, a common cause of hospital infections and toxic shock syndrome.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP. (BT,N)
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 25 percent. The results disappointed Wall Street and depressed the the company's stock.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Caterpillar Earnings, in a Surprise, Rise by 7.5%
description: Caterpillar Inc. said today that earnings rose 7.5 percent in the fourth quarter, surprising analysts, who had expected a decline, and sending the company's stock up 10 percent.

title: In Jail Business, Nashville Company Leads Crowded Field
description: In 1983, two former West Point roommates, one a lawyer, the other a business consultant, cooked up what was then a rather unusual idea: private prisons.

title: AUTO RACING;$3.6 Million Purse Planned In CART Race on Indy Day
description: A race purse of at least $3.6 million, with a minimum $1 million winner's share, was announced yesterday for the U.S. 500, the race that will be run on May 26, the same day as the Indianapolis 500, as a protest by car owners against new Indy 500 qualifying rules.

title: Studies Find Beta Carotene, Used by Millions, Doesn't Forestall Canceror Heart Disease
description: Two large studies have found that contrary to the beliefs or hopes of the millions of Americans who take it, beta carotene, a vigorously promoted vitamin supplement, is completely ineffective in preventing cancer or heart disease. One of the studies found that it might even be harmful to some people.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Weak Reports Bolster Prices Of Treasuries
description: Prices of Treasury securities returned close to their two-week highs yesterday. For the third consecutive day, market participants bought on weak economic data that pointed to continued low inflation.

title: Home Video
description: Last week in the snowy East, cleaned-out shelves and soggy carpeting were the rule in many video stores. Bad weather always starts a run on just about every tape in the house. At the Video Room in Manhattan, for instance, a clientele whose predilections usually run to sophisticated fare was making off with "Clueless," the California high school tale starring the new "it" girl, Alicia Silverstone.

title: NYC;In a Firehouse, New Burdens, Old Worries
description: THE call came in at 9:47 P.M., and the first thing that Firefighter Charlie Hayes did wasn't to grab his gear. The first thing he did was to shut off the stove where he had been cooking dinner for his firehouse mates from Ladder Company 120 and Engine Company 283.

title: Kohlberg Kravis to Purchase Xerox Unit for $2.7 Billion
description: Culminating its exit from the financial services field, the Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell Talegen Holdings Inc., its property and casualty insurance subsidiary, to an investor group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and Talegen management for $2.7 billion.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Divide Religious Right
description: With only three weeks to go before the first votes are cast in the 1996 Presidential caucuses and primaries, religious conservatives are a political force fractured, their allegiances divided among several Republican candidates.

title: Orange County Threatens Suits
description: Orange County today put many of Wall Street's largest brokerages and law firms on notice that they could be its next legal targets.

title: Tokyo Journal;The Land of Laureates: Japan's Passion Is Poetry
description: She is young and famous, with her own weekly television show, a radio program and fans who fawn over her on the street, but Madoka Mayuzumi is neither a movie actress nor a rock star.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Rises as Europeans Move to Cut Interest Rates
description: The dollar rose against most major currencies yesterday amid expectations of further interest rate cuts in Europe and speculation that leading industrial nations will endorse a stronger dollar at a weekend meeting.

title: Cutbacks at L. L. Bean
description: The catalogue retailer L. L. Bean Inc. offered employees severance and early-retirement packages today in an effort to trim its work force as sales of its outdoor gear fall below expectations. Bean, which also froze wages and left a hiring freeze in place, did not specify a target number for the job cuts.

title: Astronauts Say Space Station Work Is Feasible
description: The astronauts on the shuttle Endeavour who walked in space said today that their work during two excursions into the spacecraft's cargo bay showed that the work needed to build a space station could be done.

title: Marcia Davenport, Biographer, Is Dead at 92
description: Marcia Davenport, a biographer of Mozart and best-selling novelist, died on Tuesday in a hospital in Monterey, Calif. She was 92 and lived in Pebble Beach, Calif.

title: A Bit of July, Sort of, in January
description: The weather system that produced yesterday's rain, thunder, fog and warmth, in which much of this winter's deep snowfall vanished, might be considered a garden-variety thunderstorm in July. But it comes to New York in January about once a decade.

title: SKIING;Street Finds the Rhythm To Capture a Downhill
description: Picabo Street, the first American woman ever to win the season downhill title, beat Sweden's Pernilla Wiberg by 0.58 seconds today on the track where she began an impressive streak of five victories last year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FIGURE SKATING;Urmanov Withdraws
description: The Olympic champion ALEKSEI URMANOV of Russia has withdrawn from this year's European figure skating championships, organizers confirmed yesterday. The championships begin tomorrow in Sofia, Bulgaria, with men's qualifying and continue through the week. Urmanov reportedly has conjunctivitis, an inflammation of the eye's inner surface.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Job Growth in December Quiets Fears of Recession

title: Pro-Chechen Ferry Hijackers Surrender to Turks
description: Turkish authorities, ignoring Russian demands that they act more forcefully, ended a 72-hour hostage crisis on the Black Sea without bloodshed tonight, persuading pro-Chechen hijackers to surrender and release the more than 200 hostages they had been holding aboard a captured ferry.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Chrysler Reports Strong Earning on Its Mini-Van Sales
description: Buoyed by brisk mini-van sales, the Chrysler Corporation announced unexpectedly strong fourth-quarter earnings today, producing a sharp jump in its stock price and strengthening the hand of the auto maker's management in its efforts to retain control of the company.

title: Gale Winds, Fog and Cats and Dogs: Not Just Another Bad Hair Day
description: Josephine Schneider had safely negotiated the sidewalks littered with shards of windows sent tumbling from their frames by the frenzied winds yesterday, relieved that she was on the homestretch to the Staten Island Ferry building. Then a sudden blast knocked her flat across the roadway.

title: POLITICS: IN CALIFORNIA;Nader as Green Party Nominee May Dull Clinton's Prospects in Golden State
description: One of the great imponderables in every Presidential election is whither California's 54 electoral votes, the largest lode of all.

title: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;World Cup Comes to TV, and Maybe the Garden
description: Hockey's World Cup, a tournament to be played in late August and early September, might be making a two-game stop in midtown Manhattan. Stephen J. Solomon, senior vice-president and chief operating officer of the National Hockey League, said today that Madison Square Garden was one of the finalists in contention as a site.

title: Maybe It Wasn't the Economy in the '92 Election After All
description: Could inaccurate Federal data have cost President George Bush a second term? Have they led some economists to proclaim a surge in worker output that may well be a statistical illusion?

title: COMPANY NEWS;KODAK TO PAY $168 MILLION IN PERFORMANCE BONUSES
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would pay $168 million to about 45,700 employees in the United States under the company's distinctive wage dividend program. This compares with the $137 million paid last year to 48,500 eligible employees, the company said. On March 8, employees are to receive a payment equal to 8.22 percent of their 1995 participating wages and salaries, a 20 percent increase from 6.82 percent in 1994, according to Kodak. This wage dividend is based on a return on net assets of 22.2 percent and recognizes the efforts of employees to improve the company's performance, it added. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Kodak closed up $2.375, at $69.375.

title: A Sermon at the Mosque
description: Above the murmur of worship within a stifling hot Harlem mosque yesterday, three shouts suddenly rang out as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani padded in stockinged feet toward the podium.

title: 1,000 Patients Lose Insurance To a Loophole
description: About 1,000 of the state's sickest residents are on the verge of losing private health insurance because of a legal glitch in a process that was supposed to transfer their coverage from a longstanding Blue Cross policy to different health plans.

title: Novell Executive Quits Over Revamping Plan
description: Novell Inc., the leading producer of software for desktop computer networks, yesterday announced the resignation of its executive vice president and chief technology officer, Sheldon Laube, who joined the company only last May.

title: As a Lawyer, He's Exemplary; as a Robber, an Enigma
description: Sitting beside his lawyer in Federal District Court today, a diminutive man in a conservative gray suit, starched, striped cotton shirt and conservative tie massaged his temples as if trying to banish a migraine.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Prosecutors Critical of Law
description: The Essex County Assistant Prosecutors Association yesterday denounced the decision by the County Executive, James W. Treffinger, to start enforcing a law requiring employees of the county to live within its borders. The group said it was a "quick fix, Newt Gingrich type of approach" that will create costly court backlogs and exacerbate jail overcrowding, as experienced prosecutors who live elsewhere leave their jobs rather than move.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Spooky Little Tricks Within the Labyrinth
description: Carnival spook houses are usually most thrilling just before you step into them; what's inside can never match the lurid promises of their exteriors. So in a way it seems apt that the most definite pleasures of the SoHo Rep revival of "Dark Ride," Len Jenkin's midway sideshow of a play from 1981, actually occur before the production begins.

title: Jobs Data Send Most Bond Prices Down
description: Prices of all Treasury securities except the 30-year bond were down yesterday, as many investors sold on what is considered negative economic news for the bond market, although it is good for most everyone else.

title: Financing Settled for Job-Creation Zone in Depressed Areas
description: After months of debate, Federal, state and city government leaders gathered in Harlem yesterday to announce that they had finally agreed to provide the money to establish an empowerment zone intended to create jobs and business opportunities in depressed areas of Harlem, the South Bronx and Washington Heights.

title: Employers Add to Payrolls
description: Easing fears that the economy is headed toward recession, the Labor Department reported yesterday that employers had added a moderate 151,000 jobs to payrolls in December. The jobless rate remained steady at 5.6 percent. The Clinton Administration hailed the report. Page 36.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Whitman Not Laughing at Ad
description: Just do not blame the goat. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is demanding that the U.S. Virgin Islands tourism office withdraw a television commercial that seems to ridicule the idea of vacationing in New Jersey. The advertisement depicts an islander fretting that his homeland is such a magnificent place that he cannot think of anywhere to vacation. When his goat bleats as if making a suggestion, the islander replies with disdain, "New Jersey? Nah!"

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Blow to Banned Runner
description: The Portuguese Government yesterday rejected a request by the International Amateur Athletic Federation to review urine samples of the British 800-meter runner DIANE MODAHL, banned for four years after testing positive for drugs at a 1994 meet in Lisbon.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Guarantee Williams a Nice Raise: $2 Million
description: If Bernie Williams suddenly took pity on George Steinbrenner and his mushrooming Yankees payroll -- which today soared beyond $50 million -- and if he accepted the club's salary arbitration figure and did nothing to try to get more money, he would still receive a remarkable raise of more than $2 million for the coming season.

title: SUPER BOWL: NOTEBOOK;Cowher and Steelers Just Want to Have Fun
description: Those tears in Bill Cowher's eyes have turned to twinkles of mirth.

title: No Respite From Murder;City Decline in Killings Is Not Echoed in Bedford-Stuyvesant
description: From the stoop of Junior's bodega in Bedford-Stuyvesant, New York's falling crime rate seems like nothing more than a mirage to Jose Arapioamnou.

title: Punishment Won't Prevent 'Poisoned Babies'
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Companies Competing To Be First in Gas to Mexico
description: The competition to profit from the opening of Mexico's energy market intensified this week as Tenneco Inc. entered a race with California's huge utilities to become the first American company to ship natural gas for retail sale in Mexico.

title: Michael Matthews, Theater Writer, 37
description: Michael Matthews, a theater writer, performance artist and one of Ping Chong's principal collaborators in the experimental theater, died in Amsterdam on Jan. 11. He was 37.

title: Accused Mexican Narcotics Trafficker Is Said to Offer to Answer AllQuestions
description: Juan Garcia Abrego, the accused narcotics trafficker, told Federal Bureau of Investigation agents after his arrest and expulsion from Mexico "that he would be glad to answer any and all questions the agents would pose to him," according to an F.B.I. account of the encounter.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about William P. Tavoulareas, a former president of the Mobil Corporation, misstated his birthplace. It was Brooklyn, not Greece.

title: CONCERT REVIEW;Making Music of the Music In Langston Hughes Poems
description: It is no wonder that composers as stylistically diverse as Alexander Zemlinsky, Kurt Weill, Harry T. Burleigh and Elie Siegmeister were drawn to Langston Hughes's poetry. His distillations of the black American experience are by turns haunting, searing and slyly humorous, and his language has a musicality of its own, something that comes through in rhythms that invite melody and in an emotional clarity that demands a response.

title: BOSNIA FOES FINISH PULLBACK BUT FAIL ON P.O.W. RELEASE
description: Bosnian Serb and Bosnian Government forces today completed the pullback of most of their troops and heavy weapons from confrontation lines in compliance with one of the most significant deadlines set by the Dayton peace agreement.

title: Punishment Won't Prevent 'Poisoned Babies'
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: IN THE SOUTH;A Southern Democrat Resists The Lure of Party Switching
description: Like the manatees of Florida and the whooping cranes of Texas, Representative Gene Taylor of Mississippi belongs to an endangered species.

title: The Neediest Cases;For a Mother, Help at Home Eases Transition After Surgery
description: The shaking in her left foot was certainly strange, but the doctors at the hospital were unable to pinpoint a cause, so they sent Mariana Whythe home.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Study: 90% Speed on Road
description: Governor Whitman, whose car was clocked traveling over 80 miles an hour recently, is not the only one in a hurry on New Jersey highways. According to a study by the State Department of Transportation, about 90 percent of the vehicles on the Turnpike travel above 55 m.p.h., and drivers routinely exceed the limit on other highways, sometimes by substantial margins.

title: In Palestinian Vote, Message Lies in the Mandate
description: Early Saturday morning, Palestinians are to begin voting for the first time for their own government, and about the only thing that has not produced suspense or tension is the result.

title: FIGURE SKATING;Kwan Leads, With New Polish and Poise
description: This season, 15-year-old Michelle Kwan has undergone an image makeover, attempting to evoke the persona of a young woman instead of a promising innocent. She now wears more sophisticated makeup and costumes, but her skating has also become demonstrably more mature.

title: NATO Backs Off Helping Bosnia War Crimes Panel
description: With only one prisoner in custody and money dwindling, the international war crimes tribunal got sympathy but little else today when it put its case before NATO, seeking help to secure mass grave sites in Bosnia and to arrest more than 50 indicted war criminals and deliver them to The Hague for trial.

title: Frank Dorsa, 88, Waffle Developer
description: Frank Dorsa, who invented the frozen waffle and teamed up with his brothers to found what became Eggo Food Products, died on Wednesday here. He was 88.

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUORUM HEALTH SHARES RISE ON MERGER TALKS
description: The shares of Quorum Health Group Inc. rose yesterday after the company said that it was in merger talks and that it expected to report second-quarter earnings that exceed Wall Street estimates. Quorum, a hospital operator, said the merger discussions were with an undis closed health care company. At yesterday's closing Nasdaq price of $27, up $1.125, Quorum has a market value of $1.29 billion. The company said it expected to post net income of $16.9 million, or 34 cents a share, for the quarter ended Dec. 31. That would be a 23 percent gain over the year-ago $13.8 million, or 28 cents a share.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AIRTOURS SAYS CARNIVAL MAY BUY A STAKE
description: Airtours P.L.C., a British package tour and holiday company, said yesterday that the Carnival Corporation, the world's largest cruise ship operator, was considering buying a stake in the company of less than 30 percent after the sale of new shares. At yesterday's stock price, a 30 percent stake in the Airtours would be worth about $229 million. Airtours and Carnival have been discussing future cooperation that could lead to Carnival buying a stake through the issue of new shares, some of which also would be offered to existing shareholders.

title: Korean Bribe Rekindles Flight 007 Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: Editorial Notebook: Bannerman's Folly;A Hudson Island, Haunted by Goblins
description: For a few seconds in the movie "North by Northwest," at the beginning of the epic train journey, a strange scene flashes past outside the window: an island with a brooding, vaguely Scottish-looking castle on it. Riders bound north on Amtrak or Metro-North's Hudson Line today can see the same sight if they venture north of Cold Spring. A thousand feet out into the Hudson sits Bannerman's Island, with its strange ruins, looking like something out of a 19th-century engraving.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF CEPHALON SINK ON F.D.A. MOVE
description: Shares of Cephalon Inc. plunged 34 percent yesterday after the company said late on Thursday that the Food and Drug Administration had declined to permit expanded clinical tests of its treatment for Lou Gehrig's disease. The company's stock had risen sharply in expectation of speedy F.D.A. approval of broader trials for the drug, Myotrophin. The Chiron Corporation, which is Cephalon's marketing partner for Myotrophin, has also benefited from investor optimism. The F.D.A.'s concerns apparently are related to a trial in Europe, reported in November, in which the mortality rate of treated patients was nearly twice that of patients taking a placebo. Cephalon stock was down $12.50, to $23.375 a share, in Nasdaq trading. Chiron's shares were down $5.50, at $104 each. Lou Gehrig's disease is a progressive paralysis.

title: Shame in Germany
description: Will Carl von Ossietzky, the legendary German anti-Nazi journalist of the early 1930's, be posthumously rehabilitated? I weigh my words when I declare that, if he is not, it will be a shame.

title: U.S. Payrolls Expand but Jobless Rate Remains at 5.6%
description: Easing fears for the moment that the economy is on the verge of sliding into a recession, the Labor Department reported today that employers added a moderate 151,000 jobs to payrolls in December. The unemployment rate remained steady at 5.6 percent.

title: Gordon Foster, 91, Expert on Metallurgy And American Ferns
description: F. Gordon Foster, a metallurgical engineer whose interest in microscopy led him to become an authority on ferns, some of the oldest plants on earth, died on Sunday at the Monroe Village retirement community in Jamesburg, N.J. He was 91.

title: General to Be Named Drug Program Chief
description: Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey of the Army, who heads the Army's Southern Command in Panama, is expected to replace Lee Brown as chief of the Clinton Administration's anti-drug program, a senior Government official says.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Elie Out 10 to 12 Weeks
description: MARIO ELIE's surgery on Thursday to repair broken bones in his right wrist was pronounced successful, but his timetable for recovery is now listed as 10 to 12 weeks instead of 6 to 8. That means the Houston Rockets will be without one of their best clutch performers until near the playoffs.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPANY'S SHARES RISE ON EARNINGS REPORT
description: Shares of the Microsoft Corporation rose strongly yesterday after the software company reported better-than-expected second-quarter earnings on strong sales of its Windows 95 operating system. Shares of the world's biggest personal computer software company gained $4.25, to $91.875, in Nasdaq trading of 14.2 million shares. Microsoft said its second-quarter profit from operations rose a better-than-expected 45 percent. The company also reported strong sales of its general business programs, consumer software and networking software. At least three Wall Street analysts raised their rating on Microsoft's stock because of bullish projections about the company's earning growth for the rest of the fiscal year.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: Boys' Basketball

title: BASKETBALL;Jazz Downs Magic Behind Malone's 37
description: John Stockton had 17 assists and scored 11 of his 15 points in the fourth quarter and Karl Malone scored 37 points as the Utah Jazz defeated the Orlando Magic, 111-99, tonight.

title: The New Great Wall of China
description: In yet another distressing effort to strengthen its authoritarian power, the Chinese Government has placed new and self-injuring curbs on the flow of information from the rest of the world. All news services providing economic data in China are now to be "supervised" by the official New China News Agency. A benign reading is that the agency is less interested in enforcing ideological conformity than in exacting a generous user fee from Western providers, chiefly Reuters and Dow Jones. But all too probably, the official "supervisors" will soon be blotting out unwelcome information.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6

title: How Not to Program VCR
description: Subway service on the I.R.T. No. 3 line was suspended for more than an hour yesterday after someone threw a VCR onto the electrified third rail, engulfing several cars in smoke.

title: Dole Releases His Tax Returns And Aims Challenge at Forbes
description: Senator Bob Dole released his tax returns today going back to 1966, and challenged his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination to do the same.

title: RASH OF FAILURES IN FLIGHT CONTROL
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that 7 of the 10 major power failures that struck air traffic control centers across the country in recent months -- some resulting in hundreds of flight delays -- were largely caused by technicians who did not fully understand the new power supply equipment they were putting into use.

title: No Headline
description: They were very heavily armed, with TNT sticks strapped to their bodies. But when they realized that news of their action had been sent around the world, they decided that they had achieved their goal."

title: Kay Strozzi, Actress, 96
description: Kay Strozzi, an actress who appeared on Broadway in the 1920's and 30's and who also performed on radio and television, died on Thursday at the Bayberry Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 96.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Drop in Fines Worries Group
description: Though casinos took in more than $3 billion last year, the State Council on Compulsive Gambling, which depends on fines against casinos to help those with gambling problems, said that it is almost tapped out. The agency said yesterday that it might have to stop addiction treatment and other services unless the state lays more cash on the table. In recent years, as the Casino Control Commission has relaxed its regulation and oversight of the industry, fines have declined sharply -- from $856,000 in 1993 to $434,000 in 1995. In the past, the first $500,000 in annual fines went to the council. For the fiscal year beginning April 1, the council expects to get only $75,000.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Startling Rise in Jobless Rate
description: In a sudden downturn that reflects the continuing impact of corporate cutbacks, unemployment in the New York region worsened significantly in December, with New Jersey having the second worst rate of joblessness of any major industrial state.

title: About New York;Imperial Gems, For Viewing And Devouring
description: A NARROW side street off the East River where drab, institutional buildings tower over a dusty jumble of cars looked like a suitable enough setting for a Russian lunch. Admit it, the usual impression of Russian food is that besides potatoes and bread, most of it's in short supply.

title: Officer Gets 5-year Term
description: One of six police officers who pleaded guilty in a corruption investigation was sentenced today to five years in prison, an unusually long term that the judge said was intended to serve as a deterrent.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Fokker Needs More Cash To Survive, Official Says
description: The Prime Minister of the Netherlands, Wim Kok, said yesterday that the Dutch aircraft builder Fokker had a slim chance of surviving unless its German majority owner put more money into a rescue package. The Government has been negotiating with the Daimler-Benz subsidiary that owns 51 percent of Fokker about how much each side would contribute to the bailout.

title: S.E.C. Deals a Blow to First Bank's Bid for First Interstate
description: The $10 billion bid by the First Bank System of Minneapolis to buy the First Interstate Bancorporation of Los Angeleswas dealt a possibly fatal blow yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which ruled that First Bank could not buy back its own stock for two years.

title: 2 Blasts Hit Nigeria Soon After Air Crash
description: Separate explosions have shaken an airport and a hotel in Nigeria, just days after a group claimed it had sabotaged a plane that crashed on Wednesday, killing a son of the country's military ruler.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japanese Government Issues Report on Banks
description: Japan's Finance Ministry tried yesterday to ease criticism of its bailout plan for housing lenders by releasing a report with details on the $76 billion worth of loans that went sour. But many critics called the disclosure insufficient to gain public acceptance of the plan to use Government money to help bail out the institutions, which invested heavily in speculative real estate deals in the late 1980's.

title: Journal;Magical Rushdie Tour
description: If you hear a pop-pop-pop," my mother-in-law instructed from Scarsdale, "hit the floor!"

title: Report Says Rohatyn Is Candidate for Fed
description: The name of Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, emerged yesterday as a candidate for vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Masur's Way With the B Minor Mass
description: There are many good reasons for modern symphony orchestras to continue to address Bach, despite the incursions of the early-music movement. In New York, one of the best reasons is Kurt Masur.

title: NEW YORK REGION REGISTERS A SURGE IN UNEMPLOYMENT
description: In a sudden downturn that reflects the continuing impact of corporate cutbacks, unemployment in the New York region worsened significantly in December, with New Jersey having the second-worst rate of joblessness of any big industrial state.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PERKIN-ELMER SHARES RISE FOLLOWING EARNINGS REPORT
description: Shares of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation rose 9 percent yesterday after it reported late on Thursday that it had had a strong rise in earnings and that it planned to cut costs. In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of the company, which makes analytical instruments, closed up $3.875, at $45. The company said earnings for its second quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, rose to $22.8 million, or 53 cents a share, from $17.1 million, or 40 cents per share, in the corresponding period in 1994. The company said it planned to take a third-quarter after-tax charge of $65 million to $75 million, or $1.30 to $1.50 a share, as part of a restructuring plan for its analytical instruments business.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BI Agrees to Purchase
description: BI Group P.L.C. agreed yesterday to be bought by the National Industries Company of Kuwait for L96.3 million ($149 million) in cash. BI, an engineering and design concern, which makes products for the aerospace, marine and auto industries, said National Industries agreed to pay 132 pence a share. Shares of BI Group soared 21 pence, to 131 pence, in London trading. National Industries said it desired BI's technology and its exposure to markets outside the Middle East as National tries to diversify its operations. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Negotiators Approve Military Bill In Compromise With President
description: Congressional leaders agreed today on a $265 billion Pentagon budget that meets President Clinton's major demands, which means the measure will probably be signed into law.

title: Aides Say Mrs. Clinton Erred In Claiming Press Got All Files
description: The White House said tonight that Hillary Rodham Clinton had erred when she said during her current book tour that in 1992 she and her aides had made available to the press all of the information they had about the Whitewater land venture and her legal work for a failing Arkansas savings and loan association.

title: A 'Living Wage' Law Would Benefit New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Victor Bisharat, 75, Stamford Architect
description: Victor Hanna Bisharat, an architect who designed buildings in downtown Stamford, Conn., died on Jan. 10 at his home in Sacramento, Calif. He was 75.

title: Posting Matter From Church On Internet Is Ruled Illegal
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a Virginia man violated the copyrights of the Church of Scientology by posting confidential church documents on the Internet, even though the material was obtained from public court records.

title: Fear of Viruses
description: In the next few days, the Food and Drug Administration and the Centers for Disease Control are expected to publish guidelines to address many safety issues surrounding the transplanting of animal organs and tissues into human patients. This report will follow the recent operation to transplant bone marrow from a baboon to Jeff Getty, a San Francisco-area resident infected with the AIDS virus.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BRITISH AIRWAYS SAYS IT WILL NOT BUY MORE USAIR SHARES
description: British Airways P.L.C. said yesterday that it would not exercise two options to buy another $450 million worth of preference shares in USAir Group Inc. The British carrier bought a 24.6 percent stake in USAir in 1993, hoping to expand the linkup if the United States lifted its 25 percent ceiling on foreign ownership. The Department of Transportation has not changed its stance, however, and British Airways said in a statement that an increase in the ceiling "was not expected to be forthcoming."

title: Observer;More Profusion, Please
description: I am asked to write a letter of recommendation on behalf of a man who needs none. A long, successful career and exemplary character recommend him so persuasively that it is silly to ask for hastily scribbled epistolary testimony to his excellence.

title: Funeral Home Ends Surcharge for AIDS
description: Under pressure from the Justice Department, a Virginia funeral home is paying refunds and damages to nine families it charged extra for embalming their relatives because they had died of AIDS or its complications.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;49ers Hire Former Jet
description: The San Francisco 49ers yesterday named the former Jets cornerback and safety JOHNNIE LYNN as their defensive backs coach.

title: FIGURE SKATING;A Pair of Dreams
description: In January 1994, while the rest of the figure skating world grew transfixed by the clubbing attack on Nancy Kerrigan by associates of Tonya Harding, Brian Wells set out on a solitary, improbable journey out of obscurity.

title: State Trooper Shot in Camden Drug Sweep
description: A New Jersey state trooper was shot andcritically wounded last night and a drug suspect was shot to death in Camden, two weeks after a contingent of troopers began to patrol the desperately poor city to assist the local police in the face of mounting crime.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the fourth-quarter financial results of the Eastman Kodak Company misstated its net income for the quarter in some editions. It was $275 million, not $375 million.

title: Sports of The Times;The Nets' Bermuda Triangle
description: AMID talk of clean slates and new beginnings, Willis Reed began yesterday's telephone conference call by announcing that the Nets had completed a trade, sending Kenny Anderson and Gerald Glass to Charlotte.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Germany and Britain Agree on Jet Project
description: Germany and Britain said yesterday that they had resolved differences over how to share work on the $60 billion Eurofighter project. The agreement between the two nations' military procurement ministers is subject to approval by the German Parliament, where some question the new-generation jet fighter's cost and military value.

title: Changes Can Save Veterans' Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ELECTRIC BOAT JOB CUTS TO TOTAL 3,200 IN 1996
description: Revising a statement earlier in the week, Electric Boat said yesterday that it would cut about 3,200 jobs this year, or more than 20 percent of its work force, because of a sharp decline in submarine orders. The job cuts will include about 700 layoffs at the company's plant in North Kingstown, R.I., which were not included in a statement made Thursday, which said 1,500 people would be laid off companywide. Total employment at Electric Boat, a division of General Dynamics, now stands at about 13,900.

title: A. G. Gaston, 103, a Champion Of Black Economic Advances
description: A. G. Gaston, a black multimillionaire businessman in Alabama who used his money and influence in the cause of civil rights and shrugged off accusations that he was an Uncle Tom, died yesterday in Birmingham, his hometown. He was 103.

title: BASKETBALL;The Other Cornerstone Drops: Anderson Is Traded
description: For four seasons, Derrick Coleman and Kenny Anderson played together as the cornerstones of the Nets franchise. Their future was to be intertwined with the Nets' future. That was the plan. In the end, though, the plan unraveled. Neither player wanted to stay in New Jersey, in Anderson's case not even for $40 million.

title: 22-Month Sentence For Rabbi's Aide
description: A rabbi's assistant from Brooklyn was sentenced to 22 months in prison today for sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl who sat beside him during a flight from Australia to Los Angeles.

title: Putting Porsche in the Pink
description: Not too long ago, the production floor of Porsche's factory was not a pretty sight. Workers would storm off in a huff. Managers would fume. Voices would rise above the hum and bang of the line.

title: Yeltsin Criticized for Handling of Chechen Hostage Crisis
description: As Russia's latest hostage crisis subsided, President Boris N. Yeltsin faced scathing criticism of the bloody and bungled military operation his troops led against Chechen rebels holding hostages in Pervomayskoye.

title: Punishment Won't Prevent 'Poisoned Babies'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Sunday about the Barney's Inc. bankruptcy filing misstated the extent to which factors -- the financial go-betweens that guarantee payments to retail suppliers for a fee -- had stopped doing business with the Barneys New York stores before the company filed for bankruptcy protection. While some had stopped, several large factors continued to work with Barneys.

title: Company Briefs
description: PLATE GLASS AND SHATTERPRUFE INDUSTRIES LTD., Johannesburg, South Africa, a glass maker, said its Windshields America unit would merge with U.S. Auto Glass to create the largest automotive glass replacement company in the United States.

title: Garment Acquisition
description: Marisa Christina Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Adrienne Vittadini Inc., a New York-based maker of high-end women's clothing, for $19 million in cash and stock initially. Marisa Christina, which makes women's and children's clothing, could eventually pay up to $58 million, depending on Adrienne Vittadini's profitability in 1998 and 2000.

title: In Buildings Strike, Debate Over Fair Wages
description: With the strike by New York's building maintenance workers now more than two weeks old, it has become not just a test of the two sides' strength, but increasingly a debate over what wage level is fair.

title: I.B.M. Again Leads Surge As Dow Posts Gain of 60.33
description: The stock market soared in heavy trading yesterday, led once again by I.B.M., which climbed 5 3/4, to 102. Many other companies with favorable earnings reports also posted higher prices. More than a billion shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Rutgers Hires Benedict
description: JIM BENEDICT, a former Rutgers receiver who spent two decades coaching high school sports in New Jersey, was named an assistant coach for the Scarlet Knights, TERRY SHEA, the new coach, said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EDISON BROTHERS SELLS ENTERTAINMENT UNITS
description: Edison Brothers Stores Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Edison Brothers Mall Entertainment and Horizon Entertainment to a unit of Tokyo-based Namco Ltd. Edison, which filed for protection from creditors under bankruptcy law in November, said Namco Cybertainment Inc. submitted the higher of two bids for the subsidiaries at an auction held on Thursday. The deal is subject to approval by United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware. The Edison subsidiaries operate about 128 game rooms and entertainment centers. Edison operates about 2,700 apparel, footwear and entertainment specialty stores and is closing about 500 stores by Jan. 31.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CANAL PLUS TO BUY CAROLCO PICTURES FILM LIBRARY
description: The financially troubled movie producer Carolco Pictures Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its film library, which holds such hits as "Basic Instinct" and "Total Recall," to an affiliate of the French pay television company Canal Plus for $58 million. The deal is subject to certain conditions, including approval by the bankruptcy court, a Carolco statement said.

title: Sinan A. Korle, 81, U.N. Protocol Chief

Most economists agree this is just a "pause in growth," the ministry said in its January economic report, "which does not mean a premature end to the economic expansion seen since spring of 1993." The signs for 1996 are that growth will resume "in the course of the year," the ministry said. It predicted a "renewed worsening" of unemployment in the short term. (Bloomberg Business News)

It is an attractive piece but not a shattering one: its composer was, from available evidence, gifted but not inspired. Krasa might have gone on to greater things if his life had not been cut short in his mid-40's. He might also have faded into obscurity.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

He was a ruthless dictator who profited from luck, but he was also a shrewd strategist who rebuilt Spain's postwar economy, our reviewer, Paul Johnson, said last year. Although Mr. Johnson felt this biography overly emphasized Franco's evil, he found it "full of fascinating details . . . like Boswell on Johnson." A SON AT THE FRONT By Edith Wharton. Northern Illinois University, $14. The war at home is the theme of this novel, first published in 1922 and never before available in paperback. Drawing on the author's experiences, it portrays the collision between the aloof sensibilities of American expatriates living in Paris and the ardent desires of the French to defend their land in World War I. John Campton, a divorced American painter, is loath to have George, his French-born son, join the fighting at the front. But George's desires intervene. M. F. Egan, writing in The New York Times in 1923, said of Wharton's novel: "So far she has done nothing that equals it. She sounds the finest depths of sentiment without becoming sentimental."

title: Kapsa's March
description: THE BRIDE OF TEXAS By Josef Skvorecky. Translated by Kaca Polackova Henley. Illustrated. 436 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $27. AT 71, Josef Skvorecky remains an ironist, a disposition granted him by nature and by the successive totalitarian regimes under which he lived until he emigrated from Czechoslovakia to Canada in 1968. In his novels, Mr. Skvorecky writes with the skeptical authority of an ironic witness to tragic events. He approaches matters of principle offhandedly, as if to remind the reader how indelicately principles are adduced in an absolutist state. "Faith?" asks one of his characters in the aftermath of the Prague Spring. "Where, except maybe in a madhouse, is there any faith left to be lost?" Yet Mr. Skvorecky's novels abound in faith, though it's guarded by the self-exposing irony of a writer. So it is remarkable to come upon "The Bride of Texas" (it was published in Czech in 1992). Mr. Skvorecky has set this work among a group of Bohemian-born soldiers during the final weeks of the American Civil War, when Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman was marching northward through South Carolina in a landscape set alight by withdrawing rebel forces and by stray elements of his own advance troops called "bummers." At the end, Sherman would turn away from a climactic battle at Bentonville, N.C., because he knew the war was almost over and because, as he says, war "is not an exercise in mass execution."

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction;Stuffed Sparrows and Other Statements
description: The French artist Annette Messager is remarkable for many reasons: she is one of a handful of French women artists who have been exhibited internationally since the 1960's; she has addressed, with unflagging originality, feminist issues while working in a country with no coherent feminist tradition in painting; and her multimedia artworks have a push-me, pull-you ambivalence that makes them deliciously provocative. ANNETTE MESSAGER (Los Angeles County Museum of Art/Museum of Modern Art/Abrams, paper, $24.95), the catalogue to her first retrospective exhibition in the United States, now at the Art Institute in Chicago, offers a concise introduction to her art. Ms. Messager, whose greatest influence is the work of the Surrealists, often works in series; photographs and taxidermized animals have been two constants of her introspective and sometimes menacing artworks. One of her most tender yet macabre early series, "The Boarders," featured an installation of stuffed sparrows in hand-knit sweaters, which she baptized, punished and took for "walks," conflating maternal, childlike and corporal impulses. In the 70's, she tackled themes other artists pursued much later: her photo series "Voluntary Tortures," which documented women's mudpacks and plastic surgeries, anticipated the work of Jenny Saville and Orlan by nearly two decades, and she used jokes and aphorisms as a means of ironic cultural commentary long before Richard Prince and Jenny Holzer did. Recently, Ms. Messager has combined drawing and stuffed toys in more pointedly political pieces about global issues. Written by the exhibition's curators, Sheryl Conkelton of the Museum of Modern Art and Carol S. Eliel of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, "Annette Messager" overlooks some of the artist's quirkier early works (for "My Approaches," for example, she sat at a cafe table and photographed businessmen's flies), and it neglects to clarify this proto-feminist artist's relationship to American feminist art of the 70's, many of whose concerns she shared. Still, it traces the evolution of Ms. Messager's singular vision and confirms her status as one of France's most engaging post-modern artists. Margot Mifflin

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A 1950's Nuclear Bunker Will Open for Tours

title: Corrections

The Engineering Vanguard Program of the National Action Council for Minorities in Engineering was created as the Engineering Posse Program through a partnership with Meta networks, a New York group that works with teen-agers.

title: YOUR HOME;New Help On Taxes For Elderly
description: BEGINNING this month, thousands of New York City residents will become eligible for participation in two city-financed programs designed to provide property-tax assistance or rent-increase exemptions to certain elderly property owners and renters.

title: The Capitalist;Fidelities Revisited
description: IT HAS NOW BEEN SIX MONTHS since I used this column to advertise my purchase of Silicon Graphics. I bought 500 shares in the company, of whose business I was perfectly ignorant, on the basis of a private tip from Jeff Vinik, the manager of Fidelity's $54 billion Magellan fund. My thinking ran as follows: across America people were handing over billions of dollars each month to Vinik to invest. Vinik was injecting some meaningful fraction of what he was given into Silicon Graphics, causing its share price to rise.

title: THE LIVES THEY LIVED
description: In your introduction, you write that Yitzhak Rabin, Israel's Prime Minister, was "gunned down in a racist act.' However you might describe this shattering assassination, it most definitely was not a racist act. Not all the horrors in our contemporary world are racist.

title: Pictures and a Mystery From 1850's Jerusalem
description: WILLIAM POLAND was in his garage in Minnesota, fixing his car, when he heard a story on National Public Radio that caught his attention. A photographer, John Barnier, had discovered a rare collection of 19th-century glass-plate negatives at a garage sale near St. Paul. The 134 images depicted Jerusalem in the middle 1850's and were said to be the work of an obscure photographer, Mendel John Deniss.
