title: The Third Rock From Ursa Majoris
description: Life imitates art. For some time, Hollywood has fostered an interest in extraterrestrials. A new TV series featuring an extraterrestrial family which visits Earth and takes human form -- the leader disguises himself as a physicist, apparently so that his eccentricities are not viewed as unusual -- continues TV's fascination with aliens. In one of the oldest TV science fiction series, the science mission of the U.S.S. Enterprise is clearly stated: to explore strange new worlds, to seek out new life and new civilizations.

title: Adding Emotion to Erudition at the Y;The Organizer Behind a Jazzier, Growing Lecture Series

title: Using Guidebooks

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Team Owners Know the Issues, but They Don't Have Any Answers

The fans, however, apparently don't care about different rules for different leagues and balanced schedules for both leagues because the owners aren't doing anything about those issues.

title: ART;Some Views of India, Old and New
description: SO far as recognition in the United States is concerned, contemporary painters and sculptors from India have yet to match their counterparts in literature and film. One explanation may simply be underexposure, for while individual expatriates are to be found exhibiting in and around New York City, shows that bring them together are few and far between.

title: Invisible Wounds
description: SPEAKING OF SADNESS Depression, Disconnection, and the Meanings of Illness. By David A. Karp. 240 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25. UNLIKE people who suffer devastating illnesses that can be "documented" by numbers and pictures, people who suffer severe depression find it almost impossible to articulate their particular experiences of hell because they have no burn marks to show for it. In his book "Speaking of Sadness: Depression, Disconnection, and the Meanings of Illness," David A. Karp contends that the phenomenology of depression is as important to study as the more commonly researched issues of incidence, etiology and treatment. A person does not just wake up one day and announce, "I am a depressed person." Each statement he makes about himself, his depression, his relationships and his future is the result of an evolutionary process in which he assumes an "illness identity" over time.

title: STYLE;Show Time!
description: We'd done grunge. We'd done the glamour revival. The clock was about to strike noon on the 90's -- a decade that, by the time the clothes hit the stores, would be officially half over -- and still no discernible style had emerged. There was no "look" that our children would grow up to dismiss as "so 90's," rolling their eyes; no unanimous silhouette like the hourglass shape that earmarked the 50's; no sartorial invention like the miniskirt or the bell-bottom pant, which set the 60's down in history. Fashion (we're reminded on a regular basis) is theatre now, and as the curtain went up on spring 1996 -- a round of shows that began in early October, in Milan, passed through Paris and drew to a close five weeks later, in New York -- the 90's were still up for grabs, there for the taking by anyone with a vision strong enough to carry the next five years.

title: Delicatessen Owner Is Shot to Death In Brooklyn Robbery
description: A Brooklyn delicatessen owner was shot to death on Friday during a robbery in his store minutes before he was to close it for the night, the police said. The killers fled with the day's receipts.

title: JERSEY;Taking Slush Seriously, at $6 an Hour

Lee Thompson's FLAME OVER INDIA (1959), from England. It's a nicely stylized adventure, flavored by Ms. Bacall's Manhattan rasp and a crisp cluster of British pros like Kenneth More, Wilfrid Hyde-White, Isabel Jeans and Herbert Lom. The film was a timely career boost for the widow of Bogart, who had been warmly welcomed to London by the Laurence Oliviers. Then came "Flame." Neat job, though a well-placed boulder would have stopped the train -- SAT./EARLY SUN. at 1:45 A.M. on CHANNEL 21. Howard Thompson

The saguaro is native only to the Sonoran desert, which covers a fair-sized swatch of northwestern Mexico, the Baja peninsula and southwestern Arizona.

description: In 1990, a remarkably composed 19-year-old of Greek origin played nearly flawless power tennis against his elders in his national tennis championship.

description: MULINO'S presents its diners with one of the most beautiful dining rooms in the county. The luxurious space, comfortable seating, handsome decor and, not least, the glass wall showing a seasonal garden and waterfall beyond -- all guarantee patrons serenity and respite from the bustle just outside the door.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;Memories Filtered Through a Rosy Lens
description: FORGET THE FACT THAT Aaron Birnbaum is 4 feet 9 inches tall. "At 100, everyone has shrunk a bit," said Mr. Birnbaum, a folk artist who turned to painting at 70 after he closed his dress-manufacturing business. "I had some suits; I had to shorten the pants. I think I lost two inches."

She paces the length of Suite 122 of the Comfort Inn, which also doubles as her union office, wearing denim shorts, a vivid red T-shirt that says, "Union, Yes!" and a pair of floppy slippers decorated with neon-colored puppies. Exhaustion (or, perhaps, the slippers) has the unlikely effect of making her look even younger than her 23 years. She has slept for 9 hours during the past 48, and her meals today will be, in order, from McDonald's, Burger King and Pizza Hut.

title: HARVEY PENICK
description: As the son of one of the original members of the club where Harvey Penick was the golf pro for so long, I was being given a lesson by the master, in hopes that I would carry on the family addiction to golf. I must have been 18, the year 1952. On the practice tee, Harvey had me hit a ball with a No. 2 wood. Hit solid, the ball began its rise but after about 20 feet appeared to explode in the air and drop heavily to the ground. After sharing a surprised look, Harvey and I walked to the tee to find the ball had hit a bird in flight, immediately killing it. Harvey glanced up, without raising his head, and said with a wryness that was all his, "Damndest birdie I ever saw." ROBERT SWEARINGEN, M.D. New York

They installed plumbing, built walls and patched a leaky ceiling. "For a while," recalled Mr. Newmann, "we were essentially camping in a construction site."

description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: Secrets of the Sands
description: FOUR CORNERS History, Land, and People of the Desert Southwest. By Kenneth A. Brown. Illustrated. 372 pp. New York: HarperCollins Publishers. $26. THE Colorado Plateau was the last blank spot on the map in the contiguous United States. Not a single plateau but a labyrinth of plateaus, canyons, peaks and desert basins occupying adjacent parts of Utah, Arizona, New Mexico and Colorado, the region remained unexplored until the mid-19th century. Since then, it has inspired some of our best thinking and writing about wild nature and humanity's relationship with it. Arid climate and rugged terrain provided seminal opportunities for the developing sciences of geology and archeology. Anasazi cliff dwellings remained remarkably well preserved 700 years after their abandonment, and sedimentary strata provided a record of evolution since the Paleozoic Era. Writers like Wallace Stegner, Ann Zwinger and Edward Abbey have made the plateau a major literary region.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Anderson Trade Delayed By Reeves
description: The Nets delayed today the four-player trade that sent Kenny Anderson and Gerald Glass to Charlotte for Kendall Gill and Khalid Reeves.

description: More and more, the Presidential campaign of 1996 is sounding like the Congressional campaign of 1994, with anti-Washington issues of term limits and Congressional pensions punctuating the discourse.

He walks the same sidewalks today as he did growing up, and he sees many of the same faces -- only now he watches over the neighborhood and keeps pace with the news on the street.

description: WITH a portfolio of more than $500,000, Johnny Byrd of Norfolk, Va., seems to be the kind of investor who could afford to relax.

His skin was mottled, his body wasting away from the disease that would soon take his life, just as it had killed two others whose bodies had been committed to the fire only hours before.

title: Winning by Losing on Trade
description: The newly created World Trade Organization issued its first major ruling last week, rendering a judgment against the United States. A judicial panel ruled that a provision in the Clean Air Act discriminates against foreign oil producers, violating trade rules. Contrary to a reflexive denunciation by Pat Buchanan, the Republican Presidential candidate who charged that the ruling threatens American sovereignty, the action shows that the trade organization is off to a good start. In the long run, the W.T.O. will greatly benefit Americans.

title: JAZZ VIEW;Album by Album, a History Emerges
description: THE ARRIVAL OF EIGHT NEW CD'S FROM the Dutch label Criss Cross brings a feast of mainstream jazz. The pianist Darrell Grant's "New Pop" is a tribute to the Horace Silver school of small-group arranging, but made modern. Tim Warfield's "Cool Blue" is an unrestrained and passionate session by one of the strongest young tenor saxophonists in jazz. The pianist Bill Charlap's "Souvenir" has ease and elegance that are rarely found in jazz, especially among younger musicians.

The result has been air pollution, frayed tempers, accidents and countless hours of lost work and leisure time.

title: Safe-Sex Lies
description: I HAVE BEEN TESTED FOR H.I.V. THREE times. I've gone to clinics and stuck my arm out for those disposable needles, each time forgetting the fear and nausea that descend upon me before the results come back, those minutes spent in a publicly financed waiting room staring at a video loop about "living with" this thing that kills you. These tests have taken place over five years, and the results have always been negative -- not surprisingly in retrospect, since I am not a member of a "high-risk group," don't sleep around and don't take pity on heroin-addicted bass players by going to bed with them in the hopes of being thanked in the liner notes of their first major independent release. Still, getting tested always seemed like the thing to do. Despite my demographic profile, despite the fact that I grew up middle class, attended an elite college and do not personally know any women or straight men within that demographic profile who have the AIDS virus, I am terrified of this disease. I went to a college where condoms and dental dams lay in baskets in dormitory lobbies, where it seemed incumbent on health service counselors to give us the straight talk, to tell us never, ever to have sex without condoms unless we wanted to die; that's right, die, shrivel overnight, vomit up our futures, pose a threat to others. (And they'd seen it happen, oh, yes, they had.) They gave us pamphlets, didn't quite explain how to use dental dams, told us where we could get tested, threw us more fistfuls of condoms (even some glow-in-the-dark brands, just for variety). This can actually be fun, they said, if only we'd adopt a better attitude.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry;The Color of Fatality
description: Alberto Manguel's foreword to A BLUE TALE AND OTHER STORIES (University of Chicago, $14.95), a posthumous volume by Marguerite Yourcenar, explains that the three "curiosities" collected here, written between 1927 and 1930, when the author was in her mid-20's, shed light on her artistic development and life. While fruitful critical and biographical connections can be drawn between the stories and Yourcenar's formidable oeuvre -- particularly "Memoirs of Hadrian," "Alexis" and "Oriental Tales" -- the stories also stand on their own. As translated by Mr. Manguel, the prose of the young Yourcenar is accomplished and her vision arrestingly mature. In the first story, "A Blue Tale," European merchants set out to plunder a cave full of sapphires on a Middle Eastern island only to meet failure, death and destitution. The spare recitation and repeated use of the color blue prove to be haunting features in this fable of greed, in which a woman catches sapphires in her hair for the merchants; after she is cruelly kidnapped, her tears turn to aquamarines. In "The First Evening," initially written by Yourcenar's father and revised by her at his request, a jaded, self-absorbed man travels with his young wife to their honeymoon in Switzerland. His fear of life's banality, which engulfs him as he approaches his conjugal bed, is momentarily abated by a telegram announcing the death of his former mistress, who still preoccupies him. The last story, "An Evil Spell," further reveals Yourcenar's imaginative powers as she describes a witch hunt, set somewhere near the Mediterranean in southern France. Here a woman named Algenare is deemed to have cast an evil spell on a woman she envies. Pointing up the human need for scapegoats, Yourcenar illustrates how naming and becoming are one, as the villagers brand Algenare a witch and Algenare herself finds in the night sky "in large trembling strokes, the giant letters of the witches' alphabet." For its insight into human frailty and vice, for its language forged with precision and nuance, this slim trio of tales is richly rewarding. GARDNER MCFALL

title: The Etiquette Police

PEOPLE got rich in this country in the last half of the 19th century, lots of them. And they did it fast. Working in the mills and the mines and on the railroads, penniless immigrants and dirt-poor farm boys clambered up to great wealth in one generation. Then they descended on New York and San Francisco, those newly minted millionaires, to savor the high life and ape the swells -- the Astors, the Rhinelanders and the Vanderbilts -- who had made it a generation before. They had money; what they lacked was taste.

description: Two decades ago, in a distant life, I was hired fresh out of law school to be a starting associate at a large Wall Street law firm. A year later, I left to pursue other adventures. But I retain fond memories of my brief high-paying apprenticeship in big-time corporate law. The firm was a surprisingly friendly place, and working there satisfied a wonky interest in the intricacies of the Federal tax code, and an ambition, stemming from my 60's upbringing, to be part of important social change.

title: In America;Kids for Sale
description: Sometimes you just have to swallow hard and drink another gin," said the teen-aged prostitute in Bangkok, Thailand. "I couldn't get through some nights unless I was drunk."

title: A Grittier Edge to Films at Sundance
description: Brad Pitt flew in. So did John Travolta. Burt Reynolds and Brooke Shields showed up. Even Kenneth Branagh came, with his personal trainer.

title: World News Briefs;Highest Muslim Leader Of Tajikistan Is Slain
description: The Muslim spiritual leader of Tajikistan was killed along with four other people on Sunday night, just before the planned resumption of peace talks intended to settle three years of civil war in the mountainous central Asian state. A Foreign Ministry spokeswoman said by telephone today from the capital, Dushanbe, that Mufti Fatkhulla Sharipov, 53, his wife, son and two others were killed by unknown assailants at his home to the west of the city.

title: Faulty Application of Paint Is Cited in Stairwell Fires
description: Fire and Housing Authority officials said yesterday that they had determined what went wrong in efforts to protect New York City's housing projects from a terrifying series of stairwell fires and would complete work in the most susceptible buildings this week.

title: Goldman, Sachs Partners Decide Not to Sell, After All
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, Wall Street's last big private partnership, has decided after weeks of deliberation that it will not put itself up for sale, people who attended the firm's annual partners' meeting over the weekend said yesterday.

title: Panel Wants More Nurses in Nursing Homes
description: Nursing homes should be required by Federal law to keep registered nurses on duty around the clock to lower the number of patient deaths and hospital admissions, a panel of medical experts says.

title: Bradley Unearthed
description: In a new book and several recent policy speeches, Senator Bill Bradley is speaking up on things he wants people to hear. Still, his plans for his own political future are unformed.

title: Bringing Advanced Medical Expertise to the World's Poorest Regions
description: The patient was getting the best care the local doctors could provide. But this case needed outside expertise, and a long-distance phone call was not an option.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;An Old-Style Mayor's Struggle in a City of the 60's
description: Along with drawing a sharp portrait of "The Last Boss," tonight's offering from "The American Experience" sketches the big changes in America's big cities in the years of Richard J. Daley's rule as Mayor of Chicago. Phe two-hour documentary tells how a tough, smart neighborhood pol who rose to be a player in national politics in the 1950's was confounded in the 1960's by urban transformations that were far beyond his control or comprehension.

title: Viacom Golden Parachute Has A Short Ripcord
description: Few things make Sumner M. Redstone's pulse quicken more than a hard-fought business deal. Recalling how he sold Madison Square Garden last year for $1.075 billion, Mr. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom Inc., said, "My heart was in my mouth for the last $50 million."

title: Islamic Group Vows Revenge On Americans
description: The most powerful group of Muslim militants in Egypt has vowed to strike at American "interests and people" in revenge for the life sentence for Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman.

title: Congresswoman Faces Increasing Skepticism
description: With a month to digest charges that their Congresswoman was elected with illegal campaign contributions, few people in this family-oriented state seem to accept Representative Enid Waldholtz's defense that her husband made all the money decisions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM G. KESSINGER is leaving Haverford College for the second time. Mr. Kessinger, who graduated from the liberal arts college in Haverford, Pa., in 1965, and came back as its president in 1988, announced last week that he will step down on July 1 to become president of the Aga Khan Trust for Culture.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Rich Repast Topped by Whipped Cream
description: The program that Neeme Jarvi and the Detroit Symphony Orchestra presented on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall was like a high-fat, low-fiber meal. The richest item was Richard Strauss's "Schlagobers" ("Whipped Cream") suite: 50 minutes of extravagantly orchestrated waltzes, marches, gallops and schmaltzy reveries. The music is drawn from an unsuccessful 1924 ballet, a tale of youngsters fresh from communion services at church who run afoul of a pastry shop. To his standard battery of instruments, Strauss here adds some exotic touches: sand blocks, tambourines, castanets. The music is like an overstuffed Viennese cream puff, one of those delectable desserts that you dig into greedily but can't finish. It certainly provided Mr. Jarvi with a chance to show off his orchestra's precision, power and color.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;At the Met, A Singer Everyone Is Watching
description: New singers have taken over most of the roles in the Metropolitan Opera's production of "Don Giovanni" in recent weeks, and on Thursday evening, Jane Eaglen joined the cast as Donna Anna in her delayed house debut. She was originally scheduled to sing on Jan. 10 and again in the broadcast on Jan. 13, but she had to bow out because of illness.

title: 2 Arrests in Robbery At Doctor's Office
description: A 63-year-old man whose criminal record dates back to 1946 was arrested on Saturday after entering a Manhattan doctor's office, pulling a knife and demanding money, the police said. Investigators say he may be responsible for a string of similar robberies.

title: BASKETBALL;New Nets And Beard Sitting In Limbo
description: After a day off yesterday, the Nets will return to practice today to prepare for tomorrow night's game at Toronto. The problem is that Coach Butch Beard and his staff aren't sure which players will be at their disposal when the Nets meet the Raptors at the Skydome.

title: A Puzzling Path: From P.S. 40 to a Cell in Peru
description: Before he goes to bed each night, Mark Berenson listens to a tape of his daughter Lori singing. He allows himself only one song a night from the tapes, which she used to send home from Peru, the country that has now convicted her of treason and sentenced her, at 26, to life in prison.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Let the Pre-Game Begin: Switzer and America's Team Arrive in Arizona
description: They do not need a map.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Alice Acheson, 100, Washington Painter
description: Alice Stanley Acheson, a painter and the widow of Dean Acheson, President Harry S. Truman's Secretary of State, died on Saturday at her home in Washington. She was 100.

title: Drug Approval For Medimmune
description: Medimmune Inc. received Food and Drug Administration approval Friday to sell Respigam, one of the company's most important drugs, to reduce the incidence of respiratory infections in certain high-risk infants.

title: Ex-Communist Polish Premier May Resign Over Charges of Spying forMoscow
description: A spy scandal centering on Prime Minister Joseph Oleksy's decade-long dealings with a K.G.B. agent is likely to result in his resignation this week, politicians and diplomats said today.

title: Golden Globe Award Winners
description: The Golden Globe Awards were presented last night during a ceremony in Beverly Hills, Calif., that was broadcast on NBC. The Golden Globes, given by the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, often are indicators of the Academy Awards, which are to be presented on March 25. Unlike the Oscars, the Golden Globes divide the film category into two sections, dramatic and musical or comedy, and give prizes to television shows as well.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. The reports were delayed by the partial shutdown of the Government.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Levi Strauss Japan, Tokyo, to Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, to handle television and print advertising for the Levi's brand in Japan, previously handled by McCann-Erickson Tokyo, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos. The billings were estimated at $15 million. Bartle Bogle handles Levi Strauss accounts in countries including Britain. London Underground to Young & Rubicam London, to handle advertising, previously handled by Foote, Cone & Belding London, owned by True North Communications. The billings were estimated at $1.8 million to $2.2 million.

title: Hearings Approach Harassment Of First Lady, Clinton Aide Says
description: President Clinton's chief of staff said today that a Republican Congressional inquiry into Hillary Rodham Clinton's role in the Whitewater affair was getting dangerously close to political harassment.

title: Ticketmaster Starts a Cheer-Filled Magazine
description: Live!, an unabashedly celebratory magazine about live entertainment in theaters, stadiums, concert halls, amusement parks and performing arts centers around the country, will make its debut tomorrow. It is published by Ticketmaster, the national ticket sales giant with an unabashed interest in selling as many tickets to as many events as possible.

title: World News Briefs;51 Dead, Dozens Missing As Indonesian Ferry Sinks
description: At least 51 people died in a ferry that sank off the northern tip of Sumatra late last week, and hopes faded today that rescuers could find survivors among the more than 100 passengers still missing.

title: Sidney Korshak, 88, Dies; Fabled Fixer for the Chicago Mob
description: Sidney R. Korshak, a labor lawyer who used his reputation as the Chicago mob's man in Los Angeles to become one of Hollywood's most fabled and influential fixers, died on Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills. He was 88.

title: Essay;Who's the 'Someone'?
description: The unremarked Whitewater revelation of the past week was Hillary Clinton's admission to investigators that in 1988 she had "authorized the destruction of" Rose Law Firm records about her recent representation of the Madison S.& L.

title: Sports of The Times;Slick, Slicker, Slickest: Reese, Rizzuto, Dark
description: IT was a simpler time in America, when rock 'n' roll was just a gleam in some guitarist's eye, when we thought there were only 10 billion galaxies in the universe and not, as recently discovered, 50 billion or more of them, and when there were only 16 teams in the major leagues, not the 28 (and soon to be 30) that now spill across the country.

title: A Planned Congressional Trip Was Justified
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Official Views Evidence of Mass Killing in Bosnia
description: Standing at the edge of a snow-covered field believed to be the burial place of hundreds of Muslims killed by the Bosnian Serbs, the American Assistant Secretary of State for Human Rights, John C. Shattuck, and two officials from the war crimes tribunal at The Hague said they had seen enough evidence, in the first visit by Western human rights officials to the area, to corroborate reports of widespread mass executions.

title: Treasury's Sales This Week Will Include Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of bills and notes, beginning with today's auction of new three- and six-month bills. The Treasury will auction a two-year note tomorrow and a five-year note on Wednesday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AWARDS;Five Athletes Are Honored
description: Among the five professional athletes being honored for their humanitarian work are HAKEEM OLAJUWON of the Houston Rockets, the tennis champion ANDRE AGASSI and BOOMER ESIASON of the Jets. Also winning USA Weekend magazine's Most Caring Athlete Awards are JIM EISENREICH of the Philadelphia Phillies and golfer BETSY KING. (AP)

title: A Promising Palestinian Election
description: Saturday's elections for a Palestinian president and a legislative council marked another milestone toward peaceful coexistence between self-governing Israeli and Palestinian communities. The voting extended the evolution of the Palestine Liberation Organization from a guerrilla movement to an elected party of government and conferred a mandate of democratic legitimacy on the P.L.O.'s longtime leader, Yasir Arafat.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Spared Worst of Floods
description: Swollen rivers and streams across the mid-Atlantic states receded yesterday as tens of thousands of evacuated residents returned to flood-ravaged homes and businesses. While New Jersey escaped the worst of the damage, the Delaware River did make its way into hundreds of homes and into a newly renovated State House Annex in Trenton. There was also flooding along the Millstone and Raritan Rivers. [Pages A1 and B5.]

title: Many Schools Scramble to Make Up Time Lost to Snow
description: The flakes are melting, but the flak is just starting for school officials scrambling to schedule the most snow makeup days in a generation.

description: The war on illicit drugs has yet to gain prominence in this campaign year, although public concern about drug abuse is unabated.

title: U.S. Acted Properly In South Korea Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Turks and Plain English
description: Stars like Tony Bennett, Rod Stewart and Eric Clapton found new fame with "Unplugged" albums, which feature tracks uncluttered by electronic enhancements. Politicians can learn from this. Last week, a group of freshmen Republican senators led by Spence Abraham of Michigan set off from Washington on a national bus tour to take a plain-talk conservative message to the people. Call it Conservative Young Turks, Unplugged.

title: George Oliver, 76, Actor and Teacher
description: George B. Oliver, professor emeritus of dramatic literature at Nassau Community College and a former actor on Broadway, died on Jan. 14 at North Penn Hospital in Lansdale, Pa. He was 76 and lived in Willow Grove, Pa.

title: High-Level Graft Case Rocks India's Political Establishment
description: Introducing new uncertainties into Indian politics only three months before a general election, prosecutors have taken the lid off a multimillion-dollar payoff scandal that has embroiled dozens of high-ranking politicians and civil servants, including prominent figures in all three major political parties.

title: FIGURE SKATING;National Championships: A Soap Opera in Sequins
description: As usual, figure skating's national championships provided a week of the inspiring, the riveting, the poignant, the outrageous, the revealing, the concealing, the soaring and the plunging. And that was just the costumes.

description: By this afternoon, Jerome and Greg Carr were back at home, watching firefighters pump water from their basement and trying to start two waterlogged cars parked in the yard.

description: The debate about how to balance the budget is distorted by a singular phenomenon. Both sides, President and Congressional Republicans, treat as untouchable one of the biggest spending areas: defense.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Statue for a Modest Genius
description: The borough council has allowed itself to be persuaded that a statue would be a fitting tribute to Albert Einstein, among the town's most famous residents. (At first, some people thought that the gesture would have offended Einstein, a determinedly modest man.)

title: Giuliani Faces Another Deficit Despite Cutting
description: For the last two years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has wrestled down huge gaps in New York City's budgets, slashing spending, cutting municipal jobs and trimming welfare rolls. And yet, as he begins his third year in office, the Mayor faces another gaping hole in his spending plan and a new round of cuts that could further erode the city's services.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jobless Rate Jumps to 7.3%
description: When it comes to jobs, the news in New Jersey recently has not been good. On Friday, the Federal Government announced that the state's unemployment rate jumped to 7.3 percent in December from 6.1 percent in November; that translates into 295,000 people without jobs.

description: The University of California voted on Friday to halt the pay of two of three doctors at the University of California at Irvine who were accused of implanting patients with eggs or embryos without their consent.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: A House Republican Leader Raises the Ante on Budget The House majority leader, Representative Dick Armey, said Congress would refuse to extend the nation's ability to borrow money to meet its bills unless President Clinton yielded to the Republican budget-cutting initiatives and determination to decrease "the size and intrusiveness of government."

title: Investors Buy Ads Against RJR Nabisco
description: In full-page newspaper advertisements headlined "RJR to Shareholders: Drop Dead!" the investors Bennett S. LeBow and Carl C. Icahn, who are seeking a rapid spinoff of RJR Nabisco's food business from its tobacco operations, have started the public phase of their battle to win the hearts and minds of shareholders.

title: Card for Subways and Sundries
description: Want a newspaper? A sandwich? An umbrella? In a few years, if the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has its way, commuters may be buying them with the same cards they swipe through the subway turnstiles to pay their fares.

description: A police officer searching for sus pects in an armed robbery fatally shot an unarmed, 25-year-old man at the Polo Grounds Houses in Wash ington Heights on Saturday night, said Chief Joseph R. Leake, the com manding officer of the police depart ment's housing bureau.

description: At least 33 Islamic militants were killed in weekend clashes with Algerian security forces, including 8 in an incident in which 2 men were holding a 6-year-old child hostage. The child was released unharmed moments before the confrontation.

description: Stocks traded lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 169.23 points, or 0.83 percent, at 20,196.53. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 4.28 points.

title: A Young Victim of AIDS Gets a Proper Goodbye
description: Her mother died of AIDS, and so did her father, but it was not clear that Kai Evans was infected with the virus until she was 7 and caught chicken pox.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Freshman's Presence Helps Huskies Send a Message
description: Ricky Moore did not grow up today. It just looked that way as Connecticut's freshman point guard rapidly develops into another bit of bad news for the rest of the Big East. Growth is gradual and sometimes undetectable. But Moore's emergence this afternoon, into the gut of a tough, resourceful Syracuse team that reminded the Hartford Civic Center sellout of the way the Big East used to feel, became memorable for his eye-catching skills.

title: Ranchers Hurt By Steep Drop In Beef Prices
description: In the 1980's, falling beef prices led to the failure of thousands of ranches, with more than 80,000 ranches disappearing from 1986 through 1990.

description: Ferrero International B. The billings were estimated at $60 million.

title: Palestinian Vote: Dawn for Most, Legitimacy for Arafat
description: The start of Ramadan, the Muslim month of repentance, brought a somber curtain down today on celebrations of the Palestinian election, but not before the Palestinian radio blared out a final round of jubilant proclamations that "a new day has dawned over Palestine."

title: World News Briefs;Austria Demands Details On Cold War Arsenals
description: Austria's leadership demanded today that the United States supply details of 79 secret American arsenals that remain scattered across Austria more than 40 years after they were hidden in case of a Soviet invasion.

title: POP REVIEW;Craziness as a Cause Worth the Trouble
description: In "Paranoid," his first song at the Continental Airlines Arena on Thursday night, Ozzy Osbourne urged the audience to go crazy. He dipped his head in a bucket of water and flung the water on the crowd; he sprayed onlookers with a water hose made to look like a gun. He cued fans to shout along, and as the song ended he tore his T-shirt nearly in half.

description: Answering the objections of Indian nationalists, the Enron Corporation said today that it had agreed to cut sharply the cost of the electricity that a huge project in India will provide.

title: Intensity' Plan Shows Publishing's Big Profit Hunt
description: Five years ago, a new novel by Dean Koontz would have been heavily marketed, zoomed onto best-seller lists and stayed there long enough to sell 400,000 hard-cover copies to loyal legions of horror-thriller fans. Who could want more? Very few hard-cover books begin life expecting to pull in those kinds of numbers.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Feel A Bit Healthier
description: When the Rangers practiced for the first time in a week yesterday, they got encouraging news. Goalie Mike Richter and defensemen Mattias Norstrom, out since Dec. 30, and Doug Lidster, out since Jan. 5, all skated for the first time since being injured.

description: It has been 12 years since the weekly listings of television's 10 most popular programs did not include a comedy from Carsey-Werner Productions -- and that string of success now looks secure at least through the end of the century.

description: LORNE MUNROE, the principal cellist of the New York Philharmonic, is moving on, too, but in his case it is to retirement. His last concert will be on Feb. 27.

description: Please, give me some room," Don Nelson said, a hint of irritation in his voice. It was late Saturday night here, and he was standing in a narrow arena hallway, his appearance more than slightly disheveled. He was moving those annoyingly close microphones away from his barrel chest for the second time in a week.

description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER REVIEW;Shakespearean Vienna With Modern Tensions
description: It's too bad, really, that Sigmund Freud won't be showing up in Vienna for another few centuries. Because there's one eminent 17th-century citizen of that city, as portrayed in the unmoored production of "Measure for Measure" that opened last night, who could definitely use his attention.

title: THEATER REVIEW;The Menace Simmering Beneath Family Chatter
description: In the Sanctuary Theater Workshop's production of Paul Alexander's "Strangers in the Land of Canaan," Rip Torn, as director, gives a fine lesson in how to hold an audience's interest through about three-quarters of a play that starts at the level of old-fashioned Hollywood comedy and declines into a muddle of pop psychology.

title: Firebrand Who Got Singed Says Being Speaker Suffices
description: One day in November, facing criticism for whining too much about his Air Force One trip while budget talks were going nowhere, Newt Gingrich confessed to five or six close allies, "I feel like a good Triple-A player who can't hit major league pitching."

description: A 16-year-old boy was killed last night when he slipped in front of a city bus and was struck in East New York, Brooklyn, the police said.

description: AFTER being urged incessantly to look for "Intel inside," consumers are being offered a chance to look inside Intel.

title: National Book Critics Circle Announces Award Nominees
description: Moo," Jane Smiley's novel about intrigue at a Midwestern state university, and "The Liars' Club," Mary Karr's memoir about growing up with alcoholic parents in Texas, are among the 25 books nominated by the National Book Critics Circle for its 1995 awards.

title: God's Will and Public Will On Agenda for 5 Candidates
description: At a meeting here mixing discussion of national policy issues with thoughts about God's will for America, five Republican Presidential candidates took turns appealing to a gathering of Christian conservatives, who reserved their loudest cheers for attacks on legalized abortion and the authority of the United Nations.

title: Rhode Island Oil Spill Is More Serious Than Initially Thought
description: Salvage workers yesterday began pumping heating oil from a leaking barge that ran aground near a Rhode Island beach on Friday, trying to contain what has been called the state's worst oil spill.

title: Times Delivery in Florida
description: Lauderdale, Fla., to distribute The Times in Broward and Palm Beach Counties in Florida. The Sun-Sentinel, which is owned by the Tribune Company, will begin single-copy sales today and home delivery in March. William L. Pollak, executive vice president for circulation at The Times, said the newspaper was in discussions with other newspaper companies around the country to establish similar delivery arrangements.

description: Pat Hannon, who lives in a suburb of St. Louis, worries that her golden retrievers, Chelsea and Callista, might be stolen. Where she lives, Mrs. Hannon said, dog theft is a big problem. "They are pure breeds and very friendly," she said.

description: Texas-El Paso Coach DON HASKINS remained in the hospital yesterday after having a mild heart attack during a game Saturday night in El Paso. "He's resting comfortably and says he feels great," said the school's sports information director, EDDIE MULLENS.

description: After a chase through five towns that injured five police officers, a kidnapping suspect was behind bars yesterday in the Passaic County Jail.

description: By most accounts, the United States Congress in its first year of Republican rule has been an irascible, bellicose, name-calling, foot-dragging, tie-pulling place defined by an utter absence of bipartisan instinct.

title: Investor Group Seeks Spinoff by Woolworth
description: In what may be the first rumblings of shareholder impatience with the troubled Woolworth Corporation, one investor group has requested that the retailer spin off its footwear and apparel divisions.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IP TIMBERLANDS TO SELL MOST OF A UNIT FOR $550 MILLION
description: IP Timberlands Ltd. said yesterday that it plans to sell more than 80 percent of its IP Pacific Forests L.P. unit in an initial public offering for about $550 million, as part of an $800 million capital-raising effort. IP Pacific Forests plans to sell limited partnership units in the public offering and $350 million in senior debt securities to repay existing debt. IP Timberlands, based in Purchase, N.Y., also said it would make an extraordinary distribution of approximately $5 to $7 per class A unit. But the company said it might have to reduce the regular quarterly distribution of 72 cents. The International Paper Company owns 84 percent of the class A units, and all of class B. IP Timberland class A units fell $1.875 to close at $22.75. The company owns about 300,000 acres of forest in Oregon and Washington.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES
description: World Wide Web, offering its service without charge to readers in the United States. The electronic newspaper includes articles and classified advertising from each days current issue and a new section CyberTimes, with Times articles supplemented by original reporting on the world of new media.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROADMASTER TO CLOSE PLANT AND CUT 600 JOBS
description: Roadmaster Industries, which makes bicycles, wagons, scooters and fitness equipment, said yesterday that it would cut about 600 jobs and close one plant as it warned of losses for the fourth quarter of 1995 and the full year. The Atlanta-based company also agreed to sell its Nelson/Weather-Rite camping division to the Brunswick Corporation for $120 million in cash. The company said it planned to close its fitness manufacturing operation in Tyler, Tex., and consolidate its fitness production at the Opelika, Ala., plant. The company also said it would reduce its lamp, distribution and other operations. The restructuring will result in a one-time charge to 1995 net income, it said.

title: Complex and Hidden Brain in Gut Makes Stomachaches and Butterflies
description: EVER wonder why people get "butterflies" in the stomach before going on stage? Or why an impending job interview can cause an attack of intestinal cramps? And why antidepressants targeted for the brain cause nausea or abdominal upset in millions of people who take such drugs?

title: Hillary Clinton Is Subpoenaed To Testify Before a Grand Jury
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has been subpoenaed to appear before a Federal grand jury that is investigating whether anyone at the White House obstructed justice in the handling of records from the First Lady's former law firm.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AMERICAN EXPRESS CO. (AXP,N)
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 14.6 percent in the fourth quarter, bolstered by rising consumer spending and gains in its travel business.

title: Dance in Review
description: The Stages of Love In Movement Alone Colin Connor Ohio Theater

title: ON HOCKEY;Gretzky and Messier: A Tale With Two Endings
description: To watch Mark Messier and Wayne Gretzky play against each other last night was to observe two athletic legends during differing and diminishing periods of their extraordinary careers.

title: In Japan, Even Toddlers Feel the Pressure to Excel
description: Shotaro Kamegai is naturally busy on weekday mornings, but life in the afternoons has grown unusually hectic as well.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Bahrain Detains Key Opposition Leaders
description: Bahrain said today that it had arrested eight Shiite Muslim opposition leaders, including Sheik Abdul-Amir al-Jamri, accused of inciting anti-Government protests, the state-owned Bahrain television said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a newspaper advertisement headlined "RJR to Shareholders: Drop Dead!" misstated the ad's circulation. It ran in The New York Times, and was submitted to The Wall Street Journal for yesterday's issue, but did not appear.

title: Serb Pledges Cooperation
description: Pressed by an American official's tour of suspected mass grave sites, President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia proclaimed his support today for human-rights investigations in Bosnia.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Stake in Remy Unit
description: The Highland Distilleries Company said yesterday that it had bought a 26 percent stake in the malt whisky distiller Macallan-Glenlivet P.L.C. for L46.6 million, or $71 million, in cash from Remy Cointreau of France. "The sale represents a significant part of the debt reduction program announced by Remy Cointreau" last week, Remy said in a statement. Highland, which supplies the Famous Grouse Scotch whisky and has distributed the Macallan single malt through a subsidiary since 1994, said the purchase would help diversify its earnings. Reuters

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Speeding Child-Abuse Data
description: Two lawmakers have introduced bills to lift "the cloak of confidentiality" they say is thrown over child-abuse cases by the Division of Family and Youth Services. The bills, sponsored by Senator James E. McGreevey and Assemblyman William D. Pascrell, would change laws that have made it difficult for information about abuse cases to be exchanged among child-welfare officials, the police, schools and other agencies. Their measures are modeled on bills before the New York Legislature inspired by the case of Elisa Izquierdo, a 6-year-old who the authorities say was tortured to death by her mother.

title: SCIENTIST AT WORK: Vilayanur Ramachandran;Figuring Out the Brain From Its Acts of Denial
description: WHAT kind of equipment do you need to probe the mysteries of the human brain?

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Dungy Named Coach For Bucs
description: After having been labeled a head-coaching candidate for several years, Tony Dungy today became the sixth coach in the Tampa Bay Buccaneers' 20-year history.

title: 2 Fund Groups Said to Be Seeking Buyers
description: Michael F. Price, the money manager, is seeking to sell his $13 billion Mutual Series family of mutual funds, an investment banker whose client may want to buy the fund group said yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;D.M.B.& B. Gains LG Group Account
description: The LG Group in Seoul, South Korea, which was formerly known as Lucky Goldstar, said yesterday that, as expected, it had named D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York as the first agency to handle its worldwide corporate advertising account. The billings were estimated at $40 million.

title: On My Mind;As Night the Day
description: Stalin and Mao did not kill millions of their fellow citizens by famine. Middle East dictatorships have not shot thousands of their own people. South African apartheid did not purposefully condemn most of the black majority to poverty, police terrorism and menial labor. The Holocaust never happened.

title: Evangelicals Ask Government to Fight Persecution of Christians
description: A group of Christian leaders, with the nation's largest evangelical organization in the forefront, is opening a campaign to place the fight against the persecution of Christians in many countries on the Federal Government's agenda and to mobilize church members behind it.

title: Looking for Exotic Worlds? Nearby Sea Floor Rivals Planets
description: THE murky depths of the sea just off the coasts of the continental United States harbor a surprising variety of worlds as exotic as those found in space, scientists from Columbia University report.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 115.61 points, or nearly six-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,080.92. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 169.23 points.

title: Nassau to Limit Smoking on July 1
description: The Nassau County Health Department today approved new smoking regulations that are similar in most respects to those adopted in recent years by Suffolk County and New York City.

title: New Jersey Man Is Slain by Police Officer at Pool Hall
description: A police officer searching for suspects in an armed robbery fatally shot an unarmed, 25-year-old man at the Polo Grounds Houses in Washington Heights on Saturday night, said Chief Joseph R. Leake, the commanding officer of the police department's housing bureau.

title: BASKETBALL;Williams Gets Blunt About the Nets
description: Jayson Williams was home in bed Sunday night battling the flu, but the Nets' 6-foot-10-inch center started feeling better when he got around to talking about the departure of Derrick Coleman and Kenny Anderson, and the impending arrival of Kendall Gill and Khalid Reeves.

title: Intel Facing Suits Over Testing Error
description: Four lawsuits have been filed against the Intel Corporation since the company's acknowledgment that it had overstated the performance of some of its Pentium computer chips because of a software error.

title: BASKETBALL;Nets Give Trade Stamp of Approval
description: Kenny Anderson will not be coming back to New Jersey. The Nets officially agreed to their four-player trade with the Hornets today after a medical test on Khalid Reeves's sprained left ankle showed that the injury was not severe enough to cancel the deal.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CHECKERS DRIVE-IN RESTAURANTS INC., Clearwater, Fla., a hamburger chain, is considering at least two proposals to sell control of the company. It is seeking an offer of at least $150 million, or $2.96 a share.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Twenty years ago, Representative PATRICIA SCHROEDER, Democrat of Colorado, was unceremoniously ejected when she attempted to attend the awards dinner of the then all-male Touchdown Club in Washington.

title: In Japan, to Be Profound Takes Fewer Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennsylvania Flood Losses Could Reach $700 Million
description: As the flood waters of Pennsylvania's big rivers receded today from their overflow levels of the weekend, thousands of residents returned to their homes only to find them uninhabitable, and the state said the economic losses could reach $700 million.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BORDEN TO SELL WORLDWIDE PLASTIC PACKAGING UNIT
description: Borden Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its worldwide plastic packaging unit to focus on its main businesses. Borden, based in Columbus, Ohio, makes dairy items, pasta, snacks and other food products. It said the packaging unit had annual sales of $625 million. The unit has 27 plants in 12 countries with 3,500 employees. Borden, which is owned by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, has hired Morgan Stanley to help with the sale. Borden will use proceeds from the sale primarily for investment in other business areas, C. Robert Kidder, the company's chief executive, said. Borden employs about 30,000 people at nearly 200 plants.

title: Executive Changes
description: AVIALL INC., Dallas, announced the resignation of John H. Nicholson, senior vice president of Aviall Engine Services, and named R. Frank Leftwich, president of Aviall Asia Ltd., to the added post of executive vice president of sales and marketing of Aviall Engine Services.

title: An Insurer's Dream, With No Middleman;ITT Hartford Thrives on Retiree Group
description: In the troubled world of insurance, the news lately has been of mergers and layoffs, record claims and stagnant returns. It is about the last industry where you would expect a company to build a new business of more than $1 billion in revenues in little more than a decade..

title: COMPANY REPORTS;USAir Posts Annual Profit After Seven Years of Losses
description: USAir Group Inc. said today that it posted a profit in the fourth quarter on higher revenue and continued cost-cutting and also announced its first annual profit since 1988.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GOODYEAR EXPECTS TO REPORT HIGHER EARNINGS AND SALES
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it expected fourth-quarter earnings to rise about 8 percent on higher sales. Goodyear's stock was up $2.625 at $46.125. The company said it expected profits of $143 million to $148 million, or 94 cents to 97 cents a share. A year ago the company earned $136.5 million, or 90 cents a share. Goodyear said it also expected to report record sales for the quarter, exceeding the $3.2 billion posted a year earlier. Goodyear said the results would be released on Feb. 5.

title: BASKETBALL;Seton Hall Moved by St. John's Message
description: The boastful words were plastered in front of every Seton Hall locker before tonight's game. Zendon Hamilton had predicted that St. John's would handle the Pirates, so Seton Hall became perturbed and then reacted. Next time, Hamilton will probably keep quiet.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Suspect Held in Killing In '74 of Chilean General
description: More than 21 years after a car bomb killed a former Chilean army commander and his wife outside the Buenos Aires home where they lived in exile, the authorities have arrested a suspect.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;Valenzuela Barred From Riding
description: Jockey PAT VALENZUELA, best known for riding Sunday Silence, is barred from Florida's Gulfstream Park until he takes another drug test and explains what it was he submitted in place of a urine sample. But when that will be was unknown yesterday, because track officials say they have been trying for three days to contact Valenzuela. He hasn't been officially suspended. (AP)

title: Neutrino Bomb' Idea Expands Debate on Human Extinction
description: ALTHOUGH paleontologists agree that the history of life on earth has been punctuated by five great extinction events, the causes of these catastrophes, including the one that killed off the dinosaurs, are subjects of endless controversy. A new hypothesis based on cosmic "neutrino bombs" promises to complicate the debate still more.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Cowboys Looking As Loose As Ever
description: When the Cowboys' owner, Jerry Jones, met with the news media today, he sounded as if he were arguing for a new energy bill on C-Span. He went on and on for more than an hour. Coach Barry Switzer was patiently waiting to speak next. Didn't matter.

title: By Design;70's Ponytail With a 90's Twist
description: All of those 1970's-inspired clothes that designers showed for spring brought back the long and straight center-parted hair style favored in the 70's. And whenever long straight hair is in fashion, along comes the ponytail.

title: Chase-Chemical Deal Challenged in Court
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation's $10 billion purchase of the Chase Manhattan Corporation has been challenged in two courts by a local community group that has forced concessions from several big banks pursuing mergers.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Low-Cost Houses Planned
description: With $10 million in support from state and Federal agencies, a community development group plans to build more than 100 houses and renovate 175 others in the neighborhood near the Camden waterfront once home to the poet Walt Whitman. Roy Jones, director of the project for the Lanning Square West Neighborhood Corporation, said the homes would be sold at half their market value, with preference for 5 percent mortgages given to people who work for the city. The payment would be $225 a month on a $35,000 mortgage for a three-bedroom home worth $70,000, he said.

title: An Irate G.O.P. Set to Take On State of Clinton
description: For the State of the Union Message, all eyes are usually on the President. But with tensions running so high in Washington these days because of the budget standoff and Presidential politics, the Republicans are drawing plenty of attention to themselves.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Iraq to Sell Stock
description: Hurt financially by United Nations trade sanctions, the Iraqi Government plans to raise money by selling stock in some state-owned businesses, the country's Finance Minister said on Sunday. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Hikmat Mizban Ibrahim as saying the Government will use the money to invest in "productive projects." Mr. Ibrahim said the privatization move was part of Baghdad's recent "reform program," which includes scrapping unprofitable state enterprises and cutting Government spending.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GAMING COMPANIES ADJUST TERMS OF MERGER AGREEMENT
description: The Alliance Gaming Corporation and Bally Gaming International Inc. amended the terms of their merger agreement yesterday to assure that the combined company has enough cash to fuel growth. Under the amended agreement, Bally shareholders will receive a combination of cash and Alliance preferred and common stock totaling $11.70 per Bally share, the two Las Vegas-based companies said. The original agreement valued Bally Gaming at about $13 a share. Bally Gaming, the world's largest maker of casino gambling equipment, agreed to a takeover by Alliance in October after fighting the bid for months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Visiting Nurse Service of New York to Ted Chin & Co., New York, as the first agency of record. The billings were estimated at $1 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State No Longer the Goat
description: The goat is history. To the great relief of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and other state officials, the Virgin Islands Tourism Department is dropping a commercial in which an islander fretted to his goat that he did not know where to vacation because home was so magnificent. The goat says, "Blah." The islander says, "New Jersey? Nah." State Senator Joe Kyrillos said yesterday that there was an open invitation for the Governor of the Virgin Islands to visit New Jersey, and bring the goat along. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Corrections Officers Complete Sweep of Hudson County Jail
description: The 160 state corrections officers who temporarily took over the Hudson County jail in Kearny last week left the site yesterday, except for a small management team that remained to help administer the jail for the county. State officials said they had successfully swept the building for contraband ranging from drugs to homemade weapons.

title: Where Is the Expansion in Veterans' Hospital System?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Luxottica Expands Link to Deutsch
description: The Luxottica Group, the United States unit of Luxottica S.p.A. in Milan, Italy, said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Deutsch Inc. in New York by naming that agency to introduce its Luxottica brand of eyewear in the United States. The billings were estimated at $25 million.

title: Setback for U.S. Regulators in Texas Case
description: In a setback for Federal regulators, a judge ruled today that a Texas company was not in contempt of a 1995 court order concerning its sale of a life insurance policy's death benefits to investors.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swiss Franc Hurts Nestle
description: Nestle S.A. announced yesterday that its sales fell slightly to 56.4 billion Swiss francs, or $47.4 billion, last year because of the strength of the Swiss currency. Describing its 1995 performance as satisfactory, the Swiss-based multinational predicted higher sales and profits for 1996. Analysts said the results were in line with expectations. The Swiss franc soared against most big currencies last year, hurting Swiss exporters. (AP)

title: Chechen Insurgent, Still Defiant, Pledges to Carry On the Struggle
description: Russia's humiliation at the hands of Chechen guerrillas deepened further today, when the leader of the hostage raid of the last 10 days emerged from seclusion to ridicule his enemies and promise that the fight would continue.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;$28,325 a Year at Princeton
description: Studying, sleeping and eating will all cost more at Princeton University next year. The school announced yesterday that undergraduate tuition for the 1996-97 school year would be $22,000, room charges $2,900 and board charges $3,425. That is $28,325, up 4.6 percent from this year. The university said the rate of increase was the lowest since 1967-68. The new rates were approved by the trustees Saturday as part of a $525.4 million operating budget.

title: Ex-Aide Accuses Colombia Leader in Scandal
description: A former Defense Minister and campaign manager for President Ernesto Samper said in a televised interview tonight that Mr. Samper knew that Colombian drug traffickers were contributing money to his 1994 presidential campaign.

title: CHRONICLE
description: WYNONNA JUDD, the country singer, and ARCH KELLEY 3D, a yacht salesman, attracted more attention than they wanted but still managed to keep their wedding on Sunday a very private affair, The Associated Press reported.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: A Rally for America Online On Possible Netscape Deal
description: Shares of America Online Inc. surged 12 percent yesterday following reports that the company might form an alliance with Netscape, the leading maker of software for browsing the Internet's World Wide Web. Shares of the Netscape Communications Corporation rose 11 percent.

title: Observer;Steve, Bob, Bill, Etc.
description: Suddenly he is Steve. Never heard of the guy until the other day, and already I'm calling him Steve. Rich is what Steve is. Rich, rich, rich.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Haskins to Undergo Double Bypass
description: Texas-El Paso Coach DON HASKINS, who has been hospitalized since suffering a heart attack during a game against New Mexico last weekend, was to hav' double-bypass surgery today and may miss the rest of the basketball season. (AP)

title: After Helping Wife Die, Man Considers Plea Deal
description: There are days, George Delury says, when he wonders about his motives when he gave his ailing, deteriorating wife a mixture of antidepressants and water and watched her drink it until she died.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fewer Delays at Airport
description: Newark International Airport is No. 7 and it's glad. For several years, the Federal Aviation Administration rated Newark the nation's worst airport for delays. In the latest rankings, Newark dropped to seventh on the list, which includes the country's 55 busiest airports. Elsewhere in the metropolitan region, La Guardia was No. 8 and Kennedy No. 11. Chicago's O'Hare International was No. 1.

title: Seton Lloyd, 93, Rediscoverer of a Lost Empire
description: Seton Lloyd, a British archeologist who put his architectural training to use when he led spectacular digs in Iraq and Turkey, died on Jan. 7, London newspapers reported. He was 93 and lived in Faringdon, England.

title: Clinton to Ban Contracts to Companies That Hire Illegal Aliens
description: President Clinton is expected to issue an order barring Federal contracts with companies that illegally hire undocumented foreign workers, Administration officials said today.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Take a Letter, Ms. or Mr. Computer
description: COMPUTER understanding of human speech always seems to be just around the corner. Until recently, only a fool or an optimist would try to dictate an entire column to a little computer, and I am not an optimist. But I wrote that last sentence, and some of the ones that follow, on the smallest of I.B.M. Thinkpad subnotebooks with the help of an International Business Machines system called Voicetype Dictation. It costs about $1,000 to $1,100, depending on configuration.

title: Polish Secret Police Still Making Trouble, Dissidents Say
description: Two of Poland's most prominent dissidents, who were jailed many times by the Communist secret police, wrote in an open letter published today that the nation's intelligence services are just as powerful now as they were in the Communist era.

title: Don't Depict Islam, the Religion, as a Menace;West's Biggest Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: A Michelangelo on 5th Ave.? It Seems So
description: One of the more stately houses on Fifth Avenue is No. 972, between 78th and 79th Streets. Designed by Stanford White for the family of Payne Whitney and built between 1902 and 1906, it was bought by the French Government in the 1950's and today houses the cultural services of the French Embassy.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAMPBELL SOUP TO SELL MRS. PAUL'S SEAFOOD UNIT
description: The Campbell Soup Company, the nation's largest soup maker, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Mrs. Paul's frozen seafood business to VDK Holdings, which also owns Van de Kamp's frozen seafood. Campbell said it wanted to focus on its core frozen food operations, including Swanson, Pepperidge Farm and Campbell's Foodservice. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. But analysts said Campbell had probably received $60 million to $80 million for the unit. The sale includes the Mrs. Paul's trademark, production equipment and inventories but will not include any of Campbell's manufacturing plants.

title: O.J. Simpson, Under Oath
description: For the first time, O. J. Simpson has spoken under oath about the deaths of Nicole Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman. Though the proceedings will not begin until April, Mr. Simpson began giving his deposition yesterday in the wrongful-death lawsuit brought by the victims' families.

title: 49ers Hire Cavanaugh
description: Matt Cavanaugh, who played for the 49ers from 1983 to 1985 as a backup to Joe Montana, was named San Francisco's quarterbacks coach today.

title: Japan Pledges to Open Economy, But Lack of Detail Raises Doubts
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto today pledged far-reaching changes in Japan's economic structure and promised a "thoroughgoing deregulation" of the thicket of restrictions that curb just about every aspect of commercial life.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AMATEUR ATHLETICS;Johnson Wins Owens Award
description: MICHAEL JOHNSON, the world 200-meter and 400-meter champion last year, has been voted winner of the 1996 Jesse Owens international trophy award.

title: Don't Depict Islam, the Religion, as a Menace;Warships in the Gulf
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;HARLEY-DAVIDSON TO SELL RECREATIONAL VEHICLE UNIT
description: Harley-Davidson Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Holiday Rambler recreational vehicle business for about $50 million so it could focus on meeting the booming demand for its motorcycles. Harley, the Milwaukee-based company that is the only domestic motorcycle producer, also said it was exploring the sale of its commercial truck and molded plastics businesses. Harley-Davidson agreed to sell its Holiday Rambler division to the Monaco Coach Corporation of Junction City, Ore., a maker of leisure vehicles, for $50 million in cash, preferred stock and notes. Harley's stock was up $3.375, or 13 percent, to $30.25, as 3.2 million shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Deals by Bancorp Hawaii
description: Bancorp Hawaii Inc. said today that it would acquire a majority stake in Banque de Tahiti in French Polynesia and Banque de Nouvelle Caledonie-Credit Lyonnais in New Caledonia, a Coral Sea island. Bancorp Hawaii said the total purchase price was about $53 million.

title: Flat Tax Lite
description: The flat tax has emerged as the central issue in the Republican Presidential primaries. The debate now pits an ideal, pure flat tax proposed by Steve Forbes against modified plans proposed by Phil Gramm and Patrick J. Buchanan that retain popular deductions like home mortgage interest and charitable contributions.

title: Maybelline Board Backs Sweetened Offer From L'Oreal
description: In the bidding war for Maybelline Inc., the Memphis-based cosmetics company, L'Oreal S.A. has increased its bid to $44 a share and Maybelline's directors have recommended that shareholders approve the offer, Maybelline said yesterday. But, it is not certain that L'Oreal's sweetened bid will be the last volley.

title: Don't Depict Islam, the Religion, as a Menace;Separate the Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Snow Flecks

title: G.M. to Cut Number of Dealers by Up to 30%
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that as part of a plan to strengthen the identity of its brands, it would cut the number of G.M. dealerships by 20 to 30 percent over the next dozen years.

title: Flood Waters Receding As Damage Is Assessed
description: Flood waters rolled back yesterday across hundreds of square miles in New York State and the Middle Atlantic States, leaving thick layers of mud, terrible human suffering and financial losses that are sure to be staggering.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Drilling in Venezuela
description: Venezuela awarded drilling rights yesterday to a consortium led by the Mobil Corporation on the first exploration tract the country has made available to foreign oil companies since the industry was nationalized in the mid-70's. "We are disposed to invest an additional $1 billion in Venezuela if the conditions improve," said Ron Wilson, president of Mobil Latin American Business Ventures. Among these improved conditions were the lifting of foreign exchange controls, he said. Reuters

title: 3 Are Said to Plead Guilty In Rikers Brutality Inquiry
description: When correction officers wanted to move Anthony Bryant, a prisoner on Rikers Island, to another area of the James A. Thomas Center jail in May 1990, he adamantly refused, saying he feared jail-house enemies there would kill him. But, a lawyer for Mr. Bryant's family said, his fellow inmates never had that chance, because the officers got to Mr. Bryant first.

title: In Deal, Chevron Passes Some Operations to NGC
description: The Chevron Corporation, a major force in the production of natural gas, agreed to turn over its gathering, processing and marketing operations to the NGC Corporation, a fast-growing company that has been a leader in marketing since the gas industry was deregulated in late 1980's.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Woodson Grows Fond of the Team He Loved to Hate
description: By his own admission, Darren Woodson did not grow up a Dallas Cowboys fan.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Forte in Deal to Sell 67 White Hart Hotels
description: Forte P.L.C., the beleaguered British hotel and restaurant company, agreed yesterday to sell 67 of its 72 White Hart hotel properties to the Regal Hotels Group for L122 million, or about $184 million. Among other conditions, the sale is subject to the failure of the Granada Group's bid to take over Forte. Forte has been attempting to block Granada's bid of L3.8 billion by selling hotel assets.

title: More Budget Woes for the City
description: As if on schedule, the winter season has brought a torrent of painful developments that will make it harder for New York City to balance its budget. Real estate tax revenues are down. Savings that the city had projected in welfare, Medicaid and other areas have fallen short of targets. Relations with all the municipal labor unions have been in turmoil since the teachers rejected their contract last fall. Faced with a gap that could widen to $2 billion for the next fiscal year, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani needs to rethink some of his basic assumptions about how to restore the city to solvency.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Steelers Say They Did Not Come to Lose
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers, undaunted by the rain, the oddsmakers, the burden of defending the American Conference, and especially the prospect of facing the archrival Cowboys, arrived tonight for Sunday's meeting in Super Bowl XXX.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mexico Trade Surplus
description: Mexico racked up a $7.4 billion trade surplus in 1995 compared with a deficit of more than twice that size in 1994, the Finance Ministry said yesterday. It was the country's first trade surplus since 1989. Fueled by a sharp decline in the peso that made Mexican goods cheaper abroad, exports surged 31.2 percent to $78.89 billion. Imports, meanwhile, dropped 8.6 percent, to $72.49 billion, as a deep recession dampened demand for foreign goods. The country accumulated an $18.46 billion trade shortfall in 1994. Reuters

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rise in British G.D.P.
description: The growth of the British economy was the weakest in the fourth quarter of 1995 that it has been in three years, suggesting that a buildup in manufacturing inventories undermined the recovery. The Central Statistical Office said yesterday that the first estimate of economic growth for the fourth quarter showed gross domestic product was four-tenths of 1 percent higher than in the previous three months. That was in line with expectations. Compared with the corresponding 1994 quarter, the economy expanded by 1.8 percent in the 1995 period. Bloomberg Business News

title: A Flood-Torn Village Finds It Has Friends From the City
description: On one side of the mud-caked street, firefighters from the Bronx unloaded pumps and coils of garden hose. On the other, a dozen firefighters from the Westchester village of Buchanan manned heavy hoses sucking water from the flooded basement of a drugstore.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Possibilities From Garage-Sale Junk
description: Ken Butler fulfills the fantasies of any kid who pretended to play guitar on random objects lying around the house. He has sculptured not only guitars but also violins and cellos from a baroque assortment of garage-sale items: shovels, tennis rackets, hockey sticks, axes, even a large carving knife. These impromptu instruments are amazing sights in themselves, and they have been exhibited as such in art galleries.

title: Morgan Stanley to Disclose Bridge Loan Fund Today
description: Jumping on the one-stop shopping bandwagon that has swept the securities industry, Morgan Stanley & Company today plans to announce a $600 million bridge loan fund, Morgan Stanley Bridge Fund L.L.C.

title: Clashing Over Welfare Cuts;Closing of Westchester Benefits Offices Is Criticized
description: Last year, when Frances Gilkes needed to talk to her welfare worker about her benefits, she walked a block and a half from her apartment to the social services office on North Avenue, the main artery in downtown New Rochelle. "It took five minutes at most," said Ms. Gilkes, a 43-year-old mother of three who suffers from a herniated disk, the result of an injury that occurred two years ago when she was doing volunteer work at a senior citizens center.

description: Whether the satellite dishes that crown nearly every roof here are, well, entirely legal is not entirely clear.

description: An escapee from a prison work program abducted a woman working at a veterinary clinic at gunpoint today and a second woman from her home nearby, forcing them into a sport utility vehicle and driving away, the authorities said.

description: IS there anyone left in New York who still believes that the Knicks can compete for a championship?

description: Bowing to what appeared to be insurmountable financial pressure, First Interstate Bancorporation said yesterday that it was now negotiating to sell itself to Wells Fargo & Company for $11.2 billion, breaking off its engagement to First Bank System.

description: When the New York City Ballet danced George Balanchine's "Four Temperaments" on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater, it gave an exciting performance of a masterpiece that has astonished audiences since its premiere in 1946.

description: Stung by the stabbing death of a school headmaster, Britons surrendered more than 37,000 knives in a monthlong campaign to make the country safer.
