description: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told Republican Congressional leaders today that he has run out of legal options to sidestep the national borrowing limit and cannot keep the Government from defaulting on its debts after Feb. 29 without selling off the national gold reserve or holding up tax refunds.

title: Tanzania Closes Border With Burundi
description: The Tanzanian Army has shut the border with Burundi, turning back 17,000 Rwandan Hutu refugees fleeing Burundi's ethnic violence, a senior aid official said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Daimler-Benz Expects a Loss Of at Least $4.2 Billion in '95
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., the maker of Mercedes-Benz automobiles and trucks and Germany's largest industrial concern, said today that it expected to report one of the biggest losses in business history, largely because it was abandoning the troubled Dutch commuter-aircraft subsidiary, and writing off the loss.

title: HOCKEY;Campbell Finds Way To Make Rangers Go
description: The Rangers continue to streak. Their coach is on some kind of roll, as well.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rubin Warns Ways to Avoid Default Are Running Out Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told Republican leaders that he had run out of legal options to sidestep the national borrowing limit and could not keep the Government from defaulting on its debts after Feb. 29 without selling the national gold reserve or holding up tax refunds -- options he described as "completely unacceptable."

title: MUSIC REVIEW;It's Back To Basics In Sardinia
description: One thing a concertgoer with open ears can learn from the World Music Institute's presentations is that there is a seemingly inexhaustible supply of musical cultures out there, many of them ancient and virtually untouched by the jet age. The institute's latest find, which it presented on Saturday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, is cantu a tenores, an unaccompanied Sardinian vocal form. The performers, Tenores di Oniferi, were making their first appearances outside Italy.

title: Israel Eldad, 86, a Top Leader In Palestine Jewish Underground
description: Israel Eldad, a leader of the Jewish underground before Israel became a nation and for 50 years one of the most influential figures of the Israeli right wing, died today, his family said. He was 86.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCA Nears a Deal for Stake in Interscope
description: MCA Inc. is close to reaching an unusual arrangement to pay $200 million for 50 percent of Interscope Records, the company best known for its gangsta rap music, people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Youth to Dotage: How Love Changes
description: THE LAW OF ENCLOSURES By Dale Peck 306 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.

title: Possible Bias Attack Leaves Boy Critical
description: A 13-year-old boy was critically injured yesterday after a group of junior high school students in East New York, Brooklyn, hit him on the head with a bottle and kicked him in what the police described as a possibly racially motivated attack.

title: PERIPHERALS;Works Within Works
description: WHEN you start Clarisworks 4.0, the new version written to take full advantage of Windows 95, the screen presents a list of its six modules: word processing, drawing, painting, spreadsheet, database and communications. You select one to start with.

title: Simpson Begins Deposition In Civil Lawsuit on Slayings
description: More than three months after he was acquitted of murder charges in the deaths of his former wife and her friend, O. J. Simpson answered questions under oath today in civil lawsuits filed by the two victims' families.

description: Some Hope for the Schools

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: BASKETBALL;Louisiana Tech Is Toppled
description: Abby Conklin scored all 12 of her points in the final 10 minutes to lead Tennessee to a 77-72 upset victory last night over previously unbeaten, top-ranked Louisiana Tech. The victory gave the No. 4 Lady Vols (16-3) a sweep of the nation's top two teams in the last four days. Tennessee beat then-No. 2 Vanderbilt on Friday night.

title: The Mexican Connection
description: The recent arrest and expulsion to the United States of Juan Garcia Abrego brings to justice a man who for years symbolized the untouchability of Mexico's top drug lords. His organization's smuggling of Colombian cocaine into the United States earned him a place on the Federal Bureau of Investigation's list of its 10 most wanted fugitives.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Counselor's Funeral Bill Paid
description: The Morris County freeholders will pay for the funeral of Robert Heavey, a counselor injured a year ago in a melee at the Morris County Youth Center. "As far as I'm concerned, his status is the same as an officer slain in the line of duty," Freeholder Sue Murphy Ostergaard said yesterday, "and we'll pay the entire $7,000 bill."

title: Theories About Jupiter Fall as Facts Pour In
description: IN its successful plunge into the crushing Jovian depths last month, a capsule from the Galileo spacecraft survived for 57 minutes to transmit a wealth of data from the first view inside the atmosphere of Jupiter or any of the giant gaseous planets. This was time enough to jolt scientists with surprises about the planet's clouds, winds, water and chemical composition and second thoughts about their own theories of planetary formation.

description: Scenes of Struggle And Introspection Yancey Dance Theater Merce Cunningham Studio

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Beaten By Avalanche
description: Jon Klemm scored 48 seconds into the game and Peter Forsberg added the game-winning goal in the third period tonight as the Colorado Avalanche held off the Islanders, 4-3

title: BASKETBALL;Knicks' Mason Is Denying Involvement in Dispute
description: Anthony Mason said today that he was not involved in a disturbance outside a Manhattan nightclub early this morning, saying he had nothing to do with a man who identified Mason as one of several assailants who struck him.

title: Don't Depict Islam, the Religion, as a Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: Kuhlman Raises Bid for Cable Maker
description: The Kuhlman Corporation raised its offer for Communication Cable Inc. today to $37 million shortly after the company, an electronic wire and cable maker, agreed to be acquired by Pentair Inc. for $35.6 million.

title: C.F.T.C. Says Ruling Didn't Expand Scope
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that a 1995 ruling did not expand its regulatory powers to include certain derivative contracts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Steve Rosen was named executive vice president and public relations director at Elkman Advertising and Public Relations, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., succeeding Ed Shapson, who joined Gillespie, Princeton, N.J., as a managing director. Mr. Rosen was president for public relations at the Weightman Group, Philadelphia.

title: Arafat and Friends Win Big
description: Results of the Palestinian elections published today after repeated delays in vote-counting show a decisive victory for Yasir Arafat and members of his Fatah movement, who will dominate the newly elected Palestinian Council.

title: MCI Signs Siemens Deal
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said today that it had signed signed five agreements with Siemens Rolm Communications Inc., a unit of Siemens A.G. of Germany, to offer services and discounts to each other's customers. MCI said it would gain $1 billion in additional business from the deals in the next five years.

title: Nassau Chief Recommends Schoolfare For Parents
description: Adopting an idea proposed last year by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Nassau County Executive said today that parents on welfare should be required to work in the public schools.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Vivid Harmony of an Aged Verdi
description: The eerie calm that opened Robert Shaw's Verdi program at Carnegie Hall on Sunday ended up speaking more loudly than the extroversions that followed it. The afternoon's major attraction had been the Requiem, famously described by Hans von Bulow as an "opera in clerical dress." The "Ave Maria" acted as curtain raiser, a clearing of the throat before the bigger choral doings of the day. Yet it is this brief, falsely modest piece that remains in the mind.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tentative Deal for Toll Takers
description: Toll collectors for the New Jersey Turnpike would get no raises for two years under a tentative contract agreement. The four-year deal announced yesterday by the turnpike authority would provide raises of 3.5 percent in each of the contract's final two years, The Associated Press said. Union leaders say they do not expect their 1,500 members to be thrilled by the agreement but they do expect ratification.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;The Red Sox Sign Cole
description: The Boston Red Sox signed outfielder ALEX COLE, a free agent, yesterday to a one-year deal that clears the way for the team to acquire the ace reliever HEATHCLIFF SLOCUMB from Philadelphia.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;Christian Scientists Rebuffed in Ruling By Supreme Court
description: The mother of a young boy who died from untreated diabetes, and the Christian Science practitioners who administered prayer rather than insulin as the 11-year-old slipped into a coma, failed today to persuade the Supreme Court to hear their appeal of a $1.5 million damage judgment won in a lawsuit by the boy's father.

title: Patterns
description: Designers' Gala in a Tent?

title: Perot as a Political Presence: 1992 All Over Again?
description: He is bankrolling a new political party that has already secured a place on the ballot in California and North Dakota and is promising to run its Presidential candidate in all 50 states this fall.

title: Support the Chechens
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Company Agrees to Buy Mafia-Linked Waste Hauler
description: In a move that officials say should lower garbage removal costs for businesses in New York City, one of the nation's biggest waste hauling companies said yesterday that it would enter the city's market by taking over a carting company that is under indictment as part of a Mafia-run cartel.

title: Sorrow but No Surprise at a Death
description: On Friday night, Jake Bloom, a Hollywood lawyer with numerous clients in the movie industry, phoned Michael Eisner, chairman of the Walt Disney Company, to inform him of the death of Don Simpson, one of Hollywood's most prominent producers and a one-time colleague of Mr. Eisner's.

title: No Headline
description: Given the remarkably large number of documented works by Michelangelo that have been lost, it's reasonable to suppose that some of them will be found -- and likely that some of them will be found right under our noses." -- NICHOLAS PENNY, an art expert, on a statue in Manhattan believed to be by Michelangelo. [C16:4.]

title: New Discoveries Turn Astronomers Toward Hunt for New Planets
description: FORTY billion more galaxies in the universe, half of its missing mass perhaps accounted for in burned-out stars and two new planets of distant stars -- not a bad haul of discoveries for one week. But it only seems that coy nature had suddenly lifted a few veils concealing deep cosmic mysteries just in time for the winter meeting of the American Astronomical Society in San Antonio.

title: Two Boys Lost In Toy Heaven
description: A child's dream, but a parent's nightmare: two boys were locked in a Toys 'R' Us store and spent the night playing while 150 volunteers searched for them.

title: Utilicorp in $3 Billion Deal With Kansas City Power
description: Two big utilities based in Kansas City, Mo., Utilicorp United Inc. and the Kansas City Power and Light Company, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a $3 billion deal that would create a huge new utility that would seek to market gas and electricity nationwide.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Saturday about the possible loss of private health insurance for about 1,000 of New York State's sickest residents referred incorrectly in some editions to the rule that currently bars the transfer of those patients to new health plans. It is a provision of Federal Medicare law, not state law.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Kingdom Hopes Experience Will Stand Up to the Test
description: In 1984, when Roger Kingdom won the first of his two consecutive Olympic gold medals in the 110-meter hurdles, Mark Crear was 15 years old and Allen Johnson 13.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;First Claim Filed Under Nafta
description: The United States said today that Canadian tariffs on American milk products, eggs, chickens and barley violated the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;AT&T Enters TV Business Via Satellite
description: Posing perhaps the most formidable challenge yet to the cable television industry, AT&T plans to invest in the nation's leading satellite broadcasting service and to market its programming to a vast audience that includes 90 million telephone customers. AT&T said yesterday that it would pay $137.5 million for a 2.5 percent stake in the service, DirecTV, which competes with cable by beaming 175 channels of television programming from orbiting satellites to household dishes the size of pizza pans.

title: Review/Fashion;In Paris Couture, a Study in Contrasts
description: Watching Gianni Versace during John Galliano's first show for Givenchy makes it difficult not to recall images of Mr. Versace's first turn at bat at haute couture. The term "at bat" comes to mind because buried within the myriad themes at his first show was the world of sports, and Linda Evangelista was complaining backstage about a jeweled baseball cap she had to wear. Shalom Harlow, walking the runway in one of her first haute couture shows, was in tears.

title: The N.C.A.A. Gets It Right
description: After a 10-year power struggle within the National Collegiate Athletic Association -- the group that sets rules for undergraduate sports -- college presidents have won a big victory in their campaign to control runaway athletic programs.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Spending Cuts and Layoffs
description: Essex County would cut its spending and its work force under the budget proposed yesterday by County Executive James W. Treffinger. The $492.4 million in spending would be $37.6 million less than in 1995. The budget would cut 299 jobs, all but 33 through layoffs. Mr. Treffinger said 188 of the layoffs would come at the county's geriatric center, to be sold this year. The freeholders plan six budget hearings around the county. The first, on money for schools, parks and public works, will be today at 6 P.M. at Maplewood Town Hall.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Companies to Sell 25% of Phone Venture
description: Hutchison Whampoa Ltd. and British Aerospace P.L.C. said yesterday that they would sell 25 percent of their Orange P.L.C. mobile telephone venture, yielding L500 million, or $750 million, to repay existing loans. Hutchison said it would sell shares in a global initial public offering of the company in March.

title: Is West Slighting Africa's Hot Spots Like Liberia?
description: When the chief American delegate to the United Nations, Madeleine K. Albright, stopped here briefly on Wednesday during a tour of several African countries, there were the predictable pledges of assistance from Washington to war-torn Liberia.

title: Abortion Foes Rally in Capital to Urge Changes in the Law
description: Tens of thousands of abortion opponents gathered in Washington today, as they have each of the last 22 years on the anniversary of the landmark Supreme Court ruling that legalized abortion, to press the Government for changes in the law.

title: 11 City Schools Shed Label As Failures
description: When Thelma Baxter was assigned to be principal of Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx four years ago, she inherited a giant school with discipline problems, poor academic performance and low morale among teachers.

title: A Victory That Nips at Arafat's Heels
description: In jeans, boots, and a long green trench coat, Salah Taamari walked out of his four-wheel-drive vehicle into the warm embrace of his supporters on Sunday, a local hero who had won big against the party machine of Yasir Arafat.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAREMARK TAKES CHARGE AFTER STOCK'S VALUE FALLS
TENNIS;For Seles, Winning Only Looks Easy
description: It was not quite as straightforward as the 6-1, 6-2 score indicated. But Monica Seles is on a Grand Slam roll for the moment, meeting with victory, adversity and potentially awkward questions and treating them just the same.

title: Market Place;What to Do About Broker Arbitrations?
description: Here's a clever idea about how to persuade brokerage firms to compensate clients they have treated badly: Change the rules to make sure that other prospective clients do not find out about it. Then the broker will be more inclined to settle quietly.

title: Rifkin Is Sentenced In a Seventh Murder
description: Joel Rifkin, who has admitted killing 17 women in New York City and surrounding areas, was sentenced yesterday to up to life in prison in the death of one of his victims. He had already been sentenced for the murders of six other women.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Add Gilkey to Outfield Equation
description: The Mets all but sealed their outfield alignment for this season yesterday when they completed extended negotiations with the outfield-rich St. Louis Cardinals and acquired left fielder Bernard Gilkey for three minor leaguers.

title: Bank of Tokyo Pursues Embezzlement Case
description: The Bank of Tokyo, a leading Japanese bank, said today that it had lodged a criminal complaint against a former employee who is said to have embezzled 850 million yen, about $8 million.

title: Vulcan Deal in Chemicals
description: The Vulcan Materials Company said today that it had agreed to buy the Mayo Chemical Company, a maker of specialty chemicals, for an undisclosed price. Vulcan, which makes construction materials and chemical products, is based here. It said the acquisition would complement its specialty-chemicals division and increase its production of products used in the water-purification, paper and textile industries.

title: The 'Horsy Set' Objects to a Stereotype
description: To the Editor:

title: NYC;Waiting To Exhale In Exile
description: THEY'RE the Building Front Tribe. You see them at the entrances of office towers, conspicuous in winter because so many are in shirtsleeves; huddled masses yearning to breathe freely on anything that comes in a pack of 20, be it filtered, unfiltered or mentholated.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;After Too Many Setbacks, A Woman Gets a Respite
description: Hers was the sort of childhood better left to movies and bad dreams. Her mother was a crack addict who worshiped Satan, and Yorna Mera said she was forced to do the same.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Tartabull Traded to White Sox
description: The Chicago White Sox acquired outfielder DANNY TARTABULL from the Oakland Athletics for two minor leaguers yesterday. Chicago sent the left-handed pitcher ANDREW LORRAINE and outfielder CHARLES POE to Oakland.

title: Assembly Bill Would Ban On-Line Smut to Minors
description: The Legislature completed passage of a bill today that would make it a punishable offense to send pornographic materials to minors over computer networks.

title: Increase in Food Stamps
description: The number of people who received food stamps rose to 26.11 million in October 1995, the Agriculture Department reported today, saying the increase was due in part to emergency food aid to hurricane victims.

title: W.O. Aydelotte, 85, Innovative Historian Who Used Statistics
description: William O. Aydelotte, a retired University of Iowa professor who was one of the first historians elected to the National Academy of Sciences, died on Wednesday at University Hospitals in Iowa City. He was 85 and lived in Iowa City.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;The Browns Are Going Nowhere Until All the Lawsuits Are Settled
description: The Cleveland Browns hardly seem to exist as a sports team anymore as the legal thicket around their proposed move to Baltimore grows.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Fractious Family in Free Fall
description: The program for "The Preservation Society," now at Primary Stages, states that William S. Leavengood's new play is set in the mountains of western North Carolina. But its 'ore relevant location is the terrain of topical living-room comedy pioneered by Norman Lear in television shows like "All in the Family" and "Maude."

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: BASKETBALL;Will the Right Knicks Show Up Tonight?
description: The Knicks are about to pass their denial stage. They do not know how or why, but they have come to grips with the fact that they are a team of two faces: the gentle souls who apologize for hard fouls and take pity on expansion teams, and the in-your-face crew that will stop at nothing to stop Michael Jordan.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Emirate in Oil Deal
description: The American investor Michael Dingman has signed an oil and gas exploration deal with the United Arab Emirates state of Ras al Khaima, a local government official said yesterday. The Ras al Khaima Oil and Gas Company, headed by Mr. Dingman, signed the onshore and offshore oil and gas exploration agreement on Saturday. Reuters

title: U.A.W. Is Setting Bargaining Strategy
description: The United Automobile Workers union, in preparing for labor talks with the Big Three auto makers this summer, signaled today that just about everything it has bargained for in the past would be on its agenda again.

title: Chess
description: No matter how important thorough analysis is to tournament players, they must keep it in balance with the demands of the clock. The deepest, most ingenious conception ever intended for the chessboard yields nothing if you suffer a time forfeit before bringing it to fulfillment.

title: Secrecy Lifted on Destroying Chemical Arms
description: In a break with nearly 50 years of cold-war secrecy, the United States Army said today that it was slowly destroying more than 60 million pounds of chemical weapons.

title: Good News for President in the Latest Poll
description: In his State of the Union Message tonight, President Clinton will address a public that is suddenly expressing new concerns about the Federal deficit but still gives Mr. Clinton higher marks than the Republican Congress for trying to break the budget impasse, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Boeing Gets $4 Billion Order by G.E.
description: Acting on a view that global aircraft demand is set to rebound, the General Electric Company's aircraft leasing business announced yesterday that it intended to buy more than $4 billion worth of jetliners from the Boeing Company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lord, Dentsu Names a New Chief
description: Lord, Dentsu & Partners, a joint venture of Dentsu Inc. and Young & Rubicam Inc., said yesterday that it had named James W. Hood, executive vice president and director for corporate development at Young & Rubicam in New York, as chief executive. Mr. Hood, 43, also assumes responsibilities from William Perkins, 42, who had been president and chief operating officer since April and is leaving.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Country Meeting Rockabilly
description: Two very different approaches to performing collided during a night of hillbilly, rockabilly and country music on Friday at the Rodeo Bar. BR5-49, which opened the show, has honed its sound by playing four nights a week for nearly two years at Robert's Western Wear, a boot store by day, in Nashville. Sleepy LaBeef, on the other hand, is a grizzled road warrior, an Elvis Presley contemporary who has spent most of the last few decades playing in bars around the country.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Drop on Talk Of a Default
description: Investors in the credit markets turned bearish yesterday in response to fresh Republican threats over the weekend to thwart an increase in the Federal debt limit unless it was done on their terms.

title: Man Falls to Death Fleeing U.S. Agents
description: Six illegal immigrants who had been stopped by Federal agents near the Mexican border fell off a 120-foot cliff after they ran away in the dark, the Border Patrol said on Sunday. One man died and the others were injured, as was the Border Patrol agent who went to their assistance.

title: Fokker Abandoned By Daimler-Benz; 9,000 Jobs at Stake
description: STUTTGART  Daimler-Benz AGcut its financial lifeline Monday to Fokker NV, dealing a potential death blow to the struggling Dutch aircraft maker whose financial troubles will contribute to a staggering $4 billion loss for 1995 at the German parent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: COMPANY NEWS;JOHNSON & JOHNSON WILL COMPLETE PURCHASE OF CORDIS
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would complete its $1.8 billion purchase of the Cordis Corporation, a medical device maker, ending weeks of uncertainty about whether the deal would go through. Cordis shares soared $7.8125, or almost 8 percent, to $107.5625, in Nasdaq trading. Johnson & Johnson, the world's largest health-care-products company, spurred worries last month about its $109-a-share acquisition, saying it needed an extra month to go over Cordis's books. Johnson & Johnson refused to say what it was looking for and Cordis shares plunged 11 percent in one day. Although Johnson & Johnson still would not say what it found, the two companies said that Cordis's shareholders would meet on Feb. 23 to give final approval to the deal.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Merrill Lynch Profit Up 87% In 4th Quarter
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage company, reported a hefty increase in fourth-quarter and yearly profits yesterday, joining the string of Wall Street firms solidifying turnarounds after a weak bond market wreaked havoc on the industry in 1994.

title: Richard Cobb, 78, an Authority On the French Revolution, Dies
description: Richard Cobb, an iconoclastic British historian who helped revolutionize the study of the French Revolution by concentrating on the minutiae of big events, died on Jan. 15 at his home in Abingdon, England. He was 78.

title: Hold the Mustaches
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ASARCO WILL TAKE CHARGE AND CEASE SOME OPERATIONS
description: Asarco Inc., one of the world's largest copper producers, said yesterday that it would take a $79.5 million after-tax fourth-quarter charge and cease its lead refining operations in Omaha. As a result, Asarco said it expected a fourth-quarter loss. Asarco announced the charge and the decision to end the lead refining operations after the stock market closed.

title: Modern Musem Buys Sherman Photo Series
description: The Museum of Modern Art has purchased what is widely considered a cornerstone of post-modernism, a complete set of Cindy Sherman's "Untitled Film Stills," the museum announced yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Computer magazines are proliferating, but advertisers are looking elsewhere, too.
description: IN the alphabet soup of computer publications, PC Magazine is the advertising page leader. But when it comes to sheer growth, there's Computer Life, Family PC and PC World, not to mention PC Computing.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Military Copter With 39 Is Missing Off Sri Lanka
description: An air force helicopter with 39 people aboard disappeared off the northern coast of Sri Lanka today, and the military said Tamil rebels had asserted that they shot it down.

title: Bring Extraterrestrial Musings Down to Earth;Stellar Eavesdropping
description: To the Editor:

title: ON BASEBALL;Mets Hope to Serve Up Something for Everyone
description: William Rodriguez, a 28-year-old from the Bronx, stood in the old Jets locker room at Shea Stadium yesterday dressed in the uniform of choice for today's younger generation: baggy blue jeans, even baggier flannel shirt, baseball cap pulled low across his forehead.

title: NATO Forces Are Warned Of U.S. Extremist in Bosnia
description: As if land mines and simmering ethnic tensions were not enough, NATO forces in Bosnia were instructed today to be on the lookout for an American citizen said to be a political extremist and a potential threat, NATO officials said today.

title: Advice to Under-35's
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;GERBER SELLS ITS CHILDREN'S APPAREL BUSINESS
description: The Gerber Products Company, a unit of Switzerland's Sandoz Ltd., said yesterday that it had sold its apparel business to GCIH Inc., an investment group formed by management and a private equity fund. Terms were not disclosed. Gerber, a maker of baby products, agreed to give the unit, Gerber Childrenswear Inc., an exclusive license to use the Gerber name and trademark on clothing sold in the United States, Canada, Mexico, Argentina and the Caribbean. Gerber Childrenswear has annual sales of about $200 million.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Iona's Defense Shuts Down Jaspers
description: With 14 minutes 30 seconds left in last night's game, Jason Hoover of Manhattan made a driving layup that trimmed Iona's lead to 39-36. With 7:14 left, Justin Phoenix of Manhattan sank a layup. In the seven-plus minutes between those two field goals, Iona ran off 16 straight points and went on to rout the Jaspers, 67-49.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Charges in Vandalism Case
description: For the first time, Federal civil rights charges have been lodged in a cemetery desecration case, prosecutors say. Kevin Coombs, 18, of Garfield, and Christopher E. Talbot, 19, of Lodi, were charged in Federal court yesterday with vandalizing 18 graves last Halloween at a Jewish cemetery in Saddlebrook.

title: No Headline
description: The era of big government is over."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;China Drafting Rules On Internet Links
description: China's State Council, striving to embrace the Internet but not its pornographic and political content, adopted unspecified draft rules yesterday governing links to overseas computer information networks. In an executive meeting led by Prime Minister Li Peng, the council reiterated its provisional approval for global computer links, the official New China News Agency reported.

title: After Rising Faster Than Inflation for Years, Tuition Begins to Dropat Many Colleges
description: Despite the conventional wisdom that the costs of higher education will keep rising, a once-unthinkable phrase, tuition cuts, has been heard more frequently at America's colleges and universities.

description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Advance Cited In Diagnosis Of a Cancer
description: Mayo Clinic doctors say they have developed a formula for telling the difference between prostate cancers that require surgery and those that grow so slowly they can safely be left alone.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an interview with a commander of rebels in Chechnya, a region of southern Russia, omitted credit in some editions for the news agency that obtained it. The rebel commander, Salman Raduyev, spoke to Reuters.

title: STATE OF THE UNION;Clinton Starts With Joke, on Speaker
description: President Clinton gave Speaker Newt Gingrich just what he wanted tonight.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Housing Market Ages
description: The New Jersey housing market has reached "advanced middle age," a new report from Rutgers University says.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Jail Escape Route Discovered
description: State corrections officers who seized control of the Hudson County Jail uncovered an escape route built by prisoners.

title: How Military Contractors Increase Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Rabin Assassin's Testimony: My Goal Was to Paralyze Him
description: Answering murder charges at his trial today, Yigal Amir said he had intended only to paralyze Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and his policies when he fired three shots that killed Mr. Rabin on Nov. 4.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Agee Still Pursuing His N.B.A. Dream
description: There is a little more muscle, the head is shaved and there's a diamond stud in his left ear, but the shy grin is the same and Arthur Agee is instantly recognizable to anyone who watched more than four years of his life unfold in the documentary film "Hoop Dreams." At 23, he is still chasing his dream of playing in the National Basketball Association, although right now the hunt has taken him far afield. Agee is is playing for the Winnipeg Cyclone in the fledgling five-team International Basketball Association.

title: Book Notes
description: Reversal of Tradition

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Irvin Calmly Takes a Hike on Media Day
description: Cowboys receiver Michael Irvin has a love-hate relationship with the news media, and today he showed both aspects of that relationship. For about 12 minutes this morning, with the sun beaming down on Sun Devil Stadium, Irvin was beaming, too. He spoke eloquently about who may be his direct opponent on Sunday, the Steelers' Pro Bowl cornerback Rod Woodson.

title: How Military Contractors Increase Profit
description: To the Editor:

title: Texaco Spending Up
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it would spend $3.6 billion this year on oil and natural gas exploration programs, which is an increase of $500 million from 1995's spending.

title: Creditors Give Fokker a Month To Plot Survival
description: Seeking time to avert collapse, Fokker N.V., the Dutch aircraft maker, said tonight that its main subsidiaries had been granted one month's protection from creditors after the cutoff of financial support from Daimler-Benz A. G., its German benefactor.

title: New Heart for Retarded Woman
description: A woman with Down syndrome who was at first refused a heart-lung transplant because doctors did not think she was smart enough to handle the effects underwent the operation today.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: THE INDUSTRY;Broadcasters Wary, But Glad Clinton Has Offered to Talk
description: Executives in the broadcast industry said last night that they would welcome the opportunity to meet with President Clinton to discuss ways to improve the programs on television. But they reacted uncomfortably to being thrust back under a political spotlight by the President.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Market Place;When owners aren't around, management pays itself well.
description: IF you're going to be a boss, it's a good idea to make sure the owners have no power over what you get paid.

title: The Poor Don't Wield Charity Market Clout
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Tagliabue Asks Senate For Antitrust Protection
description: On his second visit in two months to the United States Senate to request legal protection against franchise movement, the National Football League's commissioner, Paul Tagliabue, today assailed teams that sue the league to assert their rights to hopscotch cities for sweetheart deals.

title: F.A.A. Decisions Linked To Air Computer Problems
description: The nation's air traffic control system suffers long, costly breakdowns not just because it is old, but also because poor decisions by the Federal Aviation Administration have left the agency ill-prepared to maintain the 30-year-old computers, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New Campaigns
description: The actor Anthony Edwards, a star of the NBC series "E.R.," will take his first role in advertising with a campaign for Keycorp, the financial services company in Cleveland. The campaign, which carries the theme "Key. For a new America," is the first by Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York since being awarded the Keycorp account in September. An initial television commercial features Mr. Edwards supplying a voice-over narration; he is scheduled to appear in spots that will run in the spring.

title: John Kenyon, 68, a Historian And Expert on Stuart England
description: John Kenyon, a scholar of Stuart England and a prolific author on its history, died on Jan. 6 at a hospital near his home in Dereham, Norfolk, England. He was 68.

title: Veering Car Kills Girl and Injures Sitter on Upper West Side
description: A 19-month-old girl was killed and her baby sitter seriously injured on the Upper West Side yesterday when an out-of-control car turned a leisurely stroll into a journey of horror, dragging them across the sidewalk and slamming them into the plate-glass window of a health food store.

title: With Doctor Surplus, U.S. Is Urged to Cut Residency Training
description: The United States has a growing surfeit of doctors, primarily caused by an excess of foreign-trained physicians, and to control the problem the nation should quickly move to reduce residency programs for training new doctors, a panel of experts said today.

title: Dow Loses 27.09 on Concern Over Earnings
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday, a day after the Dow Jones industrial average streaked to an all-time high.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Wine Talk
description: WHEN you buy a bottle of California chardonnay, you expect it to be full of chardonnay, right? Right. But don't count on it.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;New Airport Arrivals Hall
description: Newark International Airport opens a $120 million international arrivals hall today, a move that aviation experts say puts Newark in position to become the region's busiest airport. The addition to Terminal B is designed to handle 3,000 passengers per hour when it is fully operating by year's end. [Page A1.]

title: Guatemala Killing
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn Couple Arrested in Stolen-Check Scheme
description: A Brooklyn couple in their 50's were arrested late Monday after the police said they found drugs, guns, stolen Government checks and a pipe bomb in their Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment.

title: COMPANY NEWS;POCO PETROLEUMS TO BUY SOME AMOCO ASSETS
description: Poco Petroleums Ltd. agreed yesterday to buy energy interests in the Swan Hills area of Alberta from the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company, a unit of the Amoco Corporation, for about $145 million (Canadian), or about $106 million (United States). Poco, an oil and natural-gas producer, also agreed to buy some properties in the Harmattan area of Alberta from an undisclosed energy company. Terms of that purchase were not disclosed. Poco, which is based in Calgary, Alberta, said the properties to be acquired from Amoco had 1995 revenue of $35 million (Canadian) after royalties and operating costs. In the second deal, the properties had 1995 net revenue of $11.3 million (Canadian). Poco also said it planned to sell 15 million common shares to help finance the deal.

title: Ford Tests the Price Barrier;Auto Maker Takes a Risk With Fancy Redesigns
description: When the Ford Motor Company introduces the redesigned F-150 XLT pickup on Thursday, the truck will not have simple steel bumpers. Instead, its rear bumpers will glisten with chrome -- an option for which customers used to pay $150.

title: Boy Shot as He Walked To School in Manhattan
description: John Paul Valentine, 9 years old, has been living for most of his life in an Upper West Side foster home, where he was shielded from the drug dealing and crime of his family's neighborhood in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Prepared Text for the President's State of the Union Message
description: Following is President Clinton's State of the Union Message last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Invite In the Rich? PEN Is Pondering
description: A proposal that might add wealthy nonwriters to the board of the PEN American Center, a group devoted to defending the freedom of writers, has led to alarm among members that the well heeled are about to take charge and to cries of censorship in a stronghold of intellectual freedom.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Canadian Rail Servicing
description: The Canadian National Railway Company said this week that it would eliminate 202 jobs as part of a move to consolidate three underused locomotive-maintenance shops in eastern Canada. The railroad will concentrate its eastern maintenance operations in Toronto, while reducing activity at centers in Montreal and Moncton, New Brunswick. The consolidation will save $25 million (Canadian) a year, or about $18 million (United States).

title: Some Like It Hot: Roasting at 500degrees
description: BARBARA KAFKA, now 62 and as opinionated, articulate and elegant as ever, is on the telephone.

title: HOCKEY;Muller Trade Gives Islanders A Headache Until the End
description: Fittingly, it took another surreal delay. But there was finally a resolution to the Kirk Muller soap opera.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan Trade Surplus Shrinks For the First Time in 5 Years
description: Japan's giant overall trade surplus shrank in 1995 for the first time in five years, led by a substantial narrowing in the politically sensitive gap with the United States.

title: Carter Burden, Progressive Patrician, 54, Dies
description: Carter Burden, who epitomized the young patrician partygiver of the early 1960's, who flashed across the political firmament as a progressive New York City Councilman a few years later and who spent his latter years as a publisher, founder of a broadcasting empire and benefactor of the arts, died yesterday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 54.

title: Street Fairs Need Reform
description: Recent revelations of financial irregularities in the operation of New York City's San Gennaro Festival make it clear that the event, if it is to continue, must be run by a new sponsor. But San Gennaro's difficulties are only a small slice of the problems raised by the proliferation of the city's street fairs. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani should use this opening to tackle the adverse impact on quality of life and on local business caused by monster street fairs in general.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;In the Bulls' Galaxy, Knicks Lost in Space
description: How wide is the gap between the Chicago Bulls and the Knicks? Do the words Grand Canyon mean anything to you?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Seeking consistency for a change, Pepsi plays off its 1995 campaign.
description: THE Pepsi-Cola Company has spent most of this decade in seeming agreement with Ralph Waldo Emerson's assessment of consistency, disdaining it as the hobgoblin of little minds -- or perhaps of minds located in Atlanta. But the 1996 advertising for the company's flagship brands, which begins appearing on Sunday, strives to benefit from what has gone before.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Dec. 29, about the highlights and low points of campaigns that appeared in 1995, misidentified the agency that handles Subaru of America. It is Temerlin McClain, a division of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, not the Richards Group.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOLSON TO SELL CHEMICALS UNIT TO UNILEVER
description: The Molson Companies, Canada's biggest brewer, agreed yesterday to sell most of its chemicals unit, the Diversey Corporation, to Unilever N.V. for $780 million (Canadian), or about $569 million (United States). Molson, which also owns the Montreal Canadiens hockey team, said it would focus on brewing and sports. Molson said Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products concern, would acquire all of Diversey's cleaning and sanitizing business except for its Novamax metal-finishing business, water-treatment business and United States institutional cleaning-supplies and laundry business. Molson agreed to sell the cleaning business to a Diversey management group, but terms were not disclosed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;G.E. SELLS ITS GENIE ON-LINE OPERATION TO YOVELLE
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it had sold its struggling Genie computer on-line service to the Yovelle Renaissance Corporation, a closely held company in Queens. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Genie, which is 10 years old, fell behind larger rivals, including America Online and Compuserve, in the increasingly competitive on-line and Internet markets. Analysts have said that G.E. largely ignored Genie, failing to spend enough money to make the service known among consumers. G.E. said it sold Genie because it did not fit with the core business of the company's information services unit, which focuses on serving corporate customers.

title: Real Estate;Stroock & Stroock is moving into space vacated in lower Manhattan when Mudge Rose disbanded.
description: WHEN the law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon disbanded in mid-December, it left a large vacancy at 180 Maiden Lane, a 41-story, 1.1 million-square-foot office building in lower Manhattan.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Arbitration Avoided
description: MEL ROJAS and the Montreal Expos settled on a $2.025 million contract yesterday to avoid arbitration. Rojas, who became the Exp's' closer last season with the departure of JOHN WETTELAND and saved 30 games, had submitted a figure of $2.15 million. Montreal had offered $1.9 million.

title: France to Miss '95 Deficit Target 'by Just a Little Bit'
description: PARIS  France will miss its 1995 budget deficit target of 322 billion francs, but it will stay within a "reasonable" distance, according to Finance Minister Jean Arthuis.

title: Text of the G.O.P. Response: 'The Future and the Values That WillShape It'
description: Following is the Republican response by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas to President Clinton's State of the Union Message last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Backing Further Into a Tribute to Geriatric Verdi
description: New York City has inadvertently backed into a mini-tribute to Giuseppe Verdi's geriatric renaissance. "Otello" passed through the Metropolitan Opera House in the fall and is shortly to return. Two of the Four Sacred Pieces surfaced at Robert Shaw's choral afternoon at Carnegie Hall over the weekend. Now the Met has revived its "Falstaff" production, though decline and decrepitude leave Franco Zeffirelli's 1964 creation scarcely breathing.

title: Colombia Leader's Accuser Is Causing Political Turmoil
description: Colombia's politics have been thrown into turmoil by a former senior official's charges that President Ernesto Samper knowingly received contributions by drug traffickers to his 1994 campaign.

title: John Paul Walsh, 78, Engineer In 2d U.S. Satellite Launching
description: John Paul Walsh, an engineer who was the scientist at Cape Canaveral in charge of the launching of the second American satellite to go into orbit, died last Friday at Indian River Community Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 78 and lived in Vero Beach.

title: Patients Challenge Mental Health Plans
description: Millions of people participate in health plans that use managed care for their mental health benefits. A growing number are complaining that in the name of saving money, managed care companies are denying essential mental health services, and as a result patients are suffering.

title: SHOPPING WITH: Ilene Beckerman;Wearing Her Life on Her Sleeve
description: I DIDN'T tell Ilene Beckerman about my prom dress. But if I had drawn it for her, it would have looked like this: an ivory scoop-neck gown with long, full sleeves, an Empire waist -- very Juliet -- and down around the hem, three red stains where Romeo sloshed his sloe gin fizz.

title: Steep Drop in Rate of Student Loan Default
description: The percentage of borrowers defaulting on their Federal student loans has sharply dropped and the Government recouped $2 billion in the last fiscal year from those in default, Education Secretary Richard Riley said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: NATIONAL CITY CORP., Cleveland, said it had won Federal Reserve approval of its plan to acquire Integra Financial Corp., Pittsburgh, for $2.1 billion in stock.

title: CHRONICLE
description: What is the most time-consuming job in magazine journalism? It could be the one held by JULE CAMPBELL, a senior editor at Sports Illustrated who has been responsible for its swimsuit issue for the last 32 years.

title: 3 Municipal Union Locals Approve 5-Year Contract
description: Showing signs that worries about job security are beginning to take hold, three locals in New York City's largest municipal workers' union overwhelmingly approved a proposed five-year contract this week. But several union officials said it was still too close to call whether the agreement would win a majority from the union's 56 locals.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;NEC Sets Plant in China
description: The NEC Corporation of Japan said yesterday that it would start manufacturing the most advanced 4-megabit dynamic random access memory (D-RAM) chips in China next November. NEC will spend 12 billion yen ($113 million) to build the memory chip production line in China as part of its Beijing-based joint venture, the Shougang NEC Electronics Company, the company said. Construction will start next month. (AP)

title: International Panel Asks Britain to Ease Terms on I.R.A. at Talks
description: The international commission for disarmament in Northern Ireland has recommended that Britain drop its demand that the Irish Republican Army begin to disarm before its political arm, Sinn Fein, is allowed to take part in full-fledged peace talks, officials and diplomats said today.

title: Contour in Bid for Up to 65% of Kelley
description: The Contour Production Company has agreed to buy up to a 65 percent stake of the Kelley Oil and Gas Corporation with a $75 million investment, the companies said today.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Share Genetic Secrets
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: St. John's-Georgetown

title: Nasdaq Reports a Decline In Uncovered Short Sales
description: In the largest decline since January 1995, the number of open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market fell 3.8 percent in the month that ended on Jan. 12, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BANC ONE PLANS BUYBACK AND SPECIAL DIVIDEND
description: The board of the Banc One Corporation approved a special 10 percent stock dividend yesterday and authorized the repurchase of as many as 15 million common shares. The stock dividend is to be paid on March 6 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 21. The stock buyback program comes after the bank's repurchase of 21 million shares -- equal to what it issued to pay for Louisiana-based Premier Bancorp on Jan. 3. The 15 million shares represent 3.7 percent of Banc One's 410 million outstanding shares. The shares of Banc One, which is based in Columbus, Ohio, dropped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $36.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mrs. Clinton's Power
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BMW in South Africa
description: The German auto maker BMW A.G. said yesterday that it would invest about $274 million in the next four years in its South African subsidiary. (Dow Jones)

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Some Donors Have a Cause in Mind
description: The check and the note will vary each year, but the arrival of the envelope will not. This year, the check was $250 and the note was brief.

title: In South Texas, a Swat at an Old Pest Stirs a Revolt
description: For decades, the boll weevil was the scourge of cotton farmers across the South, periodically raging across the fields and destroying crops with a fury worthy of General Sherman. By 1974, though, the Federal Government was envisioning ultimate victory: a program that could all but eradicate the bug by the end of the century.

title: Apple Takeover Rumors Fuel Feverish Trading
description: Shares of Apple Computer Inc. fell in after-hours trading today, after the company's chairman attempted to contain continuing rumors of an impending takeover by flatly stating, "Apple is not for sale."

title: City Is to Study Port Unit
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has fought a running battle with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said yesterday that he has commissioned a study to determine how New York would fare without the authority.

title: Newark Airport Is Pressing to Surpass Kennedy
description: Newark International Airport formally opens a sprawling, $120 million international arrivals hall on Wednesday, a move that aviation experts say positions Newark to become the region's busiest airport.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Net Up 12% at Siemens
description: The German electronics giant Siemens A.G. said yesterday that its profit rose 12 percent, to 503 million marks ($347 million), in the quarter that ended on Sept. 30. International growth was the catalyst for a 6 percent sales increase, the company said. The company earned 448 million marks a year earlier. Sales totaled 19.7 billion marks ($13.6 billion) in the quarter, the first in the company's fiscal year, up from 18.5 billion marks. (AP)

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Stallion Owner Has a Solution
description: The owner of the Baltimore Stallions has come up with an idea that he says would delight football fans in Cleveland and Baltimore -- let the Browns stay where they are and allow his Canadian Football League champions to join the National Football League in 1996.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Walt Disney Says Earnings Rose 2.9% in First Quarter
description: The Walt Disney Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose 2.9 percent in its fiscal first quarter, as the company's performance was restrained by marginal gains from its film division.

title: Ursula C. Schwerin, 71, Dies; Was President of CUNY Tech
description: Dr. Ursula C. Schwerin, former president of New York City Technical College and the first woman to head a technical college in the United States, died on Friday in a nursing home in Stamford, Conn. She was 71 and had been a longtime resident of Queens.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Canada Settles Claim On Canceled Helicopters
description: Canada's Government said yesterday that it had reached a settlement agreement with E. H. Industries, a jointly owned unit of Westland Helicopters Ltd. of Britain and Agusta S.p.A. of Italy, for a claim arising from the 1993 cancellation of the EH-101 helicopter program. The settlement, worth $157.8 million (Canadian), or $115 million (United States), was reached in October but was made public only yesterday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP. (LMT,N)
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 15 percent as the company continued to reduce operating costs.

title: In a Cashless Future, Robots Will Cook
description: It's a typical day in the year 2006. After a hectic afternoon of negotiating contracts with business partners in Hong Kong, London, Moscow and the Bronx, you step from your office and into your kitchen. What's for lunch? You press a hand on your personal diagnostic machine, and quicker then you can say Michael Jackson does Sinatra, the unit checks your blood pressure, cholesterol and weight-fat ratio and reads out your nutritional requirements. Up pops suggested menus.

title: Weight of Snow Is Blamed in Roof Collapse
description: The weight of drifting snow and rain, rather than structural problems, caused the the roof of a Waldbaum's supermarket in North Massapequa to collapse on Jan. 12, according to an engineering report prepared for Waldbaum's.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets Hold 'Charity Drive' In Toronto
description: Nets Coach Butch Beard looked at the stat sheet and did not know whether to laugh or cry.

title: Suicide Backers Lose in Custody Dispute
description: A patient with Alzheimer's disease should stay with the son who wants him to live, rather than with other relatives who may try to take him to see Dr. Jack Kevorkian, who has attended 26 suicides of ill people, a judge ruled today.

title: About New York;Street Art: Free Speech Or Just Stuff?
description: ALEX SALONOV eked out a living in Moscow selling his deep-hued cityscapes -- where else -- on bustling streets and in parks.

title: Earl of Warwick, 61, Who Sold His Castle to Madame Tussauds
description: David Robin Francis Guy Greville, the Eighth Earl of Warwick, who created an uproar when he stripped his family's ancestral castle of its art treasures and then sold it to the Madame Tussauds organization as a tourist attraction, died on Saturday in Torremolinos, Spain. He was 61 and maintained homes there and in New York, Paris and the Turks and Caicos Islands.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: THE CONFLICT;Republicans Tussle Over Stopgate Bill but Agree to Put Off Debt Issue Until February
description: House and Senate Republicans agreed today to put off action on the national debt limit until late February, but they failed to agree on details of a bill intended to keep the Government from another partial shutdown on Saturday.

title: U.S.-British Electronics Merger Is Planned
description: In a trans-Atlantic merger of equals, Farnell Electronics P.L.C. of Leeds, England, and the Premier Industrial Corporation, which is based in Cleveland, announced yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a cash and stock transaction valued at about $2.8 billion.

title: STATE OF THE UNION;Clinton Picks General to Lead War on Drugs
description: In his State of the Union Message tonight, President Clinton announced the nomination of Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, one of the nation's most decorated military commanders, as the new director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy.

title: Hamed Abulnasr, 82, the Leader Of Major Islamic Group in Egypt
description: Hamed Abulnasr, the leader of the Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest and most powerful Islamic fundamentalist group, died in a Cairo hospital on Saturday, the group said. He was 82.

title: A Pointless Conflict in Angola
description: A telling comment on Angola's 20-year civil war was volunteered with a shrug by a former rebel soldier, Bernardo Calindo, age 23. "I have no idea what this war is about," he told Suzanne Daley of The Times. "You will have to ask someone who is older." In truth, nobody can provide a coherent explanation for the persistence of this conflict. Angola bleeds not for reasons of interest or ideology, it would seem, but because of weakness, folly and the bad faith of rival leaders. The world is right to be exasperated with this pointless war.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler-Benz Unit Selling 9 Operations
description: The AEG unit of Daimler-Benz A.G. is selling nine medium-sized businesses with annual sales of 700 million marks ($476 million) to CWB Capital Partners, CWB said yesterday. Management, including some former AEG executives, will take a 25 percent stake in a holding company set up for the purpose, CWB said. No price was disclosed.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Dominate, From the First Shot
description: The Devils started the second half of the season after the All-Star Game break under the most ideal circumstances tonight -- they faced a lowly Los Angeles team and scored a goal on their first shot. They dominated play territorially for most of the game, although they managed only two more goals, the last with 68 seconds left, against an opponent that had trouble putting two passes together.

title: Food Notes
description: Culinary History 101

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti Says '95 Loss Will Exceed Forecasts
description: Olivetti S.p.A. of Italy, Europe's biggest computer company, said yesterday that its loss for 1995 would be a larger-than-expected 1.55 trillion lire ($972 million) because of revamping costs. Those expenses, at 1.05 trillion lire, were 150 billion lire more than had been expected. The company has reduced its work force by 5,000, to 30,200. Not counting the revamping costs, the company lost 500 billion lire, bringing the total loss for the year up to 1.55 trillion.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Salomon Earnings Declined From 3d Quarter to the 4th
description: Salomon Inc., the parent of Salomon Brothers, the beleaguered investment bank, reported a steep decline in profits yesterday from the third to the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Sports of The Times;Curtain Falls On Rivalry We Loved
description: THE signal that the rivalry we knew and loved was ended came long before the proof was in the whipping. Michael Jordan was finishing with the news media mob following the Chicago Bulls' morning shoot-around, when out from behind the blue curtain, into the runway leading to the court, came a smiling, onetime band of Jordan bashers.

title: Whitewater Panel Looks At Clinton-McDougal Ties
description: The Senate Whitewater committee today began a new phase of its inquiry, taking up the relationship more than a decade ago between James B. McDougal, the owner of a troubled Arkansas savings and loan association, and his business partners in the Whitewater real estate deal, Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary.

title: Finalists in Westinghouse High School Science Contest
description: Following are the finalists in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, according to Science Service Inc., publisher of Science News and administrator of the program for the Westinghouse Foundation:

title: Plain and Simple;Zesty Sicilian Vegetable Dish Is a Natural Over Fusilli
description: Mimmetta LoMonte, caterer and former restaurateur, cooks soul-satisfying Sicilian food. In her cookbook "Mimmetta LoMonte's Classic Italian Cooking" (Simon & Schuster, 1990), she offers a vegetable dish of fennel, orange juice and pine nuts. Though the ingredients were not intended to be served over pasta, they seem natural for a sauce. The accompanying dish of green beans with sun-dried tomatoes is quick to make.

title: State of the Campaign
description: The Bill Clinton who ran for President in 1992 showed up in the Capitol last night. As State of the Union addresses go, this one was unusually partisan. It was, in fact, the first stump speech of the Clinton re-election campaign and for that reason is likely to cause consternation among the Republicans and stir some courage among dispirited Democrats.

title: G.O.P. Ballot Ruling: Forbes Goes 9 for 11
description: Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign largely failed today in its first attempt to prove that Steve Forbes had not met the Republican Party's tough rules for earning a spot on the state primary ballot.

title: Familiar Names At Archer-Daniels
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company has reshuffled key board committees to consist of outside directors who include a retired company chairman and the current treasurer's father, surprising some major shareholders.

title: In Louisiana, Church Pews Are Trenches In G.O.P. War
description: It is a Wednesday night, and Patrick J. Buchanan, like a modern-day circuit rider, is making the rounds of midweek services at evangelical churches in southwestern Louisiana. Careering through red lights with the help of a police escort, his campaign van speeds from the First Baptist Church of Moss Bluff to the Victory Worship Center in Sulphur to the Eastwood United Pentacostal Church in Lake Charles.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Case of Multiple Personalities
description: Tracey Ullman is a brilliant performer in search of a breakthrough format. Her new series of 10 half-hour weekly episodes on HBO, "Tracey Takes On. . . .," zanily barrels forward in the right direction. Ms. Ullman is once again the chameleonlike impersonator, slipping in and out of an array of characters with uncanny visual and vocal accuracy. Some bits work better than others, but in terms of pure performance, they are all fascinating.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Cardinals Sign Olson
description: The St. Louis Cardinals added a possible bargain-basement closer yesterday, signing GREGG OLSON to a $600,000 minor league contract. Olson, 28, saved 160 games from 1989 to 1993, but missed most of the last two seasons with a partly torn tendon in his right elbow. Last year, he played for Cleveland and Kansas City, as well as Cleveland's Class AAA affiliate in Buffalo. (AP)

title: Bristol-Myers Reports Loss In 4th Quarter
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company reported yesterday a net loss of $208 million for the last three months of 1995. The loss includes a new after-tax write-off of $590 million for claims by women who say they were injured by breast implants and a $310 million charge for plant closings and reorganizing.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Budget Fight Hurts Price Of Long Bond
description: Prices of long-term Treasury securities dropped again yesterday, as investors fretted over the stalled budget negotiations and faced a large supply of new securities.

title: Personal Health
description: SO you think the allergy season is over? After all, in much of the country, the weeds are dead, trees are bare, and grasses lie dormant under ice and snow. How then do you account for that "cold" that seems to be hanging around for months -- the runny or stuffy nose, sneezing, postnasal drip, irritating cough and itchy throat that don't seem to go away and stay away?

title: INSIDE
description: Warning From China

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Net Up but Texas Instruments Disappoints
description: Texas Instruments reported disappointing earnings today, and then compounded the letdown by forecasting that the entire computer chip industry was facing slower growth and sagging prices.

title: Lincoln Journal;Cathedral Schism Causing High-Church Dudgeon
description: Lincoln Cathedral is a testament to the majesty of medieval faith. It was built on a high hill beginning in 1072 and it is crowned by three honey-colored towers that seem to punch through the sky. Floodlighted at night, the cathedral can be seen across a drab landscape of pylons and highways for 25 miles, and it shimmers like the dome of a celestial city.

title: Refco Settles Commodity-Pool Case by U.S.
description: Refco Inc. has agreed to pay a $925,000 civil fine as part of a settlement of charges that the firm failed to properly segregate funds in five German commodity pools, the Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today.

title: Rebel Radio Operator Exports His Know-How
description: If she bought the parts for a transmitter, the mysterious caller wanted to know, could she use them to build a mobile radio station in the heart of Mexico City?

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;With Lloyd, Brace for a Knockout
description: Avoid Lloyd." That is what banners scream at Pittsburgh Steelers home games. They attempt to warn opponents that Steelers linebacker Greg Lloyd is lurking, panting, a step away from knocking you out. Better block him, better account for him. Every down. Every snap.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;A Perfect Place For the Magic
description: Shaquille O'Neal scored 20 points and Dennis Scott had five 3-pointers tonight as the Orlando Magic stayed unbeaten at home with a 105-90 rout of the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Showdown: Bulls Are the Show, Knicks the Down
description: The move was not surprising, if only because the player executing it had so many more dazzling ones on his resume.

title: S.E.C. Deal Seen in Orange County Inquiry
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to announce a deal on Wednesday that could end its yearlong inquiry into the role of Orange County in its investment crisis, people close to the matter said today.

title: Agency Tackled Complaints on Lack of Heat
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE OF THE UNION: THE ASSESSMENT;Talking Like a Front-Runner
description: President Clinton gave a front-runner's speech tonight, the speech of a candidate confident that he is ahead.

title: Shuttling Through the Night: The Overnighters' Odyssey;Homeless People Living Between Shelter Visits
description: It was another muttering, fatigue-fogged midnight in the sour-aired waiting room of the homeless shelter at Bellevue Hospital. Fifty men in dingy parkas slumped awkwardly on chairs, staring or snoring, the murmur broken every few minutes by the blare of a bus announcement.

title: Chancellor Fights Pataki On Cutbacks For Schools
description: In testimony before state legislators today, New York City's Schools Chancellor, Dr. Rudy Crew, harshly criticized Gov. George E. Pataki's proposed budget, warning that cuts in education spending would damage an already fragile system.

title: TENNIS;Rubin Puts Vicario Out in 3:33 Marathon
description: Come on someone!"

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Ron Harper's Legs Show Lots of Life
description: Once upon a time, like about a year ago, the word on Ron Harper was that he had lost his legs. This isn't quite as tragic as it might read, since in basketball argot this simply meant that Harper didn't have the old-time spring in his legs, that the old wheels didn't revolve with the alacrity they once did.

title: Chilean Politicians Urge Pinochet to Resign
description: Politicians from Chile's ruling coalition called today for the former dictator Augusto Pinochet to resign as army chief after a former secret service agent was arrested for the murder of an exiled general.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Low Inventory of Natural Gas Causes Prices to Surge by 15%
description: Futures prices for natural gas soared 15 percent yesterday on concerns that inventories were uncomfortably low with two months of winter demand still to come.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;The Cowboys Just Kick Back and Enjoy the Ride
description: They will do no manual labor until Super Bowl Sunday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRADING IN HELENE CURTIS FUELS DEAL RUMORS
description: Heavy trading in the shares of Helene Curtis Industries Inc. convinced some arbitragers yesterday that a deal for the company was likely. Curtis shares rose $8.25, or 18 percent, to close at $53.125, on New York Stock Exchange volume of 482,700 shares. The stock has risen 74 percent since its Jan. 10 close of $30.50. The exchange asked the company to issue a statement about any corporate development that might explain the stock activity, but the company declined to comment. Curtis, which is based in Chicago, makes Suave shampoos and Degree antiperspirants. Shamrock Holdings had asked Curtis last week to sell itself or alter its stock structure.

title: A Blizzard of Eggs
description: To The Living Section:

title: COMPANY NEWS;KAUFMAN & BROAD AGREES TO ACQUIRE RAYCO
description: The Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, the largest home builder in the West, signed a definitive agreement yesterday to acquire Rayco Ltd. in a deal valued at $110 million in cash and debt assumption. The acquisition includes the title, mortgage and brokerage affiliates of Rayco, a privately held home builder with a 45 percent market share in San Antonio and annual revenue of $235 million. Kaufman, which is based in Los Angeles, has 13 operating divisions, in California, Arizona, Nevada, New Mexico, Colorado and Utah.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EINSTEIN BROS. TO BUY NOAH'S BAGEL STORES
description: Einstein Bros. Bagels Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Noah's New York Bagels Inc., a fast-growing West Coast bagel retailer in which the Starbucks Corporation has a 20 percent stake, for about $100 million in cash and stock. The deal is part of a plan by Einstein, a privately held company in Golden, Colo., to continue its growth. The acquisition would raise Einstein's network to more than 100 bagel stores in 10 states. The purchase is to be partly financed by an existing $80 million loan from the restaurant chain Boston Chicken Inc., and that company has also agreed to provide a new $40 million loan for development of both bagel chains.

title: Yeltsin at Bay
description: His health is shaky, his popularity and public credibility are in free fall, and his Communist opponents have never been stronger. President Boris N. Yeltsin, 65, says he will probably run for re-election next June.

title: On the Inside Track in the $1 Million Pillsbury Bake-Off
description: THEY call themselves the Pillsbury mafia. They are five friends and relatives who in total have been finalists 10 times in the Pillsbury Bake-Off in the last 22 years and have taken home assorted stoves, can openers, mixers, knife sets, beach towels, oven mitts and some cash, but never a big prize. When you include their immediate families, the figure rises to 17.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Tax Evasion Admitted
description: A former president of the New Jersey Association of Public Accountants admitted yesterday in Federal court that he failed to declare $67,000 in income on his tax returns from 1990 through 1992. Philip M. Shore, 49, of Midland Park, said that he sometimes put money in safe deposit boxes after clients paid him. Officials say he owes $21,000 in taxes on the unreported income.

title: Eating Well
description: ONCE or twice a year this column answers questions raised by readers. Recently, the mail has focused on two Eating Well columns: one on the safety of tofu; the other on pesticides in fruits and vegetables. A third subject that generated mail involves fat -- the macronutrient on almost everyone's mind.

title: David J. O'Connell, TV Producer, 79
description: David J. O'Connell, a television producer who won an Emmy award for "Marcus Welby, M.D." and made one of the first miniseries, died on Jan. 16. He was 79.

title: Incomes Rose Only Slightly In November
description: Personal incomes edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the Commerce Department said today, providing another sign that the economy was slowing.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Prospects Line Up for House
description: A battle is shaping up in the Democratic Party for the Congressional seat being vacated by Robert Torricelli, who is running for the Senate.

title: Where There's Smoke, There May Be a Turkey
description: WHEN Barbara Kafka appeared on "Good Morning America" last Thanksgiving Day, she managed to cook a 12-pound turkey in less than two hours that was pronounced "absolutely delicious" by the show's hosts.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Digital Reports Large Increase In Net Income
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported a more than sevenfold increase in its fiscal second-quarter earnings today on growth in the company's core large-computer and personal-computer businesses and strong demand for its Alpha chips.

title: U. of California Postpones Shift In Policy on Affirmative Action
description: In what proponents of affirmative action hailed as a sign that the University of California may reconsider its ban on the use of race and sex to select students, university officials said today that they would delay starting the new policy by one year.

title: Reported Beatings of Inmates Prompt Changes at Rikers Unit
description: Acknowledging that there was strong evidence of brutality by city correction officers against inmates, city officials said yesterday that they were making changes in the Rikers Island punitive segregation area where inmates are said to have been beaten.

title: Journal;Calling Ralph Bellamy
description: If this were the 1930's, Steve Forbes, a zillionaire's bespectacled son with a passion for numbers, would be played by Ralph Bellamy and would lose the girl to Cary Grant. But this being the madcap 1990's, we are asked to believe that Mr. Forbes is successfully wooing the country. This week he's starring on the covers of both Time and Newsweek. How long before he's standing before Congress, orating on the State of the Union?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Indiana Upends Michigan

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;In Woodson's World, Steelers Come First
description: It is a problem only to Rod Woodson.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: THE RESPONSE;Dole Says President Defends Old Elites Seeking Largesse
description: Delivering the Republican response to President Clinton's State of the Union Message, Senator Bob Dole tried tonight to take from the President the mantle of "change," deriding Mr. Clinton as an elitist and "almost the last public defender of a discredited status quo."

title: Japanese Stocks Increase
description: Japanese stocks rose here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 231.82 points, or 1.15 percent, at 20,312.74. On Tuesday, the Nikkei lost 115.61 points.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's subpoena to appear before a Federal grand jury referred incorrectly to the past Government service of the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr. While Mr. Starr served as Solicitor General in the Bush Administration, he was not in the Reagan Administration.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JANE SELL TRESE, a Tony Award-winning actress, has a starring role on Broadway every Tuesday, but she's not giving up her day job as an executive assistant in a multinational advertising agency yet.

title: Hartford Plans to End the Private Management of Its Public Schools
description: Hartford school officials said today that they intended to end the nation's largest experiment in private management of public schools, leaving the contractor, Education Alternatives Inc., once the leader in private management, with no contracts in public school systems.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Parties Gain From Lobbies
description: Both political parties got big money from the tobacco industry and police unions in the last quarter of 1995, when the Legislature was debating cigarette taxes and police contracts.

title: Taiwan Competes With China to Win African Hearts
description: At the height of cold-war intrigue in Africa between the superpowers, Ethiopia and Somalia switched allegiances almost overnight in 1977, in a stunning realignment of the continent's strategic checkerboard.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONE MILLS EXPECTS LOSS IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: The Cone Mills Corporation, a textile maker, said yesterday that it expected a fourth-quarter loss of about 50 cents a share, mostly from accounting measures related to a drop in the value of certain stock holdings. Cone Mills, based in Greensboro, N.C., earned $7.3 million, or 24 cents a share, on sales of $205.1 million for the fourth quarter that ended on Jan. 1, 1995. Cone Mills said the charges were primarily related to write-downs of its equity interest and disposal of a portion of its ownership in Compania Industrial de Parras S.A., of Mexico. Cone Mills said that excluding the charges, it expected a loss of a few cents a share because of continued weaknesses in specialty sportswear and decorative-print fabric markets. The company also plans to take write-downs associated with the relocation of its headquarters and other efforts to modernize the company.

title: FILM REVIEW;An Iranian Tale of a Girl and Her Goldfish
description: The White Balloon" was shown as part of the 1995 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29. The film opens today at the Lincoln Plaza @inemas, Broadway at 63d Street.

title: Human Genome Plans Corn Venture
description: Human Genome Sciences Inc. said today that it would collaborate with Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. to discover the properties of corn genes.

title: Joseph S. Bruno, 83; Built Grocery Chain
