description: Joseph S. Bruno, who built a tiny downtown grocery store into a large grocery and pharmacy chain that included the Piggly Wiggly and Food Fair supermarkets, died on Sunday. He was 83 and lived in Birmingham.

title: Peru Applied Law In Case of American
description: To the Editor:

title: Threat to Press Freedom Seen in Kenya
description: The Government is moving to enact two laws that journalists here say would muzzle independent newspapers during the year preceding the next election, early next year.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Declares That 'Era Of Big Government Is Over' In his State of the Union address, the President offered his ideas of limited government to compete with the Republican vision, but said "we cannot go back to the time when our citizens were left to fend for themselves." He added, "I am convinced we will balance the budget and make permanent deficits yesterday's legacy." [Page A1.]

title: Hello, Dolly!' to Close
description: Hello, Dolly!," a revival of the 1964 musical with book by Michael Stewart and music and lyrics by Jerry Herman, directed by Lee Roy Reams and starring Carol Channing, is to end its limited engagement after the matinee on Sunday at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, Manhattan. The show will have had 118 regular performances and 8 previews.

title: As China Threatens Taiwan, It Makes Sure U.S. Listens
description: The Chinese leadership has sent unusually explicit warnings to the Clinton Administration that China has completed plans for a limited attack on Taiwan that could be mounted in the weeks after Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, wins the first democratic balloting for the presidency in March.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Fighting Over the New Talent at Sundance
description: One of the more enthusiastically receiped pieces of film here is the quick trailer that introduces each feature-film program. Made as a class project by students at the Pasadena Art College of Design, it shows assembly-line workers cranking out film cans, then labeling one and loading it onto a truck. "Where do they take it?" asks one grungy, bored-looking worker. "Utah!" exclaims another in disbelief.

title: Eye for Stars Turns Into Knack for Astronomy, Westinghouse Awards Show
description: For the first decade of Naomi Sue Bates's life, her family lived, by choice, without electricity and running water in a sturdy old house made of squared logs, tucked high on McComas Ridge in West Virginia. But foresaking modern conveniences and scraping by on a $10,000 income, in a good year, did not mean that the Bateses were unaffected by their surroundings.

title: FEARING ATTACK, U.S. IS TIGHTENING BOSNIA SECURITY
description: American forces in Bosnia have heightened security after intelligence reports suggested that militant Muslim groups were planning attacks against American targets in Bosnia.

title: I.B.M. Is Freed From Old Curbs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has been freed from most 40-year-old restrictions on its ability to compete for computer services and related businesses after a Federal judge agreed to change a 1956 antitrust settlement with the Justice Department, the company announced yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Flyers Trade for Quinn
description: The Ottawa Senators traded center DAN QUINN to the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday for future considerations. He was the Senators' second-leading scorer when he was let go with little explanation on New Year's Eve. After clearing waivers, Quinn was loaned to the International Hockey League's Detroit Vipers. (AP)

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;The Film at the Root of the Outcry Over Orphans
description: It is impossible not to be moved by the pictures of sickly children in "The Dying Rooms," but quite possible to withhold a judgment that the Chinese authorities are allowing orphans to die as a matter of national policy. That is not an expression of faith in the beneficence of China's rulers, just an acknowledgment of a want of solid information.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Granada Says Bid for Forte Is Successful
description: Granada Group P.L.C. said today that it had gained control of Forte P.L.C. after institutional investors lined up in support of the company's L3.9 billion ($5.9 billion) hostile takeover offer.

title: Corrections
description: A review in Weekend on Jan. 5 about "Craft in the Machine Age: 1920-1945" at the American Craft Museum in Manhattan misidentified the tribe of two Southwest American Indian potters, Maria and Julian Martinez. They were Pueblos from the San Ildefonso Pueblo in New Mexico, not Navajos.

title: Bahrain Seizes More Protesters After Sabotage
description: Bahrain said today that it had arrested more people as part of extensive measures to dismantle "a subversive organization" that was behind anti-Government protests and acts of sabotage.

title: STATE OF THE UNION: THE OVERVIEW;CLINTON OFFERS CHALLENGE TO NATION, DECLARING, 'ERA OF BIG GOVERNMENT IS OVER'
description: Offering his own idea of limited government to compete with the Republican vision, President Clinton tonight challenged the nation to provide enough educational opportunities, economic security and freedom from crime to allow Americans to make the most of an "age of possibility."

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Avedon, From Paris Fashion to Haiku
description: Trumpeting a combination of exclusivity and intimacy, "American Masters" celebrates its 10th anniversary on PBS tonight with "Richard Avedon: Darkness and Light." It is not entirely clear what Helen Whitney, the director, producer and writer, seeks to achieve in this portrait of the famous photographer. He is celebrated lustily, of course, for his work in fashion. But his claims to being a serious artist, especially in his portraits with the signature white backgrounds, are given a more ambiguous spin as carping is heard in the background.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Executive Departure At Houston Effler
description: Don Effler, a co-founder and top executive at Houston Effler Herstek Favat in Boston and a partner in the agency company Houston Effler Inc., has abruptly left both, effective immediately.

title: Sharpe Plans a Comeback
description: Sterling Sharpe, the former Green Bay receiver who was forced to retire because of a neck injury, says he will try to play again, maybe as early as next season.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Fierce Rebel Who Prefigures Mao
description: GOD'S CHINESE SON The Taiping Heavenly Kingdom of Hong Xiuquan By Jonathan D. Spence 400 pages. W.W. Norton. $27.50

title: Business Travel;Uruguay is becoming a hot spot -- at least hot enough to support daily flights from New York.
description: AS the air wars over South America continue to escalate, business travelers are being rewarded with a wide selection of flights. Beginning Feb. 5, for example, United Airlines will add Thursday and Saturday flights from Kennedy International Airport in New York to Montevideo, Uruguay, giving the carrier one flight every day.

title: Sex Offender Wins Delay In Notification Of Community
description: In a ruling that highlights the conflicting judicial opinions on the constitutionality of New Jersey's "Megan's Law," a Federal judge has temporarily barred authorities from notifying schools and other institutions that a man now living in Englewood pleaded guilty two decades ago to molesting and killing two boys.

title: More Rain Is Expected in Flooded Region
description: Federal inspectors toured flooded regions yesterday, trying to affix dollar figures to the wreckage caused by melting snow and runaway rivers, and weather forecasters said fresh rain could hamper recovery.

title: A Date in the Kitchen
description: To The Living Section:

title: Foreign Affairs;The Next Rwanda
description: Flying into Burundi you cross the calm waters of Lake Tanganyika and the lush, verdant hillsides of Eastern Zaire. You drive into the capital, Bujumbura, and it looks to be a charming little lakefront town, where longhorn cattle mingle amid the traffic and the banana trees. Your first stop is the Prime Minister's office, where America's U.N. representative, Madeleine Albright, is delivering a message. The first thing you notice about the buildings is that they have all their windows -- a vast improvement over Liberia. The air is clear. The city is quiet. And then a young Burundian official waiting outside the Prime Ministry pierces your mirage. "We are all buying guns," she says softly. "We are living hour by hour here."

title: STATE OF THE UNION: THE SCENE -- CAPITOL SKETCHBOOK;First Lady Finds Herself Center Stage in a Subplot
description: Her physical presence was like a metaphor," said Representative Peter T. King, describing the intriguing political tableau provided by Hillary Rodham Clinton tonight as she listened in the front row of the House gallery to her husband's State of the Union Message. She seemed to smile with care, as if not exactly enchanted by her life in the capital city.

title: Correction: Saltimbocca
description: A recipe in the Plain and Simple column on Jan. 10 about an inexpensive saltimbocca made with chicken, instead of veal, omitted olive oil from the list of ingredients and from the nutritional analysis. Here is a corrected version:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NYNEX CORP. (NYN,N)
description: The Nynex Corporation reported yesterday that its profit jumped 19 percent in the fourth quarter because of an increased number of customers and more telephone calls.

title: Executive Changes
description: LOJACK CORP., Dedham, Mass., named Joseph F. Abely 2d, formerly senior vice president and chief financial officer, to the new position of chief operating officer and also to the position of president, succeeding C. Michael Daley, who continues as chief executive.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;$1.8 Million Jackpot Winner
description: A town clerk from upstate New York won $1.8 million at a slot machine, the biggest payoff ever on a 25-cent machine in Atlantic City. The A.P. said Nancy Reff, 55, of Ovid, N.Y., had played $20 worth of quarters on Monday when she hit the jackpot. SUSAN JO KELLER

title: Congress of Quitters
description: During a bitter exchange on the Senate floor in April 1850, Henry Foote of Mississippi drew a pistol and advanced on Thomas Hart Benton of Missouri. Senator Benton stood up, allegedly pulled open his shirt and cried out, "Let the assassin fire!" Cooler heads wrestled the gun from Senator Foote's hands and order was restored.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;CBS Executive Chosen to Head NBC's All-News Cable Channel
description: NBC yesterday appointed Mark Harrington, a longtime CBS executive, to be vice president and general manager of its new all-news cable network, currently called MSNBC.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Rookie Prefers a Place In the Distant Spotlight
description: As the Steelers' first-round draft pick, Mark Bruener found himself at the center of attention when Pittsburgh went to training camp last summer.

title: Seoul Indicts An Ex-Leader For Massacre In the 1980's
description: South Korean prosecutors indicted former President Chun Doo Hwan today for overseeing the massacre of hundreds of pro-democracy demonstrators in 1980, an incident that has haunted South Korea and that now has more resonance than ever throughout Asia.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Auto Racing KODIAK RACING -- Announced the resignation of Waddell Wilson, general manager of the Larry Hedrick Motorsports Team.

title: The Reality of Palestine
description: The Palestinian voice has been muffled since the beginning of the Arab-Jewish conflict, and for more than 100 years the Palestinians have never been given the right to speak out for themselves. Their national identity has been negotiated between different parties to the conflict and rendered a moot question at best.

title: Critics Say Managed-Care Savings Are Eroding Mental Care
description: NIGHT after night in Laura McRae's feverish nightmares she would be chased and beaten; she would startle awake, her heart pounding, awash in cold sweat and terror. Days were filled with anxiety as vivid flashbacks of beatings by her former husband would suddenly flood her with fear.

title: On the Environment, Pataki Is Seen in All Shades of Green
description: Last Wednesday morning, Gov. George E. Pataki was warmly praised by environmental groups for resolving a bitter dispute over logging in the Adirondack Park. "The Governor has found the middle ground between protecting the critical resources of the park and the legitimate needs of landowners," Sarah Meyland, president of a private environmental group, said.

title: Former Lotus Chief to Lead Business Service on the Internet
description: Jim P. Manzi, the fiery former chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, has been named president and chief executive at Industry.Net, a little-known, privately held Internet company based in Pittsburgh. Mr. Manzi acknowledged that he had also made a "significant" investment in Industry.Net, an investment that makes him one of the company's major shareholders.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Tomorrows That Failed
description: IN Moscow in 1898, Konstantin Tsiolkovsky, a deaf, 41-year-old mathematics teacher, sat alone in his crowded workshop after class and dreamed up a "reaction machine." It was a giant, bullet-shaped tube that he believed could be powered by liquid fuel and could blast humans into the heavens.

title: J. Moe Newman, Clothing Chain Founder, 87
description: J. Moe Newman, co-founder of a New York clothing chain that at its peak had some 150 outlets nationwide, died on Jan. 13 at his home on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was 87.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Camby Watches on the Bench As Minutemen Give Their All
description: In the din of stuffed Fitzgerald Field House, with the best player on the top-ranked team watching from the bench, Coach John Calipari yelled at his Massachusetts Minutemen. This was no time for the return of Marcus Camby, not in a hot, hostile environment and the Minutemen down by 12 from the start. Not with Camby absent from any hard practices since his still-unexplained collapse nine days ago. The others would have to do all the heavy lifting, and Calipari was there to scold, to beg, to remind them what it would take.

title: Bring Extraterrestrial Musings Down to Earth
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon Aides Tried to Manipulate Nonpartisan Nationwide Polls
description: White House memorandums in the National Archives show that aides to former President Richard M. Nixon tried to obtain the results of independent polls conducted by George Gallup Jr. and Louis Harris before they were published to exploit favorable data and occasionally to squelch negative findings.

title: Currents;Love Your Furniture. How Much for The Table?
description: KATHY SHORR doesn't so much work from home as she lives in her shop.

title: Investment by Vitro
description: The glass maker Vitro S.A. of Mexico will invest $126 million in the next two years in its United States unit, the Anchor Glass Container Corporation, to upgrade machinery and improve profit margins, according to Anchor's new chief executive, Alfonso Gomez Palacio. Anchor's antiquated machinery has concerned analysts and investors who have wondered how well the company can fare in a weak bottle-making market.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EVELYN HALPERT, the head of the Brearley School, the private girls' school on the Upper East Side, has announced that she will step down in June 1997.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;J.& J.'s Profit Was Up 23% In 4th Quarter
description: Johnson & Johnson said today that earnings rose 23 percent in the fourth quarter -- more than expected -- lifted by strong sales of new drugs and medical devices.

title: Islamic Extremism Is Not One Large Entity
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties;Letters From the Edge
description: Jealous of the attention the special prosecutor is getting by subpoenaing Hillary Rodham Clinton to testify before a Federal grand jury, Al D'Amato tries to grab back the spotlight by accepting Mrs. Clinton's offer to answer questions from the Whitewater Committee in writing.

title: Currents;Ultimate In Kitchen Glamour
description: IF Martha Stewart and the handbag artist Judith Leiber were shipwrecked on a desert island, this might be a result: an entirely beaded kitchen.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Fazio Replaces Dungy
description: The Minnesota Vikings named FOGE FAZIO as defensive coordinator yesterday, two days after TONY DUNGY left to become coach of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Fazio, 56, coached inside linebackers for the Vikings this season, his first season in Minnesota after five with the Jets. Fazio also spent nine years at the University of Pittsburgh, five as defensive coordinator and four as head coach. (AP)

title: Schools Chief Calls for Loftier Standards
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew pledged yesterday to devise an ambitious new set of standards for students in New York City's public high schools, prodding them to attain fluency in a foreign language, mastery of higher mathematics and the ability to communicate in a "sophisticated" way.

title: G.O.P. LAWMAKERS OFFER TO ABANDON DEBT-LIMIT THREAT
description: Congressional Republicans said today that they would abandon the national debt as a weapon against President Clinton if he would support modest budget and tax cuts as a "down payment" on a balanced budget.

title: Garden Q. and A.
description: Plant Societies

title: On How to Suffer, and the Reasons
description: ''The more death you see, the more you want to live," declares Irena Lillien (Beata Fudalej), a feisty young Jewish woman fleeing the Nazis in Andrzej Wajda's powerful new film, "Holy Week." Hostile to her protectors in a suburban Warsaw apartment house where she refuses to remain discreetly out of sight, the character is one of the more unsympathetic Holocaust victims to be portrayed in a movie. Irena has no use for the notion that wisdom is acquired through suffering. "Suffering makes you a worse person, a much worse person," she says with an edge of bitter self-awareness.

title: Rescuing the Schools
description: Rudy Crew's first statement of goals as New York City's Schools Chancellor was both grim and hopeful. Addressing the Board of Education, Dr. Crew painted a dismal but accurate portrait of a system that expects many children to fail and delivers that message by poor teaching and by letting the schools collapse physically around the children's heads. At the same time, he offered several systemwide initiatives that he hopes will reverse the pattern of failure and give the city's 1.1 million schoolchildren a chance.

title: Imperial Congress Threatens Health of Union
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Willing to Give Food Aid to North Korea
description: The United States said today that it was ready to give food aid to North Korea, in concert with Japan and South Korea, as the United Nations reported a worsening threat of famine.

title: Stocks Jump to Yet Another High, Led by Technology Issues
description: Stocks jumped broadly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average setting another new record. Technology shares were stars of the market.

title: Alfred S. Evans, 78, Expert On Origins of Mononucleosis
description: Dr. Alfred S. Evans, an emeritus professor of epidemiology at the Yale University School of Medicine who investigated the role of the Epstein-Barr virus in infectious mononucleosis and other diseases, died on Sunday at his home in North Branford, Conn. He was 78.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: IN PERFORMANCE: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Voice at Home In Bel Canto Stuart Neill, tenor Alice Tully Hall

title: Ex-Employees of Travel Office Say Rumors Led to Their Ouster
description: Seven White House travel office employees who were dismissed from their jobs in 1993 told a House panel today that top Clinton aides used unconfirmed rumors of mismanagement as a pretext to replace them with friends and relatives of the President.

title: Francis Connelly, 54, Educator And the Dean of Baruch College
description: Francis J. (Bud) Connelly, a distinguished business educator who for 14 years was the dean of Baruch College, the business school of the City University of New York, died on Friday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 54, and lived in Annandale, Va.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;$200 Million Is Set for Jobs
description: On the heels of recent reports of weakness in the state's job and housing markets, a state official said yesterday that she would speed the release of $200 million to "prime the pump and create jobs in the housing market."

title: Polish Premier, Ex-Communist Accused of Spying, Resigns
description: In one of Poland's most significant political moments since the fall of Communism, Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy announced his resignation in a televised speech tonight, declaring he was innocent of allegations that he had spied for Moscow for more than a decade.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Whitman Sets Budget Stage
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman told a group of mayors yesterday that it was too soon to relax efforts to make government "smarter and leaner."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;98 More Than Enough
description: After failing to turn around a Rutgers-Camden (N.J.) team that has lost 98 straight games since the 1991-92 season, WILBUR (PONY) WILSON stepped down as head coach yesterday, citing health reasons.

title: Company Plans to Leave Hartford Schools
description: A day after being informed its services were no longer wanted, a company helping to manage Hartford's public schools said it would pull out Jan. 31 unless the city met its demands.

title: New Flexibility By Iraq on Oil Worries Market
description: After a five-year standoff, Iraq's willingness to hold talks with the United Nations about selling oil for the purchase of food has raised prospects for an accord this year. But it could also provoke a sustained decline in oil prices, industry executives and analysts said today.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Indiana Bank Acquisition
description: The First Merchants Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire Union National Bancorp of Liberty, Ind., for $25 million in stock. First Merchants is a bank holding company based here. The deal, which has been approved by both companies' boards, is expected to be completed by the middle of the year.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Eerie Orgy With Music To Match
description: Last year at La Mama, three German performers -- Achim Gieseler, a composer and keyboardist; Michael Altmann, an actor, and Thilo Krigar, a cellist -- presented a radical interpretation of Schubert's "Winterreise" that transformed the work into a barked-out Brechtian theater piece. These compelling artists have returned to present "The Dead Man," an erotic narration by the French philosopher and novelist Georges Bataille that turns the text into an hourlong chamber work for narrator, keyboards and cello. La Mama is a hospitable place to try out such genre-blurring experiments.

title: Cabbies Protest Plan Requiring New Cars More Often
description: With New York City's taxi agency expected to approve a 20 percent fare increase today, many cabbies are complaining that the proposal is a bad deal for them because the new rules will also require them to replace their cabs more often.

title: Newark Hires Company to Tutor Classes
description: Newark's state-operated school district signed a contract today with a private education company to teach remedial math and reading classes in three public high schools.

title: Economic Scene;Washington may tighten up on reporting of fees by trial lawyers.
description: EVERY interest payment, stock sale and royalty payment these days generates a notice to the Internal Revenue Service. But when a lawyer receives a settlement on behalf of a client and keeps a big part of it as his fee, the I.R.S. learns about the money only if the lawyer includes it on his tax form.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Salomon Inc.'s financial results misstated the performance of Phibro, the company's commodities unit. Phibro's pretax earnings in 1995 increased almost 5 percent; they did not decline.

title: Clinton Wins Praise For Talk on Values
description: In kitchens, coffee shops and nursing homes across the nation, people watched as President Clinton delivered his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, and many found that they liked what they heard, especially when Mr. Clinton talked about education and cultural values.

title: Giuliani Weighs Reducing Police Force by 1,000 Jobs
description: The Giuliani administration is considering reducing the size of New York City's police force by almost 1,000 officers, from almost 38,000 now, to help close a widening gap in the city's budget, senior officials said yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Riley's Brand of Basketball Works for Knicks
description: Pat Riley has always known the formula: Great big man equals great rewards on the court. Having been fortunate enough to have had Patrick Ewing on his roster for four seasons, Riley went out and acquired Alonzo Mourning in one of his first moves as the Miami Heat's coach.

title: HOCKEY;A Hat Trick for Hatcher
description: Defenseman Kevin Hatcher's third goal of the night snapped a tie and lifted the Dallas Stars to a 5-3 victory over the Edmonton Oilers tonight.

title: Extend the Whitewater Committee
description: One might reasonably expect the Senate Whitewater committee to finish its business by Feb. 29, when its mandate expires. But at a time when important documents keep popping up unexpectedly and witnesses keep contradicting one another and themselves, the chairman, Alfonse D'Amato, is right to seek an extension. There are clear political reasons for Republicans to prolong their inquiry, but given the White House's failure to address many unanswered questions, there is also a strong public interest in keeping the committee alive.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHONE CENTERS TO CLOSE, COSTING ABOUT 2,500 JOBS
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close its 338 Phone Center retail stores next month, cutting about 2,500 jobs, as part of its preparation for splitting into three companies. The company said it would rely on other retailers to sell its telephones, answering machines and related products. AT&T said it would continue to honor warranties and service claims from customers of the Phone Centers. People who lease phones from AT&T will be able to work with independent service agents. The job cuts at the Phone Centers are part of the company's overall reduction of about 40,000 of its 300,000 jobs.

title: A Little Museum That Could
description: THE exhibition space glows like a many-sided Chinese lantern, beckoning visitors inside. There, in poignant tableaux of objects -- some lovingly preserved, others salvaged from Dumpsters and abandoned apartments -- is the stuff of life. Specifically, of Chinese lives in North and South America over the last century and a half.

title: Computer Idea Gets Mixed Response
description: It seemed like motherhood and apple pie for the Microsoft era: a proposal to put a computer linked to the Internet in every American classroom by the year 2000.

title: Bridge
description: The first major event of the year, the Volmac World Top tournament ended Sunday in The Hague and was truly international. The 16 pairs came from 12 countries, with the winners coming from Norway.

title: House Democrats Buoyed, But G.O.P. Retains an Edge
description: The battle for control of the House of Representatives begins with the Democrats showing surprising strength in the polls, making their chances of regaining a majority look far better than they did six months ago. But many analysts say the Republicans still have the advantage in raising money, recruiting candidates and the shape of the political map.

title: Brookhaven Journal;Author Is Back in Court, And Town Is Starstruck
description: As courtroom drama, it was hardly the stuff of a John Grisham page-turner. The testimony was leadened with talk of boxcar couplings, railroad switching operations and actuarial estimates on the value of a lost life.

title: SUPER BOWL;Most Black Players Find Switzer Easy to Relate To
description: When Barry Switzer became the Dallas Cowboys' coach two years ago, he began to meet with the players left over from the Jimmy Johnson era. Safety Darren Woodson had heard about this swaggering coach from the University of Oklahoma and he was cautious, to say the least.

title: Executive Changes
description: GOOD GUYS INC., Brisbane, Calif., said its founder, Ronald Unkefer, who stepped down as chief executive three years ago, had resigned as chairman. A successor has not been named.

title: 2 in Lucchese Gang Accused of 'Mob Hit'
description: On a bright May morning in 1990, James D. Bishop, a Democratic district leader and former head of the painters' union, was backing his Lincoln sedan into a parking spot in Whitestone, Queens, when a barrage of bullets ended his life.

title: In Japan, a Ritual of Mourning for Abortions
description: Winding her way among thousands of tiny statuettes in an ancient hillside temple, Yuka Sugimoto finds the one she is seeking and lingers in contemplation of the secret, haunting act that brought her here.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Youth Had Gun, Police Say
description: The teen-ager shot to death by a narcotics detective on Tuesday night in Newark's West Ward had pointed a gun at two officers, officials said yesterday.

title: AT HOME WITH: Jamaica Kincaid;Dark Words, Light Being
description: IT was your average fabulous literary cocktail party, full of floating kisses and dropping names.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP. (UTX,N)
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, exceeding analyst estimates, as profit improved at its big Pratt & Whitney aircraft-engine unit.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Motivation and Enthusiasm Make Woman a Star Worker
description: She is neither a restaurant reviewer nor a rock star, but in Joanna Matcham's mind, she has a dream job. Ms. Matcham, 43, is a grocery bagger for a Brooklyn supermarket, a job she so enjoys that she recently asked her manager for longer hours.

title: Pairgain Sues Brokerage Firm
description: Pairgain Technologies Inc. said today that it had filed a lawsuit against the Capital Insight brokerage firm and its president, Jay Goldinger, contending they engaged in unauthorized trading and violated Federal securities laws.

title: SUPER BOWL;Troy Aikman Asks, 'Is That All There Is?'
description: He owns no his-and-her towels.

title: Japan's Plans in Space
description: Japan, indicating that it was ready to go into space alone, today outlined an ambitious space exploration program, including helping to put a huge telescope on the Moon.

title: Guilty Plea In Episcopal Theft Case
description: In the latest chapter of a scandal that has rocked the Episcopal Church, the institution's former national treasurer pleaded guilty today to embezzling more than $1.5 million from church accounts and failing to pay Federal income taxes on some of the money.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;French Company Gets Approval for Aid
description: Comptoir des Entrepreneurs, a French real estate financing company, won European Commission approval yesterday for an estimated 15.2 billion French francs ($3.1 billion) of Government aid. "The aid was approved in exchange for drastic restructuring at Comptoir," the commission said in a statement.

title: Essay;'Notorious Defaulter'
description: Toward the end of his second term, George Washington tired of press criticism -- exploded in a letter to Thomas Jefferson: "I had no conception . . . that every act of my administration would be tortured . . . in such exaggerated form and indecent terms as could scarcely be applied to a Nero, a notorious defaulter or even a common pickpocket."

title: Legislature Sends Pataki Bill on Police Arbitration
description: The State Legislature today gave overwhelming approval to a bill that would change the way New York City resolves contract disputes with its police and fire unions, passing the hotly contested issue to Gov. George E. Pataki for a final decision.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Key Rate Is Cut By the Bundesbank
description: Germany's central bank sanctioned a large cut in its key money market rate yesterday. The Bundesbank said it had allocated securities repurchase funds at a lowest accepted rate of 3.55 percent, down from last week's lowest rate of 3.65 percent. Dealers said the decision to cut a tenth of percentage point off the "repo" rate underscored the central bank's intentions to continue fine-tuning policy.

title: STOCK RISES ON WORD OF TALKS ABOUT POSSIBLE MERGER
description: Helene Curtis Industries said yesterday that it was in talks with one or more undisclosed parties about a possible merger. The stock of Helene Curtis, which makes personal-care products, has risen sharply in recent days. Last week Shamrock Holdings Inc., which holds a 7.6 percent stake in Helene Curtis, urged the company to seek a buyer. After the acknowledgment of merger talks, the company's shares jumped $12.75 yesterday, to $65.875, more than double the closing price of $30.375 on Jan. 11. Helene Curtis, which is based in Chicago, has said it is considering a proposal by Shamrock Holdings to drop its dual-class stock structure. Under that arrangement, the family of the president and chief executive, Ronald J. Gidwitz, has more than 80 percent voting control of Helene Curtis, even though the family's equity stake is about 30 percent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAUSCH & LOMB POSTS LOSS FOR 4TH QUARTER
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. posted a loss of $3.36 million for the fourth quarter yesterday after setting aside $25.4 million to cover the costs of layoffs, litigation and a retirement package for the departing chief executive, Daniel E. Gill. The company, which makes optical and health care products, also announced that it was restating its financial results for 1993 and 1994. For more than a year, the Securities and Exchange Commission has been investigating accounting practices in the company's contact-lens division. In late 1993, Bausch & Lomb, which is based in Rochester, oversupplied distributors with contact lenses and sunglasses through aggressive marketing, and it was forced to buy back much of the inventory, reduce production and cut jobs. The restatement of results will reduce revenues and earnings from contact lenses and sunglasses for 1993. Results for 1994 will be increased by a corresponding amount.

title: COLLEGE HOCKEY REPORT
description: ECAC Women

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Trammell Will Be Back
description: ALAN TRAMMELL has put an end to the retirement talk. The shortstop said yesterday that he would return for his 20th season with the Detroit Tigers, as a utility infielder.

title: SKIING;Ski Area Cracks Down on Smoking
description: Visiting a ski resort might make a nice vacation for Mr. Butts, the tobacco industry caricature created by the "Doonesbury" cartoonist, Garry Trudeau. Mr. Butts would very likely feel right at home in a setting where his skinny, white torso schusses down slopes littered with cigarette butts.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Wall St. Firms Say Earnings Rose Sharply
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. and Alex. Brown Inc., two of Wall Street's most closely watched niche players in the securities industry, yesterday posted sharply higher earnings in the fourth quarter.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Is Sued on Water Act
description: Fifteen years is long enough to wait for the state to comply with the Federal Clean Water Act, according to two environmental groups that filed suit against New Jersey yesterday.

title: President of Colombia Vows To Stay On Despite Scandal
description: President Ernesto Samper again defied increasing calls for his resignation under pressure of the mounting evidence that he knowingly accepted millions of dollars from drug traffickers, saying tonight that he would not resign from his "constitutional mandate."

title: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUP TO BUY STAKE IN NATIONAL LODGING
description: The shares of the National Lodging Corporation rose to a 52-week high yesterday after the company agreed in principle to sell about 4 million common shares, worth about $57 million, to Chartwell Leisure Associates 2 L.P. National Lodging's stock closed up $1.625, at $12.25, in Nasdaq trading after reaching a 52-week high of $13.75 earlier. The shares are to be sold for $14.25 apiece. National Lodging said Chartwell, which consists mostly of members of the Fisher real estate family and trusts for the benefit of the de Gunzberg and Gordon Getty families, now would own about 52 percent of National Lodging. National Lodging, formerly the National Gaming Corporation, bought 16 Travelodge hotels and interests in 96 others last month.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNIT OF IRISH BANK TO EXPAND PRESENCE NEAR WASHINGTON
description: Allied Irish Banks P.L.C. said yesterday that its United States subsidiary, First Maryland Bancorp, had agreed to buy First Washington Bancorp of Herndon, Va., for $83.5 million. Allied Irish said the acquisition of First Washington, which has 17 branches, would help First Maryland develop its presence around Washington, D.C., where it already has 40 branches. First Washington is the parent company of Washington Federal Savings Bank, a savings and loan.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Some Visitors From Washington
description: There are several reasons to drop in on the Washington Ballet, which opened a run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday night. One is the English choreographer Graham Lustig, whose ballet "Evening" has the same striking fusion of intellect and feeling as its music by Benjamin Britten.

title: Court Won't Shift Okinawa Rape Case
description: Japan's highest court rejected an appeal today by the mother of an American serviceman accused of rape, ordering that his trial continue on the island where the attack occurred.

title: Austin Hansen, Visual Chronicler of Harlem Life, Dies at 85
description: Austin Hansen, who chronicled the life of Harlem in thousands of photographs over six decades, died on Tuesday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center on First Avenue and 23d Street in Manhattan. Mr. Hansen, who lived in West Harlem, was 85.

title: Another Century and House
description: To The Home Section:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: Dennis Holt, chairman and chief executive of Western International Media, Los Angeles, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., was named leader of the year by the Western States Advertising Agencies Association. He will be honored at a dinner on Feb. 13 in Los Angeles.

title: Apple's Woes May Benefit Consumers
description: This may be a difficult time to be an Apple Computer shareholder, but that does not make it a bad time to buy an Apple Macintosh computer, computer industry analysts say.

title: SUPER BOWL;Did Cowboys Help Sooners?
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association is investigating whether Oklahoma Coach John Blake improperly used his ties to the Dallas Cowboys to recruit players, the Austin American-Statesman reported today.

title: Police Patrols To Increase Where Child Was Shot
description: One day after a 9-year-old was caught in a crossfire of bullets on his way to school on the Upper West Side, police officials announced yesterday that they would station more officers in the area as children walk to and from the school.

title: Final Stock of the Smallpox Virus Now Nearer to Extinction in Labs
description: After several stays of execution, the smallpox virus, one of the biggest killers in history, is back on death row.

title: Recouping After the Meltdown
description: FIRST the snow. Then the drip-drip, that continual noise sounding just like raindrops falling from the roof. Then, as the night progressed, the mysterious drips would stop, only to begin again the next morning as the temperature rose. Or an upstairs window would shimmer with rivulets of water as if the rain had once again started in earnest.

title: Archer Daniels Plans Ethanol Expansion
description: Further enhancing its position as the nation's lowest-cost and most flexible producer of ethanol, the Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said yesterday that it would double its capacity to produce beverage alcohol from its ethanol lines in Peoria, Ill., and Clinton, Iowa, to 210 million gallons annually this year, then double its beverage alcohol capacity again in 1997.

title: Sun's Bid for Apple Computer Placed Below Stock's Price
description: Sun Microsystems wants to merge with Apple Computer, but it thinks Apple is worth far less than its current market price.

title: Dole's Response Gets a Response of Its Own, and It's FairlyUnderwhelming
description: Millions of those who watched President Clinton deliver his State of the Union Message on Tuesday did not stay tuned to hear the response that Senator Bob Dole presented after the address. Perhaps, Republicans around the nation said today, that was just as well.

title: 12 Guilty in Church Bombs
description: Twelve people, including several linked to the leftist Sandinista party, were convicted today in a string of church bombings that had raised security concerns for Pope John Paul II's visit next month.

title: IN PERFORMANCE: THEATER
description: To Remain Upright In a Low-Down Reality 'A Trip to the Beach' Theater Off Park

title: 67 Million Settlement by Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust Company has agreed to pay $67 million to Air Products and Chemicals Inc. to settle a dispute over money-losing derivatives contracts, the companies announced yesterday.

title: To Feed That Craving For Gadgets
description: Still reeling from about $3 billion in lost retail sales because of snowstorms in the East and facing what many experts say will be a year pocked with retail bankruptcies, the 55,000 people who attended this year's International Housewares Show were an edgy bunch.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: French Battle Lines Form Again After a Month of Labor Peace
description: A month after the end of the most disruptive strikes in a decade, French labor unions and the Government are squaring off for new confrontations, even though the most sensitive parts of the Government deficit-reduction plan that set off the unrest have been dropped.

title: Currents;Books for a Cause, and a Cafe, Too
description: IF cafe-bookstores work for selling new books, why not for volumes of the pre-read kind?

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Camby Is Set To Play Again
description: With Marcus Camby ready to play again Saturday, his neurologist said he hopes he never learns why the Massachusetts basketball star collapsed before a recent game. Dr. David A. Drachman said today that test results received since Camby was released from the hospital last week revealed no abnormality.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;N.B.A. Players Union Dismisses Gourdine
description: In yet another convulsive turn within the volatile National Basketball Players Association, Simon Gourdine has been ousted as executive director by a unanimous vote of player representatives, according to people within the union and National Basketball Association management.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;American Express unexpectedly doubles the agencies on its advertising roster, to two.
description: THE American Express Company yesterday awarded its first advertising assignments to Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York by naming Y.& R. to create campaigns for all of its financial-services businesses.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Dismiss Rodman's Talk
description: The day after the Bulls' Dennis Rodman suggested that they were "yellow" in Tuesday's night's loss to Chicago, the Knicks laughed it off as Rodman merely being Rodman.

title: Wells Fargo Wins Battle for First Interstate
description: Winning a bitter four-month hostile takeover battle, Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the First Interstate Bancorporation for $11.6 billion, the most ever paid for an American bank.

title: Florida Bomb Kills Man and Raises Concern on Increase in RandomAttacks
description: A Chinese restaurant chef walking home after work was the random victim of a bomb rigged with a trip wire that exploded and killed him as he passed a bus stop near here.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Ruth Hubble, Who Is 88 And Will Die Tonight
description: WHITE RABBIT By Kate Phillips 212 pages. Houghton Mifflin $21.95.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Israelis and Syrians Resume Talks in U.S.
description: Israel and Syria resumed peace talks today with American mediators hoping that the participation of two generals on each side would encourage compromises.

title: Republican Party Seeks A Fund-Raising Record
description: The Republican National Committee said today that it hoped to break a record for political fund raising at a single event by bringing in more than $15 million at its annual dinner, in part by offering big contributors private meetings with major elected officials.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;An Ogilvy Chief Leaves After a Year
description: Frank Parrish, chairman and chief executive of the North American operations of Ogilvy & Mather Direct Worldwide in New York, has left after almost a year in that job. As a result, the agency, which is owned by the WPP Group, has restructured by creating a unit, the Ogilvy & Mather Direct Group, to oversee all direct marketing operations in New York.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders' Subtraction of Muller Should Prove a Plus for Milbury
description: Islander Coach Mike Milbury took on the added title of general manager last month primarily because his predecessor, Don Maloney, could not resolve the Kirk Muller morass.

title: A Troubled Anniversary
description: Some legal rights grow more secure over time. But as Roe v. Wade, the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion, marked its 23d anniversary this week, that right is under siege across the country.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Xerox Results Weaker Than Anticipated
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that it posted a net loss in the fourth quarter, reflecting a $1.5 billion charge related to the sale of the company's insurance unit and other items. On an operating basis, the company's results were weaker than expected, and Xerox's shares fell 10.6 percent today.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;On How to Suffer, and the Reasons
description: The more death you see, the more you want to live," declares Irena Lillien (Beata Fudalej), a feisty young Jewish woman fleeing the Nazis in Andrzej Wajda's powerful new film, "Holy Week." Hostile to her protectors in a suburban Warsaw apartment house where she refuses to remain discreetly out of sight, the character is one of the more unsympathetic Holocaust victims to be portrayed in a movie. Irena has no use for the notion that wisdom is acquired through suffering. "Suffering makes you a worse person, a much worse person," she says with an edge of bitter self-awareness.

title: 3 NATO Soldiers Killed
description: Two Portuguese soldiers and one Italian were killed in an accidental explosion in Sarajevo today, the first deaths among NATO troops in Bosnia since they arrived last month.

title: BellSouth's Chairman Is Planning to Retire
description: John L. Clendenin announced today that he would retire as chairman, president and chief executive of the BellSouth Corporation at the end of 1996.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Trouble for Receiver
description: Buffalo Bills wide receiver RUSSELL COPELAND must appear tomorrow in Hamburg (N.Y.) Town Court on charges that he broke his girlfriend's nose during a fight.

title: Mattel Seeks Hasbro but Is Rebuffed
description: In a move that stunned the toy industry, Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it had offered to buy Hasbro Inc. and that Hasbro's board had rejected the overture.

title: Orange County Settlement Sends a Signal From S.E.C.
description: Thirteen months after Orange County, Calif., filed for bankruptcy, the county government, its Board of Supervisors and two former top officials settled today with the Securities and Exchange Commission over charges that they had committed securities fraud by hiding the county's risky financial condition and making false statements to investors.

title: U.S. Has No Basis for Prosecuting Simpson on Civil Rights Case
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPER BOWL: NOTEBOOK;Super Silence Of the Steelers
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers the team, not the players -- could face a fine from the National Football League as a result of a mass no-show by more than 20 players for today's daily news conference.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHYRON TO BUY BRITISH VIDEO EQUIPMENT COMPANY
description: The Chyron Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire all the outstanding shares of Pro-Bel Ltd. for $21.1 million in cash, notes and stock. Pro-Bel, a privately held company based in Britain, makes video signal switching equipment and control software for broadcast systems. Chyron, which is based in Melville, L.I., makes products that broadcasters use to create special effects and titles on television screens. Pro-Bel had profits of $2.1 million on revenue of about $27.2 million in 1995.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Surge On New Hope Of a Rate Cut
description: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded sharply yesterday as more evidence of a weak economy heightened expectations of another interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve, and a stronger dollar brought buyers back into the market.

title: The State of the Worker
description: The first duty of the State, President Clinton seemed to say on Tuesday night, is to open up in the morning. After Woodrow Wilson's 14 Points and Franklin Roosevelt's Four Freedoms, we have come down to this: "Let's just open up!"

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ciba-Geigy Says Sales Fell but Sees Profit
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G. said yesterday that its sales declined 6 percent in 1995, damped by the strong Swiss franc. But it said nevertheless that it would report earnings "considerably higher" than those of 1994. Profits are scheduled to be reported on March 26. The big chemical and pharmaceutical company had sales of 20.69 billion Swiss francs -- about $17.4 billion -- last year, down from 22.05 billion francs a year earlier.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SPYGLASS INC., Naperville, Ill., has agreed to buy Stonehand Inc., Cambridge, Mass., a privately held provider of Internet software, for $9.5 million.

title: Frenzied Premiere For a Simple Chair
description: IN America, people throng to stores for signings of books, sports memorabilia and rock albums almost every day. Germans do those things too, but during last week's International Furniture Fair in Cologne, the mob at one of the city's most stylish home furnishings stores had one thing on its mind: autographed chairs.

title: Police Bolster Patrols Where Child Was Shot
description: A day after a 9-year-old boy was caught in a crossfire of bullets on his way to school on the Upper West Side, police officials announced that they would station more officers in the area as children walk to and from the school.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: OLYMPICS;Top Woman Runner Out of Marathon Trials
description: OLGA APPELL, the leading qualifier for the United States Women's Olympic Marathon Trials, has withdrawn from the Feb. 10 race, which will be run in Columbia, S.C., because of a training injury.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about an interview with George Delury, who faces manslaughter charges for helping his wife commit suicide, referred incorrectly to its rarity. Newsday published an interview with him on Jan. 16; his interview with The New York Times was not the first since his arrest in July.

title: Sports of The Times;Switzer And Cowher Hip to Hype
description: IN a Freudian slip, or maybe just a footballian slip, Barry Switzer mentioned during his Super Bowl inquisition about being "here at the Orange Bowl," as he was nine times while he was the University of Oklahoma coach.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers' Streak Survives Garden Pressure Cooker
description: There was plenty on the line at Madison Square Garden last night. And both the Rangers and the Flyers played like it.

title: Perry Says U.S. Spy Agencies Will Help Bosnia Tribunal
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that United States intelligence agencies could and would supply "important clues" to the international tribunal investigating war crimes in Bosnia.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Judge's Recusal Is Sought
description: Representative Dick Zimmer thinks Federal District Judge Nicholas H. Politan should recuse himself from handling cases involving "Megan's Law."

title: CHRONICLE
description: Good help is hard to find, and even harder to hold onto. Just ask the PRINCESS OF WALES, who is in the market for a new secretary, among other things.

title: Moving Toward Cure of Tick-Borne Illness
description: Researchers said today that for the first time they had been able to isolate and grow the bacterium that causes a recently identified and sometimes fatal disease transmitted to people by the same tick that carries Lyme disease.

title: Currents;Artistry in Paris Under the Arches
description: THE historic furniture district of Paris, the area to the east of the Place de la Bastille, is once again buzzing with activity. In the last couple of years, the Viaduc des Arts along the Avenue Daumesmil has become home to more than 30 furniture shops, art galleries and artisan's studios. All are housed beneath the arches of an old railway viaduct that offers cavernous spaces of stone and brick that soar to 21 feet.

title: Shooting of Officer Ruled Self-Defense
description: A Brooklyn grand jury decided yesterday not to charge a man in the death of an off-duty police officer last week after a 911 recording and a medical examiner's report indicated that the man had acted in self-defense, according to the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CISCO SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY INTERNET SOFTWARE MAKER
description: Cisco Systems Inc. said late on Tuesday that it had agreed to acquire TGV Software Inc., a supplier of Internet software that connects computers over networks, in a stock swap valued at $115 million. Cisco, a provider of computer networking products like routers, switches and network management software, will exchange one common share for every five TGV shares. Cisco's stock was up $2.875 at $80.75 in Nasdaq trading of 5.5 million shares, and TGV's shares jumped $4.50 each, or about 40 percent, to $15.50, on trading of almost 1.2 million shares. TGV is based in Santa Cruz, Calif., and Cisco is based in San Jose, Calif.

title: Chechen Rebels Release 46 Of the 90 Hostages They Held
description: Chechen rebels today released 46 of the hostages they had seized in a raid this month in a neighboring republic that touched off a prolonged siege and humiliated the Russian Government and military.

description: A man who killed a convenience store clerk was executed by injection on Tuesday night after a 22-minute delay to allow medical personnel to find a vein large enough for the needle.

title: American Center In Paris Must Sell Its Home
description: The American Center, which for 65 years has served as both promoter and window of American culture in Paris, announced today that it had lost its battle for economic survival and would close and sell its new ultra-modern headquarters on the eastern edge of the city.

description: An American soldier whose refusal to serve under United Nations command in the Balkans was praised by conservatives but called a potential "cancer" by the Army, was convicted of disobedience today and given a bad-conduct discharge.

description: Cliff Freeman & Partners in New York announced management changes yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Acer's U.S. Unit Reassigns Account
description: The Acer America Corporation in San Jose, Calif., a unit of the Taiwan company Acer Inc. that markets personal computers, has named Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco to handle its account, which had been at Lai, Venuti & Lai in Santa Clara, Calif., for four years. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million. Riney was awarded the account after a review that had been narrowed to that agency and two other finalists, also in San Francisco: Anderson & Lembke, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Citron Haligman Bedecarre.

title: Boeing Allowed to Head Contract Group
description: Reversing an earlier decision, Federal regulators agreed today to let the Boeing Company head a group of companies seeking a $1 billion contract to modernize air traffic control software and work stations at about 200 stations near airports.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNUM TO SELL TAX-SHELTERED ANNUITY BUSINESS
description: The Lincoln National Life Insurance Company agreed yesterday to acquire the tax-sheltered annuity business of the UNUM Corporation for about $70 million. Lincoln National Life, a life insurance unit of the Lincoln National Corporation, said the purchase included about 1,700 contracts, with assets under management of $3.2 billion. Tax-sheltered annuities are tax-deferred retirement plans available to employees of certain tax-exempt institutions. UNUM, which is based in Portland, Me., is a provider of disability insurance. It announced last fall that it planned to leave the tax-sheltered annuity business. Lincoln National Life is based in Fort Wayne, Ind.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Tanzania to Let In 12,000 More Rwandans
description: Tanzania has agreed to provide temporary refuge for up to 12,000 Rwandans fleeing the same ethnic violence in Burundi that drove them from their homeland, the United Nations said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LYNCH JONES BUYS JOHNSON REDBOOK SERVICE
description: Lynch Jones & Ryan said yesterday that it had acquired the Johnson Redbook Service, a research organization that provides reports on sales by retailers. Terms were not disclosed. Johnson Redbook has been an affiliate of Lynch Jones, a brokerage firm based in New York, since 1991, but Lynch Jones did not have an ownership stake. The service was bought from the estate of the founder, Edward F. Johnson, who died last year at the age of 73. Lynch Jones named Jay Meltzer managing director of Johnson Redbook. Mr. Meltzer joined the service last July.

title: Henry S. Villard, 95, Diplomat Who Wrote Books in Retirement
description: Henry Serrano Villard, a former ambassador who retired in 1961 and turned to writing books, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 95 and lived in Los Angeles, Europe and the Bahamas.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti Shares Fall As Wider Loss Is Seen
description: Olivetti shares dropped yesterday after the Italian computer and office products company late on Tuesday forecast a wider-than-expected loss for 1995. The company said it expected to lose 1.55 trillion lire ($1 billion) in 1995, as costs to reorganize its computer unit and dismiss workers surpassed expectations. The company had a pretax loss from operations of 500 billion lire and one-time charges of 1.05 trillion.

title: China Threatens Taiwan

Beijing pounced on an unofficial visit to America last year by Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, to register its strong objection to any potential change in Taiwan's status. But China has now escalated tensions by recklessly raising the prospect that it might use military force to intimidate Taiwan. The United States and other countries must make clear that such a step would unravel Beijing's relations with the international community and undermine China's prized economic boom.

title: Are Pop Charts Manipulated?
description: Until 1991 the pop music charts were notoriously unreliable. Paying off record store employees with free albums, concert tickets and even vacations and washing machines was the standard music-business method of manipulating record sales figures. Even the Billboard magazine charts, considered the most prestigious in the business, were compiled from store managers' oral reports, which were inaccurate to begin with and easily swayed.

description: MORE companies than ever before announced spinoffs last year, so it was only a matter of time before the rumors of a year ago came up again: that Pepsico Inc. is considering an imminent separation of its beverage business from its sometimes-troubled Pizza Hut, KFC and Taco Bell fast-food chains.

title: BASKETBALL;Slur Incident Gets Uglier
description: A New Mepico State administrator today said that Long Beach State Coach Seth Greenberg had "impugned" the school and the entire state of New Mexico in his reaction to an anti-Semitic message left in his team's locker room earlier this week. Greenberg countered by calling New Mexico State's response to the incident "an insult."

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRSTAR PLANS TO DISMISS 1,400 EMPLOYEES
description: The Firstar Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 1,400 workers in the next 17 months to cut its annual operating costs by $110 million. Firstar, a bank company based in Milwaukee, plans to eliminate another 1,100 jobs through attrition, for a total reduction of 2,500. The company plans to have 7,300 workers after the cuts. Firstar plans to take a charge of $31 million, or 42 cents a share, against its earnings in the first quarter for the dismissals and for other costs. Firstar, which has $19.2 billion in assets, has more than 240 branches, in six states. The company made its announcement after the close of trading. Firstar stock had risen $1, to $40.

title: ART REVIEW;Exploring Common Ground of the Surreal and the Abstract

The story is almost certainly false, but it has an irresistible appeal to art historians looking for connections between Surrealism and Abstract Expression. Two current Manhattan exhibitions -- "Andre Masson in America," at the Zabriskie Gallery, and "Baziotes, Kamrowski, Pollock," at the Washburn Gallery -- offer an unusual opportunity for firsthand research on the topic.

And these women were in skiers' plumage, while for movie types who turn up, life is a Gap ad. Also, these women had strolled into the room and sat down in a normal manner. Actors at Sundance perfect a casual skulk and are much more often seen darting out exits than making entrances.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain Sells BAA Stake
description: The British Government has sold its remaining 2.9 percent stake in BAA P.L.C., which operates seven airports in Britain. The sale raised about L150 million ($228 million), which the Government will use to cut its budget deficit. The Government sold about 29.5 million shares in BAA, which was first offered to investors in 1987, to Merrill Lynch International Ltd. The Merrill unit plans to sell the BAA shares to institutional investors. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: CHRONICLE
description: OPRAH WINFREY is collaborating with BOB GREENE, an exercise physiologist, on a health and fitness book and journal to be published in the fall by Hyperion and the Harpo Entertainment Group, Ms. Winfrey's company.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The news that Joe's Shanghai, one of the finest restaurants in Flushing, Queens, has opened a Pell Street branch seems to have spread quickly through Chinatown. The small storefront is only two weeks old but by noon there is a substantial line for tables and the wait increases throughout the lunch hour.

title: A New Obstacle in Ireland
description: The stalled peace process in Northern Ireland got a nudge this week from an international commission headed by former Senator George Mitchell. It suggested a compromise plan for getting rid of the guns in the conflict and moving ahead with crucial all-party talks. But Prime Minister John Major of Britain quickly offered a new precondition to the talks. In the process, he alienated Northern Ireland's Social Democratic and Labor Party, a key player in any solution to the Northern Irish problem, and broke ranks with the Irish Government, which has helped build the fragile consensus for peace.

title: Twilight of the Monarchs
description: As many as 30 million mon arch butterflies perhaps 30 percent of the North American monarch population -- died after a snowstorm hit their sanctuaries in Mexico on Dec. 30. But storms are not the real threat to the monarchs, which have wintered in the cold Mexican mountaintops for more than 10,000 years.

title: POLITICS: THE FIRST LADY;Admiring Crowds Cheer Mrs. Clinton
description: On the eve of her testimony before a Federal grand jury investigating the Whitewater cases, Hillary Rodham Clinton took a campaign swing in New Hampshire today and was met by crowds whose enthusiasm bordered on adoration.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Monarch's Slide Into Dementia
description: It is kindest, perhaps, to think of it as merely another bead on the abacus: No. 30 out of 36 in the continuing marathon of the complete plays of William Shakespeare from the New York Shakespeare Festival. It's the most difficult one to get right, anyway: practically impossible. And now at least, for the record, it has been done.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Subsidies and Social Issues

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERLING GROUP TO BUY ANOTHER UNIT FROM DU PONT
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its medical diagnostic imaging unit to Sterling Group Inc., an investor group in Houston, for an undisclosed amount. The diagnostic imaging business, based in Glasgow, Del., has 2,100 employees and annual sales of about $525 million. In May, Du Pont said it would sell its four medical products units to pay back some of the $8.4 billion in debt it took on in April, when it repurchased 23 percent of its outstanding stock. Sterling Group, headed by Gordon Cain, bought two other Du Pont businesses through leveraged buyouts in 1984 and 1987. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: MEASURE TO AVERT A THIRD SHUTDOWN IS PASSED IN HOUSE
description: House Republicans and the White House agreed today on a deal that would provide 45 days of spending for parts of the Government that are still without a permanent budget and free enough money to allow most foreign aid programs to continue for the rest of the fiscal year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR PREDICTS DROP IN EARNINGS
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation predicted yesterday that its earnings for its third quarter would decline because of slower sales of the parts that it makes for analog mobile telephones and personal computers. The company said that sales growth for the quarter, which ends on Feb. 25, will fall short of analysts' expectations and that earnings per share will be lower than a year earlier. According to First Call, analysts had expected the company to earn about 52 cents a share, up from 42 cents a year earlier. The company's shares fell 62.5 cents yesterday, to $17.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. (Reuters)

title: Inside Art
description: Elections and Art Loans

title: Animals Killed, An Island Is Abuzz
description: Madelyne Tolentino says it jumped like a kangaroo and smelled like sulfur. Luis Guadalupe swears it was as ugly as a demon and flew through the air as he and his brother-in-law fled for dear life. Two dozen other people here say they have seen it, a vampire-like predator that they say killed scores of animals.

title: SUPER BOWL;A Proud Mother Takes Emmitt Inc. on the Road
description: When she walks into the room, her presence is felt immediately. She is the chief operating officer of a company called Emmitt Inc., a business that collects and sells trading cards and collectibles signed by Dallas running back Emmitt Smith. Her son is busy but he completely trusts his mom, so she takes care of the business. And Mary Smith does that with the same relentless drive that has helped propel her son to the top of his game.

title: 25 and Under
description: Tradition fills Christos Hasapo-Taverna. This handsome Greek-American steakhouse was opened last summer in Astoria, Queens, by two young partners, Nick Adamis, 32, and Nikki Parissis-Batalias, 24, who wanted to recreate a traditional Greek market that combines a butcher shop, or hasapo (pronounced HAHS-ah-poh), with a restaurant.

title: In Brooklyn, Garden To Charge Admission
description: Faced with a steep drop in public financing and rising operating costs, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the 52-acre emerald expanse in the heart of the city's most populous borough, will begin charging admission for the first time in March. The garden, a meticulously groomed triangle near Prospect Park, has become the most popular horticultural attraction in the region.

title: TV WEEKEND;A Modern-Day Version of Wilde's Ghost Story
description: Oscar Wilde's ghost of "The Canterville Ghost" is back, doing his damnedest to frighten an American family from his spooky castle. In a 1944 film, directed by Jules Dassin, the ghost was played by Charles Laughton, surrounded by a cast that included Margaret O'Brien, Robert Young and Peter Lawford. This time, updated in a way that would probably give Wilde the shivers, he is portrayed by the peripatetic Patrick Stewart, possessor of one of the most authoritative voices in show business. Mr. Stewart also happens to be a producer.

title: FILM REVIEW;Looking to 'Johnny Guitar' for Guidance
description: The Sexual Life of the Belgians" was shown as part of 1995's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Caryn James's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 1. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village.

title: Dime Officers Are Indicted
description: Seven former loan officers of Dime Savings Bank, a unit of Dime Bancorp, were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on charges that they falsified home mortgage loan documents in New Hampshire in the late 1980's.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Rises vs. Mark on Report Of U.S.-German Plan to Back It
description: The dollar rose to a four-month high against the German mark yesterday in late New York trading, recouping early losses. The gain was fueled by a report that German and United States officials wanted to strengthen the dollar against the mark.

title: Winners and Losers in the Rohatyn Sweepstakes;Future of Lazard Freres If Fed Comes Calling
description: To many New Yorkers and even some in the financial community, Felix G. Rohatyn, Wall Street's premier adviser on takeovers, is Lazard Freres & Company, the international investment bank.

title: Day After It Refused Mattel, Hasbro Sees Its Stock Vault
description: Investors loaded up on Hasbro Inc. stock yesterday, even as representatives of the toy manufacturer mustered an aggressive defense in explaining why a $5.2 billion merger offer from Mattel had been rejected.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Cowboy in the Black Forest;Daimler Chief's Tough Style Isn't Business as Usual for Europe
description: On a warm evening last July, the chairman of Daimler-Benz A.G. and two of his subordinates were stopped by the Italian police near Rome's Spanish Steps, "in an exuberant mood" and carrying a bottle of red wine.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HIGHWOODS PROPERTIES TO ACQUIRE NASHVILLE DEVELOPER
description: Highwoods Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Eakin & Smith Inc., an office developer based in Nashville, in a deal valued at $100 million. The transaction gives Highwoods ownership of seven office buildings, with a total of 848,000 square feet, in suburban Nashville; a 103,000-square-foot office building under development; 18 acres of land, and brokerage and property-management operations. The purchase, which is expected to be completed by March 15 and which includes the assumption of $36 million in debt, will give Highwoods about a 6 percent share of Nashville's 17-million-square-foot office market. Highwoods, based in Raleigh, N.C., owns 87 office buildings and 103 industrial properties, mainly in North Carolina. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: The Heirs of Franco Woo Spain's Centrist Voters
description: If Franco could have come back from the dead and visited Madrid this weekend, the old dictator would have had trouble distinguishing right from left and friend from foe.

title: SUPER BOWL;Steeler Cornerback Awaits Confrontation
description: Preparing for what could be the most physical of all 30 Super Bowls, the Pittsburgh Steelers put on their helmets today and continued to pound one another in practice.

title: FILM REVIEW;Ms. Workaholic's Mr. Right
description: In the wistful romance "Bed of Roses," Lisa (Mary Stuart Masterson) has an enviable problem. Though she spends her working days as a vice president talking about things like cost-benefit analysis, she has developed a secret admirer. The admirer sends her flowers out of the blue, as if to acknowledge that he understands her essential loneliness. Even better, when it comes to flowers, the secret admirer has sensationally good taste.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Desperado 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $99.11. Laser disk, $39.95. 103 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Clinton's Speech Oversold Health of Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Flood of Cash to Mutual Funds Helped to Fuel '95 Bull Market
description: Lured by an unprecedented bull market, and with aging baby boomers growing more concerned about retirement, stock mutual funds are taking in more money than ever before. And that money in turn is driving up stock prices, helping to bring in more money for the funds.

title: Setback for FedEx Pilots
description: The Air Line Pilots Association ended a work slowdown at Federal Express on Tuesday without attaining a new contract.

title: Stepfather Is Indicted In Elisa's Case
description: The stepfather of Elisa Izquierdo, the 6-year-old whose death galvanized New York City and led to the creation of a new child protection agency, was charged yesterday with slamming Elisa's head against a wall weeks before her death, as two of her siblings watched.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about children's book awards from the American Library Association misattributed the illustrations in "Her Stories." They were by Leo and Diane Dillon, not by Bonnie Verberg, who wrote the book.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DOW CHEMICAL CO. (DOW,N)
description: The Dow Chemical Company's earnings rose in the fourth quarter, benefiting from higher prices for several basic chemicals and lower manufacturing costs.

title: Judge's Rejection of Evidence Is Criticized
description: Law-enforcement officials and political leaders criticized a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday for throwing out evidence in a drug case in part because he believed it was understandable, and not suspicious, for four men to run away when they recognized a police officer.

title: INSIDE
description: Michigan Enterprise Efforts

title: BASKETBALL;UConn Isn't Pushed Around
description: The challenge for Connecticut's Huskies was different tonight. The backcourt of Ray Allen and Doron Sheffer, perhaps the best in the nation, commands the respect of its opponents. But at Pittsburgh, in Ralph Willard's second season as coach, respect means a challenge.

title: FILM REVIEW;The Insect Behavior Shown by Victorians
description: The mood is eminently correct, the setting grand, the manners formal. But beneath the elaborate Victorian rituals and intricate costumes on display in "Angels and Insects," there lurks as mesmerizingly bizarre a film as you may ever see.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bates to Handle Kinney Shoes Chain
description: The Woolworth specialty footwear division of the Woolworth Corporation in New York said yesterday that it had named Bates U.S.A. in New York to handle advertising for its Kinney Shoes chain, which had most recently been handled by Arnold Fortuna Lawner & Cabot in Boston. The billings were estimated at $6 million. The decision came after a seven-week review that had been narrowed to Bates and two other finalists: Gray Kirk/VanSant in Baltimore and Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York. Bates already handles advertising for the Woolworth athletic footwear division, which includes the Foot Locker chain.

title: Mexican Disavows Link To a Drug Trafficker
description: To the Editor:

title: Killer of 2 Is Hanged In Delaware as Kin Of Victims Watch
description: A man who murdered an elderly couple 17 years ago went to the gallows early today, the nation's third execution by hanging since 1965.

title: Italy Once Again in Crisis, But the Situation Is Normal
description: Italy is going through another crisis this month, a word that in the local political lexicon defines the period after one Government falls and before another emerges to takes its place.

title: Whitney to Buy New Iberia
description: The Whitney Holding Corporation said on Wednesday that it planned to buy New Iberia Bancorp Inc. for $54 million in stock. The deal values New Iberia's stock at about $27 a share. New Iberia shares closed today at $26.25, up $3.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Norman MacCaig, A Scottish Poet, 85
description: Norman MacCaig, whose spare and disciplined verse made him one of Scotland's most esteemed poets, died on Tuesday in Astley Ainslie Hospital, where he was being treated for injuries from a fall this month. He was 85.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Rutgers Agrees on a Mediator
description: The administration and faculty union at Rutgers University agreed yesterday to bring a state-appointed mediator into their stalled contract talks. The 2,400 professors and 1,600 teaching and graduate assistants in the Rutgers Council of the American Association of University Professors have been working without a contract since June 30.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Cowboys Trying to Put Race Issue to Rest
description: Crises come in bunches.

title: Mayor's Aide In Newark Is Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury charged Mayor Sharpe James's closest aide today with accepting bribes in exchange for city contracts. He is the highest-ranking official to be indicted in the two-year-old investigation into corruption in Newark.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Chevron Deal in Poland
description: Poland's second-largest oil refinery, Rafineria Gdanska S.A., has signed a contract with the Chevron Corporation to use the company's licensed technology in a planned $400 million upgrading. The refinery in Gdansk will use Chevron's technology for a new hydrocracker unit, which is used to make diesel fuel, a spokesman for the refinery said. The price that the refinery will pay Chevron for the license was not disclosed, but it is included in the upgrading cost, which is being financed by Merrill Lynch & Company, the spokesman said.

title: Jonathan Larson, 35, Composer Of Rock Opera and Musicals
