description: Jonathan Larson, the composer and author of the musical "Rent," which had been scheduled to begin previews at the New York Theater Workshop last night, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 35.

title: Yeltsin Picks Soviet-Era Aide To Guide Russian Economy
description: In the most vivid display yet of his disenchantment with economic reform, President Boris N. Yeltsin chose a Soviet-schooled industrialist today to serve as Russia's top economic official.

title: POLITICS;Fund Raising Could Help Forbes Recoup His Costs
description: Steve Forbes, heir to a magazine-publishing fortune, is passing the hat for his Presidential bid, transforming him into the political equivalent of a venture capitalist in the Republican primaries.

title: Psychological Warfare Intensifies : Beijing Ups the Ante On Its Taiwan Threats
description: SINGAPORE  From all appearances, Beijing's latest reaction to a published report that it is ready to launch a limited attack on Taiwan is designed to achieve one of China's tactical objectives: to heighten the island's sense of vulnerability.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Chairman Plans to Bid For Some Forte Hotels
description: Sir Rocco Forte, the chairman of Forte P.L.C. said yesterday that he would bid for the hotels that Granada Group P.L.C. is acquiring as part of its L3.9 billion ($5.9 billion) takeover of Forte but does not want. Sir Rocco, who lost control on Tuesday of the hotel and restaurant empire built by his family, said he was preparing a management buyout offer for 167 Forte hotels, which have a book value of L2.5 billion. He plans to bid for all the Forte hotels except the Posthouse and Travelodge chains, which Granada will keep.

title: A Facilitator for Good Cholesterol Is Found
description: Researchers said today that they have discovered a long-elusive molecule that allows a beneficial form of cholesterol to hook up to cells, a finding that could help scientists explain how the substance helps prevent clogged arteries.

title: Whitman's Aides Project A Rise in Tax Collections
description: Despite a shortfall in some tax revenues this year and recent signs that the New Jersey economy has stalled, the Whitman administration today projected moderate economic growth and a rise in state tax revenues in the coming year.

title: Albany's Anti-City Vote
description: New York City's budget problems are so severe that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani is thinking about cutting the size of the police force. At the same time, however, the State Legislature is doing its best to make the Mayor's job harder by passing bills that would increase the cost of the city's police and fire departments. The Legislature could not have picked a more inopportune time to cater to special interests. Gov. George Pataki can do Mr. Giuliani a favor by using his veto pen.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Casino Group Joins Bill Fight
description: The Casino Association of New Jersey has weighed in on a piece of legislation that has two big casino developers at each other's throats.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRIARC FINDS NEW BUYER FOR TEXTILE BUSINESS
description: The Triarc Companies said yesterday that it would sell its Graniteville textile business and that it planned an initial public offering for its National Propane unit. The company said it would sell Graniteville to Avondale Inc., of Monroe, Ga., for $255 million in cash. Triarc previously agreed to sell Graniteville to Galey & Lord Inc., but said yesterday that both companies had agreed to end the deal. Triarc will also seek Securities and Exchange Commission permission to market limited partnership units in National Propane, in which Triarc plans to keep a stake. Triarc, a New York company that is the parent of Arby's Inc. and the Royal Crown Cola Company, plans to take one-time charges in the fourth quarter to account for the moves. (Dow Jones)

title: U.S. Report on Nation's Tobacco Use Shows Wide State-by-StateDisparities
description: The first state-by-state profile of the nation's tobacco use, the huge economic penalty it exacts and the various state tobacco-control laws was released yesterday by the Federal Government, highlighting startling disparities.

title: Study for Port Authority Finds a Trade Center Sale Is Feasible
description: A study commissioned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey concludes that selling the World Trade Center is feasible, but senior city officials and business experts yesterday questioned the figures used in the study.

title: Abroad at Home;Seize the Day
description: The Dayton peace accords gave the Government of Bosnia a historic opportunity. After the cruel years of victimization and neglect, here was a chance to build a country -- with the help of Europe and the United States.

title: On My Mind;The Death Charter
description: Once again Yasir Arafat is proving, sometimes twice a day, that he can be counted on to show he cannot be counted on.

title: Vote, and Then Change Your Party Registration Often
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: GOLF;New Club Alchemy Changes Steel to Titanium
description: It has been used in everything from eyeglasses to Patriot missiles, from valves in artificial hearts to the fuselages of Russian MIG-25's. It is 40 percent lighter, 69 percent stronger and 10 times more expensive than steel.

title: U.S. Plan to Change Iran Leaders Is an Open Secret Before It Begins
description: In an unusual operation conceived by Speaker Newt Gingrich, the Central Intelligence Agency is to mount a $18 million covert action to change the nature of the Government of Iran. The operation has not started, but the counteroffensive has.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Kids 1995. Vidmark. $96.99. 102 minutes. Closed captioned. No rating. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Next to Godliness, at Newark;Whatever Else It Lacks, Airport's Arrivals Building Is Clean
description: Why do many New Yorkers favor Newark International Airport? For the same reason Lawrence of Arabia preferred the desert: it's clean. By that standard, the airport's International Arrivals Facility, which formally opened this week, must be judged a success.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Bacteria's Role Uncertain
description: The public is not at risk. That's the first point state health officials want to make. The second point, the officials said yesterday, is that although flesh-eating bacteria were detected in a 56-year-old man and a 70-year-old woman who died at hospitals in South Jersey last week, it has not been determined if the bacteria killed them. Health officials said about 500 to 1,500 cases of the flesh-destroying strain of streptococcus A are diagnosed annually in the United States.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Balanchine's Sleepwalker
description: George Balanchine may have been a master of abstract ballet, but when he wanted to tell a story he could tell a good one. He concocted a spine-tingler when he choreographed "La Sonnambula," which the New York City Ballet danced for the first time since 1993 on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater.

title: G.O.P. BACKING OFF FROM TOUGH STAND OVER ENVIRONMENT
description: Republicans are increasingly worried that by imposing deep cuts on environmental programs they are doing even deeper political damage to their party, and they are beginning to back away from further confrontations on environmental issues.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Business Week Reports Possible Violations Linked to Column
description: Business Week magazine said yesterday that it had noticed a pattern of suspicious trading in stocks recommended in its "Inside Wall Street" column and that it had notified Federal regulators and stock exchange surveillance officials.

title: Niagara Mohawk Stock Dives After Dividend Suspension
description: Seeking to strengthen its balance sheet and call attention to its need for relief from the state, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, a big utility in upstate New York, said yesterday that its board had decided not to pay a dividend on common stock in the first quarter.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Trade Buford Away
description: Terrell Lowery, a 25-year-old outfielder more successful in college basketball than in pro baseball, became a Met yesterday in a trade with the Texas Rangers. In return, the Rangers got Damon Buford, a 25-year-old outfielder whom the Mets acquired last July in the four-player trade that sent Bobby Bonilla to Baltimore.

title: Common Sense on the Budget
description: Early last year, in a bellicose review of his first weeks as Speaker of the House, Newt Gingrich proclaimed himself "a genuine revolutionary" who was going to change the world built by "the genuine reactionaries" in the Democratic Party. But on Wednesday, a tamer, conciliatory Newt Gingrich emerged, proffering modest budget and tax cuts designed to end the current budget impasse with the White House and start toward Republican goals one step at a time. Yesterday he persuaded his cohort to keep Government offices open for 45 more days while negotiations go forward. How can it be that in just one year the self-proclaimed revolutionary is suing for peace?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Woman Convicted in Slaying
description: A Nutley woman was convicted yesterday in Essex County Superior Court of aggravated manslaughter for killing her boyfriend, a Newark police detective. Ronald Kuby, the lawyer for Michelle Gomez, had argued that she was a battered woman who suffered from dissociative disorder when she shot Joseph DiTommaso last year. Because the jury did not convict her of murder, Mr. Kuby called the verdict "a victory for battered women everywhere." Ms. Gomez faces a 30-year sentence.

title: Small Plane Sales Up
description: American makers of small aircraft reported today that in 1995 they delivered the most aircraft since 1990 and that the industry registered the biggest dollar volume since 1981. The General Aviation Manufacturers Association said 1,077 small craft were delivered last year, up 16.1 percent from 1994, and that billings for the industry were $2.8 billion, up 20.6 percent. It said that the number of planes exported was up 11.9 percent, to 310, and that export dollar value was up almost 20 percent, to $816 million.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Slight Drop In Coke Stock Despite Profit
description: Buoyed by surprisingly high beverage volume in the United States and on-target international growth, the Coca-Cola Company yesterday announced solid fourth-quarter earnings. Nevertheless, the stock fell as much as $2 during heavier-than-average trading yesterday, closing at $73.625, down $1.50.

title: COMPANY NEWS;A.I.G. TO BUY BANKAMERICA CREDIT UNIT IN HONG KONG
description: American International Group Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy SPC Credit Ltd., the Hong Kong credit unit of the BankAmerica Corporation, to strengthen its Asian consumer finance interests. The price was not disclosed but Edmund Tse, A.I.G.'s executive vice president, said it was the "largest cash acquisition of a finance company in Hong Kong so far." A.I.G., based in New York, also has finance businesses in Taiwan, Thailand and the Philippines. SPC has 12 branches in Hong Kong and assets of $641 million. (Reuters)

title: Sports of The Times;So, the Bulls Are Already The Champs?
description: THE Chicago Bulls came into town to play a basketball game last Tuesday with all the glitter, noise and wonder of the circus, a presidential campaign and a Martian landing rolled into one. The next day, as quietly as safe crackers, the Houston Rockets showed up. The Bulls haven't won a championship in two years. The Rockets are the two-time defending National Basketball Association champions. What's wrong with this picture?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan to Add Funds For Bailout of Lenders
description: The Government of Japan warned yesterday that the $6.4 billion it had set aside to bail out a group of distressed mortgage lenders would not be enough. Finance Minister Wataru Kubo said the Government had pledged support for the bailout beyond the 685 billion yen to be drawn from the next fiscal year's budget. Analysts say the new funds could come to 1 trillion yen, or $9.35 billion.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Nicaraguan Candidate Escapes Armed Attack
description: Gunmen shot at a leading presidential candidate, Arnoldo Aleman, on the campaign trail today, missing him but killing a bodyguard.

title: Executive Changes
description: ASHLAND OIL INC., Ashland, Ky., said John R. Hall, its chairman and chief executive, would retire as chief executive on Oct. 1, and chairman in January 1997. Paul W. Chellgren, president and chief operating officer, has been named to succeed Mr. Hall in both positions.

title: It's Official: Taxi Fares Will Rise
description: The Taxi and Limousine Commission approved a 20 percent increase in taxicab fares yesterday. The new rates will take effect March 1.

title: Michigan Senate Passes Bill To Curb Taxes for 8 Areas
description: Taking one of the most aggressive steps yet by a state to use tax policies rather than spending ones to revitalize impoverished areas, the Michigan Senate today passed a bill that would abolish all state and local income and property taxes in eight areas singled out for economic development.

title: Executive Is Said to Accept Transit Authority's Top Job
description: The chief of the transit system in Washington, D.C., has accepted the top job at the New York City Transit Authority, a high-ranking New York transit official said last night, and will take the helm at a time of deep budget cuts and uncertain capital projects at the nation's largest public transportation system.

title: NYC;G.O.P. Primary Makes Arafat Look Good
description: NOW that the Palestinians have successfully held their first general elections, it is a good time to ask whether they have any advice for others who over the years have had similarly scant contact with free and open balloting.

title: London Journal;Death Notice: A TV Travesty of Tories and Royals
description: It's 10 o'clock Saturday morning and already a nice rhythm has descended on the subversion and anarchy being churned out in the cavernous studio in west London. The cameras are humming along.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;For more than a quarter of the advertisers, it'll be Super Bowl I.
description: THE Dallas Cowboys have played in the Super Bowl before. So too have the Pittsburgh Steelers. But when they meet Sunday in Super Bowl XXX, it will be Super Bowl I for more than a quarter of the advertisers buying commercials in the NBC broadcast of the game.

title: Petro Y. Shelest, 87, Ukraine Party Chief Ousted as 'Localist'
description: Petro Y. Shelest, a former Communist Party chief here who was ousted for defending the Ukrainian language and culture against Russian influence in the 1960's, died in Moscow this week, the Ukrainian Embassy there said today. He was 87.

title: Giuliani Vows No Patrol Cuts If He Trims the Police Force
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani pledged yesterday that the Police Department would not reduce the number of officers patrolling New York City's streets and subways or the level of public safety, even as he acknowledged that he was considering a reduction of 1,000 officers to help balance the city's budget.

title: ART REVIEW;A Forgotten People, Distant Only in Time
description: When it comes to ancient art, most of us want to have it both ways: to love it at first sight, without knowing a jot about it, and also to be able to understand it on its own terms.

title: Future in Doubt, Apple Still Fills A Crucial Post
description: Indicating that business goes on even as its fate as an independent company hangs in the balance, Apple Computer Inc. today filled a high-level executive post that had been open for nearly a year.

title: FILM REVIEW;Technology Runs Amok
description: One lesson Hollywood never seems to learn is that the scariest monsters are the ones rarely if ever seen. When the creepy title characters of the science-fiction thriller "Screamers" first appear in the film, they are mysterious bulges scuttling under the contaminated sands of a distant war-ravaged planet, like rats under a carpet.

title: Union Leader's Salary
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;P.& G. Expands Role With Gray
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had expanded its relationship with Grey Advertising in New York by naming that agency to handle the introduction of Olean, the company's brand of the fat substitute olestra. The announcement came a day after the Government approved the use of olestra in snacks like potato chips and crackers. The billings were not disclosed.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Mayor's Aide Is Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury charged Mayor Sharpe James's closest aide yesterday with accepting bribes in exchange for city contracts. Jackie R. Mattison, the Mayor's chief of staff, is the highest-ranking official to be indicted in the two-year-old investigation into corruption in Newark. [Page A1.]

title: News Corp. And MCI Win Satellite Slot
description: After a brief but spirited bidding war, MCI Communications and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation agreed today to pay the Federal Government $682 million for the last unclaimed orbital slot for a satellite that can beam television straight to individual homes across the United States.

title: TV SPORTS;Wiseacre Maguire Will Call Big Game
description: NBC's Paul Maguire -- who will call his first Super Bowl on Sunday, with Dick Enberg and Phil Simms -- has had plenty of practice at being a scamp.

title: Grandfather Didn't Know From Downsizing
description: To the Editor:

title: Warning Label Recommended for a Blood-Pressure Drug
description: An advisory committee to the Food and Drug Administration recommended last night that the agency take steps to discourage doctors from prescribing a drug used to reduce high blood pressure and relieve the pains of angina.

title: Rifkin, at a Sentencing, Apologizes for 17 Murders
description: Joel Rifkin, who has admitted killing 17 women, said he was sorry yesterday and told the families of his victims that he had never understood just what it was that drove him to murder.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Colombian Party Ends Support for President
description: Colombia's main opposition party said today that it would withdraw all support from the Government of President Ernesto Samper.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Many Faces of Honor, From Plantation to Ghetto
description: ALL GOD'S CHILDREN The Bosket Family and the American Tradition of Violence By Fox Butterfield 389 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $27.50

title: SUPER BOWL: NOTEBOOK;Montana, Mr. Cool, Is Surprised by 49ers' Moves
description: It is only fitting that Joe Montana is here at Super Bowl XXX, even if he isn't playing. For so long, he owned this event.

title: Coldwell Going Back to Roots
description: The Coldwell Banker Corporation said today that it would return to the commercial real estate business, through a new unit, Coldwell Banker Commercial Affiliates Inc.

title: Also of Note
description: Critics' choices of some other Manhattan art shows:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8

title: Leonor Fini, 87, Set Designer And a Painter of the Fantastic
description: Leonor Fini, an Argentine-born artist and theater designer who was as well known for her eccentric lifestyle as she was for her erotic and fantastic paintings, died on Jan. 18 in a Paris hospital. She was 87.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HANDY ANDY HOME CENTERS TO CLOSE REMAINING STORES
description: Handy Andy Home Improvement Centers Inc., which was forced by creditors into bankruptcy last fall, said yesterday that it would close its remaining 54 stores, eliminating about 2,500 jobs. The company, based in Schaumburg, Ill., was already closing about 20 of its home-improvement stores. In filing for Chapter 11 protection on Oct. 17, Handy Andy listed debts of $123 million and said it planned to reorganize into hardware supermarkets. But several banks that it had owed money preferred that Handy Andy liquidate all operations to help repay its debts, the company's president, Richard George, said. The stores in Illinois, Michigan, Missouri, Ohio, Tennessee and Wisconsin are to close by June. (AP)

title: SUPER BOWL;Jets Deny Any Frerotte Deal
description: Boomer Esiason, who has a home in Carefree, Ariz., about an hour's drive from the Super Bowl hoopla, looked spiffy in a houndstooth check jacket and was upbeat today, even while discussing his uncertain future with the Jets.

title: When Month's Rent Means Everything
description: For Maria Moore and her three children, the only thing standing between stability and homelessness was just one month's rent.

title: Home Resales Fall Despite Lower Mortgage Rates
description: Sales of previously owned homes fell in December for a third straight month, despite the lowest mortgage rates in nearly two years, a realty group said today, in another sign of a slowing economy.

title: African Women in France Battling Polygamy
description: Khadi Keita shifted in her chair in a Paris cafe as she described the day she became a stranger in her own home. That was the day in 1985 when her husband suddenly arrived here with a new wife.

title: TENNIS;The Rallies Stop Here: Agassi Falls To Chang
description: This time, there would be no improbable comeback for Andre Agassi at the Australian Open. Michael Chang is not the sort to give up a hard-earned advantage.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Former President GEORGE BUSH and his wife, BARBARA, are appearing a television advertisement for the Houston Astros.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Outsider Art Fair' Puck Building Houston Street and Lafayette Street, SoHo Today through Sunday

title: Art in Review
description: 'Raised by Wolves' Pace Wildenstein MacGill Gallery 32 East 57th Street Through Feb. 22

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Key Players in Washington Agree to 45-Day Budget House Republicans and the White House agreed to provide 45 days of spending for the parts of the Government that are still without a permanent budget, and the House approved the measure. Senate Democrats objected to education cuts, but were unlikely to be able restore that money. Disagreements also emerged about how to keep the Government from defaulting after March 1.

title: Yoicks! And Off Go Hunters, Hounds And Maybe a Fox
description: IT is noontime. Thirty-eight men and women wearing tan breeches and scarlet and black coats with velvet caps gear up for a sport that was a favorite of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and, last year, a scandal for Prince Charles when he took along his young sons.

title: Noel Johnson, Whose Regimen Set an Example, Is Dead at 95
description: The way Noel Johnson always told it, by the time he hit the down slope of his 60's he was so overweight and so out of shape it was all he could do to lift his cigarette to his lips.

title: Mortgage Rate Falls to 7%
description: The rates for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages dropped to a 23-month low this week of 7 percent from 7.02 percent in the week earlier, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. The average rate at lenders around the country was down from 7.11 percent at the start of the year. The average adjustable mortgage rate fell to 5.37 percent, from 5.48 percent a week earlier. Fifteen-year fixed-rate mortgage rates fell to 6.50 percent, from 6.53 percent in the week earlier.

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUORUM HEALTH ENDS MERGER TALKS AND ITS STOCK FALLS
description: Quorum Health Group Inc., which operates hospitals and provides hospital consulting services, said yesterday that it had ended talks with another health care company about a possible merger. Quorum, based in Brentwood, Tenn., disclosed the talks last week but did not identify the company. Its shares, which rose after last week's announcement, fell $3.25 yesterday, to $24.75, in Nasdaq trading. (Dow Jones)

title: Airline in Bankruptcy
description: Business Express Inc. said this week that Saab Aircraft of America, along with two affiliated companies, had filed a petition forcing Business Express into Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AT&T Loses $2.68 Billion In Quarter
description: The AT&T Corporation reported a fourth-quarter loss of $2.68 billion yesterday, reflecting $6.25 billion in previously announced write-offs associated with a planned reorganization and efforts to cut 40,000 people from the company's payroll.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices Plunge Over a Point On Treasuries
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday after talk of selling by some large hedge funds weighed on already jittery investors.

title: Guard Is Killed in Payroll Holdup in Bronx
description: An armed security guard for a Bronx check-cashing company was shot and fatally wounded yesterday in a holdup as he delivered a cash payroll to a Bronx medical center, and the police said two gunmen escaped with $120,000.

title: Home Video
description: Progress Report

title: Disappointing Earnings Push Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices slipped yesterday amid disappointment over earnings posted by some of the nation's largest corporations.

title: Long-Term Therapy May Not Survive Managed-Care Model
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philips Unit Expects A $203 Million Loss
description: Grundig A.G., the German consumer electronics unit of Philips Electronics N.V., said yesterday that it expected to report an operating loss of about 300 million marks ($203 million) for 1995. The loss would follow deficits of 348 million marks in 1994 and 296 million in 1993.

title: TENNIS;Huber Is Rolling Now, But Seles Stands in Way
description: Steffi Graf did not play in this Australian Open. But if Monica Seles wants to win her fourth title on the high-bouncing Rebound Ace surface that suits her so well, she will have to defeat the woman who has often been labeled Graf's heir apparent.

title: BASKETBALL;Ward's Effort Worth Waiting For
description: It is a quandary that every coach eventually faces, and one Don Nelson has already dealt with in the case of Charlie Ward. What should be done with a young player admired for his skills but not completely trusted when your team is trying to crawl back into a game it badly needs?

title: FILM REVIEW;Fond Memories of Mississippi in the 50's
description: When Clifton Taulbert was a little boy growing up in Mississippi during the last years of enforced segregation, his stern great-grandfather took him aside, scribbled two letters on a piece of cardboard and instructed him to memorize them. W means white, the grandfather, who was known as Poppa (Al Freeman Jr.), explained firmly, and C colored. If Clifton had to use a public restroom or a drinking fountain, Poppa warned, he had to remember to always look for the facility announced by the letter C.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP. (SGP,N)
description: Booming sales for the Schering-Plough Corporation's allergy medicine Claritin helped the company to a gain in fourth-quarter profits of more than 17 percent.

title: HOCKEY;Campbell Not Impressed By the Rangers' Streak
description: Back and forth skated the Rangers, their blades spraying ice chips from the Playland practice surface as they abruptly stopped and started. The 4-4 tie with Philadelphia the night before, in Madison Square Garden, left their fans content and drew plenty of media praise.

title: U.N. Says a German Promoted Iraq A-Arms
description: A German atomic scientist played a critical role in Iraq's attempt to build a nuclear bomb in the years before the Persian Gulf war, a senior official with International Atomic Energy Agency said today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Problem With Mayor's Goods
description: The law came between Mayor Larry Manus and his Calvins this week.

title: U.S. to Press Inquiry Into Anti-Abortion Violence
description: Attorney General Janet Reno promised today to continue pursuing evidence of any conspiracy in anti-abortion violence and to protect clinics "as vigorously as possible."

title: Cornell Sets Record by Raising $1.5 Billion in 5 Years
description: Cornell University has announced the completion of the largest fund-raising campaign in the history of higher education, raising $1.5 billion in five years, $250 million more than its original goal.

title: Murder, Madness And Mayhem
description: IT could have been called the Preppy Murder, but in 1836 the word "preppy" did not exist. Nevertheless, New York fed on on the Jewett case with a carnal appetite. The scandal was just too, too delicious.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENRON CORP., Houston, the natural gas company, said its Capital and Trade Resources unit had bought a 38.67 percent stake in Promigas S.A., an oil and gas company in Colombia, for $100.5 million.

title: Vote, and Then Change Your Party Registration Often
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE INVESTIGATION;Ex-Official Tells of Alerting Clinton About an Associate
description: The former Arkansas regulator at the center of several Whitewater investigations told a Senate panel today that in 1986 she had alerted Gov. Bill Clinton's office that Federal officials were about to force the removal of his business partner from an ailing savings and loan association.

title: Suspect in Hypodermic Jabbing Is Declared Unfit to Stand Trial
description: A homeless man who was accused of stabbing a 6-year-old Queens girl with a hypodermic needle was ordered yesterday to remain in a psychiatric hospital.

title: No Headline
description: One wife on her own is trouble. When there are several, they are forced to be polite and well behaved. If they misbehave, you threaten that you'll take another wife."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Despite a Drop in Revenue, Boeing's Profit Is Up Sharply
description: The Boeing Company reported yesterday that its earnings rose 39 percent, to $218 million, in the fourth quarter. The results were better than many industry analysts on Wall Street had expected, although expectations appear to have been clouded by factors that included a recent strike against the company and tax credits.

title: BASKETBALL;A Pause at the Meadowlands for Anderson's New Path
description: Kenny Anderson smiled when asked what kind of greeting he expected Friday night at Continental Airlines Arena.

title: Winners and Losers in the Rohatyn Sweepstakes;Friends in High Places Sing Banker's Praises
description: With Felix G. Rohatyn, the New York investment banker, now officially on the list of those being considered for vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, a rare bit of public lobbying is under way on his behalf.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FINGERHUT REPORTS EARNINGS AND CONSIDERS SPINOFFS
description: The Fingerhut Companies said yesterday that it had hired Smith Barney Inc. and Bear, Stearns & Company to provide advice on a possible spinoff of its financial products and information services units. The company's core business is the marketing of consumer products through catalogues and on television. The company, based in Minnetonka, Minn., also reported yesterday that its net income rose to $30.3 million, or 63 cents a share, in the fourth quarter. That compares with net income of $12.7 million in the corresponding period a year earlier, when the company took a one-time after-tax charge of $19.4 million. Analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research expected earnings of 67 cents a share for the most recent quarter. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;A Style That's Written in His Face
description: Randy Logan recognized the chin almost immediately, but he wasn't sure it belonged to someone he had played beside on the Philadelphia Eagles back in 1983.

title: Polish Coalition Fails to Agree on a New Premier
description: The two parties in Poland's governing coalition failed today to choose a successor to Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy, who announced on Wednesday that he would resign over allegations that he had spied for Moscow.

title: POLITICS: THE FRONT-RUNNER;Dole, in Iowa, Unleashes Tough New Attacks
description: Showing a new feistiness, Senator Bob Dole fought back today against critics who said that his lackluster response to President Clinton's State of the Union Message on Tuesday indicated a weak candidate who would be a poor standard bearer against the telegenic President.

title: KEEP IN MIND
description: A Potpourri That Ranges From 'Little Women' to 'Grease'

title: Review/Fashion;Making the Case for Couture
description: The thing about a standing ovation is that in fashion, as in any art, the motive can be unclear: is the audience standing out of joy or running for a quick exit?

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Stock prices were higher here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 249.15 points, or 1.22 percent, at 20,663.84. On Thursday, the Nikkei gained 101.95 points.

title: FILM REVIEW;Dark Fantasy as a Refuge From a Manic-Depressive Mother
description: Anyone who has superstitiously tried to avoid stepping on cracks in the sidewalk can relate to the desperate little rituals improvised by the 10-year-old title character of Rebecca Miller's hauntingly sad film, "Angela."

title: About Real Estate;Filling a Niche in Property Management
description: In the world of residential property management in Manhattan, the focus has long been on entire condominium and cooperative buildings. But a few companies are now managing apartments for individual owners and small investors with fewer than six residences.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Fictional Nemesis for a Legendary Spy
description: Early in the York Theater Company's revival of the 1967 musical "Mata Hari," there is a glimmer of expectation that the show, whose original Broadway-bound production closed out of town, might have an amusing trick up its sleeve. That moment comes when the title character performs a slinky Hindu dance for the aristocratic guests at an elegant French salon. Lowering her eyes and twirling two red scarves, Mata Hari (Marguerite MacIntyre) slithers through the kind of hootchy-kootchy routine that was a staple of 1950's Hollywood costume dramas and that two generations of drag performers have enshrined as camp.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHARTER BANCSHARES AGREES TO NATIONSBANK MERGER
description: Charter Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that its board had signed a definitive agreement to merge with the Nationsbank Corporation in a stock swap valued at $25.795 a share, or about $94.7 million, for the shares that Nationsbank does not already own. Under the agreement, each share of Charter's regular common and class B stock will be exchanged for 0.385 share of Nationsbank common stock. The value of the deal is based on Wednesday's closing price of $67 for Nationsbank's common stock. Before the deal, Nationsbank held 2.7 million shares, or 42 percent, of Charter's common stock. Charter, of Houston, has 21 branches in Houston and had assets of more than $900 million as of Dec. 31. Nationsbank is based in Charlotte, N.C.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Laker Airways Licenses
description: Sir Freddie Laker said yesterday that he had won a license to start a new trans-Atlantic charter airline in March. The carrier, Laker Airways Inc., said it had been granted licenses by the United States Department of Transportation to operate worldwide charter services out of the country as well as scheduled domestic services. The first flight, from Florida to Britain, is scheduled for March 27. It will be Sir Freddie's first service into London's Gatwick airport since his Skytrain airline collapsed in a fare war 14 years ago.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Something to Talk About 1995. Warner. $103.91. Laser disk, $34.98. 105 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;PROCTER & GAMBLE CO. (PG,N)
description: Shares of the Procter & Gamble Company fell yesterday after the company reported fiscal second-quarter earnings that were a penny shy of Wall Street estimates.

title: HOCKEY;Kings Trade for Stevens
description: The struggling Los Angeles Kings acquired left wing Kevin Stevens from the Boston Bruins today in exchange for right wing Rick Tocchet. The deal came nine days after Wayne Gretzky's agent, Michael Barnett, met with team executives to discuss a possible trade of the National Hockey League's leading career scorer or the upgrading of the Kings' roster. Gretzky becomes an unrestricted free agent after this season.

title: SUPER BOWL;N.F.L. Union Asks for Federal Study on Turf Injuries
description: The National Football League Players Association, working jointly with the league, has commissioned a study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to examine injuries that occur on artificial turf and natural grass. An N.F.L. Office of Field Maintenance has been created, as well.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Mystery of Rampo 1995. Evergreen. 103 minutes. Japanese with English subtitles. No rating.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Wall Drawings '96' The Drawing Center 35 Wooster Street, SoHo Through Feb. 10

title: Deficit May Trip G.O.P. As It Rushes for an Exit
description: This week's proposal by Republicans in the House to call a formal end to budget talks with the White House, and instead enact those spending cuts that both sides have already agreed to, is probably deft politics. But it is unlikely to make even a modest contribution toward erasing the Federal deficit.

title: Clinton's Speech Oversold Health of Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Pam Conrad, 48, Children's Author
description: Pam Conrad, the author of "Prairie Songs," "Stonewords: A Ghost Story" and other works for children and young adults, died on Monday at her home in Rockville Center, L.I. She was 48.

title: For Copper Plaintiffs, the Venue Is Peru
description: The Southern Peru Copper Company won dismissal today of a lawsuit filed in United States District Court here by hundreds of Peruvians who accused the company of pollution. Judge Janis Graham Jack ruled that Federal and international law required that the case be tried in Peru.

title: Officer Is Acquitted in Theft and Perjury
description: A police officer arrested in the 30th Precinct corruption scandal was acquitted yesterday by a jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of charges that he lied under oath about an arrest and stole money from the suspect in the case.

title: Judge Limited Testimony on Taxi Chief
description: Seeking to prove the existence of a violent drug enterprise in Brooklyn, Federal prosecutors portrayed the city's Taxi and Limousine Chairman, Christopher R. Lynn, last September as the gang's former "house counsel."

title: Clinton's Speech Oversold Health of Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Murder Hearing for Boy, 8
description: An 8-year-old boy who may be New Jersey's youngest felony murder suspect is due in Family Court here today. The Hudson County Prosecutor, Carmen Messano, has said he will not seek jail time for the third grader, who was charged after a Dec. 24 blaze that killed a man who lived with the boy and his grandmother. Mr. Messano said he believed that prosecuting the case would help the boy take advantage of help from the justice system, like counseling and supervision.

title: Taxi Board Votes Age Limit for Cabs, and a Rise in Fares
description: New York City's taxi commission yesterday approved a 20 percent fare increase and imposed the first mandatory retirement age for yellow cabs, over the protests of drivers who said that what the panel was giving with one hand, it was taking with the other.

title: Long-Term Therapy May Not Survive Managed-Care Model
description: To the Editor:

title: In America;Unholy Alliance In Nigeria
description: Dr. Owens Wiwa, a Nigerian physician, had nurtured the faint hope that the Royal Dutch/Shell Group would use its powerful influence with the Nigerian Government to help secure the release of his brother, Ken Saro-Wiwa, a poet, playwright and environmental activist who was in prison on trumped-up murder charges.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Seeking the Meaning Of Being German Today
description: What exactly does it mean to be German? Few questions in our century have proven more formidable and fraught with strife. In "U-ni-ty," an enigmatic but powerful new show at the Museum of Modern Art, Michael Schmidt, a photographer from Berlin, addresses the puzzle of German identity yet again. He offers no easily graspable answers, but his stark installation of black-and-white photographs, some his own and others taken from the mass media, set up a tense fabric of suggestions about the nature of Germanness and the condition of German society.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Call this the story of the diva and the designer.

title: In Interview, Simpson Appeals for Privacy
description: O. J. Simpson declared his innocence once again in a live interview on Wednesday night on cable television and appealed to the American public to let him live his life in peace.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti Holders End a Syndicate
description: A key shareholder syndicate in Italy's troubled Olivetti group, led by the chairman, Carlo De Benedetti, broke up yesterday -- a significant move in a country where such pacts control many top companies. The syndicate, controlled by Mr. De Benedetti's CIR S.p.A. holding group, had just under 20 percent of Olivetti's stock, and its demise could weaken the chairman's position at the company, which he has controlled for nearly two decades.

title: BOXING;Botha Tests Positive Again
description: A second urinalysis test of the International Boxing Federation heavyweight champion Francois Botha has come back positive for steroids, the federation announced today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bear, Stearns in Greece
description: Bear, Stearns & Company said yesterday that it was joining with the National Mortgage Bank of Greece, the leading Greek mortgage bank, to bundle local loans into mortgage-backed securities. "The agreement with the National Mortgage Bank is a major step in our strategy to develop asset securitization in Europe," said James E. Cayne, president and chief executive officer at Bear, Stearns in New York. The National Mortgage Bank has total assets exceeding 1.7 trillion drachmas ($7 billion). (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Theodore Jungreis, 74, a Rabbi With an Imaginative Approach
description: Rabbi Theodore Jungreis, a scholar of the Torah and Talmud, scion of a Hungarian rabbinic dynasty and spiritual leader of an Orthodox congregation on Long Island, died on Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 74 and lived in North Woodmere, L.I.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Battle Over Trash Monopoly
description: At his swearing-in yesterday as president of the New Jersey Association of Counties, Walter W. Porter Jr., a Passaic County freeholder, gave a big yank in the tug-of-war between the state's 21 counties and 567 municipalities over trash disposal. Mr. Porter vowed to keep the current system, which gives counties a legal monopoly on the disposal of solid waste generated within their borders, enabling them to claim the dumping fees to pay off bonds issued for landfills and incinerators.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCDONNELL DIVIDEND INCREASE AND STOCK SPLIT SOUGHT
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that its board had voted to increase the quarterly dividend by 20 percent, to 24 cents, and to recommend a 2-for-1 split of the company's common stock. To facilitate the proposed split, McDonnell Douglas's board recommended increasing the authorized common stock to 400 million shares from 200 million. A vote on the stock split is set for the annual meeting of shareholders on April 26.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Rise in Immigration
description: Largely because of foreign immigration, New Jersey's population grew by 43,000 in 1995, according to Census Bureau data released yesterday. The growth, the 19th largest increase of the 50 states, was augmented by about 33,000 immigrants, whose number combined with the normal birth rate to offset the departure of 36,000 residents from the state, the bureau said. With 7.95 million residents, the state is the ninth most populous.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;After a Charge, Unisys Has Loss Of $676 Million
description: Still struggling to turn itself around after several unsuccessful attempts, the Unisys Corporation reported a fourth-quarter loss of $676.8 million yesterday and said that it took a charge of $671 million, largely to pay for the elimination of 7,900 jobs, or about 21 percent of its work force.

title: Bernard Rosenberg, 72, Author And a Professor of Sociology
description: Bernard Rosenberg, distinguished professor emeritus of sociology at City College and the City University Graduate Center and a contributing editor of the intellectual journal Dissent from its inception, died on Thursday at the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in the Bronx. Professor Rosenberg, who lived on the East Side of Manhattan, was 72.

title: Javits Center Lands Big One: Internet Show
description: In a business coup that may bolster the checkered reputation of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the organizer of the nation's largest Internet trade exhibition said yesterday that it would hold its annual show there beginning in December.

title: New York State Population Fell in '95, Census Update Shows
description: New York State lost more population from mid-1994 to mid-1995 than any other state, the United States Census Bureau said yesterday as it released figures that portend a further decline in political influence for the Empire State.

title: Beliefs
description: When the Rev. Harvey Cox, the Victor Thomas Professor of Religion at Harvard University, suggested in the Jan. 1 issue of The Nation magazine that fear and loathing of the religious right was pushing secular liberals into a self-defeating antagonism toward all religiously based arguments about public policy, he didn't have to wait long for a response.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Kenny Who? Gill Takes The Spotlight Off Anderson
description: It was supposed to be Kenny Anderson's homecoming. But Kendall Gill laid out his own welcome mat and claimed the Continental Airlines Arena for his own with a stirring performance that inspired more cheers for the Nets than boos for Anderson.

title: West Is Distant Mirror to China's Infant Deaths;How to Help Families
description: To the Editor:

title: 3D U.S. SHUTDOWN AVERTED BY BILL ON STOPGAP PLAN
description: The Senate today passed and President Clinton signed stopgap spending legislation to keep the Government open for another seven weeks, at reduced spending levels.

title: 5th Firefighter Is Vital
description: To the Editor:

title: Attorney General Settles With Union Over Bias Complaint
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco has settled a complaint that a union filed against him last spring, after he rescinded an executive order that banned discrimination against gay and lesbian workers in his office.

title: Sotheby's Is Said to Be Pressured to Raise Its Stock Price
description: The art world went on alert yesterday when an investment group led by the Bass family disclosed that it had increased its stake in Sotheby's Holdings Inc. and hinted that it would prod the auction house to raise its stock price.

title: There Was Nothing to Be Seen But Coverage Was Extensive
description: CNN had not been this excited since the O.J. Simpson verdict. It had legal experts to talk about strategy. It had political commentators to analyze the fallout. It had reporters stationed outside the courthouse to give live updates.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX: NOTEBOOK;League Provides a Lift for Cowher
description: Ah, those Pittsburgh guys. Here is Bill Cowher, the youngest head coach in Super Bowl history, his team greeted by a thousand fans wearing black Steelers shirts, as big back home as Mario Lemieux. In a few days he gets to coach against the Dallas Cowboys in Super Bowl XXX.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;A Sure Thing: America Will Watch
description: If Super Bowl blowouts are as inevitable as sunrise, why don't fans leave their television sets in droves? Why does the sports bar stay packed?

title: A Female Richard II Captivates the French
description: Shakespeare's ill-fated Richard II has often been portrayed as effeminate, as if that served to explain his easy ouster from the throne by his cousin, Henry Bolingbroke. For the British director Deborah Warner, however, stage effeminacy today automatically suggests homosexuality. That, she felt, would distort Richard's complex relationship with the future Henry IV.

title: Economic Surge in BangladeshUndercut by Political Turmoil
description: Each morning, as the smoggy winter dawn begins to lift, thousands of women in colorful saris, some cradling infants, walk in a silent tide along the causeway leading from the Baridara slum district toward this city's growing network of garment factories.

title: Harold Brodkey, 65, New Yorker Writer And Novelist, Dies of Illness HeWrote About
description: Harold Brodkey, a novelist, short-story writer and essayist known almost as much for his failure to publish as for the books he eventually did publish, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 65.

title: CBS News Televises Disputed Interview On Tobacco Giant
description: Freed by the disclosure of testimony by a former tobacco company executive, CBS News last night broadcast parts of an interview with the executive that the network's legal department had previously barred its "60 Minutes" program from putting on the air.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHYSICIAN COMPUTER IN VENTURE WITH GLAXO WELLCOME
description: The Physician Computer Network Inc. and Glaxo Wellcome Inc. said yesterday that they had formed a 50-50 joint venture to provide information technology systems and services to the health care industry. Physician Computer said both companies contributed product and development assets to the venture and would contribute at least $50 million more in capital, with $43 million coming from Glaxo Wellcome. The venture, not yet named, will be operated independently of the parent companies, Physician Computer said. Physician Computer makes network computer systems for health care providers. Glaxo Wellcome is a unit of Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. of Britain.

title: Renter's Discovery Lead to Charges in Sale of Stolen Treasure
description: The identity of the person whose discovery of a cache of letters led to indictments of the heirs of an American soldier in the sale of the Quedlinburg art treasures has come to light as the heirs awaited arraignment in a nearby Federal court.

title: BASEBALL;Two Mets Agree to Terms
description: The Mets cut their salary arbitration cases in half yesterday, reaching agreement with Bernard Gilkey, their new left fielder, and Todd Hundley, their repaired catcher.

title: Sports of The Times;A New Day Dawning At the Point
description: KENNY ANDERSON faced the press yesterday. Not the snarling, clawing press with defenders trying to break his stride, but the press with mikes and pens and pads intently recording his every word.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COPY MACHINE MAKER IS RAISING PRICES
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that it would raise prices on document processing products by 2 percent to 7 percent to most commercial customers in the United States as of Feb. 1. Increases for contract and government customers will take effect at the beginning of the next contract period. For convenience and work-group copiers, prices will rise 5 to 7 percent, Xerox said. Most departmental copiers will go up 2 to 5 percent. On Wednesday, Xerox said it lost more than $1 billion in the fourth quarter and $472 million for the year after writing off the costs of selling its insurance businesses.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNR INDUSTRIES TO SELL FOUR OF ITS FIVE BUSINESSES
description: UNR Industries of Chicago said yesterday that it would begin talks with several parties to sell four of its five businesses to focus on its Rohn telecommunications division. The businesses to be sold make mechanical and structural steel tubing; steel and plastic shopping carts; stainless steel and composite sinks, and inventory-picking systems. The company's Rohn division is the nation's largest supplier of towers, mounts, shelters and cabinets to the telecommunications industry. Its sales have grown to about $145 million in 1995 from $67 million in 1992.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Former Police Chief Dies
description: The former South Hackensack Police Chief, Arthur Montenegro, whose career ended in scandal, died Thursday of a heart attack at age 45. Mr. Montenegro's career as a police officer came to an end in 1994, when he resigned after being charged with ordering two officers not to file charges against two men held on minor drug charges. After pleading guilty to witness tampering, the popular police chief was sentenced to probation and community service. A large turnout of residents and law enforcement officers is expected at a 10 A.M. funeral Mass on Sunday at St. Mary's Church in Hackensack. JOE SHARKEY

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Pakistan Accuses India Of Shelling a Mosque
description: Indian gunners fired two rockets today at a mosque in the Pakistani-controlled part of Kashmir, killing 19 worshipers, Pakistani officials said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO BUY SYMBIOSIS FOR $153 MILLION
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Symbiosis Corporation, a unit of the American Home Products Corporation, for about $153 million in cash, subject to regulatory approval. Symbiosis produces specialty medical devices. Boston Scientific's Microvasive Endoscopy division is a client. Boston Scientific, also a maker of medical devices, said it expected the acquisition to bring "important strategic and economic synergies." Shares of Boston Scientific rose $2.50 yesterday, to $49.50, while shares of American Home Products rose $2.50, to $98.625.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Lakers Expect Johnson to Return to the Court Soon
description: Magic Johnson and the Los Angeles Lakers have discussed his possible return as a player, and several current Lakers said yesterday that they expected him to join the team soon.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Dutch to Make Loan to Keep Fokker Afloat for a While
description: The Dutch Government said today that it would grant an emergency bailout package worth $219 million to Fokker N.V., but acknowledged that the money would keep the aircraft maker from collapse for no more than six weeks.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;STET Will Acquire Chile Phone Stake
description: STET S.p.A. of Milan said yesterday that it would pay $270 million for a 16 percent stake in Chile's major telephone company, extending the Italian Government-controlled telecommunications company's investments in South America. STET said it had beaten out MCI Communications in the bidding to acquire a holding in Empresa Nacional de Telecomunicaciones S.A..

title: You're All Finalist!
description: These are dark days for the prize patrols.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Old Cowboys Set the Tone, And the Newer Ones Notice
description: It doesn't take long to learn what the Dallas Cowboys expect from a new player: Don't mess up. And when you practice, you had better work up a sweat.

title: Art, Lost and Found
description: One night last October Dr. Kathleen Weil-Garris Brandt, an authority on 16th-century Italian sculpture, walked by the French Embassy's cultural services building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan. A teacher at New York University's Institute of Fine Arts just around the corner, she had passed the building countless times, but this night it was brilliantly lighted for a party.

title: FILM REVIEW;Tormentor Turns Timid Until . . .
description: No matter how much we think we've outgrown our schoolyard traumas, most of us have peer-inflicted wounds that we will carry around with us the rest of our lives. That uncomfortable truth could be the springboard for a family movie of some depth. But "Big Bully," which opened yesterday, reduces the concept into a formulaic comedy whose smug psychologizing is glaringly false.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Suffer Power Outage
description: Jason Arnott's first goal in nearly three weeks broke a tie early in the third period and powered the Edmonton Oilers to a 4-1 victory over th' struggling Islanders tonight.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the special Business World Outlook '96 section of Business Day on Jan. 2, about trends in the book industry, misstated the ownership of the Borders bookstore chain. It is the Borders Group Inc. (The Kmart Corporation had owned the chain, but sold its remaining stake in August.)

title: Limited, but Useful, Health Reform
description: Two years ago President Clinton challenged Congress to pass a bill that would overhaul the entire health-care industry. In this week's State of the Union address, he settled for a much diminished, yet welcome, goal. The President called on Congress to pass a bipartisan bill, sponsored by Senators Kassebaum and Kennedy, that would make it easier for individuals with health problems to buy coverage. The bill was approved unanimously in committee in August but has been inexplicably denied a floor vote by the majority leader, Bob Dole, who two years ago sponsored a bill that included nearly the same provisions.

title: Colombia Vice President Rebuffs Embattled Chief on Vote
description: As protests against President Ernesto Samper multiplied today, his Vice President moved to distance himself from the Colombian leader's calls for a national referendum -- the political life raft he is trying to construct for his troubled presidency.

title: Thaba Bosiu Journal;Rain and Revelry Send Good King to His Grave
description: The coffin of King Moshoeshoe II, monarch of Lesotho for 36 years, was lowered into the ground here today as two elements central to this tiny nation's fate drummed down on the lid: the stony soil of Thaba Bosiu, and the driving rain.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Ever Quirky, and Now Gifted, Too;With $42 Million, Bard College Joins a New League
description: Small and slightly quirky liberal arts colleges tend to turn out almost as many poets as they do bankers. As a result, they seldom receive the king-sized gifts needed to entice talented professors and embellish their campuses.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Comeback for Breland
description: MARK BRELAND, the former two-time World Boxing Association welterweight champion, retired after being stopped in the sixth round by JORGE VACA on Nov. 9, 1992. That bout was his first since he lost the welterweight title for the second time on July 8, 1990.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L. Another Shutout for Carey Jim Carey stopped 20 shots for his fourth shutout of the season and Joe Juneau scored with 14 minutes 55 seconds left to lead the Washington Capitals past the visiting Buffalo Sabres, 1-0, last night.

title: AUTO RACING;Camaraderie Is Watchword On Eve of First Indy 200
description: The lineup for the first Indy Racing League event was set today, and what the field may lack in glamour it makes up for in camaraderie.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Still No. 1 in Auto Insurance
description: The highway speed limit might be staying at 55 miles per hour, but New Jersey motorists are again racing ahead of every other state when it comes to auto insurance rates, which are the highest in the country, according to a study by the National Association of Insurance Commissioners. The average annual insurance cost for a car in New Jersey is $964. The national average is $650. Elizabeth Randall, the State Insurance Commissioner, said being first is not a welcome distinction. "I do not want to see us continue in that No. 1 spot," she said.

title: Whose Wishes on Dying
description: To the Editor:

title: One by One, Bosnia Tallies the Missing
description: A worn, blue folder holds the information that keeps the wounds of war open here. Inside are the names and histories of hundreds of Muslims who have disappeared from the area. Fikret Kurtovic is the keeper of the folder in a dismal office where he works with two assistants.

title: Inventories Fell During November
description: Stocks of unsold goods on wholesalers' shelves declined in November by the largest amount in nearly two years, while sales increased, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Observer;A Oneness By the Tube
description: The Super Bowl is as phony as a tear rolling down a press agent's cheek, but how can you not like it anyhow?

title: COMPANY NEWS;BENCKISER SEEKS APPROVAL TO BUY MAYBELLINE SHARES
description: An affiliate of Benckiser G.m.b.H. is seeking antitrust clearance to acquire Maybelline Inc., even though the German company dropped out of a bidding contest for Maybelline earlier this week. Benckiser Cosmetics Holdings Inc. forwarded a Jan. 23 notice to Maybelline saying that the estate of Albert Reimann, a Benckiser co-founder, had a "good faith intention" to acquire more than $15 million and more than 50 percent of Maybelline's common shares on the open market. Maybelline filed a copy of the notice with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday. Benckiser's action, however, may be more of a contingency plan than an effort to pursue Maybelline, people familiar with the situation said. On Monday the company decided not to top a bid for Maybelline by L'Oreal S.A.

title: About New York;Making an Entrance Over Exits
description: BRUCE JAMES descended into the maelstrom of the West 72d Street I.R.T. subway station girded for battle -- strapped into a rock-climbing harness hooked to a day-glo rope. As he rappelled his way down the narrow steps and past curious stares, a police officer gently warned him.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Warship Cruises China-Taiwan Passage
description: A United States aircraft carrier passed through the strait dividing Taiwan and China last month, the first United States Navy presence in the sensitive area in 17 years.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Tagliabue Soothes Browns' Two Cities
description: Paul Tagliabue, the National Football League commissioner, signaled today for a fair catch of sorts in an effort to prevent either city from getting hurt when the issue of the Cleveland Browns moving to Baltimore is resolved.

title: The Flu's Lethal Future
description: The modern era of medicine dates back to the heroic figures of Louis Pasteur and Robert Koch late in the previous century. The microbiological science they founded generated a stream of discoveries about bacteria and viruses as agents of communicable disease, and led to the development of vaccines and antibiotics to control them. Equally important was the scientific foundation of elementary hygiene, from hand washing to precautions against sexual transmission of disease.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Hitting 100-Year Mark
description: When MILT GASTON talks about the good old days of baseball, he knows what he's talking about. Gaston goes into the baseball books today for becoming the eighth major leaguer -- of more than 14,000 players in history -- to turn 100 years old.

title: DANCE REVIEW;To the Sousa Marches, Balanchine's Valentine
description: The New York City Ballet is like a geyser erupting with renewed force, exploding with young and experienced talent all at once.

title: Adelphi's Finances Raise New Question
description: For almost a decade, the chairwoman of the board of Adelphi University on Long Island has been the prime insurance agent for the university, despite a consultant's finding that a rival firm offered more comprehensive coverage at a savings of more than $135,000 a year. The chairwoman, Ernesta G. Procope, is an ally of the university's president, Peter Diamandopoulos.

title: Mattel Keeps Pressure On Hasbro
description: Mattel Inc. continued its war for the hearts and minds -- and wallets -- of Hasbro Inc. investors yesterday as it made public a letter suggesting that the breakdown of merger discussions earlier this week was not a result of antitrust concerns, as Hasbro contended.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;MEXICO TO REPAY PART OF U.S. LOAN
description: Responding to signs of its economic recuperation and impatience in the Clinton Administration for repayment, Mexico plans to return on Monday the $1.3 billion it borrowed from the United States last year.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Flood Warning for Weekend
description: As the remnants of the Blizzard of 1996 melt away, with heavy rain expected, some flood-prone areas are expecting another weekend of problems.

title: POP REVIEW;Traveling Beyond Folk Music Basics
description: Dar Williams has a sweet soprano voice, an acoustic guitar, memories of a suburban childhood and wounds from ex-lovers. So do dozens, perhaps hundreds of other songwriters on the coffeehouse circuit. But Ms. Williams, who performed at a packed Bottom Line on Thursday night, also has the craft and heart to make the folky basics ring true again.

title: Panel Clears Plan to Enlarge Taxicab Fleet
description: City Council members cleared the way yesterday for the addition of 400 new medallion cabs, the first increase in New York's fleet of yellow taxis since 1937.

title: Inquiry on Seat Belts
description: The rear seat belts in 1995 Chrysler Cirrus and Dodge Stratus cars that were built before last May 15 fail to meet Federal standards for strength, the Government's highway safety agency said on Tuesday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARMIKE CINEMAS INC., Columbus, Ga., which owns a chain of theaters, agreed to acquire 12 movie theaters from Fox Theaters Corp. of Wyomissing, Pa., for undisclosed terms.

title: Pataki Budget Plans Increases in Park Fees
description: The Pataki administration hopes to raise $7.5 million by increasing fees at state parks, historical sites and campsites, a parks official said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Taxi Fleet to Grow

title: Hillary Clinton Tells Grand Jury She Cannot Account for Records
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton testified for more than four hours today before a Federal grand jury investigating whether there has been obstruction of justice at the White House in the inquiry into the First Lady's former Arkansas law firm.

title: Focus at Adelphi Widens To Board Members' Role
description: For almost a decade, the chairwoman of Adelphi University's board has been the prime insurance agent for the university, despite a consultant's warnings that a rival firm offered more comprehensive coverage at a savings of more than $135,000 a year.

title: Truth and Advertising
description: In 1988, Richard Threlkeld did a report for ABC News pointing out inaccuracies in a commercial by George Bush's Presidential campaign. But Mr. Threlkeld's message was lost.

title: Clinton Blocks Welfare Innovation
description: To the Editor:

title: TENNIS;For Becker Or Chang, A Slam At Last
description: No matter what happens in the men's final here on Sunday, a drought is about to end.

title: Saturn Plan For Used Cars
description: The Saturn division of General Motors plans to greatly expand its used-car business starting next month, Saturn officials said today.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a covert intelligence operation by the United States against Iran referred incorrectly in some editions to the goal of the program. As noted in the article, it is to change Iranian Government policies, not to topple the current leadership there.

title: Dow Closes at a High Again And Ends Week Up 87.07
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed at a new high yesterday for the third time this week, spurred by an easing of investor concern over the progress of Federal budget talks and by strong corporate earnings.

title: After 3-Year Wait, Arms Pact Wins Senate Backing but Faces New RussianOpposition
description: Today, three years after President Bush and President Boris N. Yeltsin signed a major strategic arms reduction treaty, Start II, the Senate approved it, 87 to 4.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Exploring The Pacific, Musically Speaking
description: For listeners who keep tabs on the migration of musical ideas, it is hardly news that original and captivating music is being written by composers from the Pacific Rim, a region that includes the west coasts of North, Central and South America as well as much of Asia, Australia and New Zealand. The Juilliard School presented a healthy overview of these composers this week in its annual Focus festival. Coincidentally, on Thursday evening the Japan Society presented recent works by Somei Satoh, a composer whose mystical, post-Minimalist works have found a large American following thanks to a series of recordings on the New Albion label.

title: POLITICS: CLINTON'S ADVISERS;Sharp Split Over Issues: Economics Or Values?
description: James Carville, the political strategist for Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign, will soon be on the book tour circuit with a prescription for the Democratic Party: focus on pocketbook issues like wage stagnation and measures to promote family stability.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by Dow Jones in Business Day on Wednesday about a research agreement between Human Genome Sciences Inc. and Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. misstated the size of the contract. Human Genome will receive $16 million over three years, not $18 million.

title: Fed Watchers See a Shave for Rates
description: To most economists looking at signs of a slowing economy and well-subdued inflation, the question on interest rates boils down to this: Why not cut?

title: A Humane Plan for Iraq
description: Iraq's increasingly desperate economic and diplomatic isolation seems to have softened Saddam Hussein's resistance to a humanitarian plan for feeding his country's hungry children. Baghdad has now agreed to talk with the United Nations about carrying out an American-sponsored resolution that would allow Iraq to sell $2 billion worth of oil over the next six months to help finance purchases of food and medicine.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Farrakhan, in Libya, Seeks to 'Unify' Muslims
description: Louis Farrakhan, head of the Nation of Islam, visited Libya this week to meet Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and discussed how to "unify, mobilize and organize" American Muslims for elections in the United States this year.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Boot Camp for G.O.P. Freshmen
description: The freshmen who marched into Washington at the head of the Republican revolution a year ago met here today for a midterm retreat, where they planned to lick their wounds from a year of battles and to gather strength for another charge at big government. Instead, they heard themselves lambasted by conservative hard-liners, whose visions made even the sternest among them blink.

title: Don't Tar All Street Fairs With the Inconvenience Brush
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: NEW THINKING ON POLLING;Changing Opinions Through Information and Debate
description: A little bit of reliable information, plus plenty of time to digest it and debate it, can be a liberating thing.

title: News Analysis;Giuliani Credits Strategy For the City's Safer Streets
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's public contemplation of reducing the size of the police force this week may have been driven by budgetary pressures, but beneath it runs a continuing argument over who is truly responsible for the city's remarkable drop in crime.

title: POLITICS;Big Blizzard in Iowa Freezes Candidates' Campaign Blitzes
description: Forget the old saying that the Presidential campaign does not begin in earnest until the snow falls in Iowa, site of the first caucuses.

title: No Headline
description: Many people see Eva Peron as either a saint or the incarnation of Satan. That means I definitely can identify with her."

title: Man in the News;Fervent, Tough Manager
description: Lawrence G. Reuter, the man who was named yesterday to head the New York City Transit Authority, is both a self-described advocate for public transportation and, transit officials say, a tough budget-cutter in tune with an era of declining subsidies and rising costs.

title: China Needs Americans' Help With Dam
description: To the Editor:

title: West Is Distant Mirror to China's Infant Deaths
description: To the Editor:

title: Cloning Thelma Baxter
description: A strong, resourceful principal can transform a failing school. Thelma Baxter of Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx is proving that axiom yet again. When Ms. Baxter became principal four years ago, Roosevelt was in bad shape, with a prominent place on the State Department of Education's list of failing schools.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Surges as China Buys 77.2 Million Bushels in 3 Days
description: Wheat prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after China finished a three-day buying spree of 77.2 million bushels, equal to one-fourth of the wheat produced last year in Kansas.

title: Bridge
description: There was a surprising oddity, perhaps unique in practical play, about the diagramed deal played in November at the Bridge Deck in Scarsdale, N.Y. A co-owner, Rose Johnson, sat North, with Rick Zucker of Tarrytown, N.Y., South.

title: F.T.C. Is Said To Investigate Toys 'R' Us
description: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating complaints that Toys "R" Us, the nation's largest toy retailer, has unfairly used its marketing power to discourage manufacturers from selling popular toys through discount stores, industry executives said yesterday.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants' DeBerg Is Arrested
description: Steve DeBerg, the quarterbacks coach for the Giants, was arrested and charged with drunken driving early yesterday morning after going the wrong way on a one-way street in Manhattan.

title: Frank Howard, 86, the Coach Of Top Clemson Football Teams
description: Frank Howard, the colorful coach who in 30 years took Clemson University from football obscurity to the ranks of the national elite, died yesterday at his home in Clemson, S.C. He was 86.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SARA LEE NEGOTIATING TO BUY SOME BAYER PRODUCTS
description: The Sara Lee Corporation said yesterday that it was negotiating to buy several product lines from the consumer care division of Germany's Bayer A.G. An agreement is expected to be reached in the coming months, Sara Lee said in a statement. The product lines include the brands, trademarks and related fixed assets of Delial cosmetic sun protection products, Satina skin care products, Quenty facial care products and Natreen/Natrena tabletop sweeteners and low-calorie food, Sara Lee said. Total sales of the products were about $155 million in the 1995 fiscal year, the company said.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Come to Boston As Bruins Reorganize
description: When the Rangers play for the first time in the new Fleet Center in Boston this afternoon, they will face a Bruin team doing some major retooling after a spotty first half. It vaguely resembles the Bruin team that the Rangers defeated, 4-2, in their only previous meeting this season last Dec. 13 at Madison Square Garden.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.B.A.;Sixers Say Lucas Stays For the Rest of Season
description: JOHN LUCAS can rest easy -- for now. Lucas will retain his titles as coach, general manager and vice president of basketball operations for the woeful Philadelphia 76ers, the owner, HAROLD KATZ, said yesterday. "He has my full support," said Katz, adding that Lucas would get the chance to finish the second year of his four-year contract before a decision would be made on his future.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMOCO RESOLVES DISPUTE INVOLVED IN A SALE TO POCO
description: Poco Petroleums Ltd. and the Amoco Canada Petroleum Company said yesterday that they had resolved a dispute with Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., clearing the way for Amoco to sell part of an Alberta oilfield to Poco by Wednesday. Earlier this week Poco, an oil and natural gas producer, agreed to buy Amoco Canada's interest in the Swan Hills area of Alberta for $145 million (Canadian), or about $105 million (United States). But then Gulf Canada filed a motion to block the transaction, saying it had right of first refusal to the land. Under the resolution, Gulf will withdraw its motion.

title: Man's Death In a Struggle Is Pronounced A Homicide
description: The death of a Queens man during a confrontation with the police last month was ruled a homicide yesterday by the New York City Medical Examiner.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Grant Money for New Officers
description: Newark will soon be able to hire 13 new police officers. The money comes from $4.6 million in grants from the United States Justice Department's community policing division announced yesterday. Nine other municipalities will be able to hire one officer each from the grant money, which covers 75 percent of a new officer's salary for three years. Almost $3 million of the funds are designated for new equipment.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Polish Leaders Meet To Form Government
description: President Aleksander Kwasniewski met with opposition leaders today on a plan to assemble a new Government after Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy, under investigation for allegedly passing state secrets to Moscow, submitted his resignation.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 18 about the new District Attorney of San Francisco referred incorrectly in some editions to the part of the local population who had undergone sex changes or planned to do so. No precise estimate is available. In a report last year, the San Francisc Human Rights Commission said informal surveys indicated that the city had about 6,000 "transgendered individuals" (not 10,000), a varied group ranging from those who have undergone sex change operations to those who dress as members of the opposite sex.

title: Indicted Aide Is Reassigned In Newark
description: Mayor Sharpe James said today that he had reassigned his longtime chief of staff, indicted this week on charges of accepting bribes in exchange for city contracts, to a new, unspecified job in the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Giuliani and Bratton Assail U.S. Judge's Ruling in Drug Case
description: For the second day in a row, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner William J. Bratton yesterday assailed a Federal judge for tossing out as evidence $4 million in drugs and a videotaped confession by a woman who admitted that she was transporting cocaine and heroin in her car.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Currents column of The Home Section on Thursday referred incorrectly to the museum that is showing a beaded kitchen as part of an exhibition called "A Labor of Love." It is the New Museum of Contemporary Art.

title: Speedy Ride on the French Railway Gives One View of the Labor Strike
description: Claude Bouquet has been working on the railroad most of his life.
