Today his day began at the Montparnasse station in Paris at 7:39 A.M., when he hoisted himself into the engineer's cabin of a silver-and-blue, super-high-speed train so streamlined it seems to be streaking along even when standing still.

title: President Plans to Sign Bill To Cut Troops With H.I.V.
description: President Clinton plans to approve a military budget bill that requires the Pentagon to discharge troops infected with the virus that causes AIDS, even though he cited this provision as a reason he vetoed an earlier version of the measure.

title: Movie Does Disservice to Mentally Ill
description: To the Editor:

title: Details of Tobacco Executive's Assertions Are Disclosed
description: The details of accusations made by a former research chief of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation against the company and senior executives became public yesterday with the disclosure of a transcript of sealed testimony he gave in a deposition in Mississippi.

title: Grand Jury Inquiries Tied to Clintons
description: The independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, using grand juries in Little Rock, Ark., and Washington, is investigating these matters:

title: Journal;Silence Of the Lambs
description: Which is the biggest scandal in Hollywood this week? The strange death of "Top Gun" producer Don Simpson? Tom Arnold's tasteless display of sexism at the Golden Globe Awards? The behind-the-scenes effort to deny Jane Austen an Oscar nomination for any of her three hit movies of '95?

title: TENNIS;Return Complete, Seles Takes Title
description: The record book will show that Monica Seles won the Australian Open in 1991, 1992, 1993 and 1996. What the record book will not show is that Seles actually won it four times in a row.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHIEF TO SPEND $1 MILLION BONUS ON COMPANY'S STOCK
description: Floyd Hall, chief executive of the Kmart Corporation, said yesterday that he would invest his $1 million bonus in the company's stock as sign of confidence that he would turn the struggling discount retailer around. Mr. Hall already owns 500,000 shares of the company's stock, which closed down 12.5 cents, at $5.75, in New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday. Mr. Hall said he planned to keep most of Kmart's 2,169 discount stores open, issue an unspecified amount of stock in mid-March, introduce a revitalized store layout that emphasizes children's and women's clothing and test-market a Kmart credit card.

title: No Sign of Shift in Talks on Apple-Sun Merger
description: If anyone thinks a deal is imminent between Apple Computer and Sun Microsystems, Scott McNealy, chief executive of Sun, is apparently not among them. He is planning to spend Saturday and Sunday in Monterey, Calif., playing in the AT&T Pro-Am golf tournament.

title: POLITICS: A CHALLENGER'S TEAM;Forbes Strategist Made Helms's Tough Ads
description: As Republican Presidential candidates compete for the title of Mr. Conservative Values, Steve Forbes is making his pitch with the aid of a campaign strategist who earned his stripes helping mastermind the successful re-election campaigns of a conservative icon: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;New Fraud Charges to Be Filed Against One of Maxwell's Sons
description: Prosecutors who lost a high-profile fraud case against two sons of the late publisher Robert Maxwell said today that they would bring new charges against one of the sons and three former company executives.

title: HIGH SCHOOL REPORT
description: Boys' Basketball

title: Battle Brews in Atlantic City
description: What happens when you mix tons of garbage, millions of dollars in proposed tax cuts and a couple of powerful competitors with outsized egos?

title: When Idols Collide
description: It is not hard to see why the producers picked Madonna -- wildly popular and practiced at playing sexually charged roles -- for the part of Eva Peron in a movie that is expected to portray the legendary First Lady as an opportunist who slept her way to power.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Approaching the Finale of a Daring Era
description: Of the six compositions presented this week by the St. Louis Symphony, only Haydn's Symphony No. 70 was written outside the present century. Leonard Slatkin is in his final season with the St. Louis, and his concerts on Wednesday and Thursday at Carnegie Hall summed up some exceptionally adventuresome programming over 17 years. Peter Mennin, Luciano Berio, Claude Baker, Elgar and Rachmaninoff made for a peculiar 20th-century syllabus, but the resourceful Mr. Slatkin made them work together, even when individual pieces caused puzzlement.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Korea Sends Food And Blankets to North
description: South Korea shipped blankets and noodles to famine-threatened North Korea today for the third time, but talks with the United States and Japan on further relief ended without agreement.

title: Bonn Orders German Cyberspace Off-Limits to a Neo-Nazi
description: The German Communications Ministry ordered a major German computer network Friday to bar access to a neo-Nazi's Internet Web site.

title: Losing the Insurer of Last Resort
description: It used to be that if you planned carefully, chose the right health insurer and paid your premiums on time, you could avoid financial ruin from a serious illness. That's the whole idea of insurance, after all. But as New York State moves toward an entirely profit-driven health insurance market, hundreds of consumers are about to get a rude awakening.

title: Brash Funeral Chain Meets Its Match in Old South
description: The O'Keefes have been burying Mississippi's dead since the Civil War, when an Irish immigrant who ran a livery stable in this Gulf Coast town discovered a lucrative sideline as an undertaker.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;New to the Super Bowl, Coaches Tread Warily
description: They have both become known for their ability to relate well to players. Their players say they would do anything for them, fight for t'em, play hard for them. There is no question about that.

title: Treasury Prices Snap Back From Slide With Good Gain
description: Treasury prices recovered strongly from early losses yesterday, halting a recent slide on revived hopes of a Federal budget agreement.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fed Watchers Expect A Cut in Rates Next Week Federal Reserve policy makers meet next week to discuss interest rates, and while many economists would expect lower rates, because of low inflation and signs of a slowing economy, the Fed will consider several unusual factors. There's the budget impasse, and the disruption in economic statistics.

title: The Neediest Cases;Rearing a Second Family, With Help
description: Carmen R. dozed fitfully beneath a painting of Jesus Christ as three children came bursting in after their school day, shouting hello and chattering among themselves. Her face broke into a smile.

title: Du Pont Accused of a Killing Holds Off Police at His Home
description: Dozens of police officers surrounded the estate of John E. du Pont, a chemical company heir and a wrestling benefactor, last night and into this morning because the police suspected him of fatally shooting on Friday a former Olympic champion who lived on the 800-acre property.

title: Yeltsin Principles?
description: To the Editor:

title: House Ethics Panel Throws Out New Complaint Against Gingrich
description: Days after the lawyer for Speaker Newt Gingrich called for their dismissal, several accusations against Mr. Gingrich have been thrown out by the House ethics committee. The allegations accused the Speaker of violating Federal election laws and tax laws and taking payoffs from political contributors.

title: Taking Roll at City Council: 'Here' Is Not Where Some Are
description: When members of the New York City Council approved $15,500 raises for themselves late last year, Councilman Jose Rivera stood before his colleagues in the Council chamber and gave an impassioned defense of his work record. He argued that the Council's designation as a part-time legislature was in name only.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ECHOSTAR WINS BIG SATELLITE LICENSE
description: The Echostar DBS Corporation, a division of Echostar Communications, won an auction yesterday for a direct broadcast satellite license that covers mostly the western half of the United States, the Federal Communications Commission said. Echostar, based in Englewood, Colo., beat out the MCI Communications Corporation with its bid of $52.3 million after 25 rounds of bidding. Echostar and MCI were the only bidders in the auction. Shares of Echostar rose 75 cents yesterday, to $25.50. "We are a lean, mean company with tremendous economies of scale," Charlie Ergen, Echostar's founder and chief executive, said at the auction site. The company, founded in 1980, went public last June as a maker of large satellite dishes and other satellite equipment, with the promise of direct broadcast satellite service in its future. The company launched its first satellite last month. On Thursday, Echostar bid for a separate nationwide broadcast satellite license but its bid was topped by MCI.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Camby Is Set to Play
description: MARCUS CAMBY, assured that his heart and brain are fine, plans to return against St. Bonaventure today despite his slight concern that he could pass out again.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Simpson's Interviewer: How to Strike a Balance
description: But first a word for the interviewer. If O. J. Simpson assumed that by choosing Black Entertainment Television for his first post-acquittal on-screen appearance he would be assured of a warm homecoming, he was not counting on Ed Gordon. In his 60 minutes of fame, the businesslike young host managed to resist most of the lures of the celebrity interview.

title: Whitman Budget Rides on Optimism
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman delivered her celebrated campaign promise to cut state income tax rates a year ahead of schedule, but she has yet to move as aggressively on her other campaign pledge to make government "smarter and smaller."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Fans Accused of Taunts
description: Alabama-Birmingham Coach GENE BARTOW said Memphis fans taunted his players with racial epithets during a game Wednesday. Bartow said the comments included "Hey, boy" and "Hey, boy, we didn't want to own you."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Love and Larceny at the Slots
description: It was a casino love story: boy meets girl while playing slot machines, and an instant romance develops after he learns she had hit a $10,000 jackpot the day before. That night, he tells her he is going out for Chinese food -- and walks away with $7,580 from her pocketbook. Yesterday, Ashot Manoukian, 35, a Philadelphia cabdriver, was sentenced to three months in jail for taking the money from a 49-year-old Morristown woman whose heart he won, temporarily, last April.

title: Firing Squad Executes Killer
description: John Albert Taylor politely lifted his chin for a prison warden to secure a strap around his neck before a firing squad carried out the killer's death sentence early today.

title: ROAD AND RAIL;Straightening Out the Perilous Somerville Circle
description: Out on the new, improved Somerville Circle, drivers still swerve and bob and weave. Hesitators, looking lost, still glance nervously over one shoulder, then the other. The brave ones still treat the circle like a racetrack, cutting across freshly painted lane markers to the inside, then slingshotting off at the exits like freed electrons. And still, though less frequently, come the squeal of brakes and the crunch of metal.

title: Sunday January 28,1996: OLYMPICS;Stop the Music!
description: The Summer Olympics honchos in Atlanta are not looking for a theme song, but half the world's songwriters seem to think so. Though there has never been a call for submissions, when Mitchell Gershenfeld took over as a producer of music programs in June 1994, there were already a dozen boxes of cassettes and sheet music awaiting him. Since then, hundreds of new unsolicitations have followed. Because of liability and copyright issues, Gershenfeld can't even listen to the tapes. But many would-be lyricists do include a cover letter. "My favorite," the producer says, "was a song I thought would be a great new slogan. It was called: 'Winning Is Important. But So Is Being Nice.' That was a lovely thought."

description: WHEN officials at the Brookhaven National Laboratory recently disclosed that radioactive tritium and a volatile hydrocarbon, trichloroethane, had penetrated deeply into ground water to the south, neighbors were angry and upset.

description: Karen Machover, a psychologist who developed a method of personality analysis based on an interpretation of drawings of the human figure, died on Monday at her apartment in Manhattan. She was 93.

Charles Millard had resigned from his East Side City Council seat on Dec. 1, and anyone who wanted to succeed him had just 12 days to gather the thousands of signatures needed to qualify for the special election in January. My friend Gifford Miller was game, and his mother, Lynden, and I were out there in the mean sleet with just four days to go.

The Rev. Thomas J. Mullelly, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated with Dr. Daniel M. Young, a Baptist minister, at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: JAZZ VIEW;One Who Dared To Be Different
description: IT COULD BE HEARD IN THE first bar of any solo by the baritone saxophonist Gerry Mulligan, a relaxed feeling that hinted at a type of happiness unusual in jazz. The work of Mr. Mulligan, who died on Jan. 20 at the age of 68, and of a handful of other white, largely West Coast, musicians was looked upon as the incarnation of the California sensibility in the 1950's and 60's. The music shouted its unperturbable coolness. More than anything it reflected a typically American optimism that flowered after the war, a belief that anything was possible, any adversity could be overcome. It was music from the victor's point of view.

description: In two weeks, Gov. George E. Pataki is expected to unveil his plan to create the world's longest urban waterfront park, a 4.5-mile strip along the Hudson River. His action will end a year of turmoil for the $300 million, 105-acre project, which proponents say will shape the area for decades.

A third of the 1,076 adults surveyed last week said they didn't care which team won.

Thus, LeBeau has not been squirming all week about the prospects of facing the Cowboys' massive offensive line, quarterback Troy Aikman's rocket arm, running back Emmitt Smith's powerful legs and receiver Michael Irvin's deft hands in Super Bowl XXX at Sun Devil Stadium.

title: A Witness to Her Time
description: RAT BOHEMIA By Sarah Schulman. 232 pp. New York: Dutton. $19.95. SO many books about AIDS have been sentimental that it's a relief to read one that refuses to find transcendence in the act of dying. As someone who is himself H.I.V. positive, I tend to avoid reading AIDS novels; the only thing I want to read is tomorrow's newspaper saying that a cure has been found. But given my high level of resistance, I suppose my surrender to "Rat Bohemia" is all the more a testimonial to its gimlet-eyed accuracy, its zero-degree honesty, its charnel-house humor. AIDS burnout has at last found its bard in Sarah Schulman.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;On Line, Finding The Right Room

In the voting last weekend, the Palestinians also elected an 88-member council dominated by Mr. Arafat's Fatah organization, although many of those elected either ran as independents or were known as critics of Mr. Arafat, promising at least a lively debate.

They may now occupy only a small fraction of available channel space in the growing universe of entertainment programming. But in the minds of the viewing public, they all have distinct identities, and they shed those identities at their own risk.

title: Rant, Listen, Exploit, Learn, Scare, Help, Manipulate, Lead
description: WITH THE GOVERNMENT STILL CLOSED after 21 days, the Speaker was ready to speak. "Hobson!" he bellowed. "Either sit down and shut up or leave the room!" Normally at a caucus of the 236 House Republicans official business competes with a buzz of background conversation. But on this morning in early January, as he stood in the high-ceilinged caucus room of the Cannon Building, across from the Capitol, Newt Gingrich wanted quiet. He had said so once, politely. Now he had a 59-year-old Congressman, David L. Hobson, hurrying to his seat.

TOWARD the end of Robert Cohen's second novel, "The Here and Now," the narrator's best friend, Warren Pinsky, comes back to New York from Texas and remarks that he misses Jews. title: For Croton, a Greenway Instead of a Wall of Condos
description: NEVER again will the Kitchawanc tribe scour the oyster beds of Senasqua -- the Indian name for the spit of land, now known as Croton Point, that juts into the Hudson River 33 miles north of Manhattan. But the masts atop a full-scale replica of Henry Hudson's Half Moon may dance in the breeze off the river's eastern shore, just as those of the 17th-century explorer's vessel did back in 1609. And, because of a recent deal that brought together the interests of a private landowner and the Village of Croton-on-Hudson, through the intercession of three not-for-profit land preservation groups, a wooded bramble of riverfront just north of the peninsula will forever be open to the public.

His sepulchral response to the State of the Union speech led his rivals for the Republican Presidential nomination to club him openly as a candidate who cannot defeat President Clinton. Having kept his well-known temper in check throughout the campaign, Mr. Dole then reverted to form, pugnaciously lashing out against liberal elitists in the media and rich-boy Republicans. The inescapable message for Republican voters was that their once golden opportunity to win back the White House was in danger of falling apart.

Dealers and customers often choose or reject films on the strength of the message on the box. In "Peace and Its Discontents" he follows his own precept well: few can match the pungency with which he challenges conventional wisdom on the Middle East peace process -- the belief that it is an ineluctably good thing, threatened by self-evidently bad extremists.

title: The Nation;To the Right Stuff and Back
description: A DECADE after the Challenger disaster, it is easy to think of Christa McAuliffe as an aberration, as NASA's sole attempt to get beyond the right-stuff syndrome, to enlarge the boundaries of the astronaut corps. The high-school teacher from Concord, N. H., who climbed aboard the space shuttle Challenger at Cape Canaveral on the cold morning of Jan. 28, 1986, hoped to share what she called "the ultimate field trip" with the nation's children, instructing them on the wonders of weightlessness and the riddles of the starry unknown. title: Books in Brief: FICTION & POETRY;  A Nation in Ruins
description: In 1946, a young American photographer named John Vachon was sent to Poland by the recently formed United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to document that agency's aid efforts in a country suffering from the catastrophic ravages of World War II. Vachon (1914-75), who had been part of a distinguished photographic team working for the Farm Security Administration in the 1930's, did not much relish doing official publicity shots, and most of the pictures he took in Poland were put away in archives without being published; but, as they are collected in POLAND, 1946: The Photographs and Letters of John Vachon (Smithsonian Institution, $39.95), they bring back, with a startling poignancy, a time that for most of us is a forgotten historical zone. In Poland, perhaps more than in most of Europe, the war didn't really finish with its official end; and in his trips across the country, Vachon everywhere found the evidence of a continuing battle for survival, of massive social rearrangement and of still-seething political conflicts. Cities in rubble, children with rickets, villages burned to cinders by underground units fighting the newest Soviet domination, inhabitants of formerly German cities being deported, repatriates from Eastern territories being transported in filthy boxcars: this could be a terribly depressing record -- and yet, oddly, it isn't. In his letters to his wife, Vachon, despite his political naivete, wrote with great understanding not only about the hardships he witnessed, but also about the courage and dignity of the people he encountered -- and his images convey this fundamental sympathy. In the many faces of strangely grown-up children, in the eyes of repatriates looking up with stubborn gravity, in the haunting melancholy of lone figures among ruins, in a family of peasants against a moody rural landscape or a row of women salvaging bricks from a crumbled building, Vachon repeatedly caught both the pain of what had happened and the sense of fierce life reasserting itself. These impressionistic and somberly beautiful photographs constitute a deeply affecting portrait of a place and a people struggling to emerge from a terrible war into an uneasy peace. Eva Hoffman

title: Only Connect
description: Primary Colors By Anonymous. 366 pp. New York: Random House. $24. THIS book was written by an artful thief, someone who knew just how much he could steal and get away with it. Although it is advertised as a novel, it tells the story of the 1992 Democratic primaries pretty much exactly as they must have appeared through the eyes of George Stephanopoulos. Almost every character, incident and setting has been drawn directly from life, and the author does everything in his power to make sure that we do not miss the connections. Bill Clinton is recast as Governor (of a small Southern state) Jack Stanton, complete with bimbo eruptions, a draft problem and a strident wife (here named Susan). The pious Governor of New York, Mario Cuomo, has become the pious Governor of New York, Orlando Ozio; Gennifer Flowers has become Cashmere McLeod (with tapes); Hope, Ark., has become Grace Junction (the state is unnamed). Even the journalists are impossible to miss: the oenophile R. W. Apple Jr. of The New York Times makes a cameo appearance as the oenophile A. P. Caulley of The New York Times. It is a strange reversal of the usual conventions of fiction. Only the identity of the author remains unknown to the reader.

There was a Greek-American, a Czech-American, Jewish Americans, black Americans and white Americans, there were Air Force crewmen from small towns and State Department experts from Ivy League colleges, and they were all standing there shoulder to shoulder. As they posed for the camera, I watched the Rwandan ground crew watching them. They had a slightly quizzical look. I couldn't help but wonder what the Rwandans made of this scene.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;This Must Be Love
description: The romantic heroes of classic literature are not -- let's be honest here -- good dating material. Craggy and handsome, perhaps, but sadly wanting in interpersonal skills. This explains why the romantic heroines of classic literature always end up with the short end of the stick, throwing themselves under trains and whatnot. In FRANKLY SCARLETT, I DO GIVE A DAMN! Classic Romances Retold (HarperCollins, $9.95) two writers (women, naturally) have reimagined a dozen of the great love stories, and this time each male role is played by a responsible adult who's in touch with his feminine side and not afraid of making a commitment. In Beverly West and Nancy K. Peske's version of "Wuthering Heights," for example, Heathcliff is not the wild-eyed hunk who was always making scenes on the moors. Instead, like Edgar Linton, he appreciates Cathy's "obvious complexity" and is willing to share her in a mnagetrois. In an alternative "Gone With the Wind," Rhett Butler tells Scarlett he realizes "the antebellum South's restricted vision of womanhood has been a tremendous obstacle in your path toward self-realization," then offers to cook dinner for the two of them. As for "Casablanca," forget the "hill of beans" scene on the tarmac. In this retelling, Rick and Ilsa escape with the stolen letters of transit, while the bisexual Victor Lazlo stays behind with Sam to run Rick's Place and explore "the beginning of a beautiful relationship." Funny but a bit predictable (Delilah encourages Samson to get "one of those trendy new blunt cuts," plus manicure and facial), the stories in "Frankly Scarlett, I Do Give a Damn!" remind us that love doesn't have to be tragic to be interesting -- but it helps. Patricia T. O'Conner

title: Science Fiction
description: Despite what casual readers might think, science fiction is not about prediction. The confusion arises because science fiction writers, in inventing suitable backgrounds for their stories, often set their narratives in the near future -- up to 100 years or so ahead of the present time. Occasionally, the imagined details turn out to be prophetic. But these are rare exceptions, and for a good reason. Except when a writer's intention is cautionary or satirical, the near futures of science fiction serve purely literary purposes: to sustain a particular plot, to give a certain set of characters room to interact. In other words, the narrative impulse drives the invention of a future, not vice versa.

description: STATISTICS NOTWITHSTANDING, THERE IS STILL NO SHORTAGE OF violent crime in New York and, therefore, no shortage of crime scenes. The Crime Scene Unit of the Police Department's detective bureau is the largest of its kind in the country, and the busiest. Based in the Bronx, the unit responded to about 3,000 calls for assistance last year, many of them involving murders; a few C.S.U. detectives were even enlisted to help investigate the Oklahoma City bombing. Some of the unit's 78 detectives and supervisors have also been trained as serologists, entomologists, embalmers, architects and engineers -- the better to determine just how a murder was committed and, consequently, who committed it.

title: A Hospital Winds Up With an Out of State Partner
description: ONE day last fall, Oct. 19 to be exact, started out as just another busy time for Victoria Miller, wife, mother of five and parish secretary at Our Lady of the Lakes Roman Catholic Church in New Milford. She was at work at about 1 P.M. when she first began to feel odd. Ten minutes later, Mrs. Miller had a seizure and collapsed. She was rushed by ambulance to New Milford Hospital where a CAT scan and an M.R.I. showed a brain tumor.

The companies said they planned to invest an additional $1 billion to provide entertainment and communications services. Earlier in the week, AT&T; said it would pay $137.5 million for a 2.5 percent stake in DirecTV, which beams 175 channels from satellites to home dishes.

description: The Emerald Isle Immigration Center's annual benefit, which featured an Irish harpist playing "The Battle Hymn of the Republic" while a rabbi invoked a blessing over the crudites, was one of those dull but worthy events that only a candidate could enjoy. description: Marilyn Hunte, a Flatbush resident, has frequently discussed the violence of the streets with her son, Jared. Clearly, those discussions have seeped deep into Jared's psyche. A sixth-grader at Intermediate School 62, he recently won first place for his poem on the topic, "Eliminating Violence in My Community," in the junior high school division of a citywide poetry and essay competition that commemorates the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday.

title: MUSIC;Three Legends to Offer Programs on Weekend
description: RETIREMENT is not in the vocabulary of two legendary performers appearing in Westchester next weekend. On Friday night at 8, Purchase College will be host to a concert by Lou Rawls, who for 40 or so years has been singing gospel, soul and jazz, essentially fusing elements of all those styles. The program was not available at press time, but chances are it will include such top-selling Rawls hits as "You'll Never Find Another Love Like Mine" and "Love Is a Hurtin' Thing." The box office number is 251-6200.

Cooper was an All-Star in 1993 and 1994 when he was with the Boston Red Sox. He has a career .272 batting average with 30 homers, but last year hit just .230 with 3 home runs and 40 runs batted in 118 games.

description: The only Senator from the Deep South to vote for the Civil Rights Act of 1964, Ralph W. Yarborough, a liberal Democrat from Texas who fought to expand the role of the Federal Government in assisting veterans, workers, the poor and the infirm, died today after a long illness, said DeAnna Dicuffa, an assistant who worked in his law office. He was 92 and lived in Austin.

title: Angkor Emerges From the Jungle
description: TRUE to the beliefs in reincarnation of the Hindu and Buddhist kings who built them, the temples of Angkor are being reborn in a new Cambodia. A few years ago a voracious jungle choked doorways and devoured walls, and guerrilla bands hid out there and mined the underbrush. Now the palaces, temples and towers of Angkor -- monuments created centuries ago by a little-known Khmer civilization that glorified an undulating green jungle landscape -- are emerging from decades of neglect and desecration.

title: ON POLITICS;Soon to Be Retired, But Not to Be Silent
description: It is pretty easy to call Bill Bradley a quitter, and a lot of people are doing it. Some politicians slaver and sweat for the United States Senate from the moment they make their first run for the local zoning board, so they can't believe anyone would just walk away from such a prize.

Razieh, the character at the center of "The White Balloon," replies, "I wanted to see what it was that was not good for me to watch."

title: MAKING IT WORK: Adiel Gonzalez, Without Crutch;The City's Only Quadriplegic Cabby Takes Life as It Comes, Remains Patient and Seeks No Help
description: IT is a rainy afternoon on West 31st Street as a column of angry cabbies honk and curse their way around double-parked trucks and jaywalking pedestrians. Amid the nerve-racking chaos, one cabdriver, Adiel Gonzalez, patiently waits as an elderly woman ignores the "Don't Walk" sign and hobbles slowly in front of his vehicle, the wind and her battered umbrella pulling her in all directions. Mr. Gonzalez, 31 and a quadriplegic, is unfazed. "I'm in no rush," he says. "It takes a lot more than gridlock to aggravate me."

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: HOTEL;Payoff for Pack Rats
description: Anyone who saves hotel bills from 50 years ago needs more streamlined record keeping, but at least now -- finally -- there is a payoff. The Willard Inter-Continental hotel in Washington is celebrating the chain's 50th anniversary by offering 1946 room rates to anyone with a Willard hotel bill from that year. Inter-Continental rates were $8 to $10 a night back then.

title: January 21-27;Japan's Surplus Slips
description: Always on the defensive where trade is concerned, Japanese officials are breathing a little easier. Japan's massive trade surplus with the world shrank in 1995 for the first time in five years. Its imbalance with the United States dropped a sharp 17 percent to $45.6 billion, using a calculation method that gives lower figures than the one used by Washington. The rise of the Japanese yen against the dollar in the last three years crimped exports of cars and other products, but it made imported products seem like bargains to the Japanese. ANDREW POLLACK

The less they see of the light, the better for them (and for those who rank them among the supreme achievements of European art). As for their being fingered and breathed on, as used to happen even in major museums, it is murder in slow motion.

Today, in contrast, the practice of using tiny needles to cure certain ailments is given a great deal of acceptance in the United States -- so much so that the New York Medical College recently began a training program in acupuncture for doctors and dentists.

I know who is not having sex (separate rooms, separate beds). I know about eating disorders (pictures of svelte models taped to an empty fridge). I arrange sex toys and dust prescription bottles.

title: January 21-27;Poles Lose a Premier
description: When Poland elected a former Communist, Alexander Kwasniewski, as President last November, unseating the anti-Communist icon Lech Walesa, the moment was seen as a kind of passage for a fledgling democracy trying to reconcile a bitter past with a need to recognize the governing skills of the old ruling class. But the memory of Soviet domination still shadows the political landscape, and last week Prime Minister Jozef Oleksy, a close associate of Mr. Kwasniewski, announced his resignation while still protesting his innocence of accusations that he had spied for Moscow. A former head of the Commmunist Party Central Committee's ideology department, he has acknowledged a friendship with a K.G.B. officer. Still he declared on television: "I resign because I am innocent. I was never disloyal to Poland."

For those seeking to restore the 103-year-old building, the castle bridges the past and the future, connecting Paterson's glory days as capital of silk manufacturing with the uncertain days to come.

title: HOME CLINIC;How to Maintain Heating Systems
description: IT is important for the homeowner to understand his heating system so that it can be maintained properly. Heating systems are usually characterized by the medium they use to transmit heat from the furnace to the living quarters. Systems that heat and move air throughout the house are called forced-air heating systems. Hydronic systems use either hot water or steam to conduct heat. This week this column will focus on forced-air heating. In the following weeks, the focus will be on hot-water heating, then steam heating.

title: ART REVIEW;. . . The Twain May (or May Not) Meet
description: THE premise of the exhibition at the Bergen Museum of Art and Science here is summed up by the title: "The Curator as Artist/The Artist as Curator." In a small statement, the curator, Judith Landsman, explains that it was born of her experience as an educator, faced with students asking where shows came from, what were the criteria for choosing artists and so on. Such questions seem capricious at best. Yet Ms. Landsman asks them of the present show's participants, believing that the element of the public that is hostile to art would be less so if it had, as she puts it, "access to process," a phrase that could raise a few hackles on its own.

The mezzo-soprano and the composer are Joanna and Lucy Simon, not Joanne and Elsie. The third sister is Carly Simon, the singer and songwriter.

title: Cuttings;Keeping the Vegetable Gene Pool Lively and Well

This bible has no pictures, which is almost a relief after staring at all those pinups of luscious red tomatoes, gleaming hot peppers and luminous melons from France. Every time I've tried to grow a melon, not to mention one from France, it has shriveled up and died, or it has ripened to tasteless mush. But do I turn the page? No, I sit there thinking, "Maybe this year."

Barry McCaffrey took over the United States Army's Southern Command, which supports drug interdiction operations in Latin America, in 1994, he spent a night riding around New York City in a police car for a cop's-eye glimpse of the narcotics trade. Last week, President Clinton nominated the four-star general as his new Director of National Drug Control Policy, a Cabinet-level position created in the 1980's (with lackluster results so far) to coordinate attempts by 50 Government agencies.

title: Sports of The Times;Win or Lose, Hall Awaits Cowboy Trio
description: THEY belong in a western movie, three cowboys riding slowly into a dusty town for a good time. The town toughs would know better than to mess with them. One can shoot you down. One can run you over. One can catch whatever is thrown at him.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Concern for an Assistant Coach's Welfare Increases Within the Giants Organization
description: When word spread throughout the Giants organization on Friday that the quarterback coach Steve DeBerg had been charged with drunken driving early that morning, few expressed surprise. In fact, many had been concerned for months that something like this would happen.

title: Eenie, Meenie;Picking America's Favorite Russian
description: AMERICANS are watching in confusion as Russia beats against the current, borne ceaselessly into the past. With Boris Yeltsin shelling villages, firing reformers, blowing the budget and placing intelligence operatives in key positions throughout the Government, trying to reinvent himself again before presidential elections in June, is he still America's guy?

title: For the Families, Painful Memories Are Revived
description: The candles flickered and the choir hummed and Pearl Montgomery McNair stood dutifully beside her son's grave each year when this sleepy town mourned him and the other astronauts lost in the Challenger explosion. But when anyone asked, she told them her son had survived the fall from the sky.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: THE COLLECTED POEMS OF LANGSTON HUGHES Edited by Arnold Rampersad and David Roessel. Vintage Classics, $16. Except for pieces written in high school and college, this volume presents the whole of Hughes's work: 860 poems, ranging from light and jazzy verse to passionate and sometimes polemical meditations. "Langston Hughes is one of the essential figures in American literature," our reviewer, Henry Taylor, said in 1994. He added, "His stature demands a collection like this."

title: ON CAMPUS;Deadline Nears for Part-Time Professors
description: More than 1,300 part-time faculty members at New Jersey's state colleges have joined forces to create a union, and they will soon find out whether the state will object.

title: ART;Japanese Buddhist Artifacts That Convey Profound Serenity
description: THE multitude of Buddhas in Buddhism may exceed the number of Virgin Marys in Christendom, but there is only one historical Buddha, and he is relatively well documented. Siddhartha Gautama, also known as Sakyamuni, was born (about 563 B.C.) to the purple in India, and it appears that he died there after a life of 85 or so years.

title: Conversations: Mae Bertha Carter;Deep in the Mississippi Delta, 1965, The Blues Was About Civil Rights
description: IN most eras there would be little about Mae Bertha Carter or her family that the world would consider remarkable. Black, poor, uneducated and the parents of 13 children, Mrs. Carter and her husband, Matthew, eked out subsistence as sharecroppers in the Mississippi Delta. Theirs was a world bounded by the unchanging tasks for the changing seasons -- planting, chopping (thinning and weeding) and picking cotton -- and by the subservience and degradation of segregation.

title: The Least Worst Land
description: A HANDMADE WILDERNESS By Don Schueler. 283 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95. LOVE stories come in all different shapes and forms. A work of nonfiction, whose primary subject is the ecology of a sandy, difficult parcel of land in southwestern Mississippi, seems a particularly unlikely one, but "A Handmade Wilderness," Don Schueler's fifth book, is a love story nonetheless. It is the tale of a man's passion for the bit of earth that he carefully oversees with someone he loves, and of their mutual devotion to and respect for the plants and creatures that coexist there.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Opera Less Grand For a Heroless Era?
description: NEW OPERAS, LIKE MUSIC IN GENERAL, have had a hard time getting over the 19th century. That was a time for heroes. Ours is not. The French had their barricades and Americans their Gettysburg; great dreams were inscribed on banners waved high and hard. We, it seems, are reduced to budget battles and dirty Balkan wars, yet our fantasies don't give up. Maybe this is why the public's embrace of the grand-opera tradition is more passionate than ever, and why we happily coddle its anachronisms.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Tyson Likes Cowboys
description: Although he has never been to a Super Bowl and admits he has only a "slight feel for the game," MIKE TYSON has a prediction.

title: The Prisoner of Beauty
description: Architecture critics almost never get to live in the buildings they write about, but for 10 exceptional days last July I did just that. My friend Seth Rosenthal and I spent our summer vacation at the legendary Casa Malaparte on the isle of Capri.

title: GETTING VERTICAL
description: I was happy to see climbing make its way to the mainstream, but I hope people realize that climbing in a gym is like investing in the stock market with Monopoly money (Style: "Getting Vertical," by Mary Tannen, Jan. 7). Yes, you can win and lose, but is it real?

title: CLOTHESLINE
description: Not since an airline's "Fly Me" campaign have I seen anything so blatantly sexist as your fashion article "Clothesline" (Jan. 7), which featured barefoot blondes -- wearing $1,000 dresses and daft expressions -- dangling from a clothesline over the words "So, is this what they mean by sundried tomatoes?" I can just hear your style editor defending it: "Pshaw, most readers knew we were joking."

title: A Business of the Cloth Finds a Surge in Demand
description: WITH the big "M" sewn on the front, they seem like ordinary letter sweaters from a Big 10 university. Until the second look.

title: A Coach Who Teaches Speed
description: KICKOUTS!" Danny Williams's voice echoed through the musty air of Darien High's old gym. At once, the members of the boys' indoor track team moved down the floor double file, lifting their knees high before kicking out, flamingo-like, and trying to keep straight faces while doing so.

title: ATLANTIC CITYCaesar's Palace
description: I LOVE coming back to this hall," Joel Caesar sighed as he explored the East Hall of the Atlantic City Convention Center before the opening of last week's Atlantic City Pool and Spa Show. "It's such a beautiful old building."

title: Corrections
description: A table on Dec. 31 listing the frequency of consumer complaints against major moving companies misidentified the company that had 3.02 complaints for each 1,000 moves in 1994, according to the Interstate Commerce Commission. It was Atlas Van Lines, not Atlas Red Ball.

title: Police in Virgin Islands on Alert After the Shootings of 3 Tourists
description: The shootings of three tourists from the mainland this week have caused turmoil, with the Governor ordering roadblocks, vehicle searches and a nighttime curfew for youths.

title: POP MUSIC;New Releases
description: MARK DRESSER: 'FORCE GREEN' Soul Note

title: Sunday January 28,1996: HARD READING;Hold the Mayo
description: Rejected authors are homeless again: the nation's only library for unpublished books is calling it quits. Financial distress and volunteer burnout have crippled the five-year-old Brautigan Library, located in Burlington, Vt., and based on one in Richard Brautigan's cult classic, "The Abortion: An Historical Romance 1966." The equal-opportunity library accepted all manuscripts without judgment.

title: Movie Madness
description: THE UNKINDEST CUT How a Hatchet-Man Critic Made His Own $7,000 Movie and Put It All on His Credit Card. By Joe Queenan. 310 pp. New York: Hyperion. $22.95.

title: No Headline
description: I did two years in the army to become a citizen of Israel like everybody else. When they tell me that since 1984 they've been spilling the blood, it feels like the army means nothing, that I'll never be part of Israel, because my color is black and my blood is contaminated. It really hurts. -- ZIVA TEDELA, an Ethiopian Jew who immigrated to Israel. [A3:2.]

title: 16 French Hostages Freed
description: Under threat of military attack, tribesmen today released 16 French tourists held in the remote mountains of Yemen.

title: Flood Alerts Lifted in Most of Region
description: Despite a weekend of heavy rain, flood warnings were lifted in upstate New York for all but one county by yesterday afternoon.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review in Weekend on Friday about "King Lear" at the Joseph Papp Public Theater misidentified the actor in the play's nude scene. It is Rob Campbell, who plays Edgar, not Thomas Hill, who plays the Earl of Gloucester.

title: Corrections
description: The real estate column in Business Day on Jan. 10, about leasing activity at the New York Information Technology Center at 55 Broad Street, misstated the building's previous use. The brokerage firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert was the anchor tenant in the building; it did not have its headquarters there.

title: Stepping Out of a Frigid House, Du Pont Heir Is Seized by Police
description: Saying he was cold and wanted to repair the boilers that heat his home, John E. du Pont walked out of his house after a 48-hour standoff today and was arrested by SWAT team members, the police said.

title: Russia Is Distrusted on Uranium Deal
description: The Clinton Administration is scrambling to fend off accusations that it cannot verify whether Moscow is cheating on a deal that was central to ending the cold war -- the purchase by the United States of enriched uranium from thousands of Russian nuclear warheads.

title: Bridge
description: The star American partnership of Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell capped a sensational six-month streak by winning the Macallan International Pairs Championship in London on Friday. With teammates, Bob Wolff, Bob Hamman, Nick Nickell and Dick Freeman, they won the Spingold Knockout Teams in New Orleans in August, the World Team Championship in Beijing in October and the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams in Atlanta in November.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings this week:

title: U.S. and France Suspend Aid After Military Coup in Niger
description: Soldiers patrolled Niamey, the capital of Niger, today after a military coup that ousted the elected President, Mahamane Ousmane, and France and the United States said that they had suspended aid.

title: New Hero as Cowboys Win Super Bowl, 27-17
description: There was no upset at the Super Bowl yesterday as the Dallas Cowboys won their third championship in four years, defeating the Pittsburgh Steelers, 27-17, in Tempe, Ariz. But the most valuable player was one of the unlikeliest of heroes: Larry Brown, a cornerback who plays opposite the celebrated Deion Sanders.

title: Police Arrest 26 in Raids On 14 Gambling Operations
description: Prompted by a rash of illegal betting on the Super Bowl, about 100 law enforcement officers and members of the Brooklyn District Attorney's office raided 14 gambling operations Saturday in Brooklyn and Queens and on Staten Island.

title: MEDIA: PRESS;Joey Skaggs, who delights in practical jokes on the press, has got a million of  them.
description: WHEN it comes to gulling the news media, Joey Skaggs is an undisputed pro, the Willie Sutton of the counterfeit news release. During the last 28 years, Mr. Skaggs has concocted more than a dozen phony stories and has had them covered by newspapers, magazines and television.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;UConn's 'Hoopla' Swamps Virginia
description: The term they use is Hoopla. That is how the Connecticut Huskies describe those moments when their defensive effort creates the pace they seek, when an opponent is being overwhelmed. "When everything is going our way," said Rudy Johnson, the senior who imported the term from his home in Jacksonville, Fla. "Everybody is getting layups. We're getting steals."

title: In Performance: THEATER
description: Grandma and Her Brood, Then Enter the Hunk "The Yiddish Trojan Women" American Jewish Theater

title: Even in Peace, a Family Is Balkanized
description: As children, Irena Tomic and her cousin Tanya Madjarevic played with Barbie dolls together. They were best friends by the time they were adolescents, enjoying summer weekends around the swimming pool at Miss Tomic's house in the wooded hills outside Tuzla.

title: For Anxious Workers: Wage-Hour Reforms
description: To the Editor:

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;For O'Donnell, It's a Game of Misreads, Mistakes and Misgivings
description: For Neil O'Donnell, all the bad things he had worried might happen to the Steelers did in Super Bowl XXX today. Worst of all, as quarterback he bears much of the burden for their 27-17 loss to the Cowboys: His two interceptions at the hands of Larry Brown resulted in the decisive points in the game.

title: A Drinking Water Dispute Is Personal
description: Four feet of asphalt stands between the Perrone family and clean drinking water, and the only man in this Rockland County town who can give them permission to connect to the public water main has refused to do so.

title: Out of 'Icebox' but Not Into the Cold
description: Howard and Patricia Tillem are no strangers to poverty, but just as they approached the breaking point a few years ago, their family was touched by charity and hope.

title: Don't Expect Many Colleges to Lower Tuition
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;No Bust-Out, Just a Hole
description: The bust-out turned out to be a bust. Hudson County officials have changed their minds about a hole in the wall discovered when 160 Department of Corrections officers in riot gear seized the Hudson County Correctional Facility on Jan. 19, the A.P. reported.

title: German Consciences
description: To the Editor:

title: Films on Junior High School And a Farm Win at Sundance
description: Welcome to the Dollhouse," a sly, hilarious black comedy about a junior high school girl facing the slings and arrows of preadolescence, is the official hit of this year's Sundance Film Festival. It stars a wily young actress named Heather Matarazzo and was written and directed by Todd Solondz, who accepted the Grand Jury Prize for best dramatic feature on Saturday night. Wearing spectacles and looking nervous, he bore an odd, unmistakable resemblance to his film's main character. Mr. Solondz, whose film was also widely admired at last fall's Toronto Film Festival, shyly described "Welcome to the Dollhouse" as "a movie from truly the most unpromising of premises, but really a beautiful thing for me."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lifeguard Receives Probation
description: A 36-year-old lifeguard who was reading a magazine when an 8-year-old boy nearly drowned last March in an Atlantic City pool has been sentenced to five years' probation, a year's house arrest, 300 hours of community service and a $300 fine and was ordered to undergo psychological counseling, the A.P. said.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Cowboys Overcome Offensive Crisis
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers knew from the opening series that this Dallas team was unlike any other they had faced all season. Linebacker Greg Lloyd especially knew. He was knocked down twice in that opening series by guard Nate Newton.

title: A Prison Blurs Colors of Gangs To Curb Violence Among Rivals
description: After nearly losing control of its prisons to gangs in the early 1990's, Connecticut has restored order by offering violent gang members a choice: Repudiate your blood oath to the group, or serve your entire sentence locked in a cell 23 hours a day.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Boy Wonder vs. Newspaper King
description: Beginning as an imagined life, "Citizen Kane" ended by damaging three real lives. The reputations of William Randolph Hearst and Marion Davies, the movie's undisguised subjects, and the career of Orson Welles, its maker, never recovered. Such is the theme of "The Battle Over Citizen Kane," which combines social history, movie lore a'd psychological interpretation in an engrossing two hours.

title: A Texas Paper In a Dispute Over Gay Editor
description: After one reader complained, The Fort Worth Star-Telegram transferred an openly gay editor of a weekly children's section and apologized for failing to oversee his contributions to a weekly gay newspaper.

title: For Alexander, the Spotlight Keeps Shifting to Someone Else
description: With his dark suit, crisp powder-blue shirt and blue and white checked tie, Lamar Alexander certainly looked the part of a serious Presidential candidate. Now, he was trying to persuade the 60 people gathered in a church fellowship hall on a bitter cold morning to view him that way.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Episcopal Stand on Suicide
description: Countering centuries of Christian doctrine, the Episcopal Diocese of Newark has determined suicide to be morally acceptable under some circumstances.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;In the quest to sort through a sea of Web data, a sudden flash of light.
description: WITH some 16 million pages on the World Wide Web, a gazillion entertainment titles, and oceans of data on big-ticket products like cars, soon we will need the rest of our lives to find what we want.

title: Man Is Held in Deaths of 2 Maine Nuns
description: A man with a history of mental illness was being held in the deaths of two elderly nuns after police said he broke into a small convent in Waterville, Me., on Saturday evening. Two other nuns were also seriously injured in what police described as one of the worst crimes in the history of the state.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;That Other Cornerback Found Right Spot Twice
description: The game was dropped in his lap.

title: California Treasurer Bars Goldman, Sachs
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has been barred from acting as a financial adviser in any California treasury or authority transaction because of a legal dispute with the state, the state Treasurer's office disclosed today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the tentative release dates for major economic indicators this week. The reports were delayed by the partial shutdown of the Government.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Orderlies Won't Be Charged
description: The Monmouth County Prosecutor said he believes that the negligence of orderlies may have caused the death of a 64-year-old patient at Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital. But the Prosecutor, John Kaye, said that while the findings of an investigation would be presented to a grand jury, the orderlies, who were not named, would not face criminal charges.

title: Spendthrift Priorities Delay Kenya's Bid for More Aid
description: When President Daniel arap Moi flew to Uganda last week for talks with other East African leaders, he traveled in luxury aboard a brand-new private jet that the taxpayers of this cash-strapped country bought last month for about $50 million.

title: 3 Britons Believed Killed by Bosnia Mine
description: Three British soldiers on a routine patrol in western Bosnia were presumed dead today after their vehicle was blown up in an unmarked minefield, and a 28-year-old American officer was shot in the neck and slightly wounded in the Serb-held Sarajevo suburb of Ilidza. NATO spokesmen said the American officer, Second Lieut. Shawn H. Watts, 28, of Greenwood, Miss., was back on duty after being grazed by a sniper at 6 A.M. today.

title: In Performance: THEATER
description: Solomon Falls for a Feminist. Now Really, Is That Wise? 'Sheba' Playhouse 91

title: Early Signs Are Promising for George Magazine
description: John F. Kennedy Jr. and his partner, Michael Berman, are sitting on top of the world.

title: Olga Havel, 62, Prague Rights Figure
description: Olga Havel, a human rights campaigner and wife of President Vaclav Havel, died on Saturday. She was 62.

title: Abroad at Home;Winter Of Discontent
description: Political scientists write about it. All of us feel it. There is a sickness in the American political system, a withering of the public faith in government that is so essential to our democracy.

title: HOCKEY;Islanders Lose Fifth in Row
description: Four games out West. Four more defeats. That sums up the bleak road trip the Islanders completed Saturday night with a 6-3 loss in Vancouver.

title: France Dismisses Atom-Test Protests
description: France brushed aside protests today over its nuclear test in the South Pacific on Saturday, the biggest and probably the last in a series it began last year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Taking Refuge in Sweet Visions of Childhood
description: INVENTING WONDERLAND The Lives and Fantasies of Lewis Carroll, Edward Lear, J. M. Barrie, Kenneth Grahame and A. A. Milne By Jackie Wullschlager Illustrated. 228 pages. The Free Press. $24.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Friday about Noel Johnson, a distance runner who set records in several age categories, misstated his age at death. He was 96, not 95.

title: Rig Count Down by 13
description: The number of oil and gas rigs operating in the United States dropped by 13 last week to 703, Baker Hughes Inc. said. During the corresponding week a year ago, there were 731 rigs operating nationwide. Of the rigs running last week, 404 were exploring for natural gas and 291 for oil.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Parolee's Name Made Public
description: Guardian Angels roamed Englewood's central business district yesterday, distributing leaflets identifying a paroled murderer and child molester whose name and address a Federal judge had ordered New Jersey officials to withhold.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Labor's Declining Power To Call and Win Strikes In an economy characterized by large-scale layoffs and growing insecurity, American workers are increasingly reluctant to strike. The number of strikes last year fell to the lowest level since World War II; there were 32 strikes involving 1,000 workers or more, half the number of a decade ago.

title: Essay;Good Guys Win 2
description: Hence, loathed Melancholy!

title: With Growing Risks, Strikes Reach a Low
description: Despite periodic battles like an 18-month walkout against Caterpillar, American workers have been increasingly reluctant to take the last resort of staging a strike. That led to a postwar record with just 32 strikes last year involving 1,000 workers or more, half the amount of a decade ago and one-eighth the level two decades ago.

title: Henry Lewis, Conductor Who Broke Racial Barriers of U.S. Orchestras,Is Dead at 63
description: Henry Lewis, who broke racial barriers in the music world as the first black conductor and music director of a major American orchestra, the New Jersey Symphony, and as the first black to conduct at the Metropolitan Opera in New York, died on Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: One European Currency: Is the 1999 Target Credible?
description: A single European currency by the end of the 1990's is a goal that seems as distant today as German unity did at the beginning of the 1980's. Then as now, politicians were swearing that they wanted it, and experts were telling them that it was unrealistic.

title: FLIGHT TO NOWHERE: A SPECIAL REPORT;AMBITIOUS UPDATE OF AIR NAVIGATION BECOMES A FIASCO
description: Stymied by mismanagement, the Federal Aviation Administration has squandered 15 years and at least half a billion dollars on a new air traffic control system that is still years from completion and already obsolete.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Iona Wins 7th in a Row
description: Mindaugas Timinskas scored 22 points and grabbed 9 rebounds, leading Iona to its seventh straight victory, 97-74 over Colgate today.

title: Newsprint Price Increases Might Be Limited
description: Faced with the near doubling of newsprint prices during the last two years, newspapers have compressed page widths, squeezed more content, including advertising, into smaller formats, and made their supplies stretch further by using lighter-weight paper.

title: Rabin Killer Acts as Lawyer After His Quits
description: Yitzhak Rabin's confessed assassin, Yigal Amir, cross-examined prosecution witnesses himself today after one of his lawyers resigned.

title: Tamper Not With the Fifth Amendment
description: To the Editor:

title: Marriott Said to Be In Bid for Hotels
description: Marriott International Inc. is leading the bidding to buy the bulk of the upscale Meridien and Exclusive hotels, which Granada Group P.L.C. acquired with the L3.8 billion ($5.7 billion) takeover of Forte P.L.C., according to an article in The Sunday Times of London.

title: TV SPORTS;In the Sad Absence Of the Spectacular, NBC Does Its Best
description: It is impossible to focus on the Super Bowl when you're expecting the Publishers Clearing House Prize Patrol. Where are they? What's their latest possible arrival time? How can I pay attention to a mere game when I'm fretting about whether to serve the patrol white or red wine with my $10 million steak?

description: The last time Boris Becker won a Grand Slam title, he shook hands with Ivan Lendl and sprinted out of Flinders Park to skip among the trees.

description: Uncle Sam wants you. Or at least your money.

title: Daiwa Asset Transfer Set
description: Daiwa Bank Ltd., which has been forced to leave the United States for covering up $1.1 billion in bond trading losses, said last night that it would sell its American operations to Sumitomo Bank Ltd. for $65 million.

title: 2 Companies Set to Introduce $500 Internet Browsing Units
description: The much-debated $500 Internet browser terminal will make its first appearance Monday at a computer industry conference in Southern California, as Sun Microsystems and Oracle introduce prototypes of the machines.

title: Seattle Boy, 4, Enthroned as a Lama in Nepal
description: He may be only 4, but his devout followers, who believe him to be the reincaration of a Buddhist monk, have waited nine years for his return.

title: Tax Stock Trades to Close New York Budget Gap
description: To the Editor: Re "More Budget Woes for the City" (editorial, Jan. 23):

title: Strikes at 50-Year Low
description: In an economy characterized by large-scale layoffs and growing insecurity, American workers have become increasingly reluctant to take the risky step of going on strike, causing the number of strikes last year to fall to the lowest level since World War II.

title: Patents
description: THE elections in November notwithstanding, the Patent and Trademark Commissioner, Bruce A. Lehman, describes his present tenure as only his first term in office. Settling into a chair for an interview at his headquarters last week, a panoramic view of the Potomac River and the capital behind him, he responded to a question about his plans for the agency with a discussion of 1997 and beyond.

title: Your Flat Tax, My Bonanza
description: Pass the flat tax, make my day!

title: Operation on Wrong Hip
description: The State Health Department has started an investigation into why an elderly man received an operation on the wrong hip.

title: Ruth Berghaus, 68, Director And Choreographer, Is Dead
description: Ruth Berghaus, the modernist choreographer and opera director and a leading theatrical figure in postwar Europe, died on Thursday at her lakeside home in Zeuthen, Germany, near Berlin. She was 68.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The writer HAROLD BRODKEY, who died on Friday of complications from AIDS, detailed his last few years in a series of personal essays, some of which appeared in The New Yorker magazine. This week, The New Yorker published the final installment of those essays, in which the writer discusses coming to terms with death as the disease overtakes him.

title: ON COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Paths Cross Everywhere but on Court
description: They left from the same airport for the same destination to play the same opponent in the same fieldhouse in the same week. If the Pittsburgh airport-mall was only slightly more gigantic, and the walk from the gate to the curb was just a little more exhausting, the basketball teams from Massachusetts and Connecticut might have stumbled into each other sometime 'ast Wednesday.

title: Free Mannes Concert
description: Kurt Masur, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, is to conduct the orchestra of the Mannes College of Music in a performance of Beethoven's Symphony No. 7 and Shostakovich's Symphony No. 1 tonight at 8 at Riverside Church (Riverside Drive at 120th Street, Morningside Heights). The concert, which is free, marks the 65th anniversary of the church and the 80th anniversary of Mannes College. Timothy Smith, the church music director, is to give a preconcert organ recital at 7:30. Information: (212) 580-0210.

title: Singers Cancel Recital
description: A joint recital by the soprano Camellia Johnson and the bass-baritone Simon Estes planned for Feb. 11 at Alice Tully Hall has been canceled because of scheduling conflicts. Tickets may be exchanged for others in the hall's Art of the Song series, or refunds may be obtained at the box office. Information: (212) 875-5050.

title: A New Gulf in American Education, the Digital Divide
description: At the bottom of the ramp here on the west side of town, two exits down Highway 280 from Apple Computer's headquarters, you can turn left and within a few blocks arrive at the Harker School, a pricey and prestigious private elementary and junior high school. Turn right, drive a mile or so, and you're near Anderson Elementary, a public school attended by children of one of the region's poorest communities.

title: When High Technology Meets Low Stock Price
description: Never much of a bean counter, Carlo de Benedetti is watching the numbers closely these days, as shares in Olivetti S.p.A., the electronics company he controls, are buffeted by a wave of selling that appears to reflect bets that the share price will continue to decline.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Bosnia Troops Watch Game
description: Outside, it was after midnight, and a forbidding-looking factory compound was swimming in equal parts mud and fog. All the same, inside mess halls and climatized tents, it was Super, er, Monday for United States soldiers.

title: U.S. Treasury Offerings Planned This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week begins with today's auction of new three- and six-month bills. On Thursday, the Treasury will auction a one-year note.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Howard Celebrates The End of a Drought
description: Coach MIKE McLEESE finally popped the cork on the bottle of Champagne that sat in his office mini-fridge for seven weeks. Howard University, the last remaining team without a victory in Division I men's basketball, had won one at last.

title: Birds of Prey Turn Victims;Use of Pesticide Occasions a 'Senseless Slaughter'
description: On a bright, cold afternoon two days before Christmas, Allan Shope and two friends were hunting partridge in the snowy patchwork of farms and forests here when they stumbled on what Mr. Shope called a scene of "senseless slaughter."

title: SUPER BOWL XXX: NOTEBOOK;Greene vs. Newton: Guess Who Has Last Laugh
description: Nate Newton had a quick reaction to Kevin Greene's sour-grapes remarks when the game ended. Greene was gloating that the Steelers had held the victorious Cowboys to only 56 yards rushing.

description: To the Editor:

title: Doing the Chores, With Relish and Regrets
description: When the building maintenance strike began 25 days ago, Michael M. Downey faced a daunting task: get the snow shoveled, carpets vacuumed, bathrooms cleaned and lobby floors waxed at 12 Manhattan office towers when his 1,100 maintenance workers were on the picket line.

title: Herbert Dow 2d, 68; Headed Foundation
description: Herbert Henry Dow 2d, the president of the Herbert H. and Grace A. Dow Foundation and a former executive of the chemical company founded by his grandfather, died on Friday in Houston. He was 68 and lived in Midland, Mich.

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Comparing The Minor And Major
description: Success doesn't come any bigger than Tchaikovsky's first piano concerto. Three times Tchaikovsky tried to repeat that success with other works for piano and orchestra. On Thursday night Kurt Masur and the New York Philharmonic, with the pianist Elisabeth Leonskaja, performed two of them: the surviving first movement of his Piano Concerto No. 3 (the recycled materials of an abandoned symphony), and the Concert Fantasy. Though they were interesting to hear, it was not difficult to understand why these works have virtually disappeared.

title: Bosnian Combatants Free More Prisoners
description: Bosnian Serbs and the Muslim-led Goverment freed captives today under terms of the peace agreement.

title: Hispanic Agents Face Hurdles on Border Patrol
description: When Sara G. Guzman, a United States Border Patrol agent, tells her father about chasing illegal aliens through the canyons and scrub along this stretch of rusty frontier fence with Mexico, he says in Spanish: "Yes, I remember. I used to cross there."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ex-Mayor Spared Jail Time
description: Despite a prosecutor's plea for a jail sentence, former Mayor Carmen J. Gaita Jr., 45, was sentenced to four years' probation for official misconduct and charges of intent to distribute marijuana, the A.P. said.

title: A Valuable Voice for the Fed
description: The White House is considering Felix Rohatyn, the investment banker who helped save New York City from financial collapse in the 1970's, as a possible nominee to become vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. He would be a worthy choice, a man of stature and experience whose views might help the Fed wring the most growth out of the economy.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Bulls Keep Streak Going Against Suns
description: Michael Jordan can be on a roll or in a rare slump. Scottie Pippen can be in control or atypically out. Dennis Rodman can be pulling down rebounds or nursing injuries.

title: Corrections
description: A picture credit on Friday with an article about polygamy among African immigrants to France misspelled the photographer's surname. He was Patrick Zachmann, not Zimmerman.

title: Sports of The Times;How Jones Bought the Super Bowl
description: IN other years the Super Bowl was never for sale. But this time it's as if several months ago, Jerry Jones, the ostentatious owner of the Dallas Cowboys, strolled into Tiffany, only five midtown Manhattan blocks from the National Football League headquarters.

title: Dev Kanta Borooah, Ex-India Party Leader, 82
description: Dev Kanta Borooah, a former president of the governing Congress Party in India, died today after suffering a heart attack, United News of India said. He was 82.

title: Argentine Military for Rent; Turns Swords Into Tin Cups
description: Strange things are afoot at Argentina's oldest and most important military base.

description: Twenty-one months after a young woman reported that she was raped in broad daylight in Prospect Park, the police are running out of leads, and detectives are growing pessimistic about whether they will ever find the attacker.

title: Joseph Brodsky, Exiled Poet Who Won Nobel, Dies at 55
description: Joseph Brodsky, the persecuted Russian poet who settled in the United States in the early 1970's, won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1987 and became his adopted country's poet laureate, died yesterday at his apartment in Brooklyn Heights. He was 55.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;'4 Saints' Flouting A Faded Dogma
description: It was 1934 and art was thick with Freud and Mann. New paintings or classic novels still greeted the onlooker with a surface -- a first impression -- but now that surface had become a door. Behind it deep significance was sure to lie. "What does it say?" was only preface to the question that counted: "What does it mean?" "Four Saints in Three Acts" appeared that year bearing an answer: that art can say something and mean very little.

title: Oliver North Supports a Former Opponent Over Another Foe
description: Oliver L. North today unexpectedly jump-started the campaign of a man who was his political nemesis by launching an attack on Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, who is being challenged by the former foe for the Republican nomination.

description: The Limited Inc., the specialty- store company that operates the Limited and Lerners chains and has a controlling interest in the company that operates Victoria's Secret, yesterday announced a $1.62 billion stock buyback apparently intended to lift the value of its shares, which have languished.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX: The Cowboy Way Is That Championship Season;Brown Plays Starring Role To Thwart Steelers' Hopes
description: The stars come out and sparkle the brightest on this stage. A star-studded Dallas team was the marquee attraction in Super Bowl XXX today, and the 76,347 fans in Sun Devil Stadium, as well as the millions watching worldwide, anticipated that the Cowboys -- and particularly their offense -- would reign supreme over the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about the United Automobile Workers' plans for bargaining with the Big Three auto makers misstated a provision of a labor contract between the union and the General Motors Corporation. If the company closes an assembly plant because of a strike by the union at a G.M. parts factory, the company does not have to continue paying furloughed U.A.W. workers at the assembly plant.

description: Magic Johnson's return to the court with the Los Angeles Lakers might come as early as tomorrow night against the Golden State Warriors.

description: Context is everything. Or is it? One ponders the question every time the New York City Ballet performs George Balanchine's "Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3," which on Saturday night featured Wendy Whelan's debut in the difficult ballerina role. Margaret Tracey had danced the part the night before in the season's first performance of the work at the New York State Theater.

description: It was thought that the Soviet break-up would be the end of its domination in figure skating. But if this year's European Championships, held last week in Sofia, Bulgaria, are any indication, it just isn't happening that way.

description: THE tumult surrounding Apple Computer Inc. is extending to the company's agency relationships.

description: ILANA VERED, the concert pianist, had an emotional reunion the other day -- with her piano. She had not seen it for a year and a half and had all but given it up for lost.

title: America's Role in Russia
description: With Boris Yeltsin clumsily trying to distance himself from his reform record to placate voters as Russian presidential elections approach, President Clinton faces a delicate and difficult time in managing relations with Moscow. The days of bear hugs and political partnership with the Russian leader are over. Washington now owes Mr. Yeltsin a blunt condemnation of his drift away from economic reform, and a firm policy designed to discourage further erosion by Mr. Yeltsin or a successor.

title: The Man Who Would Buy Apple;But Sun's Chief, Scott McNealy, Probably Won't Be Caught Overpaying
description: At the headquarters of Sun Microsystems Inc. in Mountain View, Calif., there is no corporate art on the walls. There are no company limousines or reserved parking places. No one is allowed to personalize the stationery, by having a name embossed on the company letterhead. Those frills cost money.

description: The grandstands were filled and cowboy hats trailed out the door of the hottest livestock sale of this year's National Western Stock Show and Rodeo: the elk auction.

description: Bill Cowher had promised that he would pull out all the stops in Super Bowl XXX against the Cowboys. It's the last game of the season, he reasoned, why not?

title: When Confidentiality Becomes a Curse
description: When a youngster known to New York's child welfare agencies dies from abuse or neglect, the public has a clear interest in knowing what officials did and did not do to prevent the tragedy. But officials routinely take cover under state confidentiality laws. Elisa Izquierdo's death last November reawakened interest in these outdated statutes, and a panel of the State Commission of Investigation has now suggested sweeping changes. The State Legislature, which can make these changes, should pay attention.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Uromed Corp., Needham, Mass., to the Sudler & Hennessey unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the maker of products to treat urological and gynecological disorders. The billings were estimated at $2 million to $3 million. Lockheed Martin Aeronautical Systems, Marietta, Ga., to Gray Kirk/Van Sant, Baltimore, to handle its account, previously handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Los Angeles. The billings were estimated at more than $2 million.

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stock prices were lower here today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 74.64 points, or 0.36 percent, at 20,589.20. On Friday, the index rose 249.15 points, or 1.22 percent.

title: G.O.P. Hopes for Communications Vote Soon
description: House and Senate Republican leaders will try to pass the stalled communications bill this week, increasingly confident that they have resolved a dispute among themselves over provisions that reserve a valuable parcel of the nation's airwaves for digital television services.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Recalling a Tough Mission
description: The memories were still vivid; the shock and pain still palpable. A decade after the deadly explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, some 20 alumni returned yesterday to the Valley Middle School to commemorate their intense teamwork as gifted eighth graders in a project to simulate the mission.

description: A shipping label glued to an explosive device led to the arrests of two men in the attempted bombing of the Internal Revenue Service building here last month, The Reno Gazette-Journal said today.

title: No Headline
description: Marie Sardella kept repeating the words like a mantra when the hours in her flower shop in Walpole, Mass., grew long and frantic during the holiday season.

description: Thousands of Ethiopian Jews clashed with riot policemen outside the Prime Minister's office today in a protest over the news that blood they donated was secretly dumped because of fear that it was contaminated with the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Germans Again Bar Internet Access, This Time to Neo-Nazism
description: For the second time in two months, Germany has pushed to the forefront of governments trying to impose state censorship on the Internet, putting pressure on a commercial provider of on-line service to block access to material the Government considers illegal under German law.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Is Army Contract All It Can Be?
description: The United States Army has begun conducting a mandated review, which is held every five years, of its advertising contract, with billings estimated at $60 million annually. Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York has handled the contract since 1987; the current contract is scheduled to expire on March 31, 1997.

description: NEW YORK CITY has an election coming up. See if you can guess what it is:
