description: Compuserve Inc., the computer on-line service, has unexpectedly changed agencies on its account, with billings estimated at more than $10 million, only six months after a review.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Just Trying To Be As Direct As Possible
description: K. D. Lang comes from the town of Consort in Alberta, Canada, population around 200, give or take a dozen. After she discovered Patsy Cline recordings in the early 1980's, Ms. Lang embarked on a singing and composing career that has included best-selling albums, three Grammy Awards and coming out of the closet as a lesbian. Her life -- she is now in her early 30's -- is given a charming and thoughtful close-up tonight on Bravo's "South Bank Show."

title: Bronx Girl, 4, Is Critically Hurt in a Fire She Set
description: A 4-year-old Bronx girl was critically injured last night after becoming trapped in her apartment bedroom by a fire she set while playing with matches, officials said.

description: In what is considered the Government's highest honor for intellectual accomplishment, TONI MORRISON, the Nobel Prize-winning novelist, has been chosen to deliver the 25th Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities.

title: TOKYO JOURNAL;Rappers' Credo: No Sex, Please? We're Japanese
description: Yuri Ichii is one of Japan's biggest rap stars, but it was tea that she choked on, not something stronger, when she was asked about rap music's associations with sex, drugs and violence.

title: Micron, in Reversal, Rehires Ousted Chief
description: In an extraordinary reversal, Micron Technology Inc. reinstated Steven R. Appleton as its chairman and chief executive.

title: Orders for U.S. Machine Tools Reached 16-Year High in 1995
description: Orders for American industrial tools rose nearly 17 percent in December, capping a year in which orders reached their highest levels since 1979, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said yesterday.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;In Big East State Rivalry, Rutgers Edged by Hall
description: With 15.4 seconds left today, Damon Santiago of Rutgers sank a 3-point shot from the top of the key, trimming Seton Hall's lead to 4 points. With 7.9 seconds left, same shooter, same spot, same result, and the Pirates led by only 1.

title: Guccione Halts Publication Of Omni And Longevity
description: General Media International, whose flagship publication is Penthouse magazine, has suspended publication of Omni and Longevity magazines and laid off 40 staff members.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The Eight-Man Shuffle Returns to New York
description: Don Nelson, who sometimes reinvents his te'ms faster than the 24-second shot clock can expire, went back to the laboratory over the weekend. Reasoning that the Knicks need something to cure their inconsistency, he said he was returning to an eight-man rotation much sooner than he would have liked.

title: Chief Leaves Unit of Western Publishing
description: The president and chief executive of the Western Publishing Company has resigned after eight months and returned to Pearson P.L.C., his former employer.

title: Polluter Released Early
description: Evelyn Berman Frank, 80, who pleaded guilty in 1990 to dumping tons of sludge into New York Harbor and off New Jersey beaches, has been released from prison after serving nine months of a three-year sentence.

title: Bob Pastor, Boxer, 82
description: Bob Pastor, a Manhattan-born boxer who achieved brief glory by entering the ring twice against the famed heavyweight champion Joe Louis, died of pneumonia Friday at a nursing home in Saratoga Springs, Fla. He was 82.

title: Eat, Sleep and Breathe Politics on Internet
description: Three Internet services will allow fans of this year's Presidential race to play campaign manager and dissect the raw fixings of political news -- including polls, speech texts, ad scripts, videotapes of candidates' appearances and even copies of their tax returns.

title: Forbes Gathers Strength as Other Republicans Try to Wait Out Storm
description: When a television light above his head burned out with a pop and a sizzle while he was speaking here at the Globe firefighting equipment factory on Saturday, Senator Bob Dole did not miss a beat.

title: HOCKEY;First-Rate Performance By Second-String Healy
description: The rectangular goal frame measures 24 square feet. The round, flat puck is one inch thick and three inches in diameter. It travels at various speeds, at various heights, from various directions.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Losing a Friend and Finding Violence
description: Contemporary fiction doesn't get much better than "The Butcher Boy," Patrick McCabe's hypnotic 1992 novel about a psychopathic youth in provincial Ireland. Told entirely from the perspective of its disturbed narrator, the book achieves a Joycean, rhythmic stream of consciousness that seems to take over its readers' own thought patterns. It is a gratifying rarity: a sustained piece of bravura in which every technical risk pays off.

title: Empire Needs Washington's Help
description: An unintended quirk in Federal law threatens to strip about 640 chronically ill New Yorkers of their private health insurance with Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Some advocates for the potential victims have fingered Empire as the villain. But Empire did not create the problem, nor can Empire solve it.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the continuing influence of former Mayor Edward I. Koch misstated the age of his confidant Dan Wolf, former owner of The Village Voice. He is 80, not 81.

title: Please Admit Poor, Pitiful Me
description: As a graduate of University of California at Berkeley, I was fascinated by the Board of Regents's new affirmative action guidelines that consider social and economic disadvantage instead of the race and sex criteria of yesteryear. Admissions officers will give preference to students from "difficult family situations," which applicants can describe in personal essays.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Legal Action Planned
description: The manager for MATS WILANDER said yesterday that the Swedish player denied allegations that he took drugs and said he was taking legal action against the International Tennis Federation. BILL RYAN, the manager, told the Swedish news media that Wilander would sue the I.T.F. for breach of contract in a London court.

title: Colombia in Crisis
description: President Ernesto Samper of Colombia has been under growing pressure to resign since his closest political associate charged earlier this month that Mr. Samper knowingly accepted huge campaign contributions from leaders of the Cali cocaine cartel when he ran for president in 1994. Mr. Samper denies the charges and refuses to step aside, offering instead a national referendum on his political future.

title: U.S. Pinpoints Weapons Caches in Austria
description: The United States Ambassador, Swanee Hunt, handed over an envelope today giving the location and contents of 79 arms caches the Americans set up in Austria in the early 1950's.

title: Heinz Weissenstein, 84, a Photographer
description: Heinz H. Weissenstein, a photographer whose work dealt with musicians and social organizations, died on Saturday in the Berkshire Medical Center in Pittsfield, Mass. He was 84 and lived in Lenox, Mass.

title: Apology in Dispute on Affirmative Action
description: The president of the University of California apologized today to the governing Regents of the nine-campus system for trying to delay their much-disputed order banning affirmative action in student admissions, saying he should not have acted on the matter unilaterally. And he offered a compromise that would split the difference between his proposed date and the board's.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;RHONE-POULENC RORER INC. (RPR,N)
description: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 67 percent, mainly because of charges for the purchase of Fisons P.L.C.. The company said it would cut its work force by about 10 percent, or 2,900 jobs, through dismissals and the sale of businesses.

title: G.O.P. MAY REVIVE A WELFARE PLAN TO SNARE CLINTON
description: In a shift that could cause intense political difficulty for the White House, many leading House Republicans say they now want to pass the Senate version of a vast welfare bill, which President Clinton endorsed four months ago.

title: Japan to Extend Its Bailout Plan
description: The Japanese Cabinet approved a plan today to allocate more public money to cover losses at bankrupt housing lenders, a measure that could increase the bailout's cost to more than $10 billion.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;VW Deliveries Up 8.3%
description: Volkswagen A.G., Europe's largest car maker, said yesterday that its worldwide deliveries climbed 8.3 percent in 1995, to 3.6 million vehicles. The largest jump in deliveries came in China, where they surged 49.3 percent, to 221,700 units, but deliveries in North America fell 31.9 percent, to 202,700. Although overall North American business fell, deliveries in the United States climbed 21.7 percent, to 133,200. (Reuters)

title: 3 Out of Loop in the Cabinet Are Campaign Assets
description: They are among the people Bill Clinton brought to Washington to give his Cabinet the face of America. The new-age, government-can-do-good thinkers who were supposed to help him enact the new Democratic agenda for the 1990's.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;High Rollers in the World of Campaign Financing
description: Even if the news that big political contributors receive big favors does not knock you off the couch, tonight's peppy offering from "Frontline" provides enough details of how the system works to confirm your most cynical assumptions. "So You Want to Buy a President?" demonstrates that an investigative report can be humorous without being trivial, serious without being shrill.

title: On My Mind;Contempt In Court
description: The strength of major democratic institutions depends on something that can be neither commanded nor enacted -- whether the public comes to think of them with respect or contempt.

title: U.S. Memo On Israel Cited Its Spy Aims
description: A Defense Department employee sent a confidential memorandum to American military contractors last month warning that Israel would try to spy on them and to use the religious affinities of their Jewish employees to obtain secret information.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Whitman's Welfare Plan
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed an overhaul of the state welfare program that would help ease the transition to work and would let beneficiaries earn more outside income. But under the plan, benefits would be limited to five years, recipients would have to stay current with child support payments, and teen-age recipients would have to stay in school and live with an adult. [Page A1.]

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;South Africa Gunmen Kill 8 Job-Seekers
description: South African gunmen killed eight people and wounded 23 today in an attack on job-seekers that the governing party says may have been intended to undermine peace efforts in a violence-racked province.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NABISCO HOLDINGS CORP. (NA,N)
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 3 percent because of tough competition in the cookie, cracker and nut markets and the costs of introducing products.

title: Two Portraits Lay Firebombing of Subway To 'Twisted' Rage or theEffects of Prozac
description: Enraged at his failure to find a job as a computer technician and burdened with debt, Edward J. Leary plotted to extort money from the Transit Authority by planning a series of subway bombings, a prosecutor charged yesterday at the beginning of Mr. Leary's trial.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SMITH'S AGREES TO A STOCK SWAP FOR SMITTY'S
description: Smith's Food and Drug Centers said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Smitty's 28 supermarkets in Phoenix and Tucson, Ariz., for stock and debt totaling about $239.5 million. Smith's said it would swap more than three million shares of its class B common stock for all of Smitty's outstanding common stock, and would assume or refinance about $148 million of Smitty's debt. On Jan. 15, Smith's said it was calling off merger talks with Smitty's, an Arizona supermarket chain controlled by the Yucaipa Companies, a Los Angeles-based private investment company. Smith's did not say what caused a resumption of the talks. Also, Smith's offered to buy back 50 percent of its class A and class B stock for $36 a share. Smith's stock fell $3.625, to $26.50, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Dow Closes Above 5,300 on Rate-Cut Hopes
description: The stock market rose yesterday, as traders responded to strong earnings reports and hoped the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates this week.

title: Discipline or Abuse? Arrest Renews a Debate
description: Korey Wax had behaved so badly in school that he was suspended, and when he got home, his father punished the 8-year-old further, whacking him several times across the back and chest with a three-foot rubber snake, the kind that people win in carnival booths.

title: U.S. PC Makers Don't Gain Any Market Share in Japan
description: Makers of American personal computers stopped gaining market share in Japan last year, having brought about ferocious price competition by their Japanese competitors, a market research firm reported today.

title: Saul Goodman, 89, a Timpanist Who Made Drums Sing, Is Dead
description: Saul Goodman, who turned a chance teen-age encounter with a set of kettledrums into an acclaimed 46-year career as the principal timpanist of the New York Philharmonic, died on Friday in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89.

title: How Plan By Pataki Compares
description: In a wide-ranging plan presented late last year as part of his budget package, Gov. George E. Pataki is trying to prod people off New York's welfare rolls through strict eligibility requirements and incentives for recipients to enter the work force.

title: Apple Freezes Most Spending For Research
description: Uncertainty about Apple Computer Inc.'s future continued to gnaw at the company today, as Apple froze most research spending, while Standard & Poor's downgraded Apple's debt rating and a selloff pushed the company's shares to a 52-week closing low.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RELIANCE TRUST TO BUY BANK SOUTH PORTFOLIO
description: The Reliance Trust Company, a fast-growing independent trust company based in Georgia, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Bank South Corporation's $3.5 billion corporate trust portfolio for an undisclosed price. The portfolio, which consists primarily of state and local municipal bonds in addition to regional and national securities, is expected to raise Reliance's portfolio to $6 billion. Reliance has serviced Bank South's 400 corporate trust accounts since 1993, when it received the option to buy Bank South's corporate trust business if Bank South was ever acquired. Earlier this month, the Nationsbank Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., completed its $1.69 billion acquisition of Bank South, gaining dominance in Georgia.

title: 240 Million Is Offered for Leslie Fay Unit
description: A new suitor has surfaced for Sassco, the most profitable division of the Leslie Fay Companies, the women's apparel manufacturer that has languished in bankruptcy protection for almost three years.

title: Berlin Journal;A Curator Who Doesn't Blush Easily
description: Half a century ago, a young German war widow named Beate Uhse began selling understated sex manuals from the back of her bicycle in the northern town of Flensburg. Now she is believed to be both the world's largest vendor of sex-related items and one of Germany's best-known personalities.

title: By Design;Shantung: Count the Ways
description: After several decades in disfavor, old-fashioned silk shantung -- that shiny slubbed fabric that takes color so beautifully -- has made a strong comeback in resort and spring collections.

title: Second Greatest Toolmaker? A Title Crows Can Crow About
description: THE cognitive ability to design, make, standardize and use tools is widely thought to be a hallmark of human society, exceeding the capacity even of chimpanzees, mankind's brightest primate relatives. But a biologist who has spent three years studying a breed of crows in South Pacific rain forests reports that the birds actually make tool kits to extract worms and other prey from holes in trees and dead wood.

title: POLITICS: IN CONGRESS;An Anti-PAC Fight Angers G.O.P.
description: In control of Congress for the first time in 40 years, Republicans are proving to be as adept as Democrats in using their majority status to raise money for re-election.
