description: To the Editor:

title: Learning With Less
description: In offering his vision last week for the public schools of New York City, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew described a retooled system where every student would read at grade level by third grade, master a foreign language and, perhaps, calculus by the 12th, and graduate on time.

title: Japanese Stocks Gain
description: Stocks traded higher here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues rose 133.24 points, or 0.65 percent, to 20,722.44. On Monday, the index lost 74.64 points.

title: Whitman Plans Welfare Limits And Incentives to Promote Work
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed an overhaul of the state welfare program today that would provide more help to ease the transition to work and would let beneficiaries earn more outside income.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Slings and Arrows Do Not Stop Dallas
description: Imagine pulling boiling coffee from a microwave and attempting to drink it instantly. Imagine biting into the coldest ice cream and expecting it to melt at the touch.

title: Senate Confirms a Nominee for the S.E.C.
description: After an extended delay, the Senate has approved the nomination of an Ohio law professor, Isaac C. Hunt Jr., to fill a vacant seat on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Saudi Gadfly and British Embarrassment
description: Each Friday for nearly two years, Mohammed al-Masari has faxed a newsletter to contacts in his native Saudi Arabia, reporting on what he calls the rampant corruption, human rights abuses and tyranny of the Saudi royal family.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KENT R. WEEKS, an archeologist and a professor of Egyptology at the American University in Cairo, is not a movie star, a television personality or a best-selling author. But he now has an indisputable marker of celebrity: a stable of agents at the William Morris agency.

title: Kevorkian Attends Another Death; Woman's Body Is Left in Van
description: Barely two weeks before he is scheduled to face trial for assisting in two 1993 suicides, Dr. Jack Kevorkian attended the death of a 48-year-old Wisconsin woman whose body was left in the retired pathologist's battered 1968 Volkswagen van outside the medical examiner's office here.

title: Taxis to Begin Flat $30 Fare For Kennedy
description: For thousands of tourists, business travelers and New Yorkers returning home who stream through Kennedy International Airport every day, life just became a little simpler. Starting today, the taxi fare from the airport to Manhattan is $30, no matter what.

title: POLITICS: THE DEBATES;Sites Are Proposed for Candidates to Face Off
description: The nonpartisan commission that organizes the Presidential and Vice-Presidential debates recommended today that St. Louis, St. Petersburg, Fla., San Diego and Hartford be the sites for four debates this fall.

title: BASKETBALL;Ewing Rules the Paint as Knicks Top Heat
description: Patrick Ewing had already burned him on the blocks and Hubert Davis had already burned him from the beyond the 3-point arc. It was then that Pat Riley began going on about how the Knicks should get more credit for their accomplishments, how, candlelight vigils and all, he expects them to "be there at the end."

title: Acquisition by Thomson
description: The Thomson Corporation's publishing unit said today that it had acquired Coriolis Group Inc. of Scottsdale, for an undisclosed amount. Coriolis publishes books, a magazine and computer software that is used to browse the Internet and is also used by professional software programmers. Thomson, which is based in Toronto, bought Coriolis through its International Thomson Publishing unit of Stamford, Conn.

title: Parts Contract From G.M.
description: Johnson Controls Inc. and Chivas Products Ltd. have received a six-year, $900 million contract from the General Motors Corporation to produce parts for interiors of G.M. vehicles, the auto maker said today. Johnson Controls and Chivas Products, a privately held, minority-owned company in Sterling Heights, Mich., will build a manufacturing plant in Detroit. Chivas will have majority ownership in the venture. Johnson Controls, of Milwaukee, will be responsible for product design, engineering and development, while Chivas will make the products.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Samsung May Provide Aid for Fokker
description: Hopes rose yesterday for the survival of the Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V. after a South Korean rival emerged as a potential rescuer and speculators drove Fokker's stock higher. Fokker has been scrambling for a partner since its German parent company, Daimler-Benz A.G., cut off a cash lifeline a week ago.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Holding Fate in Their Hand Gives Solace to the Steelers
description: The Steelers' backup tackle James Parrish, who won a Super Bowl ring with the Cowboys in 1993, has been on both sides now. If he was broken up about Pittsburgh's 27-17 loss to Dallas in Super Bowl XXX he wasn't showing it.

title: Dr. Elizabeth Monroe Boggs, 82, Founder of Group for Retarded
description: Dr. Elizabeth Monroe Boggs, a co-founder and past president of the Association for Retarded Citizens, died on Saturday at Cooper Medical Center in Camden, N.J. She was 82 and a resident of Hampton, N.J.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Is It Fixed? How Do You Know?
description: MANUFACTURERS often improve computer products without fanfare. Problems are fixed. Bugs are slain. Features are added. Often these improvements cost virtually nothing. But when and whether you get them, or even find out about them, can depend on perseverance, fortitude and luck.

title: Expedition to Far New Jersey Finds Trove of Amber Fossils
description: AN American Museum of Natural History expedition -- to New Jersey -- has uncovered one of the richest deposits of amber ever found, with fossils of 100 previously unknown species of insects and plants trapped in the ancient fossilized tree sap.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANTAM DOUBLEDAY DELL PUBLISHING GROUP INC., New York, a division of the Bertelsmann Book Group North America unit of Bertelsmann A.G., named Jack Hoeft, its president and chief executive, to the additional position of chairman.

title: Mayor Plans To Eliminate Five Agencies
description: Redrawing the blueprint of New York City's municipal bureaucracy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to propose eliminating at least five city agencies -- including the Department of Transportation -- and consolidating their functions into other offices, senior aides said yesterday.

title: YACHT RACING;America's Cup Quest: Everybody in Water?
description: In a plan unique in America's Cup history, the New York Yacht Club announced details yesterday of an aggressive effort to recapture the trophy it once held for 132 years.

title: POP REVIEW;Tony Bennett's Nostalgia And Happy Crescendos
description: Tony Bennett's sold-out show at Radio City Music Hall on Friday was odd in that Mr. Bennett, a singer with exceptional abilities, seemed loath to use them. Virtually every song, creeping ballad or up-tempo burner ended with a crescendo that was at its best an acceptance of the show-business desire to end everything happily, and at its worst the destruction of whatever mood Mr. Bennett had built for the song.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ragu Sauce Account Is Placed in Review
description: The Van den Bergh Foods Company unit of Unilever, the British-Dutch consumer products giant, said yesterday that it had placed in review the account of its Ragu line of pasta sauces. The account, with billings estimated at $20 million, has been handled by J. Walter Thompson New York for the last eight years.

title: For Texaco, A Transition At the Top
description: Peter I. Bijur, a 53-year-old senior vice president of Texaco Inc. with wide experience overseas, was elected yesterday to succeed Alfred C. DeCrane Jr., who will retire as chairman and chief executive on July 1.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STERLING CHEMICALS CONSIDERS SALE OF COMPANY
description: The shares of Sterling Chemicals Inc. rose 35 percent yesterday after the Houston-based chemical company said it was discussing the sale of the company with several parties. The company said it had hired Lazard Freres & Company to act as its financial adviser. Sterling's stock rose $3.25, to $12.50, in New York Stock Exchange trading of almost 2.9 million shares. The company said there was no guarantee that a transaction would take place. Sterling Chemicals, which now has market capitalization of $675 million, was formed in 1986 when Sterling Group Inc., an investor group led by Gordon A. Cain, who is now Sterling's chairman, bought a Texas City chemical plant from the Monsanto Company for $213 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 7 about a school for children of performers with the Big Apple Circus omitted attribution for a statement by Philip Anthony Giordano Jr., the Big Apple's general manager. Mr. Giordano, who praised the circus as an educational environment, was interviewed by the newspaper Education Week.

title: Opera House in Venice Is Destroyed by Fire
description: Venice's La Fenice opera house, one of the most important in Italy, was destroyed by fire today, a month before it was to reopen after renovation. A police spokesman had no details of the cause of the fire.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: FIRST WASHINGTON REALTY TRUST INC., Bethesda, Md., a real estate investment trust, said it planned to purchase a shopping center in Germantown, Md., and an incomplete center in Centreville, Va., for $31 million.

title: NYC;Straphangers Get a Rebate? Whoyakiddin'?
description: AT 12:30 P.M. the other day, as a northbound No. 4 train pulled into the 149th Street-Grand Concourse station in the Bronx, passengers were told that the train was being taken out of service and they would have to get off.

title: Acrimony, Not Accord, Abounds at Libel Hearing
description: Halfway through unusually acrimonious arguments over the merits of the libel lawsuit against Mike McAlary, a Daily News columnist, Justice Charles E. Ramos sighed yesterday and said: "This is not an easy case."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Again Set Records, Led by Drug Issues The stock market rose, as the Dow industrials marched past 5,300 points for the first time, closing at 5,304.98, up 33.23, on strong corporate earnings and hopes for an interest rate cut.

title: A Secret Agency's Secret Budgets Yield Lost Billions, Officials Say
description: The National Reconnaissance Office, the secret agency that builds spy satellites, lost track of more than $2 billion in classified money last year, largely because of its own internal secrecy, intelligence officials say.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Colombia misstated the timing of an interview in which a former Colombian Cabinet official said President Ernesto Samper had known that drug traffickers contributed money to his campaign in 1994. The televised interview appeared on Jan. 22, not Jan. 21.

title: HOCKEY;No Reason for Rangers To Rush Richter Back
description: Ranger goalie Mike Richter, who suffered a groin muscle tear on Dec. 30, resumed full practice with the team, which is training in Vail, Colo., early this week.

title: Bosnia P.O.W. Releases Gain, Slowly
description: Bosnia's warring factions inched closer today to meeting their agreements to exchange prisoners of war, although they are more than a week behind the schedule contained in the Dayton peace accord and have yet to free at least 112 prisoners known to be held.

title: POLITICS;Forbes Says He Would Appoint More Judges Like Scalia
description: Offering a window on his thoughts about fighting crime, Steve Forbes today described Justice Antonin Scalia as a role model for the kind of judge he would like to see on the nation's courts.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Super Bowl Was Animal Lover's Paradise
description: The Rams, Bengals and Eagles were missing from Super Bowl XXX along with the Colts, Jaguars and Cardinals. But in their absence, advertisers unleashed an ark's worth of animals upon the game's record estimated audience of 138.5 million viewers.

title: Tribune Plans An Acquisition
description: Continuing to reshuffle its educational investments, the Tribune Company said today that it had agreed to buy the privately held Educational Publishing Company for $200 million in cash.

title: A Touring Troupe That Plays Classics On Main Street
description: Twenty-five years ago, the Acting Company was a gleam, but a steady gleam, in John Houseman's eye. Having been involved in the creation of seven theatrical organizations, including the Mercury Theater in collaboration with Orson Welles, he still wanted to start a company that would be based on "actor-training and ensemble playing."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Quebec Separatist Becomes Premier, Pledging Economic Agenda
description: Lucien Bouchard, Quebec's most popular politician and the man who brought separatist forces to within a whisker of victory in last October's referendum, was sworn in today as the province's 27th Premier, but he promised to boost employment and strengthen public finances before staging another independence vote.

title: INSIDE
description: Health Costs Rise, for Some

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANG LEE, the movie director who has won accolades for his films "Sense and Sensibility" and "Eat Drink Man Woman," is saying thanks to his alma mater, the New York University Tisch School of the Arts. He has established the Ang Lee Fellowship for graduate film students at the school.

title: Excerpts From Whitman's Budget Speech
description: Following are excerpts from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's budget message, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: First Branch in Life's Tree Was 2 Billion Years Ago
description: THE tree of life has many branches, lichen and lily, thistle and thorn, all creatures great and small. The tree's trunk, as nearly as anyone can tell, took root under a dimmer sun in the warm waters of a cooling earth, in the calm after its long and stormy infancy. Life began as microorganisms with a single cell, the simplest of biochemical factories wrapped in porous membrane, but at first lacking so much as a nucleus.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GERMAN BANK BUYS FIRM IN LONDON
description: West Merchant Bank, the investment banking arm of the German giant Westdeutsche Landesbank, said yesterday that it had bought Panmure Gordon from the Nationsbank Corporation, but would not confirm speculation that it had paid at least $45 million. Nationsbank's chief executive, J. G. Richards Roddey, said that the American bank, based in Charlotte, N.C., remained committed to international capital markets and would continue to build on its existing operations in London. West Merchant had already been expanding and was expected to double its staff of 300 in London in the next few months. Nationsbank took control of Panmure, which has 260 employees, in 1987.

title: Official Defends Link With Suspect
description: While amateur wrestling officials knew of erratic behavior by John E. du Pont, it was "beyond anybody's comprehension" that he would ever harm any wrestlers training at his estate in suburban Philadelphia, the president of U.S.A. Wrestling said today.

title: Uunet Posts a Loss After Acquisition
description: Uunet Technologies Inc. yesterday posted a fourth-quarter loss because of acquisition expenses. The company, which leases data lines that are used to connect computers to the Internet, also said it planned another public stock offering that could raise about $285 million at current prices.

title: BASKETBALL;Johnson Finally Says the Magic Words: 'It's On'
description: The owner just activated himself.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Touch of Sweetness (and Brassiness)
description: The New York City Ballet presented the choreographic epuivalent of pops concerts on Saturday and Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater, with both matinees featuring lighthearted choreography.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Uncertainties Hurt Prices Of Treasuries
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, under pressure from uncertainty over economic conditions and this week's Federal Reserve meeting.

title: Witnessing the Tailspin of a Friend
description: Exactly one mile. That is the distance from John E. du Pont's front door to his own. Thousands of times, from the age of 8 until now, 32-year-old Mike Gostigian has made the trip to the rolling du Pont estate to swim in the pool, to run on the wooded trails, to ride horses, to practice target shooting and fencing, events that make up the modern pentathlon. Twice, Mr. Gostigian has become an Olympian, fulfilling a dream that Mr. du Pont once held as his own.

title: Gaming Joint Venture
description: Full House Resorts Inc. and the Gtech Holdings Corporation have agreed to form a venture to finance and develop Native American and casino gaming ventures, the companies said yesterday. Full House will identify and develop new gaming business opportunities, and Gtech will provide project management, technology and other expertise.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Second Suitor Seen For Lloyds Chemists
description: The shares of Lloyds Chemists P.L.C. rose yesterday on speculation that Gehe A.G. of Germany was poised to make a counterbid to the offer by Unichem P.L.C. of L514.2 million ($771 million). Shares in Lloyds, a British pharmacy and drug wholesaling chain, rose 26 pence yesterday, to 452 pence ($6.79).

title: Survey Finds Health Costs Rose in '95
description: The cost of employees' health care resumed its climb last year after a surprising dip in 1994. And the upward trend is apparently continuing in 1996, according to surveys of employers published yesterday by two big benefits consulting firms.

title: French Ask: Is Art Still a Hobby?
description: Whether it is out of fear of thieves or of inquisitive tax inspectors or simply because of indifference to current artwork, French private collectors hardly make a ripple in the French art market today. In fact, it has become commonplace to blame the absence of dedicated collectors for the crisis in French contemporary art.

title: Y's Lecture Impresario
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: France Ending Nuclear Tests That Caused Broad Protests
description: The French Government said today that it had ended its nuclear weapons test program for good after conducting an underground blast in the South Pacific on Saturday, the last in a series of six such tests that were deplored by most of France's European allies and scores of other countries.

title: THE NEEDIEST CASES;Timely Cash Assistance Rescues 2 Households
description: Two Manhattan households, separated by about two dozen blocks and very different circumstances, had one pressing need in common. Both had experienced financial hardship and were badly in need of emergency help.

title: Thruston Johnson, Violinist, 81
description: Thruston Johnson, a violinist and director of phe International Festival Series, a program of music of many nations, died on Thursday at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 81 and lived in Manhattan.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Unser in IROC Series
description: AL UNSER JR., the biggest winner in the International Race of Champions series, was among four drivers named to complete the 12-man field for the all-star event. Joining Unser, who owns nine IROC race victories and two series championships, were his fellow Indy Car stars SCOTT PRUETT and ROBBY GORDON, and the S.C.C.A. Trans-Am champion TOM KENDALL. The series begins Feb. 16 at Daytona International Speedway in Florida. (AP)

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Breaking Out of Japan's Orbit
description: It has long been an article of faith in this industrially oriented society that, to borrow from an American saying, what's good for Toyota is good for Japan.

title: POLITICS: ON JUDGES;'Judicial Dictatorship' Spurns People's Will, Buchanan Says
description: Trying to elevate the visibility of both social issues and himself in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, Patrick J. Buchanan lashed out today at a "judicial dictatorship" that he said was in "active opposition to the wishes of the majority."

title: Cutting a Lifeline To AIDS Study;3 Drug-Testing Programs In New York Are Eliminated
description: A 26-year-old student from Flatbush has found that a new cream keeps the AIDS-related precancerous cells in her cervix at bay. A former drug user has been trying out a new cocktail of virus fighters. And a 37-year-old woman with a T-cell count so low that it might as well be zero has been hoping that an experimental strategy will help her "just to live a few years."

title: Review/Fashion;In Paris, Men's Wear Fit for Parody
description: The fall Paris men's wear season was ripe for a sendup, perhaps one called "Monty Python's School of Silly Catwalks."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Net Surges at Chip Maker
description: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V., Europe's only independent semiconductor maker, said yesterday that its profits jumped 53.8 percent in the fourth quarter and 45 percent for all of 1995. SGS-Thomson, based in St. Genis-Pouilly, France, said its fourth-quarter earnings rose to $168 million from $109.2 million, while its full-year profits rose to $526.5 million from $362.5 million. The company, whose stock is listed in Paris and New York, completed a public offering of 20.7 million shares in the fourth quarter. (Reuters)

title: Market Place;What of Gap, the rare retailer that had a good Christmas?
description: IF a Gap Inc. stockholder had been in the middle of the Old Navy store in Chelsea on Christmas Eve, she would have been silly with joy.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A John Irving Sampler Of Testimony and Tales
description: TRYING TO SAVE PIGGY SNEED By John Irving 432 pages. Arcade Publishing. $21.95.

title: No Headline
description: The guys have educated themselves, and when you educate yourself, you don't have to think all those crazy thoughts. -- MAGIC JOHNSON, returning to the N.B.A. [B13:1.]

title: Microsoft and MCI Agree On an Internet Alliance
description: In the promiscuous world of digital technology, where most companies prefer playing the field to going steady, MCI Communications said yesterday that it had signed an Internet alliance with the Microsoft Corporation. This, even though it already has an on-line partnership with the News Corporation.

title: N.C.A.A. Discriminates on Test-Score Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: PATAKI IS SEEKING CURBING OF RIGHTS OF CRIME SUSPECTS
description: Gov. George E. Pataki went on the attack against the state's highest court today, announcing that he would introduce legislation to counter rulings that he contended go too far in protecting the rights of criminal defendants.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend on Jan. 19 about two exhibitions of Joseph Cornell's box constructions and collages, at the Whitney Museum of American Art and at C&M Arts in Manhattan, misstated the date of a retrospective of his work at the Guggenheim Museum. It was held in 1967, before Cornell's death in 1972.

title: How to Make New York Metrocard More Convenient and Secure
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: IN THE LEAD;Dole Asserts Press Avoids Close Scrutiny Of Opponent
description: Senator Bob Dole blamed the press today for a new poll that shows him trailing Steve Forbes, the wealthy publishing heir, in the Republican Presidential primary in New Hampshire.

title: BASKETBALLON PRO BASKETBALL;Riley and Johnson: Bonded by Past, and Future
description: In many ways, Pat Riley and Magic Johnson will be forever linked. They won four championships together. They have remained close friends. And now, both men are trying to recapture the great times they once knew.

title: Ice Shelves Melting as Forecast, but Disaster Script Is in Doubt
description: SCIENTISTS have long feared that global warming might eventually cause the vast West Antarctic Ice Sheet to melt, raising the worldwide sea level by a catastrophic 20 feet or so. The first warning sign, the experts said, would be the retreat of ice shelves that extend off the Antarctic coast into the ocean.

title: Prudential Will Sell Mortgage Unit to Norwest
description: The Norwest Corporation said today that it would buy the Prudential Insurance Company's mortgage-lending unit and half its mortgage-processing business to bolster its No. 1 rank in the American mortgage industry.

title: Mexican Stocks Climb to Highs
description: Mexican stocks ended trading today at record highs, buoyed by news that Mexico had raised fresh funds on international markets and that it had received a new loan from the Inter-American Development Bank.

title: Mrs. Whitman's 'Tough Choices'
description: After two years of emphasizing tax cuts, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey has broadened her approach and called for reduced state spending. Her newly proposed budget of "tough choices" would trim expenditures -- an overdue and inevitable response to the gap created by her earlier ill-advised tax reductions. But the budget also shows at least some sensitivity to those who depend on government for their basic needs.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;H.M.O. Joins Competition
description: One of Connecticut's largest health maintenance organizations, Physicians Health Services, said yesterday that it received state approval to operate in all 21 counties of New Jersey, from its headquarters in Paramus. The company -- which has signed up 4,000 doctors and 65 hospitals in New Jersey -- will compete with 25 other health maintenance organizations that already cover 1.5 million New Jersey residents. JOE SHARKEY

title: COMPANY NEWS;PENSKE MOTORSPORTS PLANS PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Penske Motorsports Inc., the Detroit-based professional car-racing promoter, said yesterday that it was going to make an initial offering of 3.25 million common shares. The company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it expected to raise $51 million to $59 million, after expenses, assuming its shares are sold for $17 apiece. It said some proceeds would be used to construct a speedway in California and to repay debt. Penske Motorsports owns and operates the Michigan International Speedway in Brooklyn, Mich., and the Nazareth Speedway in Nazareth, Pa.

title: Securities Investigation at Sylvan Learning
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. is investigating a possible insider trading case that hits close to home.

title: Joint Custody for the Michelangelo? Mais Oui!
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL TO ACQUIRE BIOCRAFT
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, Israel's biggest drug company, agreed yesterday to buy Biocraft Laboratories Inc. of Fair Lawn, N.J., a maker of generic drugs, for stock valued at $295.7 million. The acquisition would raise Teva's share of the United States generic drug market to 8 percent from 5 percent. Teva's United States subsidiary, the Lemmon Company, and Biocraft would have combined annual sales of $390 million. Based on Teva's closing price of $45.25 on Friday, Biocraft shareholders would get 0.461 Teva American depository receipt for each Biocraft share. There are 14.18 million Biocraft shares outstanding. Biocraft rose $5.50, to $19.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Teva A.D.R.'s fell $1.125, to $44.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Observer;The New Isolationism
description: Thousands turned out the other day for the burial of Lesotho's King Moshoeshoe II on top of Night Mountain. The King, who had ruled for 36 years, was known for tolerance, persuasiveness and learning.

title: Dole and Forbes Lawyers Clash on Ballot Petitions
description: Sitting amid large black boxes filled with thousands of election petitions, lawyers for Senator Bob Dole and Steve Forbes, the multimillionaire businessman, spent hours yesterday wrangling over the minutiae of New York State's election laws, arguing over the contents and the validity of Mr. Forbes's nominating petitions for the Republican Presidential primary.

title: Secret' Iran Scenario Leaves U.S. No Cover
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.N. Talks Set on Plan To Sell Iraqi Oil
description: Talks between Iraq and the United Nations on a plan to sell up to $2 billion in Iraqi oil over six months will begin on Feb. 6, the United Nations spokeswoman said today.

title: Q&A
description: Birds in Blizzards

title: Palestinians Owe Yasir Arafat Their Present and Future;Israeli Homeowners
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL Overtime Brings Victory to Villanova After enduring a poor game shooting, Eric Eberz never flinched, even with the game on the line. Eberz's 3-pointer 51 seconds into overtime gave No. 6 Villanova the lead for good and the Wildcats held off No. 18 Syracuse, 72-69, last night in the Carrier Dome.

title: Johnson's Return On Television
description: TNT will televise Magic Johnson's comeback game against Golden State tonight at 10:30 P.M. Eastern time, and Friday night's game against Chicago, also at 10:30. "No question this should have a positive effect on our ratings," said Kevin O'Malley, executive vice president of Turner Sports.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK CITY

title: Pataki and Official Visit Flooded Areas
description: Gov. George E. Pataki took the Federal Government's coordinator of emergency response on a tour today of northern New York State areas ravaged by flooding two weekends ago.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Friday with an article about a devastated Bosnian village referred incorrectly to the site in some copies. The highlighted village, called Ulice, should have been one in Bosnia, not a town of the same name in Croatia.

title: Chess
description: If the machines learned anything in the Sixth Harvard Cup Human vs. Computer Chess Challenge, it would have been: don't play warm-up games with people.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about an ethics compaint against Speaker Newt Gingrich misstated Lauren Sims's position. She is a spokeswoman for Mr. Gingrich, not for the House ethics committee.

title: After 151 Years, Baptist Baylor Kicks Up Its Heels, Just a Little
description: There will be no smoking. There will be no drinking. There will be plenty of chaperones. But for the first time in 151 years, there will be dancing at Baylor University.

title: Sports of The Times;Can the Cowboys Fill Their Holes Again?
description: AFTER about 15 minutes of his final Super Bowl XXX inquisition yesterday morning, Barry Switzer scanned all the notebooks and microphones to see if there were any more questions. When the Cowboys coach didn't hear any, he smiled and turned away from the lectern.

title: Sharp Regional Incongruity Found In Medical Costs and Treatments
description: A NEW study reports that medical care, adjusted for local costs of living, costs twice as much in some areas of the country as it does in others.

title: Sports of The Times;Magic Plays For Himself And Others
description: It took three years for Magic Johnson to realize. He was letting other basketball players lean on him and shove him out of scoring range.

title: Colombians Grow Bitter At Leader
description: President Ernesto Samper's all-out effort to keep his hold on power despite charges that his administration has been inflitrated by drug traffickers appears to be backfiring, fueling indignation among many Colombians instead.

title: Micron Offers No Insight On Chief's Exit and Return
description: Hundreds of shareholders and employees packed the convention center here today, drawn by the corporate soap opera that has captivated both locals and Wall Street: Why did Steve Appleton, chief executive of Micron Technology Inc., return to his job on Friday, just a week after resigning?

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Despite 20th Millrose, Clark Has Many Goals
description: Joetta Clark's dark hair has not a speck of gray. At 5 feet 8 inches and 123 pounds, her figure has not a speck of fat. So how come, when this figurative graybeard will run on Friday night in the Chemical Bank Millrose Games in Madison Square Garden, it will be her 20th Millrose appearance in 21 years?

title: Unions Try to Push Past Workers' Fears to Sign Up Poultry Plants inSouth
description: Cantrail Berry recalls the day Rossco Johnson showed up at the Sanderson Farms chicken processing plant, driving a shiny black, souped-up pickup truck with a throaty Floatmaster muffler, chrome-plated wheels and the Laborers' International Union of North America logo painted in gold on the doors.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IPL ENERGY PLANS BID FOR CONSUMERS' GAS
description: IPL Energy Inc. said yesterday that it planned to bid $21 (Canadian) a share for the 15 percent of the Consumers' Gas Company it does not already own. Shareholders would be offered payment in cash and IPL shares or cash alone. IPL and Consumers' Gas plan to make a joint application to the Ontario government asking for removal of the requirement that Consumers' Gas maintain a 15 percent public float. Consumers' Gas stock closed at $19.50 on Friday on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Shareholders who choose cash and stock would receive $19.50 worth of IPL shares and $1.50 a share in cash. Yesterday, Consumers' rose 37.5 cents, to $19.875.

title: ON BASKETBALL;Another Long Climb Begins at Columbia
description: Armond Hill was an eighth grader at St. James grammar school in Brooklyn when he made his first serious foray into art. Although he was immersed in basketball, Hill entered a citywide art contest on a lark. He won. The prize was a scholarship to the Brooklyn Museum. Suddenly, a 13-year-old was confronted with a choice: basketball or art. Hill chose basketball.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MATTEL HIRES ADVISER FOR HASBRO TAKEOVER BID
description: Mattel Inc., the world's biggest toy company, said yesterday that it had hired the CS First Boston Corporation as its adviser on its $5.2 billion takeover bid for Hasbro Inc. Mattel, based in El Segundo, Calif., said last Wednesday that it would offer to buy Hasbro, the No. 2 company in the industry. But Hasbro, based in Pawtucket, R.I., rejected the bid, saying such a merger would violate antitrust laws. Mattel, the maker of Barbie dolls and Fisher-Price toys, said it had offered to pay Hasbro, the maker of Monopoly and Scrabble, $100 million if it agreed to a merger and the combination was then blocked by antitrust objections. Mattel shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $31.75, while Hasbro shares rose 75 cents to close at $43.75.

title: Patterns
description: Nicole Miller's Campaign

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;A Clash of Titanic Web Browsers
description: FOR many people, Netscape is synonymous with the Internet. The Netscape Communications Corporation, whose corporate symbol is a fire-breathing monster nicknamed Mozilla, makes the Netscape Navigator software used by millions of people to operate and browse the Internet's popular World Wide Web.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOME SAVINGS TO HALT SOME MORTGAGE LENDING
description: Home Savings of America, the principal unit of H. F. Ahmanson and Company, said yesterday that it would discontinue its wholesale mortgage lending program. In its wholesale lending business, begun late last year, Home Savings originated mortgage loans through independent mortgage brokers. The company plans to continue to originate mortgage loans through its network of more than 500 loan consultants and community loan officers. Home Savings, a savings and loan in Irwindale, Calif., operates 343 financial service centers.

title: Extravaganza XXX
description: For a change, Super Bowl viewers this year got a plausible football contest to go with the gaudy halftime show and debut of new advertising spots that in Januarys past have offered more excitement than the game itself. The Dallas Cowboys, the best team money can buy, held off a late charge by the proletarian Pittsburgh Steelers in Super Bowl XXX. Until late in the fourth quarter, when the Steelers' erratic quarterback Neil O'Donnell was intercepted for the second time, a dramatic denouement seemed possible. Galvanized by a perfect onside kick, the Steelers actually seemed capable of becoming the first team from the American Football Conference to win the Super Bowl since 1984.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Chang Leads U.S. Team Into Davis Cup Play
description: MICHAEL CHANG, TODD MARTIN, PATRICK McENROE and PAT GALBRAITH were named yesterday to the United States team that will face Mexico in the opening round of Davis Cup World Group play.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BOSTON RED SOX -- Traded Lee Tinsley and Glenn Murray, outfielders, and Ken Ryan, pitcher, to Philadelphia for Heathcliff Slocumb and Larry Wimberly, pitchers, and Rick Holyfield, outfielder.

title: Joint Custody for the Michelangelo? Mais Oui!
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volvo Sales Rise 6.7%
description: Volvo A.B., the Swedish maker of luxury cars, said yesterday that it had sold 374,600 cars in 1995, an increase of 6.7 percent, gaining market share as the global car market remained unchanged at 34.6 million. Volvo advanced most in North America, where sales rose 9.7 percent, to 57,100 cars. In Europe, sales gained 5.6 percent, to 219,800 cars. Volvo has not reported its 1995 earnings. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: U.N., Pressing for Restraint, Delays Its Action on Burundi
description: After weeks of warnings from Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali and relief agencies that Burundi was on the brink of a civil war, the Security Council passed a resolution today calling for restraint, reconciliation and the rule of law. But it put off any international action on the crisis until late next month at the earliest.

title: On TV, Showing Life as Lived
description: The revolution, as they used to say, will not be televised. On the other hand there's always room in prime time for another sitcom.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;The Cowboys' Season: Up, Down and Up Again
description: Dallas Coach Barry Switzer looked as if he had just rolled out of bed when he met with the news media for the final time early this morning. In fact, he had not slept at all. He came, he saw, he danced all night.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Selling Geriatric Center
description: After months of rancorous debate, Essex County officials are selling the 232-bed Essex Geriatric Center to the Kessler Rehabilitation Corporation for $7.8 million and have sent layoff notices to the 180 employees of the center. The sale is expected to be approved by the State Department of Health within 90 days.

title: SUPER BOWL XXX;Best Rating In 10 Years
description: The lack of a blowout at Super Bowl XXX Sunday night catapulted the game on NBC to its highest rating since 1986. The Cowboys' 27-17 victory over the Steelers generated a 46.1 national Nielsen rating, up 11 percent from 1995.

title: HOCKEY;Isles' Goalie Could Make A Big Dent in the Crease
description: For the Islanders -- and for Eric Fichaud -- the future is now.

title: Lawyers in Duke Estate Case Ask the Judge to Step Aside
description: The legal war over the $1.2 billion estate of Doris Duke, the late tobacco heiress, took another surprising turn yesterday when lawyers challenged the objectivity of the Manhattan judge who is handling the case and asked her to step aside.

title: France and Polygamy
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Youths in Murder Trial Deny Knowledge of a Gun
description: In a sometimes tense and emotional court session, two teen-age brothers admitted yesterday that they had taken part in a Brooklyn robbery in which their uncle shot and killed a police officer, but they insisted they had not known beforehand that the uncle had a gun.

title: BASEBALL;Red Sox Finally Make Trade for Slocumb
description: In the culmination of a long-discussed trade, the Boston Red Sox got the relief pitcher they wanted yesterday. The Minnesota Twins, at the same time, got an outfielder for the kind of contract that owners love.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Monitor for Troubled School
description: After a Weequahic High School student was slashed with a box cutter during a fight in the cafeteria last week, a top official of the state-run Newark school district has "assumed temporary leadership" of the school, according to a letter sent to parents from Beverly L. Hall, the district's Superintendent. Gladys Hillman-Jones, the Assistant Executive Superintendent, will monitor conditions at the violence-plagued school, where a girl required 500 stitches in her face after the fight.

title: Logging in Siberia Sets Off a Battle in the U.S.
description: A team of American entrepreneurs and their Russian partners have devised a novel way to turn cold-war atomic expertise to peacetime profits: by sterilizing Russian logs with radiation to make them safe for export to the United States.

title: U.S. Ships Shifted to Gulf After Hint of Iraqi Buildup
description: Five years after the Persian Gulf war, a dozen United States Navy cargo ships laden with tanks, armored vehicles and other military hardware are anchored off the coast here, reflecting the wariness of American forces that Iraq might start the conflict again.

title: Funeral Chain Settles, Avoiding a Big Bill
description: The Loewen Group said yesterday that it had agreed to settle a Mississippi lawsuit that it said would have pushed the company toward bankruptcy. The suit was settled for cash and stock valued at $175 million.

title: BASKETBALL;Johnson Is Meeting Less Resistance
description: Magic Johnson is expected to be welcomed back more openly by his peers than he was when he attempted his last comeback in 1992. But how many players are still concerned about playing against someone who is H.I.V.-positive? And will those concerns be diminished by the increased information and education concerning AIDS that has been made available to National Basketball Association players?

title: Christopher F. Bannister, 58, a Master Builder of Harpsichords
description: Christopher F. Bannister, a master harpsichord maker who left his mark on a rarefied field by adapting 18th-century instruments to 20th-century technology, died on Wednesday at a hospital in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 58.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Flood Alert Remains in Effect
description: A flood warning continued yesterday along the swollen Passaic River, where 100 residents were forced from their homes over the weekend. Capt. Orrie DuBois of the Wayne Police Department said that about 50 displaced residents remained in a Red Cross shelter at Wayne Valley High School yesterday, while the rest stayed with relatives or friends.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Marriott Rejects Proposal
description: Marriott International, the United States-based hotel chain, said yesterday that it had rejected an assets- swap offer from the British television and leisure company Granada Group P.L.C. under which Marriott would have acquired the Meridien chain and some trophy hotels. Granada succeeded last week in a bid of L3.9 billion ($5.9 billion) to acquire Forte, the owner of Meridien. It plans to sell the Meridien and Exclusive chains, including such trophy properties as Grosvenor House in London. "Granada approached Marriott with that deal, but Marriott rejected it," a Marriott spokeswoman said. (Reuters)

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Trafalgar to Sell Unit
description: Trafalgar House P.L.C., the troubled British conglomerate, agreed yesterday to sell its British home construction business to Persimmon P.L.C. for L170 million, or about $255.6 million. The companies said earlier this month that they were having discussions. The sale of the unit, Ideal Homes, will end Trafalgar's involvement in residential construction. The company said in December that it would sell its house-building operations in the United States. (Dow Jones)

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Dog, Her Guru and Brunch
description: She has a dog's life, a real cynical business, but her death is pretty and her reincarnation a magnificent spectacle. She is, of course, Rose, who began as a mere puppy years ago in "A Dog's Life," the first part of Lee Breuer s epic trilogy, "Animations," and who now comes full circle in the last section, "An Epidog," given a spectacular production by Mabou Mines and the Gertrude Stein Repertory Theater. The play runs through Sunday at the Here Art Center, 145 Avenue of the Americas, at Spring Street in SoHo.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MADGE NETWORKS TO BUY TELEOS COMMUNICATIONS
description: Madge Networks, a maker of computer networking products, said yesterday that it would acquire the privately held Teleos Communications Inc., which provides wide-area-network access switches, for about $165 million in stock. Wide-area networks link computer users across geographical regions. Under the deal, Madge would issue common shares worth $165 million to Teleos in a pooling of interests. The number of shares would be determined just before the deal's close. Madge's stock slipped 37.5 cents, to $37.875, in Nasdaq trading. Separately, Madge said it had agreed to license Teleos's switching technology for integrated services digital networks to Cisco Systems Inc. for use as a building block in Cisco's universal access server products.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Bono Subs for Marino
description: Kansas City quarterback STEVE BONO was chosen to replace the injured Miami quarterback DAN MARINO on the American Football Conference team for the Pro Bowl. With Marino out, Cincinnati's JEFF BLAKE will start the all-star game on Sunday night.

title: Compaq Rank Again No. 1 In PC Sales
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation retained its top ranking as the world's leading marketer of personal computers last year, but I.B.M. edged past troubled Apple Computer for the No. 2 position.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Princeton Names Librarian
description: Karin Trainer has a pretty good idea of what she wants to do when she starts her new job at Princeton University: "Basically, create the library of the 21st century." Ms. Trainer, currently an associate librarian at Yale University, was recently named university librarian at Princeton. She starts in July. The challenge, she said yesterday, is to build a "rich array of electronic information services" on the foundation of the existing collection of five million printed works.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Filing Taxes Over the Phone
description: To the inevitabilities of death and taxes, add voice mail. About 275,000 taxpayers in 12 counties are being offered the opportunity to file their state income taxes from a computer-linked phone system called TeleFile. In a pilot project, the selected taxpayers will fill out a questionnaire, and then file their taxes by responding, via voice and keypad entry, to computer-generated questions on the phone.

title: Boy, 12, to Be Nation's Youngest Prison Inmate
description: A judge today accepted a state request to send a 12-year-old boy to a state juvenile penitentiary, making him the nation's youngest inmate at a high-security prison.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Odds of Another Oil Crisis: Saudi Stability Plays a Large Role
description: Oil Shock III. Could it happen again?

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Samsung Tells Of Auto Plans
description: Samsung Group announced a $13 billion plan today to turn its fledgling automobile subsidiary into one of the world's top 10 car makers by 2010.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Oil Drops Again on Iraq Talks; Natural Gas and Wheat Soar
description: Crude oil prices slumped yesterday after the United Nations scheduled a date for talks with Iraq on a plan to allow limited oil sales, raising the prospect that the leadership in Baghdad might accept an offer it had rejected in the past.

title: 3-Drug Therapy Shows Promise Against AIDS
description: A combination of an experimental anti-AIDS drug and two licensed ones appears to be the most powerful AIDS therapy ever tested on infected patients, a researcher from the experimental drug's developer said at a scientific meeting here today.

title: War in the Caucasus?
description: The civil war in Chechnya, once largely confined to the rebel republic, now threatens to spread through the Caucasus and even beyond. The seizure of hostages in neighboring Dagestan and the hijacking of a ferry in Turkish waters this month reflected this ominous turn in the conflict, which could easily draw in Georgia and Azerbaijan, and possibly Turkey and Iran.

title: Joint Custody for the Michelangelo? Mais Oui!
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani to Propose Merging of Agencies
description: Redrawing the blueprint of New York City's municipal bureaucracy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to propose eliminating at least five city agencies -- including the Department of Transportation -- and consolidating their functions into other offices, senior aides said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hanson's Brick Unit In Belgian Deal
description: Hanson P.L.C., the British industrial conglomerate, said yesterday that its Hanson Brick unit had agreed to buy a controlling interest in the Belgian brick maker Desimpel Kortemark. Hanson Brick will receive 50.1 percent of Desimpel in a deal that values the company at about 5.7 billion Belgian francs (about $186 million), according to a statement from Hanson.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Mustaf's Cousin Guilty
description: LAVONNIE WOOTEN was convicted yesterday in Phoenix of murdering the pregnant girlfriend of his cousin, JERROD MUSTAF, a former Phoenix Suns and Knicks player.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;10-Year Terms Sought For G.I.'s in Okinawa
description: Japanese prosecutors today demanded ten-year prison terms for three American servicemen accused of the rape of a 12-year-old Okinawan girl, a crime that brought nationwide resentment against American bases in Japan.

title: Visa Lottery Is Given Credit For Neighborhood Revival
description: An annual visa lottery that strives to diversify immigration to this country has revitalized some New York City neighborhoods, attracting thousands of Irish and Polish immigrants to once-fading neighborhoods, according to city demographers.

title: 2-Year-Old Girl Is Found Beaten
description: A 2-year-old girl was found beaten and comatose yesterday in her father's room at a temporary homeless shelter in the Bronx, the police said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Screening of Workers Sought
description: Home health care and nursing home workers would be subject to criminal-record checks under a bill sent by committee to the State Assembly yesterday for a vote. Under the proposed law, inspired by the 1993 murder of a 75-year-old Brick Township woman by a home health care worker, employers who failed to comply with the background check requirement could be fined $1,000.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies yesterday about a Defense Department employee's warning to American defense contractors that Israel would try to spy on them misspelled the given name of an American convicted of spying for Israel. He is Jonathan Pollard, not Jonathon.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.B.A.;Hardaway and O'Neal Each Fined $6,000
description: TIM HARDAWAY of the Golden State Warriors and SHAQUILLE O'NEAL of the Orlando Magic were fined by the National Basketball Association yesterday for comments and actions involving officials. The incidents took place in separate games on Saturday.

title: Evangelical Group Defends Laws Protecting Endangered Species as aModern 'Noah's Ark'
description: Congressional conservatives, who have already seen some religious allies on moral and cultural issues attack the overhaul of welfare and Medicaid, will face another such challenge today as a group of evangelical Christians urges support for the Endangered Species Act and the defeat of proposals to weaken it.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Davis Surges As Starks Struggles
description: Lately, one of them hits every shot he takes and the other one cannot find the net. While Hubert Davis continues to thrive, John Starks continues to struggle. There is no gray area, only swishes and misses.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Smith's Race Against (Father) Time
description: The great Olympic track and field experiment is under way. The place is Homewood, Ala., outside of Birmingham. The event is the 400 meters, one lap around the track. The object of the experiment is 39-year-old Willie Smith, a former Olympic gold medal contender who has not competed in five years.

title: Prosecutors Say Guards Beat Inmates and Tried a Cover-Up
description: Prosecutors in Union County, N.J., charged yesterday that county corrections officers, including the head of the local union, threatened and harassed other guards to try to cover up the beating of a group of inmates last June.

title: Music In Review;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: In Praise of the Reformation And a Spirit of Tolerance American Symphony Orchestra Avery Fisher Hall

title: Judge Baer's Tortured Reasoning
description: With his controversial ruling last week tossing out key evidence and a voluntary confession in a major drug conspiracy case, Federal District Judge Harold Baer Jr. apparently hoped to make a point about the serious problem of police corruption in New York City that he helped uncover as a member of the 1993 Mollen commission. What the judge managed to do instead, through his sloppy reasoning, was to undermine respect for the legal system, encourage citizens to flee the police and deter honest cops in drug-infested neighborhoods from doing their job.

title: Symbol of Inhumanity in Bosnia Now Says 'Not Me'
description: Thin and pale, Borislav Herak does not fit the picture of the rapist and killer he confessed to being nearly three years ago. He is quiet and subdued, an ex-store clerk residing in a 6-by-12 foot prison cell.

title: Proposal for Nasdaq Wins U.S. Support
description: The Justice Department has endorsed a plan to revise pricing on the Nasdaq stock market, saying that the changes could undermine Nasdaq broker-dealers' "willingness and ability to collude" on stock prices.

title: Enhanced 911 System Is on Line Citywide
description: Seven years after an enhanced 911 system was first proposed for New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday unveiled the new computerized system, which automatically displays every caller's telephone number and address on a dispatcher's computer screen.

title: Dan Duva, 44, Boxing Promoter Who Guided Many Champions
description: Dan Duva, who was raised in boxing's buccaneering world, left it to become a lawyer and then returned as one of its major promoters, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 44.

title: At the Nation's Table;Dancing and Dining On the 21st Floor
description: When the hotel and restaurant developer William Kimpton bought the Sir Francis Drake in San Francisco in 1994 and saved it from mustiness, he also wanted to breathe new life into the rooftop lounge. So he turned to Harry Denton, who is known as much for his unrestrained enthusiasm as for his brasserie-cum-dance club, Harry Denton's Bar and Grill, which is adjacent to another Kimpton property in San Francisco, the Harbor Court Hotel.

title: W. E. Hanford, 87, Chemist Who Changed World
description: Dr. William E. Hanford, an industrial chemist whose wide-ranging interests led to both the development of polyurethanes and the first liquid household detergent, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Bethesda, Md., where he lived. He was 87.

title: Hasbro and Mattel Continue To Bicker Over Merger Bid
description: The "he said, she said" sniping that has swirled around Hasbro Inc. and Mattel Inc. for the last week continued yesterday, as the toy makers traded broadsides about the legality of Mattel's $5.2 billion offer to merge with Hasbro.

title: Robert H. Ebert, 81, Who Led Harvard Medical School, Dies
description: Dr. Robert H. Ebert, the longtime dean of the Harvard Medical School and founder of the nation's first academic health maintenance organization, died on Monday in Boston. He was 81 and lived in Wayland, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about recent polls on Republican Presidential candidates in New Hampshire referred incorrectly in some editions to a finding by the Pew Research Center in Washington. Its poll showed Steve Forbes ahead of Senator Bob Dole by 29 percent to 24 percent, not trailing him.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Hyett, Broadbent & Heimbrodt Advertising, San Francisco, was awarded two accounts with combined billings estimated at $4.5 million: Monterey Pasta Co., Danville, Calif., previously handled in-house, and Heald Colleges, San Francisco, previously at Ron Wren Advertising, San Francisco.

title: COMPANY NEWS;POLYGRAM SAID TO DROP GOLDWYN OFFER
description: Polygram N.V. has dropped its offer to acquire the Samuel Goldwyn Company, a person at Polygram, who is close to the negotiations, said. The person, who requested anonymity, said the company was frustrated by the drawn-out negotiations with the independent film studio. Polygram, a unit of Philips Electronics N.V., had offered $62 million for Goldwyn's library of films and television programs in December, but the offer was topped when Metromedia International Group Inc. offered $115 million for all of the financially troubled company. Polygram revised its offer several times, but Goldywn missed deadlines, the Polygram insider said. Polygram sent a letter to Goldwyn on Monday advising the company of its decision to withdraw.

title: Yevtushenko to Teach Poetry In Russian at Queens College
description: When the spring semester begins next week, students at Queens College will be able to study Russian poetry and literature with Yevgeny Yevtushenko, the Russian poet, who has joined the faculty there. But they will have to know Russian; for the first semester, at least, he will teach in his native language.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Frigid Weather in Midwest Spurs A Jump in Winter Wheat Prices
description: Winter wheat prices surged on the Kansas City Board of Trade yesterday, as frigid temperatures sweeping across the Midwest threatened to kill dormant crops and cut output.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Bulls' Bench Rescues 16th Straight Victory
description: There may be no stopping the Chicago Bulls if they win on a night when Michael Jordan hits only 27 percent of his shots.

title: FEDERAL IMPASSE A STUMBLING BLOCK TO STATE BUDGETS
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is warning that a protracted battle in Washington over the Federal budget will throw New York State's new budget into turmoil and force him to make deep new cuts in spending on top of the ones already proposed.

title: Music In Review;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: From Schumann and Schubert, With Attention to the Poetry Edith Wiens, soprano The Frick Collection

title: Confusion in the Skies
description: Washington has mismanaged the nation's air traffic control system for at least a decade and a half. Competent studies have found the system statistically "safe" but threatened by dying equipment -- scheduled for replacement by gear that will itself be obsolete the moment it is installed. Reforms enacted and proposed may yet send the Federal Aviation Administration in the right direction, but at the moment it is years behind the available technology.

title: Giuliani Wary of Cuts
description: After sharply cutting New York City services for two years, Mayor Giuliani is now proposing to slow the reductions. In his next budget, he said, he will safeguard spending for child welfare, the elderly, health and parks, among other services.

title: Why Raising Minimum Wage Will Hurt, Not Help, the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: EASTERN COLLEGE REPORT
description: St. John's

title: Judge Voids an Alabama Law Against Gay Campus Groups
description: An Alabama law barring gay and lesbian groups on college campuses from receiving public money or other official support has been declared unconstitutional by a Federal judge.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOEWEN GROUP SAYS IT MIGHT SETTLE ANOTHER BIG SUIT
description: Loewen Group Inc., which settled a huge lawsuit this week, indicated it might settle a $60 million breach of contract suit with the Provident American Corporation, a Philadelphia insurance company. "I believe we will find a mutually satisfying settlement," said Raymond Loewen, chairman and chief executive of the company. The suit stems from a contract dispute in 1992. Loewen's comments came just days after the company settled a case in Mississippi that might have forced it into bankruptcy. Loewen, a Canadian funeral-home chain, agreed to pay Jerry O'Keefe, the owner of Gulf National Group in Mississippi, about $175 million in a breach of contract dispute.

title: Julius Posener, 91, an Architect And Critic of Modern Movement
description: Julius Posener, an architect, critic and teacher who was an active figure in the European Modernist movement for much of the 20th century, died on Monday at his home in Berlin. He was 91.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Mayor May Seek House Seat
description: Mayor William Pascrell Jr. is expected to join the Democratic candidates hoping to unseat United States Representative William J. Martini, a Republican, in the fall. Mr. Pascrell, 59, who is also a State Assemblyman, has not formally announced, but Joseph Doria, the Assembly minority leader, said yesterday that he would support a Pascrell candidacy.

title: Subjects in Radiation Experiment Were Not Informed, Panel Says
description: The Air Force failed to properly inform the human subjects of experiments carried out in Alaska in the 1950's that they were being exposed to small amounts of radiation, a committee of the National Research Council said yesterday.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;Rams Are Grateful To Lose By Just 30
description: When the trip here from the Bronx is nothing new for the Fordham Rams, when the road through the Atlantic 10 no longer seems this steep, let no one say that Ashley Macarchuk is jumping on the bandwagon. She will be able to say that she was in the Mullins Center five days before she turned 2 months old, the night her grandfather Nick, the coach of the Rams, walked gratefully toward Massachusetts Coach John Calipari after another long night in a season of them.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Less Aid for Municipalities
description: Details of the Whitman administration's proposal for state aid to municipalities that were released yesterday show a $71 million decline, reflecting lower utility-tax revenues. Over the weekend, the administration announced that the new budget assumed that the $1.5 billion in state assistance to municipalities would remain flat.

title: HOCKEY;Fichaud Gives the Islanders a Ray of Hope
description: Eric Fichaud is a rookie goalie who is touted as a bright prospect for a dreary Islander franchise. His National Hockey League career began encouragingly tonight at Nassau Coliseum when he stopped 22 of 26 shots in a 5-4 overtime victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

title: In Performance;DANCE
description: Collaboration Onstage And the Silver Screen 'Dance and Film' Ohio Theater

title: Giuliani Seeks $150 Million From Assistance Agency
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to seek $150 million in cash from the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation to help close a gap in this year's budget, turning once again to the agency created 20 years ago to help New York City avert bankruptcy, senior officials said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOUNTASIA ENTERTAINMENT REJECTS TAKEOVER BID
description: Mountasia Entertainment International rejected an unsolicited takeover offer by an investment group yesterday, saying the bid represented an uncertain value for the company's shareholders. Mountasia, an operator of family entertainment centers based in Alpharetta, Ga., said the bid, which was valued about $61 million plus the assumption of $35 million in debt, contained a "substantial" noncash component. The offer was made by a group led by Hisham Araim, a former director of the company, and the investor Robert Nihon. The bid, announced in mid-January, was about $6 million higher than an original offer made by the group in December.

title: Big Spending Pledges by Yeltsin Are Worrying Foreign Creditors
description: As top specialists from the International Monetary Fund complete a painstaking review of Russia's eligibility for critical foreign loans, President Boris N. Yeltsin has embarked on a pre-election promising spree that economists say casts new doubt on his commitment to economic discipline.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Best Efforts by Williams and Nets Fall Short at End
description: A sensational, one-man rebounding show by Jayson Williams and a gutsy effort by the injury-riddled Nets for the seven-eighths of tonight's game went for naught because the Sonics simply had too much depth and the Nets simply ran out of gas.

title: American Express Plan Cuts Restaurant No-Shows
description: PEOPLE who would not dream of ignoring an appointment at the barber or the hairdresser think nothing of making restaurant reservations, then failing to call and cancel if their plans change. Tables stand empty when other diners are waiting, an inconvenience that is costly to a restaurant. To combat the problem, some restaurants routinely overbook, especially on Saturday nights when no-shows occur most often.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: N.B.A.;Trail Blazers Add a Third Robinson
description: The Portland Trail Blazers signed the backup point guard RUMEAL ROBINSON yesterday for the rest of the season. Robinson had signed two 10-day contracts with the club after the rookie RANDOLPH CHILDRESS dislocated his shoulder. The Blazers lead the league in Robinsons with three: CLIFFORD, JAMES and RUMEAL. (AP)

title: Chuck Close to Get a Show at the Modern
description: Chuck Close delivered the second half of a one-two punch to the art world yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Hanson P.L.C. to Be Broken Up Into 4 Companies
description: After keeping the corporate and investment worlds off balance through more than two decades of unceasing acquisitions and divestitures, Lord Hanson, the chairman of the British-American conglomerate Hanson P.L.C., pulled off his biggest surprise today, saying that he would break the company into four publicly traded parts.

title: Killing of 2 Nuns Prompts Questioning of Mental Care
description: The parents of Mark Bechard noticed with mounting alarm in the last few weeks that their 37-year-old son, a manic depressive, was growing agitated and paranoid.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Gains vs. Mark and Yen; Cuts in Europe's Rates Expected
description: The dollar rose against most leading currencies in New York yesterday as expectations grew that European central banks would soon lower interest rates.

title: Red Cross Shuts Bosnia Office After Protest
description: The Red Cross suspended one of its main operations in Bosnia today after anguished Muslim women, wanting to know the fate of relatives, stormed its offices.

title: Peru's Flawed Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Not on Line, It's on Cable;In a Test City, Sitcoms and Internet Travel Together
description: Charles Tolbert goes on line for all the usual reasons: to swap E-mail with friends, participate in chat groups or just roam around the Web.

title: How Packaging Reaches Out and Grabs Susceptible Shoppers
description: FOR Thomas Hine, the typical supermarket, with more than 30,000 products, is filled with sensory experiences meant to preach or teach. Their hidden language led him to write "The Total Package: The Evolution and Secret Meanings of Boxes, Bottles, Cans and Tubes" (Little, Brown, 1995).

title: INSIDE
description: Silver Lining on Wall Street

title: The Neediest Cases;For Some, Giving Is New. For Others, It Is Tradition.
description: Carol D. Sherr, who lives in Larchmont, N.Y., has probably never heard of Beth Lord, of Manhattan, but the two women are forever bound by an act of good will.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEXAS INSTRUMENTS TO SELL PARTS BUSINESS TO SOLECTRON
description: The Solectron Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two operations from Texas Instruments Inc. that assemble circuit panels for personal computers. The transaction was valued at about $130 million. Shares of Solectron gained $3.125, to $44.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, while shares of Texas Instruments were unchanged at $46.75. Under the agreement, Solectron, an electronics maker based in Milpitas, Calif., will buy Texas Instruments' assets in Austin, Tex., and Malaysia. Texas Instruments, the maker of semiconductors and electronic components based in Dallas, said it would keep its other circuit panel plant in Aversa, Italy.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 17 about an appearance by the Israeli President, Ezer Weizman, before the German Parliament misstated the date of the Wannsee Conference, at which Nazi leaders drafted a plan to annihilate European Jewry. It was 1942, not 1941.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP. (MCIC,NNM)
description: The MCI Communications Corporation reported fourth-quarter net income yesterday of $284 million, or 41 cents a share. In comparison with the corresponding quarter in 1994, when large pretax charges held down reported profits, net income was up 88.1 percent; excluding the charges, the gain was 17 percent.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Shelby Undergoes Kidney Transplant
description: CARROLL SHELBY, a legend in racing and the design industry, underwent successful kidney transplant surgery yesterday, receiving a new organ from his son.

title: U.S. Brokers Peace Accord In the Aegean
description: Responding to the entreaties of President Clinton and other senior American officials, Greece and Turkey late this evening pulled back from a military confrontation over a tiny, uninhabited island in the Aegean.

title: Infected With Human Virus, A Chimpanzee Develops AIDS
description: A chimpanzee has developed AIDS more than a decade after it was injected with H.I.V.-1, the main AIDS virus, scientists reported at a scientific meeting here today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: First Union Plans Purchase
description: The First Union Rail Corporation, the freight-car leasing unit of the First Union Corporation, said on Monday that it would acquire the Northbrook Rail Corporation, a transportation management concern based in Arlington Heights, Ill. Terms were not disclosed. First Union Rail said the acquisition would make it the fourth-largest general service freight-car company in North America. Northbrook's 3,100 freight cars would increase First Union Rail's lease fleet to more than 13,000 cars.

title: POP REVIEW;Young Musicians Expanding on the Job
description: The bassist Omer Avital's exceptional set at Smalls on Thursday night was cause for optimism for two reasons. The first is that the handful of young musicians in the band who were good improvisers a year ago have become more than that. Expressive, powerful and well informed, the sextet doesn't have a weak link.

title: S.E.C. Explains Look at Muni Bonds
description: At a time when the Securities and Exchange Commission is under attack by many in the municipal bond market, the agency's top enforcement official, William R. McLucas, said today that the agency was doing "nothing new" in ferreting out fraud by public officials and the issuers of municipal securities.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pearson Buys TV Assets
description: Pearson P.L.C. agreed yesterday to pay L46 million ($69 million) for all of SelecTV P.L.C.'s television assets, except its cable channel, which Carlton Communications P.L.C. agreed to buy for L5.2 million. Pearson, which publishes The Financial Times, agreed to sell SelecTV's 15 percent stake in Meridian Broadcasting to an existing shareholder, MAI Group P.L.C., for L27 million. SelecTV announced last year that it was for sale. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Ewing a Star For 10th Time
description: Leading a cadre of veterans who are schooling many of the league's young stars these days, Patrick Ewing of the Knicks was named to his 10th All-Star Game today.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Ismail Kadare;A Meeting Of the Venerated And Best Known
description: IN the category of Only in New York, here was Ismail Kadare, the best known and most venerated cultural figure of Albania, sampling for the first time the best known and most venerated product of the United States: the hamburger.

description: To the Editor:

title: Boston School Shows Cities Another Wa
description: When President Clinton spoke in his State of the Union Message about teachers' forming their own schools, he was talking about people like Sarah Kass, the principal of the City on a Hill charter school here.
