description: Scotland in a Bottle

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan Weighs Costly Rescue Of Lenders
description: Japan's lawmakers opened debate today on a multibillion-dollar plan to bail out mortgage lenders using public money, a proposal that has caused taxpayer outcries and has deeply divided the Parliament.

title: Lure of the Education Market Remains Strong for Business
description: Despite last week's collapse of the nation's largest experiment in private management of public schools, in Hartford, there are increasing signs, from the growth of new businesses to rising stock performance, that public education is becoming an enticing market for private businesses.

title: Officials Cut Water Flow From Muddy Reservoirs
description: Saying recent flash floods have muddied several upstate reservoirs, New York City water officials yesterday temporarily closed an aqueduct from the Catskills that supplies 40 percent of the city's water and all of the water for about 95,000 Westchester County residents.

title: San Yu, 74, Former Leader Of Myanmar
description: U San Yu, who was President of Myanmar -- formerly Burma -- from 1981 to 1988, died on Sunday in a military hospital in Yangon. He was 78 and lived near the city.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Grilled Tuna With a Vibrant Salsa
description: For this simple grilled dish of tuna marinated in lime, be sure to use a thick slice of fish so that it can be sufficiently cooked but still retain a moist, pink interior.

title: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;UConn Women Overcome a Cold Start
description: For 13 minutes tonight, the women's basketball team from the University of Connecticut needed to warm up just to be able to say it came into Villanova ice cold.

title: Lemon Grass Isn't Just for Chefs Anymore
description: CHEFS across the country, smitten with the cool pungency and citric aroma of lemon grass, are using this Asian plant in everything from soup to sorbet.

title: Music In Review;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: A Potpourri On Period Instruments Palladian Ensemble Miller Theater

title: POLITICS;Democrat Wins Race in Oregon For Packwood's Seat in Senate
description: Representative Ron Wyden survived attacks labeling him a tax-and-spend liberal to narrowly win a special Senate election today to replace Bob Packwood. It was the nation's first Congressional election conducted by mail.

title: Public Firefighting Goes Private
description: Several times in recent days, Salvatore Cresenzi, the Mayor of this prosperous, normally placid suburb 15 miles north of New York City, has walked out of his three-bedroom home to find his red and tan Chevy van marred with an ominous missive.

title: 1 Million Gift By Ozzie Smith
description: St. Louis Cardinals shortstop Ozzie Smith has pledged $1 million to help construct an athletic complex that includes a baseball stadium in his name at Cal Poly-San Luis Obispo.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actor STACY KEACH predicted that the show he was starring in on Monday evening with a troupe of big- name political figures and journalists would be a success. "People enjoy the Washington group getting up and making fools of themselves," he said. "It's more interesting if it's not too polished."

title: Jerusalem Journal;Handing Down the Word, but Not Carved in Stone
description: As of this week, an Israeli who wants a toaster-oven need no longer do a pantomime before a dumbfounded store clerk or reach for a foreign tongue. Now he or she can walk into a store with head held high and demand a tanuron.

title: Shugrue's Plan for Pan Am: Low Costs and Lower Fares
description: Pan American World Airways -- which Martin R. Shugrue, a former Pan Am and Eastern Airlines executive, plans to revive this summer -- expects to have among the lowest operating costs of any scheduled jet airline, according to a business plan Mr. Shugrue outlined yesterday.

title: Police Say Drunken Nanny Assaulted Two
description: She came with good references, but a nanny spent her first day on a new job drinking wine, neglecting the two children she was hired to care for and attacking both her employer and a police officer, Suffolk County authorities said today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PANENERGY TO ACQUIRE NATURAL GAS ASSETS FROM MOBIL
description: The Panenergy Corporation said yesterday that it would purchase the Mobil Corporation's interest in some natural gas gathering, processing and pipeline assets in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Utah. The transaction, valued at about $300 million, involves the sale of about 2,600 miles of pipeline and Mobil's interest in 24 natural gas plants. Mobil, based in Fairfax, Va., and Panenergy also said they intended to combine their natural gas marketing operations in a new joint venture. Panenergy, based in Houston, will own 60 percent of the new entity, while Mobil will own 40 percent. The Mobil assets to be acquired by Panenergy will not be included in the joint venture.

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Policeman in Haiti Killed by Hostile Gunfire
description: A United Nations police officer from Benin became the first member of the United Nations peacekeeping mission in Haiti to be killed by hostile fire, the United Nations said today.

title: As the Shopping Cart Turns
description: SUPERMARKETS have heard the vox populi "No time to cook! No time to cook!" -- and they are reinventing themselves. The newest stores are determined to snare customers with a trio of irresistible forces: convenience, service and, above all, "meal solutions."

title: POLITICS;Buchanan and Forbes Beat Dole in an Alaska Poll
description: Bob Dole finished a distant third behind two rivals, Patrick J. Buchanan and Steve Forbes, in an unofficial Republican Presidential straw poll in Alaska, results of the three-day balloting showed today.

title: First a Faulty Steam Pipe, Then an Old Water Main, Then Tempers
description: Two unrelated failures of the city's creaky infrastructure -- a steam pipe that spewed a rust-colored plume of asbestos-laden debris and a water-main break that unleashed a basement-flooding torrent -- disrupted much of the East Side yesterday, throwing off the workaday rhythms of thousands of people and forcing confused pedestrians and angry motorists to take long detours well past the rush hour.

title: Data Speed Is the Dominant Issue at a PC Fair
description: If there is any doubt that the Internet has fundamentally transformed the personal computer industry, it can be dispelled quickly by looking at the new products in a high-technology beauty pageant here. And cable modems seem to be drawing attentive glances.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;LILLY (ELI) & CO. (LLY,N)
description: Eli Lilly Company posted an 18 percent rise in fourth-quarter profits yesterday, saying increased sales abroad helped offset pressure on drug prices in the United States.

title: Vanguard Group Trims Fees for Advisers
description: Vanguard Group, the nation's No. 2 mutual fund company, is cutting the fees it pays investment advisers for 17 of its biggest funds, including its flagship Windsor Fund.

title: Pataki Scraps Plan To Test Car Fumes
description: Gov. George E. Pataki scrapped a plan today that would have forced residents of the New York City area to have car emissions checked annually at a few central testing sites.

title: Budgets Are Piling Up, but Not Solutions
description: Here is how convoluted the budget talks have become: The Clinton Administration said today that it was preparing its 1997 budget for delivery to Congress on Monday, even while it mades a last, desperate effort with moderates in Congress to save the 1996 budget, which was supposed to go into effect four months ago.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Germany and France Move To Pep Up Their Economies
description: Rushing to stimulate growth and hoping that a joint effort will embolden worried consumers in Europe's two biggest economies, Germany and France announced measures today aimed at encouraging spending, increasing growth, cutting taxes on business and reducing unemployment.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Cruise Missile Is Test-Fired From a Ship By Iran's Navy
description: Iran has increased its military power in the Persian Gulf in the last year, most recently by testing a new Chinese cruise missile fired from a ship, senior Pentagon officials said today.

title: Joseph De Rugeriis Opera Conductor, 48
description: Joseph De Rugeriis, an opera conductor and administrator, died on Jan. 23 at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 48 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Data Gloomy On Consumers And Retailers
description: The economy entered the new year on a dismal note as the holiday shopping season was even worse for retailers than most Wall Street economists had expected and consumers' confidence in the economy sank to the lowest level in nearly two years, according to statistics released yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times;The Poster That Came To Life
description: BEGIN with the thought that many of these college-age kids with the millionaire contracts and the droopy shorts think nothing happened in professional basketball before 1980. That nothing that predates Magic and Bird, and later on Michael.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Murdoch Joins a Cable-TV Rush Into the Crowded All-News Field
description: Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation and Fox Inc., yesterday became the latest entrant in the business of providing 24-hour news channels, promising a new competitor to the Cable News Network by the end of the year.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Expectations Of a Rate Cut Raise Bonds
description: Expectations of an imminent rate cut by the Federal Reserve brought a steady stream of buyers to the bond market yesterday, causing prices to climb.

title: Harold Goldberg, 68; Led Moody's Rating Unit
description: Harold H. Goldberg, who for 14 years was the forceful chairman of the committees at Moody's Investors Service that rate the quality of corporate debt, died Monday night at Norwalk Hospital in Connecticut. He was 68.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADVANCED POLYMER TO BUYS DOW'S POLYTRAP TECHNOLOGY
description: Advanced Polymer Systems Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire the full rights to the Dow Corning Corporation's Polytrap technology, which is used in personal care products like deodorants and razor blades. The company also bought the rights to sell all products using Polymeric Transport Systems, a technology based on Polytrap and Advanced Polymer's Microsponge systems. Advanced Polymer, a personal care products company based in Redwood City, Calif., paid an undisclosed amount of common stock to acquire the rights. Polymeric Transport Systems are used to release ingredients in response to stimulants, including rubbing and changes in temperature. The companies had previously shared the rights to market the systems, which are used in deodorants, lipsticks and other cosmetics. Shares of Advanced Polymer rose 37.5 cents, to $6.875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Guilty Plea on School Bribery
description: Christine Day pleaded guilty in State Superior Court yesterday to bribing Newark school and city officials in exchange for almost $500,000 in payments for goods and services that were never delivered. Her husband, Roger C. Day Jr., is in jail in Rome fighting extradition to the United States to face the same charges.

description: In percent

title: COMPANY REPORTS;G.M. Reports Surging Profits, Partly Because Of Tax Gains
description: The General Motors Corporation's core business suffered several reversals late last year, but nimble work by the company's tax accountants sent its net income soaring in the fourth quarter.

title: Real Estate;A California city is attracting short-term leases to a naval shipyard while it works on a long-term plan.
description: IN what its backers view as a test of a new approach to the conversion of a military base to civilian uses, a real estate firm has begun a plan for short-term subleases by industrial and office users at the Mare Island Naval Shipyard.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No one can say MADONNA doesn't throw herself into a role.

title: HOCKEY;Devils Win, 3-2, in Overtime
description: Steve Thomas deflected in a pass from Bobby Holik at 3 minutes 46 seconds of overtime to give the Devils a 3-2 victory over the Vancouver Canucks tonight.

title: POLITICS: THE LEADMedia Watch; Dole Tilts With Foes, Suggested And Real
description: It is three weeks before the first votes are cast in the Republican Presidential primaries, but Senator Bob Dole is already being portrayed as under siege, losing ground daily to Steve Forbes in a tightening contest that has all the hallmarks of Mr. Dole's political collapse in 1988.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Nominated to Lead Advertising Group
description: Two agency executives have been nominated to serve as the 1996-97 leaders of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, known as the Four A's.

title: Jet Aviator Killed in Nashville Had Earlier Crash, Navy Says
description: The flier whose Navy F-14A fighter plunged into a Nashville suburb on Monday, killing himself and four other people, crashed another jet into the sea last April. But Navy investigators and senior admirals forgave him, saying he made a mistake in pursuit of the combative flying that the Navy wants and encourages in its pilots.

title: Arguments Begin on Shifting Site of Oklahoma Bomb Trial
description: While families of some of the 168 victims of the Federal Building bombing sat red-eyed or weeping quietly in the courtroom today, prosecutors and defense lawyers began arguments on a request by the two defendants, Timothy J. McVeigh and Terry L. Nichols, to move the trial out of the state.

description: Unexpected Narrator For a Corigliano Work Manhattan Chamber Sinfonia Manhattan School of Music

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Placido Domingo The Moor, Via PBS
description: With the destruction by fire this week of La Fenice, Venice's opera house and one of Europe's most exquisite theaters, the issue of cultural preservation once again becomes pressing. Happily, one consolation is immediately at hand. "The Metropolitan Opera Presents" has been taping productions at its Lincoln Center home for 20 years, compiling an invaluable library of world-renowned performances and performers. The re'ord is extended splendidly tonight with Verdi's towering masterwork "Otello," featuring a career-crowning performance by Placido Domingo in the title role.

title: At the Nation's Table;Two Barns Made For Romantic Dining
description: It is no coincidence that Valentine's Day reservations keep rolling in at the White Barn Inn Restaurant, one of only two American Automobile Association Tour Book five-diamond restaurants in New England. It is known for its pampering and choreographed service as well as its contemporary New England cuisine that focuses on home-grown seasonal herbs and vegetables, and seafood caught locally.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Strawberry Enters Plea in Support Case
description: DARRYL STRAWBERRY pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges that he ignored a court's order to make support payments for his two children. Strawberry, a free agent since the Yankees released him in November, is charged with one count of willful failure to provide child support and two counts of failure to obey a court order. His former wife, LISA, contends that he owes more than $370,000 in back payments. They were divorced in 1993. (AP)

title: World News Briefs;Peru Tribunal Denies U.S. Woman's Appeal
description: A Peruvian military tribunal today rejected the appeal by an American woman of her conviction and life sentence for helping to lead a Marxist guerrilla group, her local lawyer said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TRACK AND FIELD;Bailey Accuses Christie of Faking Injury
description: The Canadian sprinter DONOVAN BAILEY yesterday accused his British rival LINFORD CHRISTIE of faking injury in the 100-meter final at last summer's world championships.

title: Yemeni Soldier Slain In Clash With Tribe
description: One member of Yemen's security forces was killed and four were wounded in a clash today with rural tribesmen who kidnapped and later released a group of French tourists, a Yemeni security official said.

title: POP REVIEW;A Huge Sound Leavened With Humor
description: Roy Hargrove's big band, which he convenes only on occasion, is normally a party group, wild and loud and intent on having fun. On Monday night at the Village Vanguard, where the band played for a full house, its usual sense of humor was on vibrant display.

title: A Four-Year Tribute To American Music
description: The New York Philharmonic is to begin a four-year survey of American music during its 1996-97 season, which opens on Sept. 18 and runs through May 31, 1997. The opening- night concert, with Kurt Masur conducting and Anne-Sophie Mutter as the soloist in the Brahms Violin Concerto, is to be broadcast by PBS in its "Live From Lincoln Center" series, the orchestra said yesterday.

title: Twist in a Killing
description: A white man who had told the police that a black man killed his fiancee has been arrested and charged with offering an acquaintance $20,000 to kill the woman. The suspect, Robert Harris, 23, and an acquaintance, Russell Brill, 22, of Baltimore, face first-degree murder and felony handgun charges in the death of Theresa McLeod, said a police spokesman, Rob Weinhold., The men were arrested on Monday.

title: Prison for Young Killers Renews Debate on Saving Society's Lost
description: The little one is 12 years old, stands less than 5 feet tall and will be the youngest child locked up in a maximum-security juvenile prison in the country.

title: Replacements Lift Building Owners in Strike
description: They work largely in the shadows as they clean bathrooms and wax floors at night, but at least 15,000 temporary replacements are being used during the building workers' strike in New York City, according to real estate executives -- the biggest use of such workers in recent city history.

title: POLITICS: THE ENDORSEMENTS;Hopefuls Go a-Courtin' And Kemp Is the Prize
description: Colin who? Suddenly, the most sought after figure in Republican Presidential politics -- at least for this week -- is Jack F. Kemp.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bouygues of France Posts First Annual Loss
description: Bouygues S.A., France's largest construction company, sustained its first full-year loss ever in 1995, after setting aside provisions to cover lower values of property assets and start-up costs for a new mobile telephone network. The company said yesterday that preliminary estimates for 1995 showed it had lost about 4 billion francs ($800 million) last year after setting aside 4.4 billion francs in one-time charges. In 1994 it earned 573 million francs.

title: World News Briefs;Honored Mexican Agent Arrested With Drugs
description: An agent who was voted "Policeman of the Year" in a northern Mexican state has been arrested on suspicion of drug trafficking after being detained with 436 pounds of marijuana, the Televisa television network reported today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Homeowner Gets 2 Cents In
description: Jack Cacciato put in his 2 cents' worth yesterday, finally paying his fourth-quarter property taxes in full at Hackensack City Hall after receiving a second delinquency notice for the pennies still due. Mr. Cacciato said he thought the demand for the extra 2 cents was a mistake until the stern second notice arrived. "The gentleman came in and paid his 2 cents this morning," said Hackensack's tax collector, Peggy Moncrief.

description: The splashy female lead opposite Tom Cruise in his big new movie, "Jerry Maguire," is a role craved by practically every Hollywood actress under the age of 35.

title: Jerry Siegel, Superman's Creator, Dies at 81
description: Jerry Siegel, whose teen-age yearning for girls gave the world Superman, died in Los Angeles on Sunday. He was 81 but was remembered less as the Cleveland visionary who dreamed up the greatest superhero of all time than as the naive young man who sold the rights to a billion-dollar cultural and commercial juggernaut for $130.

title: Israel Eases Rules on Foreign Stock Issues
description: The Bank of Israel said today that it would lift restrictions on stock offerings by foreign companies on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Barrick's New Policy Could Increase Price of Gold
description: The world's most profitable gold-mining company, the Barrick Gold Corporation, signaled changes today in its hedging policies that could mean higher prices for gold.

description: THE Mediterranean diet is starting to show up in South Africa. And with it comes olive oil.

title: Wine Talk
description: GRAPE shortages, a weak dollar, the price of barrels, poor weather, good weather, signs in the heavens, rumors of war, you name it -- there are always plenty of reasons for the price of wine to go up.

description: LIEUT. GIOVANNI BELLO sidled up to the woman in black, ignoring the matinee crowd descending upon Carmine's restaurant near Times Square.

description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANHEUSER-BUSCH FORMS FRENCH AND SWISS PARTNERSHIPS
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that it had formed partnerships with France's largest brewer and a leading Swiss brewer. In France, the partnership is with Brasseries Kronenbourg, Europe's second-largest brewer. The other partnership is with Gastrodrink, a company jointly owned by Kronenbourg and Feldschlosschen Holding A.G. of Switzerland. Anheuser-Busch, based in St. Louis, said the deals would provide increased support for sales in France and Switzerland, whose beer markets are experiencing strong growth.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 90.30 points, or more than four-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,812.74. On Tuesday, the Nikkei rose 133.24 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent.

title: OLYMPICS;Murdoch Loses Bid on Europe's TV Rights
description: The International Olympic Committee sold the European television rights to each Olympics from 2000 to 2008 for $1.442 billion to the European Broadcasting Union yesterday, bypassing a $1.8 billion bid from Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation.

title: The Power of Prayer, Denied
description: When Thomas Jefferson described religious freedom as "the most inalienable and sacred of all human rights," he could not have imagined that the time would come when American citizens would be forced to pay ruinous damages for exercising it.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Plan for Hospital Care
description: The Black Ministers Council of New Jersey yesterday called for a 2 to 3 percent tax on health insurance premiums to reimburse New Jersey hospitals for providing charity care to uninsured people, mainly the working poor, The Associated Press reported. Last year, the state paid $400 million for hospital charity care, but so far this year the funds have not been renewed. JOE SHARKEY

description: A STRUGGLE FOR POWER The American Revolution By Theodore Draper 544 pages. Times Books. $35.

description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Vehicle Exports Drop in Japan
description: Exports of vehicles made in Japan, a cornerstone of the country's economy, fell last year to their lowest level in almost two decades, mainly because of a strong yen and increased overseas output by Japanese makers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 20 about the announcement of an empowerment zone to promote development in upper Manhattan and the South Bronx referred incorrectly to some audience members who held placards about Gov. George E. Pataki. They were supporters of the Governor, who attended the announcement, not critics.

title: Denying Sex Harassment, Haytaian Sues His Accuser
description: Chuck Haytaian, chairman of the New Jersey Republican Party and the departing Assembly Speaker, filed a defamation suit today against the senior legislative assistant who has accused him of sexual harassment.

title: At the Nation's Table;From Mexico, With Tortillas
description: After moving from Guadalajara, Mexico, to Boston 10 years ago to live with her sister, Heidi Maria Hartung could not find the bread that she ate while growing up -- tortillas made from a high-starch, nonsweet variety of white corn.

title: Personal Health
description: NEXT week, 2.5 million students at more than 600 colleges and universities will be invited to participate in the first nationwide screening program for some of the most common serious illnesses among teen-agers and young adults: eating disorders. Those who participate in the free, anonymous screening will hear an educational presentation, fill out a questionnaire and meet individually with a health professional.

title: In Connecticut, Comptroller Predicts a Large Budget Gap
description: State Comptroller Nancy Wyman today projected a deficit of as much as $600 million in the state budget in the next fiscal year, raising questions about how the state will be able to enact a $200 million tax cut scheduled to take effect in time for 1997 tax returns.

title: A Stunned Venice Surveys the Ruins Of a Beloved Hall
description: Italy mourned one of its most beloved monuments today after a dramatic fire on Monday night destroyed Venice's opera house, La Fenice, leaving behind a blackened shell and the smoldering ruins of its gilded, elegant interior.

title: A France Less Aloof
description: Jacques Chirac, the first Gaullist President of France since 1974, has used the initial months of his tenure to undo the Gaullist legacy of deliberate estrangement from NATO and the United States. That has created a positive atmosphere for his state visit to the United States, which begins today.

title: California Keeps College Tuitions Level
description: To the Editor:

title: As Cultures Meet in South Africa, So Do the Cuisines
description: SOUTH AFRICAN cooking is in its infancy," said Lannice Snyman, a cookbook author and restaurant critic in Cape Town. "It's only 300 years old." That makes it about the same age as American cooking, and if weren't for apartheid, the cuisine of South Africa would probably have undergone the kinds earth-shaking changes that have taken place in this country since the 1970's.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Eyeing Ward for Relief Role
description: Every time the Yankees indicate they are finished accumulating pitchers for their 1996 pennant run, they go out and sign someone else. This week the object of their added efforts is Duane Ward, once a star closer for the Toronto Blue Jays who has endured two years of injuries.

title: TRACK AND FIELD;Slow but Steady Trip To the Millrose 3,000
description: For Brad Schlapak, it is like a bad dream.

title: Foreign Affairs;African Madness
description: The Angolan village of Bailundo, which sits atop Angola's central plateau, feels like the Hollywood version of a rebel stronghold. Every home is pockmarked with bullet holes, stores have no roofs, benches have no seats, streets have no cars. A tattered banner reading "Long Live Dr. Savimbi" hangs in the square, and guerrillas with bullet-belts draped across their chests languidly stroll the sidewalks. The main hotel in town is missing its roof and most of its walls, but the balcony survives, where they serve cold South African beer and roasted nuts. Bailundo is a living ghost town.

title: Studies Using Brain Imaging Hint at Alzheimer Precursors
description: NEW discoveries about the earliest signs of Alzheimer's disease in the brain may one day offer a way to make the diagnosis well before the disease has produced senility, allowing people to make plans for their futures while they are still lucid.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Gala Tribute by and for Members of the Ailey Company
description: Is Michael Jackson performing tonight?" a man asked teasingly as he wedged himself into the jammed lobby of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center on Saturday night. The gloved one was nowhere in sight. But he was the only missing element in "Ailey on Ailey," an evening of enjoyable new dance, superb performing, good food and good-heartedness. Put together by Michael Joy, Nasha Thomas, Michael Thomas and other members of the senior and junior Ailey companies, the gala benefit raised money for the new Ailey Dancers Resource Fund, created to help dancers facing retirement and sudden emergencies.

title: Russia Reform To Continue, Clinton Says After Meeting
description: President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, after meetings today with Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin of Russia, expressed their confidence in Russia's continuing commitment to market reform despite Moscow's dismissal of well-known reformers and new plans for large social expenditures.

title: U.N. Panel Says Zaire Blocks Rwandan Arms Inquiry
description: The Government of Zaire is obstructing the work of an international commission investigating the illegal arming and training of Rwandan exiles attacking Rwanda across the border between the two countries, a report to the Security Council said today.

title: FILM REVIEW;Repression, A Painter And Desire
description: The early 20th-century Austrian painter portrayed in Herbert Vesely's film "Egon Schiele: Epcess and Punishment" has just the sort of credentials that, crudely exploited, could inspire a fervent cult. Handsome, talented and prosecuted for his anatomically explicit female nudes, Schiele died of influenza at the age of 28. How many legends have been spun from the images of golden artistic rebels who died before reaching their prime?

title: COMPANY NEWS;ST. JUDE MEDICAL TO ACQUIRE HEART-DEVICE MAKER
description: St. Jude Medical Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Daig Corporation, a maker of specialized cardiovascular devices, in a stock transaction valued at about $442.5 million. St. Jude, a maker of heart valves and other devices based in St. Paul, will exchange 10 million shares for all of Daig's stock. Daig, based in Minnetonka, Minn., is a manufacturer of products to diagnose and treat cardiovascular illnesses, including coronary heart disease. Daig had sales of $38.3 million in the year that ended Sept. 30. In Nasdaq trading, shares of Daig gained $2.75, to $26.75, and shares of St. Jude fell $1.50, to $42.75.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Full Senate Sessions on Cable
description: Gavel-to-gavel television coverage of State Senate sessions will be available in more than two million homes starting Monday under a one-year pilot project announced yesterday between the Senate and the Cable Television Network. Modeled on C-SPAN's coverage of Congress, the programming will be live, without commentary, with cameras fixed on the Senate president, the person speaking before the chamber or the voting board.

title: Why Raising Minimum Wage Will Hurt, Not Help, the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Peru Selects Group for Sale
description: The Government of Peru today selected a group headed by Merrill Lynch & Company and J. P. Morgan & Company to manage the sale of its remaining $1.4 billion stake in the country's telephone company.

title: Of Home and Homer
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMOCO TO CONSIDER SALE OF FOAM BUSINESS
description: The Amoco Corporation said yesterday that it might sell its Amoco Foam Products unit, which had sales last year of $288 million. Amoco, the oil and chemicals giant based in Chicago, said it was reviewing strategic alternatives for the division. "We feel that Amoco Foam may well be a better strategic fit for another company," said Enrique Sosa, executive vice president of Amoco's chemical division. He added that the unit was "strongly profitable." Amoco Foam, based in Atlanta, manufactures polystyrene foam products at nine plants in the United States. The products include cups and plates, packaging trays for meat and poultry and industrial products.

title: News AnalysisGiuliani's Softer Tone;After Years of Social Service Cuts, Mayor Changes Targets
description: Having made dramatic cuts in New York City's budget for the last two years, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he now plans to slow down those reductions, arguing that further cuts in some social service agencies could hurt "the morale of the city."

title: China Hints at a Timetable To Take Control of Taiwan
description: China took the first step today toward setting a timetable for the unification of Taiwan with the Chinese mainland, saying that after the return of Hong Kong and Macao to Chinese rule in 1997 and 1999 respectively, unification with Taiwan will become a top priority.

title: Suit Charges Bias in Tests For Custodians
description: The United States Justice Department filed suit yesterday against New York City and its Board of Education, charging that tests given to prospective school custodians and their supervisors were heavily weighted against members of minority groups.

title: Besieged Colombian President Hints He Might Step Down
description: President Ernesto Samper, who is embroiled in accusations that his 1994 election campaign solicited some $6.1 million from drug traffickers, today maintained that he was innocent but opened the possibility he will step down if Congress decides he should.

title: New Test Predicts Progress of AIDS Virus, Scientists Say
description: A new test that measures the amount of the AIDS virus in blood predicts the progression of infection to disease sooner and more accurately than the standard test, researchers from the University of Pittsburgh said today at a scientific meeting here.

title: CHRONICLE
description: President JACQUES CHIRAC of France, scheduled to arrive in Washington today for a two-day visit, plans to pay tribute tomorrow morning to three American diplomats killed when the armored personnel carrier they were in plunged over a ravine in Bosnia in August.

title: Making Nursing Homes Safer
description: The rape of a comatose young woman in a nursing home near Rochester, N.Y., is a dramatic reminder of the abuses that often plague these facilities. The only redeeming feature in this story is that it should give a forceful shove to the proposal by Dennis Vacco, New York State's Attorney General, for meticulous background checks of nursing home employees.

title: Journal;'Dolly' Goes Away
description: Until her closing performance in New York last Sunday, I hadn't seen Carol Channing in "Hello, Dolly!" since I was 14 and the show was in Washington, trying out on its way to Broadway. On that night, the audience roared at a newly added Act I finale in which Dolly, a widow, sang of how she must stop mourning and reclaim her life "before the parade passes by." Only weeks earlier President Kennedy's funeral cortege had passed by the theater on its way down Pennsylvania Avenue. Miss Channing was our own irrational incitement to throw off grief and start living again.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: PHIBRO REFINING INC., Houston, a division of Salomon Brothers, has reduced production at two refineries on the Gulf Coast because of poor profit margins.

title: Fixed $30 Taxi Fare Is a Hit With Tourists
description: Bronwyn and Michael Shirley, of Sydney, Australia, would not know the Triborough Bridge from the Verrazano-Narrows, so more than once, on arriving in New York City, they were taken for a ride when they were taken for a ride. No more.

title: Emanuel Gordon, Nuclear Engineer, 76
description: Emanuel Gordon, a nuclear engineer who worked on the Manhattan Project and held many patents on nuclear fuel, died on Monday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. Mr. Gordon, who lived in Rockville, Md., was 76.

description: Half a century ago, residents clinging to this played-out silver-mining town grumbled when Park City was listed in the guidebook "Ghost Towns of the West."

description: Parents who are afraid to have their babies vaccinated against whooping cough because of the shots' side effects may soon get their first alternative protection from the respiratory ailment.

description: Later this year, New York area hockey fans could see Brian Leetch playing against Aleksei Kovalev in Madison Square Garden. And neither would be wearing a Rangers sweater.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Ex-Official Charged on Taxes
description: Michael J. Bent, 51, an accountant and real estate broker who was formerly a Stafford Township councilman, was indicted yesterday on charges of evading $690,000 in Federal taxes after diverting for his personal use shareholder investments in a fitness center he owned from 1987 to 1991, prosecutors said.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;RJR Nabisco Registers Improved Results
description: Stabilizing the market share of its full-price domestic cigarette business, but struggling to overcome unexpected disappointments in its food business, the RJR Nabisco Holdings Company reported improved fourth-quarter results yesterday that matched analysts' estimates.

description: Donald J. Trump is taking a new tack in his continuing battle with Harry Helmsley and others over control of the Empire State Building.

title: World News Briefs;Explosions Kill Dozens In Sri Lankan Capital
description: Blasts believed caused by car bombs thundered through downtown Colombo today, damaging high-rise buildings and creating panic in the city's business center. Witnesses said dozens of people were dead in the street, and hundreds injured.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Toll Takers Back Contract
description: Most of the 1,500 toll takers and maintenance and clerical workers for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority voted to accept a four-year contract that freezes wages for two years and drops a no-layoff provision, the authority said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Philip Morris Takes A Big Polish Stake
description: Philip Morris has signed a $372 million deal with Poland to take a majority stake in the country's biggest cigarette producer, Zaklady Przemyslu Tytoniowego Krakow. Philip Morris said yesterday that it would pay $227 million for a 33 percent stake in the state-owned plant and for the right to acquire a further 32 percent once it fulfilled its pledge to invest $145 million over the next three years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;Stung by plunging tourism, Rio de Janeiro hopes Della Femina will put it back on the travel map.
description: TO revive its flagging tourist industry, Rio de Janeiro is getting ready to package itself as a sophisticated destination for international travelers, particularly Americans. Fittingly, the package bears some sophisticated markings of its own.

title: Schools Turn to Surveillance Camera as Tool of Order
description: Steve Anstead, a junior at Dana Hills High School, has little remorse for his role in a tennis ball-throwing melee last year in the school cafeteria. His only regret is that it was videotaped by a school employee. After administrators reviewed the tape, there was little doubt about which students to punish.

title: Dow Up 76.23 on Hopes Fed Will Ease Rates
description: Stocks were propelled higher yesterday, continuing their record-setting pace amid heightened optimism that Federal Reserve policy makers would cut interest rates today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DELTA AIR LINES TO ADD 665 CUSTOMER-SERVICE JOBS
description: In a switch for a company that has cut 11,000 jobs in the last two years, Delta Air Lines Inc. said yesterday that it would add 665 customer-service jobs by the summer. The airline said 485 of the new full-time jobs would be at the company's headquarters in Atlanta. Most of the jobs will be filled by employees who have been relegated to part-time status. Delta, the nation's third-largest carrier, also said it would purchase an unspecified amount of ground-handling equipment and add managers to oversee its baggage-handling operations.

title: A Futile Rush In Desperation For Green Card
description: Mohammed Uddin was sound asleep in his Queens apartment when he got the call. The Government was giving out green cards at the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service offices in Manhattan, his friend told him.

description: IF Lord Hanson had decided to retire a few years earlier, he would be leaving with a much better record on Wall Street.

description: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES is setting its sights on some pretty important targets: elite-level participants in its competitors' frequent-flier plans.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Murdoch Joins the Fray, With 24-Hour News Channel Rupert Murdoch, left, the head of News Corporation and the Fox network, entered the business of providing a 24-hour news channel, promising a new competitor to the Cable News Network.

title: 20 Years After Thievery, Rare Gold Ornaments Will Return to Greece
description: A collection of rare ancient Mycenaean gold jewelry and ornaments that had passed through the hands of grave robbers and art dealers in at least two countries made its last foreign stop here today before being shipped back to its native Greece.
